Rapper Boldy James was born in Atlanta
column2: hails from Detroit
column3: and sounds like he's never stepped outside of Queensbridge. The producer Alchemist is from Beverly Hills
column4: but has produced some of gangsta rap's bleakest East Coast rap
column5: for Mobb Deep and others. The two of them together makes perfect sense: For them
column6: Queensbridge is a state of mind
column7: a place to visit within the world of records. On My 1st Chemistry Set
column8: they key into that thick atmosphere like a couple of virtuosos.

column1: The obvious out of the way first: Boldy's voice is a dead ringer for Mobb Deep's Prodigy. The resemblance is so strong it raises hackles the first time he opens his mouth. But like Action Bronson
column2: who has ambled past his constant Ghostface comparisons to his own persona
column3: Boldy sneaks a unique sensibility under the cover of a very familiar sound. He's a dead-eyed tough guy
column4: a position that starts at ""unamused"" and goes darker from there
column5: but beneath the pose
column6: his words leap eagerly around
column7: betraying his dirty secret: enthusiasm. ""I used to write raps off of my spelling words
column8: so I could learn the meaning of them and how to spell them
column9: he told David Drake back in 2012. ""Because if you use a word in a sentence
column10: and don’t know the meaning
column11: you can use the words around it to get the definition of the word you were looking for."" Respectfully
column12: this isn't the most intimidating sentiment in the world
column13: and it positions Boldy closer to someone like Black Hippy's resident word-nerd Ab-Soul.

column1: On ""Moochie
column2: he gives a slang lesson that isn't a lesson at all
column3: but a chance to render you glassy-eyed: ""My dank Mary Jane and my big chain Julie/A deuce is a split
column4: a baby is a stoolie/A kilo is a brick
column5: a quarter is a cutie/If you tellin you a snitch/county is the skidooski."" Got that? On ""Rappies
column6: he mutters ""Slow rolling them snow bunnies in Clinton Township/Them bastards trying to give me about sixty/For transacting them Graham crackers of that brown shit"" and the syntax—transacting them Graham crackers of that brown shit—blooms and lingers.  Oh
column7: and he's got a deadpan sense of humor: ""Life is Precious/a fat ugly bitch that'll get you whacked
column8: he cracks on ""What's the Word"". On ""Traction
column9: he slyly quotes Redman's ""Time 4 Sum Aksion""
column10: and while Boldy isn't exactly a straitjacket-straining wildcard like Red
column11: their rhyme pads could definitely be friends.

column1: Alchemist
column2: for his part
column3: brings his most muted and sensually gloomy side to the project. Boldy has a lot to say
column4: and Alc
column5: though the bigger name of the pair by far
column6: settles back
column7: each beat just present enough to give the exact right cotton-mouth coating to Boldy's verses. ""You Know"" loops a busy bass line and almost nothing else—some wisps of strings
column8: a clipped vocal like a red sock in the dryer. ""Moochie"" is just a shiver of violin tremolos
column9: scratches
column10: and some highly unsettling music-box chimes. The drums don't knock
column11: and in fact barely rise above a cough.

column1: There are guests that breeze through. Freeway continues his murderously intense lap of the mixtape circuit's lower rung; when he raps
column2: it's impossible not to want him to be back on top
column3: at least for that moment. Action Bronson trades bars with Boldy on ""Traction."" Earl Sweatshirt delivers a thicket of quotables—you need to hear what he does with the rich rhyming possibilities of ""Tan Cressida""
column4: which he lays out and then attacks like a juicy steak. But none of them eclipse Boldy
column5: who makes the most of this opportunity and delivers some of the best verses of his career. He has been steadily deepening
column6: as a writer and rapper
column7: and by now
column8: the lousy emotional weather of QB rap is his own
column9:
a personal storm cloud he generates wherever he goes.

James Jackson Toth has a tattoo on his wrist that reads “WWNYD.” The “NY” stands for Neil Young
column2: whom Toth has personally elevated to “the status of Jesus Christ
column3: ” as he said in a recent assessment of Young’s discography. In that same piece
column4: Toth asserted that Young “made a career of being consistently inconsistent.” That sounds familiar: Grayson Currin noted that “longtime fans of Wooden Wand forsook consistency long ago” when reviewing Toth’s last record under the name Wooden Wand
column5: Blood Oaths of the New Blues
column6: and in Brent Sirota’s press notes for Wooden Wand & the World War IV
column7: he says Toth’s work is so varied that “you might have lost track of Wooden Wand some years back.” It seems Toth has adopted Young’s mercurial approach to writing songs
column8: assembling bands
column9: and releasing records.

column1: So it’s ironic that the most Neil Young-sounding album in the Wooden Wand discography comes during one of the most consistent stretches of Toth’s career. He’s worked with the same group for three straight albums—finally giving them a name
column2: The World War IV
column3: on this one—and all three are solid additions to his oeuvre. Actually
column4: Blood Oaths is much more than just solid
column5: one of the best albums of Toth’s career in any guise. Wooden Wand & the World War IV isn’t on that level
column6: but it’s quite good
column7: partially because it picks one tack and sticks with it. In other words
column8: it’s consistent.

column1: That consistency is as about tone as it is about sound. Every track here is comfortably low-key
column2: exuding a calm aura that doesn’t scream for attention–in fact
column3: Toth rarely raises his voice. But he and comrades Dave Hickox and Jody Nelson do raise their guitars at times
column4: locking into ascending solos that expand each track
column5: adding to the casual
column6: unfettered atmosphere. That’s when Neil Young and Crazy Horse echo loudest
column7: in the way that their music often feels as much like loose jams as written songs.

column1: Loose isn’t the best way to describe Wooden Wand & the World War IV
column2: though. Its songs are modest and contained
column3: never feeling like they last too long. But often it seems we’re getting small glimpses of bigger journeys. In fact
column4: Toth wrote only one song fully (the slow
column5: country-ish “Our Father the Monster”) before the album was recorded. The rest grew from riffs written by the World War IV to which Toth added melodies and lyrics. The result feels a bit like what might happen if Young and Crazy Horse sliced up the great jam they posted on their website in early 2012 and rounded the results into individual songs.

column1: The best songs on Wooden Wand & the World War IV combine easy power with an undercurrent of tension. On “Directions to Debbie Harry’s House”
column2: tension comes from the push of Janet Elizabeth Simpson’s bass
column3: as well as the way her accompanying vocals accent Toth’s lead. The urgency of “I Hate the Nightlife” arrives in Toth’s searing mid-song solo
column4: an instant rival to Young’s more fiery forays. There’s even some suspense in the breezy “Complaint Dept.""
column5: whose simple swing feels like it could blow in the wind forever. But the more I listen
column6: the more immediate it feels
column7: pushing forward with a vital pulse.

column1: If there’s a drawback to Wooden Wand & the World IV
column2: it’s that the songs take time to sink in
column3: and none are instant classics. For me
column4: that’s a strength: this record isn’t about peaks and valleys but steadiness
column5: and a such there’s not a dull moment to be found. If you’re new to Toth’s work and looking to be quickly blown away
column6: don’t start here. But keep some space open on your shelf
column7: because if you get hooked by any other Wooden Wand record
column8:
it’ll likely lead you to Wooden Wand & the World War IV.

""I don't pay attention to what's happening now
column3: M.I.A. said in an interview a few weeks before the release of her notoriously-long-delayed fourth album
column4: Matangi
column5: ""My references are beyond the [music] industry….I'm talking about the goddess Matangi
column6: who invented music 5
column7: 000 years ago."" That line is quintessential M.I.A.: artfully provocative
column8: magnificently over-it (""If you don’t give a fuck
column9: she declared in a pixelated deadpan on her last mixtape
column10: ""Then I don’t give a damn"")
column11: and difficult to square with a fact-checker. The Sri-Lankan-born
column12: London-bred artist has hyped Matangi as her ""spiritual album
column13: and
column14: sure
column15: there are plenty of references to the titular Hindu goddess and other Eastern-spiritual phenomena throughout its 15 tracks. But contrary to her claims
column16: there are also hints that she’s still paying (somewhat selective) attention to the kind of American music she so brilliantly re-appropriated on her pair of mid-aughts masterpieces
column17: Arular and Kala: There’s a Weeknd sample
column18: at least two different Drake disses
column19: and a handful of tracks produced by Hit-Boy. Let’s also not forget when she took to Twitter all of 14 months ago to clear up rumors about the already-delayed album
column20: claiming that the finished product would sound like ""Paul Simon on acid.""

column1: Contradictory? Sure—but who cares. The people who treat M.I.A.’s controversial career like a never-ending game of gotcha miss the point; from day one
column2: her contradictions have enlivened her music and saved it from heavy-handed moralizing. A decade after her first mixtape
column3: it now feels safe to call M.I.A. one of the most forward-thinking pop artists of the last decade: She aestheticized deadpan cross-cultural juxtaposition before Tumblr was even a thing
column4: she predicted the controversy surrounding the N.S.A.’s surveillance program
column5: and professed that a pop star might be more like a fashion designer than a musician back when Kanye West was still wearing a bear suit. Matangi
column6: then
column7: is a disappointing record not for any reasons having to do with its (or its maker’s) lack of a coherent moral imperative. (""Ain’t no Dalai Lama
column8: she shrugs unapologetically on the skronky intro track
column9: ""Karmageddon"".) No
column10: Matangi is a disappointing record because of how listlessly over and ""beyond"" everything it is—to the point that it often feels uncharacteristically weary and out of touch.

column1: M.I.A.’s inability to compromise is
column2: in some ways
column3: what makes her music and attitude so appealing. But in more recent years that very quality has begun to wreak havoc on her recorded output. There was
column4: of course
column5: the fuck-all aural minefield that was her last proper album
column6: /\/\/\Y/\. In light of the N.S.A. revelations
column7: some have attempted to reclaim the album (some of which focused on the then-puzzling claim that ""Google connected to the government"") as an unsung masterpiece—though most people consider it a million-and-a-half-dollar middle finger towards the new fans who hopped aboard after M.I.A.’s accidental smash hit ""Paper Planes"". Matangi is not as abrasive or hook-averse as its predecessor
column8: but it seems to have suffered because of her combative relationship with her label
column9: Interscope. Initially slated for release in December of last year
column10: M.I.A. and the label butted heads (they allegedly thought the material was “too positive”); it seems they only agreed on a release date when she threatened to leak the album on Twitter. In the meantime
column11: much of this material seems to have sat on the shelf
column12: growing staler by the month.

column1: This is most glaring on ""YALA"" (""you always live again"")
column2: an ode to reincarnation (and also: pole-dancing) that flies in the face of the youth-cult of YOLO. ""If you only live once
column3: she muses in a stoner-voiced spoken word towards the end of the song
column4: ""Why do we keep doing the same shit? Back home
column5: where I come from
column6: we keep being born again and again."" Fair enough
column7: but ""YALA"" barks harder than it actually bites. The fact that its chorus is peppered with chants of ""YOLO"" makes it feel like it’s trying to have it both ways—an anti-YOLO song that can also slyly ride the phrase’s cultural coattails. (And maybe it would have
column8: had that train not left the station at least a year ago now.) Much of Matangi’s sensibility feels similarly dated
column9: limp
column10: or just plain perplexing: There’s a decade-too-late Lara Croft line
column11: another Drake diss on the riotous title track feels too vague (""Started from the bottom/ But Drake gets all the credit"") to warrant a response
column12: and then a moment when she calls out—and here the beat drops out like she’s about to say something seriously scathing—Julianne Moore…?

column1: Matangi’s promised focus on ""spirituality""
column2: too
column3: often feels thin
column4: avoiding most attempts at depth in favor of gauche puns (""Karmageddon"") and easy rhymes like
column5: ""If you’re gonna be me you need a manifesto/ If you ain’t got one you better get one presto."" That last line is from ""Matangi""
column6: whose Switch-produced beat enlivens the proceedings a bit
column7: though it does feel like a re-tread (#YALA?) of Kala’s hyperkinetic standout ""Bird Flu"". A much lower moment
column8: though
column9: is ""Sexodus""
column10: a cardboard-stiff booty jam that repurposes the Weeknd’s ""Lonely Star"". The sample doesn’t add much to the pulseless track
column11: but Abel Tesfaye should be grateful: By comparison
column12: ""Kiss Land"" now sounds like a downright sexy thing to call a song.

column1: Ultimately
column2: some of these beats do redeem Matangi. Though marred by snoozy rapping (""I’m so tangy people call me Matangi"")
column3: ""Bring the Noize"" is a sensory-overloaded throwback to the best of Arular
column4: and ""Only 1 U"" (which Maya herself co-produced) is a playfully clanging
column5: chopped-and-screwed mosaic of bells and whistles. Towering high above the rest of the material
column6: though
column7: is the near-perfect early-2012 single ""Bad Girls""
column8: which
column9: nearly two years and infinite plays later
column10: still feels fresh as the first time you heard it. When it appears on Matangi
column11: though
column12: it just feels like a tease of what this record could have been
column13: had its vision been a little less cluttered and vague. As plenty of critics pointed out when /\/\/\Y/\ was released
column14: M.I.A. is at her most radical when she’s participating in rather than fleeing from the pop world—all the better to stand as a stark (if forgivably flawed) presence laughing at its hypocrisies. After all
column15: ""Bad Girls"" was so undeniable that a <i><a href=""http://rapgenius.com/Kanye-west-diamonds-from-sierra-leone-remix-lyrics#note-17918"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">business
column16: man referenced it in a song he released through a Samsung advertisement disguised as a mobile phone app that was later investigated for violating its users’ privacy. M.I.A.
column17: no doubt
column18: would appreciate the irony—and
column19: if she were channeling her disses with more laser focus
column20: be uniquely qualified to point it out.

column1: Matangi is not without charms
column2: but unlike her most potent releases it sounds less interested in pushing and prodding the culture forward and more content to soar safely above it. ""There is nothing that can touch me now
column3: she sings on the nursery-rhyme earworm ""Come Walk With Me”. It’s one of the only moments she feels like she’s actually channeling Matangi—she sounds blissfully free
column4: superhumanly defiant
column5: and 5
column6:
000 feet above it all. Is it selfish to say it’s a shame? We could use her down here.

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/19900/homepage_large.aab4bacb.jpg|MellowHigh|30371.0|MellowHigh|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Odd Future']|2013-11-05 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:51:07.592483|"

""This Album Is Packed With Gun Sounds
column2: Grams OF Coke And Dead Cops. The Perfect Soundtrack For Mobbing On A Dark Halloween Night""—That's how Odd Future Wolf Gang Kill Them All duo MellowHype's album BLACKENDWHITE was introduced on Tumblr when it was released on Halloween three years ago. With its creepy cover
column3: jarring beats and frequently sinister content
column4: it was
column5: in the true spirit of the holiday
column6: a release engineered to be scary. And let's not forget how scary OFWGKTA were. Coming in the wake of <a href=""http://pitchfork.com/artists/29179-tyler-the-creator/"" target=""_blank"">Tyler
column7: the Creator's unhinged
column8: slur-laden Bastard and Earl Sweatshirt's rape-and-murder-filled Earl
column9: right as Odd Future was beginning to generate serious buzz
column10: BLACKENEDWHITE was the three's-a-trend release that confirmed the image of the collective as violent sociopaths
column11: relentless teenage pranksters and provocative game-changers. There was both genuine fascination and serious concern about the ways Odd Future might upend the status quo. On a more basic level
column12: MellowHype was just all about the idea of Halloween: When they weren't busy making their own homemade horror movie soundtracks
column13: they were the guys outside hip-hop's comfortably fun party who were having even more fun egging the house.

column1: This Halloween
column2: MellowHype members Hodgy Beats and Left Brain are no longer out smashing mailboxes or dressing up like corpses
column3: but rather inside
column4: smoking weed and wearing 90s rapper costumes with their friend Domo Genesis as part of the trio MellowHigh. The scariest thing about the group's self-titled album isn't the subject matter
column5: which
column6: even at its most provocative
column7: is basically boilerplate shit-talking
column8: nor is it the jarring beats
column9: which are too crisply mastered to suggest any real threat. Instead
column10: it's a sort of a deeper dread
column11: the kind that sinks in after a couple of Halloweens spent lazily wearing the same ""soccer player"" or ""businessman"" costume
column12: when you realize that your ways of doing things that are supposed to be fun have become totally mundane. MellowHigh is not disorienting but rather frighteningly familiar.

column1: The issue
column2: in a lot of ways
column3: is that the people involved have gotten better at making music. Domo has sharpened his focus since his early days as Odd Future's jovial
column4: lackadaisical stoner
column5: and recent releases—particularly Earl's Doris— have seen him staking out a role as the group's go-to guy for accomplished
column6: rapidly delivered verses. Hodgy
column7: too
column8: has matured as a rapper
column9: playing with more complex rhyme schemes and growing more comfortable on Left Brain's increasingly challenging production. With a few years of added practice and improved recording resources
column10: MellowHigh's members have figured out how to consistently deliver
column11: but they've also lost the edge of unpredictability that made a release like BLACKENEDWHITE so compelling. That album's rougher mixes and scattershot approach to rapping felt like a group clamoring for attention and making the best of what they had; MellowHigh is the work of people who know they have their audience's attention doing their best to make more or less what's expected of them.

column1: A few years ago
column2: these would have been the guys making fun of a group making hashtag rhymes like ""I'm all about they wives/Stepford"" and dropping a lightly Auto-Tuned hook with the phrase ""this real shit is going out of style"" in it. Now
column3: they're the ones doing it. When Tyler and Earl offer their wacky
column4: charismatic guest verses
column5: it's particularly clear who would be considered OF royalty at this point. Conversely
column6: when journeyman stoner rappers Curren$y and Smoke DZA stop by for a joint torch-passing moment on ""HighLife""
column7: they seem a bit like Ghosts of Rap Careers Yet to Come
column8: reminders that there's a safe
column9: well-established lane for lyrically proficient dudes who like talking about weed and are willing to tour a lot.

column1: That's not to give off the impression that MellowHigh is complacent
column2: or even particularly conventional. Compared to MellowHype's monotonous Numbers
column3: MellowHigh is an improvement
column4: a show of good faith that Odd Future isn't quite content to settle into rote lyrical recitations and cash in on their lucrative side business selling socks. For one thing
column5: the group takes on the challenge of singing some hooks
column6: particularly on the single ""Yu""
column7: a prickly G-funk foray with a beat full of minimal piano stabs
column8: and the frenetic ""Get'n Drunk
column9: which sees Hodgy Beats taking on the role of a more ratchet Kid Cudi. Meanwhile
column10: crunk anthem ""Roofless"" fits perfectly alongside MellowHype's other moshpit bangers
column11: a wholly appropriate subgenre experiment. The debt to 90s influences is clear—the entertaining castoff ""Cigarillo"" explicitly suggests ""we should do that Master P shit
column12: where he does all those conversations on at the same time""—but the net is wide
column13: and familiar echoes of East Coast lyricists or groups like Tha Dogg Pound and Three 6 Mafia interact in unexpected ways with Left Brain's consistently abrasive production.

column1: A master of screaming
column2: repellant synths on this album
column3: Left Brain has shifted his sound from low-budget noir to blockbuster dystopian thriller
column4: and he particularly excels on tracks like the looming ""Air"" and the climactic ""Cold World"". Elsewhere
column5: the heaving bass line on ""Troublesome"" makes the whole thing sound like it's happening in a boiler room
column6: and ""Extinguisher"" uses a sample of an actual scream and thunderous drums to elevate it well above standard boom-bap fare. These beats are huge
column7: intimidating walls of sound. They could use more imposing rappers to stand up to them. It may be that surprising people is a young man's game
column8: and it's time for Domo Genesis and Hodgy Beats to settle into their comfortable roles as confident
column9: reliable spitters. But for an album that sounds as off-the-wall as MellowHigh
column10:
it feels like a bit of a cop out to be content with insubstantial rapping.

column2:
Hell 3:00 AM|28709.0|James Ferraro|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Hippos in Tanks']|2013-11-05 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:51:08.152945|"

James Ferraro’s latest album
column3: <i>NYC
column4: Hell 3:00 AM
column5: opens with 22 seconds of a text-to-speech app repeating the word “money” over and over in a synthesized woman’s voice that was probably engineered to sound neutral but
column6: in this contex
column7: sounds like the flattened affect of a person in the midst of a psychotic break. If
column8: as its title strongly suggests
column9: the record is meant to function as some sort of portrait of New York City
column10: it gets off to an accurate start.

column1: The picture that emerges from there on isn’t any more flattering. It may be Bloomberg’s shiny technotopian New York that Ferraro’s portraying
column2: but he renders it in the grimy grey-on-grey palette of the city’s gutted-out Seventies
column3: an eternal night time of dirty concrete and menacing shadows like something out of an Abel Ferrara movie. Ferraro’s one of the leading figures in a successful movement to establish for contemporary R&B the same kind of avant-garde movement that other pop styles like rock and rap have had for years. The movement’s most popular member is the Weeknd
column4: and although Ferraro’s past work has been more aggressively experimental
column5: and boasted a heavier house music influence
column6: they were at least in the same general orbit together. <i>NYC
column7: Hell 3:00 AM feels like he’s slipped from that orbit completely and crash landed face down in a gutter.

column1: It’s a bleak album that totally inverts the druggy nocturnal glamour that’s become avant-R&B’s default mode. While it faithfully recreates the feeling of being chemically imbalanced late at night
column2: it’s not the fun kind. The compositions are harshly minimalist
column3: skeletal assemblages of beats that feel like half the drums are missing
column4: distended keyboard parts fading in and out like something in a fever dream
column5: and overblown field recordings of police scanners and traffic noise
column6: just in case your anxiety wasn’t already elevated enough already. It’s not the fashionable
column7: tastefully arranged kind of minimalism that’s currently de rigueur with tastemaking electronic musicians
column8: but rather something sickly and enervated
column9: like the songs once had more parts and a more robust sound but have somehow been starved down to their current states.

column1: The tracks tend towards abstraction
column2: and at a few points the album seems to lose any sort interest in rhythm and melody
column3: relying instead on mood and texture alone. Other times they’ll cohere into something that’s more or less identifiable as an R&B song (“Close Ups” and “Cheek Bones""
column4: which sound glamorous but aren’t)
column5: and even then the bare sketches of melody take a back seat to establishing a smoggy atmosphere. The whole thing feels like it’s coated in a layer of greasy
column6: digitally simulated dirt. Here and there Ferraro adds his own vocals
column7: mumbled beyond comprehensibility
column8: always a little off-key and sleep-deprived
column9: and touched with just enough modulation effects to sound like the recording’s physically warped.

column1: If NYC
column2: Hell 3:00 AM sounds like an unpleasant listen
column3: that’s because
column4: on some levels
column5: it is. Ferraro has some of a noise musician’s combatively challenging nature
column6: and at times seems to be going out of his way to unsettle his listeners. (Sometimes a little too far
column7: like when he tries to evoke the psychic stress of living in the city by literally sampling 9/11 news broadcasts.) The thing is that much of it this unpleasantness just adds to the fascination. It helps the record succeed as a verite-tinged portrait of life in New York City
column8: or at least one aspect of it that doesn’t often make it into movies these days. It also helps it to create another type of portrait
column9: one of the most vividly true to life depictions of serious depression that’s ever been recorded. Stripping R&B of its ability to inspire pleasure turns out to be the perfect pop music metaphor for the crippling anhedonia that’s part and parcel of the severe depressive experience—a sensual form with its sensuality drained away
column10: transformed into something ugly and oppressive.

column1: The fact that Ferraro’s able to work in an R&B medium using ugliness as his primary aesthetic says a lot about how real the style’s avant garde is
column2: and about how far they’re willing to push things. It also says a lot about how good things can get if they keep pushing. <i>NYC
column3: Hell 3:00 AM isn’t going to be your thing if you’re on the hunt for the next edgy crooner about to blow up—you’re only going to hear it in DJ sets if the DJ is extremely brave or suicidal or both. But if what you’re looking for is an experience
column4: one that can offer something extremely rare and powerful
column5: if not exactly fun
column6:
then this is it.

Spanish moss
column2: brass beds
column3: overgrown yards
column4: burning sage. To Widowspeak
column5: these artifacts represent the hazy
column6: lazy birthplace of swamp rock and Delta blues
column7: which singer Molly Hamilton and multi-instrumentalist Robert Earl Thomas fell in love with last year after touring their sophomore LP Almanac across the American Southeast. The duo incorporated these sights
column8: sounds
column9: and smoke into a six-note guitar riff they had been sitting on for awhile. That became the motif for The Swamps
column10: a stopgap EP between Widowspeak’s last full-length and their next one. After hopscotching across the country from the Pacific Northwest and Chicago to Brooklyn and exploring that wanderlust in Almanac
column11: Widowspeak have settled on a thematically consistent aesthetic that suits them.

column1: “True Believer” is the first song Widowspeak recorded for The Swamps
column2: and fittingly it’s the one that sounds closest to Almanac. (Thomas has said this EP
column3: which Kevin McMahon also produced
column4: leans more toward Widowspeak’s last record than their putative third LP). It opens much like “Locusts”
column5: with a similarly note-bent but lower-pitched bloom from Thomas’ Fender Telecaster. Where the latter track was tightly coiled like a tense calm before the plague
column6: on “True Believer” Hamilton literally lets her hair down (“tangled sheets
column7: tangled hair”) and swoons into the romanticized slide guitar. The religious imagery on Almanac’s “Dyed in the Wool” can also be found in ""True Believer""–“speak in tongues
column8: ” “shake off that devil fever
column9: ” “pilgrim lips”–but this time Hamilton tinges her turns of phrase with the vivid mysticism of the South’s voodoo culture rather than falling back on idiomatic poetry in the vein of “cut from the cloth.""

column1: Hamilton’s lyrics “The house was a good one
column2: but the yard was overgrown” on “Calico” are actually a good metaphor for Almanac
column3: a fine record that still occasionally got lost on its forays into Western and Latin themes. Most of The Swamps
column4: by contrast
column5: rides on opening instrumental “Theme From the Swamps”
column6: obviously a kind of mission statement for the EP. Those six creaky
column7: twangy
column8: back-porch rocking-chair notes prove to be a tangible yet versatile anchor for Widowspeak’s songwriting. This time
column9: most of the genre-specific accents–the castanet rolls on “Smoke and Mirrors”
column10: shakers rattling in the background of “The Swamps”
column11: tambourines stalking through “Calico” like spurs on a cowboy boot–enhance what’s already there instead of distracting from it. The only weak spot on The Swamps might be “Brass Bed”
column12: a lovely track that suffers from simply too much going on–multi-part harmonies
column13: twinkling pianos
column14: and “That’s Amore”-esque guitar stylings
column15: and awkward lyrical syntax (“Find me underneath the linen/ Trying hard to get forgiven”).

column1: Widowspeak do their best work when they take a minute to smell the sage
column2: not necessarily when they forge ahead into new territories; and to a certain extent the band recognizes this and embraces it on The Swamps. In a recent interview
column3: Thomas suggested that Almanac
column4: with its big
column5: brassy arrangements and relatively quick tempos
column6: was an exercise in nostalgia “backlash” while their latest collection of songs takes the opposite tack. “You can’t be too nostalgic
column7: you can’t get caught in something like that
column8: ” he said
column9: referring to the former. “In the swamps
column10: you feel sticky
column11: and slowed down
column12: and caught. And in terms of our music
column13: we’re never like a really fast
column14: loud band.” He’s right: Hamilton’s languorous croon will never be able to fully escape Hope Sandoval’s shadow–nor should she try–and Thomas’ arrangements will probably always owe a fair piece to the 60s' gun-slinging theme songs of the Wild West
column15: which have been the band's bread and butter since Widowspeak's album cover re-imagined the giant spiders from Wild Wild West. Widowspeak seem to have found a home in the swamps
column16:
and now they're inviting us in to set awhile.

0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/19850/homepage_large.7d7140b2.jpg|Allegoria|30030.0|Sapphire Slows|['Pop/R&B']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Not Not Fun']|2013-11-05 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:51:09.218882|"

Beyond the neon-lit
column2: movie friendly downtown of Tokyo lie the backstreets and quiet neighborhoods where Sapphire Slows honed her sound. Despite making her music alone at home
column3: Kinuko Hiramatsu’s solo project developed within a like-minded community of bedroom producers that emerged in Japan’s capital starting in 2009. Revolving around the Cuz Me Pain record label
column4: outfits like Jesse Ruins (briefly signed to Captured Tracks)
column5: Faron Square
column6: and the Beauty created songs inspired by the house music playing in the popular clubs in Shibuya
column7: but with a level of intimacy and longing appropriate for artists operating mostly alone in their apartments.

column1: Sapphire Slows existed within and learned from this scene
column2: and her debut full-length album
column3: <i>Allegoria
column4: wonderfully captures the shadowy essence of this corner of Tokyo music. The 10 tracks here are minimal dance numbers featuring beats that could slide into many DJ sets
column5: but they're undercut with an uneasiness provided by Hiramatsu’s wispy vocals. This style isn’t unique to Sapphire Slows or the various Japanese artists she’s tied to sonically—a visit to one of Cuz Me Pain’s DJ nights often include tracks from similarly skeletal outfits like Solar Bears
column6: Miracles Club
column7: and nearly everyone on Los Angeles label Not Not Fun
column8: who released Allegoria. Yet what she does so well here is balance floor-filling sounds with the hair-raising atmosphere.

column1: Hiramatsu pulls this off so well thanks to her vocals. She mixes them low into Allegoria's tracks so her singing becomes a ghostly whisper that’s often unintelligible. Words sometimes emerge clearly from the ether
column2: like on the Morse-code-like-beeping “Rules
column3: ” while other times she’s content singing only syllables like on “Fade Out.” But the overall effect of her voice registers the same either way—Hiramatsu is more interested in delivering a particular texture rather than saying anything concrete.

column1: This steadfast sonic devotion has hurt Sapphire Slows’ previous EPs and singles compilations – her dark take on dance music is intriguing
column2: but a whole disc of it can go from mysterious to tedious. For Allegoria
column3: Hiramatsu has balanced out all the creepiness with some of her most playful recordings to date. Opener “Dry Fruits” shuffles ahead on bass and vocals familiar to her work
column4: but also features a bright synth at its center and some party-starting percussion deeper in the mix. “Third Party” practically vamps
column5: Hiramatsu’s singing sounding relaxed. The sequencing of these songs is a bit off—they are the first two songs on Allegoria
column6: and one of them would serve better as a break during the album’s more sinister core—but they do add some variety to Sapphire Slows’ sound.

column1: The bulk of her debut album
column2: though
column3: remains shivery. The back end of this album is especially memorable
column4: as Hiramatsu has learned to grace her music with a gripping sense of drama. “As You Know” starts out sounding like anything else in her catalog
column5: but then Hiramatsu pushes her voice into new direction
column6: singing higher and stretching out words long than she has before. It makes the music resonate emotionally more. “Can I Get Out of This Silence” embraces minimalism
column7: letting her lungful vocals stick out more than usual
column8: only rippling synths and forceful drums cutting through them. The title track ends the album on an especially strong note
column9: as Hiramatsu once again expands her vocal delivery as the music around her subtly morphs for six minutes
column10: every bit of it captivating.

column1: Allegoria is a strong entry point into Sapphire Slows’ music and a varied enough recording to never really become a chore
column2: even if several songs seems content to coast on her formula. But Hiramatsu’s first proper album is also important because it is a strong representation of what a particular Tokyo music community has been playing around with for several years now. Alongside Jesse Ruins’ singles collection Dream Analysis
column3:
Allegoria is an excellent distillation of this in-the-shadows scene. 

"|18657.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18657-sapphire-slows-allegoria/|7.0|Patrick St. Michel

Cut Copy never sounded like a band that had a problem getting to the point. Nor did they ever sound like a band that needed a serotonin boost. Yet
column3: even “Lights & Music”
column4: “Need You Now”
column5: “Hearts on Fire”
column6: “Take Me Over” and just about any of the Australian quartet’s uniformly excellent and directly-titled singles can sound wishy-washy and kinda dark in the face of Free Your Mind
column7: its Successories screen-saver album cover and Dan Whitford’s claim that the title refers to a freedom that’s “universally positive and timeless.”  Maybe Cut Copy were hippies all along
column8: and whether you think that’s progress or a serious regression
column9: Free Your Mind is at least a sensible continuation of their trajectory from the cosmopolitan
column10: club-friendly and DFA-affiliated In Ghost Colours to the breezier
column11: more festival-ready 80s pop of Zonoscope.  But there’s a difference between freeing your mind
column12: losing your mind and just flat-out shutting it down. And you just wish Cut Copy left even something to the imagination
column13: as their most overtly fun and least dynamic music restates the obvious over and over again throughout Free Your Mind.

column1: Their aims are admirable here. Whitford claimed the band took their inspiration from the Summers of Love
column2: both 1967 and 1989. Philosophically and sonically
column3: those years are something of a package deal anyway—Stone Roses and Inspiral Carpets were essentially psychedelic pop-rock bands with beats
column4: while Primal Scream and Happy Mondays had no qualms about straight-up pilfering the era. You can’t doubt Cut Copy’s commitment to sidling up with nu-Madchester types like Jagwar Ma and Paradise
column5: as there’s barely any modernist touch to be found on the title track
column6: just all of your favorite E’s and wizz signifiers
column7: sorted out neatly: staggered house piano vamps
column8: endlessly thumping bass drum and Whitford letting his vocals get all baggy in every sense of the word
column9: an amalgamation of Shaun Ryder’s dysfunctional relationship with pitch
column10: Ian Brown’s bedheaded proclamations and Bobby Gillespie’s revolutionary hokum.

column1: In about five minutes
column2: you hear everything new Cut Copy has to offer
column3: though they stay true to their strange nostalgia for the future by slipping inside the proverbial acid house on “Let Me Show You Love” and all but sampling Stone Roses’ “Don’t Stop” on “Take Me Higher"". There are enough highlights to still make their ecstatic live shows a must-see; “Walking in the Sky” is stately flower-child pop while “We Are Explorers” reaches the hands-in-the-air mania as effectively as their previous singles. But with its timbale breakdown
column4: a chorus melody with sharp contours rather than flabby curves
column5: it’s just a reminder of what you're missing out on here.

column1: Free Your Mind has a personality
column2: at least. It’s a concept album of sorts
column3: taking you out of the desert (Coachella’s EDM-friendly Sahara Tent?)
column4: above the city and... something about the waves. You wouldn’t think they’d have much more to say about holistic healing and solar-religiosity after ending Zonoscope with a 15-minute song named “Sun God""
column5: and they don’t really
column6: though it doesn’t stop them from trying—the lyrical component of Free Your Mind is straight Screamadelica magnet poetry about us getting higher/shining brighter than the sun and getting free and getting loaded. And while Whitford’s slack affectations are pitch-perfect on “Free Your Mind”
column7: elsewhere the same effect just means he’s singing off key
column8: capturing the tone of his influences
column9: but lacking the necessary rock-star posturing.

column1: If this seems like an unusual amount of focus on Cut Copy’s lyrics
column2: it’s because the music itself seems content to keep the beat and little else. Though it’s every bit as sequentially-formatted as In Ghost Colours or Zonoscope
column3: Free Your Mind lacks the dynamism of its predecessors
column4: the DJ-curated ebb and flow. You can laugh at the ridiculous spoken word interludes
column5: but they’re about the only thing that can jar you out of the mid-album lull created as Free Your Mind goes forward. With few exceptions
column6: it’s basically a Cut Copy album that’s just deep cuts—you get the same octave-jumping funk basslines (“In Memory Capsule”)
column7: the occasional acoustic-laced pop-rock (“Dark Corners & Mountain Tops”) and slow-moving disco-pop from their past records
column8: only with lumpier melodies and Dave Fridmann’s mixing job using reverb like packing peanuts to make Free Your Mind sound both puffy and stiff.

column1: Cut Copy’s music has always been simple; the difficult part was trying to explain in non-illusory terms what made Bright Like Neon Love
column2: In Ghost Colours and Zonoscope glorious and uplifting rather than silly or even flat out dumb. My take is that they had omnivorous enough taste to show they take their craft seriously
column3: while avoiding crowd-moving mock profundity and proving they don’t take themselves all that serious. Free Your Mind manages to be Cut Copy's most homogenous and it's most ""message-based"" record yet
column4: and in doing little other than turning on
column5: tuning in and dropping out
column6:
there’s precious little separating it from the vapid electro-pop to which Cut Copy used to be an alternative.

"|18689.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18689-cut-copy-free-your-mind/|6.4|Ian Cohen

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/19796/homepage_large.b08dcfc2.jpg|The Regal Years: 1997-2004|339.0|The Beta Band|['Rock']|0.0|1.0|0.0|['Parlophone']|2013-11-04 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:51:10.506449|"

For a group that made a virtue of its flaws
column2: the one perfect thing about the Beta Band was their timing. In the late-1990s
column3: as Y2K-bug experts/fear-mongers started hitting the talk-show circuit to warn us of the impending global technological meltdown
column4: the Beta Band brought with them the reassurance that we’d still be able to get out of our heads even in the event of a worldwide blackout. In stark contrast to the bloated Britpop dominating their homeland at the time
column5: the Beta Band crafted majestic music out of the most modest means: mantric psych-folk anthems built atop a jew’s-harp drone and bongo bounce (“She’s the One”); drum-circle workouts (“B+A”) that hit hard enough to leave fissures in the earth’s crust; a cappella beat-boxed
column6: bell-clanging chants that could make a quiet night around the campfire feel like peak-hour at the Hacienda (“The House Song”).

column1: These epochal early recordings—as heard on the Champion Versions
column2: Patty Patty Sound
column3: and Los Amigos del Betas Bandidos EPs—imagined the White Album as recorded at Black Ark: music of the ancients that sounded as though it was beaming in through radio transmissions from another galaxy. Though not without kindred spirits—from Beck’s stoner-folk freakery to Cornershop’s pan-cultural polyglot—the Betas more acutely symbolized an act of a retreat: from camera-mugging music-press ass-kissery
column4: from suffocating urbanism
column5: from accelerated modernity. They never came close to topping the charts (unless you count the in-store one at Championship Vinyl)
column6: but they had a profound effect on bands that did: in their wake
column7: Radiohead turned more insular
column8: Oasis got trippier
column9: and even Travis started booking photo shoots out in the sticks. To this day
column10: after more than a decade of familiarization and canonization
column11: listening to these early EPs still feels like unearthing some lost artifact whose place and date of origin are difficult to decode.

column1: Those extended players were released in limited editions over the course of 1997 and early 1998
column2: but they locked together into a perfect full-length album sequence when reissued in September 98 as The Three EPs compilation. Now
column3: The Regal Years attempts a similar
column4: if more difficult trick: combining the band’s entire recorded output into a seamless
column5: six-disc listening experience. It’s especially challenging because
column6: over the course of their seven-year existence
column7: the Beta Band were not a band that enjoyed a linear evolution from one album to next. Rather
column8: each of their official albums stand as discrete
column9: often oppositional units
column10: shaped by the particular pressures weighing down on the band at the time.

column1: Most notorious of all is the Beta Band’s self-titled 1999 effort
column2: which deflated the ballooning expectations surrounding the group in the wake of The Three EPs with all the elegance and subtlety of a whoopee cushion. In place of its predecessors’ melting-pot fusion of cross-genre influences
column3: The Beta Band pits them at war with one another
column4: stopping the hypnotic space-rock groove of “It’s Not Too Beautiful” dead in its tracks with a destablizing orchestral sample from John Barry’s Black Hole soundtrack
column5: or fashioning a “Beta Band Rap” that’s actually equal parts barbershop-quartet serenade
column6: proto-“Lazy Sunday” faux b-boy braggadocio
column7: and Elvis pelvis thrusts. Over its four-and-a-half minutes
column8: the latter song sees the Beta Band turn into the Meta Band
column9: unraveling two years of carefully cultivated mystique by recounting in painstaking detail the band’s origin story to date
column10: right down to commentary on the free dinners paid for by the Parlophone A&R reps trying to sign them. (""A meal like that
column11: yo/ We never ate!"")

column1: That’s just one of many gestures on The Beta Band that blurs the line between being genuinely weird and quote-unquote “wacky
column2: ” from the endless chipmunked funk of “Smiling” to the electro-square-dance pastiche “Dance O’er the Border”. “I’m at 90 degrees to the rest of the world
column3: ” Steve Mason sings on the charming country-rock ramble
column4: “Round the Bend”
column5: an all-too-accurate advertisement for a record that packs all the hair-pulling complication of a geometry exam. Mason’s actual assessment of The Beta Band was far less subtle; just prior to its release
column6: citing budgetary and deadline pressures
column7: he infamously told the press the album “was fucking awful—the worst album released this year.” But if the record violently vascillates between fascinating and frustrating on a song-by-song basis
column8: its over-arching oddness retains its own peculiar allure. At the very least
column9: The Beta Band stands as a time capsule of possibly the last instance when a group this strange could not just get signed to a major label
column10: but use the company dime to make themselves sound even stranger. (And this is to say nothing of the complementary disc of ambient field recordings that were included in press mail-outs of The Beta Band
column11: but eventually scrapped from the official release.)

column1: The Beta Band never quite recovered their momentum after the self-titled-album stumble. Though they would harness the shambolic qualities of their recordings into a tight and powerful live act (earning them tour invites from Radiohead)
column2: their subsequent albums were refined to a fault. It was easy to underrate Hot Shots II at the time of its 2001 release: siphoning off the skeletal
column3: breakbeat skitter and moody atmospherics of The Beta Band’s Bonnie Tyler-quoting highlight “The Hard One”
column4: the album mostly lacked the exuberant eccentricity and percussive grooves of the Betas’ signature works
column5: and proved wholly out of step with popular UK tastes that were shifting toward the more visceral retro-rock pleasures of the Strokes and the White Stripes. (Not to mention the fact that trip-hoppy lead single “Squares” leans on a string sample that felt like an eight-years-too-late echo of Portishead’s “Glory Box”.) But the passage of time has been very kind to this record
column6: which now feels remarkably prescient in initiating a conversation between left-field rock and modern R&B that still continues to this day. And standouts like “Al Sharp” and “Eclipse” presented golden opportunities to showcase the fortitude of Mason’s songwriting in less cluttered surroundings
column7: pointing the way to the intimacty and immediacy of his post-Betas solo records.

column1: Alas
column2: Hot Shots II did little to reverse the group’s waning popularity and diminishing critical cachet
column3: a circumstance alluded to in the self-deprecating title of 2004’s Heroes to Zeros. But The Beta Band hardly sound defeated here. Of all the stylistic guises the Betas had toyed with over the years
column4: straight-up
column5: riff-driven rock was never one of them
column6: and yet Heroes to Zeros evinces a heretofore unleashed arena-conquering bravado and clarity—most audible in the Red Rocks-toppling surge of “Assessment” and the massive Madchester-schooled swing of “Out-Side”—without tempering the band’s idiosyncratic essence. Of course
column7: it figures that
column8: for a group with as troubled a track record as theirs
column9: the Beta Band’s most outwardly accessible effort would prove to be their least successful
column10: the last straw that would lead to their unceremonious break-up in December 2004.

column1: It didn’t take long for Regal to capitalize on the headlines generated by group’s sudden demise—a career-spanning compilation
column2: The Best of The Beta Band
column3: appeared in 2005 as both an epitaph and a catalyst for post-mortem reappraisal. However
column4: now that Mason has established a steady solo career (following a prolonged period of depression in the wake of the Betas’ split)
column5: enough time has passed to reapproach the group's work with fresh ears. And while a six-CD box set may seem forbidding to all but the most hardcore fans (who likely still have all of these albums close at hand)
column6: The Regal Years arrives with both a very reasonable price point ($42.99—not much more than what I paid for The Three EPs on import back in the day) and a wealth of bonus material. Comprising key transitory non-album singles (like 2000’s Hot Shots II precursor “To You Alone”/“Sequinsizer”)
column7: B-sides
column8: demos
column9: radio sessions
column10: and concert recordings
column11: these add-ons—two discs’ worth—will be equally revelatory to long-time enthusiasts and tourists alike.

column1: Despite the disjointed
column2: reactive nature of their discography
column3: the Beta Band’s albums were united by the fact that none of them represented an absolute finished product; rather
column4: their songs were like living organisms that could assume radically altered shapes under different conditions
column5: be it a BBC appearance or a T in the Park gig before a crowd of thousands. A 1997 visit to Radio 1 shows this policy of impermanence in full effect from day one—where “B+A” gets distended into the sort of brown-note funk jam the Beasties Boys would throw down with Money Mark
column6: the once-imposing 15-minute Floydian dub collage “The Monolith” is sculpted into a much more immediate five-minute piece that unearths the melody lurking within its Pompeii-scaled expanse. And this exploratory impulse remained in place until the band’s final show at London’s Shepherd’s Bush Empire
column7: which is represented here by six tracks
column8: including an adrenalized “Dr. Baker” and a rendition of “The House Song” that climaxes with a drum-set-crashing duel. (The full concert was featured as a bonus disc in The Best of the Beta Band.) But even more impressive is how deep cuts from the less-illumated corners of the catalogue are transformed into show-stopping knockouts
column9: like the rebirth of The Beta Band’s acoustic trance “Broken Up a Ding Dong” as a synth-buzzed motorik odyssey
column10: or a version of the Hot Shots II stomper “Quiet” that gets loosened into a piano-rolled mambo
column11: or an unplugged strip-down of Heroes to Zeroes’ “Out-Side” that shirks the original’s playful go-go-dancer sway to expose the white-knuckled tension at the song’s core. In this regard
column12: The Regal Years does a thorough job of not just compiling the Beta Band's recorded legacy
column13: but underscoring the real reason why they're missed—it’s not just for the music they left behind
column14:
but for the infinite possibilities within it that had yet to be explored.

"|18603.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18603-the-beta-band-the-regal-years-1997-2004/|8.4|Stuart Berman

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/19782/homepage_large.262db95a.jpg|Surfing Strange|30624.0|Swearin'|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Salinas']|2013-11-04 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:51:11.088020|"

On their 2012 self-titled debut album
column2: Swearin' introduced themselves as nuanced purveyors of a particular sentiment
column3: the kind newsmagazines and think-pieces would label ""millennial."" Ripping through 12 hook-heavy songs in 28 minutes
column4: with Allison Crutchfield at the mic most of the time
column5: the quartet emerged boldly
column6: confronting the unattractive realities of their unsteady adulthood in rebellious tempos
column7: battling it with calls for jubilant bodily motion and youthfully existential shout-alongs. That first record sublimated their discontent into its own defiant salve: dissatisfaction expressed satisfyingly.

column1: The second time around
column2: on Surfing Strange
column3: that jubilation is almost gone
column4: though the foursome's restlessness still persists. But now it's expanding
column5: to encompass sentiment along with style
column6: too. Their disillusionment feels bleaker here
column7: refocusing on more interpersonal subjects like dissolving relationships and miscommunications; the musical expression of those intimacies has slowed and thickened to accommodate a more square-shouldered approach. ""Dust in the Gold Sack"" and ""Watered Down""
column8: the pair of opening numbers
column9: set the album's crumbly
column10: emotionally decaying tone. At 4:18
column11: the next song
column12: ""Mermaid""
column13: is the longest the band has ever released; it's also at once their most aggressive and subtle
column14: a mixed style that they wear well
column15: even if it does rely heavily on forbears to accomplish it (the Breeders and Pixies are two of their most obvious reference points).

column1: The gang does bring back a number of their strong suits
column2: like arranging vivid settings (""Gold Sack"" is great for these
column3: as Crutchfield gazes at ""cracks in the ceiling/ Above us"" and traverses on Brooklyn streets ""Back and forth down Bedford and Nostrand/ You set things in motion"") and setting themselves apart from their peers (""Parts of Speech"" could be a biting condemnation of a ratings-obsessed contemporary: ""Convoluted you are/ Guarded in fear on the radio/ It's no wonder/ when you just measure things in numbers""). So don't worry
column4: these are still your good friends Swearin'
column5: they've just become a bit more consumed with their problems. And
column6: for now
column7: it's a good thing.

column1: While much of the press surrounding Surfing's predecessor translated its Crutchfield-heavy sound as part of a larger narrative about the musical split between Allison and her twin sister Katie (the singer-songwriter behind Waxahatchee)
column2: this sophomore effort pointedly democratizes
column3: in both form and function. Guitarist Kyle Gilbride and bassist Keith Spencer (especially Spencer
column4: who sings lead for the first time on ""Melanoma"" and ""Glare of the Sun"") make their songwriting presence known by sharing vocal duties more evenly with Crutchfield
column5: establishing the rule that ""if you write it
column6: you sing it."" The choice decentralizes (and perhaps dashes somewhat) the expectations Swearin' fans might have had thanks to the female-fronted promise of the first record
column7: but the delegated duties play as more honest to the group's reason for being: they work through personal snags simultaneously and together
column8: not at the pleasure of a frontperson.

column1: There isn't much explicit growth on the record
column2: but where it does express itself is in the development of the players' technical skills. Drummer Jeff Bolt's style hasn't really changed across the two albums
column3: but in this new context
column4: it becomes more textural than punk-loud; and that coarse chord progression that thunks its way pragmatically through their songs' clever
column5: well-defined melodies has become more idiosyncratic. Sure
column6: it isn't unique
column7: but Gilbride and Crutchfield do it irresistibly; it defines the band more and more as they progress
column8: and it's one of their strongest suits
column9: second only to their knack for marrying familiar alt-rock re-interpretations to cuttingly contemporary sentiments.

column1: Surfing contains few of its light-footed predecessor's punky sparks
column2: so often the recalibrated songs come off a little sludgy and unfocused. ""Mermaid""
column3: an earful of definitive
column4: muttering distortion
column5: might seem the obvious example
column6: but the mid-tempo ""Echo Locate"" and psychedelic
column7: piano-lined ""Glare of the Sun"" are the bigger culprits. ('""Echo""
column8: despite its powerful chorus
column9: has an off-puttingly slow start and ""Glare
column10: for better or worse
column11: is Swearin's take on the Blake Sennett solo number that appears on every Rilo Kiley album.) The catharsis of ""Kenosha"" or ""Crashing"" doesn't live here
column12: and the respite we do get
column13: in a song like ""Loretta's Flowers""—the album's simplest
column14: loveliest
column15: most affecting cut
column16: about trying to help a loved one who doesn't want to be saved—drops the record in the other direction
column17: into half-resentful heartbreak. Unlike on Swearin'
column18: there's little hope for sonic comfort from reality
column19: save perhaps ""Young""
column20: a tellingly titled
column21: sprightly love song that despite its optimism seems detached from its LP-mates. But that trudge is the essence of this second round
column22: and in that it's effective. Surfing takes the disenchanted bits of Swearin' and blows them out into 34 minutes of honed unrest—it's a self-aware

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/19846/homepage_large.53952a53.jpg|Just In Case|31391.0|Doley Bernays|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['self-released']|2013-11-04 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:51:11.590208|"

Doley Bernays is a promising
column2: still-developing rapper from the Bronx with a lot of other rappers' voices rattling around inside his own. You can hear some of Kendrick's Chosen-One determination
column3: some of Meek Mill's life-or-death panic. He can rap in acrobatic thickets
column4: flipping in and out of double and triple time. But the star of his debut EP is not Doley: it is Doley's producer MP Williams
column5: who supervises the entire project
column6: and who drapes the record in a thousand glorious rippling harps and interstellar synths. Williams is probably best known to the world for ""Ghetto Symphony""
column7: from A$AP Rocky's <i>LongLiveA$AP
column8: and if the sprawling
column9: gorgeous sound of Just in Case is any indication
column10: he has the kind of reach and ambition that warrants a full-length instrumental LP. On Just In Case
column11: he's in permanent ""smoking weed under star projectors"" mode.

column1: There are a lot of big ideas siphoned off from other major artists sluicing around Just In Case. The melted
column2: downcast mood and rainy synth pads are post-Take Care; the nested
column3: suitelike song structure and psychedelic over-ripeness is post-My Beautiful Dark Twisted Fantasy. But even if Doley and Williams are chasing down big ambitions with borrowed parts
column4: the sounds themselves are overwhelming. A few moments here are worth the price of admission: The downshift halfway through ""Just In Case""
column5: where Williams clobbers us with treated vocal hits; the slowed string pads fighting through clotted air on ""We Belong Here""
column6: the deadmau5 sample that sits at the center of the nerve-twitch drums on ""Raise Your Weapon"". Doley raps about struggles and desperation
column7: but the music is soft
column8: dreamlike
column9: and gentle
column10: the drum programming skittering across the surface like water bugs.

column1: Doley and Williams have pitched Just In Case as an EP
column2: which laughably undersells what they're doing. The album feels painstakingly crafted
column3: and formally ambitious as a whole
column4: in a way that 99 percent of free rap releases don't. Song structures maul themselves and twist into new shapes that have nothing to do with pure rap: ""Till We Fall"" changes key
column5: loses its drums
column6: and subsides into an intimate James Blake cyber-mumble for its chorus. ""Darkside Glow"" interrupts itself three-quarters of the way through with another beat
column7: this one warped and hissy
column8: dropping in like a skipping turntable.

column1: Doley's small
column2: urgent voice flits around this grand canvas ably. He's technically brilliant as a rapper
column3: and his greatest gifts are ferociousness and tenacity—when he digs into a beat
column4: he leaves claw marks. As a sheer display of raw skill
column5: ""Blessed"" is stunning
column6: on ""I Know Pain""
column7: he harmonizes with himself in triple time
column8: a la Bone Thugs. He pours a tremendous amount of emotional information into each verse
column9: which is why it's disappointing that so much of it slides off; his vocal delivery just isn't distinctive enough
column10: his writing not flavorful enough
column11: for his hunger to stick. He's pained
column12: he's hungry
column13: he's true of heart—except for a few powerfully honest moments on ""Tommy & Keish"" and ""I Know Pain"" he doesn't manage to communicate much more to us than that.

column1: Still
column2: he often sounds incredible
column3: even if what he's here to tell us hasn't quite come into focus. He's aligned himself with a producer with a powerful artistic vision
column4: and he's forged a calling-card debut project with a unique imprint. Even if Doley sounds vaguely like a few other rappers
column5: not a lot of street-level rap
column6: and almost no New York rap
column7: feels like Just In Case. That takes savvy
column8: and demands attention
column9:
and Just In Case will probably win him some diehard fans that he deserves.

"|18653.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18653-doley-bernays-just-in-case/|7.0|Jayson Greene

column1: 0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/19888/homepage_large.db35609e.jpg|Antiphon|4827.0|Midlake|['Rock'
column2:
'Experimental']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['ATO']|2013-11-04 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:51:12.123615|"

Midlake don’t get enough credit for being ahead of their time. Actually
column3: they don’t get any credit
column4: understandable in light of the Denton
column5: Tex.
column6: sextet's antiquated imagery and sepia-drunk sound. But the formula that made The Trials of Van Occupanther a sleeper hit in 2006—bearded indie-folk meets California soft-rock meets Fleetwood Mac at their most glassy-eyed—would likely make it a massive success in 2013. It’s certainly in their best interest to revisit that style after the clock-stopping Tull torpor of The Courage of Others
column7: and guitarist Eric Pulido claims their fourth LP Antiphon “is the most honest representation of the band as a whole.” Except he goes on to say
column8: “as opposed to one person’s vision that we were trying to facilitate.” Pulido got an internal promotion to frontman after the departure of singer-songwriter Tim Smith in 2012
column9: and...shots fired?

column1: Antiphon does somehow manage to be a “forget everything you know about Midlake!” album as well as a “return to form
column2: ” at least if you remember that Van Occupanther was preceded by the burlier
column3: less precious (title aside) Bamnan and Silvercork in 2004. Pulido’s words foreshadow a more aggressive tack on the part of Midlake and they certainly oblige during the first half of Antiphon. If the title track and “Provider” don’t exactly boogie
column4: they’re at least rollin’ and tumblin’
column5: with the shuffling beats and sticky
column6: distorted guitar leads that invert Midlake’s previous ratio of rock to folk. More notably
column7: the flutes and other non-strung instruments are pushed to the periphery
column8: foregrounding a lightly psychedelic blues that I suppose recalls Fleetwood Mac before their big personnel shakeup. Likewise
column9: Pulido begins the record asking the listener to “start a war
column10: ” and goes on to speak of foxholes and space shuttles. There’s even one song called “It’s Going Down”
column11: which doesn’t sound all that more vigorous than what came before it
column12: but hey
column13: make your own Yung Joc ""meet me at the farmer's market"" jokes.

column1: But throughout
column2: it’s clear that Smith’s departure is an amputation that doesn’t change Midlake’s DNA. They’ve got a couple of opening gigs for Pearl Jam in the near future
column3: so that should give you an idea of whether they’ve retained the earnestness of their previous work. Pulido doesn’t have Smith’s distinct
column4: dulcet tone
column5: though it’s actually to Midlake’s advantage on Antiphon. His vocals are alopecia-stricken
column6: almost fascinating in their lack of texture even when layered in harmony
column7: offering no resistance to the bulkier music backing him. So Antiphon never sounds awkward even when he sings about space travel on “Corruption” (“we went to the moon/ with a tycoon”) in a way that comes off as quaint as the more typically Midlake-y concerns like sorting out “The Old and the Young” and having a good woman waiting at home by the fire.

column1: The bigger shift is in the production
column2: provided by Grammy-nominated Tony Hoffer. His most frequently cited credits are Beck and Air
column3: who both ended up working with Nigel Godrich on their very next albums
column4: so I’ve come to think of his aesthetic as a kind of Radiohead starter kit. Midlake get that kind of sound here—you wouldn’t call it overproduced
column5: but there’s tons of production if you know where to listen for it
column6: as the stereo panning is neatly utilized
column7: the percussion crisp and non-obtrusive
column8: while all of the folk instruments are spit-shined and shellacked. It’s a retro-modernist (or modernist-retro) schematic
column9: aspiring for Laurel Canyon decor while paying West Hollywood rent.

column1: As far as
column2: the songs themselves—well
column3: to Antiphon’s credit
column4: it's a very consistent record. And to its detriment
column5: it's a very consistent record. While Antiphon might be the most honest representation of Midlake
column6: Smith’s ostensible iron fist penned songs like “Roscoe” and “We Gathered In Spring”
column7: songs that bore a personality and vision that the overly democratic Antiphon eschews. The nice things I thought I was going to say about the title track are actually applicable to “Provider” once I remembered which one was which. “It’s Going Down” also stood out mainly because it repeats the title
column8: “Vale” only because it’s an instrumental and thus the most memorable song here by default. After “Vale”
column9: side B of Antiphon has about as much melodic grounding as a drone record
column10: and if it wasn’t for a reprise of “Provider” at the close
column11: you’d be hard pressed to recall the goodwill generated at the beginning.

column1: And that’s problematic
column2: because if they aren’t going to offer much in the way of innovation or currency
column3: Midlake should at the very least be tuneful enough to counterbalance it. In our review of Swans’ pulverizing two-hour art-rock opus The Seer
column4: Mike Powell explained its appeal by paraphrasing a quote from Ben Marcus regarding the nature of experimental fiction: it wasn't a record for someone deciding whether or not they'd rather be listening to music or playing paintball. By the same token
column5: Midlake isn’t competing with Swans records. Considering who they are competing with makes for an even less flattering comparison. It’s not hard to find folky rock bands with stronger melodies
column6: bolder personae
column7: or even ones that are just flat-out weirder while operating squarely within the mainstream: let’s not forget that Fleet Foxes used a couple minutes of saxophone on their last album and purists flipped the fuck out. That doesn’t change the fact that Antiphon is still a likeable
column8: pleasant listen that will always wait for you by the hearth after a long day. But for a “forget everything you know about Midlake!” album
column9:
it's almost exactly how you remember them.

"|18696.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18696-midlake-antiphon/|6.0|Ian Cohen
