0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/19871/homepage_large.4fe9c0fd.jpg|Nonfiction|31225.0|The Range|['Electronic']|1.0|0.0|0.0|['Donky Pitch']|2013-10-31 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:51:13.513046|"

Albums like Nonfiction
column2: the first full-length from producer James Hinton (aka the Range)
column3: never get the credit they deserve: They’re too neat
column4: too industrious
column5: too polite—too many of the qualities we look for in coworkers and roommates and not enough of the ones we look for in artists. “I studied some math in school
column6: ” Hinton told us in a recent Rising interview. Math! Terrific. A sentence later he brings up his admiration for soft-rocker Bruce Hornsby. At 25
column7: Hinton may have already blown the youth vote.

column1: Nonfiction isn’t an album easily pegged to any scene or narrative currently circulating about electronic music. Its rhythms are rooted in hip-hop
column2: drum & bass
column3: and late-90s R&B
column4: rendered on the scale of someone making music more for home listening than club play. Even at its busiest
column5: the album feels tidy and compact
column6: like the gears of a prewar pocketwatch. (What’s interesting to me about Hinton’s syncopations—the jazzy
column7: double-time blasts of hi-hat and snare drum—is that syncopation is usually used to make a straight beat sound momentarily off-balance
column8: whereas on Nonfiction
column9: the more syncopated the tracks are
column10: the more orderly they feel.)

column1: Nearly every track here is pretty
column2: in the most conventional sense of the word. Soft pianos
column3: fake strings
column4: bass that stretches like taffy
column5: and synth blips that twinkle like itsy bitsy stars—if the sounds on Nonfiction showed up on your doorstep in the dead of night
column6: you’d probably let them in without question. On a lot of the album<i>
column7: Hinton’s approach reminds me of Aphex Twin circa Richard D. James tracks like “4” and “Girl/Boy Song”—songs that juxtapose a cute surface with a hard-hitting
column8: even threatening undercurrent. The difference is that James is a perennial misfit who always seemed to be half-joking and Hinton operates with the earnestness of a post-rock band working in miniature.

column1: Nonfiction's highlights-- ""Metal Swing
column2: ""Jamie"" and ""FM Myth""-- are built around vocal samples. House and dance music have a long tradition of making the human voice do contortions on tape that they could never do live—a possibility afforded by samplers and digital recording
column3: which enable producers to chop
column4: cut
column5: paste
column6: and loop in ways that would’ve been agonizing in the analog era. On Nonfiction
column7: Hinton allows his vocalists full phrases
column8: sometimes even sentences. Usually
column9: these vocalists are gruff-sounding English dudes who seem to have been wounded by something they aren’t ready to get too specific about. (Hinton says he mostly finds them on YouTube
column10: a site that lets us glimpse into the lives of strangers in a way that feels both intimate and yet impossibly cryptic.) They repeat their laments
column11: sometimes for minutes on end
column12: while the music grows steadily around them. The result feels like a series of time-lapse portraits of people refusing to change despite their changing environment—a nice
column13: melancholy touch on an album that tends to take extroverted music and turn it inward.

column1: Even if you listen to Nonfiction—and even if you like it—it probably won’t inspire you to call anyone up and say
column2: “[Expletive]
column3: I just got back from the library
column4: or the office
column5: or picking up [friend’s name] at the airport
column6: and I had this new Range album on at a reasonable volume the whole time
column7: and it totally increased my general sense of well-being!” What it might inspire
column8: though
column9: is a kind of passive
column10: slowly gestating admiration—the kind usually best measured in iTunes plays three or four months down the line
column11: the kind you tend to recognize several hours into a workday in front of your computer
column12: the kind that doesn’t surge like a fire but instead grows patiently
column13:
like a vine. 

"|18679.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18679-the-range-nonfiction/|8.2|Mike Powell

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/19865/homepage_large.d327a0af.jpg|Rapor EP|28560.0|Active Child|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Vagrant']|2013-10-31 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:51:14.010176|"

Pat Grossi isn’t the kind of guy who just blends in: you don’t encounter a lot of tall
column2: lanky
column3: redheaded harpists with a voice that actually earns the “choirboy” descriptor. Starting with his 2010 EP Curtis Lane
column4: the music Grossi performs as Active Child aspired to be every bit as singular
column5: situating his rangy vocals within post-dubstep clicks
column6: porcelain R&B and a ghosted production aesthetic. Yet
column7: by his 2011 debut You Are All I See
column8: Active Child became a strangely centrist affair
column9: as artists that shared many of those stylistic tics (James Blake
column10: Bon Iver
column11: collaborator How To Dress Well
column12: Jai Paul) were some of the year’s major indie figures. His new EP Rapor turns out to be every bit as momentous as You Are All I See
column13: but for the exact opposite reasons. Whereas the center had once shifted to a sound Active Child had been developing for years
column15: Grossi’s aiming squarely for an established
column16: already-crowded middle.

column1: And so
column2: you’ll get a lot of “what the kids are into these days” on Rapor. There isn’t much harp here at all—the pristine spaces of his previous work are filled with louder beats
column3: louder synths and a shift from stained glass preciousness to neon pop. Grossi’s voice remains
column4: and that’s a good thing
column5: as his falsetto is distinct amongst his peers
column6: a strangely chesty thing that recalls Philip Bailey of Earth
column7: Wind & Fire (and also
column8: “Easy Lover”). It was best utilized on “Hanging On” and “Playing House”
column9: tortured slow burners that gave a soulful edge to music that was often a little too monastic for some.

column1: Unfortunately
column2: Rapor tries to shift to more extroverted
column3: club-friendly aesthetic while still presenting Active Child as deadly serious business. And without pop’s pleasure principle
column4: Rapor often ends up sounding unintentionally silly rather than fun (much like the “Playing House” video). Up-and-comer Mikky Ekko shows up to contribute nasal half-raps on “Subtle” and what should be some airy pop piffle (“the beat goes on and on forever/and the record on repeat comes back around/girl you don’t wanna be alone dancing in the dark”) bears an unfortunate poptimist studiousness; it’s the work of people desperately trying to tell you they really mean it. As a result
column5: “Subtle” recalls the unfortunate “urban” deep cut you’d find tacked onto late 90s boy band albums. Meanwhile
column6: a guest spot from Ellie Goulding provides a tremendous profile boost to blatantly M83-styled stargazing duet “Silhouette”
column7: but neither her vaporous vocals or the hollowed-out synth toms help it achieve liftoff.

column1: The remainder of Rapor isn’t bad
column2: just disappointing in the sense that a potentially unique artist sounds all too eager to look at the indie-pop landscape
column3: say “me too!” and little else. As with You Are All I See
column4: Grossi’s songwriting is still ostensibly personal
column5: but lack any sort of defining character—typical lyrics like “Take me back to the start/before we ever fell apart”
column6: indicate Rapor could be viewed as a pocket-sized breakup album
column7: but combined with the standard-issue arrangements behind them
column8: it could really be anyone’s. Rapor should be a display of Grossi’s adaptability
column9:
but it just ends up leaving you to wonder what he actually stands for as an artist.

"|18673.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18673-active-child-rapor-ep/|5.6|Ian Cohen

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/19876/homepage_large.9141c56a.jpg|Overdue|31799.0|Circuit Des Yeux|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Ba Da Bing!']|2013-10-31 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:51:14.570511|"

Haley Fohr knows how to dirge. There’s usually some darkness in the music she makes as Circuit Des Yeux
column2: and often a lot of it. Drop your needle anywhere within her discography and even the most upbeat songs sound deadly serious. Her early records sometimes distanced that somber tone with thick distortion or hissy echo
column3: which added mystery. But over time her work has become clearer
column4: and Overdue
column5: her fourth full-length
column6: is the most direct
column7: immediate record she’s made. It’s also her best.

column1: That’s because increased clarity reveals how many ways Fohr can hit the same emotional target. There’s variety in the instrumentation: dramatic
column2: string-like synths
column3: bittersweet acoustic strums
column4: grinding electric guitars
column5: and all kinds of rhythmic foundations. There’s also variety in her voice
column6: which echoes the melancholy warble of Antony
column7: the goth-howl of Diamanda Galás
column8: and the chilly authority of Nico. But she also has a unique way of turning every phrase dark. It’s hard to imagine anyone else making a casual line like “rollin’ in my Nova 88” sound so grave.

column1: That line shows the variety of lyrical angles Fohr is willing to take
column2: trusting that a committed approach can add weight to any sentiment. She’s right: every couplet and stanza on Overdue is forceful
column3: no matter what Fohr’s singing about. Roughly half the songs are sung in second person
column4: giving them a fateful hue. “When your body leaves you/ You won’t need anything to hold onto
column5: ” she sings in “Hegira”
column6: as if she’s a god reporting the future.  The rest use first person
column7: suggesting Fohr’s a victim of the same fate she just foretold. “Who has learned to bleed my innards?/ Who has given me the deepest winters?” she sings in the slow
column8: minimal “Acarina”
column9: over music that sounds like Body/Head covering Low. Those and many of Fohr’s words dodge literal interpretation
column10: dislocated from whatever specific scenarios inspired them. But there is one couplet that seems like a clear statement of intent: “If the truth sets you free/ I’d rather be living in my dreams.”

column1: Each song on Overdue feels like a lived-in dream—not just in its hypnotic
column2: voice-in-head sound
column3: but also in the way Fohr builds atmosphere like a sonic set designer. Gradually
column4: details accumulate and an internal logic takes over. Sometimes this comes from simple increases in activity
column5: as instruments rise toward mutual climaxes. But in other spots the ascent is sneakier
column6: taking you places before you know it. Take “Bud & Gin”
column7: whose folky lilt feels repetitive
column8: but eventually—with the help of Fohr’s ambient moans—traverses a range of moods. At the end
column9: she literally rewinds the song
column10: as if she’s become so caught up in it that the only way to find her footing is to retrace her steps.

column1: Such wanderings may make Overdue sound like heavy going
column2: and certainly much of it is. But Fohr puts so much power behind her music that following her into the emotional depths can be intoxicating
column3: and even life-affirming. After all
column4: one of the best things art can do is make you feel something
column5: whatever that something may be. On Overdue
column6:
Haley Fohr is more than up to that task.

"|18684.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18684-circuit-des-yeux-overdue/|7.2|Marc Masters

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/19877/homepage_large.8d4de683.jpg|Sunset Blvd.|31803.0|Yancey Boys|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Delicious Vinyl']|2013-10-31 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:51:15.122975|"

There’s a real irony in J Dilla’s legacy as a musician. The multitudes of producers influenced by the Detroit beatmaker’s sample chopping
column2: drum-slicing ways have gone on to make some of the more progressive music out right now
column3: to the point where Donuts
column4: in its influence
column5: can be seen as a beat record analogue to the influence of The Velvet Underground & Nico.  At the same time
column6: those who have control over the Detroit producer’s actual trove of beats have burrowed further into themselves
column7: making
column8: for the most part
column9: conservative
column10: reactionary rap music.  The majority of posthumous releases featuring Dilla’s name have been stuffy at best
column11: and at worst
column12: stunted by a paralysis-inducing reverence that makes it impossible for the featured rappers to explore new territory.

column1: One of the exceptions to that rule was the album Yancey Boys from Dilla’s younger brother
column2: who goes by the name Illa J. The album worked
column3: mostly because it was powered by a primo selection of early Dilla beats
column4: but also due to Illa’s understated approach to lyrics. The key to the success of the Slum Village records that Dilla produced was T3 and Baatin’s willingness to let the beats carry the weight
column5: keeping their rhymes light and fluffy. Illa J with typical younger sibling reverence
column6: adhered to the same philosophy in 2008
column7: and does so again on his new release Sunset Blvd.
column8: this time with old Dilla associate Frank Nitt representing as another member of the Yancey Boys and a whole gang of Dilla-ites along for the ride.

column1: That the record features another bumper crop of previously unreleased Dilla beats goes a long way towards explaining its success. “Fisherman”
column2: the first song on the album
column3: is a wonderful example
column4: turning on a beautiful loop which finds Dilla operating in California soul-tinged boom-bap. The beats here are mostly in that mold
column5: warm counterpoints to the Fantastic-era Detroit beats
column6: on which Dilla is subtly breaking out of the rigid boom-bap template in ways that hint at his unique ability to maintain control while working with a vast array of dynamic sounds. (Check
column7: for instance
column8: the way that the sampled cover of “Let the Sun Shine Is” is melded into different beats on “Jeep Volume.”)

column1: Backpack rap like that featured on Sunset Blvd. is often stigmatized as rappity-rap
column2: lyricism for lyricism’s sake that is often exhausting in its density. To the contrary
column3: most of the verses featured on the record are golden-age throwbacks
column4: the raps serving as little more than additional structure through which the loops reverberate. Dilla’s beats need space: the rappers here
column5: most prominently Illa J (a much better rhymer than his brother was) are aware of that.

column1: Then too
column2: there are star turns from veterans sometimes thought to be over the hill: Talib Kweli has a beautiful feature on “Flowers”
column3: and even in self-aggrandizing mode
column4: Common delivers a verse that’s a reminder of the rapper he once was. The worst part of the record though comes from a third veteran
column5: albeit one without the resume of those first two. Frank Nitt has trouble even blending into the background
column6: so cringe-worthy are some of his rhymes and because he's an honorific Yancey Boy
column7: he gets plenty screen time here. The worst attempt at simile on the record belongs to him (“spot you like you Spotify”) but there are plenty of candidates to choose from
column8: and his instincts are still to pile on Dilla beatification which most of the other featured rappers thankfully avoid. The beats
column9: after all
column10: say everything that needs to be said.

column1: Illa J has shown a penchant for straightforward soul in the past
column2: and the slower tracks on the album sparkle. The handclap-happy “Rock My World” has the energy of early aughts B. Rich while Eric Roberson’s turn on the early cut “Lovin’ U” is an early indication of this project’s ambition in comparison to other recent Dilla projects. We get so used to hearing Dilla’s rap beats (there was a five-year time period when every rapper on the come-up would freestyle over “Lightworks”) that we sometimes take for granted the immensity of the musician we lost. Hearing how good his beats sound when turned to soul and R&B makes for a fresh reminder of Dilla’s immense talent
column3: and the ways that it could have been shaped to all kinds of genres
column4: how much he had to contribute to the wider world of music.

column1: But Sunset Blvd. refuses to let itself be colored by regret. This is the most joyous record that we’ve seen from Dilla’s disciples since the producer’s death in 2006. By avoiding the tendency to wallow in the past or to define itself in opposition to contemporary rap
column2: it joins the ranks of albums from Camp Lo and Black Milk
column3: two other former backpack acts who updated their formula successfully this year
column4:
breaking free of the cliches that had held them back and making genuinely engaging hip-hop music.

It’s hard to know where to put Miracle. The self-described “boy band” are on Planet Mu
column2: one of electronic music’s more experimental “big” labels. Steve Moore
column3: the American behind the album’s lush bed of electronics
column4: is a synth wizard known for his droning epics
column5: lush dance tracks
column6: and italo-aping band Zombi. UK singer Daniel O’Sullivan
column7: meanwhile
column8: has worked with any number of left-field rock outfits from Sunn O))) to Guapo (the band he fronts). Together
column9: they make creeping synth pop that feels like Depeche Mode steeped in the fog of the Misty Mountains—there’s nothing really experimental
column10: dance
column11: or rock about it at all. It’s moody and serious stuff
column12: evident from the outset with “Good Love”
column13: where arpeggios snake at a glacial pace as O’Sullivan bellows about the “most high
column14: all-powerful good love” with all the pomp and circumstance of a late 70s fantasy metal epic.

column1: If it wasn’t obvious from that
column2: there’s something else running underneath Mercury than the facile synth-pop revivalist label that others will lobby at it. Let’s get this out of the way: O’Sullivan has a pleasing
column3: resolutely British voice that recalls a higher-register Dave Gahan—he’s a dead ringer on “Something Is Wrong”
column4: which has an existential-dread chorus (“Something is wrong/ I don’t know what it means to be in love”) that would be a long lost Black Celebration cut. But most of the time

column6: and his arch phrasing is more goth-inflected folk than fey synth-pop posturing. There’s also a certain muscular chug to these tracks that you wouldn’t necessarily get from mid-80s Sire Records—a propulsive crawl learned from Moore’s dance records and his work in Zombi.

column1: Those synths? They make the record
column2: which is important
column3: because Mercury is all synths—no guitars or anything that sounds close to a band here. It's a beautifully-produced record
column4: with such a grasp on its machines that it doesn’t even need straight drums—the title track is a buzzing collection of cogs and whirling machinery
column5: woodpecker woodblocks
column6: and other strange percussive devices driving it forward in the place of lumpen drum machines. Moore’s unique sensibilities can jar with O’Sullivan’s pop ambitions as much as they elevate them
column7: however. On “Neverending Arc”

column9: O’Sullivans leaden melody lines slide right off Moore’s icy walls
column10: and the grand power ballad “Breathless” doesn’t have a grandiose hook to match its “Take My Breath Away” bombast.

column1: The album’s final passage offers up a glimpse at an alternate mode for the duo. Penultimate track “Wild Nights” is a windswept series of arpeggios that feels like psychedelic-era Beatles as imagined by William Orbit
column2: and the perpetual krautrock groove is carried over into 10-minute closer “Organon”. Here
column3: one of Moore’s characteristic long-form swirls is given over to eerie chanting by O’Sullivan
column4: indulging in the eerie English folk tradition that he hints at elsewhere.

column1: While it’s easy enough to imagine how wonderful an LP made up entirely of these yawning ambient tracks would be
column2: that’s not entirely fair to Moore and O’Sullivan. Mercury feels like an addition to the canon of 80s synth pop albums rather than an attempt to xerox them
column3: mainly because of its sincerity—there’s no sly winking or irony here
column4: period. That it such a record would come on Planet Mu and be produced by these two particular artists is a strange story indeed
column5:
but the music speaks for itself—anyone who fancies long lost synth-pop obscurities would probably find at least a few songs to like on Mercury.

The video for the Flaming Lips’ thundering 1999 single “Race for the Prize” appropriately features someone in the midst of a race
column2: a physical emblem of the song's overwhelmed scientists who are working around the clock to develop a cure for some fatal disease. But since the release of that video—and the game-changing album from which it sprung

column4: the Lips have been a hard band to keep up with
column5: indulging us in both the thrill of the chase and the exhaustion that inevitably results from it.

column1: Even as they’ve entered their fourth decade of existence
column2: the band has become more outrageously prolific with each passing year
column3: as the expediency of the internet age—combined with the band’s inherent resourcefulness—has allowed them to document and release their every passing whim
column4: and seemingly record with every artist they’ve ever posed with for a backstage festival selfie. The band’s unforgivably bleak 13th album
column5: The Terror

column7: and even that’s since been superseded by a just-announced
column8: imminent split-release with Tame Impala. We’re at the point now where the Lips’ proper records feel less like a cumulative elaboration of their interim activities than a respite from them.

column1: But even for a band that’s experimented with every type of release format—from simultaneously played quadruple-CD sets to USB singles encased in foodstuffs to songs that require you to book a day off work to listen to—the Peace Sword EP holds a unique place among the Lips’ sprawling discography. The Lips have sporadically released EPs before
column2: but—outside of their unrecognizably garage-grimed 1984 debut—they’ve usually taken the form of intra-band collaborations or an official single padded out with covers
column3: demos
column4: and other novelties (not to mention some canonical lost gems). But Peace Sword is something else: a holistic six-song release that
column5: at 36 minutes
column6: basically counts as the second full-length album the Flaming Lips have released in 2013.

column1: The EP originated as another one of the Lips’ one-off larks: they were asked to contribute to the soundtrack of the upcoming science-fiction epic Ender’s Game (adapted from the 1985 novel by Orson Scott Card)
column2: and while lead-off track “Peace Sword (Open Your Heart)” will appear in the film
column3: the EP is fleshed out by songs that were inspired by the movie but were rejected by its makers. Of course
column4: a film set in a future where humanity can only be saved from alien-wrought extinction by a humble hero is hardly a thematic stretch for the Flaming Lips; of the two albums the band has released this year
column5: one opens with the lyric
column6: “There’s a little spaceship/ hiding in the clouds
column7: ” and it’s not even the one that was commissioned for a sci-fi flick. But if Peace Sword carries over The Terror’s dystopian chill
column8: synth-smeared mistiness
column9: and emotional fragility
column10: it’s informed as much by another Lips experiment from earlier this spring: their full-album remount of 2002’s Yoshimi Battles the Pink Robots at South by Southwest.

column1: The two albums represent the yin and yang of the Lips’ post-millennial catalogue: both are informed by the uncertainty of the future
column2: but where The Terror translates that into anxiety and despair
column3: Yoshimi is more playful and optimistic. Peace Sword—much like Ender's Game itself—is thus a proverbial fight test
column4: the space where the Lips’ light and dark energies square off in battle
column5: sometimes within the same song. “Peace Sword (Open Your Heart)” oozes forth with such kaleidoscopic splendor
column6: you can practically feel the multi-coloured balloons bounce off your head
column7: but as Coyne repeats that deceptively optimistic parenthetical refrain
column8: the song undergoes a slow decay: the drum beat starts sputtering out
column9: the background symphonic-synth fuzz becomes blindingly overpowering
column10: and the overall mood turns from celebratory to sorrowful. However
column11: the lush
column12: decadanse ballad “Is the Black at the End Good""
column13: works the other way
column14: with Coyne’s stark
column15: self-doubting verses blossoming into a resplendent
column16: arm-swaying chorus that renders the Lips’ recent half-baked Terror bonus-cut cover of “All You Need Is Love” all the more superfluous. (And
column17: intentionally or not
column18: the song’s all-inclusive
column19: hippy-dippy sentiment—“everywhere where love is/ that’s where I will be”—feels like an especially subversive affront to Orson Scott Card’s notoriously ultra-conservative views on gay marriage.)

column1: In light of The Terror and its equally unnerving predecessor Embryonic

column13: the repetitious prog-funk creeper “Wolf Children” falls flat
column14: and the 11-minute finale “Assassin Beetle – The Dream Is Ending” tries to stitch together instrumental and lyrical motifs from throughout the EP into an ominous closing suite
column15: but its mounting lurch to the finish is too dreary to feel dramatic. “The dream is ending

column17: suggesting that
column18: in this war over control of the Flaming Lips' psyche

column20:
but the valiant battles fought along the way.

The chief talking point that emerged from Laurel Halo's excellent debut album
column3: Quarantine
column4: was Halo's decision to emphasize her vocals. It seemed a hard left turn for an artist who
column5: through a spate of EPs
column6: had practiced obfuscation
column7: both in her music and in her public persona. Halo's releases since Quarantine can be read as a reaction to that album and its reception
column8: as she has steadily retreated from that album's vocally oriented post-pop—and the transparent artistic agency that it implied—into the harsh instrumental strictures of techno. Her second album
column9: the dynamic
column10: bracing Chance of Rain
column11: continues this transition
column12: further mussing her artistic motives via industrial rhythms and corrosive synth textures.

column1: The music on Chance of Rain defies easy placement—probably on purpose. It flickers between 90s-era IDM fussiness
column2: warped hypnagogic sentimentality
column3: and actual club music meant to inspire dancing. Sometimes it stops
column4: mid-song—as on the title track—to wade through a pretty
column5: jazzy piano melody
column6: only to later return to its choppy
column7: crunching kick drum attacks. This sense of placelessness
column8: its ability to obscure its purpose and cloak its creator
column9: defines Chance of Rain. It's a Laurel Halo album in name; when it plays you don't spend much time thinking about its creator or her motives.

column1: Two pretty
column2: jazzy piano pieces bookend Chance of Rain
column3: reminding us of the oft-repeated fact that Halo is a formally trained musician. In between
column4: Chance of Rain is a near constant churn of effects and shifting rhythms
column5: frequently interrupting itself to wander in new directions. The longer tracks—""Oneiroi"" and ""Thrax"" in particular—are stop-and-start affairs whose tough beats resist momentum. There's a crankiness to Chance of Rain
column6: as noxious
column7: cloudy chords hover above even the most motive tracks (""Ainnome""
column8: ""Serendip""). Tonally
column9: Chance of Rain is peers with the hoary machine music being churned out by the L.I.E.S. label
column10: but there's an odd iridescence to Halo's work not found in other noisy
column11: underground dance music.

column1: When Chance of Rain slows down
column2: as on the perplexing ""Still/Dromos"" or ""Melt""
column3: it feels industrial
column4: chemical in its potency. There's an undiluted quality to the sounds Halo conjures
column5: and its 44 minute runtime requires some endurance. Frequently ugly
column6: Chance of Rain doesn't court affection
column7: and it's hard to nestle up to something that's continually slew-footing you. Quarantine was a difficult listen because it sounded as if Halo was right in your ear; on Chance of Rain she only appears to chop at your knees before dashing back into the shadows.

column1: Halo spoke to Wire magazine about becoming more comfortable as a producer; Chance of Rain sees her place her gnarly sounds front and center
column2: the way Quarantine did with her voice. The result is still unnerving
column3: though in a more subtle way (no one is likely to tell Halo her synthesizers are too loud
column4: or not tuneful enough). When the album finds a moment of peace—like when the title track dissolves into a simple
column5: noir-ish outro—it feels forged. Craggy and hard as hell
column6: you'll wish Chance of Rain forged a few more such moments
column7: but its consistent
column8:
nagging ability to knock you off balance is worth wrestling with.

Matt Kivel's Double Exposure is a small masterpiece of humble virtues: warm
column3: patient
column4: calm. It is beautifully
column5: pristinely recorded
column6: finely wrought; its ten songs represent some of the least insistent music you will be spellbound by all year. Kivel's close-miked acoustic guitar strums close to your ear
column7: but everything above it
column8: from Kivel's high
column9: frail falsetto to the washes of electronics that occasionally stop the action
column10: is constantly threatening to dissipate. Kivel wrote and recorded it over the last two years
column11: redirecting his creative efforts away from the band Gap Dream in favor of this sort of acoustic music—not quite shapely or distinct enough to be folk
column12: too temporally detached to be grouped near rock— that is simply music we murmur to ourselves. Daily music.

column1: Ever since I first heard Double Exposure
column2: in March
column3: it has been that for me. For awhile
column4: I was hard-pressed to articulate its appeal
column5: even to myself; it was delicate and pretty
column6: for sure
column7: but I was hearing something else in it
column8: something elusive. Now that the record has made its way onto a label
column9: Olde English Spelling Bee
column10: I think I've located what that something is: There is a modesty here
column11: of a particular
column12: almost-holy sort. It's the sort that doesn't much make a spectacle or a point of its own performance. It is simply written into the delivery
column13: in Kivel's musing
column14: unaffected vocals and in his steady
column15: artful finger-picking.

column1: Nick Drake is an obvious comparison point
column2: and a strong one. Like Drake
column3: Kivel doesn't sweat comprehension in his mumbled
column4: blurred lyrics
column5: sharp phrases of which only swim occasionally to the surface: ""You said all these boys will do is fuck/ Take away their cocks and they dry up
column6: he sings
column7: startlingly

column10: he croons on ""Tetro."" The phrase ""When I'm dead"" is one of the only phrases in ""Eleison.""

column1: There is a frightening amount of death in the record
column2: in fact. But Kivel doesn't seem or sound frightened by it himself—simply drawn toward it
column3: compelled to examine it. The lullaby of ""Rainbow Trout
column4: with its refrain of ""sweet babe
column5: don't cry
column6: turns on some ghastly imagery: ""As the body/ shook with pain/ It was thrown again and again/ Up against the fissured wall/ Covered in the bile of it's maw."" And on ""Whip
column7: he sings gently
column8: clearly
column9: ""I want to kill myself."" The effect is unsettling precisely because you're unsure how unsettled to be—the song appears to be told from the perspective of a whipped horse
column10: and the phrase is sung so lightly
column11: over an ascending finger-picked line

column13: serenity.

column1: Mark Nieto produced Double Exposure
column2: and his work is strong enough to serve as a supporting character. (Paul Oldham mixed and mastered the album). Atmosphere is a fragile strength
column3: the first quality to disappear when pressed
column4: but it blossoms in headphones

column6: the pearly piano notes

column8: the humming—insect looping guitars that swarm through ""All Will Be Well""
column9: the small bursts of static at the edges of ""Days of Heaven""—each touch registers like an event within the hallowed space that Kivel creates. The album doesn't so much grow on you as accrete
column10: like daytime shadow creeping across the room. It's been seven months since I first tried to puzzle out Double Exposure
column11: and it keeps eluding me. I don't know when I'll want to stop trying
column12:

For all the talk about Bernard Fevre's unlikely resurgence under his Black Devil Disco Club guise—the mystery behind that now-beloved 1978 Disco Club EP
column2: the no-steps-missed comeback 28 Later
column3: the all-star lovefest of Circus—one aspect of his musical background seems underplayed. Before the self-titled space-disco gem that put Black Devil on the map 35 years ago
column4: Fevre worked in the production music library trenches. Rather than a nascent Giorgio Moroder-caliber pop innovator
column5: Fevre was more of a style-hopping freelancer whose best work capitalized on streamlining pre-existing trends. Think early 70s Eurodisco progenitors like the Chakachas of “Jungle Fever” fame or Cerrone's work with Kongas
column6: then add first-generation synthesizers and a deliberate eccentricity. Not for nothing is the 1975 L'Illustration Musicale LP that remains the most renowned record under his own name titled “The Strange World of Bernard Fevre”.

column1: The catch with library music is that it's a sort of work-for-hire situation
column2: meant to be a bit modular and generic even at its best. It's a field that can be just as prone to dated imitation as it is timeless experimentation
column3: ignoring the divide between catchiness and cornballery often enough that it falls under irony-courting cringe-whimsy. That's the mode Fevre falls back on in Black Moon White Sun: the music stumbles its way through an uneven if reasonably fun back catalog
column4: gathering all Fevre's odder creative tics into eight tracks' worth of irritainment that feels geared more for post-Barbarella retro-space age camp smirking than any dancefloor worth its bodies.

column1: That's not a bad goal in itself. But there's little room for error when you're trying to evoke a Kubrick-goes-bananas satellite/supperclub vibe. Think less cosmic disco and more a mish-mash of synthesized innovations. Early 70s prog Moogs play mid 80s synthpop with 90s techno chords; rearrange the decades as needed but it's still chronologically dissonant and oddly detached. Midtempo synth-lounge grooves like “Bee Boop” or “Just 3” are diverting their first couple spins
column2: mostly for the hazy nostalgia they might wind up evoking
column3: but give them a little more time and it starts feeling like audio furniture.

column1: It's not just rigidly unfunky
column2: but willfully quirky to a point where even the most die-hard fromage enthusiast might wonder if it wouldn't hurt to be at least a little bit serious. It's grimace-worthy when Fevre dredges up those early 70s notions of Euro-tourist “ethnic” beats
column3: like the bongo-driven quasi-indigenous “Sun Dance Totem” or the goopy cod-Latin “Mexo Mambo”. If it's possible for instrumental tracks to collapse under their own milky sentiment
column4: there's a pretty grueling stretch in the middle: “Maymallow” does Pet Shop Boys dirty by extracting all the sly pathos and pop wit that made their hits great
column5: padding it with tinny synth-horns that would make Stock-Aitken-Waterman wrinkle their noses. “Star Dot Com” is the relentlessly chirpy background music for every badly-tracked VHS presentation of “Just What Is the Information Superhighway?” And aside from being saccharine as all hell
column6: “The Kid in Me” demonstrates the biggest failing of Black Moon White Sun. Fevre's voice
column7: best filtered through the Dalek-soul voicebox that made cuts like “H Friend” so alluringly creepy
column8: goes largely untreated—and he sounds like Hot Chip's Alexis Taylor if he was drunk
column9: had a frog in his throat
column10:
and pronounced all his syllables in reverse so his vocals had to be played backwards. You probably wouldn't want to watch the poorly-dubbed 1981 Buck Rogers knockoff this music would score.

The best bands to come from the “thrash revival” of the mid-to-late 00s could never really be associated with the original movement—they just happened to be active when thrash became in vogue again. Most modern thrash is sickeningly indebted to the patterns of the 80s: the familiar riffs
column2: the familiar tempos
column3: the familiar denim-and-bullet-belt ensembles
column4: even the same fucking Ed Repka album covers. “You used to do the monkey
column5: but now it's not cool” may be cool again
column6: but you want to know why Metallica
column7: “sell-outs” or “falses” they may be
column8: remain more relevant than Exodus? Metallica wanted more than every one of their contemporaries. First
column9: it was better songs
column10: then it became bigger venues
column11: then it became something we'll never know
column12: but their ambition paid off. Even if commercial success isn't a goal
column13: thrash bands that stand out now do so because of some sort of similar artistic determination. Vektor want to be weirder than Voivod
column14: Iron Age imagined themselves as living Conan posters
column15: and Power Trip simply play harder than the competition.

column1: Chicago's Oozing Wound could be one of those vaulted bands to transcend flatterers
column2: and their debut full-length Retrash is certainly more original than the Warbringers and Bonded by Bloods of the world. None of the band members come from thrash backgrounds
column3: and Thrill Jockey doesn't release conventional metal albums. Retrash has been called crossover due to its punk influence
column4: but it's also got grittiness and snottiness more thrash bands could use. The album's first three songs
column5: “Everyone I Hate Should Be Killed”
column6: “New York Bands”
column7: and “Call Your Guy” focus on the band's acerbic humor. It's fitting that a Chicago band would have a song titled “New York Bands”—Chicago's a great city
column8: certainly more manageable than New York
column9: but it's not always seen as a place to go and “make it.” Cliques are annoying in all cities
column10: but they're intolerable in New York
column11: because as Oozing Wound rightfully point out
column12: “New York bands
column13: they ain't your friends
column14: they just want your cocaine.” Despite its name
column15: “New York” could also easily be about Los Angeles bands who form themselves around fashion and the hopes of a Century Media deal
column16: rather than standing out and making halfway memorable songs. “Everyone I Hate” has all of the metal's bloodlust with a refreshing sense of candor. Many of us have thought that same thing
column17: even though we won't go as far as to declare “Morality is bad for your health.” There's no fat in the riffage either
column18: which empowers the song's message further.

column1: “Call Your Guy” deals with the perils of scoring drugs
column2: but more importantly
column3: it follows a similar song structure to “New York.” For the first half
column4: guitarist and vocalist Zach Weil will yell his contempt over the band and then he shuts up and lets his riffs do the talking. Most bands would want to repeat verses over those second halves
column5: but Oozing Wound already got their point across
column6: so they proceed to lash out with every riff too punk for Megadeth and too metal for D.R.I. From “Welcome to the Spaceship
column7: Motherfuckers” until closer “Spirit Manimal”
column8: Oozing Wound show how weird they can get
column9: lyrically. “Spaceship” in particular details the cosmic voyage of a baby Jesus
column10: sent into the howling void and never to be heard from again. It's the 2013 version of Florida death metal oddballs Nocturnus' “Destroying the Manger”
column11: a tale of going back into time and killing the newborn Christ. With few exceptions
column12: most notably the aforementioned Vektor
column13: you won't see many groups going out on a limb quite like this. Then again
column14: most thrash bands don't have members who've played in various bands in punk houses on the South Side
column15: where experimentation runs free and pretensions get smashed. While it's no Manifest Decimation
column16: Retrash is still one of the year's most notable mutations of thrash
column17:
and Oozing Wound show a lot of promise to get even weirder.

About 17 and a half minutes into her debut album
column4: Sky Ferreira prods you to consider how strange it is that you’re listening to it at all. “I just want you to realize I blame myself

column1: It’s also possible she’s addressing the horde of fashion-world supporters who helped her become a raccoon-eyed ingenue better known for looking cool on Terry Richardson’s Tumblr and modeling Hedi Slimane’s Saint Laurent pieces than making music. More plausible still

column1: So it’s both a relief and a bit of a shock that Night Time

column5: singer-songwritery folk
column6: electro-pop. Night Time
column7: My Time finds Ferreira navigating her tastes more gracefully
column8: bridging the gaps between 80s pop sparkle and full-bodied 90s grunge in a streamlined way. Her primary collaborator this time is producer Ariel Rechtshaid (Solange
column9: Haim
column10: Charli XCX
column11: Vampire Weekend
column12: Usher)
column13: a guy known for adding both big-league pop polish to smaller acts and fine-tuning to bigger ones.

column1: Night Time
column2: My Time resists the self-serious instinct to position Ferreira as an artist artist— which might have been an especially powerful temptation considering she's a young woman in the music industry who’s spoken about coming into her own sense of agency. She examines emotional neglect (“Nobody Asked Me (If I Was Okay)”) and self-loathing

column4: just spending/ A giant comedy with museums and shopping with Kristine

column6: a giddily odd track with ska undertones. She’s does her glummest Chan Marshall impersonation (“Night Time
column7: My Time”)
column8: but she also refers to the men in her life as simply boys and isn’t afraid to address them in a purposefully grade-school tone: “Boys
column9: they’re a dime a dozen
column10: ” she mutters. “Boys
column11: they just make me mad.” <i>Night Time

column1: All of which was made possible by the unlikely power of “Everything Is Embarrassing”

column3: an uptempo beast that sparkles with the promise of a song destined to become some kind of hit. What’s especially remarkable is that the song achieves the impact of “Everything Is Embarrassing” without its seductive too-cool vacancy—Ferreira now sounds like she has her head held up high instead of glancing down at the floor

column6:
blissfully free of anyone else to blame.

” turns out he’s still kinda sweet and mushy on the inside.

Somewhere unstuck in time is Son Lux
column2: born Ryan Lott
column3: still trying to navigate his way through relics of the past and curios of the future. At 34
column4: he’s a consummate dilettante
column5: moving seamlessly from
column6: say
column7: inventing instrumental patches used in the score of the time-traveling sci-fi movie Looper to producing beats for Anticon rapper Beans. That’s the heady hip hop label that put out his first official pop album
column8: At War With Walls & Mazes
column9: a collage of organic and electronic samples matted together under Lott’s completely breakable voice. It took Lott almost four years to compile his debut
column10: a process that came together while he was composing music for TV ads
column11: all in the spirit of accidental curiosity. And four years is an eternity compared to his follow-up
column12: the far more dense electro-chamber pop album <i>We Are Rising
column13: which he wrote over just 28 days in 2011 at the behest of NPR.

column1: In effect
column2: Lanterns is the first Son Lux album made with an organic timeline and intention. It also happens to be a record of experimental music that strives to be something beyond just an experiment. Can flute trills actually live with an instrument built from Pro Tools? Can an arrhythmic baritone saxophone actually coexist with an 808 bass thump? For Son Lux
column3: these aren't hypotheticals or theories scribbled into a notebook
column4: these are the sounds of his native tongue and he wants to blend them all into a new language. Lanterns isn't piecemeal beats or hastily assembled clutter
column5: rather it begs to be heard as the lingua franca of the past and the future
column6: something spoken on a pseudo-spiritual plane that connects the analog and digital realms. And sometimes it totally gets close.

column1: It's best to take in the wide-angle spirit of Lanterns
column2: because Son Lux’s more than complex arrangements are always the highlight over his less than complex lyricism. When all his synapses are firing
column3: he's conjuring something like ""Lost It To Trying""
column4: the maximalist hybrid chamber pop masterpiece at the front of the album. The song tethers itself to a jittery flute/saxophone riff
column5: first found at the end of every few measures
column6: but midway through it starts to overtake the whole song. By the end
column7: there are hundreds of jittery flute/saxophone riffs spinning beneath
column8: blurring together into a whole society of sound while a few choir voices and a theremin sample float far above. If ever there can exist sound that is singularly Son Lux
column9: this is the type of all-in songwriting to get there.

column1: The other way to this sweet spot is minimalism
column2: heard on Lanterns’ other peerless track
column3: “Easy”. If “Lost It To Trying” was the sound of two whole worlds speaking at the same time
column4: “Easy” is just a few delegates from each. The timbre of Lott’s frail voice has a default setting of I'm Definitely Crying Right Now
column5: so a few digital effects layered on puts it to better use as another texture. He warbles
column6: “Pull out your heart to make the being alone easy” and it just slithers inside you undetected like the rest of the song. These two contrasting moments make up the lifeforce of the album
column7: and most of the remaining seven tracks are too often just the notes the staff: brilliant ideas that lose their brilliance when they come off the page.

column1: Compare Lanterns to one of it's more well known contemporaries
column2: Sufjan Stevens’ Age Of Adz. That's an album tuned to psychosis and schizophrenia
column3: surreal dreams and outsider art. Its future/past dichotomy lives way out on the fringe and it drags you out there. Lanterns doesn’t have much in the way of surreality or gravity; instead it uses pat spirituality and repetitive hymnic platitudes as a cructh. It’s a pop album that doesn’t trust the simplicity of pop’s tenets. “No Crimes”
column4: featuring a vocal turn by Peter Silberman of the Antlers
column5: fixates upon a similar sprinting
column6: orchestral framework as “Lost It”
column7: only it’s all climax with no plot to support it. “Pyre”
column8: like “Easy”
column9: looks for success in sparsity
column10: but more heaves its dead weight around than vibrates in an ethereal plane.

column1: It feels like Son Lux resents this world. Lott writes about leaving the ""wasting world behind"" to be transported
column2: or more likely resurrected
column3: in ""alternate worlds"" and when you can practically picture him winged
column4: robed
column5: and wearing a halo—He sings on the final track
column6: ""I'll keep my lanterns lit."" He's like a painter who doesn't always trust that what he has on the canvas is complete. He tweaks his muted beats
column7: or adds players from indie orchestra ringers yMusic—who appear throughout
column8: along with background vocals from<span> Darren King (Mutemath)
column9: Ieva Berberian (Gem Club) and Shara Worden (My Brightest Diamond). All the many collaborators are always ready with a fleck of flute or a spot of violin or another layer of angelic choir to obfuscate something simple. Conversely
column10: there's not enough danger or adventure when Lott brings out his love of Stravinsky or rap or electo-pop or maybe some weird amalgum of all three. It is hard to parse all that's disparate here
column11: and in searching for its most personal form
column12:
Son Lux unwittingly dipped into the uncanny valley of digital music trying to become human—something a little too perfect to believe.

Upset frontwoman Ali Koehler has wandered through a fair share of the nine lives that often accompany the personnel-shuffling
column2: lo-fi garage-pop world in which she's developed her reputation. Most recently she was the drummer for Best Coast
column3: until a messy split (one on which she and frontwoman Bethany Cosentino publicly disagreed); before that
column4: she cut her teeth as Frankie Rose's successor on drums in the ranks of the Vivian Girls. The rest of the band has likewise been places: lead guitarist Jenn Prince is a Vivian Girls contemporary
column5: too
column6: one who plays guitar occasionally in ""Kickball"" Katy Goodman's side project La Sera; and drummer Patty Schemel—well
column7: the former Hole drummer needs little introduction.

column1: So it's noteworthy that Upset
column2: on their first full-length
column3: with Koehler at the helm of her own ship
column4: should rewind the clock. From its opening lines to its resolved close
column5: She's Gone is a whirlwind of instantly likeable do-overs: uncomplicated
column6: sticky-catchy pop punk songs about small-picture woes that place the trio squarely back into sprightly
column7: if dissatisfied
column8: teenaged bodies. With songs like opener ""Back to School"" and the simple-progressioned ""About Me""

column10: intent upon rewriting that era's commercial pop-punk history with some decidedly more DIY and feminist ethics. ""Queen Frosteen""
column11: a simple song about adolescent female rivalry (""Queen Frosteen
column12: my enemy/ She's everything
column13: I'm nobody"") is ""If You C Jordan"" for the Rookie crowd; ""Never Wanna"" is a speedbagging lament about shy crushes that's equipped to handle New Found Glory crowds. The record's 36 minutes are the sugary product one would expect from a new Vivian Girl-meets-Hole experiment
column14: with a spunky roughness around the edges that endears them—perhaps intentionally—to both a young crowd and one that could've used a record like this when they were the young crowd.

column1: The sound of three well-vetted female musicians tearing through topics like rivals and drinking and following your dreams and kicking bad habits would
column2: if they were coming from the band's male analogs
column3: easily come off as manchild-y; at times these qualities do poke through Upset's scratchy tapestry. (Koehler and Prince are
column4: after all
column5: in their mid-20s; Schemel
column6: whose powerful contributions to Upset originated in a Twitter-facilitated friendship with Koehler
column7: is 46.) The set can feel a bit skeletal in its offerings
column8: like a demo that got pushed through too quickly
column9: and like the sugar rush of any pop punk
column10: sometimes their dedication to the aesthetic loses its flavor—""Don't Lose Your Dinosaur"" is cute but waxes a bit saccharine in a Reading Rainbow
column11: follow-your-dreams kind of way (""If it means that much to you/ Don't give up what you're meant to do
column12: ""Don't lose your dinosaur/ 'Cause there's always more where that came from"")—but the immediacy of the subject matter seems more revisionist than immature.

column1: All said
column2: She's Gone is delightfully restless teenaged guitar-pop made by grown
column3: well-traveled women
column4: the contrast of which necessarily adds a sheen of introspection over the whole affair. Its depth impresses itself in spots like the deepened instrumental break on ""Phone Calls""
column5: the album's most fleshed-out track

column9: and that Don Giovanni Records would happily add it to their close-knit
column10: youthful artillery of conscious punk.) The potential those moments bring is palpable
column11: and that low-key maturity
column12: the one that keeps She's Gone from being another delicious-yet-slapdash addition to an already replete base of teen angst
column13:
builds a platform from which the band will eventually and easily catch up with their adult selves.

Gnaw
column2: from New York
column3: are a five-piece band. But the noise metallurgists churn around one clear and inarguable point of darkness—vocal torturer Alan Dubin. Horrible Chamber
column4: the band’s much-improved second album
column5: starts without him. An out-of-tune piano plinks a diatonic melody ahead of and then in sync with a concussive electronic thud. It’s a chilly sound
column6: sure
column7: but it’s like waiting in line for a haunted house
column8: where the anticipation of what’s about to come offers the true scare. When Dubin’s pitchy scream
column9: stuck somewhere between a lupine howl and a serpentine hiss
column10: cuts in after the 40-second prelude
column11: you’re finally pushed through the front door. “Humming
column12: humming
column13: outside
column14: outside
column15: humming
column16: ” Dubin speak-screams slowly
column17: splitting every word of his harangue with rests flooded by static and a sidecar of anxiety. “You left your window open
column18: nice lady.” The next five minutes are purely repetitious
column19: Dubin redelivering his lines in broken fragments and slipping briefly into talk of knife play. The band behind him controls the shock that surrounds the sound
column20: like night watchmen looking out for the perpetrator and not the victim. It’s a point-of-view horror movie.

column1: Dubin has done this before
column2: of course. In the 90s
column3: he was the singer of O.L.D.
column4: a collaboration with James Plotkin that specialized in weirdo
column5: post-Patton industrial metal. And during the last decade
column6: he infamously offered the curdled tone at the center of Khanate
column7: the leaner and more terrorizing doom sideshow to member Stephen O’Malley’s drones in Sunn O))). But Gnaw released its 2009 debut
column8: the nine-song fisticuffs This Face
column9: a month after Khanate released its posthumous finale. The implication was clear: Gnaw was custom-built to harbor Dubin’s demented invective
column10: to make his screams the bloody
column11: bloodying star. By mixing jagged digital shards
column12: relentless power electronics
column13: piercing guitar amplifiers
column14: and mid-tempo metal drums
column15: Gnaw created a violent
column16: volatile place for Dubin to work.

column1: But This Face tried to do a bit too much at once
column2: as though the band were overenthusiastic about its savage charge. The meld of heavy metal electrics and harsh noise electronics were sometimes nebulous
column3: mostly causing the songs to feel more slight than scary. Horrible Chamber is more focused and deliberate
column4: and the net effect is much more threatening. Dubin limns scenes of murder and decay (in both cases
column5: his own and that of others)
column6: and the band not only paints the text with music to match but stands back far enough to let him work. During that gambit about the open window
column7: the manipulated piano eventually starts to sound like wind chimes plinking together calmly and creepily while madness happens inside. Across its 10 minutes
column8: “Widowkeeper” morphs slowly from a catacomb drone
column9: where Dubin death-whispers about cold hands and rotting bodies above combative electronics
column10: into a full-on doom torment
column11: where the singer drags his beleaguered voice over broken guitar waveforms like a bag of bones. It’s a brilliant move that allows suspicion to become a visceral
column12: terrifying reality. “Of Embers” is a tale of chest-beating
column13: mad-eyed domination. “I bring the mist
column14: ” Dubin bellows at one point. “We’ll take this city
column15: burn their beds
column16: ” he promises. The band pairs the ultimatums with what’s ultimately its most punishing metal—a grueling crawl across peak-and-valley drums and through hyper-distorted guitars. In the past
column17: Gnaw might’ve crowded the action with tape hiss or effected malfeasance. But here
column18: the squelchy din simply supports the roar rather than hamstring it. It’s more than a move of economy; Gnaw have gotten better at serving as Dubin’s vehicle of choice
column19: at conveying the danger he means to share.

column1: Horrible Chamber arrived in mid-October
column2: just as plastic ghouls began to populate small-town storefronts and black-cat cutouts arrived in little front yards. Those fake boogeymen remind us annually of the horror of haunting and the tingle of danger. Gnaw get beyond all that
column3: pushing their tirades and tales to the point where actual destruction seems just beyond the door. So much of that rests with Dubin
column4: just as it has with every band he’s called his own. But this time
column5: much of it rests with the band itself
column6: too
column7: which approaches Dubin’s rampages with newfound reserve and purpose. Gnaw might still lack the dramatic thrall and endless volume of Khanate
column8:
but they’ve begun to build themselves stepwise around a masterful instrument and centerpiece that no one else has.

It's likely that the first time you heard the Arcade Fire's monstrously anticipated fourth album Reflektor
column2: you were—to borrow a phrase that Win Butler spits out like a bite of bad food during the record's disco-noir title track—""staring at a screen."" This past Thursday
column3: the band posted to Youtube an 85-minute video which cued up the entirety of the double-album to visuals from Marcel Camus' kaleidoscopic 1959 film Black Orpheus. If something that happens on the internet can be considered An Event
column4: then this certainly was one; in the same moment I saw the band's official tweet announcing it
column5: two people simultaneously instant-messaged me the link. It was late afternoon on the East Coast
column6: lunchtime on the West
column7: and in that moment I did exactly what thousands of other people in those and all other time zones did: Stopped what I was doing
column8: closed some extraneous tabs and programs
column9: and listened. The auto-updating comments became a chronicle of knee-jerk first impressions: fervent gushing (""The bassline on 'Joan of Arc' is fucking epic"")
column10: groan-worthy puns (""I can't even reflect how excited this makes me!"")
column11: and egregious misspellings (""I don't understand what all the fuzz is about""). This scene would have seemed bizarre—and likely a little sad— to us decades ago
column12: and it's frightening to imagine how quaint it will seem in the future. But this is how a lot of people at this moment in time—the one in which Reflektor was made
column13: and the one it distrustfully interrogates—discover new music: Alone; together.

column1: All four of the Montreal-based band's albums have been about the tension between those two words
column2: taking up subjects like suburban isolation and the false community of religiosity
column3: but Reflektor is larger
column4: at least in scope
column5: than anything Arcade Fire have done before. Of course
column6: the stakes have been raised considerably since we've last heard from them: Their previous album

""Do you like rock'n'roll music?"" Butler asks in a mock-Elvis shudder at the beginning of glam-rock earthquake ""Normal Person"". ""Cuz I don't know if I do…"" The only way to make a Big Rock Record in 2013 is to make one that is skeptical of what it means to be a Big Rock Record in 2013.

Reflektor is at once nostalgic for—its sense of sprawl feels like a throwback to the heyday of AOR—and iconoclastic about the past. It sounds like it has ingested a bunch of the great art-rock records you're ""supposed"" to learn to appreciate in your formative listening years—Low

column2: but never in a way that suffocates you with the fumes of its polish. It's limber and loose

column1: Goofy asides

column14: calamitously
column15:
to turn around.

There's always been a physicality about the Arcade Fire's sound—we're talking
column16: after all

and remarkably succeeds.

If the music of Autechre has any kind of easy entry point
column2: it's through the series of EPs they've released over the years. Often the duo of Rob Brown and Sean Booth have used the format to extend on the knotty ideas of whatever their latest LP happened to be at the time
column3: although the results are not always concise. The runtime for the download-only EP Quaristice.Quadrange.ep.ae is around the 150-minute mark. On 1994's Anti EP  they even took a political stance
column4: using their music to protest the Criminal Justice and Public Order Act
column5: which was passed in the U.K. as a measure to curb the ""repetitive beats"" of illegal raves. Autechre's response was to program a series of non-repetitive beats across the track ""Flutter"".

column1: The music on their EPs isn't always typical of their career
column2: but it does highlight how the format has afforded Brown and Booth room to edge away from the dense constructs that consume their time elsewhere. The sheer amount of music on this year's Exai can seem daunting at first
column3: even for Autechre fans who are reasonably comfortable with every turn they've taken. Long albums are rarely an instant thrill
column4: but for this duo even single tracks can take a vast amount of time to unravel. It's one of the most beautiful aspects of Autechre
column5: whose music still sounds like it's being beamed back to us from some impossibly brutal future
column6: but a future that's actively working against the short-attention-span present.

column1: L-event isn’t a world away from the Exai material. It's not passive listening. Autechre work operates at a high level of engagement
column2: requiring a commitment from the listener that's as great as the detail poured into the music. That holds true across their output
column3: and only seems to increase with each passing record. Here
column4: all the edges are a little sharper
column5: although the level of decay has decreased since the collapsed-world framework they set up for 2008's Quaristice. The standout ""Newbound"" from this EP links to the same kind of duality felt in the excellent Exai cut ""Bladelores""
column6: where hope and futility battle against one another. It's in that kind of suggestion that the best Autechre material works
column7: where the haywire circuitry gradually unravels with a strange kind of purpose.

column1: Not all of L-event is quite so rewarding. ""Osla for n"" comes closest to payoff
column2: initially resembling an asthmatic computer descending into delirium before the ideas tail off before the end. If Exai needed editing it was in the individual track lengths as opposed to the overall work. ""Osla for n"" follows the pattern set by a track like ""veKoS"" from that album
column3: where the focus begins to slip by the middle and then drifts into aimless contemplation. At least on ""tac Lacora"" they demonstrate how well they can still transform their overriding preoccupation with digital interference into sound
column4: although there is a creeping sense that Brown and Booth are looping back on themselves
column5: returning to ground they've already covered in abundance. Still
column6: they remain lone operators out here
column7: liquefying the internet one website at a time
column8:
continually enamored with the breaking point of technology.

It's been five years since the outside world has heard much from the enigmatic Finnish group Paavoharju. Since the release of their second album
column3: 2008’s Laulu Laakson Kukista
column4: Paavoharju have apparently been taking the concept of “woodshedding” to a logical extreme. Their latest album Joko sinä tulet tänne alas tai minä nousen sinne was conceived and recorded in a variety of abandoned buildings
column5: including in a self-built sauna deep in the Tattarisuo swamp that might be reasonably described as a literal shed in the woods. The resulting album is every bit as atmospheric and inscrutable as that process might suggest.

column1: As with their previous work
column2: Paavoharju’s music on Joko is a mass of internal contradictions and counter-intuitive decisions. Though the group is still typically described in the press as a collective
column3: the bulk of the music is composed and assembled in solitude by Lauri Ainala. The exact process is likely known only to Ainala himself
column4: but most of the music here is a dense weave of submerged tape loops
column5: crackly field recordings
column6: and disembodied snippets of voice and shadowy instruments. The ground shifts continually beneath the listener’s feet as the various sound elements emerge and are allowed to decay and dissolve into one another. The sense of dissolution is broken by waves of casual synchronicity
column7: leaving an impression similar to that of tuning your dashboard AM radio to a crowded spot on the dial where traces of multiple distant broadcasts intersect to create spontaneous new compositions.

column1: The biggest change this time is that here one of those distant AM stations is broadcasting an alien strain of hip-hop. Finnish rapper Paperi T
column2: of the Helsinki group Ruger Hauer
column3: makes several appearances throughout the album. His rap and/or spoken word contributions are purposefully de-contextualized
column4: removed entirely from any urban origin and forcibly transplanted into Paavoharju’s disorienting landscapes. It adds an interesting wrinkle to the group’s formula
column5: although I’d be hard-pressed to declare it an actual improvement. At the very least
column6: Paperi T’s presence ensures that this is Paavoharju’s most lyrically-dense music to date
column7: something that is an obvious obstacle for listeners who speak no Finnish. In this environment
column8: his vocals can’t help but take on something of a theatrical appearance
column9: calling to mind something like a Finnish version of Mike Patton and somewhat diminishing the album’s general out-of-time quality.

column1: Joko sinä tulet tänne alas tai minä nousen sinne translates roughly to “Either you come down here
column2: or I will ascend there.” According to a recent interview
column3: Paavoharju borrowed that title from a quote by Tampa-based evangelical minister Rodney Howard-Browne. As with their use of hip-hop
column4: Paavoharju’s re-contextualization of this quote indicates their canny ability to blend their seemingly insular musical vision with a global array of influences. Or perhaps it might be more precise to say a universal array of influences—throughout these pieces there exist layers of wordless vocal samples that are not readily traceable to any one cultural source
column5: some of them so disquieting it can feel almost like listening to EVPs or other paranormal field recordings.

column1: At their best
column2: as on such tracks as “Kolmas Voima” (“Third Force”) or “Valkeat Majat” (“White Tents”)
column3: Paavoharju are able to conduct tricks of memory similar to those triggered by the Caretaker or the artists on the Ghost Box roster. Obscure musical elements
column4: spectral voices
column5: and stray bits of traditional Finnish song and folklore are combined to create works that can seem at once deeply alien and yet tantalizingly familiar. In the end the album's most intriguing paradox is the way Paavoharju are able to juxtapose so many noises and ideas against one another that it reaches a point where these collisions cease to be jarring at all
column6:
creating instead an immersive environment ready to be explored again and again.

column2: but German metallers Atlantean Kodex have returned

column1: For example
column2: the opening riff on instrumental “Trumpets of Doggerland” gallops straight out of Swedish one-man band Bathory's 1990 classic Hammerheart

Shades of the Viking metal that characterized Bathory’s mid-to-late period color much of The White Goddess (check out “Enthroned in Clouds and Fire” for the best Twilight of the Gods riff that never was). There are few other bands save for the Swedish trio Ereb Altor who pay such excellent tribute to Quorthon’s melancholic melodies

column4: a stately ode like the aforementioned “Enthroned in Clouds and Fire” segues into the soul-stirring album closer “White Goddess Unveiled” and a gentle piano outro. The soaring centerpiece “Heresiarch” is maybe the best representation of Atlantean Kodex in a nutshell (well
column5: 11 minutes) and tells a particularly dark tale.

column1: There's a beautiful richness to the album

column7: down the onyx steps he strides/ Roaming alone in black aether

column6: though it’s clear he takes influences from both: His strong

column9: pomp
column10: and prowess.

column1: The Churchill quotes sprinkled throughout reinforce the grandiosity of it all. “If Europe were once united in the sharing of its common inheritance

column3: to the prosperity and the glory which its three or four million people would enjoy
column4: ” is how he put it at the opening of his 1946 speech in Zurich
column5: and so he says once more as “Twelve Stars and an Azure Gown” begins its slow
column6: solemn descent. The song itself reflects the band’s greater focus on a heavier
column7: more doom-oriented sound
column8: one that suits the weight of the material as much as the airy production that allows it room to breathe. This latest album isn't a great departure from its predecessor
column9: but Atlantean Kodex have grown and matured. There’s no telling how much they'll continue to improve and perfect
column10: but given the heights they’ve reached with The White Goddess
column11:
the sky’s the limit.

column5: Austin and Boston. Many of these songs take place in mundane
column6: unglamorous locales—city trains
column7: mining towns
column8: cornfields
column9: motel rooms. And in Lee's point of view
column10: you need to discover a little space within those places that you can call your own and then invite some people to share it with. Yeah
column11: it does skew kinda hippie

column13: which always sounds populated in a way that stresses its central themes of getting your own shit together so you’re better prepared to care for someone else.

column3: think of it this way: when Sufjan
column4: Animal Collective and freak-folk came about

column6: an escalating
column7: vaguely defined war and a general sense that the country was being bullied into submission from the inside. This sort of music would inevitably be criticized for being apolitical and wimpy
column8: but having seen where all this aggression got us
column9: how could Sung Tongs or Cripple Crow not seem like the solution?

column1: Love’s Crushing Diamond works in a similar way and opens itself up to some of the same criticisms

column6: ” Lee sings “There’s always love/when you think there’s none to give”

strained or torn.” I can’t think of a statement that sounds more necessary.

0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/19857/homepage_large.8e0ea924.jpg|Wenu Wenu|27844.0|Omar Souleyman|['Global']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Ribbon Music']|2013-10-25 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:51:26.581477|"

It seems wrong to refer to a musician with a 20-year long career and a catalog of recordings that allegedly runs into the mid-triple-digits as having a “debut” anything. But Omar Souleyman’s Wenu Wenu is in fact technically his first proper recording
column2: having been cut in a studio in Greenpoint
column3: Brooklyn rather than on site at one of the thousands of weddings he’s performed over the past two decades around his home in northern Syria
column4: where his reputation as a performer par excellence once drove an entire economy of bootleg cassette recordings.

column1: Souleyman’s milieu is dabke
column2: a style of folk dance music found at social gatherings across large swaths of the Middle East
column3: built around intricately filigreed instrumental leads
column4: <span>exhortative singing
column5: and pounding
column6: trance-inducing rhythms. It’s an old style
column7: but in recent years it’s had a creative renaissance as dabke artists
column8: realizing that the form shares structural similarities with Western electronic dance music
column9: began incorporating synthesizers and four-on-the-floor drum machines into their compositions.

column1: While many of them have used the possibilities that electronic instruments offer to build epically rococo arrangements
column2: Souleyman’s take on dabke is almost brutalist in its simplicity. Live
column3: and on the five LPs of material he’s released through the American ethnographic music label Sublime Frequencies
column4: the music is performed by Souleyman and his accompanists Ali Shaker (electric saz) and Rizan Sa'id. Sa'id plays dense bursts of melody on a synthesizer emulating traditional reed sounds over a relentless beat
column5: and with Souleyman’s inimitable quavering bark laid over them
column6: the entire mix is overdriven to a point you more commonly encounter with punk bands.

column1: This combination of vivid minimalism and in-the-red performance is as essential to his popularity with Western avant garde audiences as his striking uniform of white thawb
column2: red keffiyeh
column3: and aviator shades
column4: which adds a retro ABSCAM visual flair and produces an interesting aesthetic frisson when combined with the music’s techno-futuristic glare. Kieran Hebden
column5: who produced Wenu Wenu
column6: made the wise decision not to try and improve on a sound that doesn’t need fixing.

column1: Wenu Wenu succeeds at capturing the hypnotic energy of Souleyman’s incredible live performances
column2: but backs off the overdriven sonics to give the music newfound room to breathe. In the process we can finally appreciate some of the nuances in Sa’id’s playing
column3: like the funky inflections in his basslines and the finger rolls sequenced into his drum patterns. Hearing the keyboards more clearly also gives the sound more stylistic flexibility. Synthy horn stabs in the earwormy titular opening track evoke 80s and 90s club pop
column4: while the ersatz strings and fretless bass in the midtempo “Khattaba” add a not unwelcome layer of glossy schmaltz to the mix.

column1: While some of those choices in synth patches were undoubtedly Hebden’s
column2: they’re never obvious. There are touches here and there—the subtle modulated delay on a synthesizer lead
column3: the odd filter sweep—where his participation comes through
column4: but it never sounds like he’s trying to make Wenu Wenu a Four Tet album
column5: or make Souleyman fit the parameters of Western dance music or
column6: god forbid
column7: sound fashionable.

column1: Still
column2: the music here can compete against any kind of dance music being made right now
column3: and succeed. Dabke lives or dies by its ability to make people move
column4: and although Souleyman is no-frills
column5: and borderline gruff compared to other dabke performers
column6: there’s something in his stentorian singing that’s irresistible. It’s still best experienced live
column7: but after 20 years of mostly bootleg-quality tapes
column8:
there’s finally a recording worthy of calling the next best thing.
