The 1990s are back
column2: through reunions of some of its major (and minor) bands to new acts who sound like those bands (Speedy Ortiz
column3: Swearin'
column4: Milk Music
column5: Perfect Pussy). If you were around then
column6: it's interesting watching what has and hasn't made it in the 2013 translation. There are bands from the 90s people still think about
column7: and that have been canonized
column8: but there were also groups who made great music and then disappeared. I'm thinking of acts that felt big at the time
column9: but remain footnotes a decade and change later—the Grifters
column10: Some Velvet Sidewalk
column11: Kicking Giant
column12: Steel Pole Bath Tub
column13: etc. One of the biggest bands in this regard is Unwound. You can hear their approach in any number of noisy post-punk and punk acts with deep record collections
column14: but more often than not
column15: folks don't know where those sounds came from.

column1: Along with noisy bands like Karp and Lync that were associated with Calvin Johnson and that Olympia ""love rock"" scene
column2: Unwound would have made more sense on Dischord if they weren't from the Pacific Northwest. And their music did feel very much situated in that pine-scented space. They were a part of the Pacific Northwest that was happening around the time of Nirvana and sometimes overlapped with it
column3: but one that ultimately went in a very different direction.

column1: The Tumwater
column2: Wash.
column3: trio were powerful
column4: and at the time
column5: they seemed towering—only later did you realize they were about as ""huge"" as an underground punk group on a then small
column6: nascent indie label could get before people used the internet. (Unwound released the first proper
column7: non-compilation full-length on Kill Rock Stars—1993's Fake Train—which is not something that registered at the time
column8: because you had no idea what KRS would become.) ""Huge"" also meant something different then because you never imagined the bands you listened to would graduate to anything beyond small all-ages shows
column9: and they rarely did. These were the sorts of the bands who played their local independent record stores
column10: basements
column11: and DIY spots
column12: but could also go on tours and sell out venues in other cities. In some circles Unwound were regarded as heroes
column13: but a dozen years after their breakup
column14: people still seem to know them more by name than their music.

column1: That could change: Numero Group
column2: who handled the similarly necessary Codeine reissues last year
column3: are in the midst of an epic undertaking
column4: reissuing all of Unwound's albums in box sets on limited vinyl (and as digital downloads) with a ton of rarities. They just put out the first installment
column5: Kid Is Gone
column6: covering the period leading up to Fake Train. The second pairs Fake Train with 1994's New Plastic Ideas. (Vol. 3 is reportedly 1995's The Future of What? and 1996 fan favorite Repetition; the series closes with Vol. 4
column7: 1998's somewhat spotty Challenge for a Civilized Society and 2001's post-punk/noise-rock classic Leaves Turn Inside You).

column1: Unwound's recorded output has a chaotic beauty and energy to it; live
column2: they always felt like they were on the verge of falling apart
column3: and sometimes they did: I remember driving to see them in Philadelphia at one point and they had to stop the show after Sara Lund broke her bass drum pedal. I have a memory of her trying to tape it back together and finally calling it a day
column4: and it was a fitting image: their music as being held together with duct tape. As someone who loves Unwound's earliest stuff
column5: and that gnarled live presence
column6: this first volume is especially interesting.

column1: Spread across three LPs
column2: Kid Is Gone gathers the rougher
column3: noisier
column4: rawer
column5: punkier Unwound
column6: the period where they changed their name from Giant Henry to Supertanker to Cygnus X-1 and started finding their way. (Unwound always remained all of the above
column7: but they refined elements and added others that aren't here yet.) This is the material with original drummer Brandt Sandeno
column8: who quit in 1992 and was replaced in July of that year by Sara Lund
column9: who was a friend of Kill Rock Stars founder Slim Moon and the band had met when she took a photo of them for the back cover of the 1991 Caterpillar 7"". The band I knew best was the one with her in it
column10: but it's great hearing vocalist/guitarist Justin Trosper
column11: bassist Vern Rumsey (who ran the great Punk in My Vitamins label)
column12: and Sandeno figuring things out.

column1: On the first record
column2: Caterpillar
column3: you get the seven songs from their 1991 cassette Bionic
column4: the excellent aforementioned three-song Caterpillar 7"" released by Kill Rock Stars
column5: and the track from the seminal 1991 Kill Rock Stars compilation (the Calvin Johnson-recorded ""You Speak Jealousy"")
column6: which is where you really start to hear a new
column7: more unique
column8: disengaged vocal approach
column9: even if Johnson put Trosper too far upfront in the mix. (That voice
column10: usually more buried
column11: is also there on ""Caterpillar""
column12: and you get a sense of what'll happen next
column13: sonically
column14: with the transistor squelches and drifts of the instrumental ""Crab Nebula"".)

column1: The second disc
column2: Unwound
column3: features the self-titled album
column4: which was recorded in 1992 and not released until 1995
column5: along with the 1993 self-titled Gravity 7"" and the previously unreleased momentum-building instrumentals ""I'd Die to Know You"" and ""Sugarfit""
column6: which were both recorded with Steve Fisk in 1992. Both are cool
column7: though not essential. On this record
column8: the math-y
column9: brainy post-punk Unwound starts to emerge more clearly with songs like the jittery
column10: grooving ""Rising Blood""
column11: the moody
column12: downcast
column13: throat-sick ""Fingertips""
column14: and via the extended Sonic Youth guitar squalls of ""You Bite My Tongue"". You also get their Fugazi side on ""Warmth"" and their more rabid math via ""Kid is Gone"" and rabid feedback via the early classic
column15: ""Kandy Korn Rituals"".

column1: The third disc
column2: Chant of Vengeance
column3: contains previously unissued KAOS radio material (which comes complete with bad college radio banter
column4: something that will never go away
column5: and is nice to hear situated next to the Unwound tracks) and the stuff one Damon Houk recorded live in his basement
column6: including the take on ""Hating in D"" that appears as the last track on the 1993 Kandy Korn Rituals 7"". This is one of those reissues where you'll get multiple versions of the same tracks when you factor in the live takes and the radio material. That
column7: and some of the songs appeared on A Single History: 1991–1997
column8: which was released in 1999 by Kill Rock Stars.

column1: The set also contains unreleased photos
column2: and the liners notes are extensive—you'll know more about the early days of Unwound than their parents. You get that history of the band from the early years
column3: under their earlier names
column4: but it grows more interesting when they start to gel as Unwound
column5: especially the material surrounding that Kill Rocks Stars compilation
column6: which also included Nirvana among other key acts like Bikini Kill
column7: Bratmobile
column8: and Mecca Normal
column9: and was released shortly before Nevermind broke through.

column1: It makes sense that Numero anticipate six to seven months between each release in this reissue series—it ought to give listeners time to digest the material before moving onto the next batch. Unwound were a band who changed a lot during their time together
column2: but never lost the plot; while there is this cohesion
column3: the shifts also make more sense
column4: and ultimately will mean more
column5: if these boxes are experienced in something closer to ""real time."" This was a real band
column6: a group of friends who played music because they wanted to play music. A band with ideals when ideals were about what you did in private
column7: and not just about playing a character in the press. They may not have made the history books yet
column8:
but Unwound definitely deserve to be there when someone starts writing the second volumes.

"|18356.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18356-unwound-kid-is-gone/|8.0|Brandon Stosuy

Is it better to bury the lede or to climax early? That’s the question that hangs highest at the close of Milk Money
column3: the first album in three years from solo multi-instrumentalist
column4: one-man loop station and Andrew Bird drummer Martin Dosh. Dosh begins with six slight and impressionistic pieces
column5: each stopping not only well short of the five-minute mark but of any real peak
column6: too. “Golden Silver”
column7: for instance
column8: slow-fades from a cool-blooded thicket of sighing organs
column9: twinkling pianos
column10: and thudding drums
column11: evacuating its own oxygen before any eruption can occur. “Death Set” is not nearly as dangerous or foreboding as its name implies
column12: with wild runs on multiple keyboards and stepwise sequences of bass simply folding in and out of a jungle beat until that pulse is all that remains.

column1: But the final track
column2: “Legos (for Terry)”
column3: is the most ambitious and most surprising moment of Dosh’s entire repertoire. Just shy of 25 minutes
column4: “Legos” is not only longer than the sum of the rest of the album’s parts but also longer than anything else in his back catalog by more than double. This isn’t an exercise in simply going an indeterminate distance
column5: though: Dosh wrote “Legos” as a commission for the Walker Arts Center in his homebase of Minneapolis
column6: Minn.
column7: to be played as a duet with Glenn Kotche on the night of the Wilco drummer’s premiere of<a href=""http://thethread.dukeperformances.duke.edu/2013/02/interview-elemental-composer-john-luther-adams-on-glenn-kotche-ilimaq/"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank""> his John Luther Adams collaboration
column8: Ilimaq. It’s a grand
column9: arching composition that moves between two monolithic sections with just the right balance between restraint and restlessness.

column1: Though Dosh has sold his own piano playing short in the past
column2: he summons Keith Jarrett during the first span
column3: scattering bursts and slipstreams of notes between refracted vocal samples and a chiffon layer of static. It’s a phosphorescent dawn. Dosh’s original take lasted nearly twice as long as the album version and featured no vocals
column4: but the sampled-and-splintered utterances here help introduce the song’s second half
column5: a crisscrossing wonder of kalimba and piano
column6: hi-hat and synthesizers. Their melodies and rhythms shift in and around one another like a Steve Reich epic on vacation
column7: exciting and electric. Dosh micromanages the elements as the piece progresses—steadily boosting the background hum
column8: wildly stringing together the vocal bits
column9: carefully digging into the beat a bit heavier and hotter. When all those components tumble around one another
column10: with vocals crashing against drums against electronics
column11: the feeling is ecstatic
column12: as though the composer-performer has just stepped into a field of infinitely bright light.

column1: The rest of Milk Money
column2: or Side A
column3: is simply fine. Dosh’s previous solo records
column4: especially since 2006’s audacious The Lost Take
column5: have been guest-heavy affairs
column6: with songs stuffed by big beats and rock-like codas aided by unexpected influences. Perhaps saxophonist Mike Lewis lent his horn to a tune
column7: or maybe Andrew Bird warbled a bit with his violin. They fit the eccentric
column8: interconnected scheme of Anticon
column9: the hip-hop miscreants who released almost all of Dosh’s material until now. But these pieces were all built without collaborators in mind
column10: though Dosh did retroactively add vocals from a few singers
column11: such as the slip-sliding
column12: pitch-shifted bleat during “Unto Eternity” or the soft coos webbed throughout “We are the Worst”. Still
column13: these shorts seem somewhat weightless and without anchor
column14: serving more as messengers of a changing mood than as engrossing compositions. They’re the antithesis
column15: then
column16: of the record’s finale. These numbers remain interesting on a level of one-man-band proficiency
column17: as when the rattling drums slingshot between the M83-like rumble and tropicália flute during the opener. But that’s something you notice from afar
column18: not when the songs have pulled you into their orbit—something that
column19: for the most part
column20: doesn’t occur during Milk Money.

column1: In an era of laptop beatmakers and producers able to conjure a full-band feeling from a few outputs and a mixer
column2: the sounds that Dosh gets as a solo performer are not as novel as they once were
column3: despite the workaday analog nature of how he gets them. Strangely
column4: such a consideration has never been problematic for him before Milk Money
column5: because the songs themselves moved with enough drama and dynamics to make the mechanics secondary to the material. But Milk Money can feel like a clinic
column6: a demonstration of the possibilities of his prowess without any meaningful purpose for them. Of course
column7: on Side B
column8: Dosh reveals a clinic of exactly how this should be done
column9: with categories and clichés cast aside in favor of a rigorous and thrilling composition. For Milk Money
column10: it ultimately makes no difference whether the lede is buried (it is) or the climax comes first (there isn’t much of one); this uneven album is mostly a vehicle for “Legos (for Terry)”
column11: an accomplishment that’s not only worth hearing but good enough to leave you hoping for more like it
column12:
too.

0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/19740/homepage_large.a7b2caa8.jpg|Obsian|31627.0|Castevet|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Profound Lore']|2013-10-25 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:51:29.158693|"

Castevet will tease you
column2: but don’t take it the wrong way: On their stubborn and excellent second album
column3: Obsian
column4: the New York math-metal-madman trio hint at climaxes they refuse to deliver and misdirect their redirections as a rule. When they race into instrumental codas at the exits of their blackened labyrinths
column5: as they do on opener “The Tower”
column6: they don’t do so in order to ease away from the intensity and float toward an end. They instead only get more complex
column7: drawing outside of plain rhythmic lines. When they add an acoustic guitar
column8: as they do on centerpiece “As Fathomed by Beggars and Victims”
column9: they don’t do so to soften their sound or mitigate their density. They do it to make their spider-webbed arrangements that much more intricate
column10: disrupting the generally clean spaces between their six-string bass
column11: electric guitar
column12: and ultra-articulate drums with a feathery texture. The song is built on deliberate
column13: near-pneumatic pieces
column14: but as a whole
column15: it is a euphoric rush that delivers itself to memory.

column1: Indeed
column2: the underlying draw of Obsian and Castevet at large is that ability to sound incredibly visceral and obviously convoluted at once. The parts they play are intricate to the point of prog rock
column3: but neither mannerism nor dexterity is ever the point. “The Curve”
column4: for instance
column5: races back and forth
column6: up and down for eight minutes
column7: its rhythms and riffs expanding and contracting around each other in decidedly non-linear fashion. But it hits hard
column8: too
column9: with a midsection that opens up like a cataract of liquid dark. Andrew Hock’s jigsaw vocals lead drums caught in a rolling boil.

column1: That’s the album’s most direct moment. On the whole
column2: Obsian is a difficult record
column3: comprising metal built on math-rock foundations so rigorous they might begin to resemble multi-variable calculus. While its six songs clock in at a combined 37 minutes
column4: Obsian feels longer
column5: thanks to the panoply of bits it contains and the force with which they’re delivered. In that way
column6: Castevet recalls the music of Profound Lore labelmates Portal—fairly succinct but especially layered
column7: demanding that you lean in close and devote your attention.

column1: Castevet’s debut
column2: 2010’s Mounds of Ash
column3: was by no means easy music
column4: but it would stomp and surge in recognizable ways—straight-ahead black metal charges
column5: slinking midsections and interludes
column6: grand euphoric washes. Its successor is never quite so obvious or identifiable. Sure
column7: the guitars of “Cavernous” possess the tremolo sweep and tinny sustain of black metal
column8: but the rhythm section adds unleavened weight
column9: pulling all the elements toward an irregular core. Ian Jacyszyn—a wonderful
column10: exhilarating drummer who plays like an immaculate machine connected to an imaginative mind—motors between blast beats and stuttering syncopation
column11: high-test thrash and patient doom. Hock mostly works an imported
column12: exasperated death metal bark; he welcomes in the dark
column13: crooning tenor of Nick Podgurski (Feast of the Epiphany/ex-Extra Life) for oblong closer
column14: “The Seat of Severance”.

column1: These two seem to have found the missing link
column2: too: Though they remain a trio for Obsian
column3: Castevet added Nicholas McMaster as their third and most interesting bassist to date. Familiar from Bloody Panda or his steadily increasing role in Krallice
column4: McMaster intuits the simultaneous interests of Castevet—that is
column5: to deliver both body and brain shots. The bright notes of his bass slide into the cracks between the guitars and drums
column6: sometimes suggesting jazz-fusion or King Crimson. Call it shared perspicacity: McMaster has added yet another through-line of complexity to Castevet rather than simply sitting near the edges of the trio’s motion. These three components now share the marquee.

column1: You might not take to Obsian immediately. It might sound impenetrable or
column2: more likely
column3: it will simply sound fine
column4: like American black metal tempered by vintage Touch & Go impulses. Keep at it. The first time I listened
column5: I was on a bus
column6: probably checking e-mail and watching the people around me
column7: with the music loosely in the mid-ground. But I listened again and again
column8: alternately zooming in on the elements (the dry
column9: high bass parts of McMaster just before the five-minute mark of “Cavernous”) and zooming out to see their cumulative effect (the Godflesh-toned
column10: Emperor-transcendent power of the band at the same moment). That appears to be the way Obsian was made
column11: after all
column12: with attention paid to the way details stand on their own and how they function within something much bigger than themselves
column13: a solo or a Byzantine display of dexterity. Obsian does not wither in its own freakshow of technicality or brandish any hyperbolic brutishness. Rather
column14: it finds a rarified balance between the two
column15: then teases
column16:
dares and challenges you to engage with both levels at the same time.

0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/19862/homepage_large.a8ef3f92.jpg|Guilt Trips|30667.0|Ryan Hemsworth|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Last Gang']|2013-10-24 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:51:29.647578|"

In the growing body of writing about how disastrous millennials are supposed to be
column2: people throw around phrases like “severely shortened attention spans” as an insult
column3: but the twentysomething producer Ryan Hemsworth is proof that this assumed failing can
column4: in fact
column5: be a great strength. Over his short but industrious career he’s displayed an almost pathological inability to stick with any one particular style of music for more than a few minutes at a time. He’s remixed everyone from Cat Power to Waka Flocka Flame to Danish pop duo Quadron
column6: and his DJ sets bounce nimbly between disparate styles: radio rap into ambient electronics
column7: slick 90s R&B into aggressive dancehall.

column1: In his own productions he’s been relatively more consistent
column2: but still wide-ranging. His original works tend to consist of a rap beat
column3: often one that uses the rhythms of trap rap and sounds that could've been lifted off the laptop of an experimental electronic musician
column4: layered with washes of synthesizers and manipulated vocal samples that deliver the same benzo bliss as Clams Casino and Shlohmo
column5: albeit with a more ragged
column6: deconstructed feel. With subtle tweaks to his formula he can evoke Tangerine Dream or the-Dream with equal ease.

column1: On Guilt Trips
column2: his first solo LP (after an album length collaboration with the rapper Shady Blaze) and second major release of 2013 (after May’s Still Awake EP)
column3: he’s still stylistically daring
column4: but shows off a newfound focus that’s uncharacteristic but successful. There’s more clarity here than on his past work—production-wise he’s removed much of the haze that some of his other releases swam in
column5: and the songwriting shows considerably more forethought than previous compositions
column6: which often just wandered around for a while then ended.

column1: His new stuff still meanders
column2: though now with more purpose
column3: sharper hooks
column4: and lusher instrumental textures. They’re most apparent on the several tracks here made for vocalists like avant-rapper Lofty305 and R&B singer Sinead Harnett. “Still Cold” lays a plaintive vocal by Baths over an electropop arrangement that hints at both the Postal Service and some of Brian Eno’s more accessibly quirky 70s material
column5: and is way more hummable than any of Hemsworth’s old stuff.

column1: This new straightforwardness is even more apparent on “One for Me”
column2: featuring up and coming singer Tinashe. It sounds far less like the experimental twists on radio R&B he’s made his name on
column3: and more like something you'd straight up hear on the radio

column3: the British producer and singer Kwes has done his work in the background. He mixed records for the xx in their early days and produced for his friend Mica Levi

column1: The spotlight shifted onto Kwes in 2012 when he released “B_shf_l”
column2: a hyper-endearing R&B song that helped to break him as a solo artist in early 2012. But even after that
column3: Kwes continued to focus on collaboration
column4: working with Bobby Womack and the British songstress Eliza Doolittle as well as staging a series of operas in collaboration with Peroni brewery. Meanwhile
column5: his music itself has ended up in some surprising places
column6: most recently turning up as a sample on Pusha T’s ""Who I Am"".

column1: Kwes
column2: then
column3: seems capable of working at a faster clip for and with others than he can as a solo artist. His debut album
column4: ilp
column5: has been about four years in the making
column6: partly due to a six or seven month period of creative block. Records that take a long time to make often result in an enormous patchwork of influences and ilp is no exception: the record reflects a whole host of sensibilities
column7: from the pastoral electronica of early Four Tet
column8: to the traditional R&B of Jessie Ware and the delicate production sensibilities of someone like Sampha
column9: as well as more recently absorbed ties to Oneohtrix Point Never and Brian Wilson. On ilp
column10: Kwes is trying to solve a tough creative riddle:  How can an experimental producer with a love for so many different styles of music emphasize his earnest
column11: understated songs while still allowing himself the freedom to explore?

column1: One strategy that Kwes employs is the seemingly straightforward pop song
column2: rebuilt from the ground up. This approach is epitomized by “B_shf_l""
column3: which appears again here to open the album. The song remains magnificent: its real accomplishment is using the experimental electronic music Kwes favors to recreate and recontextualize the feel of classicist pop. It’s only once you focus pretty closely that you realize “B_shf_l” is like nothing you’ve ever heard before.  “Flower” and “Rollerblades” are ""B_shf_l""’s cousins
column4: well-meaning pop songs that don’t quite have the snap of that first single.

column1: Kwes combines his two very different skill sets most successfully on the album’s two longest songs
column2: both of them anthemic
column3: metaphysical explorations nestled in thorny
column4: elaborate musical structures. “Cablecar” is an eight minute treatise of found sound and heartbreaking writing
column5: a delicate
column6: difficult song that slowly reveals itself over the course of multiple listens. And “Purplehands” takes its operative idea from the Brian Wilson influence that Kwes has been talking up recently
column7: with an exploration of food and colors serving as an elegant way to talk about love.

column1: But ilp falters on its shorter songs. Kwes frequently talks about the need for restraint and it’s clear that’s something that he struggles with in his own work. His songs have habit of getting mired
column2: or lost entirely within the context of his ambient
column3: occasionally overwrought music. A good example can be found in the transition between “Flower""
column4: and “Hives""; The former is a startlingly delicate love song
column5: the latter a static-driven instrumental. Both tracks are worthwhile but they require wholly different modes of listening and the transition from one to the other is off-putting.

column1: The problem with ilp then is that it's not sure what kind of experience it wants to give you
column2: be it pop or ambient
column3: easy or difficult listening. Kwes the singer is too often overwhelmed by Kwes the producer—he places his voice in the background much of the time
column4: allowing instrumental techniques to obscure
column5: rather than illuminate
column6: the subject of his songs. “Broke” is devastating lyrically but while the music adds to the atmosphere at the beginning of the song
column7: the two elements soon lose track of one another. The track loses momentum as a result
column8: and ends up feeling incomplete.

column1: It can feel difficult to criticize an artist as flagrantly sincere and musically talented as Kwes—this is a guy who caps off his debut album with song dedicated to the love between his grandparents
column2: after all. But as it turns out
column3: those two qualities
column4: the earnestness of the lyrics and the shifting quality of the music
column5:
combine to eventually thwart ilp’s success. Kwes’s gentle songwriting sensibilities are unable to keep up with his exploratory beat making and the result is too often a mismatch that ends up leaving the listner at a loss.

When it comes to evoking nostalgia
column2: Paul Woolford is keeping it extreme. For his Special Request project
column3: the UK producer keeps his studio space loaded with vintage hardware
column4: including an FM transmitter that allows him to broadcast over his own frequency and sample the results. This complicated process
column5: which Woolford has referred to as <a href=""http://tankmagazine.com/issue-59/radio/paul-woolford"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">""creating a false memory

column7: hearing the thrilling sounds of first-generation jungle and rave through his speakers as rave culture was forming and
column8: as the years progressed

column1: ""The attractive thing about pirate radio is that it sits outside of convention
column2: Woolford told FACT earlier this year while discussing his still-strong attachment to the format. ""So there are no rules."" The relative constraints applied to Special Request speak to a method of creating new rules to escape the encumberances of ones already in place; in other words
column3: it's a highly conceptual project
column4: and not the first of its kind. With Death of Rave
column5: sound deconstructionist Leland Kirby dismantled rave's glory days as a tribute to the culture
column6: degrading its sounds until there was little more than an exquisite corpse left over; meanwhile
column7: Burial's own decayed-throwback style owes something to the enigmatic producer becoming enamored with artifacts of an era he didn't experience first-hand: ""Old jungle

column1: With a sense of nasty-edged playfulness that keeps the project's nostalgia from lapsing into stiff reverence

column5: would similarly dive headlong into clattering waters; that record turned out to be more subtle than expected

column1: Woolford's ""no rules"" approach is evident from Soul Music's opening track

column3: an icy slice of techno reinforcing the notion that Special Request is less about evoking the sounds of pirate radio's heyday and more about recreating its anything-goes attitude. Not to say that Soul Music isn't sonically slavish to its nostalgic ideals

column3: smoggy visage. Structurally
column4: Zomby's own 'ardcore-revivalist vibes have often resembled tiny nuclear reactors constantly powering up and malfunctioning
column5: brief bursts of energy with short half-lifes. Woolford's approach is different
column6: as he lets most of these tunes stretch their legs past the five-minute mark with plenty of room to tweak their structures ever so slightly and pleasingly (see: the placid bed of tones that stride into the midsection of ""Lockjaw""'s gaping breakbeat maw). Accordingly
column7: the collection's longest cut

column9: is Soul Music's most revelatory head-rush

column1: A dense collection of dance cuts that make few overtures to those not previously converted by the genre

column7: Soul Music is a truly unique and enriching experience: a collection of old sounds from one of dance music's enduring mainstays
column8:
re-assembled in a way that sounds fresher than ever.

Last summer

column3: yeah you really got a hold on me

column1: But Happy Jawbone Family Band is not another collection of home-recorded songs that could end up on Taste the Broom Again: 2013-2017. From the beginning of their new self-titled endeavor
column2: it's obvious just how much they've cleaned up their sound. Their instruments' clarity is instantly apparent. There's a reason for the change: Most of their older stuff was recorded in the band's basement; this one was made in Gary’s Electric Studio and was recorded by Jarvis Taveniere of Woods. The organ
column3: jangling guitars
column4: harmonies
column5: and drums on opening track ""Everybody Knows About Daddy"" are hi-fi and crisp. But while there's nothing as raucously blown out as ""Now Everybody Rock Like You Got AIDS""
column6: Happy Jawbone Family Band is still very much in step with their well-established and thoroughly documented aesthetic. ""I'll Never Go Skin Deep Again"" is introduced by a lone autoharp. There's a horn section on ""Do You Want Me""
column7: plus several other elegantly implemented details
column8: like echoing guitars
column9: beatific backing voals
column10: and a string section. The resulting song is as lush and ornate as most of Sufjan Stevens' mid-2000s fare.

column1: It's tempting to lump this record in with other famous indie rock outfits
column2: what with its elaborate arrangements and twee-leaning inclinations. A previous Pitchfork review referenced Elephant 6
column3: which feels particularly applicable considering the new album's constantly shifting percussive sound and raggedly shouted vocals. Those aesthetic similarities only aid the band in delivering some of their best songs to date. ""Can't You Hear Me Ticking"" has a nice groove and the best use of ""pow pow pow"" in a chorus since James Murphy did it. There's a stately melodrama to the elaborate arrangements of ""Han Christian Andersen's 'The Little Mermaid'"". ""D-R-E-A-M-I-N'"" is a sunny pop song that makes singing along a realistic possibility on the first listen—both the spell-along chorus and the hollered ""ooohhh oh oh oh!"" vocals chanted throughout. It's got brevity and enthusiastically belted melodies that could reasonably cross over on the radio. Also: It's a song about losing a girlfriend to a Miami-based furry and murderer named Rita.

column1: Clearly
column2: they've got a knack for ridiculous imagery
column3: but their lyrical decisions never feel chaotic or petulant or obnoxious. All over the record
column4: there are phrases that could be loaded with symbolism—like their pseudo-sexual phrasings on ""Mr. Clean"" (""I wanted to get you in my bathtub""). ""Stay-at-Home Soldier"" initially evokes psychedelic imagery a la ""Lucy in the Sky with Diamonds"": ""The city I live in lays covered in cream and ladies walk on crackers."" Soon
column5: though
column6: the chorus feasibly sounds like an allusion to video game culture—staying at home
column7: training dilligently
column8: and receiving hollow rewards. And while their phrases are consistently abstract
column9: certain symbols keep popping up: Lions
column10: breakfast
column11: baths
column12: and guns are all referenced multiple times on different songs. It's hard to tell if there's symbolic or narrative utility in those specific words
column13: but they create threads that run throughout the album—connections that might not necessarily mean anything
column14: but offer a strange sort of continuity in an otherwise lyrically scattered universe.

column1: After poring over their lyrics for a while
column2: it begins to feel unreasonable and maybe even a bit irresponsible to try and ""decode"" or ""understand"" a Happy Jawbone Family Band record. Just when you think you've made a substantial observation
column3: you begin to wonder if you're the guy at the party explaining the deeper meanings and symbolism behind kids' cereals. HJFB live in this in-between space
column4: where they could be pouring their hearts out
column5: or maybe they're just fucking with you. Their songs could be played in a theater with full string and horn sections
column6: or they could just play them at somebody's house party. But who cares? When the songs are this fun
column7:
context is overrated.

Daniel Avery occupies an odd spot amongst underground dance producers: he values largesse. Aspiring to the kind of big-room
column2: anthem-wielding sound the Chemical Brothers perfected in the mid 90s—and
column3: one presumes
column4: their career trajectory—Avery eschews the hyper-rhythmic minimalism and throwback New Jersey garage sound that currently power UK club music in favor of soupy
column5: riff-driven compositions that borrow from UK fetishes past: burbling acid house
column6: elegant Detroit techno
column7: big beat.

column1: Don't mistake Avery's ambition with that of big-tent super-producers. With the blessing of UK legend Andrew Weatherall—who once summed Avery's sound as ""gimmick-free machine-funk of the highest order""—Avery cut his teeth as a resident DJ at London's Fabric
column2: an epic
column3: expertly tuned soundsystem whose main floor is outfitted with bass transducers for a more immersive experience. The tracks on his debut LP Drone Logic feel tailored to this kind of high-end environment: crisp
column4: thrumming tunes that proudly prance over a wide spectrum of frequencies. The album feels decadent
column5: like one-percenter techno: rave music made for the best systems
column6: to be played by the most talented DJs
column7: drawing only from the purest eras of British dance exceptionalism.

column1: Avery keeps his rhythmic patterns simple
column2: drawing most of his drum sounds from pre-approved house and techno palates
column3: and he does this to better showcase his big
column4: groovy synth riffs. Drone Logic is overlong at nearly 70 minutes
column5: but at no point does Avery want for melodic ideas. He loads the tracks full of acid-dusted basslines and stabbing synths
column6: occasionally punctuating key moments with short vocal samples. Tracks like ""All I Need"" can feel a little cluttered
column7: not because Avery overstuffs them but because they he never just lays in the groove; ideas and melodies are constantly being advanced. Drone Logic smartly reprises successes from Avery's early EPs
column8: opening things up with an ""album version"" of the deep
column9: hypnotic ""Water Jump"" and later delving into the springy sci-fi of ""Need Electric"".

column1: Avery's avoidance of breakbeats and his heavily melodic approach means there's a lot of Detroit in his sound
column2: especially second-wave stalwarts like Anthony ""Shake"" Shakir and Carl Craig
column3: the first generation of producers with the luxury of building on a template already defined for them. Avery's at his best at his most tuneful and romantic. ""These Nights Never End"" compliments a roiling 303 bassline with a lapping
column4: progressive synth melody and hissy strings
column5: occasionally pulling back to allow the bassline room to tickle your hips. The crisp
column6: sugary closer ""Knowing We'll Be Here"" drops a candied vocal sample among fizzing keyboards and a simple
column7: hypnotic chord progression. Avery's lush psychedelics flirt with trance music
column8: and Drone Logic often plays like a more urban version of James Holden and Nathan Fake's pastoral sprawl.

column1: It's not hard to spot Avery's influences
column2: and while his sound is by no means modern
column3: it's a different kind of retro than that being proffered by his peers. Add to that its pristine production and Drone Logic feels modern
column4: but miles away from the zeitgeist. Avery owns this space
column5: and there's a refreshing self-assuredness to Drone Logic
column6: which
column7: combined with Avery's careful hand and his connections
column8: can come off as predestined. You might find it too retro
column9: or just not hip enough
column10: but there is zero second-guessing on Avery's part: never does he glance over his shoulder with a nod to UK bass culture or a capitulate to a straight house track. Avery's singular vision might've left him a man without a country
column11:
but Drone Logic's undeniable heft and silky craft ensure he'll have plenty of takers.

Red Fang did not set out to be fine. The first song on their 2008 self-titled debut was a bleary-eyed
column3: pop-metal pummel called “Prehistoric Dog”
column4: a hilarious and juvenile burst about alien canines bound for earth on a mission of extinction. “They will erase the human race
column5: ” went the perfect and perfectly stupid gambit. “Time to kiss your ass goodbye.” In the video for the surprise hit
column6: Red Fang jammed the song repeatedly in a tiny kitchen
column7: waged war against Renaissance Faire agitators
column8: and shot-gunned beer cans until they all vomited on camera
column9: almost in unison. By the time of that album’s arrival
column10: the four dudes of Red Fang were well traveled and adequately grizzled music-lifers who had gathered in Portland
column11: Ore. This seemed like their chance to throw the rules and expectations out of the window
column12: get stoned and/or drunk
column13: and play rock'n'roll
column14: just as they did in their lovably goofy music video for an inexplicably great song. Paired with a zealous touring schedule
column15: their modest
column16: familiar
column17: no-collar approach found near-instant favor.

column1: But Whales and Leeches—Red Fang’s third album and second for Relapse Records—is markedly fine and little else. Predictable and plain
column2: it is the no-threats sort of stoner rock a teenager wouldn’t need to hide from suspecting parents
column3: the kind of no-surprises stock you might play when you find yourself in need of something completely innocuous. These 11 songs mostly push forward at mid-tempo pounces with dual guitars
column4: bass
column5: and drums hanging together until someone pulls away for a frequent and fairly unremarkable solo. There is the requisite mid-album
column6: ham-fisted
column7: mean-mugging epic (two of them
column8: actually
column9: conveniently arranged in consecutive order for maximum skipping efficiency) and the last-ditch sprint toward the end. Even the subject matter feels pat and compulsory: There are vague threats and nondescript indignation
column10: zombie tales and scatological tragedy
column11: seafaring metaphors and extemporaneous nihilism. It’s the stuff you’d expect in a textbook about this brand of rock'n'roll
column12: not from four guys who always seemed to have such unapologetic fun crafting their own mythologies.

column1: Of course
column2: Red Fang was never out to reinvent anything
column3: but they did offer ample moments of sheer enjoyment or intrigue. Despite the amount of time the people who made Red Fang had already spent in other acts
column4: that record radiated with the urgency and enthusiasm of a very young
column5: energetic rock band. Their Relapse debut
column6: 2011’s Murder the Mountains
column7: lacked some of those immediate hooks
column8: but there was a demented sense of trial-and-error written into the follow-up’s 12 tracks
column9: epitomized by the stoned-and-happy bass mess “Throw Up” and the swiveling open-road epic “Number Thirteen”. Whales and Leeches mostly returns to the concision and direction of their premiere
column10: but it lacks both the élan and the refrains that first earned Red Fang notice. And the oddball approach of their second effort has evaporated
column11: too
column12: replaced by riffs that seem like they were written on autopilot and drums that do just what you’d surmise.

column1: “Blood Like Cream” wastes a disturbing lyrical conceit on boilerplate stoner rock. The stock bridge and solo are as obvious as the shout-along choruses they connect. “Voices of the Dead’” feels like the tentative
column2: first-attempt fare of a band that’s been playing Torche and Kyuss covers in small-town dive bars but has finally worked up the nerve to test out an original in front of the locals. It’s competent
column3: but there’s not an agent trying to squeeze in the door to sign these dudes
column4: either. Doom belter Mike Scheidt of Yob lends his falsetto to “Dawn Rising”
column5: offering an intriguing counterpoint to Red Fang’s usual workaday approach. Still
column6: the song is mostly a low-tempo march toward nothing
column7: its sizable chorus beset by verses that are melodramatically and hilariously ghoulish. The momentum slow-fades into a noisy twilight
column8: as if only to indulge a cliché that Red Fang had hitherto skipped. “This Animal” summons the heavy
column9: racing approach that High on Fire perfected nearly a decade ago; Red Fang gets the sound right
column10: but the song itself is dull and indistinct
column11: a through-the-motions attempt at something not quite new.

column1: Indeed
column2: Red Fang certainly sounds good on Whales and Leeches
column3: with the production of the Decemberists multi-instrumentalist Chris Funk again giving their instruments ample breadth and weight. But they do not match that surface with substance. The songs you’ll want to take away after repeated listens are scant
column4: and the sense that the players are enjoying or testing themselves is nil. Worse still
column5: Whales and Leeches doesn’t make the case for any aesthetic approach that Red Fang can call their own. Yes
column6: you’ll hear traces of Kylesa and Kyuss
column7: Torche and Sabbath
column8: Electric Wizard and Nebula. But this is album three
column9: and it’s still difficult to figure out who or what Red Fang aims to be. Part of the answer ostensibly used to be “good times
column10: ” but after two or three trips through Whales and Leeches
column11: you might start to ask why this whole affair feels like homework—not only for the listener
column12: but also
column13: it seems
column14:
for the band that made it.

0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/19820/homepage_large.3f2dc555.jpg|Double Cup|31089.0|DJ Rashad|['Electronic']|1.0|0.0|0.0|['Hyperdub']|2013-10-22 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:51:36.653084|"

The rise of footwork as a formidable sub-genre of electronic music over the last few years has raised an interesting question: how do you listen to the stuff? On one level
column2: the Chicago-borne sound is purely functional; its high-BPM tempos
column3: disorienting bass lines
column4: and hypnotically repetitive approach to sampling form the perfect soundtrack for the juke-derived footwork style of dancing
column5: which favors fast feet and athletic skill. Near the top of this decade
column6: footwork caught the collective ear of the always-hungry-for-something-new UK dance scene: Forward-thinking label Planet Mu delivered a smattering of footwork-associated releases near the end of 2010
column7: including the first volume of the scene-surveying Bangs & Works compilation. Much of the footwork music created around that time was fascinating
column8: inspiring—and
column9: as home-listening material
column10: maddening.

column1: Footwork's relative inaccessibility suggested that it would become a niche concern in the constantly changing realm of dance music
column2: but it stayed in the conversation
column3: as solid releases from veterans of the sound
column4: boundary-pushing newcomers
column5: and canny genre-fusion outsiders pushed things in more musical and distinctly individual directions. All these roads lead to Double Cup
column6: the new album from Rashad Harden
column7: who produces as DJ Rashad. A gorgeous
column8: invigorating collection of tracks that places equal importance on melody alongside rhythmic texture
column9: Double Cup is unquestionably the strongest footwork-related LP since the genre was introduced to a wider audience. This stuff would kill on a dancefloor
column10: but you don't have to watch anyone's feet to appreciate what's on display here.

column1: Double Cup closes out a particularly fruitful year for Rashad
column2: a two-decade-plus veteran of the scene who started dancing juke at 12 and began honing his DJ and production skills just a few years later in the early 90s. In March
column3: he made his debut on Hyperdub with the Rollin' EP
column4: an expressive collection that featured the astounding ""Let It Go""
column5: a game-changer of a tune with rolling
column6: hyperspeed drums and an evocative vocal sample; in July
column7: he dropped another solid EP
column8: I Don't Give a Fuck
column9: the title track of which appears on Double Cup
column10: too. (""Let It Go""
column11: a superior cut and arguably Rashad's strongest track to date
column12: is conspicuously absent here
column13: but the record's overall high level of consistency makes its exclusion a negligible gripe.)

column1: Ironically
column2: Double Cup achieves a new level of musicality previously untouched by footwork by jettisoning much of the genre's rigid formality. This stuff is practically in Rashad's blood
column3: so his ability to dismantle the sound he's lived with for much of his life and reassemble it in a fresh and exciting way is expected as much as it is impressive. For instance
column4: he splices in other elements of beat-fixated music—jungle's frantic mania
column5: bass music's oblong structures
column6: the glowing synths of vintage house and techno
column7: West Coast hip-hop's honey-slathered haze—to fit a more footwork-indebted framework. I've heard a few people compare Double Cup's dizzying sampledelia to J Dilla's masterwork Donuts; while the former lacks the latter's cohesion and singularity of purpose
column8: both records possess the similar thrill of hearing a master of an existent genre taking their sound to new
column9: exciting heights.

column1: Footwork often sounds as handmade as it does futuristic
column2: and being able to see the seams of tracks both imperfect and flawless is one of the genre's more endearing qualities. On Double Cup
column3: those seams are more or less nonexistent—for music that is so frequently intense and hard-hitting
column4: many tracks here possess an impossibly smooth finish. From opening cut ""Feelin'""s twinkling sighs to the smothering sensuality of ""Let U No""
column5: it at times sounds like Rashad has literally opened a window in footwork's oxygen-sealed atmosphere. The bass lines smack as hard as ever
column6: but they're placed lower in the mix rather than serving as these tracks' central axis
column7: creating a more varied sonic topography that's also easier on the ears.

column1: Footwork's practitioners tend to congregate in scenes
column2: and Rashad is no different: he's a founding member of the Teklife crew
column3: whose logo is emblazoned on Double Cup's packaging
column4: and he's also a part of the largely elder-statesmen Ghettoteknicianz outfit. Accordingly
column5: Double Cup is collaborative—""I Don't Give a Fuck"" and the harrowing weed anthem ""Reggie"" are the sole Rashad solo cuts here—with DJs and frequent collaborators Spinn (whose very good LP from earlier this year
column6: TEKLIFE Vol. 2: What You Need
column7: makes for a nice companion to this record)
column8: Manny
column9: Earl
column10: and Phil pitching in on additional beats and the occasional rap cadence.

column1: It's also a largely Midwestern record
column2: and its sole misstep occurs in the form of a collaboration with a non-regional artist: UK producer Addison Groove
column3: whose 2010 single ""Footcrab"" was instrumental in introducing footwork's genetic material to bass music. His and Rashad's ""Acid Bit"" is an intriguing curiousity
column4: with plenty of the acidic synth work that the name implies
column5: but ultimately the tune is a disruption to the album's already-nebulous flow. Which raises the other caveat regarding Double Cup: listening to footwork in long stretches can be exhilarating
column6: and exhilaration can often lead to exhaustion. The record runs 51 minutes long
column7: and since it resembles less a properly structured album and more an expertly curated collection of tracks
column8: it's best taken in smaller bursts for maximal effect.

column1: The greater Chicago area has frequently been at the forefront of left-of-center sounds that have bubbled up
column2: from the coruscating rock deconstructivism of Shellac and Big Black
column3: to Gastr del Sol's amorphous genre fusion
column4: to Frankie Knuckles' still-standing reign as ""The Godfather"" of house music. The past few years
column5: especially
column6: have provided a few fresh and unfamiliar sounds in regional hip-hop and dance music
column7: and Double Cup is the latest testament to the wellspring of ingenuity that Chicago's recent musical culture has to offer. For Rashad
column8: it's a defining statement 20-plus-years in the making
column9: a brilliant document that puts him in the position any veteran would kill to occupy: instead of looking back at the past
column10:
now it's all about where he takes his sound next.

Detroit producer/rapper Black Milk favors sounds that hurt just a little—drums tweaked sideways so they check you in the shoulder instead of landing straight
column4: synth sounds with big gaps in the frequencies. He has a diehard golden-age revivalist fan base
column5: but the farther away from Native Tongues revivalism his music travels
column6: the more willfuly ugly it becomes
column7: the better he gets—the waveform of his best beats would look like a grin full of broken teeth. <i>No Poison No Paradise
column8: his latest
column9: features some of the ugliest- sounding
column10: and therefore best and most fully-realized
column11: music of his career. It's a serrated
column12: mud-caked album
column13: one that rattles and bangs like a box full of old machine parts.

column1: Black Milk opens it with a quick feint
column2: almost a joke: nine seconds of murmuring jazz organ suspiciously similar  ""Electric Relaxation"" breeze by before a blurt of static cuts through and""Interpret Sabotage""
column3: a rusted tanker crunching its treads over Reagan-era synth equipment
column4: rolls through. ""Fell in love with a certain era of music
column5: never thought it would've came with a curse
column6: he raps grimly
column7: in tight
column8: martial 6/8
column9: the music nipping gamely at his heels.

column1: The album is easily Black Milk's darkest. Even 2010's Album of the Year
column2: which wrestled with a series of devastating losses and setbacks
column3: was light-hearted by comparison
column4: its colorful tumble of live instruments and loops keeping a semblance of a party going. On No Poison No Paradise
column5: despair rots all the way into the hull. The terrifically dark ""Codes and Cab Fare"" turns a Hammond organ and a sliding bass pitch into a  sustained moan
column6: a slow plummet in free space. ""Dismal""'s woodblock knock recalls OutKast's ""Elevators
column7: but the atmosphere is minor key and uneasy
column8: gas fumes rising off an evaporated Neptunes production. The knock on ""Black Sabbath"" is hard enough to send furniture tipping over
column9: and suggests Milk could have been a meaningful contributor in the room where Yeezus was hashed out.

column1: There are a few wistful moments on No Poison that recall Milk's spiritual father figure Dilla. He reminisces about squirming uncomfortably in church pews on ""Sunday's Best""
column2: a song that fades cleverly into ""Monday's Worst""
column3: both songs breezing by on late-summer-light soul loops. Dreamlike sequencing touches like this are the only obvious marks of the concept behind No Poison
column4: which
column5: Black Milk tells us
column6: functions as series of dreams inside the head of a character named Sonny
column7: Jr.

column1: There's a reason reason this conceptual framework feels vague and mushy
column2: and it's Black Milk's career-long elephant in the room: He's a technically strong rapper
column3: someone who writes vividly and honestly
column4: who continually shuffles complex rhyme patterns
column5: who audibly pops veins with his desire to say something. But his vocal tone is grit
column6: sawdust
column7: completely lacking in character. He suffers from a severe case of what Andrew Noz years ago dubbed ""Black Thought Syndrome
column8: wherein a rapper with a surplus of substance suffers from a severe lack of style. For a guy with such a golden ear
column9: you'd think he would have figured out a way to weave his vocals more musically
column10: or more distinctively
column11: into the richly tactile music he produces in the studio.

column1: Nonetheless
column2: he seethes impressively here
column3: performing with the determination of someone who has weathered a career's worth of these sorts of dispiriting notices. A few of his lines burst through via a sheer force of iron will
column4: like on""Black Sabbath"": ""You know them slums where them slugs hum past your wig.""  His near-military focus and conviction carries the day. And he stretches out here and there—he hasn't always been the guy you think of when you think of ""baby-making music
column5: but he sounds relaxed on the convincingly slinky and unzipped ""Parallels
column6: like someone who is not only about to have sex
column7: but conceivably enjoy it. On ""Sonny
column8: Jr.
column9: he brings in Robert Glasper
column10: a vital jazz pianist and producer who has been working double-time to complicate that resume with hip-hop and R&B collaborations

column12:
and its most compelling moments are career highlights.

0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/19828/homepage_large.e457aa19.jpg|Wish Hotel EP|27801.0|Ducktails|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Domino']|2013-10-22 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:51:39.068725|"

Were I a betting man
column2: I’d have no problem putting down a year’s rent on venturing that Matt Mondanile is probably what college freshmen colloquially refer to as a “chill guy.” This is a man who once wrote a song called “Killin the Vibe” (lyric: “Don’t go killin’/ Killin’ the vibe/ I can’t take/ Your lame style”) and plays guitar for Real Estate
column3: whose 2011 record Days is the finest example of a band turning the classic Dylan lyric “jingle-jangle morning” into an ethos. A not-entirely-fair critique of Real Estate is that a lot of their songs sound the same—the band would beg to differ—but there’s no doubting a similarity of instrumental elements. On his own time
column4: Mondanile’s solo recording project Ducktails has offered a peek into what Real Estate might sound like if they began coloring outside the lines
column5: mixing genres while staying true to his pastoral roots. (Similar to how guitar predecessor Roger McGuinn guided the Byrds through several identities while still sounding like the same band.)  His newest EP
column6: Wish Hotel
column7: picks up where The Flower Lane left off
column8:
playing with electronic textures to further evoke a reflexively hazy attitude toward the way of the world.
 
The Flower Lane was made with the help of fellow New Jerseyians Big Troubles
column9: but on Wish Hotel Mondanile’s returned to recording by himself. Even so
column10: little remains of the patchy
column11: wandering quality that colored earlier Ducktails material. He’s become better at harnessing disparate elements toward a congealed whole: the swirling synthesizer reinforcing the resonant strum at the beginning of “Honey Tiger Eyes""
column12: the sustained tones that lend “Tie-Dye” an eerie
column13: otherworldly quality when combined with Mondanile’s breathy vocal. Where The Flower Lane went all over the place
column14: Wish Hotel’s brevity makes it a set of variations on a theme. This is mood music
column15: best exemplified by bucolic instrumental “Naive Music” that sounds like a really great jam session... with himself. Mondanile isn’t making any grand departures from Real Estate’s core theses
column16: but he’s using a wider range of tools to look inward and keep the vibe going. Your tolerance for that vibe may vary; reviewing The Flower Lane
column17:
Steven Hyden wrote that “after a while Mondanile’s attachment to the pleasantly ephemeral starts to feel like a dodge.”

There are indeed diminishing returns to being so laid back
column18: and Mondanile can sometimes sound like he’s mumbling with a mouthful of Oxycontin. But the slightly stupefied delivery also comes off confessional
column19: helping with the personal truth at the heart of some of his songs. On Wish Hotel
column20: Mondanile cloaks his vocals in a way that suggests layers of interior mystery
column21: like he’s reading from a water-logged
column22: page-torn diary. “Hidden under leaves no one will see/ So you might as well stay there
column23: ” he whispers on “Tie-Dye”; “It’s the story of my life/ No one believes me/ But I wish you would
column25: in spite of his lyrical introspection
column26: Mondanile doesn’t seem to be communicating any greater depth—well
column27:
that’s part of the bummer of being a chill guy. It's hard to be taken seriously when it seems like nothing bothers you at all.

Not everything about this record is hidden meanings and coy smiles

Listening to club music out of context—such as at work
column2: or at the gym—tends to produce two very different effects. Sometimes it displaces you
column3: allows escape to a nightclub
column4: or a house party
column5: or some imagined communal experience. It can also have essentially the opposite effect
column6: when its repetition and minutiae center your thoughts
column7: allowing you focus on the task at hand. The most striking aspect of Livity Sound
column8: a compilation-cum-artist album from the Bristol label and crew of the same name
column9: is that it does neither of these things. Rhythmic
column10: syncopated drum-machine music at its core
column11: Livity Sound is too abstract to transport you
column12: and too bewitching to sink into the background. The collective
column13: which takes its name from a Rastafarian word meaning
column14: roughly
column15: life-force
column16: conjures bantamweight dance music that builds on Bristol's long tradition of pioneering dub while establishing itself as one of the finest examples of bass music's assimilation of house and techno.

column1: Livity Sound
column2: the label
column3: is the brainchild of Tom Ford
column4: a Bristol fixture who aided the city's adoption of dubstep via his Punch Drunk label
column5: which released key records by locals like Appleblim
column6: Pinch
column7: and Joker (and continues to do so). Ford
column8: who records under the names Peverelist and
column9: more recently
column10: just Pev
column11: grew weary of dubstep's direction at the end of last decade. He re-focused his efforts with the help of Kowton (Joe Cowton
column12: who has produced with Julio Bashmore) and Asusu (Craig Stennett); the three combine in various iterations to form the output of Livity Sound. Much of what constitutes Livity Sound's two discs has been released before
column13: albeit only on vinyl and only in Europe. Strung together
column14: the tracks are of a piece
column15: an album that stares a swarm of knuckle-cracking drum machines in the face and emerges with a lucid
column16: psychedelic calm.

column1: The closest analogue to Livity's aesthetic might be the finely tuned hallucinations of Shackleton's Skull Disco label (on which Peverelist appeared)
column2: albeit minus that label's swampy humidity and noir-ish posturing. Livity's focus is squarely on rhythm programming: choppy
column3: hovering patterns that carry with them their own peculiar logic. Lots of toms
column4: congas
column5: and some distinct tunings ensure the tracks
column6: like those of Skull Disco
column7: have a non-Western air to them (a feeling aided by the glyphs that adorn Livity's recordings). Otherness
column8: however
column9: isn't the point; it's a byproduct of three producers working on the edges of functional club music. Indeed
column10: many of these tracks—Pev's mesmerizing ""Aztec Chant"" in particular—have for months been populating the mixes of Europe's progressive DJs. Like any good subversive
column11: a Livity track knows when to blend in.

column1: Livity Sound feels fossilized in its rigidity and dustiness. Its tracks are the calcified vestiges of Bristol's healthy dub history
column2: from the aqueous sub-bass of jungle to Massive Attack's laconic pop. The song titles are fitting: ""Remnants""
column3: ""Raw Code""
column4: ""Erosions"". Melodic elements are spare
column5: as if they've been rationed
column6: but potent: ""More Games"" features an ominous staccato synth riff borrowed from a dozen grime white labels
column7: while ""Livity"" contorts a house piano line into a carnivalesque oddity. More often
column8: the rhythms—and their off-balance syncopations
column9: their relentless clapping—compose the motifs. At times
column10: as on the steamy ""Raw Code"" or the haunted ""Too Much Time Has Passed""
column11: it feels like the producers have removed dub's all-encompassing echoes and laid its bones in the street.

column1: There's plenty of echo on Livity Sound
column2: even if it feels shallow and a little barren. It's part of what makes these tracks so disarming and hypnotic. Livity Sound is relentless without being aggressive or overbearing; it's just always there
column3: tapping away. Like Basic Channel or Digital Mystikz before them
column4: it would be easy enough to ascribe genre names to Livity Sound
column5: but it's more fulfilling to think of them as delinquent nephews of dub reggae. The tracks
column6: and the arid stare their grooves perpetuate
column7: are like crop circles drawn into the UK hardcore continuum: functionally new
column8:
eerily primeval.

Earthless don't leave room for misinterpretation or error concerning their mission: They are a long-winded guitar trio
column3: hell-bent on riding six electric strings directly out of this atmosphere. No sooner than the drums unload their initial heavy hit on the band’s first album in six years—the ridiculous ripper From the Ages—Isaiah Mitchell takes his first solo
column4: his squealing lead slashing cleanly through a vacant gaze of cymbal wash. The band soon digs back in
column5: with drummer Mario Rubalcaba and bassist Mike Eginton instantly stitching a sturdy pocket. But it’s Mitchell that almost always edges out front in Earthless. He rides through a riff and races off into tangents for minutes on end. After that lead burst during album opener “Violence of the Red Sea
column6: ” he bends a theme a half-dozen different ways
column7: whether retracing his lead with a wah-wah moan here or a whammy bar battle with himself there. Rubalcaba and Eginton don’t pull Mitchell back toward earth; they instead follow his ecstatic lead everywhere
column8: fellow travelers on his odyssey of enthusiasms.

column1: Since Earthless’ last album
column2: 2007’s Rhythms from a Cosmic Sky
column3: its members have been busy: Rubacalba has been behind the throne for new old punks OFF! and out front for San Diego pounders Spider Fever. Mitchell joined Howlin Rain for its Rick Rubin-helmed catastrophe The Russian Wilds and started the blustery
column4: concise psych group Golden Void with some high school buddies and his wife. Mitchell actually presaged Golden Void at the end of Rhythms with the swiveling Groundhogs cover “Cherry Red”
column5: the shortest bit of Earthless’ oeuvre by a quarter-hour.

column1: The experience of getting back into bands playing discrete tunes serves From the Ages well
column2: as Earthless breaks the album’s hour-plus runtime into four digestible tracks. “Violence of the Red Sea” syncs well with “Uluru Rock”
column3: a smoldering tune that’s steadily fanned until it leaps into flames. By trek’s end
column4: the rhythm section’s beating back hard against Mitchell
column5: his fingers bouncing between notes as though his hands are the levers and posts of a pinball machine. “Equus October” indulges a cosmic drift
column6: with the bass leading the Om-like way for circular drums and a twilit haze of electrostatic ambiance. It’s an uncharacteristically subdued side of Earthless. As such
column7: it only last five minutes.

column1: The closing title track
column2: however
column3: burns on for more than half an hour. It’s the sum of everything before it
column4: not only in length but also in the establishment of a structure and dynamic that allow the span to be an epic
column5: not just another tedious bro jam. The trio roars at the start
column6: drums and bass thrashing behind Mitchell’s lead. They shift into a viscous blues bounce and then into a great astral smear
column7: eventually riding an Arabian riff into a meditative rumble. The guitar lines waft like smoke across an empty field. Earthless sit still a bit too long here; remarkably
column8: this is the one moment of From the Ages where the band’s patience might test your own. But they come roaring back
column9: driving into a coda that’s heavier than anything they’ve ever done. All the solos and sidetracks collapse into one brilliant exit. A journey meant for getting lost suddenly makes good on the destination.

column2: the place and purpose of acts like Earthless or Endless Boogie elicit some interesting questions about genre and intent. These are essentially roadhouse bands
column3: capable of stretching a rock'n'roll theme from here to infinity. But when so many of us can’t pay attention enough to engage with an entire album
column4: is there a need for an hour of three dudes tracing and retracing a melody? Does this digressive stuff work only on stage
column5: where a few beers and a few puffs have softened everyone’s focus enough to sink into solo after solo after solo? Is this the jurisdiction of jam bands
column6: in the most cynical and checked-out sense? To an extent
column7: yes: Earthless’ music—not unlike that of Sleep or Bardo Pond or Eternal Tapestry or
column8: you know
column9: The Grateful Dead—requires a certain suspension of now
column10: a commitment to and comfort with being ferried away for however long they please. But From the Ages is more a reminder of the fun that can be had with the most basic elements of rock
column11: too. This is the atavistic magic of three people locked in a room only with their instruments and each other
column12: eyes closed
column13: and mouths open. Earthless are incredibly indulgent
column14: sometimes to a fault
column15: but they’re much too excitable to be called selfish or masturbatory. The dudes are once again just riffing here. It’s a trip worth taking
column16:
at least a few times.

Bethany Cosentino is 26 years old and watching the clock anxiously. On her band’s new mini-album
column2: Fade Away
column3: she’s often found monitoring the unsettling passage of time. “I don’t know who I am this year
column4: ” goes one song. “When did I wake up and suddenly my soul had grown so old?” she asks. “Last 30 seconds I’ll wait for him
column5: ” she sings
column6: resigned and bitter. “You taught me that my heart would grow old.” And as if giving herself a pep talk to buffer the unease: “Life is short but so am I. What does it matter
column7: anyway?” Over the span of three years and two full-lengths
column8: Cosentino has achieved a rarefied sort of indie-rock success and its attendant stardom
column9: but she’s still left asking the questions you ask once you realize adulthood is not the bed of enlightenment it’s advertised to be. What do I have to show for myself? Am I any smarter than I used to be? Why isn’t this getting easier? And literally: Who have I become?

column1: Fade Away attempts to answer these questions in a single
column2: satisfying way: by returning to the unmistakable elements that characterized Best Coast when they hatched during the fuzzy garage-pop boom a few years ago. She's back with propulsive melodies
column3: a significant dose of reverb
column4: repetition
column5: and sticky
column6: simple lyrics about aimlessness and the type of love that advances at a lackadaisical West Coast pace. The project is a return to form in the most literal of senses
column7: too—it’s out on Cosentino’s new label
column8: Jewel City
column9: and at an unorthodox seven-song length
column10: it has the scrappy
column11: self-governed feel of her band’s early demos
column12: albeit with a bit more polish. There are no name producers in the credits or songs that sound like jingles written for the Los Angeles Department of Tourism. Which is to say there’s nothing on Fade Away that would fit naturally on Best Coast’s slickly inert sophomore album
column13: <i>The Only Place
column14: a record that boasted maturity but never really resonated.

column1: But while it’s tempting to claim that Best Coast have reverted to a simple formula
column2: or to think of Fade Away as an easy stopgap between The Only Place and the band’s next record
column3: that’s not quite what’s happening
column4: either. There are touches of sophistication across Fade Away that Best Coast haven’t been able to achieve until now
column5: and Cosentino glides easily between shades of guitar-pop and chillier sounds. She seems as comfortable on a swooning ballad (“Fade Away”) as she does on a song that harnesses the frenetic sugar of Josie and the Pussycats (“This Lonely Morning”) or the gauzy whisper of Mazzy Star (“Baby I’m Crying”). She’s flexing her muscles as a songwriter
column6: and she makes something that’s probably very difficult sound as though it comes easily to her.

column1: The Cosentino who openly admits to struggle
column2: or to not having figured it all out
column3: then
column4: is now relegated a familiar lyrical space. It can be easy to write her words off as too simplistic
column5: too repetitive
column6: or to dismiss them as retrograde in sentiment
column7: but those qualities are what allow Best Coast to endure in a sea of acts with similar aesthetics. Cosentino is unafraid to fuss over the trivialities of plain old-fashioned love in a time when marriage has been described as the merging of brands. She’s ambivalent or confused about pretty much everything while everyone else’s tastes are codified to Likes. She has become reliably great at distilling a complex range of human emotion to basic sentences
column8: and all of a sudden
column9: the weed leaves and cats and cut-outs of the shape of California are merely kitschy insignias rather than overarching frameworks. ""I won't change/ I'll stay the same
column10: she sings on ""I Wanna Know"". While Cosentino is anxious to figure out who she’s become
column11:
Fade Away points to how strong she’s been all along.

To some
column2: Motörhead will always be more icon than band
column3: a series of irreducible images: frontman Lemmy Kilmister tilting his head to sneer into a downturned mic; his trademark muttonchops
column4: moles
column5: and vintage Rickenbacker; that arresting Gothic-font logo
column6: complete with purely cosmetic umlaut. But Motörhead are
column7: above all
column8: a working outfit. The earthy counterpart to grandiose NWOBHM contemporaries Iron Maiden and Judas Priest
column9: they've positioned themselves as the UK answer to ZZ Top—paring down their palette to the bare essentials
column10: cruising the globe decade after decade
column11: and churning out new material in their unmistakable biker-punk thrash'n'roll idiom.

column1: The three-year interim between Aftershock—the new 21st Motörhead LP—and its 2010 predecessor
column2: The World Is Yours
column3: was an unusually long one for the band
column4: who have averaged a studio album every other year for the duration of their nearly four-decade career. It's tempting to read into the data
column5: given Lemmy's health scare at the Wacken Open Air fest this past August. But if the 67-year-old frontman is slowing down
column6: he's not letting it on here.

column1: Yes
column2: in many ways
column3: Aftershock is just another Motörhead record. The album's ain't-broke
column4: wouldn't-dream-of-fixing-it style won't surprise anyone familiar with the band's current incarnation—the trio of Lemmy
column5: guitarist Phil Campbell
column6: and drummer Mikkey Dee
column7: going strong since 1995. But the measure of a Motörhead LP isn't the wealth of fresh information it provides; it's how well the release encapsulates the band's quintessential sound. The great thing about Motorhead's stubborn unchanging-ness is that each new dispatch has the potential to be their best to date.

column1: So is Aftershock the ultimate Motörhead album? Probably not. Ace of Spades is legendary for a reason
column2: and lesser-known efforts from 1986's quirky yet vicious Orgasmatron to 2004's mighty Inferno deserve places near the top of the canon. But taken on its own terms
column3: the LP is deeply satisfying and frequently thrilling. A listener with no prior knowledge of the band—an alien visitor
column4: let's say
column5: or an amnesiac—could hear this and grasp why Motörhead is rightly considered one of hard rock's true titans.

column1: Aftershock is packed with uptempo ragers
column2: the kind of track that Lemmy seems to stockpile in unlimited supply and that
column3: if you've got a taste for this sort of thing
column4: never gets old. Cranking up album-opening flattener ""Heartbreaker"" or headlong deep cut ""Going to Mexico"" feels like strapping yourself to the underside of a Harley
column5: rumbling in time with the engine
column6: and breathing pure exhaust. (Longtime collaborator Cameron Webb's production job
column7: gritty and full of oomph
column8: is a serious plus in this regard.) As rollicking as these tracks are
column9: they're far from reckless. Lemmy's affinity for the unpretentious craftsmanship of everyone from Chuck Berry to the Ramones isn't always obvious
column10: but Aftershock's brief song lengths and wealth of unshakeable choruses remind you that he's just as fixated on catchiness and concision as on speed and power.

column1: And though you'll often find Lemmy
column2: Campbell
column3: and Dee operating here as a single streamlined entity
column4: skillful arrangements ensure that the listener appreciates the component parts of this classic power trio. Check out how the players enter one-by-one at the beginning of ""Death Machine""
column5: spotlighting the mesmerizing bluster of Lemmy's distorted bass. Meanwhile
column6: the main attraction
column7: the frontman's inimitable gravelly gargle
column8: sounds as visceral as ever. On tracks like the speed-freak anthem ""End of Time""
column9: his delivery seems like a physical paradox
column10: raising the question of how such a brutally weathered instrument can retain such a high degree of melodic precision.

column1: Contrary to their monolithic image
column2: Motörhead has always seasoned their records with a few palate-cleansers
column3: and the ones on Aftershock are especially strong. ""Lost Woman Blues"" is exactly what it sounds like—a moderate-pace 12-bar brooder sung in elegantly understated fashion by a man who's earned his moaning privileges many times over. ""Dust and Glass""
column4: the most atypical track on the record
column5: is also one of the best. Backed by a chilled-out roots-rock tune with shades of Zeppelin
column6: Lemmy muses on life's ephemeral nature in an endearingly fragile sing-song.

column1: Aftershock does have its pedestrian moments. Even allowing for the Sunset Strip lasciviousness that's an integral part of the late-period Motörhead aesthetic
column2: ""Crying Shame""—with its piano-accented refrain and ""C'mon
column3: mama
column4: get down on your knees"" exhortation—still comes uncomfortably close to Great White–style cheese. But the majority of the record is a classic ride-or-die Motörhead proposition
column5: punctuated with just the right amount of breathing room. In theory
column6: what the band does might seem overfamiliar
column7: but in practice
column8:
it's a minor miracle that they're still doing it so well.
