For plenty of bands
column2: going “lo-fi” isn’t a pointed aesthetic choice so much as one made one out of total financial necessity
column3: a chance to sketch out ideas until budgets are secured for proper studio time and creative processes refined to write proper bridges in place of boilerplate feedback. A few years ago
column4: Mississippi-based musician Cole Furlow kicked his can down shitgaze hall by releasing a steady trickle of feedback-swathed pop nuggets as Dead Gaze
column5: which eventually led to a self-titled compilation of several 7’’ singles and cassettes released earlier this year. When a friend offered 11 days of free time at famed Mississippi studio Sweet Tea
column6: he seized the chance to clean up his act. On Brain Holiday
column7: he’s swept away the detritus and placed his personality front and center
column8: revealing a sharp ear for psychedelia-indebted garage rock that doesn't rely on obfuscation to get across.

column1: The new approach is clear from album opener “Yuppies Are Flowers""
column2: which jauntily layers several instruments before ceding the stage to Furlow’s supple voice. Here
column3: that voice grounds what might have been a run-of-the-mill metaphor—people as flowers growing on a tree!—with melodic intuition
column4: giving honesty to a lyric about taking your time to get your act together. “The kids are alright” isn’t a new thesis
column5: but Furlow avoids sounding defensive or snotty about his perceived complacency. If he’s arguing with an imaginary parent about his life plan
column6: his response isn’t a slammed door but a believable reassurance that everything will be alright. (“When you grow up
column7: you’ll see/ All the things that you wanted to see from me”) It’s brave but not boisterous
column8: helping him avoid coming off like just another millennial brat you read about in magazine think pieces. His vocal flexibility
column9: which allows him to sometimes sound as congenial as a band like Rooney—a decade ago
column10: parts of this record would’ve been catnip for The O.C.’s music supervisor—or as unrestrained as Howlin’ Wolf
column11: gives Brain Holiday its nuance. The twinkling arrangement on “Stay
column12: Don’t Stay” might’ve scanned as a little fey were Furlow not there to sound knowingly fragile; meanwhile
column13: “Rowdy Jungle” maximizes its utility as a slacker anthem (“Please believe me when I say there is absolutely nothing that could get in our way"") through a drawl sounds completely sure of itself but totally uninterested in convincing you.

column1: Though Brain Holiday’s lyric sheet would stand alone as a thesis of things Cole Furlow Believes
column2: his ear for collage and crunchy guitar hooks help elevate his words beyond mere didacticism. Most of the album is largely built from familiar garage rock chords—Weezer’s Green Album feels like an easy reference point
column3: as do Ty Segall’s fuzzier records—but that free studio time enabled Furlow to incorporate more disparate elements
column4: such as the mean horn that cuts through the late period Beatles-esque “Runnin on the Moon” and the plaintive piano progression driving “Breathing Creatures”. A more amateur recording definitely wouldn’t have sounded as varied or unmuddled by textural confusion.

column1: When he does default to old habits and amp up the reverb
column2: the creative intent seems more certain. “You’ll Carry on Real Nice”
column3: originally included on the self-titled album and re-recorded here
column4: sounds properly frayed and blown out as Furlow’s voice is stretched to its breaking point. Similarly
column5: “A Different Way” wraps a bold lyric—”I believe there is a different way/ And there’s nothing we can’t do”—in a rumbling
column6: sinuous column of noise like a monument to his willpower. Not all of his decisions are outright home runs
column7: but there’s rarely an unpleasant moment; it's a confident
column8: catchy record that makes you wonder if all lo-fi acts would sound this good if given that studio time
column9: or if Furlow's a real voice of his generation. My bet's on the latter. In the album’s promotional material
column10: Furlow stated his wish to make an album for people to listen “when they need something to get their brain off whatever it is that's making them go to the music in the first place."" Brain Holiday sounds like that kind of safe space
column11:
but it’s also a testament to what can be accomplished when you’re a little distracted.

"|18624.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18624-dead-gaze-brain-holiday/|7.1|Jeremy Gordon

It's kind of hard to believe that Outside
column2: the latest offering from Montreal electronic producer Mike Silver (aka CFCF)

column4: Silver has released a series of EPs that

column6: work as larger statements rather than placeholders. Reliably innovative and stimulating
column7: these efforts helped illuminate the varied intellectual curiosities (architecture
column8: film
column9: objects) that inform his constantly mutating palette
column10: often with arrestingly beautiful results. In the ever-expanding sphere of electronic musicians willing to take risks
column11: Silver managed to stand out thanks to both his willingness to think outside the box and his keen pop sensibilities. So it's no surprise that
column12: on Continent
column13: he's embracing the traditional aspects of the long-player format on Outside
column14: crafting vaporous
column15: understated tracks that often play as updates on vaguely new age-y
column16:
soft rock radio staples.

One of Silver's greatest strengths is his ability to modify his sound while still sounding uniquely like himself. Outside boasts the same familiar textures and colors we've come to expect from CFCF

column20: Peter Gabriel and even Sting

column22: inspired by ""the yearning for stability that comes from constant movement."" Amorous and aching
column23: it's no wonder Silver feels the urge to throw himself from the train

column26:
bleary landscapes rushing past your window.

The most notably different thing about Outside is the return of Silver's actual voice
column27: now more in the foreground than on any of his previous releases. It's unspectacular—hushed
column29: at times almost plainspoken—but one with a deliberate purpose
column30: used to bring more shape and emotional clarity to these pieces. He even goes so far as including a surprisingly faithful cover of Bonnie ""Prince"" Billy's ""Strange Form of Life"". But most of the time
column31: Silver's vocal presence acts as more of a distraction than a guiding light. While a good portion of these songs would sound unfinished without a lyrical component

Active Child assist on ""Train"" notwithstanding.

Much like Continent or any of the subsequent EPs released under the CFCF name
column34: Outside is designed to wash over you

column37: hokey confessional pop. Except this time around

column39: 80s adult contemporary looks. Needless to say

column43: or the funereal ""Miami Vice"" vibes (""This Breath"") that pepper the record. It's not that Silver doesn't successfully develop these ideas
column44:
but he presents them in ways that are too resolute and self serious to be effectively absorbed.

And yet
column47: often overshadowing his cheesier impulses. ""The Forest At Night"" is as revealing a title as any

column54: despite the clear lines that can be drawn from one release to the next. The shadows its shape casts may not always create flattering silhouettes
column55:
but there's both comfort and anticipation to be found in knowing that Silver's constantly tweaking the lighting.

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/19590/homepage_large.568b1c92.jpg|More Constant Than the Gods|30077.0|SubRosa|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Profound Lore']|2013-10-21 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:51:43.332663|"

“Fat of the Ram”—the pugnacious and swirling fourth track on the new album from fascinating Salt Lake City doom metal band SubRosa—is a folk song. Never mind the weighty guitars that hang like thick shadows or the forceful drums that punch through them. Forget the enraged voices that bellow the lyrics and the slide guitar line that closes tight like a noose
column2: too. Instead
column3: listen to what Rebecca Vernon has to sing: She sets a scene of accepted and quiet suffering
column4: where lakes go septic and unhappiness gets swept under the rug. Dreams are dreamt only in the privacy of homes and otherwise suppressed. The rich lords expect to be left alone
column5: to be given time to “anoint themselves in their finest.” Vernon ends with a glimpse of possible redemption
column6: a Plato’s Cave moment where the narrator intuits life outside of the town’s shadowy desolation. This is the lament of a layperson holding onto the distant promise of hope
column7: a tune not unlike one that Harry Smith might’ve collected.

column1: This isn’t surprising for SubRosa. On 2011’s No Help for the Mighty Ones
column2: the band covered the morose
column3: damned-to-hell Scottish ballad “The House Carpenter”
column4: a song Vernon admits she first heard through Smith’s Anthology of American Folk Music. But that was just an eerie a cappella interpretation. “Fat of the Ram”
column5: like the rest of More Constant than the Gods
column6: is an exceptionally articulated full-band assault
column7: arranged to give each song and story beneath it maximum impact. Often in doom
column8: the impulse can be to turn up and drown out
column9: treating the song mostly as a reason for amplifier massages. (To wit
column10: see the recent Windhand LP
column11: Soma.) This quintet—two violins
column12: three vocalists
column13: bass
column14: drums and Vernon’s wonderful guitar—are much more meticulous than that
column15: treating each number like its own opera rather than an excuse for an onslaught. Combined with Vernon’s uncommonly keen ear for hooks (however dark-hearted they may be) and the band’s grand sense of dynamics
column16: that approach keeps More Constant than the Gods moving throughout its 68 minutes. It’s too active and involving to become a slog or a bore. Instead
column17: it’s one of the year’s most exhilarating heavy metal records.

column1: The members of SubRosa seem to understand these songs and what Vernon is trying to communicate with them
column2: as if she workshopped the lyrics in front of them. The playing is never too deep or too wide
column3: always moving in service of her meaning. The irritation and insurrection written into “Fat of the Ram”
column4: for instance
column5: shows up in the music
column6: with its start-and-stop lashes of sound directed at the blindly content townsfolk and their scheming leaders. “Everywhere I look/ all I see is famine
column7: ” Vernon sings at one point
column8: her voice suddenly downshifting into droll scorn. The music slows into a formless blur behind her
column9: underlining the desperation in her observation. It’s Leadbelly kicked forward several decades. Likewise
column10: “The Usher” opens with a duet above a twinkling bed of noise
column11: Vernon trading lines with the gentle-voiced Jason McFarland as a violin etches curlicues against the din. The band finally lunges forward in unison
column12: affixing their heaviness to a surprisingly forward tempo. This is a love song to the dark and to mortality
column13: so SubRosa afford it a sinister romanticism. Bright violin leads peeking out through the down-tuned glumness
column14: and the feeling is terrifying but warm.

column1: The spirit doesn’t dovetail with the song only in these epics. Each of Constant’s six tracks either ignores or approaches the 10-minute mark
column2: except for the seven-minute “Cosey Mo”
column3: practically making it a radio single. SubRosa lend the tale of immortal grievances and obsessions appropriate drama. The strings are essential here. In the chorus
column4: the violins of Sarah Pendleton and Kim Pack surge behind the guitars and vocals
column5: helping to brand the refrain into memory. During a slinking little midsection
column6: they trace pizzicato patterns around the gathering storm of Vernon’s voice. Finally
column7: as the coda crests
column8: they mirror and then fight against Vernon’s riff
column9: reflecting the unresolved tension of the song’s quest to avenge or at least vindicate a death. Though “Cosey Mo” is the record’s shortest and most immediate song
column10: it’s not the only one capable of planting a hook. “Affliction” turns its imprecation into an indelible if understated chorus. “Ghosts of a Dead Empire”
column11: a send-up of missions for purity and perfection
column12: doesn’t necessarily have a refrain
column13: but its conclusion is memorable and haunting. Vernon’s tune moves evenly with the blown-out riff
column14: matched by harmonies and the emphatic wallop of the rhythm section. It’s a moment of post-metal triumph
column15: with splendor and volume spiraling into one radiant climax.

column1: SubRosa’s first two albums were strong testaments from a doom band with an interesting lineup and manifest interests outside of metal. On More Constant than the Gods
column2: they’ve not only managed to synthesize those enthusiasms but to do so while this strange tangle of musicians works together—unselfishly and with complete subservience to the bigger picture of song
column3: statement
column4: and album. There’s folk storytelling and alt-rock worthy choruses
column5:
doom intensity and classical grandeur. It’s hard not to be caught up in the incredible power of SubRosa’s sounds and the wide-screen permanence of their songs.  

"|18395.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18395-subrosa-more-constant-than-the-gods/|8.3|Grayson Currin

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/19854/homepage_large.e6e55708.jpg|Cut 4 Me|31712.0|Kelela|['Pop/R&B']|1.0|0.0|0.0|['Fade to Mind']|2013-10-18 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:51:44.008806|"

It used to take ages for underground sounds to find their way into mainstream pop music. Information moved more slowly
column2: recordings took more time to produce
column3: and there were layers of cultural gatekeepers to be navigated in the process
column4: so subcultures that craved obscurity could usually find it. The internet and digital recording technology have changed that. Now
column5: if your timing’s right
column6: you can see a specific synth sound or drum programming technique make its way from some nobody producer’s SoundCloud page to pop radio in maybe a couple of months
column7: but sometimes in just weeks.

column1: The shadowy postdubstep underground bass music scene
column2: for instance
column3: is currently finding itself thrust into the spotlight by Kanye
column4: Drake
column5: and their legions of followers who've adopted increasingly dark-toned aesthetic identities informed by artists like SBTRKT and Arca. This scrutiny and appropriation will only intensify in the wake of Lorde’s Pure Heroine
column6: which transmuted minimalist bass music that would've qualified as avant garde only a few months ago into chart gold. So what does a musical community with a preference for operating under the pop-cultural radar do when mainstream artists start knocking it off for parts? The smartest and most productive thing would be to launch its own competing
column7: alternative product: And now it has
column8: in the form of Kelela Mizanekristos.

column1: Raised in the Maryland suburbs around D.C. on a diet of 1990s pop-R&B divas before relocating to the bustling L.A. bass scene
column2: Kelela is attempting to do what dozens of top-tier singers
column3: songwriters
column4: and producers are also trying
column5: which is to take the moody sounds of the sorts of electronic musicians orbiting club nights/labels/collectives like Night Slugs and Fade to Mind
column6: and give them a more pop-friendly spin that will appeal to listeners who don’t normally go in for severely dark dance music.

column1: Unlike other singers working at similar aims
column2: Kelela is tight enough with the Fade to Mind/Night Slugs crews to collaborate with them directly
column3: so her beats come straight from the source: Bok Bok
column4: Nguzunguzu
column5: Girl Unit
column6: FtM founder Kingdom
column7: and other affiliated artists who’ve helped define a booming
column8: severely stripped-down sound pieced together from bits of techno
column9: grime
column10: R&B
column11: drum & bass
column12: and dubstep’s pre-neon days. It’s well-constructed launchpad that she’s acquired for herself
column13: and she doesn’t waste it.

column1: Cut 4 Me is an ambitiously catchy record as well as being an aesthetically ambitious one. Essential to this is Kelela’s decision to play against the beats' moodiness—that juxtaposition drives the album’s likability. The beat by NA for “Do It Again” is horror-movie creepy
column2: with a hypnotic John Carpenter-like keyboard figure looping over booming haunted house drums
column3: which she decided to use as the foundation for an slow-motion sex jam straight out of the Aaliyah playbook. The Nguzunguzu-produced “Enemy” is as twitchily abrasive as the most staunchly underground first-wave dubstep
column4: so she tops it with a cotton-candy pop-R&B vocal that could have been lifted from a turn of the millennium Brandy B-side.

column1: Kelela’s an unlikely diva for a scene that’s attracted more than its share of dance music purists who don’t go in for frippery like vocalists
column2: but it works. She also needs to close some of the gap between her ambition and what her voice is capable of—it’s a perfectly good voice
column3: but lacks much of the expressiveness and power that singers who don’t come by those things naturally need time to develop. But this kind of works
column4: too. A full-blast diva would obliterate the subtlety that the beats rely on
column5: and the spunky-newcomer charisma that her performance projects imparts crucial warmth to their icy sounds.

column1: The voice can be worked on
column2: though. The more important things that Cut 4 Me teaches us about Kelela are that she has the taste to pick out a fantasy all-star team of collaborators
column3: the talent to make herself heard over their beats
column4: and the intelligence to get it all together at the exact right moment. That’s all instinct
column5: and that can’t be learned. If she wants pop stardom—if not the five-star kind like Rihanna
column6:
then at least the cultishly-adored kind like her former tourmate Solange—she couldn’t be in a better place.

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/19805/homepage_large.0dc11386.jpg|Big Wheel and Others|2714.0|Cass McCombs|['Folk/Country']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Domino']|2013-10-18 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:51:44.210486|"

Few things are as quintessentially American as the mythos surrounding the West. Manifest destiny
column2: the romance of wide open plains and broken landscapes
column3: get rich quick schemes
column4: and old-fashioned wandering. Cass McCombs’ seventh full-length album
column5: <i>Big Wheel and Others
column6: takes root in this fertile soil of Americana
column7: crafting a sprawling cosmology out of its characters from the past two centuries. When <a href=""http://www.avclub.com/articles/cass-mccombs
column8: 59276/"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">I interviewed McCombs in 2011 around the time of Wit’s End
column9: he confessed a fixation on northern California’s history of “drugs
column10: gunslingers
column11: and gold.” Where he took this fixation two years later reveals all one needs to know about the wry
column12: reclusive singer-songwriter.

column1: Wheel opens with a child’s voice
column2: blithely talking about his drug use. This turns out to be an audio clip from Sean
column3: a 1969 documentary about a 4-year-old raised by Haight-Ashbury hippies. In McCombs’ mind Sean isn’t a tragic figure
column4: however
column5: but a stand-in for the unregulated San Francisco of the acid-testing 1960s. For McCombs
column6: Sean’s creepily unregulated upbringing aligns with a broader history of the Wild West
column7: like the Gold Rush’s ruthless Barbary Coast district from a century earlier
column8: and the shiftless drifters populating highway on-ramps and truck stops to this day.

column1: An eight-minute run on Side 2 encapsulates much of Wheel’s own mythology. In another edited movie clip
column2: after solidly affirming that “there’s no God around
column3: ” because “the whole world is the Indians’ world
column4: ” Sean is prompted for his thoughts on America. “You know America
column5: ” he replies. “Half of the world.” For McCombs
column6: such a naïve assertion isn’t cause to rail against patriotic chauvinism
column7: but a perfect segue into the languid Roger McGuinn-style folk-rock of “Home on the Range”. An original composition
column8: “Range” references the 19th century ode to life in Kansas
column9: rumbling with cattle and surrounded by the infinite horizons of what at the time was the American West—and for residents
column10: the entire world. The idea that Sean in 1969 shares a shrunken worldview with a Romantic 1870s rancher is not lost on McCombs. Much of Wheel emanates from this notion: the size of one’s world
column11: and the shape of one’s belief system
column12: equates to imagination plus experience.

column1: Appropriately for an album with such broad aims
column2: Wheel itself is sprawling. With an 85-minute runtime
column3: it covers most most of the musical themes and narrative fixations McCombs has drawn upon since his 2003 debut. Since that time
column4: he’s quietly become one of America’s finest chroniclers of fringe characters
column5: a writer of heart-rending love songs and psychedelic odes to the natural world
column6: a teller of tall-tales with a sense of humor dry as desert wood
column7: and that rare folksinger who actually sings about the folk. Over the last decade
column8: McCombs has been a remarkably consistent
column9: if not publicity-averse
column10: singer-songwriter
column11: comparable to Bill Callahan and Will Oldham as our foremost translators of Old
column12: Weird America into modern terms (and vice-versa). Appropriately
column13: then
column14: the lead character of “Range” is not taken with the beauty of his surroundings
column15: but in a milder form of lawnessness. “I believe in littering
column16: ” he croons to open the song. “Waste should not be hidden
column17: but seen.”

column1: Musically
column2: McCombs mixes light and dark in a similar way. His songs are often cast with an eerie serenity
column3: emanating both from his soft vocals and fondness for guitar-led arrangements that glide between sections. His songs are often very pretty
column4: though always invested with a palpable
column5: if not quite visible
column6: sense of foreboding. This  befits the characters of Wheel
column7: most of whom are alone—some desperately so—and seeking redemption
column8: if not simply trying to prove something to themselves. A sweet
column9: loping love song is set between a couple “broken down for days at a free motel/ under the Oregon ridge.” On the brooding lament “My Name Written in Water”
column10: McCombs trails a character escaping the suburbs for time spent amongst the ancient majesty of Utah mesas. Quoting Hamlet’s time-worn soliloquy on mortality
column11: he’s concerned not with where to get gas
column12: but with how the words he’s writing will represent him after he’s gone.

column1: Elsewhere
column2: McCombs packs the album full of outsize
column3: masculine characters in the mold of “Lionkiller”. Early along the tracklist is the swaggering trucker of “Big Wheel” who bags lot lizards and spouts idioms like bumper stickers (“A man is bolts
column4: a man is rust/ For a little while
column5: then the man is dust”). There’s “Joe Murder”
column6: a Coen Brothers-style telling of “Cortez the Killer”
column7: on which McCombs uncoils a sinister guitar lead grumbling with intensity
column8: while shaping the titular drug-runner through his personality quirks. Joe Murder “cut with milk sugar
column9: to eliminate cost
column10: ” to which McCombs adds: “such a frugal drifter.” Then there’s the shit-talking narrator of “Satan is My Toy”
column11: letting loose a series of randy
column12: schoolyard-quality couplets
column13: eliding curse word punchlines and relying on the listener to fill in the blanks. It’s McCombs in Nick Cave drag
column14: and the kind of song you’d expect to hear pour out of a biker bar when a fight erupts into the alley through the front doors.

column1: These songs have more muscle than the typical McCombs song
column2: with “Wheel” chugging like V-12 pistons
column3: and “Satan” smoldering with sticky saxophone smears. This befits their subject matter as well as the vibe of the album
column4: on which McCombs plays with genre more explicitly than usual. This wide-ranging approach seems to be one of Wheel’s guiding principles
column5: only once resulting in an eyebrow-raising inclusion
column6: when halfway through the album he drops a fairly inexplicable three-and-a-half minute jazz-rock instrumental. Coming from McCombs
column7: who ended PREfection with six-plus minutes of ambient car-alarm and then opened Dropping the Writ two years later with the same sound fading out
column8: such a move should be expected
column9: if not honored. Likely he’s giving us an intermission.

column1: As taken as he is with the American West as a stark
column2: limitless canvas for his characters to make their own
column3: it’s likely McCombs has an affinity for Bobby Dupea
column4: the volatile
column5: shiftless oil-well rigger from 1970’s Five Easy Pieces. Dupea has everything he could want
column6: but discards it all in fits of selfishness and unacknowledged confusion as he drives from California to Washington. Foremost among those left behind is Dupea’s girlfriend Rayette Dipesto
column7: a Tammy Wynette-worshipping waitress and the film’s saddest character. Karen Black was nominated for an Oscar for her portrayal of Rayette
column8: though it’s likely that a generation discovered her 40 years later
column9: through her haunting vocals on Catacombs’ “Dreams-Come-True-Girl”.

column1: Black died this past August
column2: and McCombs not only dedicated Wheel to her memory
column3: but gave her the lead on the second of the album’s two versions of “Brighter!” Musically
column4: the song bears mid-tempo similarities to the Orbisonian theater of “Dreams-Come-True-Girl”
column5: though it differs thematically. At once
column6: “Brighter!” is a spiritual invocation and a melancholy tale of a directionless life. “I stopped in for a little while
column7: and learned a host of sins
column8: ” Black sings in her highest register. “I wandered off a little while
column9: because you can never win.” Somewhere within the 74-year-old Black’s delivery on this couplet lies a strong hint as to McCombs’ complex moral universe: if you stop moving too long
column10:
you won’t like what you learn.

"|18612.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18612-cass-mccombs-big-wheel-and-others/|7.9|Eric Harvey

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/19855/homepage_large.f1f2245f.jpg|Forever Becoming|3472.0|Pelican|['Metal']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Southern Lord']|2013-10-18 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:51:44.861721|"

Instrumental rock bands engender a feverish devotion. Groups like Mogwai and Godspeed You! Black Emperor boast rabid fanbases yet get raked over the coals—much of the time by those same fans. But
column2: perhaps none of the aforementioned groups have seen the kind of ""Crossfire""-level handwringing as Chicago's Pelican. Couple the group's four-year hiatus with the fact that they often toe a line that dips into metal territory—another style that claims adherents quick to nitpick—and you’ve got a recipe for controversy. But
column3: on Forever Becoming’s second track
column4: Pelican seem to be issuing a gag order of sorts. Two minutes into “Deny the Absolute”
column5: it’s apparent that the band is as heavy and anthemic as ever. Pelican can’t hear you above the din.

column1: “Deny the Absolute” is a remarkable song with an even more striking center. It chugs along ominously and fiercely like something Colonel Kilgore might have selected to play after “Ride of the Valkyries”. It’s utterly thrilling
column2: a testament to Pelican’s present unity. Oft-maligned drummer Larry Herweg keeps a tight beat
column3: while his brother
column4: Bryan
column5: unleashes a thrusting bass assault. And
column6: to reiterate
column7: it is heavy: the kind of track that a baseball closer might be wise to adopt as entry music.

column1: It’s the pinnacle of Forever Becoming
column2: but the record has other worthwhile moments. “The Tundra” paces forward with a vigorous clip and ignites in its last minute. It’s further testimony that Pelican are at their best in synced-up moments. “Immutable Dusk” is more ruminative
column3: splitting the difference between the sounds of Explosions in the Sky and
column4: say
column5: Isis or Neurosis. (Most of the song titles on Forever Becoming could be easily mistaken for lost Sylvia Plath poems or
column6: at least
column7: the wall scribblings of a Sarah Lawrence College sophomore. As a recent press release ponderously reports: “Forever Becoming is an immense
column8: speaker-rattling meditation on the infinite cycle of death and life.”) “Dusk” is followed by another epic
column9: “Threnody”
column10: which adeptly explores the poles between quiet and noise.

column1: Many instrumental bands exploit builds
column2: and while Pelican do so with tact
column3: you can be left wanting more variation and exploration. “Threnody” moves from tickled picking into a teamed-up crescendo. It’s a trip
column4: the quartet—which includes guitarists Trevor de Brauw and Dallas Thomas—strumming as quickly as possible. Still
column5: it’s all a bit familiar. Haven’t others plotted out this territory previously and more effectively? And
column6: further
column7: hasn’t Pelican? Certainly
column8: a track like “Autumn Into Summer”
column9: from 2005’s Fire In Our Throats Will Beckon the Thaw
column10: uses its nearly 11 minutes to expertly showcase a raw and bold post-rock. The layered guitars on it (one of them is played by Laurent Schroeder-Lebec
column11: who departed the band last year and was replaced by Swan King’s Thomas) converse and converge with each other in a way not found on Forever Becoming.

column1: Pelican’s harder sound makes such earlier developments hazy. Yet
column2: the band comes back to them awkwardly. The album’s closer
column3: “Perpetual Dawn”
column4: is a dead-ringer for a tune Mogwai would choose to cap an LP or show. But it’s that fact—that Mogwai or Godspeed or Explosions could be playing it—which is troubling. It’s an oversimplification to declare that a share of post-rock “sounds the same” but
column5: sometimes
column6: Pelican suffers from being too weighed down by its roots. That said
column7:
when Pelican rages—in a way they never have before—they prove they still have plenty of life left.

"|18662.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18662-pelican-forever-becoming/|7.2|Colin St. John

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/19715/homepage_large.2c3b6fd9.jpg|Guitar Sounds|23340.0|Schneider TM|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Bureau B']|2013-10-18 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:51:46.503482|"

Dirk Dresselhaus
column2: who has recorded as Schneider TM since the late 1990s
column3: was once described as ""something like a German Beck."" Anyone coming to his recent music cold at this point would be justified in finding that description baffling
column4: although it's important to understand his fondness for artistic rebirth. Dresselhaus toyed with the poppy side of glitchtronica on his 2002 album Zoomer
column5: a record that remains the best known work in his canon. Guitar Sounds is about as far away from that as you can get
column6: instead emphasizing his aptitude for drone oriented pieces
column7: improvisation
column8: and explorations on the margins of music. Dresselhaus isn't too interested in formal musical constructs
column9: as highlighted on the album he released directly before this one
column10: the self-explanatory Construction Sounds. ""Whatever makes sound can be music
column11: he told the Quietus in a recent interview. ""But many things that count as music are not.""

column1: Unravelling the oblique statements Dresselhaus makes in interviews is analogous to the experience of listening to his music. Guitar Sounds has the air of a code that can't be deciphered
column2: or a puzzle with a few pieces missing. The fact that all the music is wrung out of a guitar is practically irrelevant-- this is the kind of piece that works best when it causes you to forget about the world. Getting hung up on how parts were formed
column3: how shapes were made
column4: is a shade of removal too far from its waves of noise. Not that this is a ""noise"" record
column5: per se. Mostly it's only loosely defined
column6: oscillating between parts that resemble the sparse neo-Morricone pieces of Neil Young's Dead Man soundtrack and manipulations that cause Dresselhaus' strumming to resemble Warren Ellis' emotive violin playing in the Dirty Three. At other times he sounds like a squeaky bedpost. Somehow
column7: he ties this all together in a way that follows a curious kind of logic.

column1: Mostly Guitar Sounds feels like a throwback to the 90s
column2: specifically to the point when artists loosely bracketed under the post-rock banner were gaining critical traction. There's no adherence to rhythm here in the way that
column3: say
column4: the best Tortoise work had
column5: but David Grubbs' playing in Gastr del Sol comes to mind at times
column6: particularly in the moments where Dresselhaus sounds like he's engaged in a struggle against his instrument
column7: purposefully making it do exactly what it's not designed to do. The difference is that it felt like Grubbs was building an aesthetic on albums like <i>Crookt
column8: Crackt
column9: or Fly
column10: where he found a suitable place to bed down in for a while. Dresselhaus picks things up and discards them quickly
column11: even shifting into work that resembles his own placid electronic pieces. There's not a great deal of focus here
column12: no overall thrust to cling onto. It's like watching someone ghost through styles
column13: only notionally getting to grips with them.

column1: Something that connects this work and Construction Sounds is the grating edge that Dresselhaus adds. Guitar Sounds has a decent amount of industrial grind stirred into its pallet
column2: with the guitar reconfigured as a power tool
column3: spraying disharmony in its wake. Still
column4: it's a feeling that is
column5: at times
column6: a little too similar to the one explored by Einstürzende Neubauten and Throbbing Gristle several decades earlier
column7: where all of music's ugly entrails are bled out. When Dresselhaus goes down that route it sets a wildly uneven tone
column8: somewhere between entrancing and aimless
column9: with certain facets of music history bearing down just a little too hard on his shoulder for it to become fully dislocating. Guitar Sounds works primarily as a series of exercises
column10: and it's hard not to feel that it could have been so much more than that
column11:
especially in those moments where Dresselhaus unties his brain from the world and follows his intuition.

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/19821/homepage_large.a325aaee.jpg|Timescales|31738.0|Deco|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Deceast']|2013-10-18 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:51:47.068700|"

As electronic musicians go
column2: Deco's lucked out: he's had the opportunity to keep his early feeling-out process largely under the radar. He hasn't been invisible—far from it
column3: thanks to the benefit of DJing in L.A. club circles and on internet radio. But his debut full-length Timescales comes as a surprise
column4: albeit a kind of scattershot and amorphous one. It's largely because it synthesizes so many familiar pieces so well—abstracted West Coast G-funk
column5: reverbed microhouse
column6: vintage-Hyperdub space bass—that it leaves no clue as to where his further directions could even go. It's a rare moment of fully-formed emergence from a musician who's more or less announcing himself to the wider world with a pastiche that sounds like an endpoint
column7: the kind of thing that comes from a decade's worth of evolution rather than the breakthrough release of someone who's practically unfindable on Discogs right now.

column1: The big ""what next"" can wait
column2: though. Even if Timescales threatens to revert to weathered ideas of what it means to hybridize the last few innovations in L.A.-via-wherever underground dance music
column3: the record makes no pretense of acting like it's a forward-thinking revolution. Deco shows off that DJ/curator's sense of knowing his context and history and how to merge those ideas into something evocative
column4: even if it's not necessarily evocative of something you haven't heard before. In short
column5: it's comfort sound for beat heads.

column1: Working with a bunch of known quantities doesn't keep Timescales from actually harboring some subtle resonance or deeper feeling
column2: however. Bait-and-switch is a crucial part of the formula
column3: as expectations dredged up by the best songs' early moments are gradually twisted around or otherwise tweaked in mood-altering ways. ""Skyline 3040"" teems with ambient digital-mechanical bleeps and burbles
column4: anticipating some glimmery future-kitsch manipulation of cyberpunk landscape as Apple-interface utopia—until the deep buzzing chords come in and cast a harsher
column5: lonelier light on its gradually intensifying Kode9-lineage snares. That dynamic cuts the other way
column6: too
column7: the looming dread of ""Late Night Fading"" breaking apart and settling into tranquility thanks to a canny sample flip of Cymande's ""Dove"" that plays up its guitar tone's floaty qualities.

column1: Given enough comfortable genre signifiers to work with
column2: Deco has a lot of precedent he can manipulate to unexpected ends. At least
column3: he does when it suits him—sometimes
column4: going right down the middle with a straightforward take on dark
column5: stripped-down dubstep (""Musical Family""
column6: ""Trenchtown"") or coolly simmering deep house (""At Most Sphere""
column7: ""Power Transfer"") is effective enough. But it's clear that the more leftfield moments work best
column8: balancing out subtle
column9: technical grooves with jolting chords that find anxiety somewhere in the soulfulness. Zone in on the hypnotic
column10: dubbed-out buildups that lead State Route 1 to Studio One on ""Cali Trunk Rattle"" or the title track's bracing incorporation of tight-packed drumline fills
column11: and the odd minor-key synth hits and slippery counter-beats can bolt right out at you. A few more cuts like those
column12: where thematic about-faces and joy-buzzer fills are snuck in under the cover of tradition-minded accessibility
column13:
and Deco could turn out to be some kind of low-key iconoclast.

Brows were furrowed and lips pursed when ""Kool FM""

column5: abstracting that era's chopter rhythms and throaty MCs. Kieran Hebden has developed a bit of a johnny-come-lately reputation among certain observers
column6: though
column7: his plunges into UK bass music viewed as harmless and well meaning but perhaps a bit awkward. ""Kool FM"" seemed to be the latest instance of Hebden chasing dance music's tail: over the last 12 or so months
column8: many artists returned to the breakbeat-based club music—popularized in the UK in the early and mid 90s—whose rhythms are sourced from funky
column9: sampled drum breaks rather than from more rigid and electronic drum synthesizers. Even amongst those who sought only to commemorate jungle
column10: rather than recreate or refine it
column11: Hebden might've been late.

column1: But if Hebden has been hopping trends
column2: he's been doing so fruitfully. ""Love Cry""
column3: from 2010's excellent There Is Love in You
column4: became an actual club hit
column5: as did several of the tracks from last year's Pink
column6: a compilation of extended
column7: dance-friendly singles. Hebden found a way to adhere to dance music's strictures and conventions while still applying his sun-dappled psychedelia
column8: stretching his easy melodic ideas over terse rhythms and rubbery basslines. Pink was ""Four Tet does dance music"" but
column9: hey! Four Tet's doing dance music!

column1: Likewise
column2: Beautiful Rewind borrows without apology from a trend but sounds undeniably like a Four Tet record. Jungle
column3: with its mighty musical appetite and don't-give-a-fuck sampling culture
column4: might be a nice fit for Four Tet
column5: whose music has always relied heavily on samples. Crucially
column6: it's not jungle's mangled breakbeats that interest Hebden so much as its MCs: sound-system junkies shouting up the DJs
column7: themselves
column8: or just babbling rhythmically. These gruff utterances run counterpoint to Hebden's beatific melodies and cooing female voices. There's plenty of friction: jungle and rave famously threw traditional notions of good musical taste out the window
column9: while Hebden's output
column10: with its patient tunefulness and cordial radiance
column11: is nothing if not tasteful.

column1: Beautiful Rewind echoes the ephemeral aspects of jungle
column2: the infectious rush of the new
column3: the patter of voices through radio static
column4: rather than the functional signifiers—quickening tempos
column5: mangled breakbeats—that defined it. The album serves as a compact
column6: romantic remembrance: prettier
column7: milder
column8: and less funky than its inspiration. It also feels very personal
column9: like these moments are Hebden's own recollections
column10: his own tangential relationship with a subculture. Where albums like There Is Love in You and Rounds felt inviting
column11: loving even
column12: Beautiful Rewind sometimes seems like it's drawing connections that mean more to Hebden than they ever will to us.

column1: Take
column2: for instance
column3: late-album stormers ""Buchla"" and ""Aerial""
column4: which masterfully integrate sampled MCs into their herky-jerky rhythms but fail to complement ""Unicorn""'s shimmering pools of melody. The stirring
column5: chaotic opener ""Gong"" recalls Hebden's collaborations with Burial
column6: but its steamy urban roughage is cleansed by ""Parallel Jalebi""'s tidy thrum. It's during transitions like these when Rewind comes unstitched
column7: when it feels more like a small bundle of Four Tet productions than an album.

column1: At just over 40 minutes
column2: Beautiful Rewind is an effortless listen
column3: but when it wanders it feels like a bauble
column4: one from an artist from whom we are accustomed to receiving richer gifts. Hebden has previously turned a lack of precision into broad
column5: idyllic albums
column6: but Beautiful Rewind feels as though it's circling
column7: cautiously looking for a place to land. There are still plenty of treats
column8: especially when those jungle MCs are able to unmoor Hebden from his default state of bliss-y
column9: pastoral expanse. Beautiful Rewind is staked on the past
column10: but for as much flack as Hebden takes for repeating what other artists have already done
column11:
Rewind falters most when Hebden does little more than repeat himself.

There’s a lot of self happening on the ninth proper Bonnie ""Prince"" Billy album. Will Oldham played everything himself
column2: recorded it himself
column3: released it himself
column4: and even distributed it himself by hand to record stores. Most significantly
column5: the music on Bonnie ""Prince"" Billy exudes an individual perspective—nearly every song is written in the first person
column6: and Oldham’s spare acoustic guitar
column7: breathy vocals
column8: and close-up production form a contemplative inner monologue.

column1: There’s one more bit of self about Bonnie “Prince” Billy that’s important: the fact that Oldham decided to make it self-titled. The last time he went that route was on 1994’s Palace Brothers (later re-titled Days in the Wake). That was also the last time he made a full-length album with
column2: for the most part
column3: just his voice and acoustic guitar. The result was one of the finest records in his oeuvre
column4: a suite of intimate sketches studded with now-classics like “Pushkin” and “I Am A Cinematographer"". He must’ve thought of that album while making this one<i>
column5: and when judged against its predecessor Bonnie ""Prince"" Billy measures up quite well.

column1: That’s due partially to how perfectly the solo acoustic format fits Oldham’s melding of vocals and lyrics. He weaves them together so tightly that it’s hard to tell singer from song
column2: and that’s clearest when it’s just him and a guitar. His voice shakes
column3: stretches and cracks around notes
column4: approaching rather than hitting them
column5: and his words similarly skirt themes and flirt with meaning. Concrete ideas and images emerge
column6: but nothing is ever so defined that a single interpretation is clear. Often my first impression of a song flips on subsequent listen
column7: when one bent note or one turn of phrase that I didn’t notice before makes me rethink the rest. At best Oldham’s songs are powerfully ambiguous
column8: and that’s true of all of them on Bonnie ""Prince"" Billy.

column1: This time around
column2: Oldham finds ambiguity in the elusive concept of the self—what it is
column3: how it changes
column4: how it will end. A few of these tunes are ostensibly about relationships
column5: but even those center on the self and its struggle to connect. “I see you go on/ and I go too
column6: but not with you
column7: ” Oldham sings in the album’s second song
column8: “Lessons from Stony""
column9: his voice rising with caution. On the next tune
column10: “Triumph of Will""
column11: he laments that he and his partner are “never lost together… We are two separate people/ We never will be one.” By song’s end the couple have willed their way to unity
column12: but it’s a triumph that doesn’t last long.

column1: From there
column2: Oldham becomes increasingly pessimistic about love. “All our hearts are stained and every love is tainted
column3: ” he declares at one point
column4: and later “there is no heaven for love
column5: it simply dies.” He also becomes increasingly obsessed with mortality
column6: both fascinated and terrified by death of the self. On “I Will Be Born Again” he sings the title repetitively as if trying to convince himself of the impossible. On the deceptively upbeat “This is My Cocktail” he admits fearing two things: “losing my mind
column7: losing my body.” And by the time of “Ending it All (As I Do)
column8: ” he sounds resigned: “the beginning of ending is already done.” Throughout these musings
column9: his guitar winds around like a stream of consciousness
column10: shifting between simple melodies and looser
column11: less certain structures.

column1: It may sound like Bonnie ""Prince"" Billy is an intense listen
column2: but much of it is also spry and catchy
column3: and some of it is pretty funny too. One song about a pig kept in a chest at the foot of a bed plays like a surrealist cartoon
column4: and even when Oldham is staring at death
column5: he stays wry and absurd
column6: dropping humorous motifs throughout. A particularly amusing one is his persistent use of the word “fun
column7: ” which is held up as a kind of life-goal holy grail. But its attainment is always uncertain
column8: which gives the album tension.

column1: That uncertainty
column2: and Oldham’s sense of the self as constant flux
column3: also give Bonnie ""Prince’""Billy a Zen feel—and
column4: by the end
column5: a meditative calm. Closer “Royal Quiet Deluxe” describes driving down a highway to escape a failed relationship
column6: but also to meet something greater. “If we die many times
column7: then let death come to me
column8: ” he sings spiritedly—and then suddenly switches into a upbeat epilogue. “This is the last song of its kind
column9: ” he croons as if he’s peacefully accepted his demise
column10: or moved on to something new. It’s one of the most sublime moments in a musical career already full of them—and it ends with the album’s sunniest line: “Ain’t it the best?” Once you’ve taken this fascinating journey with Oldham
column11:
it’s hard not to agree.

column2: but Courtney Barnett can do them all one better: Her TV has been broken for four years and she’s been too lazy to fix it. She reveals this detail and further underachiever credentials in a long
column3: charismatically ambling song off her double EP A Sea of Split Peas

The song—which pairs a few jangly chords with Barnett’s lazy-Tuesday drawl—alternates between the questions of a concerned parent (""Are you working hard my darling?/ We’re so worried"") and Barnett’s libertine responses (""I don’t want no 9 to 5/ Telling me that I’m alive/ And 'Man
column5: you’re doing well!'""). About halfway through
column6: Barnett’s guilty conscience emerges: Maybe she should get a job
column7: or a husband
column8: or at the very least a dog. But then the song goes on for another carefree three-and-a-half minutes

column11: sleepy towns. ""It’s a Monday

column1: The irony

If there’s one single song that can justify the existence of Paul McCartney’s 24th studio album since leaving the Beatles
column2: it’s track number five

column5: but fairly quickly the song resolves into something much more interesting. While the verses are a rose-tinted reminiscence of McCartney and John Lennon’s brief period of pre-fame friendship in Liverpool
column6: the choruses project something altogether different: “They can’t take it from me/ if they try/ I lived through those early days.” Whereas most of his hippie-era pop contemporaries enthusiastically embraced self-hagiography decades ago
column7: McCartney’s relationship with nostalgia is complicated

column9: and by embracing these complications he offers an understandably human portrait of a position few of us will ever find ourselves in: watching your life story being converted into mythology by forces outside of your control.

column1: But really

column1: Overseeing the whole project is Giles Martin

too.

Tim Hecker’s first album under his own name was called Haunt Me

column1: From its title down
column2: Haunt Me presented a model of electronic music that was spectral
column3: imperfect
column4: and capable of erosion. The most applicable metaphors for it weren’t technological

column1: Virgins is the first Tim Hecker album more focused on performance than process. Most of it was recorded with a small group of orchestral musicians affiliated with Bedroom Community

column5: and co-produced Oneohtrix Point Never’s R Plus Seven at Bedroom Community’s Greenhouse Studios in Reykjavik; Oneohtrix Point Never’s Dan Lopatin collaborated with Hecker on 2011’s Instrumental Tourist: The world of forward-thinking electro-acoustic music is a small and fraternal one.)

column1: The live-room conceit is an interesting turn for an artist who for a long time worked in a primarily digital realm: Rather than having the music conjure a space
column2: the space now shapes the music—a return to idea of sound as something that exists in the air before on hard drives

column4: scraping a ceiling
column5: trying to find a way out.

column1: Hecker’s music has always been eerie

column3: fascinated and trapped at the same time. Even the album’s quieter moments are more tense than they might’ve been on Hecker’s earlier albums—a function

It’s been four years since the release of Pearl Jam’s last studio record
column2: but it’s not like they’ve been far from view. In the interim
column3: we’ve seen reissues of their two best albums (1993’s Vs. and 1994’s Vitalogy)
column4: three live collections
column5: a slew of side-project activity
column6: and a 20th-anniversary world tour capped by the release of Cameron Crowe’s documentary Pearl Jam Twenty. As that film illustrated
column7: this band has much to be proud of
column8: having survived sudden success and the attendant media scrutiny
column9: a risky (at the time) rejection of MTV
column10: grueling court battles with Ticketmaster over fair practices
column11: fan backlash over the band’s more politicized gestures
column12: horrible tragedies
column13: and the overall collapse of the music industry with their arena-filling acumen intact.

column1: And yet
column2: even an exhaustive documentary produced by a super-fan like Crowe doesn’t have much to say about the band’s post-millennial output—because there’s really not a lot to say. Pearl Jam ceased long ago to be a band that makes records with any sense of occasion to them: no intriguing backstory
column3: no conceptual constructs to shape the album’s identity
column4: no new contemporary influences that might push them in an unexpected direction. You just get another nine to 13 Pearl Jam songs that—as per the quiet/loud division of 2004 anthology Rearviewmirror—can be easily slotted into one of two categories. (Even the tracklist sequences are invariably similar: the second song will be a no-fuss rocker that serves as the single
column5: and the album will inevitably close with a wistfully earnest ballad.) Pearl Jam are arguably the only modern rock band of note that consciously moved away from its formative
column6: hit-making sound—in the period spanning Vitalogy through to 2000’s Binaural—but came out the other side an even more traditional
column7: predictable band.

column1: So if you’ve been paying any attention to Pearl Jam’s activities over the past decade
column2: you already know what to expect from Lightning Bolt (and it’s certainly not a tribute to the Rhode Island avant-metal duo of the same name; heck
column3: even the Pink Floyd comparisons bandied about in pre-release interviews seem offbase
column4: unless your conception of Pink Floyd begins and ends with “Mother”). Like 2009’s Backspacer before it (and 2006’s Pearl Jam before it
column5: and 2002’s Riot Act before it)
column6: Lightning Bolt begins with a spirited sprint before sputtering out and winding up in dullsville. The feeling of déjà vu is compounded by the strip-mined subject matter
column7: as Eddie Vedder explores familiar themes of family strife and domestic unrest while once again celebrating the therapeutic powers of surfing and listening to music on vinyl.

column1: If Pearl Jam can no longer recapture the sort of hot-wired intensity that once had Vedder stage-diving off festival scaffolding
column2: they can at least still raise an inspired ruckus when the mood strikes: “Mind Your Manners”—a.k.a. “Spin the Black Circle Some More”—reformulates the original grunge cocktail recipe of mid-1970s hard rock and early 80s hardcore
column3: with a chooglin’ intro reminiscent of early KISS deep cut “Parasite” that gets mowed down by a boot-stomping blitzkrieg
column4: which in turn is blindsided by a sublimely melodic middle-eight. And “My Father’s Son” is the rare latter-day Pearl Jam rave-up to put the spotlight on bassist Jeff Ament
column5: whose sense of groove—once the cornerstone of the band’s sound—has been deemphasized by band’s ever-growing propensity for straight-ahead
column6: chug-a-lug rockers.

column1: Despite their punk-schooled principles
column2: Pearl Jam have never been shy about their debt to classic rock
column3: but it’s usually good classic rock: The Who
column4: Crazy Horse
column5: the Stones. And while the upward-arced anthemery of the title track and “Swallowed Whole” continue to dutifully honor this holy trinity
column6: Lightning Bolt also betrays the long-term diluting effects of spending too much time hanging on the right of the dial. “Let the Records Play” is boilerplate
column7: bad-to-the-bone blooze
column8: while the album’s centerpiece ballads tread on odious Lite-FM territory and forcefully tip the scales from poignant to maudlin
column9: whether it’s the Goo Goo Dolls sheen of “Sirens” or the Hornsby-esque piano rolls of the closing “Future Days” (definitely not a Can cover) that made the song a natural fit for the closing sequence of last week’s ""Grey’s Anatomy"". (By contrast
column10: the countrified lament “Sleeping By Myself” benefits from a lighter touch
column11: thanks to a gleaming George Harrison-style guitar refrain that draws the cheekiness out of the song’s woe-is-me sentiments.) The Pearl Jam mythos as it exists today is undeniably wrapped up in their notoriously epic live shows
column12: wherein the band is famous for loosening up and stretching out
column13: but for whatever reason
column14: that adventurous ethos rarely translates to their increasingly mannered albums. Pearl Jam on record have essentially been reduced to the rock ‘n’ roll version of wearing sweatpants: they’ve given up trying to impress anyone
column15:
so they may as well be comfortable.

There has been nearly as much discrediting punk-world chatter about Hoax and their supposed ""hype"" as tracks from the band—its previous output has spanned just over a dozen songs with such titles as ""Discipline"" and ""Living on the Brink of Suicide"". This debut full-length transcends the noise.

column1: Sanes typically sounds as though he's about to implode

column4: chainshaw guitars and gruff grunts

You could see fans of the recent brutal Nails record liking Hoax as much as followers of more accessible strains of dark punk; the band is self-loathing but not self-sabotaging. Placing headphones blaring Hoax into your eardrums has the empowering effect of plugging a phone charger into an outlet; you’re struck with a visceral surge of energy that is possibly dangerous. Play Hoax while walking down the hall at school

column11: he feels

column1: Nothing about the total misery of Hoax suggests a narrator with a lot of friends

column1: As a teenager hardcore changed my life because it ultimately repulsed me—girls were sidelined at shows and it seemed a maddening microcosm for the world in general—but Hoax remind me how I was drawn to it in the first place

One of the greatest favors and greatest injuries an artist can give his music is to give it a story before releasing it. It's a habit employed frequently these days

column7: twisty metaphors that have endeared Mercer to critics. Themes like the evils of materialism and war power it; women pepper its landscape like wispy
column8: mythological creatures. (Either he has revived one of the supporting characters from Paul's Tomb: A Triumph opener ""A Flower in a Glove""
column9: or he knows multiple skittish women named Judith.) ""Don't Give Up Your Dreams"" is the saccharine ballad; its beginning is its most gripping moment

“How can we face the storms without emancipated hearts?” This Dean Wareham asks on
column2: astonishingly
column3: his debut solo release. Is it a rhetorical question sung by a man whose heart is truly free and is offering advice
column4: or is it sung directly by a man who’s still holding himself captive? These are questions you can trace back to February of 1988
column5: when Wareham entered New Noise Studios in New York with his band Galaxie 500 and sang the same a verse
column6: and the same chorus twice
column7: all over two chords
column8: and just let the rest of the song spill out after it. The song was “Tugboat”
column9: Galaxie 500’s first single
column10: which would come to be one of the most popular entries of Wareham’s entire catalog. It minted what would be the singular sound of Wareham’s career
column11: a prototype for dream pop focused on elegance in simplicity
column12: guitars just before the thaw
column13: and plenty of leg-room. After 25 years
column14: the gravity of his early career is pulling him back.

column1: Though it’s certainly not a direct or easy route back. In 2008
column2: Wareham published the memoir Black Postcards: A Rock & Roll Romance. From the corroded flameout with his Galaxie 500 bandmates to the rise and dissolution of Luna
column3: from major label fracases to indie label collapses
column4: to broken-down cars
column5: tour vans
column6: planes
column7: busses
column8: marriages. All along
column9: Wareham’s songs reflected a man who alternated between incarceration and emancipation
column10: the conscious and un-
column11: the sober and the two-tabs of ecstasy. In the third act of his career
column12: he peered toward a thing called freedom having gone and made a couple albums with his wife and former Luna bassist Britta as Dean & Britta
column13: scoring soundtracks including one for Andy Warhol’s famous screen tests
column14: titled 13 Most Beautiful... Songs for Andy Warhol's Screen Tests). He even took Galaxie 500 songs out on the road in 2010.

column1: It’s a long road to arrive at Wareham’s debut solo record. Born unceremoniously into the world
column2: this brief and stirring mini LP stretches back to his earliest Galaxie 500 days when it was just two verses
column3: two choruses
column4: both the same
column5: and the rest of the song just spills out. Maybe he's channeling one of his heroes Lou Reed while scoring 13 Most Beautiful... or dusting off “Blue Thunder” on the road a few years ago
column6: but Wareham is at least glancing in the rear-view
column7: beautifully recapturing that moment in which everything opened up among the gauze and reverb of the magical “Tugboat.”

column1: The songs play like a return trip while all the old familiar signposts blur along in the periphery. Galaxie 500 always felt like a swift push out from the dock on into the unknown. On Emancipated Hearts
column2: Wareham’s journeys feel post-climactic
column3: suspended between the big explosion and the denouement of story about a man who’s still majorly bummed out. It’s heavy
column4: but he's always had a knack for making sense of the existential
column5: like he puts simply on “The Ticking is the Bomb”: “Fallen is the rain/ And the ticking is the bomb.” The song is just two chords above a drum kit played with what could be feathers
column6: a revving guitar idling beneath
column7: stuck between the inevitability of the future and the past.

column1: Wareham’s aim is true due in large part to enlisting Jason Quever
column2: aka Papercuts
column3: as a producer
column4: himself an acolyte of eclectic slow-core and dream pop in his music. With Quever behind the boards
column5: the electric elysium of Wareham's sound feels grounded
column6: spotted with acoustic guitars and light string arrangements. ""Love Is Colder Than Death"" limps more than it swings
column7: but it’s an earnest admission
column8: layered with his wife Britta playing bass singing harmonies above him. Wareham’s voice has lowered in registers over the years
column9: and here that plays into his role as the bemused seen-it-all.

column1: The song titles are all pulled from obscure literature
column2: poems
column3: and newspapers
column4: which Wareham then builds out from—a writing technique he’s used more than a few times in the past. The title track comes from a 1974 poem by Sir John Betjeman
column5: the expansive “The Longest Bridge in the World” is taken from a poem by Bertolt Brecht
column6: and “The Deadliest Day Since the Invasion Began” is taken from a book Leaving the Atocha Station by Ben Lerner
column7: about a poet during the Iraqi War who keeps reading that same headline in the paper. Wareham even writes in the notes that he was thinking of WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange while working on the title track. His politik hums underneath
column8: but ultimately they become notes in the margin in the larger story. Wareham has a knack for taking the words of others and filtering them through some internal mechanism that makes it all sound like it’s pouring out from his soul.

column1: Which is of course why he's has been so incredible with covers of the years
column2: from Jonathan Richman to New Order to Beat Happening. This EP proper closes with an incredible version of ur-hippy psych-folk group the Incredible String Band’s “Air”
column3: and it’s a fresh breath after much dread
column4: as Wareham hums a chorus
column5: stoned like Lee Hazlewood sipping a daiquiri on a beach. There are two more bonus tracks
column6: a great acoustic coda in “Living Too Close to the Ground” and a clunky digital remix of “Emancipated Hearts”. The former is worth seeking out for its straight-shootin’ simplicity against some of the more oblique themes of the EP
column7: while the latter is not really worth seeking out at all. Even at six tracks
column8: it’s stunning how much life (and death) Wareham spreads over these tracks
column9:
and makes these tiny whispers of songs feel like the biggest secret anyone’s ever told you.

The Men spend so much time on the road that they don’t really “get out much.” In our Guest List from earlier this year
column3: I was struck by how few hobbies they have outside of their music
column4: and beyond that
column5: they’re most excited by current bands they work with directly. Not to mention their preferred cultural touchstones are from at least several decades prior—when they say a VHS copy of Uncle Buck has been a tour van favorite
column6: you really believe them. Which is how a shitkicking
column7: raucous indie band shares an album title with a Twilight movie in 2013—it’s likely they just aren’t even aware of its existence. On a much smaller level of ubiquity is “Campfire Songs”—it’s a title associated with Animal Collective’s porchfront
column8: improvisatory EP from 2003
column9: their last release as a band that was still considered too weird for mass consumption. They might not be aware of that either
column10: but the Men are nothing if not charmingly literal: Campfire Songs is a collection of five songs recorded around a campfire during their Big Indian sessions for New Moon in Upstate New York.

column1: But the very thing that makes Campfire Songs a logical follow-up also makes it kinda unnecessary. Two of the five songs here are taken from New Moon and they’re amongst the most indicative of how their interests have shifted towards Crazy Horse and classic southern rock more than any of Neil Young’s indie rock descendents. On New Moon
column2: “I Saw Her Face” and “The Seeds” made full use of the Men’s tripartite guitar attack and were played ragged and loud. Yet
column3: removing the drums and swapping out for acoustic guitars does little to change the character of each
column4: particularly in light of the muffled
column5: dank recording of Campfire Songs—this is the Men unplugged
column6: but not Unplugged. Whether or not someone might prefer these versions
column7: they’ll do little to make you think of them differently. The same goes for “Water Babies”
column8: a solid dirge which simply sounds like the New Moon B-side that it is rather than something that was clearly inspired by Campfire Songs’ holistic format.

column1: If you’re looking to this EP for insight into the Men’s progression as a band
column2: it’s best to think of Campfire Songs as a live performance
column3: or at least chronologically structured. In the last 10 minutes
column4: the Men loosen up and realize that the intended audience for these performances is themselves. And that’s where things get interesting. After a couple of wide angle turns on Open Your Heart and New Moon
column5: in a strange way
column6: the final two new tracks on Campfire Songs take the Men back to their origins. “Patience” and “Turn Your Color” are
column7: for a lack of a better word
column8: jam sessions—loosely structured
column9: if structured at all
column10: guided by audible count-offs
column11: filled with stumbled strums
column12: and lasting nearly six minutes each. They’re not entirely au naturel
column13: with tamboura-like drones and backmasked reverb effects being added after the fact. But the combination of the gothic anti-production and detuned acoustic guitars ensure that “Patience” and “Turn Your Color” are as heavy and unpredictable as much of Leave Home even without the abrasion and distortion; previously
column14: the Men made beauty sound like an unintended byproduct of pain
column15: whereas Campfire Songs treats it as a proper artistic goal.

column1: Despite its quick turnaround time
column2: the Men actually are allowing listeners to catch up on Campfire Songs. Typically
column3: the Men’s albums are endpoints and if you catch them live
column4: they’re workshopping the next record and it’ll probably be out within the year. It’s a band whose artistic arc is in hyperdrive—the restorative nature retreat usually happens once an artist bottoms out at least a decade into their career. On the contrary
column5: to paraphrase New Moon’s “Half Angel Half Light”
column6: the Men are a rock band on a roll
column7: but as with Woods
column8: Ty Segall
column9: and Thee Oh Sees
column10: prolific and consistent bands run the risk of being taken for granted after making the inevitable leap from lo-fi. It’s not an essential release in the Men’s rapidly growing discography
column11: but as a rare snapshot of a band constantly in motion
column12:
Campfire Songs is sensible at least.

Fela Kuti's songs are as close to uncoverable as great popular music gets. They don't leave much room for interpretation: Fela's regal
column2: commanding presence was a lot of what he was selling
column3: and to mess with the watchworks of Africa 70 or Egypt 80's arrangements is to risk breaking them. Fela's patois often sounds totally wrong in a voice that doesn't come by it naturally
column4: too—and it doesn't help that a lot of his best songs were well over 10 minutes long.

column1: Nonetheless
column2: the Red Hot Organization has put together a second tribute album to Fela
column3: who would have turned 75 next week had he not died of AIDS-related complications in 1997. As with the first (2002's Red Hot + Riot)
column4: the project's M.O. is to assemble a bunch of American and African musicians in new combinations and see what they come up with; as with that album
column5: it's mostly yielded wild pitches. Red Hot + Fela largely presents itself as a blur of lesser
column6: briefer imitations of Fela's Afrobeat grooves
column7: liberally sprinkled with pro forma rapping and vocalists singing lyrics that have lost the political fire they once had.

column1: Aside from Fela's longtime drummer and bandleader Tony Allen
column2: who turns up for an update of his own 1977 track ""Afro-Disco Beat""
column3: the African musicians here (including Spoek Mathambo
column4: Congolese rapper Baloji
column5: Beninoise singer Angélique Kidjo
column6: and the Kenyan group Just a Band) come from outside the Nigerian Afrobeat tradition. That's not a bad idea
column7: even if it's a little ""Africa-is-a-country"": Fela was a pan-Africanist in his way
column8: too. But few of them have much to add to these songs. Just a Band's coffeeshop-friendly ""Who No Know Go Know"" and ""Gentleman"" (which respectively feature deeply unnecessary verses from Childish Gambino and Chance the Rapper) are particular offenders
column9: scrubbing the excitement out of what were once squawking Africa 70 blowouts.

column1: The same problem applies to some of the lesser-known American contributors. The Austin group Gender Infinity's synth-pop version of ""Highlife Time""
column2: which Fela recorded with his early band Koola Lobitos before his political (and musical) awakening
column3: is a funny idea if you're an Afrobeat nerd
column4: but bloodless in practice. And the L.A. R&B trio King's ""Go Slow"" selectively plucks a few lines from a scathingly funny song about Lagos traffic jams to turn it into a sex jam.

column1: Red Hot + Fela occasionally lives up to its possibilities
column2: fortunately. Merrill Garbus of tUnE-yArDs has talked about finding Fela's anti-feminist ""Lady"" frustrating
column3: so the hard-kicking arrangement she and Questlove put together jumps in and wrestles with it
column4: turning the lyrics over to a chorus of women
column5: with the lead vocal taken by the mighty Angélique Kidjo. (Garbus also appears
column6: along with Alabama Shakes' Brittany Howard
column7: on My Morning Jacket's rambling 14-minute ""Trouble Sleep""
column8: possibly the only Fela cover that's ever run longer than the original.)

column1: Another American artist who appears repeatedly here is saxophonist Stuart Bogie of the Brooklyn Afrobeat group Antibalas
column2: with whom he played in the pit band for the Fela musical on Broadway. Bogie's also worked with TV on the Radio in the past
column3: and that band's Kyp Malone and Tunde Adebimpe join him for a solemn
column4: airy take on ""Sorrow
column5: Tears and Blood""
column6: with its groove pared down to little more than whistling and a pizzicato string riff played by Kronos Quartet.

column1: Bogie's group Superhuman Happiness contributes two other tracks: an overwrought new wave-funk version of ""No Buredi""
column2: and a take on ""I.T.T."" that features Sahr Ngaujah
column3: who played the title role in Fela! The latter song comes from the days when Kuti and band were
column4: to paraphrase Public Enemy
column5: Nigeria's CNN; its lyrics are an attack on particular politicians and businesspeople of the late 70s
column6: and there's something jarring about hearing Ngaujah singing them in his best Fela impression over a tight
column7:
modern arrangement with loud guitar riffs. It's not that Ngaujah and Bogie somehow don't get Fela—few people understand his music better. But what the Afrobeat pioneer added to the pool that contemporary musicians can draw on was his style and sound far more than his songs.

Bill Orcutt’s guitar playing is all about possibilities. As he unfurls impulsive runs and quick turns
column3: each move opens a web of new paths he could travel. As a result
column4: when I listen to his albums I end up thinking as much about what could happen as what is happening. But then Orcutt’s plucks and strums are usually so quick and idea-filled
column5: it sometimes feels like everything that could happen actually is happening.

column1: Given this boundless approach to improvised playing
column2: A History of Every One—an album comprised solely of cover versions—is risky. By limiting himself to others’ songs
column3: Orcutt could sound handcuffed
column4: beholden to preset parameters rather than following his muse wherever it wants to take him. Further complicating matters
column5: he’s chosen tunes that are all over 50 years old (some even go back to the 1800s). Many
column6: especially ubiquitous ones like “White Christmas” and “When You Wish Upon a Star”
column7: are so culturally ingrained
column8: any attempt to transform them could be like trying to reshape the Grand Canyon.

column1: Fortunately
column2: Orcutt views these songs not as patterns to trace but collections of moments that can inspire him toward new ones. That's not really a surprise—he previously used the raw ideas in his head as points from which to launch
column3: so here he takes concepts well-worn by others and does the same. But that doesn’t make it any less of a bold move
column4: because it’s still rare to hear covers that don’t mimic originals or simply replace one style with another.

column1: Orcutt has found another way. He truly explores these songs
column2: eager to hurtle down any tangent that each phrase
column3: hook
column4: or melody could lead to. From a single note he’ll burst into a looped figure or angled run
column5: then dart back to the original figure to find more uncharted avenues to trample. His restless style makes each piece sound three-dimensional
column6: as shards of songs pass each other in a storm of string activity. It makes for exhilarating
column7: sometimes exhausting listening. But it also makes for music that
column8: though it hints at structure
column9: never sounds predictable and rarely settles.

column1: It also makes for pretty varied music considering it’s just one man and six strings—or actually four
column2: assuming Orcutt’s still playing his vintage Kay acoustic guitar. A few tracks fly by
column3: like a blistering take on “Zip a Dee Doo Dah” (from the 1946 Disney movie Song of the South) and a nearly-epileptic version of the 1915 union anthem “Solidarity Forever”. But others mix fast runs
column4: sharp stops
column5: and gradual stretches. Orcutt’s rapid-fire sounds are a wonder
column6: but it’s even more impressive when he cuts them with pauses or slows them into moments of reflection. This turns the 1925 song “Spanish is the Loving Tongue” into a kind of serrated elegy
column7: and the Lightnin’ Hopkins’ “Bring Me My Shotgun” into a seamless mesh of fire and ice. He even turns a Harvard fight song into a spirited mantra of pointed plucks and urgent moans.

column1: Those moans are stronger than ever on A History of Every One. I’m not sure if Orcutt “sings” (which for him means wordless humming
column2: howling
column3: and wheezing) more than on previous full-lengths
column4: but it sure feels like it. As the album progresses
column5: his voice becomes increasingly prominent
column6: leading the songs rather than reacting to them. By the time he gets to a swaying approximation of “Ballad of Davy Crockett”
column7: you can almost hear him crooning the melody like he’s teaching it to his guitar. Perhaps Orcutt felt more singing would help capture spirit of these originals
column8: most of which center on lyrics. But just as likely
column9: he needed to deploy all his weapons to find new ideas in songs played so much their potential might already be exhausted.

column1: A History of Every One shows that’s far from the case. It also represents a turn in Orcutt’s approach. These songs seem to have inspired a more contemplative mode. It may be paradoxical to call music this active “contemplative
column2: ” but even when he’s got the pedal to the floor
column3: you can hear Orcutt thinking these songs through—rolling them over in his mind while pouring them out from his fingers. This culminates in perhaps the simplest thing he’s ever recorded
column4: an album-closing cover of Stephen Foster’s “Massa’s in the Cold Cold Ground”. Sparse and moving
column5:
it shows Orcutt can do as much with restraint as he can with speed—opening up yet another path he can pursue.

"|18541.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18541-bill-orcutt-a-history-of-every-one/|7.8|Marc Masters
