A pile of asses locked into prime twerking position
column3: coalescing to form a giant fist that unmistakably resembles an iconic symbol typically used to represent those who are fighting against oppression: not the most subtle image in the world—but then
column4: Diplo's never been one for subtlety. The Ferry Gouw-designed cover art for Diplo's latest solo release
column5: the Revolution EP
column6: is tasteless
column7: provocative—and
column8: given pop culture's current watercooler fixation with twerking
column9: quite timely.

column1: Then again
column2: Wesley Pentz had a leg (or two) up on Miley in culturally co-opting the dance style. The bounce-heavy title track to last year's Express Yourself had an accompanying video that spawned one of the most NSFW hashtags in recent memory. Ever the canny opportunist
column3: Diplo rode the wave he hath wrought into 2013
column4: staging a failed attempt to assemble a record-breaking twerk session (a record that
column5: rightfully
column6: was finally set by bounce queen Big Freedia in NYC late last month) and putting out a video for that EP's ""Butters Theme""
column7: which questionably integrated Pussy Riot-esque balaclavas into his endlessly ass-shaking meme.

column1: On a purely musical level
column2: Express Yourself was a considerable success for Diplo. His try-anything
column3: be-everywhere ubiquity continues to reflect itself in an endlessly growing list of collaborators
column4: and the EP's six songs came with a list of features that rivaled most full-length rap releases in length alone; but in the midst of an especially collab-heavy year for one of the world's richest DJs
column5: it nonetheless affirmed that Diplo could still deliver shiny
column6: sour-sounding party music when his name's not buried in production credits. On the outset
column7: the similarities between that release and Revolution—six songs (this time
column8: four originals and two remixes)
column9: a load of guest appearances
column10: more drops than a container of Visine—suggest a desire to replicate Express Yourself's mid-level triumphs as exactly as possible.

column1: As Diplo's first solo release in nearly a decade
column2: Express Yourself benefited from a lack of set expectations
column3: and it came out smack dab in one of Diplo and Mad Decent's most commercially fruitful years in recent memory. But that was the past
column4: and Revolution arrives near the tail end of a creatively soft year for Diplo: collaborations with Snoop Lion
column5: Usher
column6: and the Weeknd—as well as a not-exactly-timely ""Gangnam Style"" remix—proved ultimately unmemorable. And then there was Major Lazer's sophomore LP
column7: Free the Universe
column8: which took the pirate-radio giddiness of its predecessor and dulled its edges with collaborative bloat and a genre-hopping lack of cohesiveness that yielded more misses than it did hits.

column1: One of Free the Universe's few memorable cuts was ""Bubble Butt""
column2: a boneheaded exercise in bass salaciousness that
column3: as the title suggested
column4: found Diplo's attention wavering south yet again. Revolution kicks itself off by completing his gluteal trilogy with ""Biggie Bounce""
column5: a song not dissimilar to its predecessor that features contributions from Jakarta-hailing EDM upstart Angger Dimas
column6: as well as an impossibly douchey verse from Atlanta pop-rap auteurs Travis Porter. With a rolling snare sample
column7: hissing-steam percussion
column8: and a deceptively deep low end that pairs nicely with a flatulent horn line
column9: ""Biggie Bounce"" is a fine example of Diplo at his most texturally engaging
column10: particularly when the track doubles into chopped-up vocal samples and gym-teacher whistles halfway through.

column1: Everything on Revolution sounds expensive and well-made
column2: as much a testament to Diplo's resources as it is to his effortlessness in turning out productions that resemble city-crushing gizmos as much as they do future Mad Decent Block Party crowd-pleasers. Specifically
column3: he's perfected the art of the almighty drop
column4: and Revolution's spring-loaded twists and turns are what stand out the most
column5: from the spacious hiccups that dot the title track's wordless chorus to the bass-siren assault that emerges from ""Crown""'s thick trance-worshipping synths. The EDM explosion in the U.S. marked the first time in Diplo's career that he wasn't at the forefront of a trend in populist American dance music; he's a smart guy
column6: so he's found a way to integrate himself into the conversation cosmetically
column7: but regardless of where you stand on the bass-face divide
column8: the garishness of Electric Zoo-esque fare is just the latest style that happens to fit Diplo like a glove.

column1: Zooming out from Revolution's more appealing micro-details
column2: however
column3: reveals the EP's fatal flaw in the form of cohesiveness. What made Express Yourself a considerably distinctive statement was its ability to jump from genre to genre and still manage to hang together as a unified body of work; Revolution sounds less considered and more like a small-scale data dump
column4: a collection of also-rans that makes poor use of its guest stars; the title track's Guetta-fied diva-electro expansiveness
column5: bolstered by faceless vocalist Kai
column6: resembles a worn copy of the low points on ex-Mad Decent affiliate Rusko's otherwise enjoyable sophomore effort
column7: last year's Songs.

column1: The watered-down boom-bap of ""Rock Steady"" boasts appearances from Action Bronson
column2: Mr. Muthafuckin' eXquire
column3: and RiFF RAFF—but the only rapper whose presence sticks is the latter
column4: purely by virtue of being the least mechanically talented of the three. RiFF RAFF's featured on ""Crown""
column5: too
column6: but he's barely distinguishable when cast about the track's synthy fromage and Mike Posner's caterwauling. Revolution is rounded out by uninspiring remixes of its title track and ""Biggie Bounce"" from respective producers Boaz van de Beatz and (fittingly) TWRK; their inclusion furthers the suspicion that this release wasn't too carefully thought out.

column1: Diplo's always been one for having too many cooks in the creative kitchen
column2: both to his advantage and detriment—but what's dismaying about the waste of talent on Revolution is that he would've ostensibly done better working with the people just lingering right under his nose. Mad Decent's 2013 has been considerably strong in terms of curation
column3: with solid releases from talents like Dillon Francis
column4: LIZ
column5: Jahan Lennon
column6: and a little-heard tune from some guy named Baauer. As mainstream dance's enfant terrible
column7: though
column8: Diplo's never been one to follow anyone's advice but his own
column9:
and Revolution is evidence enough that what he can do isn't always going to turn out as well as what he should've done instead.

Credit Kevin Barnes for knowing when he’s testing your patience. After last year’s Paralytic Stalks
column2: where his flamboyance came across as ho-hum and even his self-absorption sounded strangely obligatory
column3: Barnes changed up his process for Of Montreal’s 12th album. He left Athens
column4: Georgia
column5: and decamped to San Francisco to write. Instead of recording by himself
column6: as he has done on almost every Of Montreal album
column7: he assembled a small band of sympathetic performers. Together
column8: they eschewed computers and lofty conceptualizing
column9: favoring in-the-moment energy over down-the-rabbit-hole perfectionism. Relative to his usual dictatorial working method
column10: it was positively democratic.

column1: Especially after Stalks
column2: Lousy is bracing. It’s arguably the best—not to mention the funniest
column3: prickliest
column4: most purple
column5: and least fastidious—Of Montreal album since <a href=""http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/9796-hissing-fauna-are-you-the-destroyer/"" target=""_blank""><i><span>Hissing Fauna
column6: Are You the Destroyer? Barnes sounds more focused and straightforward
column7: perhaps newly aware that his listeners won’t follow him just anywhere. The songs here boast clearly defined choruses and verses and bridges
column8: even if his digressions within melodies lend the music an intriguing volatility.  If he was channeling Prince and Faust and the fictional glam-funk avatar Georgie Fruit on previous records

column11: somehow

column13:
as he sings on “Triumph of Disintegration”: “I had to make myself a monster just to feel something ugly enough to be true.”

column7: written in the major key
column8: hymns like ‘Oh God Our Help in Ages Past.’ So Ghanaians
column9: naturally
column10: adopted that kind of harmony; it became part of our lives.” Hearing James Brown in the late 60s

column1: That dichotomy of major and minor
column2: happy and sad
column3: haunts Return Flight. Overwhelmingly the tracks are lambent and melancholy
column4: sunsets made sonic. Still
column5: they teem. Swarms of organ notes and stinging guitar licks turn the African Brothers’ “Wope Me A Ka”—one of the most irrepressible tracks on the 13-song collection—into a connect-the-dots funk-puzzle whose final form only begins to coalesce after a shuffling
column6: skeletal break. It’s straight out of the Fela Kuti fake book

column8: born and bred in Ghana. Here
column9: though
column10: highlife’s polyrhythms and jazzy brass cast long shadows. “God is Love” by Complex Soundz may share the gospel luminosity that informs much highlife
column11: but it dangles from a downward-spiralling
column12: almost Santana-like chord pattern that feels more apocalyptic than ecstatic.

column15: murky funk that surrounds it. The most vivid example being Uppers International’s “Aja Wondo""

column17: if smoky
column18: atmosphere.

column1: Taylor’s remarks in the disc’s liner notes drive home that contrast. However
column2: they also underline the essential slipperiness
column3: the ethereal mutability
column4: of the music featured therein. Rob’s stark
column5: propulsive “Loose Up Yourself” trucks in all the multiple meanings of “loose”—politically liberated
column6: spiritually unbound
column7: sexually free—while refusing to click on a single one
column8: much in the same way its syncopated groove circles and never settles. Taylor’s own contribution to Return Flight is titled “Children Don’t Cry"". Graceful

column13:
aching reminder of everything there is to be uplifted from.

As fantastic a live band as the Dirtbombs are

column1: Ooey Gooey Chewy Ka-Blooey!
column2: it turns out

column4: or even bubblegum obscurities: it's 10 new

column6: of course

column8: two-bassist garage-rock idiom). It's a strange
column9: awkward record

column1: For one thing
column2: bubblegum is a one-song-at-a-time form—it's very hard to take an entire 1910 Fruitgum Company album
column3: say—and
column4: although Ooey Gooey is only half an hour long

column7: Jeffrey Katz
column8: and Joey Levine
column9: among others)
column10: and the singers and musicians were interchangeable to the point that four entirely different lineups of Ohio Express had hit singles between 1967 and 1969. This record
column11: though
column12: is about the band
column13: not the material: Collins' rough
column14: drawling voice is right up front
column15: and despite production flourishes here and there
column16: the Dirtbombs always sound like themselves
column17: wearing Halloween ""sexy bubblegum studio group"" outfits that don't fit them particularly well.

column1: The real failure of Ooey Gooey
column2: though
column3: is that these songs aren't particularly good pastiches. They're formally accurate: dumbed-down riffs
column4: hippie tropes
column5: easy rhymes
column6: references to candy. But stupidity alone doesn't make for wonderful bubblegum. The hits by the Archies and the Lemon Pipers and the Kasenetz-Katz bands were great pop music for five-year-olds
column7: which isn't an insult—five-year-olds have serious bullshit detectors. ""Sugar Sugar"" and ""Yummy Yummy Yummy"" are fine-tuned machines
column8: stripped of everything that doesn't instantly give pleasure
column9: and graced with detailed
column10: constantly shifting arrangements to hold their intended audience's attention. The Dirtbombs' songs here
column11: though
column12: generally have one really good idea apiece: the cowbell tattoo that runs through ""Sugar on Top""
column13: say
column14: or the innocent/lascivious conceit of ""Girl on the Carousel"". That's not enough for what they're trying to pull off.

column1: To be fair
column2: it would have been easy for Collins and company to have made Ooey Gooey's songs smirkier
column3: or to play up the dessert/oral sex metaphors more than they do (only ""Hey! Cookie"" really falls into that trap: ""Ooh
column4: such a groovy scene/ Gonna make sure I lick the plate clean""). There are a handful of very clever gestures scattered across the album
column5: too
column6: especially its closing track ""We Come in the Sunshine""

column8: though

column10: the Dirtbombs can Dirtbombify this ordinarily unscuzzy genre
column11:
too—rather than one that plays to the band's considerable strengths.

Manhattan's architecture results from the most rational possible pursuit of the irrational. That's one main argument of Delirious New York
column3: a 1978 book by Dutch theorist Rem Koolhaas that Cameron Mesirow has named as an inspiration for her second album as Glasser. It's also a useful frame for understanding the record
column4: not only its specific lyrical concerns but also its general spirit. Interiors is a methodical
column5: computer-tethered expedition into the vast
column6: wild expanse of human feeling.

column1: Glasser's 2010 debut Ring underpinned Mesirow's soaring vocals with free-flowing
column2: rhythm-obsessed eclecticism that made for a notably welcoming collection of atmospheric
column3: electronics-brushed pop. That description still largely applies to <i>Interiors
column4: but the homespun warmth and tribal rhythms of its predecessor have given way to chilly digital perfection—though plenty of organic elements persist
column5: in a way that's crucial—and the album as a whole is more thematically unified. Mesirow's voice
column6: both a singer and a songwriter
column7: still towers over the proceedings
column8: and you can look to this to orient you anytime the sonic and conceptual edifice grows too dizzying.

column3: in CGI space. Her Swedish co-producer Van Rivers

column5: applies his background in dark
column6: shuffling techno and production credits from such albums as the Knife's Karin Dreijer Andersson's self-titled 2009 solo album as Fever Ray. The nod toward heady electronic music is nothing entirely new from Glasser
column7: who has been remixed by the likes of Jamie xx and Lindstrøm
column8: but she credits her collaborator for helping carry out her blueprints. ""I was like the designer
column9: and he was the architect
column10: Mesirow told Billboard.

column2: 2009's ""Apply""

column4: and Interiors' rooms
column5: too
column6: are rarely as hermetically sealed as a cursory listen might suggest. ""Shape""
column7: the opening track and first advance track
column8: introduces the LP's silvery
column9: aerodynamicism with whooshing bass and crisp kick drums
column10: but Mesirow's layered
column11: melismatic vocals are front and center—and she's describing not a city skyline
column12: but an ocean beach. While ""Exposure"" glitchily theorizes on the ""modern trouble"" of urban living
column13: Mesirow is far more likely to use her fabricated sonic setting as a framework for exploring personal demons: The bird calls and tropical tinges on ""Dissect"" signal a lingering stylistic connection to labelmates Tanlines
column14: but next to lyrics about being ""shackled to a window/ Anything but open
column15: they also point to her much-reported struggles with spacial anxiety.

column2: it won't surprise you at this point to learn
column3: the ones within human beings. She applies the same ruthless precision to these ostensibly messier subjects

column7: an uptempo standout

column11: slightly different sentiment decades ago: ""That's us
column12: before we got there.""

0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/19792/homepage_large.db5546e1.jpg|Last Night on Earth|31727.0|Lee Ranaldo and the Dust|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Matador']|2013-10-10 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:52:04.791521|"

Atoms for Peace recently appeared on “The Daily Show” to play a couple of songs. Thom Yorke and Flea also sat down for an interview
column2: and Jon Stewart posed a common question about side projects: “Within your bands
column3: is there a sense of like
column4: ‘Oh
column5: do you not love us anymore?’” Yorke reported back
column6: “I think it’s all healthy
column7: right? It’s all healthy to free range a bit.” And while Yorke’s current project hews relatively closely to the sonic aims of Radiohead
column8: others depart more sharply from their main gigs. Such is the case with Lee Ranaldo’s latest
column9: Last Night on Earth
column10: a meandering
column11: elastic record—and a side effort that will be lost on most Sonic Youth fans.

column1: A couple of weeks ago
column2: Ranaldo wrote—knowledgably and adoringly—about a documentary capturing a 1972 Grateful Dead concert. (He previously tipped his hat to the group’s ultimate live collection from the same year
column3: Europe 72
column4: here on Pitchfork.) And he acknowledges the Dead’s influence on his current experiment with the Dust: “So I was looking at them as a model for some of the exploratory passages that the Dust and I have recently been attempting. Watching the Dead up on the screen was a real lesson in how it’s done.”

column1: The Dust consists of Sonic Youth drummer
column2: Steve Shelley
column3: as well as avant-garde journeymen Alan Licht and Tim Lüntzel. Together
column4: the quartet has crafted a companion piece to Ranaldo’s record from last year
column5: Between the Times and the Tides. While Last Night on Earth has been billed as more of a cohesive band’s vision
column6: it still suffers from a similar blurry schizophrenia. The Grateful Dead and other psychedelic troupes surely inform Last Night—many tunes clock in at over seven minutes and the closer “Blackt Out”
column7: is just a click under 12—but often Ranaldo calls his past into the fray
column8: forming a conflict. Near the end of the slow burning “Key/Hole”
column9: for instance
column10: he kicks in a raw cacophony and lets the guitar screech. He may not be playing with a screwdriver or attempting to make Michael Gira’s ears bleed
column11: but throughout Night on Earth
column12: Ranaldo takes a step back and realizes that—oh
column13: that’s right—he was in Sonic Youth. And he thrashed. Such coarse epiphanies sound strange in the context of the record’s poppier ambitions.

column1: And he’s moved into unsettled territory in terms of his own forays
column2: to boot. His 1993 collection
column3: Scriptures of the Golden Eternity
column4: boasts track lengths you’d expect from a 1960s acid acolyte but veers toward roughshod 70s clatter. Back then
column5: Ranaldo was knee-deep in stretching out the lab work he began in East Village tenements. Today
column6: an odd blend reigns supreme. Even his jam lines get crossed: The sleek “Lecce
column7: Leaving” recalls Phish’s studio recordings and the jumpy wandering of “Home Chds” Widespread Panic’s. Both songs are hampered by half-baked lyrics and disjointed progressions. “Home Chds” opens with a steady drumbeat that ramps up awkwardly  in the mode of a Gov’t Mule number—Ranaldo aiming squarely for the summer amphitheater lawn section. But couple it with his signature
column8: noisy dissonance on the denouement and the result screams jumbled 1990s: the soundtrack to a melee between fans of the factions.

column1: Last Night draws inspiration from the aftermath of Hurricane Sandy. “The Rising Tide” is the album’s centerpiece and best example of its apocalyptic tilt; and it’s catchy
column2: too. Ranaldo has a grim outlook on the current state of his environment—the title track is self-explanatory—but the severity and grimness of his outlook are constantly thwarted by a pervasive staleness. Last Night’s disaster themes can even be seen as a more pessimistic counterpart to the Dead’s 1973 album
column3: Wake of the Flood. Unfortunately
column4: Ranaldo’s lyrics don’t have the storytelling deftness that Robert Hunter’s did: On “The Rising Tide”
column5: Ranaldo sings
column6: “In this pure moment let all best intentions expire/ ‘Light up
column7: ’ you said
column8: ‘Light up so we can all feel our desires.’” Ranaldo has rightly asserted that jam bands like the Dead have been on the cutting edge of experimentation
column9: as has Sonic Youth. Still
column10: even if the theoretical dots between the two sides’ progressive elements connect
column11: Ranaldo can’t make it jibe here.

column1: There’s no edict that demands a musician
column2: branching out for a solo effort
column3: mimic the sound of his or her steady paycheck source. (Or even to earlier solo material.) Why would an artist
column4: as Yorke alludes
column5: make a solo record if not to branch out? But stumbles like the befuddling Baroque harpsichord of “Late Descent #2” or the lay-up rhymes of “By the Window” prove how difficult deviations can be. The evolving identities of Lee Ranaldo might be a valiant pursuit
column6:
but they have made for a problematic tone on Last Night on Earth.

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/19772/homepage_large.fcddacf5.jpg|Speak Soon Volume One|31693.0|Sons of the Morning|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Yellow Year']|2013-10-10 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:52:05.309003|"

Looking for no-brainers or any other form of certainty in the instrumental beat music scene is a dicey proposition. But there are ideas that come close
column2: and one of them is Prefuse 73 founder Guillermo Scott Herren working with the artists his music influenced. That holds true whether the musicians cutting tracks for labels like Brainfeeder or Friends of Friends owe a specific debt to those early Prefuse 73 albums
column3: or if they just connect to them as another piece of a larger precedent. L.A. producer Mtendere Mandowa-- b/k/a Teebs-- fits comfortably under that crowded tent. With impressionistic washes of sound like the cuts on Collections 01 and his breakthrough Ardour
column4: Teebs' aesthetic makes him a natural first choice for Herren's newest collaborative series
column5: Speak Soon
column6: as Sons of the Morning.

column1: Splitting the difference between the two artists means Vol. 1 comes across like a seamless mobius strip of mutual refinements on minimalist ambient hip-hop. And it pans out pleasantly enough over the course of a seven-track
column2: 28-minute EP. Not much gets compromised in the collaboration: both artists' senses of organically tactile ambience and brittle
column3: split-apart melody complement each other well. Laying out basslines and rhythms like elements in a field recording seems as easy as small talk for a couple of mad-scientist musicians like Herren and Mandowa. Their respective senses of musical spaciousness and fidelity-warping mood setting should've resulted in something with restless pull and positive tension
column4: but instead there's the nagging undercurrent that comes with a lot of one-off teamups—the music rarely rises above cozy competence because it doesn't feel like the two parties are challenging each other that much.

column1: If there's one thing that's really lost in Speak Soon Vol. 1
column2: it's both artists' ability to juxtapose deep kicks
column3: vibrant bass
column4: and free-form drum fills against more delicate elements as a heavy tweak of light pastoralism. The thing with both producers' aesthetic is that you could soak in the big
column5: upfront beats and then work your way down to discovering the nuances of the other
column6: subtler elements of percussion. Here
column7: the subtle bits ironically dominate. Aside from opener “The Way That Winter Passed Us” and closer “Movement in Mercury”
column8: which let their low-end pulses bump with a mild urgency
column9: the beats are pared back
column10: clicks and drips and mild tremors instead of kicks and snares and bass. And as they ebb and flow hazily
column11: the songs insinuate their moods instead of reveal them. It's a soothing diversion over a short span
column12: but over the course of five to seven minutes
column13: the reverie of cuts like “Sunday's Buzzabout” and “The Way That Wind Moves (Pt. 1)” fades out before the songs do.

column1: Still
column2: when everything clicks
column3: it can get pretty... well
column4: pretty. Sparser ambient work doesn't match up well to what these guys are usually great at
column5: but they both have too strong a sense of melodic strangeness to botch it entirely. There's a neat trick to “A Dangerous Study of Bird Life” that isolates what sounds like a single bird chirp but rhythmically repeats it ad nauseam until it comes across more like a nagging alarm—a sly punchline parallel to the way they stretch out and distort warm pop sounds into decaying beauty. And other elements—the smeared
column6: nervous-tic vocal harmonies on “The Way That Wind Moves (Pt. 2)”
column7: or grainy chimes on “The Distance from Our Fears”—prove that there's still plenty of affecting ways to draw out the beauty of sounds when they're reconstituted from debris. As a detour from the best tendencies of Teebs and Prefuse 73
column8: it's not the hoped-for clash of experimental beat music titans. But for two peers workshopping
column9:
it's just about diverting enough.

column1: 0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/19773/homepage_large.b43fafa7.jpg|Sunlight on the Moon|1325.0|Elf Power|['Rock'
column2: 'Experimental']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Darla'
column4: tried to discover a new meaning
column5: Andrew Rieger sings at the end of Sunlight on the Moon
column6: Athens psych-pop mainstays Elf Power's 12th album. Like just about any band staring down their third decade
column7: Elf Power have slowly but surely left many of those old ways behind. 2010's pristine
column8: sad-eyed Elf Power—a tribute to their late friend and occasional collaborator Vic Chesnutt—was a far cry from the fuzzed-out
column9: freewheeling psych of the late 90s LPs these Elephant 6ers built their reputation on. The prim Elf Power often seemed to confuse maturity for safety
column10: its clean
column11: carefully composed melodies coming off more staid than surprising. Sunlight on the Moon buzzes and hums more like the Elf Power of old
column12: but the songs themselves still seem a little scared of their own shadows.

column1: Rieger's never been the most effusive singer
column2: a shortcoming his clear-as-a-bell tone and oddball lyricism generally covered for. But Elf Power's recent embrace of more conventional forms—melodies
column3: lyrics
column4: production
column5: you name it—leaves Rieger without much to hide behind. He sings his way through much of Sunlight on the Moon like he's laying down guide vocals for somebody else to come in and replace; on Sunlight's title track
column6: he sings of ""dying in the war"" and ""death… in the sky"" as though he's idly shuffling through takeout menus. As a lyricist
column7: he's grown considerably since the f-bomb dropping ""Circular Malevolence"" era
column8: his metaphors richer
column9: his anxieties less overpowering. But it's gotten harder and harder to grab onto anything he's saying when all of it's sung in this dispassionate tone: ""woken and wild
column10: I hear the screams
column11: he calmly intones on ""Grotesquely Born Anew."" That makes one of us.

column1: Next to the 2008 album In a Cave's flailing and Elf Power's futzing
column2: Sunlight can feel downright rough-and-tumble. The patina of fuzz that surrounds most of these tracks makes Sunlight the scrappiest Elf Power LP in some time
column3: its scruffier numbers—""Strange Designs
column4: ""Lift the Shell""—harkening back to the days crouched around the four-track. But the stripped-down approach comes at a cost; without much adornment
column5: these songs are front-and-center
column6: a scrutiny they're not always up for. Rieger and songwriting partner Laura Carter have penned entirely too many melodies over the years to drop the ball now. But inspiration seems to be at a minimum here; the songs have been refined to the point of stiffness
column7: so plain as to be bloodless
column8: the kind of thing no amount of scuzz can cover up.

column1: Sunlight has it moments; rumbling power-popper ""Lift the Shell
column2: with its sci-fi feedback and baby gurgles
column3: is an easy highlight
column4: coming off like an Apples in Stereo tune after a bad night's sleep. The country-tinged ""Darkest Wave"" sneaks a little ""Paint It Black"" guitar into the fray
column5: while hints of mandolin elevate the stately ""Things Lost"". The album opens up quite a bit in headphones
column6: where the subtler instrumental flourishes sneak their way past the fuzz. Again
column7: these songs aren't short on craft
column8: and they're certainly never less than pretty
column9: but their spotless structures relegate any and all surprises to the back of the mix. But
column10: between these too-orderly melodies and Rieger's often diffident delivery
column11: there's simply not enough here to compel the kind of close listen you'd need to work out all of Sunlight's wrinkles. ""The floor is not collapsing
column12: the roof's not caving in"" Rieger sings on ""You're Never Gonna Go to Heaven"". That's the trouble with Sunlight on the Moon; things are just fine
column13: but 12 albums in
column14:
just fine's not quite fine enough.

0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/19761/homepage_large.75889e5b.jpg|Intersections|31610.0|Into It. Over It.|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Triple Crown']|2013-10-10 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:52:06.920758|"

On the very first line of Intersections
column2: Evan Weiss informs us he’s “traded tobacco for new north side air
column3: ” like he’s a familiar friend who can dispense with formalities
column4: just checking in to shoot the shit. This charming and occasionally exasperating quality plays a big part in defining his quasi-solo project Into It. Over It. But if you’re new to Weiss’ output
column5: the backstory is worth relating—prior to his 2011 debut Proper
column6: he'd gained notoriety around Chicago for starting seemingly dozens of bands and serving as a liaison between the upperclassmen of Midwestern emo (Their/They’re/There with Mike Kinsella) and the younger kids establishing the new vanguard. He lived in a van for a spell
column7: playing pretty much every basement and house party that would have him and spent 2007 writing a new song every week. The 52 Weeks collection was finally released in 2009 and many of these songs were titled with the kind of breathtaking mundanity (“Friday At Brian’s (I Have to Be Up in Four Hours)”
column8: “Dude-A-Form (Dude Uniform)” and geographical obsessiveness (“Rapid Shitty
column9: SD”) that presumably went the way of the Get Up Kids.

column1: As a result
column2: Proper often sounded like a record from a guy too deep in the game
column3: “thinking simple and putting life to ink
column4: ” as Weiss puts it on Intersections highlight “Obsessive Compulsive Distraction”
column5: an album of sharply written songs that were often dulled by snark and an assumption that you got all the inside jokes and cared about scene politics as much as he did. So like most of IIOI’s work
column6: the proper nouns are less important than the underlying emotion in the mission statement of “New North-Side Air"". On Intersections
column7: it’s “new air” that matters
column8: regardless of its source
column9: and with the assistance of Brian Deck’s production
column10: Weiss’ world opens up in every way and becomes a much more welcoming place to visit.

column1: If not explicitly stated
column2: the aforementioned fresh air registers as an autumn breeze
column3: as the music itself has the physiological feel of a transition season—the crisp brightness and soft-focus melodies make a lot more sense now than they did when I first heard them in summer. And the places referenced by Weiss throughout—suburban Philadelphia
column4: upstate New York and New Haven
column5: CT—evoke college campuses
column6: the turning of foliage and a perpetual amber hue. Deck’s sympathetic production leaves plenty of room for a draft to come through
column7: or
column8: mostly a chill. The songs here anticipate relationships headed towards a bitter frost rather than springing into torrid passion.

column1: Then again
column2: most of the conflicts promised by the title of Intersections play out within Weiss
column3: “just spinning wheels
column4: spinning thread and my spinning head."" It’s cerebral music in that way
column5: where most conversations appear to be one-sided and happening after the fact. And musically
column6: Weiss hears completely logical structure in his head
column7: whereas the listeners encounters all kinds of obtuse turns and strange bridges even within a loose verse-chorus template. This was by design: in an effort to avoid falling back on the pop-punk tropes that otherwise propped up Proper
column8: Weiss plays without a pick on Intersections and drummer Nick Wakim disassembled much of his cymbal setup.

column1: The result is just familiar enough to be referential without becoming derivative—Weiss’ deft
column2: rambling fingerpicked patterns bear a strong influence of Mike Kinsella’s Owen
column3: though IIOI is far more melodic and compact. In his softer vocal register
column4: there’s a boyish and bookish cloaking of mean-spirited sentiments that recalls Ben Gibbard. You’re not gonna mistake Intersections for Deck’s work with Califone or Modest Mouse
column5: though you can hear his influence in how it sounds more rustic and more electronic than Proper—the clacking percussion
column6: ringing guitars and looped vocals in “Contractual Obligations” and “A Curse Worth Believing” stand out as Weiss’ most complex studio productions by a good margin.

column1: But Intersections is also cerebral is the way one might translate as “too smart for its own good.” Weiss hasn’t lost his taste for breakup songs that foreground the narrator’s clever observations as a means of giving him the upper hand. On “Spatial Exploration”
column2: Weiss reminds an ex of the “after hours trading X-rated favors” before asking “what is this new person you’ve become?” She’s getting her shit together in a suburban kind of way
column3: and Weiss doesn’t even allow the possibility that she could be in a happier place. Later during “Upstate Blues”
column4: he warns someone to leave a cozy town where drinkers “soak their twenties into tens/ it’s like their twenties never end.” It’s seemingly compassionate
column5: though lyrics like “upstate blues they could paint your room/ cold and gray like New York and you” reveal a passive-aggressiveness behind it. It’s a standard emo pitfall that can mar otherwise exceedingly melodic and cleverly structured songs
column6: and while perversely satisfying in the correct doses
column7: but the oft accusatory tone of Intersections might unintentionally cause you to see things from the other person’s side.

column1: Above all other transitions invoked on Intersections
column2: the most crucial occurs in the second half where Weiss evolves into more compassionate narrator. “No Amount of Sound” is his riskiest song
column3: a slowcore lament for a hospitalized friend that drops any semblance of humor for incapacitating despondence. Meanwhile
column4: the first half of “The Shaking of Leaves” could be mistaken for a relationship post-mortem where Weiss feels actual sadness rather than justified resentment. Instead
column5: it’s a sequel to Proper’s “Connecticut Steps”
column6: where Weiss tried to process the murder of his friend Mitch Dubey
column7: a musician and cyclist in New Haven. The news surrounding Dubey’s murder raised a lot of uncomfortable questions about race and economics in a very stratified city and makes the concerns of Intersections
column8: as big as they are in the moment of experiencing them
column9: feel pretty damn minute.

column1: And yet
column2: with so much to untangle
column3: ""The Shaking of Leaves"" finds Weiss deferring for a simple mourning
column4: at his most concise and his most powerful. In a melody that could pass for an Irish drinking song
column5: he feels relief
column6: even joy when the New Haven newspaper says that a killer’s been named. And then he recoils in disgust when it’s revealed the accused gunman is 19 (Tashaun Fair was found not guilty after what many criticized as a botched investigation). About ten minutes later
column7: Weiss is back in his most literal depiction of an overactive mind (“Obsessive Compulsive Distraction”)
column8: but when Weiss manages to get outside himself
column9:
Intersections uses emo as a step towards something more resonant.

Pusha T’s solo career post-Clipse has often seemed rudderless. He made great strides playing the preening
column3: streetwise Mase to Kanye’s Diddy on songs like My Beautiful Dark Twisted Fantasy’s “Runaway” and Cruel Summer’s “New God Flow”
column4: but it took him a few releases (Fear of God
column5: a patchy stab at bygone Re-Up Gang mixtape glory
column6: and its sometimes distractingly star-studded sequel Fear of God II: Let Us Pray) to find his footing on his own. When he did
column7: on January’s Wrath of Caine
column8: he surfaced snarling over trap beats. The mixtape often subsisted off the sheer intensity of his delivery
column9: and it placed him in lockstep with the mainstream rap zeitgeist. But it also cut him off from the flashy new-money arrogance of the first 10 years of his career
column10: and it suffered in spots thanks to a noticeably diminished lyricism. Push flounders without a hands-on producer
column11: it would seem. For his major label debut
column12: My Name Is My Name
column13: Kanye West is that guiding light.

column1: Kanye never utters a word here
column2: Auto-Tuned scatting on “Hold On” notwithstanding
column3: but the sound and scope of the record are unmistakably Westian. The blaring fanfare and hyperactive drum programming Hudson Mohawke and Beewirks brought to “No Regrets” are direct descendants of My Beautiful Dark Twisted Fantasy’s “All of the Lights”. On opener “King Push”
column4: Kanye and Sebastian Sartor reprise the vocal sample from the breakdown in “New Slaves”
column5: pinching and distending it into funhouse versions of itself over horror movie synth stabs. Kanye’s production with DJ Mano on “Who I Am” advances the dark
column6: austere Yeezus vibe as it melds oft-used samples (the “Yeah!” from Mountain’s “Long Red” and the frantic lick from South Bronx dance-punk pioneers ESG’s “UFO”) and a swatch of Warp producer Kwes’ serene “LGOYH” into something leagues more sinister than its requisite elements. My Name Is My Name is borne out of the same minimal
column7: uncompromising darkness as Yeezus
column8: but its communion with radio rap values delivers on the accessibility that listeners put out by Yeezus’ monomaniacal hellishness clamored for.

column1: My Name Is My Name makes concessions for radio accessibility
column2: but it’s never rankled by them. Guests grace nearly every track
column3: but where they gobbled up real estate that should’ve been Pusha’s on Fear of God II
column4: on My Name Is My Name
column5: they’re mostly tasked with giving Pusha’s impish abandon wings. Frequent alley oops from singers scan as shots at offsetting the brass tacks boom bap of “Numbers on the Boards” and “Nosetalgia” with hooks
column6: but Pusha seems wholly unfazed by any of it. He nets a beat from the-Dream and a lilting Kelly Rowland hook on “Let Me Love You” and effects a Mase flow so spot-on you’ll look for him in the liner notes. Elsewhere a disembodied
column7: wraithlike Chris Brown’s good life platitudes on “Sweet Serenade” are waylaid by at every turn by gun-toting mogul talk.

column1: Rappers get the same treatment. Trap clown prince 2 Chainz and dick joke dispenser Big Sean are so outmatched on “Who I Am” that they hang back to play comic relief. (2 Chainz wins here: “Entrepreneur/ Strip club connoisseur/ Hot fudge sundae/ Pour it on you
column2: hallelujah”). On “Hold On”
column3: Pusha sneers about studio gangsters who never sold drugs
column4: then cedes verse two to corrections officer turned crack rap kingpin Rick Ross. Kendrick Lamar brings the expected lyrical pyrotechnics to “Nosetalgia”
column5: matching Pusha’s verse about growing up a dealer with reminiscences of a childhood profoundly affected by family members’ drug use
column6: and it’s the only time an outside voice comes close to stealing the show.

column1: Though My Name Is My Name can feel like a moon around Kanye West’s recent work
column2: the star here is unquestionably a reinvigorated Pusha T. This is never more apparent than on the minor Re-Up Gang reunion cut “Suicide”
column3: where Pharrell provides a skittering metallic bounce with pitch 808s in place of a bassline
column4: and Pusha and Ab-Liva trade bars with a zeal that’s been missing since the Clipse started to wither on 2009’s Til the Casket Drops. The rhymes on “Suicide” and the rest of My Name Is My Name are a cut above what we’ve come to expect from post-Clipse Pusha. He’s finally figured out how to marry the unlabored lyrical dexterity and unflappable cool of earlier work to the vengeful
column5: bottomless menace of the new material. Pusha’s released a fair amount of music since joining Kanye’s G.O.O.D. Music army three years ago
column6:
but My Name Is My Name is really the first release that delivers on the excitement initially engendered by the pairing.

The fact that there's only one unqualified banger on Le1f's new album probably says less about his ability to make instantly accessible
column2: instantly addictive
column3: highly energetic songs than it does his interest in making them. After all
column4: his two prior full-lengths were packed with frenetic crowd-pleasers
column5: and even the collaborative EP he recorded with his producer Boody
column6: which flirted hard and heavy with ambient music
column7: had a dance-floor-ready single in “Soda"".

column1: Aside from the rowdy
column2: anthemic “Damn Son” (which perfectly flips the Trap-a-holics iconic mixtape drop)
column3: his third LP is the sound of that flirtation being consummated
column4: a potently chill record built around echoing washes of synthesizers and unhurried tempos. Its second track
column5: “Cane Sugar""
column6: glides in at a modest 68 BPM
column7: with its melody coming from reverb-dripping bells and Le1f’s voice multitracked and pitch-shifted in a way that underlines the song’s syrupy pace. On any other rap album this would be the spacey experimental track slipped in on the second half; here it qualifies as a relatively eager pop number.

column1: If Le1f’s first two mixtapes were about proving that he can compete on the same level as any other rapper in the game—and after the phenomenal Fly Zone it’s hard to imagine how anyone could argue he can’t—Tree House feels like having done so
column2: he’s moved on to other more challenging pursuits. Like staking out his own space even further out from hip-hop’s core
column3: where rap
column4: R&B
column5: and dance music’s avant garde have started to bleed into one another.

column1: He may be working far enough out on pop’s fringe to still be considered wild country
column2: but he’s not alone out there. The first (and stronger) half of the album was produced almost entirely by Boody
column3: Vangelis-loving Chicago duo The-Drum
column4: and the relatively unknown NYC beatmaker Shy Guy. Although each has a distinctive style they all mesh exceptionally well
column5: bound by a shared affection for syncopated R&B rhythms
column6: minimalist arrangements
column7: and combinations of tones and reverb that suggest dark
column8: cavernous
column9: aquatic spaces
column10: as if the album was recorded in some kind of digitally simulated underground lake.

column1: The record’s consistent sonic identity is matched with an equally consistent lyrical theme
column2: which is a deep enough appreciation of freaky sex to qualify as legitimately Prince-like
column3: with lyrics that swerve between playfully cajoling would-be lovers to prayerful odes to physical intimacy. While he’s never been shy when it comes to talking about sex
column4: Tree House finds Le1f intensifying his focus on on it
column5: and in the process laying claim to part of the soul music lover man tradition
column6: complete with spoken word interludes and entire songs devoted to the topic of sensual oils.

column1: The move from the club to the bedroom has brought with it a change in Le1f’s vocal style. As a rapper he’s always been more concerned than most with emphasizing melody and texture in his performances
column2: and by leaning on them even more
column3: as he does on Tree House
column4: takes him right up to the point of actually singing. Occasionally he steps right across it
column5: as on the Drum-produced “Swerve""
column6: which with his echo-laden
column7: Auto-Tuned vocal hook ranks among the best druggy R&B moments in a year that’s offered plenty of them.

column1: The twisty artistic path that Le1f’s chosen himself has brought him close to being the anti-Drake: a melody-minded rapper with a taste for nocturnal sounds but without the sexual hangups and pathological materialism. It’s a surprising move for a musician who’s made his name on club-friendly jams
column2:
but it’s becoming obvious that following Le1f’s career is going to involve making a lot of unexpected turns. If he keeps making them so expertly that should be no problem.

Albert Hammond Jr. is not the most popular Stroke
column2: nor the most rock-star-stylish
column3: nor the one who attracts an inordinate amount of popular comedic actresses
column4: nor even the quiet one. But he is nonetheless the Strokesiest of the Strokes—if you were to ever dress up as a Stroke for Halloween
column5: you’d be copping Hammond’s one-size-too-small thrift-store sports jacket
column6: skinny tie
column7: Chuck Taylors
column8: and hair photoshopped off of Billy Ficca's head on the first Television album cover.  Accordingly
column9: out of all the extracurricular projects the Strokes have pursued over the years
column10: Hammond’s solo releases have hewed most closely to the band’s bleary-eyed
column11: tousled charm and classicist tendencies.

column1: However
column2: in the five years since Hammond’s last album
column3: the Strokes have moved further and further away from that signature scrappy sound
column4: expanding their sonic vocabulary with notoriously mixed results. Perhaps not coincidentally
column5: Hammond’s new EP sticks to the narrowest of L.E.S. lanes. Where 2006’s Yours to Keep and 2008’s ¿Cómo te Llama? presented homespun interpretations of Hammond’s most iconic inspirations (John Lennon
column6: the Beach Boys
column7: Bob Marley)
column8: on AHJ he mines a more easily attainable influence: his own band circa 10 years ago.

column1: Hammond has recently come clean about the various hard-drug habits that plagued him throughout the Strokes’ ascent
column2: which he finally kicked shortly after the release of ¿Cómo Te Llama?. As such
column3: there’s a sense that Hammond is forcefully hitting the reset button here
column4: stripping his songs back down to the basics
column5: and regaining his confidence by playing within his comfort zone. (He handles all the instrumental parts on the record
column6: save for drums.) Running a mere five songs and 15 minutes
column7: AHJ is a wholly fat-free effort that favors tight
column8: snappy
column9: emotionally direct songcraft over the genre experiments and instrumental excursions of ¿Cómo Te Llama? that suggested Hammond was headed down a more ponderous path.

column1: Hammond may not be as casually charismatic as Julian Casablancas
column2: and his songs can be modest and unassuming to a fault—the gently loping ""St. Justice"" is not so much an opening salvo as a warm-up exercise to check the levels of each instrument. But he brings a convincing poignancy and urgency when required. “Strange Tidings” recalls the dream-pop drive of “Hard to Explain”
column3: yet lines like “If I’m guilty/ It’ll show” and “control is so hard to find” provide sobering reminders of a time when Hammond had to wear long sleeves even on the hottest summer days. But while oblique references to Hammond’s darkest hours abound on AHJ (“Cooker Ship” conjures images of burnt spoons and bottoming-out in the sort of fantastical terms his hero-turned-buddy Bob Pollard would appreciate)
column4: the energy here is one of spirited
column5: defiant revitalization. And in the amazingly compact “Rude Customer”
column6: Hammond turns in a song that would’ve been the hands-down highlight on any of the past three Strokes albums. If you're precisely the sort of disenchanted old-school Strokes fan who would respond to that with
column7: ""Well
column8: that's not saying much
column9:
then the lean econo-pop of AHJ will feel all the more like a gift.

Sway
column2: the sophomore LP from San Diego-to-New York shoegazers  Tape Deck Mountain
column3: attempts a kind of hypnotic induction
column4: reeling you in with its mesmeric churn and plumes of reverb. When it works
column5: it takes hold completely
column6: engulfing your attention
column7: encroaching on your thought processes. When it doesn't
column8: well
column9: you may just find yourself getting verrry sleepy. Sway's a far more captivating set than 2009's Ghost
column10: but when the trance starts to falter
column11: Sway's daze turns anesthetic.

column1: Recorded between Austin and San Diego—with the drums and bass laid into 2"" tape—Sway's sound is rarely less than stellar. Unlike the hiss-mired Ghost
column2: which often sounded beamed in from afar
column3: Sway is considerably more enveloping
column4: placing the listener in the center of the storm. The brief symphonic feedback swell of opener ""EGBDF"" gives way to the detuned
column5: downtrodden ""Slow Hell""
column6: a Sonic Youth-esque bummer trip that finds a bleary Travis Trevisan recounting late-night drives and snorted breakfasts. Hero worship aside
column7: the loping
column8: ominous ""Hell"" could be the finest TDM track to date
column9: all snarling guitars and red-eyed murmurings. But dream popper ""Always Lie"" gets bogged down by its helicoptering reverb
column10: and ""Half Life""
column11: despite its Kevin Shields-style whale-calls
column12: eventually starts to meander.

column1: Yet it's not until ""That's You"" that Sway starts to lose its hold. Built around a thudding
column2: lockstep bassline
column3: ""That's You"" plods along listlessly
column4: taking its sweet time going nowhere. As Zach Kelly wrote in his review of Ghost
column5: Tape Deck Mountain fare best ""where guitars crash and sequencers explode."" When they pull things back
column6: as they do through much of the album's second half
column7: the spell they cast elsewhere is broken in a way they struggle to recapture. ""PI"" is Sway at its most melodic
column8: its cascading guitars and propulsive drums crashing into a giant yearning chorus. But it's quickly swallowed up by ""Pretend Friends""
column9: a loud-quiet-loud proto-grunge nod that ambles along without much aim until a short
column10: sidewinding solo slips into the frame halfway through. Things don't get much better from there: the torpid ""Mystics"" is a sketch in search of a song
column11: while ""PI II""
column12: despite a decent hook and some wriggly guitar interplay
column13: takes a couple good ideas and runs them into the ground. Husher closer ""Meta"" smacks of Drum's Not Dead-era Liars
column14: finding Trevisan moaning in watery falsetto over a hissing synthetic pulse. The focused intensity of ""Meta"" is a nice antidote to all the wandering that precedes it
column15: but it finishes Sway with a whisper
column16: when it could probably use another scream.

column1: Between Trevisan's cryptic tone—save the up-front ""Slow Hell""
column2: his vocals tend to get swallowed up
column3: only the occasional muttering about Aleister Crowley floating to the surface—and his roundabout compositions
column4: Sway's a tough record to get your head around. Though mercifully devoid of Ghost's overlong ambient interludes and its ghastly ""asshole Larry"" lyrics
column5: between its pacing and grayscale palette
column6: Sway's just too terse to for rapture and too noncommittal for mystery. Tape Deck Mountain's heavy-lidded narcosis can be transfixing
column7: but when the songs start to drift
column8:
the mind starts to wander.

Much of the press accompanying the self-titled debut of Brooklyn duo Hunters describes their live show with some variation of “wild” or “unpredictable.” Which is great for context
column2: but if you don’t live in New York
column3: and only have access to the actual album
column4: it starts to feel like a preemptive apology. During the many times I found my attention wavering during the duration of Hunters
column5: I tried to imagine what those shows might look like
column6: without consulting YouTube or Google Image Search to spoil the surprise. I picture Derek Watson with a dark
column7: matted haircut
column8: dressed entirely in denim and leather with some flannel
column9: snarled upper lip but also a bit playful and laconic. On the other side
column10: there’s Izzy Almeida
column11: playing in the back until her vocals come in
column12: and when they do
column13: she really puts herself into it. Maybe a combination of Alice Glass and Alexis Krauss
column14: a similarly hell-bent-for-leather cockiness
column15: lots of facial expressions
column16: visible tattoos and maybe a shock of dyed hair. As it turns out
column17: that’s not far off
column18: but I’m not gonna give myself a lot of credit—that’s a standard archetype when you hear grungy fuzz guitars and sneering vocals within a coed pop construct. It exists for a reason. So
column19: on some count
column20: Hunters is successful in providing a visual of what the band looks like for the people who have yet to see them in action. Problem is that even after a dozen or so listens
column21: I have no idea what Hunters actually are like.

column1: Hunters signifies a generic scare-quote “attitude” on a micro level—the distortion here is of the Big Muff or Rat pedal variety
column2: none of that tasteful tube amp stuff. Both Watson and Almeida take on an adult-adolescent vocal style
column3: which neutralizes whatever friction you’d get from their give and go interplay—I suppose both sexes sound kinda the same when projecting from the nasal passage. But in the big picture
column4: Hunters is perfectly palatable in any way that matters. The duo position themselves as a missing link between 90s grunge and the beer-swilling
column5: noisy art-pop of NYC in the early 00s
column6: two styles that have little in common other than an emphasis on dynamics which Hunters sorely lacks: in practice
column7: it's as mesmeric and even-keeled as a Kraut-rock record.

column1: For the most part
column2: a Hunters song consists of a riff that plods and chugs for a couple bars while Watson sings a clipped
column3: major-key melody and after he’s done
column4: it lunges slightly one way or the other. After a couple of measures of that
column5: the vocals trade off nearly similar cadences at nearly similar intervals. If there’s a clean guitar being played
column6: a distorted one is no more than 30 seconds away and it’ll likely churn out some variation of “Frances Farmer Will Have Her Revenge on Seattle”. And yet
column7: both the “loud” and “quiet” parts sound like they’re being played at the same volume. I imagine Hunters would be the first to tell us that this isn’t meant to be intellectualized—the lyrics really don’t offer themselves up for much analysis
column8: and they’re also sung in a way that lets you know your attention is best directed elsewhere. But trying to elucidate real differences between these songs
column9: most of which are titled like shabby chic colognes (“Narcissist”
column10: “Street Trash”
column11: “Seizure”
column12: “Blackheart”)
column13: requires a laser-guided focus and a litigator’s knack for parsing minutiae through nuanced language.

column1: On a macro scale
column2: Hunters seem awfully algorithmic as well
column3: a band that could conceivably open for every one of their fellow acts on the Mom + Pop roster without stealing their thunder. On “Street Trash” and “It’s True”
column4: the sound of cheerleading vocals over distorted guitars instantly recall Sleigh Bells
column5: but as a band that’s less beholden to noise or pure pop
column6: Hunters do little to keep you from listening to Sleigh Bells instead. Like Wavves
column7: they build hooks upon a handful of heaving power chords as a reflex
column8: but Hunters manifest little of Nathan Williams’ ambitions for variegated production; after a first half of five almost indistinguishable songs
column9: you see “Nosebleed” topping over six minutes and wonder how the hell it’s going to get there. They throw in a tempo switch about halfway through and “Nosebleed” is really just two Hunters songs stitched together. And yeah
column10: like FIDLAR you figure they drink cheap beer
column11: but they lack anything remotely resembling that band’s frightening commitment to their own debasement. Which is fine
column12: plenty of us have gone to work at 8AM totally relieved we decided against shotgunning that last beer or downing that Jager bomb. The problem is that Hunters doesn’t really deliver in the moment either
column13: as it’s not much different than reading about those wild
column14:
unpredictable shows of theirs as opposed to being there—all you think about is the fun you’re not having.

0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/19787/homepage_large.d91081c6.jpg|Bitter Rivals|28390.0|Sleigh Bells|['Pop/R&B']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Mom & Pop']|2013-10-08 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:52:11.376360|"

A decade ago
column2: Derek Miller was playing guitar in a hardcore band while Alexis Krauss was singing in a teen-pop group
column3: and they came together in Brooklyn in 2009 with the provocative idea that these two genres have more in common than conventional wisdom suggests. Sleigh Bells' spectacular 2010 debut album
column4: Treats
column5: was like Jock Jams for Hell's Angels; Miller's riffs went off like illegal bottle rockets
column6: and Krauss lilted
column7: roared
column8: and chanted (""Did you do your best today?"") with the cataclysmic cool of a cheerleader who's just hijacked a monster truck. Like all records that don’t quite sound like anything before
column9: you either loved it or hated it
column10: but you couldn’t ignore it.

column1: Finding damaged beauty in distortion and compression
column2: Treats sounded magnificently charred
column3: like it had been recorded on the only console to survive Armageddon. After its success
column4: Sleigh Bells got the opportunity to make the transition to hi-fi
column5: and there was reason to worry that squeaky-clean production might extinguish what made them original in the first place. But their 2012 sophomore album Reign of Terror did ""pulverizingly loud"" in a different
column6: though equally distinct way: It had the cavernous and slightly haunting atmosphere of a collection of songs recorded in an empty stadium. One of its best tracks was called ""Crush""—a title that compacted all of Sleigh Bells' tensions and contradictions into a single syllable. ""I got a crush on you
column7: Krauss cooed
column8: but in the very same breath she flashed a switchblade
column9: ""I gotta crush you now.""

column1: For their third album
column2: Bitter Rivals
column3: Sleigh Bells have made a few more tweaks to the formula. They've embraced more varied instrumentation—see: the lightning-strike synths on ""Sing Like A Wire""; the menacingly strummed acoustic guitar that opens ""Bitter Rivals""—and added a drummer to their live show. But most notably
column4: they've become more creatively democratic. Miller handled the lyrics
column5: music
column6: and production on the previous records
column7: but on Bitter Rivals Krauss wrote most of the melodies. The material she's composed for herself does allow her to show more range—Bitter Rivals features both Krauss's most tuneful and aggressive vocals yet
column8: sometimes within the same song—but overall it is the work of a band enduring some growing pains. The good news is that Sleigh Bells have new ideas
column9: but the often-undercooked Bitter Rivals shows they haven't yet found effective ways to execute many of them.

column1: And it doesn't take long for this to become apparent. Opening track and lead-off single ""Bitter Rivals"" starts off with a misleadingly minimalist
column2: showdown-at-high-noon vibe
column3: but it soon becomes a cluttered and unrelenting mess of chunky power chords
column4: high-voltage synthesizers
column5: and near-Karmin-grade rapping—all heaped on top of each other with little rhyme or reason. The same goes for the puzzlingly stilted ""Sing Like a Wire""
column6: which feels so disjointed it's like the verse
column7: bridge
column8: and chorus were dragged-and-dropped from three different songs. The hook hits like an earthquake
column9: but there's no build; the drop appears so suddenly that it doesn't quite feel earned.

column1: Compare these songs to the sleek
column2: expertly controlled chaos of Treats
column3: and you get the impression Krauss and Miller are still getting the hang of how to write effectively together. They've also lost a bit of the spark that once made their production so thrilling. Sleigh Bells usually have a knack for turning sounds just on the edge of punishing into something deeply
column4: viscerally pleasurable (on the first couple listens Treats seemed like the sort of thing that might permanently damage your hearing)
column5: but Bitter Rivals contains a few of the only Sleigh Bells songs that can rightfully be dismissed as ""grating."" The worst offender here is the hellish chorus of ""Minnie""
column6: which takes what are already Krauss's most uncomfortably piercing backing vocals and
column7: cruelly
column8: pitches them up. I'm pretty sure there are frequencies in this song that only dogs can hear.

column1: The slower
column2: less insistent songs on Bitter Rivals fare better. The R&B-inflected ""Young Legends"" showcases the album's strongest melody
column3: but it's unfortunate that the song's hesitant and ill-fitting production (at least half of Krauss's vocals come through sputtered and muffled like walkie-talkie transmissions) holds it back from fully blooming. The mid-tempo ""Tiger Kit"" is a more effective display of restraint; its do-or-die urgency (""You're gonna jump from that cathedral/ In front of all of these people"") is subtly kindled by synth hits that fire on cue but duck out before they overwhelm the arrangement. One of the album's brightest spots
column4: though
column5: is also its quietest: the airy ballad ""To Hell With You"" shows off Krauss's vocals with minimal effects
column6: and its lyrics slyly toy with the expectations set by its brazen title. Like ""Crush""
column7: it's partially a kiss-off
column8: but the undertones are unexpectedly sweet: ""I'll go to hell with you/ Here's the proof."" It's a rare and welcome moment of pause on a record that often feels cramped
column9: rushed
column10: and cluttered. Much has been made of the fact that it was mixed by Andrew Dawson
column11: who also worked on Yeezus
column12: but what this record really could have used is a reducer.

column2: it’s no longer enough to simply be loud. To command attention in a world that's already blaring with distractions
column3: interruptions
column4: and no shortage of airhorns
column5: a record needs to be loud in a creative
column6: compelling
column7: and previously unexplored way. Sleigh Bells have proven that they know this better than almost anybody making music right now
column8: and that's why Bitter Rivals feels like an exceptionally unfortunate misstep. It isn't enough of a disaster to put a dent in their solid fanbase
column9: but it doesn't have the spark of the stuff that built it up in the first place. Treats had the wildly aerodynamic dips of an elegantly constructed roller coaster—think of that rolling riff that careens through ""A/B Machines""
column10: or the surprise ending of ""Infinity Guitars"" when a song that goes up to 11 reveals
column11: only in the last 40 seconds
column12: that it actually goes up to 12. Bitter Rivals too often feels like a cheap thrill ride
column13:
firing on all cylinders but without any grand design.

0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/19733/homepage_large.131eb1ea.jpg|Electricity By Candlelight|28727.0|Alex Chilton|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Bar/None']|2013-10-08 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:52:11.998661|"

Every tape collector has one crown jewel—a recording of a night where a favorite artist was totally on—and Alex Chilton really needed a tape like that in his discography. Chilton's three albums with Big Star are stone classics; his subsequent recording career was spotty
column2: and after 1987's High Priest he never made a particularly worthwhile studio album. The last 20 years of his life yielded a few sterile-to-perverse records
column3: the cash-in of the Box Tops and Big Star reunions
column4: and not much else besides live shows that the faithful swore were sometimes really good
column5: if Alex was in the mood.

column1: What was going to be Chilton's second set at the Knitting Factory in New York City on a February night in 1997 was cancelled when the power went out. But somebody happened to have an acoustic guitar on hand
column2: and there were some candles
column3: and so Chilton decided to play a few songs for those audience members who were still hanging around. That turned into an impromptu 17-song set of covers that one Jeff Vargon happened to catch on tape.

column1: It's wonderful—a mess
column2: but a marvelous mess. Chilton opens with a pair of far-out-of-the-way country readymades
column3: ""Last Bouquet"" (a 1959 Clyde Owens B-side) and ""Step Right This Way"" (from a 1971 album that songwriter Glen Sherley recorded while in prison); one of Chilton's odder gifts was the ability to tell when some utterly forgotten song would sound great with his cracking
column4: tremulous voice. After that
column5: he mostly shifts to standards--""Lovesick Blues""
column6: ""I Walk the Line""
column7: ""The Girl from Ipanema""—occasionally with the audience joining in
column8: campfire-style.

column1: The crowd shouts requests for his old favorites
column2: which he shoots down
column3: although he revives a couple of jazz tunes from his 1993 album Clichés. The only song from Big Star's repertoire that turns up is a cover: Loudon Wainwright III's groupie-schtupping ballad ""Motel Blues"". This CD gilds the lily by ending with a studio recording of another country cover
column4: Johnny Lee's ""You Can Bet Your Heart on Me""
column5: which is admittedly a little more dignified than the set's actual closer
column6: an ""If I Had a Hammer"" that disintegrates into ridiculousness. (""If I had a potato..."")

column1: Electricity by Candlelight shows off Chilton's instrumental virtuosity and his impressive memory for songs. Show me someone who knows all the chords to ""Wouldn't It Be Nice"" offhand and I'll show you a Beach Boy
column2: but Chilton knocks it out with no problem
column3: then follows it with ""Surfer Girl"" and ""Solar System."" (He bluffs his way through a single verse of Joni Mitchell's ""A Case of You
column4: but come on.) The real joy of this set
column5: though
column6: is that it gives us what Chilton's later career promised but rarely delivered. He's not trying to flip anyone off
column7: or working out torment
column8: or phoning in the oldies with former bandmates and acolytes. He's just a great busker
column9:
having a really good time with his tiny audience. 

"|18542.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18542-alex-chilton-electricity-by-candlelight/|8.1|Douglas Wolk

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/19768/homepage_large.8a23ce3a.jpg|You Gots 2 Chill|8055.0|Brendan Canning|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Draper Street/SQE']|2013-10-08 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:52:12.680857|"

Compared to the messy
column2: sprawling indie rock churned out by his main band Broken Social Scene
column3: Brendan Canning's 2008 solo debut Something for All of Us was a surprisingly low-key affair filled with humble
column4: simply tuneful songs. Canning's kept busy in the half-decade since that album's release with a wide variety of activities
column5: from Broken Social Scene's studio swan song (2010's Forgiveness Rock Record) to film scores (this year's Lindsay Lohan comeback vehicle The Canyons) to a complex
column6: mysterious interactive multimedia endeavor involving director David Cronenberg and a biotech lab. Given the scope of these projects
column7: it's easy to understand why Canning's approach to his new solo record You Gots 2 Chill was decidedly laid-back and homespun: he put together his own independent label to handle the album's release (named for his home street
column8: tucked into the heart of downtown Toronto)
column9: drew the cover art himself
column10: and recorded without help from any of his Broken Social Scene associates. The album title isn't a command to listeners—it's a note to self
column11: the kind of thing you'd throw on a Post-It note and stick onto your fridge.

column1: The music contained within You Gots 2 Chill is true to the album's low-key origins and winking title. Every track is built up around a spine of fingerpicked acoustic guitar and many stop there
column2: content to exist without vocals or instrumental embellishment; Canning draws a rough-hewn
column3: earthen beauty from the strings on tracks like the misty ""Never Go to the Races"" and the wistful ""Last Song for the Summer Hideaway"". There's a refreshing sense of humor present in the album's song titles and sequencing: ""Makes You Motor"" chuckles at its unhurried mid-tempo groove
column4: while the frisky ""Plugged In"" lives off the grid just like the rest of the record. Taken together
column5: this sense of humor and the album's unadorned songwriting combine to give You Gots 2 Chill
column6: and Canning
column7: a charmingly unpretentious vibe. That's not to say that the record is entirely devoid of fully realized songs: cuts like the bubbling
column8: slowly layered ""However Long"" and the pedal steel-flecked lead single ""Bullied Days"" (sung by Snowblink's Daniela Gesundheit) are fleshed out without sacrificing Canning's ear for gentle
column9: slowly shifting melody.

column1: You Gots 2 Chill also pays quiet tribute to the sound and feel of analog technology
column2: with two interludes (""Long Live Land Lines"" and ""Once a Lighthouse"") recorded directly onto Canning's voicemail and placed onto the album. He tips his cap at the influence of the experimental acoustic guitarist John Fahey on album opener ""Post Fahey""
column3: and by devoting the remainder of the album to an exploration of the instrument's melodic possibilities and moods
column4: he makes a decent argument for its continued relevance. But You Gots 2 Chill's defining characteristic is also its key weakness: if listeners fail to grant each new mid-tempo acoustic number its fair share of attention
column5: they begin to blur together into one large mid-tempo acoustic blob. This is a bedtime record
column6: in both the complementary and dismissive senses of the word: it invites you to relax and soothes like a warm cup of tea
column7:
but can cross the line into powerfully soporific territory. 

"|18575.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18575-brendan-canning-you-gots-2-chill/|6.7|Jamieson Cox

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/19731/homepage_large.5c747d83.jpg|S/H|29955.0|Steve Hauschildt|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Editions Mego']|2013-10-08 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:52:13.393688|"

Did Steve Hauschildt consider naming this 2CD set A Young Person’s Guide to Steve Hauschildt? I ask because there are lots of similarities between S/H and his Emeralds colleague Mark McGuire’s 2011 double-disc A Young Person’s Guide to Mark McGuire. Both are compilations of rare and unreleased tracks; both offer everything from short vignettes to fleshed-out
column2: 10-minute-plus journeys; and both paint a pretty comprehensive picture of the ideas and skills each artist brought to their work in now-defunct Emeralds. Both even use a fluorescent blue color palette on their covers.

column1: This isn’t to say that Hauschildt ripped McGuire off—tons of artists have put out similar compilations—nor that his work should automatically be judged next to that of former comrades. But the two share a musical method that remains fascinating. As noted in Pitchfork's review of the McGuire set
column2: the guitarist finds “remarkable flexibility” in a narrow stylistic range. The same goes for Hauschildt’s synth-based work on S/H. Its tones and moods are devoutly consistent
column3: yet it’s richly engaging throughout.

column1: Part of that is due
column2: somewhat paradoxically
column3: to the lower-stakes nature of S/H. Many of its pieces have a work-in-progress feel
column4: moreso than the developed
column5: honed material on Hauschildt’s previous albums. There was a lot to like on those—especially 2011’s Tragedy & Geometry—but I prefer him in this kind of lab-rat
column6: see-what-sticks mode. Nothing here sounds tossed off
column7: but Hauschildt doesn't always feel obligated to stretch each idea into an ebb-and-flow song. He’s happy to focus on a single sonic concept
column8: then pursue another one on the next track rather than forcing them to work together. This tack has the added effect of making Hauschildt’s wallpaper-y pieces
column9: which can sometimes feel like filler
column10: more integral
column11: serving as transitions and pace-changers between more gripping tracks.

column1: The draft-ish quality of S/H also makes it more personal than Hauschildt’s previous releases. These are instrumental
column2: sometimes abstract pieces in which the human action that created each sound isn’t always obvious. Yet I often feel I’m getting a glimpse at the machinations of Hauschildt’s mind. His particular way of toying with ideas and sketching patterns is probing without sounding rushed. Ripples
column3: squiggles
column4: waves
column5: beats
column6: and rising chords all unfurl with the patience of a meditation. But I don’t picture Hauschildt reclined behind his instruments when I listen. Instead I imagine him leaned over his tools
column7: pushing them to replicate the sounds in his head.

column1: That image is most vivid on disc one
column2: comprising 21 previously-unreleased tracks recorded between 2010 and 2012. Everything Hauschildt is good at gets covered here
column3: especially his way of generating emotion and tension with ostensibly mellow tones. Sprinkled throughout are some more outward-bound pieces
column4: like the field-recording-like “Flyswatter” and the sci-fi stunner “Flatbed Scanner”
column5: that extend Hauschildt’s reach without diminishing his grasp. Disc two generally feels more settled. Drones and longer tones are more frequent in these pieces made between 2005 and 2009. There’s still some forward-moving stuff to dig into
column6: and lots of ways to become transfixed by Hauschildt’s extended sounds. But anyone inclined toward his pulse-heavy side will likely set disc one on repeat before drifting into disc two.

column1: It seems just as likely that any Emeralds followers underwhelmed by their 2012 swan song
column2: Just to Feel Anything
column3: will find reasons in S/H to renew their optimism about Hauschildt's musical future. I imagine he would welcome that response
column4: since
column5: as with McGuire’s solo work
column6: S/H is music designed for positivity
column7: even when it sounds solemn or melancholy. By the end of its two and a half hours
column8:
negativity is about the farthest thing from my mind.

"|18540.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18540-steve-hauschildt-sh/|7.5|Marc Masters

""Dentist drill"" is an easy comparison to reach for when describing how a noise-rock guitar sounds. But listen to the final seconds of ""Across The Horizon""
column3: the final track from the Omaha band Yuppies' self-titled record
column4: and it seems pretty clear guitarist/vocalist Jack Begley wants to eliminate the possibility that we'd think about anything else. Torquing and choking his strings
column5: he wrings out an insistent neener-neener that uncannily mimics the drill's blank
column6: skull-boring insistence. The song isn't much more than a minute
column7: but it lingers uncomfortably

column1: Yuppies

column5: post-punk lockstep

column11: all right
column12: we're going for a ride

column14: Begley tells you in ""A Ride"". Then
column15: when the doors lock
column16: he turns to you and shrieks
column17: forcefully.

column1: Yuppies is a tight
column2: white-knuckled
column3: and genuinely unpredictable record. The band recorded the entire first half of it in one long live take
column4: and the nerviness of the endeavor is palpable. Songs don't start or end

column6: thrashing like fevered limbs in sweaty bedsheets. ""Across the Prairies""
column7: the queasy

Nicolas Jaar would likely take offense with the same old dutiful recitation of his credentials— you know
column3: the Chilean-born
column4: Brown-educated electronic wunderkind
column5: Clown & Sunset label head
column6: serious artiste behind BBC’s Essential Mix of 2012
column7: musical cubes
column8: and a 5-hour MoMA performance in a geodesic dome. In our interview from earlier this year
