column10: and that’s fair enough. Who doesn’t hope to be seen as a different person at 23 than they were at 21? But that's the kind of C.V. you only play down if you're worried about being called an elitist or running for public office. That might not be so far off the mark in regards to Darkside
column11: Jaar’s partnership with guitarist Dave Harrington. The name alone triggers an automatic word association with an album owned by over 50 million people and recognized by nearly everyone who’s made it to 10th grade. The prismatic
column12: black-lit aura of their fascinating
column13: endlessly explorable debut Psychic doesn’t try to stop anyone from making that connection and if you spot Jaar’s stated influences of Can and Richie Hawtin
column14: that’s fine too: rarely has a record held such appeal for the high-minded while welcoming the simply high-minded.

column1: Though a logical extension of the prog-dance fusion explored on Darkside’s self-titled EP from 2011
column2: it makes their curious reimagination of Daft Punk’s Random Access Memories from a few months back feel like their true debut. Upon initially hearing it
column3: one could easily think of Daftside as an academic work rather than something meant for listening pleasure—a foment of the bubbling resentment towards the original’s Gatsby-esque confluence of ostentatious extravagance and genuine
column4: if self-serving
column5: benevolence; it was a hell of a party that left a lot of up-and-coming producers feeling like they were locked out of East Egg. However
column6: Psychic and Daftside have the same essential goal
column7: guided equally by artistic reverence and crackpot scheming. And that aim is to emulsify the disparate record industry obsessions that dominated right before the advent of the compact disc: opulent disco and ornate prog-rock
column8: yacht-pop and astral funk
column9: the former of each almost exclusively singles mediums
column10: the latter beholden to the LP and all sounding like the sole province of bearded
column11: flamboyantly lapelled millionaires.

column1: On the gargantuan opening gambit of “Golden Arrow”
column2: Darkside spend 11 minutes misremembering the ground rules for music neither of them were alive to hear the first time around. The heartbeat pulse serving a baseline for those distant
column3: whirring synthesizers and hollowed-out drones is pure space-rock
column4: but the gorgeous overlay of sighing cello and digital disintegration is not. When the beat finally drops after about four minutes
column5: it’s a slack and stumbling disco interloper—high on pot
column6: not blow. Those palm-muted funk guitars have After Dark bloodshot tincture
column7: but that label would never allow this much modernist
column8: bit-crushing babble in their proudly purist Italo
column9: let alone that undulating synth bass. And then
column10: Harrington’s falsetto takes off like an apparitional Gibb brother and...are we sure this isn’t disco? Do these guys have any clue what they’re doing?

column1: Thankfully
column2: the answer is “hell no”—they have a plan
column3: but no ground rules or precedents; Darkside aren’t recreating anything. The subliminal bass shadowing Jaar’s vocals on the confounding
column4: starched-shirt blues of “Paper Trails” has its own gravitational pull
column5: it only exists in music made by Nico Jaar. Nor is there a session player capable of conjuring the panglobal percussion that morphs throughout “The Only Shrine I’ve Seen”
column6: the impossibly lush layering of cymbals
column7: snares
column8: bells
column9: and claps joining the hands of church choirs
column10: marching bands
column11: and Buddhist monks. Even Harrington’s rudimentary
column12: blues box guitar soloing gives Psychic crucial
column13: humanist grounding—those slowhand Dire Straits leads are the last thing you’d expect a forward-thinking electronic musician to incorporate into their mission statement
column14: but amongst all the retro-futurist discovery

column4: the silences are moments of active listening
column5: too. “Sitra” initially registers as a necessary comedown from the stern demands of “Golden Arrow” until it pans completely in the left stereo channel. Darkside anticipate the very moment right before the disorientation of the unbalanced mix would be unnecessarily confrontational and drop you right into “Heart”
column6: a traipse down the yellow brick road set to unsettling tribal drums. And just when you think it's getting kind personal on its one narrative (“Paper Trails”)
column7: the album drifts off into staticky calm.

column1: That tranquil moment gets blown open thirty seconds later by ""The Only Shrine I've Seen"" and that’s just the first half of Psychic coming to a close. Side B only gets weirder as it hews more closely to Jaar’s associations with proper dance music. Up to this point
column2: “space disco” typically meant one thing—airy
column3: pretty
column4: generally envisioning a brighter
column5: cleaner future. “The Only Shrine I’ve Seen” and “Freak
column6: Go Home” imagine what dance music could spring up from our future lunar cities if they’re every bit the dense
column7: intimidating
column8: metal monstrosities they are here on earth
column9: teeming with both life and decay
column10: flesh and rust. The most innovative and intriguing sounds on Psychic are almost entirely dedicated to its rhythm section—panned tambourines whizzing through “Paper Trails”
column11: gooey snares on the hot-buttered closer “Metatron”
column12: “Freak
column13: Go Home”’s constant fluidity between acoustic and digital percussion. Though Psychic is the kind of immense and immersive experience typically described as “monolithic”
column14: Jaar and Harrington ensure it’s more like the bubble gracing its cover—translucent and dense
column15: electrified and organic
column16: holding a form while constantly being prodded into new shapes.

column1: When a record spends this much time reveling in pure sound
column2: it’s understandable to ask
column3: “Where’s the humanity?” The most instantly memorable lyric comes on “Paper Trails”
column4: when Jaar intones “I want a house to live in/ Baby to take care of
column5: ” though in that voice of his
column6: you never expect him to mean exactly what he says. Psychic doesn’t talk a whole lot about its feelings; true to its title
column7: it’s not looking for a heart-to-heart so much as a telepathic exchange. And in trying to read Jaar and Harrington’s minds
column8: you might think a little differently about things you already know
column9: which can be just as important as being moved. Though the psychedelic density and classic rock touchstones of Psychic are ostensibly a negation of Jaar’s breakthrough
column10: the quizzical
column11: minimalist Space Is Only Noise
column12: reconsider his intimidating biography and all of a sudden

column15: start record labels because they want to make music with their friends and
column16: yes
column17: Ivy League kids like to get stoned and listen to Pink Floyd. At least for the duration of Psychic
column18:
everything under the sun is in tune.

When bands break up or embark on extended hiatuses
column2: the cumulative effect of all those years away is automatically assumed to be degenerative. Conventional wisdom suggests that the passage of time—and the day jobs
column3: marriages
column4: and diaper changes that often go with it—will inevitably erode the youthful abandon and creative frisson that fuels inspiration
column5: not to mention the aging musician’s physical ability to retain their chops. But since reforming five years ago after a decade of inaction
column6: Chapel Hill indie-rock linchpins Polvo have been getting down to the business of blowing such theories out of the water. Their wholly impressive 2009 comeback effort
column7: In Prism
column8: instead proffered the notion that
column9: when removed from the load-in/load-out drudgery of perpetual van tours
column10: artists are able to reflect
column11: refine
column12: and re-energize—and come out the other side a stronger
column13: more confident
column14: and more intuitive band than ever before. The band’s second post-reformation record
column15: Siberia
column16: drives the point home even further.

column1: Polvo’s improved prowess can be felt in literally the album’s opening seconds. Like a beaten-down lawnmower
column2: the band’s early records needed a few tugs to rev up—think of the many false starts of “Thermal Treasure” on Today’s Active Lifestyles
column3: or the molasses-drip intro of Exploded Drawing’s “Fast Canoe”—as if the band was untangling and reorganizing its intricate strategies in real time. By contrast
column4: Siberia’s introductory salvo
column5: “Total Immersion
column6: ” provides just that in an instant—it’s as if we’re joining the band in progress at the precise moment they locked into the song’s powerful riff during hour five of an all-night jam session
column7: with all the sweat and humidity in the room shaken out through the barrelling
column8: handclapped backbeat. But where art-rock forbears like Canfamously distilled their epic improvisation sessions into more manageable pieces
column9: Polvo work the other way
column10: revealing new melodies and motifs in train-like fashion; they’re constantly opening new doors to explore
column11: but in a linear
column12: structured fashion. The real triumph of Polvo’s second phase is how they’ve managed to become a more approachable band without losing their sense of adventure—they can still go from accessible to inscrutable and back in a single chord progression but the shifts feel fluid and predestined rather than spastic and impulsive. Their songs have come more sprawling
column13: but their albums on the whole have become tighter and more focused and
column14: in the case of the breezy but byzantine ""Blues Is Loss""
column15: they have an uncanny knack for making a seven-minute song feel more like three.

column1: Siberia is very much a sister album to In Prism
column2: adopting its predecessor’s eight-song
column3: four-to-a-side composition and even its sequential trade-offs between hot-wired rockers and psychedelicized excursions. But within these set parameters
column4: the band continually surprise—in the extended fadeout to spectacular centerpiece track “The Water Wheel” alone
column5: there’s enough new passages introduced in 90 seconds to spawn another record. Just when you think “Total Immersion” is about to dissolve in a dub-fuzz quicksand
column6: its central riff suddenly reemerges like a rescue team leading you back to safety; and just as you’ve adjusted your ears to the high-beam synths (!) that  drive the chorus of “Light
column7: Raking""
column8: you’re hit with a twinned
column9: harmonic guitar solo straight out of the Brian May/Thin Lizzy playbook.

column1: These subtle classic-rock quotes—like the “Tom Sawyer”-worthy arpeggio that underpins the tranquil “Changed”—serve to make Polvo’s complex guitarchitecture more inviting to the uninitiated
column2: but what really makes Polvo 2.0 an especially enticing proposition is Ash Bowie and Dave Brylawski’s more emotionally revelatory approach to their vocals. Polvo’s 90s-era output didn’t necessarily shy away from pop melody
column3: but you often had to cut through the band’s barbed-wire discord to get at it. Siberia puts the hooks—and lyrical ruminations on passion versus reason—further out front than even In Prism
column4: to take full advantage of their ageless but increasingly expressive voices: the deceptively serene prog-folk reprieve “Old Maps"" acquires the spectral melancholy of Elliott Smith
column5: while the punchy power-pop of “Some Songs” will satisfy that rogue faction of first-album Foo Fighters fans who wish Dave Grohl would’ve continued down the winsome
column6: jangly path of “Big Me” rather than cranking up the stadium-grunge ballast. Fifteen years ago
column7: it would’ve been strange to be speak of Polvo in relation to such noted melody-makers
column8: but at this stage in their career
column9: crafting pop songs is as much an experiment for Polvo as piecing together multi-sectional avant-rock odysseys. And what makes Siberia so great is that it thoroughly succeeds on both counts—proving once again that
column10: for Polvo
column11: all those years out of the game are to be measured not in inspiration lost
column12:
but wisdom gained.

A little more than a decade after Deadringer came out
column2: there's enough music—and enough attempts at reconfiguring his style—to help you construct a picture of how all over the map RJD2's career has been. Whether it's a clear picture is another thing entirely; his shift from underground rap production next big thing to muddled indie-pop singer-songwriter to studio-bound funkateer has done a lot to confuse any set-in-stone ideas of what the RJD2 sound was or is supposed to be. His partnership with Aaron Livingston as Icebird seemed like a good first step towards a reconciliation of everything RJ had built up in his portfolio over the previous ten years or so. But it also opened the door for a big “now what?"" and the hesitant anticipation of future work that could build on the idea of an all-encompassing
column3: canonical RJD2 musical identity.

column1: And now
column2: for what feels like the first time in his career
column3: RJ has released an album that comes across as a successful culmination of all his previous ideas and experiments rather than simply a new shift in style.. The title of More Is Than Isn't says as much; these are established trademarks and tics—bombastic drum breaks
column4: sunshine-gleam brass
column5: an armada of mothership synthesizers—that definitely sound like they came from the same hands that Deadringer
column6: Since We Last Spoke and The Colossus did. But it's that first album's boom-bap crate-digging
column7: its follow-up's prog-funk ambition
column8: and his most recent album's cartoon neo-soul all streamlined into an overarching sound
column9: with all the Pavlov triggers and odd quirks and over-the-top crests that combination implies.

column1: With this album uniting everything that made RJ RJ over the years
column2: it establishes a definitive place for him after all this time: that of the hip-hop-inflected neo-soul fusionist producer who is just as comfortable working in moods as genres. With his instrumentals
column3: it's as though he's working more in potential-soundtrack mode than anything; it's easier to describe his beats nowadays for what montages or scenes they could evoke rather than where their component parts could place them demographically. You can definitely dance to a lot of it: the Isley-flecked groove of “Behold
column4: Numbers!” extends this summer's disco-funk revivalism into early fall
column5: “Winter Isn't Coming” goes all neon-space-pyramid with high-BPM footwork-jostling bongo breaks
column6: and the Rick Rubin-oid
column7: Mellotron/piano/space-laser breakdown showcase “Her Majesty's Socialist Request” has already proven through its video to be a killer b-boy/b-girl anthem.

column1: The vocal cuts are both a bit less frequent and a fair amount stronger than in his last couple records. There are a couple strong rap tracks
column2: with emerging Columbus art-rapper P. Blackk rolling out fluid doubletime boasts over the Southern bounce-style “Bathwater” and old Soul Position partner Blueprint harnessing some of that vintage “Final Frontier” smoothness into nimble heist-metaphor storytelling for the Meters-go-caper-flick soul twang of “It All Came to Me in a Dream”. And while RJ does lend that hesitant falsetto of his to one of the tracks—the twee
column3: contemplative “Dirty Hands
column4: ” where he actually fits well amongst the beatless chimes and strings—he largely leaves the vocals to R&B singers who can do his heavy-breaks production justice
column5: like Icebird collaborator Aaron Livingston (“Love and Go”) or Little Brother's Phonte Coleman (doing a more straightfaced—and affecting—version of his Percy Miracles loverman schtick on “Temperamental”). It peaks on “See You Leave
column6: ” a cut featuring Roots-affiliated rapper STS and singer/writer Khari Mateen
column7: that's as buttery as it gets; on an album that fits right in with R&B and hip-hop's free-for-all cross-genre fusion it's good to hear that RJ can build trad-soul beats with the best of them.

column1: Still
column2: as easy as it is to click with these songs as dance tracks or muso-appreciation fodder (RJ can still program and orchestrate a breakdown like nobody's business)
column3: it's better still to zone out and catch their sense of mood. While the vocal tracks are well-realized
column4: this is the first album RJ's made in a long time that actually feels like it's satisfied to say most of what it has to say in instrumental form. His style-weaving
column5: retro-contemporary instrumentation dislodges sounds from their own times and finds new modes for them. So when he rolls out burbling synthesizers that recall the early '90s heyday of ambient techno and 70s prog and glazes them over a class-of-'88 no-bullshit boom-bap break (“A Lot of Night Ahead of You”)
column6: or constructs a noir-jazz ballad that snaps from early Tom Waits tipsiness to uptempo Mayfield-style funk (“Got There
column7: Sugar?”)
column8: all the parts fit together to turn a pastiche into something a bit less beholden to the sum of its parts. It's less about where the pieces come from than what they're evoking. And even if it's made clear by the conceptual thread that ties the album together—a three-part suite that leads off the album
column9: appears at the halfway mark
column10:
and concludes it with three emotively varying takes on the same melodic theme—the fact that the whole of More Is Than Isn't evokes so many different well-built moods is testament to how much he's been able to elaborate on what he's capable of.

column3: the first single from his new full-length Lost
column4: sparked a lot of excitement amongst Trentemøller fans. The drums build from a tribal romp to a panicked bubbling
column5: rife with stealthy
column6: undercover bass—the kind that unintentionally nods to a techno-master’s version of footwork. Jonny Pierce of the Drums swoops in to set the scene for a distant dystopian landscape
column7: crooning with a combination of innocent yearning and pop-worthy sentimentality. That pop sensibility is solidified once a wave of dubstep bolsters his hook: “We gotta leave before we dieeeee.” On the surface the song feels like a relatively natural progression after Trentemøller’s 2010 Into The Great Wide Yonder
column8: an album that benefited from these types of wide-reaching cinematics. Whether Trentemøller’s newest album’s successes are indeed its songwriting is another matter.

column1: The fact that more than half of the songs on Lost carry guest vocalists is surely a sign of something. Or
column2: at the least
column3: that this producer is looking to test the boundaries of his abilities in the indie-pop/rock sphere. Sometimes his knack for blending minimal techno and house works towards that
column4: sounding both progressive and true-to-self. Other times
column5: the DJ's innovation is lost in the mix. Take “Gravity”
column6: an opening track which features Jana Hunter of Lower Dens. The song carries Trentemøller signifiers—a ping-ponging
column7: bleepy synth pattern and minimal
column8: plodding bass—but add Hunter and the singer’s haunting moans are immediately lifted into a swirl of psychedelic grooves. An enveloping of strings and a somber horn ballad sweep the track into becoming something that’s dictated by Hunter’s presence; “Gravity” is a perfectly fine Lower Dens track.

column1: “Come Undone” features Kazu Makino of Blonde Redhead and the producer’s role similarly becomes second-string to his singer. Perhaps it’s the distinct way Makino bends her melodies into syrupy moans

column4: featuring the Raveonettes' Sune Rose Wagner
column5: where we see Trentemøller's behind-the-scene skills stretched to their greatness. What begins as an exercise in the dark techno he's especially great at becomes much more. A feverish
column6: unhinged synth buzz resonates as the speed picks up
column7: making Wagner’s whispers of treacherous love sound increasingly harrowing in the process—all the while
column8: “Deceive” ends up as one of Lost's most danceable tracks.

column1: Needless to say
column2: the straight instrumentals on Lost are where Trentemøller ’s technical prowess is highlighted. As Philip Sherburne mentioned in his review of The Last Resort
column3: this is a man who “deftly fuses minimal techno
column4: big-room house
column5: and the itchy-scratchy fidgeting of IDM without sounding tokenistic.” Here the DJ stays true to this idea while leaping into other universes altogether. “Trails” unfolds as a krautrock stomp where crashing chimes and furious guitars take cues from Indian folk before hopscotching into a spacey laser-light show. (It's too bad he didn't pull Hunter onto something like this.) “Constantinople” jumps on a similar ship: a shrill accordion melody sampled from old Bollywood cruises through a bombardment of electric guitar and driving drums. Add the bass and the whole thing plays out like his own version of a wild jam session in a Turkish nightclub.

column1: It's worth noting ""Never Stop Running"" was released on vinyl
column2: its B-side featuring the instrumental track of the song. Listening to it stripped of its vocals
column3: there's no doubting that the clever structuring of epic dance-floor blends is one of Trentemøller's greatest strengths. ""Still On Fire""
column4: for example
column5: is a simply-presented industrial escapade with grunting reverb
column6: gloomy singing synths
column7: and the tinkling of a million percussive embellishments—yet it still manages to deliver an emotive punch. The question for the producer going forward is whether any of these strong
column8:
statement instrumentals are more restricted by or benefit from collaborative effort. Because sometimes he's better off dancing on his own.

Being immortalized in song by Led Zeppelin-- and collaborating with everyone from Kate Bush to Paul McCartney to Pink Floyd-- ought to do wonders for one’s career. That hasn’t always been the case for Roy Harper. In some ways he’s been the invisible glue that’s held together generations of singer-songwriters
column2: a one-man secret history of progressive folk-rock underscoring the continuum that stretches from Bert Jansch to Joanna Newsom. In other ways
column3: he’s been overshadowed by those who love him most. In 2009
column4: Harper lamented the fact that
column5: by his accounting
column6: he’d never been paid by Roger Waters for singing lead vocals on Pink Floyd’s 1975 hit “Have a Cigar”-- a song
column7: ironically
column8: that condemns the greed of the music industry. Harper had just pledged retirement from that industry
column9: one that praised him far more than rewarded him. At the time
column10: it had been nine years since he’d released an album
column11: 2000’s The Green Man. If Harper were to be believed
column12: it would be his last.

column1: It’s now been thirteen years since The Green Man-- and that gap has been stopped by Man and Myth. Still
column2: it feels like a stopgap. Harper explores no new territory
column3: sonically or thematically
column4: on the disc’s seven songs; if anything
column5: it’s a stately retreat into the 72-year-old’s well-trod sound. As always
column6: his voice is alternately dream-shrouded and strident
column7: and his fingerpicking remains fluid and supple. On “The Enemy” and “January Man""
column8: his acoustic serves as a shadowy
column9: impressionistic backdrop as he ruminates on the past
column10: both fictionally and confessionally. “The Enemy” dwells with melancholy sentiment on the faded specter of post-World Word II romanticism; “January Man” goes gingerly for its own jugular with unguarded pathos: “Time fell away/ Licking my wounds/ A lifetime astray
column11: ” Harper keens
column12: allowing his nostalgic narrative to crumble into fractured syntax.

column1: Those cracks grow too wide on “Time Is Temporary"". The song’s overbearing wordplay can’t overcome a pedestrian
column2: at times corny talking blues. “A vision of purity / In an old Pre-Raphaelite dream” Harper pines
column3: but his anachronistic overlay of 19th century aesthetics and 20th century Americana is more of a muddle than mystery. “The Stranger” fares far better. Celtic-accented and breathtakingly dynamic
column4: it’s a dark yet lilting ballad that erupts in bursts of revelation and suspense. Harper’s obsession with myth is given a suitably epic treatment on “Heaven Is Here""
column5: a 15-minute odyssey that recalls his 1971 masterpiece Stormcock in its richness and scope. What begins as a simple recounting of the tale of Jason and the Argonauts morphs slowly
column6: across a mist of crystalline strumming and elliptical verse
column7: into a deep gaze into Harper’s own mirror. “O how do I/ Retrace my youth/ From present lie/ To former truth
column8: ” he sings. As cheeky and clever as Harper can be
column9: it doesn’t seem like meta-commentary on his own body of work; rather
column10: it’s a study in the gray area between myth and mythopoeia that imagines a prog-folk Joseph Campbell.

column1: The steady cadence of Man and Myth is most strikingly broken up by “Cloud Cuckooland"". Harper trots out one of the most overworked metaphors in Western culture
column2: but he aims it at a fresh target: fame. Unfortunately
column3: it’s not aimed well. Despite a bombastic assist from Pete Townshend
column4: who unleashes an inspired burst of riffage
column5: “Cloud Cuckooland” paints the post-millennium as a little more than a place where “The punters gather at primetime/ On the flat screens of their dreams/ To vote for dumb celebrity.” Harper dresses up the rest of his rant in pretty language-- including a shout-out to one of his closest contemporaries
column6: Neil Young: “The great shampooed are stranded/ With the cowgirls in the sand”-- but it’s still a rant. Existing in the fissures between stardom and obscurity
column7: between myth and man
column8:
Harper has never been either. Man and Myth won’t change that.

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/19728/homepage_large.8f4faae3.jpg|R Plus Seven|28187.0|Oneohtrix Point Never|['Experimental']|1.0|0.0|0.0|['Warp']|2013-10-04 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:52:16.891838|"

There’s a continual tension in experimental electronic music between developing and owning a particular sound and exploring new ones. Creating a unique identity is difficult
column2: and sometimes breaking out of it once it's been established is even harder. Daniel Lopatin of Oneohtrix Point Never is an artist working at one end of this spectrum. He’s restless
column3: searching for new terrain
column4: and his more recent full-lengths have found him reinventing himself with each new record. R Plus Seven
column5: the follow-up to 2011’s Replica
column6: sounds little like previous OPN releases. But despite the radical shifts—and this is what makes this project so consistently rewarding—you can still hear him in it; there are bedrock approaches and clear musical values that you can pick out as Lopatin.

column1: The general approach on R Plus Seven is to build new music using the bright yet cold textures of the early age of personal computing. The aesthetic is identifiably “80s
column2: ” but it’s not the 80s of new wave
column3: with its familiar array of synthesizers. Instead
column4: Lopatin focuses on the hauntingly clean and clear pre-set sounds that were available for early
column5: crude digital music production (and which were often used in commercial applications
column6: from bumpers for local PBS shows to soundtracking instructional videos) and adds the kind of short-burst bits of information that were common when a sampler could hold two or three seconds of 8-bit audio. While this sort of throwback is common in electronic music
column7: for Lopatin it serves a purpose beyond reference. R Plus Seven is aware of how music and textures like this are likely to be received
column8: but it plays with our collective unconscious of music technology to develop something that comes off as strange and otherworldly and
column9: most importantly
column10: rich with feeling
column11: despite the icy surface layer.

column1: There’s a weird kind of innocence in this sound palette. The fake horns and whooshing vocal samples evoke a time when “the computer” as a concept was still very much rooted in the future rather than the present. The chintzy approximations of common instruments contain a sort of implicit critique of the idea that technology will save us all
column2: but Lopatin’s music doesn’t get hung up on irony
column3: even though it's definitely in the mix. It’s this quality
column4: of highlighting the vacuous side of this music while simultaneously embracing its humor and poignancy
column5: that elevates the OPN project to another plane.

column1: Along those lines
column2: during my first few listens to R Plus Seven
column3: it was hard not to think of James Ferraro’s recent work in this area
column4: specifically his album Far Side Virtual
column5: which used the impossibly cheerful and polished sound of early digital culture to emphasize the music’s connection to mindless
column6: friction-free commerce. To Ferraro’s credit
column7: he’s kept a poker face when presenting this music
column8: and you never quite knew where he was coming from
column9: which made the listening experience fraught with ambiguity and anxiety. But Lopatin comes at it from another angle. He wants his music to do things that music is traditionally known to do: change
column10: develop
column11: use melody to convey feelings
column12: build tension and then release it. That all of this happens within such tightly controlled parameters makes the fact that the record is emotionally engaging that much more impressive. Common sonic threads include wispy digitized voices on tracks like “Americans” and “Chrome Country” that bring to mind the then-exotic turn-of-the-80s sound of the Fairlight synthesizer
column13: an early sampling device
column14: along with many brittle digital versions of sounds that are distantly “exotic
column15: ” conveying the feel of a blocky pixilated representation of a jungle or beach scenes.

column1: Indeed
column2: with “Americans” and “Inside World”
column3: the album makes sharp use of contrasts between the real and the virtual
column4: between “natural” and the representation of natural. I’m tempted to call it Fifth World Music in homage to the 1980 John Hassel/Brian Eno album Fourth World: Possible Musics
column5: a record that has a clear spiritual connection to this one. Hassel and Eno hoped to filter ancient tribal sounds through the sound of technology to create an alien but distantly familiar landscape (their project generated discussion about clumsy wording and potentially problematic ideas of what constituted “primitive” music
column6: but that’s a subject for another time). Lopatin grapples with some of those ideas of decontextualization and colliding worlds
column7: but the meeting place is closer to a tableau from Second Life
column8: providing another layer of disorientation.

column1: Still
column2: I can’t underscore strongly enough that
column3: as with Replica
column4: all of this takes place in a realm where musicality is paramount. You don’t listen to this record thinking about theory; it’s beautiful stuff
column5: with chords and tunes and sections you remember. And it also draws from more sounds and eras than I’ve given it credit for. Opening track “Boring Angel” seems a tribute to the glorious repetition of Terry Riley’s process music
column6: while “Along” and “Cryo” are closer to the mood and structure of that place where late-90s IDM sounds met the winding structures of post-rock. R Plus Seven doesn’t have quite the disembodied weirdness of Replica
column7: but it’s no less accomplished
column8:
another intriguing chapter from an artist whose work remains alive with possibility.

0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/19791/homepage_large.08cbeee8.jpg|Is Survived By|31567.0|Touché Amoré|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Deathwish']|2013-10-04 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:52:18.195884|"

After a bracing EP and two genre-revitalizing LPs
column2: nothing was the same for Los Angeles post-hardcore band Touché Amoré going into Is Survived By. Lead singer Jeremy Bolm’s got a lot on his mind-- He’s concerned about what his third album will mean for his legacy as an artist and whether he’s focused too much on what he does rather than who he is. He sees the replication of his father’s shortcomings in his current relationships
column3: but realizes his old man did the best he could. Fake friends are forgiven and then quickly forgotten as Bolm starts to like who he’s becoming. Or
column4: in short
column5: Touché Amoré started from the bottom and the whole team’s fuckin’ here on the superlative Is Survived By
column6: including Balance & Composure’s Jon Simmons
column7: Andy Hull of Manchester Orchestra and revered indie producer Brad Wood.

column1: Granted
column2: it’s unlikely that Is Survived By will divert the attention of Drake listeners this week even if they’d find plenty of thematic similarities. But it’s not impossible and Touché Amoré appear keenly aware that Is Survived By has them poised to reach beyond a fanbase that can be described as “hardcore” one way or the other. For the most part
column3: Bolm is trying to maintain some sort of grace while kinda freaking out about the situation-- “you can call this coming clean or a repeat of what you know/ about the struggles I once had as I’m learning to let go”
column4: goes the frantic introduction of “To Write Content.” He tips his hand with the mere title of “Social Caterpillar” and assures the listener
column5: “don’t worry I still get dizzy in the usual situations.” Sure
column6: he was still pulling hours at a Burbank record shop this year
column7: but as the frontman for an intensely loved and meaningful punk band
column8: he gets put in a lot of unusual situations for the typical guy.

column1: For example
column2: the one he encounters on opener “Just Exist”
column3: where someone inquires how he’d “like to be remembered”
column4: the sort of question typically asked of
column5: say
column6: Drake. His answer becomes the sole joke on an album of almost superhuman sobriety-- “I simply smiled and said ‘I’d rather stay forever.’” By the song’s end
column7: he figures out the trick is in the title (“you’ll never know much of the truth/so I’ll just exist”) and as insular as Bolm’s concerns may be
column8: Touché Amoré veer towards accessibility in all aspects on Is Survived By.

column1: Bolm still maintains the same jagged wail that got Touché Amoré (not wrongfully) tagged as “screamo” at the outset-- all grit and serration
column2: no affectation-- and the band provides plenty of max-chaos-per-second supercolliders in the form of “DNA” and “Blue Angel"". Only this time
column3: they’re placed in the context of these funny things called “songs.” Some of them run up to three whole minutes and beyond
column4: some are slow and even pretty in a twinkly emo kind of way (“To Write Content”
column5: “Non Fiction”)
column6: some are love songs and all of them are produced with clarity and precision by a guy whose big credits are for Liz Phair
column7: Smashing Pumpkins and Sunny Day Real Estate records that are older than a lot of the kids I see at Touché Amoré shows.

column1: Is Survived By is about 50% longer than any other Touché Amoré album and the quintet wisely instruct the listener how to pace themselves. The near a cappella “Praise/Love” and near post-rock instrumental “Non Fiction” would be remarkable for introducing variety alone; in the scheme of Is Survived By
column2: they’re plot devices
column3: introducing lyrical and musical motifs repeated immediately thereafter in “Anyone/Anything” and “Steps"". These tracks jolt the listener right back with choruses that go outside the scope of “melodic hardcore” into a bruised and spittle-flecked pop-punk that comes awfully close to radio-friendly
column4: even if you’ll never hear it at Warped Tour.

column1: In essence
column2: it’s an excellent band continuing to be excellent with more people paying attention. They haven’t lost sight of what got them here
column3: however the band downplays their own virtuosity by emphasizing a studied recklessness
column4: cranking out one anthemic riff after another
column5: providing a familiar melodic framework that just skirts total recall. They serve as a setting for a frontman who barks out words that take the shape of narratives and conversations rather than poetry. In particular
column6: “Harbor” and “To Write Content” are story-songs as well as cerebral exercises based upon the multiple (mis)readings of their titles. On the latter
column7: Bolm meets Hull for the first time through mutual friends in New York and communes over a common concern shared by an LA punk band and a southern
column8: grungy emo act-- can your personal happiness be an artistic liability?

column1: There is a lot of “I” and “me” on Is Survived By
column2: but it focuses on the social utility of the self
column3: that a content person is more likely to make a positive difference. On the closing title track
column4: Bolm implores the listener to “write a song that everyone can sing along to/ so when you’re gone
column5: you can live on/they won’t forget you.” It’s easy to meet that statement with cynicism: surely
column6: our society would be better off if fewer people believed they were a special little snowflake with a song that needs to be heard
column7: right? But if you haven’t seen Touché Amoré live
column8: you should
column9: in part because it provides the proper visual-- the raw-throated
column10: stone-faced man you hear on Is Survived By is liable to appear cleancut
column11: constantly smiling even and he knows his band would be nothing without you. “Is Survived By” is pretty much an audio thank you note. The physicality of Is Survived By is more like a bear hug than an ass-kicking
column12: wherein the passion can be scary at first
column13: but it’s disarming
column14: done out of love. They take this stuff seriously because this
column15: <i>right here
column16: matters. You matter. And within these songs is the struggle in realizing that self-esteem comes more from estimable acts than outside validation. Is Survived By should receive plenty praise anyway
column17: but Touché Amoré lead by example.

It's difficult
column2: if not totally impossible at this point
column3: to pry Khaela Maricich from the clutches of 2006
column4: where we last left her minimal pop project with the LP Paper Television. That Maricich proclaims
column5: ""We invented love"" on ""Make It Up""
column6: the opening track of the project's new eponymous album
column7: isn't entirely hyperbole; the Blow
column8: comprised of Maricich and collaborator Jona Bechtolt of YACHT from 2004 until the latter's exit and visual artist Melissa Dyne's entrance in 2007
column9: have done their best to capture a certain
column10: adorable shade of affection (see: the relative ubiquity of ""Parentheses""). At that moment—only seven years ago
column11: but it feels like a generation in Blow time—the project proved itself a master of a petite
column12: wittily articulate style almost all its own
column13: establishing a four-years-in-the-making identity that
column14: wherever or whenever you heard it
column15: fastened itself to a piece of your life that you may or may not be inclined to revisit just yet.

column1: Now
column2: to meet 2013
column3: the Blow might have traded Olympia's K Records for Brooklyn's Kanine
column4: and Dyne is contributing songwriting and production in addition to her duties as the band's installation artist-in-residence
column5: but they haven't stretched too much farther outside the world Maricich has been carving out for herself since splitting off from the Microphones around the turn of the century. The Blow hopscotches through doubts and fears and mushy lovestuff much like its predecessors
column6: rarely skipping boxes or treading out of bounds. Once again
column7: Maricich's coy lyricism is littered with bite-sized
column8: memorable quips. Her observations about gender (""He wants to talk to you 'cause you're a girl
column9: and he likes girls/ We all like girls/ I flashed my powder-pink handgun and I walked right through"")
column10: oft-insecure self-reflection (""I heard a rumor that I was amazing/ I tell myself everything I hear about myself"")
column11: and the soullessness of dating without purpose (""A kiss was just something to do with my tongue until you kissed me"") are as beguiling as ever
column12: fish-hooking an impatient ear back into a song so structurally simple and almost routine that
column13: upon first listen
column14: it could otherwise glide past as been-there
column15: aughts-era synth twee with ease. Unsurprisingly
column16: two of its shortest
column17: pithiest songs—""I Tell Myself Everything"" and ""Like Girls""—are its shining moment.

column1: Throughout
column2: Dyne's instrumentation grooves close to the chest
column3: beginning with the irresistible percussive bursts and adding a few embellishments
column4: mostly toward the record's end: the synth-and-vocals stereo experimentation on ""The Specter""
column5: the otherworldly echo that orbits ""Not Dead Yet""'s slow crawl. It's smart
column6: carefully assembled commentary with a blithe score—a Blow record
column7: in other words. Faced with a musical landscape that's increasingly ravenous for growth in leaps and bounds
column8: the consistency after so long is refreshing
column9: even if they make no attempt to remove themselves from their (and our) cute past.

column1: At the same time
column2: that steadfastness often reads as reluctance. Maricich seems aware of this. ""I will admit that I fear the future/ or I fear there won't be one at all
column3: she sings on ""From the Future"". ""I can see the future beckoning with its dirty little finger/ When it calls to me
column4: I will follow."" She hasn't—or perhaps it simply hasn't rung her yet. It's hard to tell whether staunchly sticking to the script is part of the performance or not; if it is
column5: it does the album too few favors. It's too late in the game for that.

column1: In a recent blog post
column2: Maricich characterized her tween self as ""fairly brazen and painfully inhibited
column3: something she says ultimately motivated her as a performer later in life; even after all this time
column4: those are often The Blow's qualities
column5: too. Hesitation strings the album along a bit
column6: loosening it so it rambles collectively
column7: despite each song's precise individual character. ""Make It Up"" is a perfect reintroduction to the band's signature bop
column8: and while ending on ""Not Dead Yet"" probably would've left a stronger impression than successor ""You're My Light""
column9: they are a strong dual finale nonetheless. This
column10: it seems
column11: is where 2006 catches up with the Blow: Where these songs once demanded a whole lot of Northwestern indie-boom attention with their coy appraisals (both inward and outward)
column12: in today's context they tend to melt backwards
column13:
into the songs we already know. Dreamy respites are quite difficult to inhabit for long.

There isn't much logic behind Quasi
column3: the Portland-based band that Sam Coomes and Janet Weiss have occasionally returned to over the past 20 years. For instance: They produced a video for the song ""See You on Mars"" to herald the release of this record
column4: a clip which consists of a blizzard of vintage clips all stuck together with scant regard for coherence. Coomes and Weiss don't deal in reason
column5: at least not in this guise. Weiss' work with Sleater-Kinney
column6: Wild Flag
column7: and Stephen Malkmus and the Jicks
column8: plus their joint tenure as back-up band to Elliott Smith
column9: provided a fairly comprehensible path to follow. Quasi are more turbulent in spirit
column10: especially here on Mole City
column11: a wayward
column12: asymmetrical double album that sees them returning to the two-piece format after a period with Jicks bassist Joanna Bolme.

column1: Something that remains from prior Quasi records is Coomes and Weiss' love of producing short
column2: sweet pop songs smeared in lashings of distortion. Coomes sounds like he was born with a fuzz pedal permanently attached to his foot
column3: ready to whitewash the world with it. That mode of operation is the core Quasi sound
column4: the safe haven they build for themselves around all the idiosyncratic turns they take elsewhere. Coomes' familiar organ sound is often to the fore
column5: sometimes leading him into barroom and honky-tonk directions. But they can just as easily dip into droney synth work (""Chrome Duck""
column6: ""Loopy"")
column7: twee 90s indie on Weiss' vocal turn (""R.I.P."")
column8: or
column9: on one of the most affecting songs here
column10: skirt around the kind of twilight blues found on Chris Bell's I Am the Cosmos (""Chumps of Chance"").

column1: Quasi reek of the 70s
column2: primarily through a love of power pop
column3: Big Star
column4: Todd Rundgren
column5: and occasional moments of rock pomposity. The baroque beginnings of ""Headshrinker"" devolve into a burst of soloing of which Queen's Brian May would be proud. There's never an overall sense of direction
column6: or a feel Coomes and Weiss are looking to stretch across this record as its primary arc. Instead
column7: Mole City resembles a jumble of all the thoughts and inclinations they've had since their last album
column8: 2010's American Gong. It's a mess
column9: but Quasi find virtue in clutter
column10: turning it into their primary motive for existence as a band. Still
column11: it's hard to digest over the course of 24 tracks
column12: including a limp ""Tomorrow Never Knows"" pastiche (""Gnot"")
column13: a moment where Coomes seems to be channeling his inner Wayne Coyne (""Geraldine"")
column14: and even a half-hearted found-sound collage on the title track.

column1: The best song here is buried toward the end
column2: at a point where the less patient listener may have given up altogether. ""An Ice Cube in the Sun"" radiates warmth and anger
column3: with Coomes addressing ""the misfits of the world
column4: Weiss pounding away at her kit
column5: and a point where the whole song arches into a delirious stretch of low-key pop. It's followed by a one-minute ramble into country titled ""One & Done""—easily one of the most throwaway moments here—which serves to highlight just how frustrating Quasi can be at times. But it's hard to fault them when that's the whole point
column6:
when making music becomes akin to opening up a drawer full of old clothes and trying them on just because you can. The fact that there's a track here titled ""Clap Trap"" is both indicative of their humor and uncomfortably close to being a useful descriptor for their work.

If Staring at the X distanced Forest Fire from the New York band’s beloved 2008 debut
column2: the strummy Survival
column3: then Screens lengthens the span so far that there’s no tidy way to bridge the gap. Singer Mark Thresher has said in interviews he feels entirely disconnected from the early Forest Fire material
column4: and it shows. Screens boasts a new lineup
column5: a new sound
column6: and a new vision that exchanges homespun indie-folk for cascading synthesizers and prominent
column7: jaunty bass lines. Gone is Thresher’s Walkmen-like caterwauling; on Screens he whispers his electro-fuzz vocals in a way that’s more Mark Linkous than the Mark Thresher of old.

column1: While Screens retains the lofty ambitions of Staring at the X (“Annie” is an 11-minute krautrock experiment)
column2: the omnipresent analog synth
column3: delay effects
column4: and other sonic consistencies unite the record’s tone and mood more than the chaotic sophomore release. Screens feels focused
column5: confident. And thankfully Forest Fire’s evolution hasn’t undercut Thresher’s ability to write a taut pop song. In fact
column6: before Thresher appears in “Alone with the Wires” and “Yellow Roses”
column7: Stuart Murdoch could show up and start crooning about Dylan in the movies and it wouldn’t seem out of place. The melodies are pretty
column8: lilting
column9: and uncomplicated.

column1: This new iteration of Forest Fire is heavy on electronics
column2: but it’s rarely robotic. The repeating bass line on “Annie” could be a loop
column3: though I’d wager Galen Bremer is playing it live. A few minutes in
column4: the buoyant riff becomes an addictive
column5: hypnotic drone as Thresher casually cuts in with observations about the song’s namesake that range from the wry (“They know your name in the restaurants of New York”) to cryptic (“There’s something written on your forehead”). After 11 minutes you still don’t get a complete picture of Annie
column6: but Thresher seems more concerned with wrapping her mystery in metaphor. If all you walk away with is a vague but real sense of this woman’s magnetism
column7: that’s perfectly fine.

column1: According to the band
column2: the screens of Screens refer to the real (the screen currently in front of your face) and metaphorical (between artist and audience). Forest Fire subtly illustrates this by constructing musical barriers; Thresher’s vocals are often positioned deeper in the mix
column3: obfuscating his volume and clarity with translucent fuzz and decay. When he sings
column4: “They listen but not very closely
column5: and mostly they don’t
column6: ” on “Passengers
column7: ” it comes off like an invitation (or a dare?) to turn up the volume and lean in close. Once you take him up on the invite
column8: Thresher’s couplets have staying power—no matter how recessed or processed or mysterious they appear. On “Alone with the Wires
column9: ” he asks
column10: “How long between haircuts
column11: and who’s gonna pay for lunch?” There’s no reason anyone should have an answer for such a mundane
column12: rhetorical query
column13: but good luck keeping that snippet out of the brain folds.

column1: If “Annie” is the most avante-garde
column2: “Waiting in the Night” is the most intimate and Luna-like of the bunch; oscillating synthesizer and gently jangling guitars create a muzzy
column3: pre-dawn mood. It’s the pinnacle of Thresher’s songwriting to date. Still
column4: just like Staring at the X
column5: a couple tracks on the second half of Screens go too far off-message and lose their way. The wordless “Fixation” feels more listless than experimental
column6: and when multi-instrumentalist Natalie Stormann shares lead vocals on “The Great Wall”
column7: it’s jarring enough to disrupt the album’s continuity (though her background vocals are crucial to the dreamy vibe elsewhere). But for the most part Forest Fire employs their new vision to dizzying effect. Hitting the reset button isn’t always a graceful process for a band
column8: but on Screens the reinvention sounds natural
column9:
like this is the band Forest Fire was supposed to be all along.

Danny Brown's XXX was a concept album about desperation; ""If this shit don't work
column2: nigga

column4: with a fervent fan base both inside and out of rap. Now he's got to sort out how to best continue living. It might not be as dramatic a subject as flaming out

column1: In preparing critics and fans

column3: there isn't too many of them

column10: of course

column12: measured
column13: mature album still features plenty of lines about snorting crushed pills

column1: The album is divided into a ""Side A"" and a ""Side B

column3: he famously told a bewildered A$AP Rocky that one of his heroes was Arthur Lee before lecturing him on the merits of Forever Changes. The structure here suggests two LP sides
column4: neatly divided
column5: but one of the best things about Old is how mixed up it is—Brown's past
column6: his present
column7: his deranged side
column8: his reflective side
column9: his party songs and his nightmares. ""Problems in my past haunt my future and the present
column10: he moans on ""Clean Up"". The album is 19 songs
column11: ranging across so much emotional terrain that it almost needs to be tackled in stretches.

column1: Side A contains the heaviest
column2: most harrowing material
column3: but the demons he exorcises there don't stay put. Bad memories pop up everywhere on Old

What separates him from his Gen-X forebears is that none of what he does feels typically cool at all—he has a way of masking honest songwriting in crooked wordplay and a joke about the munchies. At his most honed

column3: Lorde is a black hole. That's the message you get from the defiantly low-concept video for her single ""Tennis Court""

column6: and

column9: Lorde is an exciting contradiction: an aspiring pop star who's had a major-label development deal since age 12 (she was discovered at a local talent show) but has retained a seemingly genuine iconoclastic streak. The other day she spoke too truthfully in an interview and accidentally insulted Taylor Swift; Katy Perry asked her to tour with her and—politely but firmly—she said no. With the global smash ""Royals"" (the first song in 17 years by a female solo artist to top Billboard’s alternative chart) she made her name by sneering at everything else on the radio (""We don't care/ We aren't caught up in your love affair""). The message is clear: Lorde has introduced herself to the world as someone who gives very few fucks. Twenty seconds into her debut album
column10: Pure Heroine
column11: she's already announced that she's bored. Twice.

column1: Lorde's voice occasionally takes the form of a wide-eyed
column2: Feist-y coo
column3: but much more often it's a low
column4: clenched growl; like everything else about her
column5: it has an air of ""wise beyond her years."" ""I didn't start writing songs until I was 13
column6: she said in a recent interview
column7: almost apologetically
column8: but then quickly accounted for the lost time
column9: ""Before that
column10: I wrote short fiction."" Now that she's a wizened 16
column11: Lorde
column12: who wrote all the lyrics on Pure Heroine and co-wrote the music

column14: empty bottles
column15: queen bees
column16: and young people who already feel old. ""I'm kinda older than I was when I rebelled without a care

column1: That carefully cultivated ambiguity is precisely what makes Pure Heroine work. ""Royals"" walks the line between rebelling against and reveling in the trappings of power
column2: luxury
column3: and excess of contemporary pop. The arrangement is economical—just a few finger snaps and a barely-there beat caught in the gravitational pull of Lorde's charisma—but overall
column4: ""Royals"" gets to have it both ways. Lorde says she wrote it thinking of how she and her friends would listen to A$AP Rocky rapping about couture while they rummaged through a particular friends' well-stocked kitchen
column5: too broke (or too lazy) to spend money on dinner. And that’s a crucial subtlety: ""Royals"" doesn't critique hip-hop culture so much as express a disconnect that many of the people who love it (Lorde included: ""I've always listened to a lot of rap"") feel when listening to songs about luxury culture. Whether she's singing about her schoolyard peers or the world's most famous pop stars (who
column6: as she admits on ""Tennis Court""

column7: head-clearing way.

column1: There are many transcendent moments of bliss on Cupid's Head—""They Won't See Me""'s high-tension tonal axis
column2: the squishy radiance of ""A Guided Tour""—but ""No. No…"" is the album's greatest moment of awe
column3: with an endlessly looped voices evocative of the Flamingos-warping abstraction of From Here We Go Sublime's title track. Each iteration of the title phrase gradually stretches it further into the void. Over a bed of stormy
column4: amorphous rhythms and off-white static
column5: the sampled voice changes shape—from high-pitched to low
column6: staccato to elongated
column7: specific to indefinable—until there's nothing left but a broken helicopter-blade beat and an unadorned vocal sample that vibrates with a menacing inflection. It's a wellspring of tension on an album that brims with paranoia.

column1: The Field's discography is paradoxical. On the one hand
column2: Cupid's Head demonstrates how much Willner's aesthetic has changed over the last six years. That those changes have been incremental
column3: and that there are clear threads going back to his debut
column4: highlight the singularity of what he does. The landscapes of dance and electronic music have shifted since the release of From Here We Go Sublime—minimal techno
column5: as well as Willner's label home Kompakt
column6: have become niché concerns—so the fact that he's still an innovator in an always-crowded field is a considerable feat. A few artists have taken bits and pieces of his style and applied them in their own way
column7: but no one has been able to sound like Willner
column8: who in turn continues to sound like no one except himself. Cupid's Head is a dark
column9:
exquisitely detailed album that rewards patience and further cements the Field's reputation as one of modern electronic music's most satisfying auteurs.

As quintessential big-word abstract rappers went
column2: Del Tha Funky Homosapien stood out in his first decade of work for all the right reasons. His unapologetic enthusiasm for geek culture ephemera and that drawling
column3: swooping nyeah-nyeah voice added a novel goofball edge to his frenzied agenda of intricate technical raps
column4: hitting his outsized peak as the frontman of the Dan the Automator/Kid Koala supergroup that comprised Deltron 3030. As the title character
column5: Del took the super-scientifical-lyrical-miracle orthodoxy of underground hip-hop lyricism and pushed it to a caricature of its logical conclusion: a proggy sci-fi cyberpunk opus as dense and imposing as a skyline from Katsuhiro Otomo's Akira
column6: if a fair amount goofier. Too silly to be pompous yet too grounded in reality to be escapist
column7: Deltron warped fanboy obsessions into cutting sociopolitical satire and erased the line between funny-ha-ha and funny-weird in the process.

column1: That was 13 years ago-- before hundreds of Nintendo-casualty rappers started recording nerdcore albums
column2: before geek culture became the overculture
column3: and before a sequel to Deltron 3030 was announced and delayed and pushed back and postponed to an extent that rivaled Detox. It's not one of those specific things that makes Event II feel a lot less worth celebrating
column4: though it's likely that expectations have been twisted a bit by them. But like every other beloved property of the Comicon set that's been rebooted to be darker
column5: grittier
column6: and less kitschy in a self-inflated attempt at passing itself off as ""mature
column7: Event II drains the Deltron concept of its anarchic post-apocalypse giddiness and goes all gloomy on us.

column1: And that's a problem for a couple reasons. One of them is that the jargon-crammed narratives that drove Del's lyrics worked when there was a lighthearted spirit to them - not an ironic or half-assed one
column2: but a context where William Gibson lingo and space-hacker Afrofuturism flowed as accessibly as his bars about weed and women did. That sense of playfulness keeps slipping out of Del's grasp for much of Event II
column3: ratcheting up the corporate-ruined wasteland of Deltron 3030's setting and abandoning his pranksterish rebel character voice for a grimmer messiah-ish figure. A Joseph Gordon-Levitt-narrated jump to the year 3040 on opening skit ""Stardate"" sets up ""The Return""
column4: a lengthy rundown of everything that went to shit in the decade since 3030 saw Deltron Zero and Automator vanish. It's here that the first big tonal clashes start jumping out out
column5: endless portrayals of dystopian desperation vaguely leavened with faint stabs at the punchlines of years gone by. After Deltron and his crew beat up a bunch of drugged-up wasteland punks who were threatening a woman
column6: Del reassures her that the assailants have been tossed in a trash compactor and ""literally minced into little bits between/pieces of leftover Chef Boyardee/ mixed with a couple-a booty magazines."" Labored jokes are bad enough; it's even worse when they're the only punchline on an entire track.

column1: From there on out it's a disjointed thread of events that reveals the other big problem with this new approach to the Deltron story: it dives in with overcomplicated yet shopworn worldbuilding at the expense of relatable detail. Sure
column2: there's references to the financial crisis and wealth gaps and the surveillance state
column3: but it gets buried under technobabble and b-movie rhetoric that's incomprehensible when it's not cliche. (Would you believe that
column4: in this blighted hellscape
column5: the totalitarian government has gone so far as to ban music?) Deltron's distinct character gets buried along with it
column6: too
column7: as his ascendance from prodigal son with a scrappy band of followers to a resurgent ultrahero commanding massive guerilla armies to straight-up 41st century afterlife power is papered over with minutia. We get a lot of observations of what's going on-- confrontations with duplicitous money men (""Pay the Price"")
column8: tactical planning (""Nobody Can"")
column9: waging psychic warfare (""Melding of the Minds"")-- but no real sense of how he got there
column10: what'll happen next
column11: or anything else that gives a tangible sense of progressive storytelling. The skits just make it worse
column12: since they hardly fit on such an otherwise straightfaced record-- why include a clip of David Chang shruggingly predicting that ""The Future of Food"" is a Jetsons machine
column13: or give David Cross and Amber Tamblyn two goes at pretending to be cranky old people on an album where the Lonely Island also rap about being cranky old people? For a narrative concept record
column14: this is only marginally less coherent when it's put on shuffle.

column1: So if it's not all that fun
column2: and it's too convoluted to follow
column3: why is this album still worth salvaging? Well
column4: despite the overcooked jumble of your typical oft-delayed all-star concept record
column5: it really does fall together as pure music. Just stop paying too much attention to Del's lyrics-- or at least pay enough attention to them that there's a brief jolt of vague futuristic intrigue when you hear the word ""lasers"" or ""Matrix""-- and that voice of his bobs and weaves with fluid timing that washes right over you like a sudden chill. It sounds weird put through a grandiose Joseph Campbell Hero's Journey
column6: but it also sounds invigorated pitted alongside a production slate that brings out the percussive punch in every last syllable. Dan the Automator skews rock without flat-out going rock
column7: integrating fuzz guitar (""Nobody Can"") or Sergio Leone twang (""Talent Supersedes"") as needed but sticking well to his wheelhouse of frantic strings
column8: martial horns
column9: and half-goth pop-soul that Kid Koala augments with characteristically off-kilter scratch work. It's also one of those weird rare alt-rap releases where nearly every hook is amazing
column10: the luxury of getting Damon Albarn at his anguished best on ""What Is This Loneliness"" or Mike Patton doing his shapeshifting-wraith thing deep in the mix of ""City Rising From the Ashes"". There've been more disappointing sequels
column11: sure
column12:
and for something this long in development it turned out decent enough. But who goes to a Del album for a downer?

The Foreign Exchange introduced their latest album
column2: Love in Flying Colors
column3: with a pair of trailer videos called “Her” and “Him
column4: ” which showed the title characters listening to each Foreign Exchange album in succession at different stages in their lives. Accompanied by the slogan “life is all about keeping a beat” the message that this is music to grow with may have been a little too on-the-nose
column5: but this process of changing and maturing has been the underlying theme for the duo’s music since 2008’s Leave It All Behind. Coming out after the dissolution of singer Phonte’s rap group Little Brother
column6: that album’s embrace of R&B felt like as much of a fulfillment of the title as its narratives of relationships in turmoil did. Phonte has generally positioned his move away from rap and into R&B—and
column7: more specifically
column8: R&B that explores the mundane intricacies of everyday relationships—as a maturation befitting someone his age (he’s now 34). Promoting Authenticity in 2010
column9: he suggested that there was a void to fill for R&B “about getting married
column10: having kids
column11: slowing down.”

column1: Love In Flying Colors is shooting for that goal: Broadly
column2: it’s a happy
column3: settled album that seems to be about coming to terms with a new
column4: stable relationship in the wake of a more tumultuous one. To achieve that tone
column5: it’s more musically ambitious than anything the Foreign Exchange have attempted before
column6: incorporating live instrumentation throughout and dabbling in a comfy palette of funk
column7: soul
column8: disco
column9: soft rock
column10: and touches of house. It’s crisp
column11: familiar and accessible
column12: but taking this approach also holds the group to a higher standard and plays against its strengths. Previous Foreign Exchange projects could lean a little bit on novelty: 2004’s Connected proved that engaging
column13: soulful hip-hop could be created by a Dutch producer and a North Carolina rapper collaborating over the internet; Leave It All Behind showed that Phonte had a better singing voice than anyone expected; Authenticity was a moody
column14: drifting work full of minimal
column15: electronic production that presaged the wave of bedroom R&B acts that would start sweeping blogs a year or two later. In contrast
column16: Love In Flying Colors isn’t just holding itself up against historical precedent
column17: it’s had the unfortunate luck of falling in the middle of a disco revival zeitgeist without the on-hand studio resources of
column18: say
column19: Daft Punk or Pharrell.

column1: Phonte and Nicolay are great at building an atmosphere in which lyrical phrases are allowed to slowly unwind and Phonte’s voice is used to fill out tracks rather than punctuate them. The clean funk of Love In Flying Colors demands sharper songwriting and stronger vocals
column2: though. If Phonte’s voice was a pleasant surprise when the group was creating understated neo-soul
column3: it’s a bit of a liability when they’re gunning for full-on Kool & the Gang thrills—a fact the duo seems to implicitly recognize by bringing in plenty of guest talent to handle some of the more ambitious melodies (one of the most fun things about the entire Foreign Exchange project is the way it’s grown from an email exchange into a fully fleshed-out musical community). Songs like “Better” and “On A Day Like Today” are missing the punch that would make them the fully realized celebrations they’re trying to be. In general
column4: the album’s meandering middle section blends together
column5: sitting in the same grooves for too long and offering little in the way of the memorable outbursts that this type of funk demands.

column1: There may be a reason
column2: too
column3: why mature subjects like settling down
column4: working through fights and getting married don’t yield much in the way of popular R&B: a meaty phrase like “tell me you’ll stay by my side for all time/ Not just a moment” doesn’t exactly go down smoothly as the climax of a song like “The Moment”
column5: which otherwise is a limber
column6: pitch-perfect dancefloor exercise that shows the direct lineage between disco and early house. And that’s far from the cheesiest lyric on the album
column7: which is heavy on oversimplifications like “sometimes it all feels so enormous/ I wonder why we even try.” Where the album does reign things in lyrically and the mood breaks away from muted satisfaction or confusion into actual excited joy
column8: it’s clear what Love In Flying Colors could be. Opener “If I Knew Then” is triumphant in its breezy declaration that “love’s flying high
column9: ” and “Dreams Are Made For Two”
column10: a duet with frequent Phonte collaborator Carlitta Durand
column11: is inviting with its climbing synths and pillowy bass line
column12: even if its couples getaway fantasy verges on wild over-sentimentality. Is there a reason that the songs tend to work better the more unreservedly happy they are? Getting to that self-assured
column13: carefree place in which this type of music works best isn’t easy
column14: and
column15: unlike in the past
column16: the Foreign Exchange aren’t letting themselves hide confusion behind studio tricks. This is all-out openness and clarity
column17: which
column18: for better or for worse
column19:
is just a little more grown-up.

They may already be tired of hearing it
column2: but-- like any casually triumphant
column3: fidelity challenged Buckeye State rockers-- comparisons between Columbus' Connections and Ohio lo-fi legends Guided by Voices seem all but inevitable. Both bands have a fondness for flooding the marketplace with new material: by the time we're through with 2013
column4: Connections will add a third LP to their catalog. Hell
column5: frontman Kevin Elliott even finds himself singing with the slightest whiff of a British accent
column6: a trademark Pollardism that
column7: as Pitchfork's Aaron Leitko wrote of this spring's Private Airplane
column8: suggests more than a little time spent kneeling at the altar of Bee Thousand. But
column9: while GBV's best songs spoke of rock'n'roll as a galvanizing force
column10: a source of salvation-- ""I shoot myself with rock'n'roll
column11: Bob Pollard sang on ""I Am a Scientist""
column12: but ""nothing else can set me free""-- Connections seem to see it as a way to hold themselves together in the face of everyday chaos.

column1: On Body Language
column2: Connections' second LP on the year
column3: Elliott explores what it's like to be down-and-out on the cusp of drinking age. The people in Connections' songs are old enough to know better but young enough not to care all that much; their romantic ideas about love and life have started to crumble
column4: but they're still not quite sure how to fill that gap. So they crash on couches
column5: punch timeclocks
column6: and hate the friends they keep falling for. ""I know you're aimless
column7: he sings on the set's first song; later
column8: it's ""I take it fuckin' easy."" The consequences of all that taking it easy
column9: all those ""dreams that turn to embarrassment
column10: have only just started to set in. But to these slackers
column11: inertia's a killer; it's easier to promise yourself you'll wake up and do better than to actually get up and do it. Body Language doesn't wallow in these feelings
column12: but it certainly speaks to them
column13: and if you've ever woken up hungover with your neck draped across some half-stranger's sectional sofa
column14: you're liable to see yourself somewhere in these songs.

column1: Musically
column2: Body Language offers considerably more uplift. Like GBV
column3: they're as scrappy as they are stirring; they stumble into bridges and gallop through choruses
column4: throwing an extra chord in wherever it'll fit without bogging down the songs' forward motion
column5: barely letting one song end before they careen into the next. Lead guitarist Dave Capaldi's screaming J. Mascis-style leads take a frontseat here
column6: to the benefit of everybody; not only does he have Mascis' tone down cold
column7: but he's got that same combination of reserve and abandon
column8: that ability to inject genuine emotion into a cluster of notes. Highlights are everywhere: the casually exuberant ""Summer Creeps"" nicks the chords from Semisonic's ""Closing Time"" and a couple lines from Tom Petty's ""Last Dance With Mary Jane"" to pay tribute to another wasted season
column9: but not before he spits out the punky ""Girl's Night Out"" like a stomach full of cheap vodka quickly curdling in his stomach. Every melody's sharp
column10: some even border on regal. But Connections tear through each one of them with slacker's nonchalance
column11: as if banging out a song as good and pure as ""Blurry Eyes"" is just no big deal.

column1: ""They didn't plan much—just an escape route
column2: and a sweet follow through
column3: Elliott sings on ""Jeni and Johnny""
column4: the story of two go-nowhere kids who decide they might just be born to run after all. If Connections have a mission statement
column5: it's probably that: they don't
column6: at first
column7: seem like the get-up-and-go types
column8: but when push comes to shove
column9: they've got all the drive and determination they need. For a certain strain of indie rocker
column10: Body Language is pure catnip. But it's more than that: a smart
column11: stupendously catchy
column12: often downright inspiring examination of the things that get us going in spite of ourselves
column13:
set to one head-stick melody after the other.

Making music from your home is easier and cheaper than heading out to a studio but this approach offers its own challenges. Mayuko Hitotsuyanagi
column2: who records as Cuushe
column3: knows them well: “The walls are really thin in Japan
column4: and if you sing loudly you’re going to annoy your neighbors. Plus I do a lot of recording at night.” She may try to keep her music muffled in her apartment
column5: but she managed to catch the ear of Tokyo’s Flau records
column6: the nation’s premier label for hushed music. Flau deals in sparseness
column7: from the kitchen-sink electronics of Kyoto’s Madegg to the nature-loving synth-pop of Cokiyu
column8: who has teamed up with Baths. The imprint was a good place for Cuushe to hone her restrained style
column9: and it nabbed American performers Julia Holter and Motion Sickness of Time Travel to remix her work last year. The results are on display in her second full-length album
column10: Butterfly Case
column11: which exploits her space-induced limitations to create a captivating collection of dream pop.

column1: Like the artists who reworked her songs
column2: Cuushe lets her music develop gradually and seems in no particular rush. Many of the songs on Butterfly Case run for more than five minutes
column3: starting in a wispy synth haze before eventually blooming into more complex structures. First track “Sort of Light” takes cues from dance music
column4: opening with muted pulses before a minimal beat pushes the song forward. Cuushe adds sonic details one at a time
column5: building the track into a formidable whirl of sound that could even prompt nervous shuffling on a dancefloor. On “Twilight”
column6: Cuushe launches with lush synths
column7: but eventually pivots the track into a gallop that ups the urgency and snaps it out of its daydream

column1: Butterfly Case makes the most of this slowly swirling template
column2: to the point where songs start sounding mechanical in the album’s second half. Late-album track “Swing Your Heart” sounds unremarkable after six previous numbers did the slow-build routine much better. More tedious are the instances where Cuushe just drifts
column3: largely eschewing beats in favor of just letting the music float. While it sounds dreamy
column4: it also rings aimless and feels like filler.

column1: Cuushe
column2: though
column3: can thank her cramped recording quarters for helping to emphasize her best sonic quality and the reason she isn’t a generic dream pop peddler. Her vocals are soft
column4: never overpowering the music on Butterfly Case; it's often hard to discern any words
column5: so her voice acts as additional sonic texture
column6: lending the production some extra depth. They can also add emotional impact—her drawn out syllables give “Twilight” a sense of longing
column7: while on closer “Hanabi”
column8: they sound hopeful.

column1: She’s at her best
column2: though
column3: when her singing manages to break through the dreaminess and deliver a simple and direct emotion. “I Miss You” boasts one of Butterfly Case’s best buildups
column4: seemingly peaking with a sing-song melody before whirring synths fade out and Cuushe sighs
column5: “I want to be with you.” Album highlight “I Love You” layers Cuushe’s voice over itself multiple times for the first half of the song
column6: but then she suddenly emerges clear from the haze as she bluntly delivers the titular phrase over and over again. It’s moments like these
column7: where she imbues her songs with a breath-on-neck intimacy
column8: when her second album stands out
column9:
and you almost can picture Cuushe quietly creating in her thin-walled apartment.
