It didn't have to be this way. Justin Timberlake could have capped his comeback year with a final single from 2013's top-selling album
column2: The 20/20 Experience—perhaps the breezy ""That Girl""—before heading out on an upcoming victory-lap arena tour. He could have left us with images of a dignified pop star
column3: as seen in David Fincher's flawless ""Suit & Tie"" video
column4: or the beguiling second half of the visual for ""Mirrors""
column5: where he offers graceful steps inside of a mysterious
column6: reflecting maze. He could have simply coveted the unlikely staying power of ""Mirrors""
column7: a smash that manages to deliver broad messages of fidelity
column8: selflessness
column9: and co-dependence while being intimate
column10: addictive
column11: and touching (and eight minutes long). He could have basked in his marathon hit parade at the VMA's; while it wasn't the show's most talked-about performance
column12: it solidified the 32-year-old's position in the pop firmament—somewhere high above the blog-churning din
column13: peering down on the foam hands
column14: Beetlejuice suits
column15: and oversized stuffed animals with a wry chuckle. He could have left us wanting more. He didn't.

column1: The 20/20 Experience 2 of 2 is not only superfluous
column2: it actually erases some of the gains made by its predecessor as it plays into the worst trappings of self-indulgence. Taken from the same 2012 sessions that birthed <i>The 20/20 Experience
column3: this album shows off similar musical tactics—multi-part songs that routinely push the seven-minute mark
column4: dense arrangements
column5: Timbaland-helmed syncopation—but instead of acting like a complement
column6: it sounds like the unripe fruits of a warm-up. Whereas 1 of 2 found a retro-futuristic freshness by mixing detailed percussion with string-laden
column7: old-Hollywood glamor
column8: 2 of 2 rehashes many of the same sonic tics of Timberlake and Timbaland's seven-year-old FutureSex/LoveSounds
column9: and
column10: in turn
column11: points to a much more stunted spectrum of creativity.

column1: Speaking of stunted: Timberlake recently joked that this new record is ""more slutty"" than its ""virginal"" partner
column2: and its subject matter can certainly be offensive—not because of its sexual nature but rather how disturbingly unsexy the singer makes it all sound. Despite ""SexyBack""—which
column3: with its motorik pulse and metallic vocal effects
column4: was more cybersex-y
column5: anyway—Timberlake's lock-step perfectionism always lent itself more to idealized romance than unadulterated attraction. And too often here
column6: his come-ons are corny enough to elicit facepalms from sixth graders. ""Girl
column7: if sex is a contest
column8: then you're coming first
column9: he suggests on ""Cabaret""
column10: seemingly accompanied by a dumb
column11: punny smirk. His supporting cast doesn't help. Timbaland shows up only to play the role of embarrassing uncle on ""TKO""
column12: starting the track off with unfortunately appropriate (and gross) baby talk: ""She kill me with the coo-coochie-coochie-coo."" Jay-Z can't help but get in on the act on ""Murder""
column13: where he hypothesizes on the efficacy of Yoko Ono's vagina: ""Know that shit gotta be lethal/ If that pussy broke up the Beatles/ Chocha ruined pop culture."" Yes
column14: he really says ""chocha."" And no
column15: it doesn't sound better when you hear him rapping it.

column1: Part of the problem with such idiotic horniness is a matter of tone; if any of the above lines and/or songs were refashioned as ""Saturday Night Live"" skits
column2: they would likely prove more effective (and markedly less disconcerting). In particular
column3: the only way to make the years-late nearly-10-minute sexy-vampire track ""True Blood"" at all palatable would be to pair it with a knowingly campy video
column4: a la ""Thriller"". Obviously
column5: Timberlake can be very funny on purpose—he's arguably the best ""SNL"" host of the last decade. But
column6: maybe due to his boy-band past or the fact that he's dabbling in traditionally black styles of music
column7: he's self-consciously made the separation between his joke tracks and his serious songs very clear. This straight face served him well on The 20/20 Experience's odes to devotion
column8: but it makes him look silly here.

column1: Elsewhere
column2: when he's not chasing after women with his tongue unraveling to his feet
column3: Looney Tunes-style
column4: he's pissed off. And if there's an emotion that suits Timberlake less than rampant lustfulness
column5: it's anger. This is the guy who'll gush that he has ""the best wife in the world"" on ""Ellen""
column6: who does everything in his power to be liked at all times. Which is not to say his ire is invalid. But
column7: as depicted on 2 of 2
column8: it is clunky. His heartbrokenness falls flat on the twangy Kid Rock-type plastic blues of ""Drink You Away""
column9: and ""Only When I Walk Away"" tries (and fails) to go for the same spurned emotions as ""What Goes Around… Comes Around""
column10: before Timberlake ends it with the couplet
column11: ""She only love me when I walk away/ I said
column12: 'Fuck you bitch
column13: we no care what you say.'"" This is followed by a little laugh that seems to say ""just kidding!"" but the tough-guy pose still leaves a rancid taste.

column1: When Timberlake went into the studio with Timbaland last year
column2: they didn't necessarily plan to make an album. His manager figured a single or an EP might arise from the 20 days of recording. But here we are with two albums—144 minutes of music in total. It's about 70 minutes too much
column3: an unwarranted glut. Based on the performance of this album's singles thus far—the good-enough ""Take Back the Night"" peaked at No. 29 while the laborious ""TKO"" just entered the charts at No. 54—public demand is significantly waning as well. With <i>The 20/20 Experience
column4: Timberlake asked his audience to accept a twisty album of love songs that was out-of-step with today's bass-first pop-radio fodder. No matter the amount of soul-sucking promotional tie-ins involved—and there were many—it was a risky gambit
column5: and it paid off on virtually every level. With 2 of 2
column6: he's a happily married man asking us to take in an album of awful pick up lines and phony angst
column7:
all over an endless bed of reheated production. It's a bridge too far.

Machinedrum existed long before Room(s): dig back a bit and you'll find a lot of dizzying glitch-hop and IDM moves on releases like 2001's Now You Know and 2002's Urban Biology that still reverberate through his more contemporary work. That Travis Stewart has since moved from Four Tet-shadowed downtempo abstraction to triple-digit BPMs and retro junglist breaks doesn't change things too much
column4: either. Always handy with muted
column5: distorted droning chords and shredded flakes of melody
column6: Machinedrum's breakthrough as an in-demand name in bass music is a logical destination in the long run; all that there was left to wait for was a context.

column1: That context is getting pretty familiar-- distant
column2: lonely vocal refrains from the Burial playbook glazed over a rhythm that could be shorthanded as juke'n'bass. If Room(s) set the stage
column3: and his work with Praveen Sharma as Sepalcure expanded the palette
column4: Vapor City finds Machinedrum getting comfortable inside the parameters that juiced his reptuation. But he's made that formula effective enough that the visceral
column5: emotional lift hasn't faded any. The early signs were there with key single “Gunshotta”: snare-kick fusillades shivering like they have hypothermia
column6: flourescent synthesizer chords reflecting off wet pavement
column7: tunnel-echo fragments of deep soul singing that are so distressed they harmonize cleanly with ruffneck ragga vocals. It's practically archetypal at this point. It's also straight-up gorgeous.

column1: Vapor City is front-loaded with those kinds of moments. Part of the thrill of listening to “Infinite Us” is hearing those yearning piano notes that open it and wondering how they'll be put through the wringer; the slow build to a huge
column2: gleaming ascension on the back of a harplike guitar arpeggio only heightens the pull between the delicate melodies and the full-steam-ahead percussion. For a while
column3: it feels like there are endless ways for him to shadowbox the rhythm. “Don't 1 2 Lose U” puts every note of its percussive synthesizer riff through a slight flange effect that
column4: coupled with the wavering vocal sample that gives it its title
column5: makes it sound like the downpour 808s are rattling a film soundtrack off the spools. And opening “Center Your Love” with a gradual un-muffling of its airy dream-pop vocal-driven riff is a slow focus into euphoria; its deep
column6: spare set of piano/guitar chords are a vivid setup for the best Boards of Canada loop Boards of Canada never made.

column1: The novelty doesn't come across as strongly on the album's latter half-- after an early peak
column2: Vapor City plays all its hands and settles into a more stripped-down stretch to the end. While it's more likely to feel like acclimation than pointless wheel-spinning stasis
column3: it also has the air of the almost-complete to it
column4: like these sparser tracks are waiting for a vocalist to complete it a'la “SXLND” becoming the backbone for Azealia Banks' “NEEDSUMLUV”. Put the demarcation line at “Vizion”
column5: a submerged descent into crumbling ambient
column6: and everything afterwards is merely deep-cut solid. There are bigger disappointments than this
column7: granted-- the worst you can say about the second half of Vapor City is that it's something of a weird choice to sequence two consecutive tracks with “lie” so prominent in the vocal hook (the downtempo Italians Do It Better-adjacent synthpop of “U Still Lie” and the hyperventilating footwork of “Eyesdontlie”). It could just be a matter of volume
column8: really. When you crank this album loud
column9: it's not just the beats that rattle the system
column10:
though they're as crisply forceful as ever. It's the intricate musical subtleties Stewart weaves through them that blow your hair back.

There isn’t a lot of precedent for what Yuck’s doing on their sophomore LP Glow & Behold.While it’s not unusual for groups in more moneyed genres to survive the departure of their lead singer
column2: they tend to bring on a hired gun—Brian Johnson
column3: Sammy Hagar
column4: Peter Cetera
column5: whoever’s singing in Journey right now. But typically in indie rock
column6: when the frontperson’s done
column7: the band is too. So here’s Yuck
column8: not only carrying on without Daniel Blumberg
column9: but also making the rare internal promotion in guitarist Max Bloom
column10: who sang on one track last time out (“Operation”). And yet
column11: Yuck seems like a good candidate to pull this off
column12: because their inexhaustibly replayable self-titled debut from 2011 was nothing but precedent—they were the best Yo La Tengo
column13: Superchunk
column14: Built to Spill and Dinosaur Jr. songs you may have heard in years
column15: but done with enough spirit
column16: melody and grace to serve as tough competition for the originals. This isn’t to denigrate the contribution of Blumberg
column17: after all
column18: he co-wrote and sang the vast majority of Yuck. But as long as they didn’t ditch their CD collection
column19: they’re still Yuck
column20: right? Well
column22: Yuck do indeed get further and deeper into their personal canon. The problem that while Yuck was an excellent facsimile of excellent bands
column23: Glow & Behold is a pretty good facsimile of pretty good bands

column1: Or
column2: to put it another way
column3: they’ve exhausted the A-list of 90s indie rock and are now modeling themselves after the next tier: we’re talking Lush
column4: Buffalo Tom
column5: the Lemonheads
column6: maybe Teenage Fanclub if we’re being generous. As a result
column7: Glow & Behold just sounds like Yuck on muscle relaxants much of the time —“Lose My Breath” and “Middle Sea” boast the same kind of fuzzed-up leads that made the guitars of  “Georgia” or “Get Away” as easy to sing along with as the vocals
column8: but little of their frazzled energy. Meanwhile
column9: “Memorial Fields” avoids getting too close to Yuck’s hangdog ballad “Suck” simply by insulating itself with synthesized strings.

column1: This shift was inevitable from a physiological standpoint
column2: as Yuck traded Blumberg’s nasal sneer for the more soft-palate lilt of Bloom. The ostensible maturation of their sound was also abetted by the production of Chris Coady
column3: who helped guide Smith Westerns from a raw and tuneful debut into a more lush
column4: distinctly British aesthetic (though on their first album
column5: Yuck was a British band that sounded extremely American). For all intents and purposes
column6: this sounds like their major-label debut: whereas a trumpet solo bisected “Suicide Policeman”
column7: there are horns on Glow & Behold and keyboards often take the place of pedal-altered guitars for a means to add ambience. As a result
column8: there are a few keepers that indulge in sounds that weren’t available to Yuck on their self-produced debut; “Rebirth” is palpably lush shoegaze
column9: while the honeyed college rock of “Lose My Breath” a convincing candidate for primetime 1995 MTV play rather than ""120 Minutes."" But for the most part
column10: Coady and Bloom combine to smooth out songs that lacked edge to begin with and Glow & Behold sounds far more homogenous than its predecessor even if boasts a near equal array of acoustic strummers
column11: wandering instrumentals and indie rock classicism.

column1: The bigger issue is that in losing Blumberg
column2: Yuck aren’t just missing their lead singer
column3: they’re missing a true frontman
column4: someone who can actually speak for them. Yuck wasn’t much for idiosyncrasy
column5: but it did have a personality—it just so happened that the alternately bummed and bristling indie rock of the 90s served as a perfect conveyance for Blumberg’s lyrics
column6: which found him dumped or just kinda in the dumps. While being every bit as plainspoken
column7: Bloom is harder to read—Glow & Behold’s song titles (“Out of Time”
column8: “Lose My Breath”
column9: “Somewhere”
column10: “Nothing New”
column11: “How Does it Feel”) suggest a topical generality and without much elaboration
column12: it’s difficult to figure out what inspired the members of Yuck to create Glow & Behold besides the urge or necessity to make a second album.

column1: Since the split between Yuck and their erstwhile frontman doesn’t seem all that amicable
column2: it’s tempting to view Blumberg’s debut as Hebronix in competition with Glow & Behold. They’re about even
column3: but the comparison is deflating because it confirms exactly what you’d expect: Unreal had shambling charm for days (or at least 35 minutes)
column4: but lacked structure and melodic guidance
column5: whereas with Glow & Behold
column6: it’s vice versa. Or
column7: while Yuck made listeners nostalgic for the first Clinton term
column8:
Glow & Behold will just make you wish it was 2011 again.

column1: 0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/19770/homepage_large.09fd6186.jpg|fetch|2735.0|Melt-Banana|['Rock'
column3: Melt-Banana have remained like an eye of a hurricane that’s 10 times crazier than the hurricane itself. One of the core bands to emerge from the same roiling soup that birthed art-damaged titans such as the Flying Luttenbachers and the Locust
column4: the female-fronted Japanese group added a few twists to the genetic makeup of 90s noise rock. Japan’s own rich noise tradition was little more than a touchstone for Melt-Banana
column5: and the group’s cryptic otherness elevated it above its peers. It was easy to see that Weasel Walter was a virtuoso slumming it
column6: and that Justin Pearson was a snotty powerviolence kid with a schtick. But Melt-Banana? Who knew what they were thinking? After a six-year break from making studio albums
column7: the new full-length fetch doesn’t answer that question. But it makes that question even more head-spinning.

column1: Melt-Banana left listeners on a curious note with 2007’s frighteningly poppy Bambi’s Dilemma
column2: but that dissonance has been resolved on fetch
column3: in true Melt-Banana fashion
column4: with more dissonance. This is the Melt-Banana of their mid-90s prime: salivating Pavlovianly over the acceleration of culture
column5: twisting the tools of psychedelia into things of surgical precision
column6: and envisioning cyberpunk grindcore before reality knew it could bear the weight of such a thing. It still might not—but fetch at least harmonizes more disharmoniously with the tenor of the times. Gleeful terror pours out of tracks like “Candy Gun” and “Then Red Eyed”; the fact that they’re the longest and shortest song on the disc
column7: respectively
column8: only bookends the dilation of spacetime that guitarist and effects technician Ichirou Agata is able to accomplish. Like a proto 8-bit composer using a looping delay pedal to preemptively echo a deterministic future
column9: he’s a watchmaker winding up a thousand thrash riffs at once then letting them go.

column1: It’s up to Yasuko Onuki to lend a human voice to Agata’s nanotech contraptions. She’s never sounded more savagely ecstatic. On “Red Data
column2: Red Stage” she’s like Dog Faced Hermans’ Marion Coutts sprinting on bipolar impulse
column3: all Situationist cheerleader chants and sugary chirp. Phonetically
column4: it’s all splinters and crystal. Melt-Banana’s grindcore roots
column5: vestigial in the first place
column6: are now only dim memories. Just as the quaint notion of sudden
column7: cataclysmic apocalypse has been replaced in the new millennium by gradual
column8: nonlinear collapse
column9: so does fetch frolic in anachronism
column10: a swarm of data-fragments retroactively reordered and held together with hair and bubblegum. “The Hive” is proof: An intro that resembles “Eruption”-era Eddie Van Halen eaten some yet unimagined remake of Tron opens space for Onuki’s sideways singsong
column11: the filtered cry of bitmapped anxiety.

column1: That Melt-Banana is making some of the best music of their career—over 20 years into the band’s existence—speaks to the universal and transcendent quality of their noise. The landscape of media
column2: society
column3: and even the microcosm of noise rock has changed greatly
column4: but Onuki and Agata have locked jaws on the diametric constants: energy versus agitation
column5: phobia versus euphoria
column6: and instant nostalgia versus the relentless pursuit of the upgrade. fetch is Melt-Banana’s own upgrade
column7: a bleeding-edge reiteration of their fractured and manicured chaos. There’s a moment in the album’s closer
column8: “Zero”
column9: in which Onuki punches her way through a web of Möbius-strip riffage to project a fleeting
column10: Technicolor afterimage of Dilemma’s pop-punk melodicism; then it seizes up
column11: hits the gas
column12: and splatters against a brick wall. A moment later
column13: it reconstitutes itself and barrels forward as if nothing happened. In a breathless whirlwind kind of way
column14:
fetch does the same for Melt-Banana.

If there's been an adventurous metal band that's come through Dallas or Austin in recent times
column2: there's a good chance Fort Worth duo Pinkish Black has opened for them. Keyboardist and vocalist Daron Beck and drummer Jon Teague flip the idea of what metal can be by employing aggression and tense space without guitars
column3: “riffs” in the traditional sense
column4: or anything in the traditional metal sense
column5: really. Pinkish Black resemble a Popol Vuh that suddenly became obsessed with denim and leather
column6: or an enterprising Goblin that
column7: after doing scores for Dario Argento
column8: discovered that headbangers love horror movies. Their self-titled debut
column9: released on Handmade Birds last year
column10: was a promising collection
column11: albiet one that could have benefitted from a little focus. And while Teague's kick drum doesn't make your heart conform to its beat on Razed to the Ground
column12: their second album and first for the large metal label Century Media
column13: it is a more accurate summation of what the band is capable of doing.

column1: Pinkish Black excel when Beck cranks the distorted bass and Teague gets busy on the kit. In this regard
column2: “Kites and Vultures” and “Rise” are the album's standout tracks
column3: as they maximize both of those strengths. In addition
column4: they're the only two tracks that start in kill mode
column5: rather than making the audience wait for the explosion. Had Zombi faced more pressure from Relapse to be more like the bands Relapse usually signs-- that is
column6: aggressive or at least putting on a facade of “aggressive”-- they may have put out something like the title track. There's that Signals-era Rush groove
column7: injected with more bass and menace. Of the band's slower songs
column8: closer “Loss of Feeling of Loss” merges the band's Kraut tendencies with their metallic side the most cohesively. Razed's sequencing is modeled much like their live show
column9: to its advantage. It starts off with a rush
column10: moves into a spacier sequence to let the audience screw their heads back on
column11: trips into another round of pummeling
column12: and then ends with one last suspension of gravity. Whereas the self-titled felt like just a collection of songs
column13: Razed has a more concrete arc. Chalk it up to signing to a major label or chalk it up to experience
column14: but either way
column15: Pinkish Black are finding themselves.

column1: While Razed is mostly a precise album
column2: some of the wandering eye that hindered the self-titled collection still creeps up. “Bad Dreamer” could use more judicious editing; the sections work in and of themselves
column3: but could be more solidly linked. As sublime as “Loss” is
column4: after a couple minutes of silence comes random high piano notes thrown into the void that killed Frank Poole. A throwback to the hidden tracks from nü-metal CDs? The world's most esoteric tribute to Pantera's “Sandblasted Skin”? Whatever it is
column5: that ending feels tacked on and unnecessary. For a band so dependent on structure-- which
column6: given metal's history of eschewing improvisation
column7: is not an issue-- it feels out of character and a betrayal of sorts. Even given these faults
column8: the rest of the record suggests a stronger
column9:
more confident Pinkish Black.

Before Danielle and Este Haim were riding motorbikes in the sun
column3: catching fish with their bare hands
column4: or making potential suitors weep with heartache
column5: they were Valli Girls. The Los Angeles sisters played guitar and bass
column6: respectively
column7: in the tween-pop quintet that was assembled and signed to major label Columbia in 2004
column8: with 1980s soft-rock linchpin Richard Marx attached as a creative contributor. The results were decidedly mixed: there was the acoustic melodrama of The Sisterhood of the Traveling Pants soundtrack cut ""Always There in You""
column9: the cruelly ironic ""Born to Lead"" (""My independent voice will have its say"")
column10: and most notoriously
column11: ""It's a Hair Thing""
column12: the dog whistle-pitched theme song for the short-lived animated TV show ""Trollz"".

column1: This early group wasn't the beginning of the Haim sisters' musical career—the pair had been performing covers with the rest of their family
column2: including youngest sister Alana
column3: since they were old enough to hold instruments. ""We're just ourselves
column4: a 17-year-old Este Haim was quoted as saying in a 2005 press release that touted the Valli Girls' debut album
column5: Valli Nation. That sentiment wasn't entirely true: as a Fader story from earlier this year detailed
column6: musical prodigies Danielle and Este weren't all that into playing songs that they didn't write
column7: so they pulled out of their contract. The family band was christened with the endearingly dorky name Rockinhaim
column8: thereafter shortened to Haim when the sisters decided to strike out on their own in 2006.

column1: So far
column2: the story of Haim has seemed ripe for the type of movie you'd catch playing on VH1 on a Sunday afternoon and Days Are Gone
column3: the trio's outstanding full-length debut
column4: is the latest plot twist. The album arrives just as Haim's impeccably crafted mix of influences—soft rock's incandescent glow
column5: R&B's sensuality
column6: the spiky-yet-polished effervescence of pop-rock—are more fashionable than ever. But Haim weren't just raised on these genres; they were raised to perform them; they may benefit from perfect timing
column7: but they scan as anything but opportunistic.

column1: Since Days Are Gone single and blog-buzz fire-starter ""Forever"" made the rounds in early 2012
column2: Haim have often been mentioned alongside Fleetwood Mac; critic Ann Powers recently described their sound as an encapsulation of Billboard's Hot 100 singles of 1987
column3: which included the Mac's Tango in the Night single ""Little Lies"". The comparison is not without merit—much of the dusky
column4: ebullient ""Honey & I""
column5: one of Days Are Gone's highest highs
column6: sounds as if The Reminder-era Feist fused together the acoustic riffs of ""I Don't Want to Know"" and ""Never Going Back Again"". But Haim also channel the best elements of their current peers: Phoenix's compressed pop economics
column7: the cool-handed spaciousness of Arctic Monkeys' recent work
column8: and Spoon's wound-coil precision.

column1: The latter quality is Haim's secret weapon. Along with drummer and L.A. scene fixture Dash Hutton
column2: Haim sound as tight and in-the-pocket as you'd expect from a group of people that have spent most of their lives making music. Simian Mobile Disco's James Ford (Arctic Monkeys
column3: Klaxons) and studio-man-of-the-moment Ariel Rechtshaid (Vampire Weekend
column4: Usher) both receive co-writing and production credits and contribute just the right touches to Haim's sleek
column5: streamlined arrangements. The record's mix is translucent and refreshingly bare-bones
column6: which affords plenty of space for Days Are Gone's many indelible hooks—the twitchy R&B of ""If I Could Change Your Mind""
column7: ""Don't Save Me""'s rollicking bursts of euphoria
column8: the resonant melancholia of closer ""Running If You Call My Name""—to work their uncanny magic.

column1: When you hear about the influences and consider just how slick the record can be
column2: you might imagine Haim coming over as faceless. But the band's most unusual quality on Days Are Gone is their ability to absorb inputs and continue to sound distinct. The album's punchy title track was co-written by Jessie Ware
column3: another artist who's made a name replicating the sounds of pop's past
column4: along with Ware's frequent songwriting collaborator Kid Harpoon (""Wildest Moments""
column5: ""Night Light""); Ware and Harpoon's style is usually easy to pick out
column6: but it's barely felt on ""Days Are Gone""
column7: as Danielle Haim's staccato delivery pops and locks where Ware's vocals would have crested and swelled. That Haim retain their identity through collaboration speaks to their confidence.

column1: The lyrics on Days Are Gone aren't necessarily built to withstand close analysis; largely
column2: the words function to add a bit of weight to the effortless
column3: feather-light melodies
column4: but Haim do know how to turn a phrase. ""The Wire""
column5: especially
column6: has some of group's most effective lines
column7: a level-headed act of kiss-off kindness (""I gave it all away/ Just so I could say that/ Well I know that you're gonna be OK anyway"") paired with a rolling melody that makes the song one of the most benevolent breakup anthems since Robyn's ""Call Your Girlfriend"".

column1: Days Are Gone is so polished that Haim could easily be seen as clinical and lifeless
column2: but their lighthearted attitude complements their recording rigor. Whether they're covering Miley Cyrus and Sheryl Crow
column3: making ""bass faces""
column4: or reuniting Rockinhaim by bringing their own parents on stage for a rendition of ""Mustang Sally""
column5: Haim come over as affable
column6: playing-to-the-rafters rock stars as well as studio pros. Taken as a whole
column7: the project is a testament to what's most important
column8: and Days Are Gone's divine pleasures suggest that
column9: rock history be damned
column10:
family business doesn't always have to be dysfunctional.

In recent years
column2: even when he's sharing the spotlight
column3: Ty Segall has been the central focus of his endeavors: Ty Segall and White Fence
column4: Ty Segall and Mikal Cronin
column5: Ty Segall Band. With Fuzz
column6: even though he's stepped back to the drumset
column7: he's still the singer
column8: he's still helping to write the songs
column9: and he's really good at drumming. Segall's records come with that inevitable ""prolific songwriter"" baggage
column10: and that might be why Fuzz tried to stay anonymous when they released their first single. Maybe the trio were trying to sidestep the Segall conversation altogether. Of course
column11: it didn't work. It was always pretty easy to figure out who was singing those songs
column12: and it didn't help when they outed themselves as Fuzz to Spin before even releasing a Fuzz record. Once again
column13: at least in their press coverage
column14: Segall receives top billing.

column1: But with an almost startlingly generic band name (that has been used a few times already)
column2: it feels clear that the attention was never meant to be solely Ty's this time. Fuzz is a power trio—a united front of longhairs who work together to build a hard rock soundscape. It's not about the people
column3: it's about the fuzz
column4: man. Segall's vocals pack the cartoon menace of early Sabbath Ozzy
column5: and his drumming is precise-yet-loose
column6: powerful
column7: thrilling. Roland Cosio helms a steady
column8: groove-ready low end. Then there's Charles Moothart
column9: the quiet guitarist who helped create the obliterating guitar sound of Slaughterhouse. He's also the band's riff writer—he'd set up a riff
column10: Segall would help him finish it and add lyrics. You don't have to live with Fuzz for very long before it's clear that the riffs and guitar solos are the main event. Moothart deserves just as much limelight as Segall.

column1: Take the opening moments of ""Sleigh Ride""
column2: ""Raise""
column3: and ""Loose Sutures""—all are kicked off by a meaty and catchy guitar line. One minute
column4: Moothart's busting an enormous guitar solo on ""Loose Sutures""
column5: the next he's doing some delicate
column6: somber work in ""Hazemaze"". He even gets to step out front on ""Raise""
column7: contributing a rare vocal turn where his assertive baritone takes a cynical look at the existance of God. And his voice sounds really good over this proto-metal guitar rock. In a vocals-specific analogy comparing Ty Segall Band to the Who
column8: Segall is Daltrey (the electric frontman vocalist)
column9: Mikal Cronin is Townshend (the tenor who can scream real good)
column10: and apparently
column11: Charles Moothart is Entwistle (the traditionally quieter one who could totally be the lead singer if he wanted to).

column1: But again
column2: while everybody gets their individual moment to shine
column3: it'd be short-sighted to pick an MVP in Fuzz. This album finds strength in the loud
column4: jam-centric prowess of all three dudes playing together. As a unit
column5: they achieve power
column6: drive
column7: and soul. They've got the same chutzpah the MC5 had on Kick Out the Jams
column8: but Fuzz don't sing about revolution. They sing about burning
column9: bleeding
column10: and burials. They're like a murder-obsessed Blue Cheer. On ""Sleigh Ride""
column11: belting in a goblin voice and spitting out every consonant as hard as he can
column12: Segall sings
column13: ""Isolation
column14: / Isolation
column15: / Feel the stiffness of isolation."" Meanwhile
column16: the band establishes vicious
column17: galloping pace—intimidation all around
column18: nowhere to hide.

column1: Like Slaughterhouse before it
column2: Fuzz is an album that depends heavily on power. But while the trio keep muscle and intimidation in play throughout the album
column3: they also leave room to calm down and breathe. Stuff like ""I Bought My Eyes"" stacked power upon power for an entire track
column4: inviting you to speed across the highway or sprint to the finish of a particularly difficult run or lift an impossibly heavy object. ""Loose Sutures"" comes to a full stop in the middle
column5: leaving only the persistent hiss of feedback. For two minutes
column6: there's no adrenaline rush—it forces you to be patient while Cosio rides out a bass solo and while Ty offers up a few drum fills. And then
column7: a slow build of drums into a full
column8: loud
column9: utterly satisfying wall of sound that crashes through to the finish. It's a similar technique to the one Sabbath implemented on Paranoid by placing the mellow ""Planet Caravan"" between ""Paranoid"" and ""Iron Man"". ""Loose Sutures"" has sweet harmonies
column10: feedback-coated quiet
column11: noise
column12: and a searing guitar solo—it's definitely a well-crafted hard rock song.

column1: Ultimately
column2: it's an album that would benefit from a few more sonically diverse moments like that one or the quiet sprawl of Fuzz's opening stretch. The band is obviously very good at delivering infectious hooks with muscle and soul
column3: but those moments only pop if there's a control in place to offset the heavier stuff. Otherwise
column4: the record becomes one big mass of fuzzy low-end guitars and occasional solos. Fuzz consistently run the risk of noodling for a bit too long or pushing one idea a little too far. It's tricky to balance loud and quiet
column5: and Fuzz are still finding their footing. They thrive when they're locked into a sturdy
column6: well-constructed groove like ""Fuzz's Fourth Dream"" (which
column7: as a stand-alone 7""
column8: is the band's best release to date). But in Fuzz's 36 minutes
column9: Segall
column10: Moothart
column11: and Cosio find several satisfyingly stoned

Mazzy Star went away in 1996 and even a few years ago there was no reason to think they would return. In that sense (and a few others—both were on Rough Trade in 1991)

Dustin Wong's solo work-- mostly instrumental
column2: heavy on blankets of overlapping guitar loops-- is executed with a sense of glee and confusion that's akin to watching a small child endlessly wrapping toilet roll around themselves. Wong took a similar approach during his time with Baltimore art punks Ponytail
column3: although that band had a greater sense of abandon than his more studied output on his own. Mediation of Ecstatic Energy is the latest LP in a rapid-fire set of releases that have come from him since the dissolution of his former band. It's the second record from him this year

column7: ""Hey you! Blow your whistle!
column8: into a barked command; by the end of the track
column9: I'm tired of being yelled at.

column1: Traxman's record collection is purportedly renowned amongst Chicago locals; he's been DJing house and juke and hip-hop for more than three decades. Obscurity
column2: though
column3: is not his game. Last year's Da Mind of Traxman featured AC/DC's ""Let There Be Rock"" amongst its absurd and hamfisted appropriations. The Architek makes hay with Juicy J (""Off Them Bars""
column4: exactly what you would expect) and
column5: hilariously
column6: Michael Jackson's ""Earth Song""
column7: flipping the song's one ominous line-- ""What about killing fields?""-- into nearly four minutes of eerie
column8: melodic paranoia.

column1: It's not the sample
column2: it's how you use it. But Traxman albums are not for trainspotters: the train is 30 yards away
column3: barreling down the tracks at you (blowing its whistle). Where DJ Rashad and RP Boo are menacing and soulful
column4: and DJ Diamond is concerned with breaking rhythmic barriers
column5: Traxman's guilelessness adds warmth and jes to his records. He's the footwork artist most willing to abandon the genre's hyper-rhythmic backbone to explore cheese and glitz. Elements of acid house
column6: juke
column7: and drum & bass meet schlock-pop
column8: glam
column9: and rap.

column1: His tracks tend to conform to one of two templates: heavily deployed vocal samples over sparse drums and more intense
column2: wordless rhythm attacks. Some of his most thrilling moments fall into the latter category. ""Japan"" utilizes a sparse beat and aquatic bass to underpin a wild
column3: staccato squeak. ""Manic"" features a long
column4: undulating synthesizer jam. Like last year's ""1988""
column5: ""Mobile Acid"" reveals acid house roots
column6: taking an already warped bassline and turning it over on itself until it's a mound of refried goo. ""Electric Funk""'s deranged beeps sound like Shangaan electro retrofitted to Chicago juke.

column1: It's those vocal samples that serve as signposts on The Architek
column2: though
column3: like the James Brown-sampling
column4: DJ Rashad-collaboration ""Bussin"" or the self-mythologizing DJ shoutout ""We Takin' Over"". ""Hold It""
column5: a longtime footwork favorite
column6: samples a large swath of Psycho's title theme and adds a short
column7: shrill vocal sample-- ""Hold it!""-- over the top. The combination doesn't make a lot of sense
column8: musically or thematically
column9: but it succeeds at feeling both familiar and alien.

column1: The middle of ""Blow Your Whistle"" features another short Collins sample. Traxman nabs her count-in to the track-- ""1! 2! 3! 4!""-- and slices into a wild
column2: disorienting breakdown. It's as fine a summation of Traxman's sound-- blurring the line between voice and rhythm-- as you're likely to find. At 21 tracks
column3: The Architek is overlong and not always engrossing
column4: but its range and confidence are impressive
column5: further cementing Traxman as footwork's mischievous
column6:
elusive virtuoso.

Loss of Self first surfaced in 2012
column2: releasing one of “those” demos-- you know
column3: the hyped
column4: talked-up
column5: too-good-for-its-own-good kind of debut that serves as either kingmaker or fluke. Pallbearer released one in 2010
column6: Lycus followed suit in 2011
column7: and this Melbourne duo took the crown for 2012. After releasing a demo like that
column8: the trick is to capture the ephemeral
column9: flighty buzz
column10: harness it to your oxcart
column11: and ride it off into the sunset with robust first week album sales and panting reviews streaming behind you. With the Flenser's release of their proper debut LP 12 Minutes
column12: Loss of Self almost accomplish that goal.

column1: It’s unfortunate 12 Minutes surfaced the same year Deafheaven deftly scooped up the “post-black metal” crown
column2: because the comparisons are inevitable. The shimmering chords
column3: the expansive post-rock melodies
column4: the sly nods towards depressive Cascadian riffs-- it’s all here. True
column5: Loss of Self are more in tune with their black metal side than many of the other post-punk/black metal hybrids floating around. The vocals never veer from their vehement rasp
column6: first dredged up on album opener “Paradise Overgrown”
column7: a song that comes across as a genuinely strange
column8: dissonant affair. (Here
column9: they sound like a group that could care less about Joy Division
column10: but have heard good things about Deathspell Omega.)

column1: The pretty parts join the party just in time for “Isolt”
column2: where despite its ragged shrieks and wild tremolo
column3: the joyful noise forces its way through. The post-punk influence is unapologetic; nearly every song has at least a few threads of lithe
column4: bright melody weaving through. No
column5: it’s not a very grim record in any sense of the word. The title track
column6: for instance
column7: is a rich
column8: layered piece that piles on clouds of cottony fuzz and
column9: if one were to ignore the strangled vocals
column10: would sound altogether happy. And while Loss of Self keep their motives quiet
column11: the baleful negativity that permeates the majority of their brethren is absent. (Is this what positive black metal sounds like? Other writers have coined the phrase
column12: and they may just be onto something here: “There Must Be Great Wisdom with Great Death” sounds positively ecstatic.)

column1: The cryptically titled “( )” is a windswept ambient interlude
column2: spanning only two minutes. Loss of Self are unique amongst their fellows in this regard: the songs they write never pass the four minute mark
column3: but manage to pack so many ideas and dollops of atmosphere into every moment that the listener never feels cheated. It’s a valuable skill
column4: especially given the oft-ignored truth that not every riff really needs nine minutes to loiter about. The bizarrely distorted reptilian vocals on “The Free Intelligence” create a jarring chorus with the omnipresent croaks. Coupled with the jumpy drumbeats and skittering riff
column5: it makes for a wobbly
column6: disorienting listen
column7: like playing Transilvanian Hunger through the blown-out stereo in your beat-up high school car.

column1: After this
column2: the new material ends
column3: and our barely cooled memories of the demo’s three tracks are refreshed
column4: re-recorded and spiffed up. The slow
column5: somber “The Inheritance” is plaintive and cold
column6: its startlingly lovely central riff moving along at a dejected pace. Tellingly
column7: it’s still the band’s strongest track
column8: even when held up against the final two demo songs. The promise they first made to us in 2012 is still there
column9: half-met. Despite their disparity
column10: none of the tracks seem to develop a very distinct sound; it blurs together charmingly enough
column11: but there’s not much that really grabs hold. Loss of Self have potential to create something truly great
column12:
but they might need just a little more time to get it together.

About a third of the way through Icona Pop's sold-out show last week at New York's Webster Hall
column3: Caroline Hjelt pulled out what appeared to be a gold-plated kazoo. ""This is a song about how much we like making out with people!"" she and bandmate Aino Jawo declared
column4: practically in unison
column5: with the triumphant and outsized exuberance of a pair of Olympians who have just won an unexpected gold medal. The song is called ""Then We Kiss""
column6: a thumping
column7: hyperactive new-wave sunburst that concludes the Swedish duo's full-length debut
column8: This Is…Icona Pop
column9: a collection of cranked-up
column10: EDM-influenced pop that sounds like a cross between ABBA's Gold and Andrew WK's I Get Wet. ""Then We Kiss"" is a perfect closer-- the kind of song to the tune of which balloons and confetti fall out of rafters-- and its final
column11: chanted lines (""All I wanna do is have a good time"") serve as a succinct summary of the 32 minutes that have come before. The only thing Icona Pop take seriously is fun
column12: which is to say that they don't take anything very seriously at all.

column1: Of course
column2: the song that elevated Icona Pop from plastic to gold kazoo status is ""I Love It""
column3: the hard-driving
column4: rainbow-brite break-up anthem that was first (and
column5: initially
column6: quietly) released as a single in May 2012. The song's life has been fascinating
column7: if not downright myth-busting. In a moment when it seems like the internet has killed off the very notion of a monoculture
column8: it became an unavoidable global hit (it just went double-platinum in the U.S.); in a moment when it seemed our pop cultural attention spans were dwindling to nothing
column9: its star burned slowly enough to make it a Song of the Summer contender two years in a row. ""I Love It"" has pinballed across the zeitgeist with anarchic glee. It has been covered by Titus Andronicus and Cookie Monster; it has soundtracked a scene of coke-addled dancing on Girls and one of primetime network pomp on Dancing With the Stars. The last time I watched the video for ""I Love It""
column10: I first had to sit through a 30-second ad that was soundtracked by ""I Love It"".

column1: To the cynical
column2: this might read like Chapter 1 of a one hit wonder story
column3: and usually these aren't the sort of circumstances under which an artist releases a debut of consistent quality
column4: or sets the foundation for a long career. But This Is…Icona Pop is a pleasant surprise: it's something more than just 11 tracks of padding around an undeniable hit. ""I Love It"" kicks things off (as it did last year's spirited yet spotty Iconic EP)
column5: but in sequence-- somewhat improbably-- it's not so much an early burn-out as it is the spark that launches the rest of the album's propulsive run.

column1: Given that Icona Pop’s preferred theme is turning lemons into (hard) lemonade
column2: they could not have a more perfect origin story. The two met at a party when each was rising from the ashes of her own respective misfortune: Jawo had just been dumped
column3: and Hjelt had just recovered from a prolonged leg injuring sustained by
column4: in her words
column5: ""jumping on a trampoline after beer pong."" Their connection was immediate and electric; they wrote their first song the next day. Though their debut album finds them working with an assortment of co-writers and producers (including Norweigan hitmakers Stargate and Swedish producer Patrik Berger)
column6: the palpable chemistry between Hjelt and Jawo is the engine driving Icona Pop's sound. Their voices-- much more often entwined than solo-- blare forcefully enough to compete with (and often overpower) the songs' pounding beats and throbbing synths
column7: but this over-exerted quality also gives their music a certain human warmth. ""Voices have to crack a little for it to sound like two people
column8: Hjelt said in a recent interview
column9: nailing the essence This Is…Icona Pop's scrappy
column10: collaborative charm. File it under ""bestie-core.""

column1: Icona Pop's best songs are the ones that tightrope-walk the line between good and bad taste-- that own their gaucheness confidently enough to transform it into glory. The strobe-light pulse of ""We Got the World"" pushes an anthemic melody into the red (Icona Pop usually sing like people who will wake up with sore throats tomorrow)
column2: while the irresistibly goofy ""On a Roll"" sounds like something Electric Six would write for the Eurovision Song Contest (""You go with me/ There will not be drinking of tea/ Huh!""). The plot of ""On A Roll"" revolves around the unbelievable luck of finding a ""brand new
column3: crispy"" $100 bill on the ground; in an Icona Pop song this is more than enough money to have a good time. This Is… embraces the spirit of glam
column4: but it's not music about the acquisition of wealth (imagine if every song on American radio were written by artists from countries with near-utopian levels of income equality) or acquisition of anything long-term
column5: really. (""You and I live
column6: don’t learn
column7: they proclaim on ""We Got the World""
column8: ""Every day we fire it up and let it burn."") Like most great party music
column9: Icona Pop's euphoria is mixed with a twinge of apocalypse
column10: like the soundtrack to a house party where the world ends before you have to separate the trash from the recycling.

column1: The first seven songs play out like a 20-minute power hour
column2: but the album loses a bit of steam after that. Clumsy lyrics (""Close my eyes and we're still naked/ But then I see that my clock is changing"") are always harder to forgive when they're caked in melodrama
column3: so the sub-Journey power ballad ""Just Another Night"" lands with a thud. Similarly
column4: the electro-reggae number ""Light Me Up"" is
column5: as you might guess from the title
column6: a little too on-the-nose. But luckily Icona Pop get it back in the end with ""Then We Kiss""
column7: a song that calls to mind the sleek
column8: luminous pair of neo-new-wave songs that Ric Ocasek produced on No Doubt's Rock Steady. ""Then We Kiss"" barely exceeds two minutes
column9: but it strays just far enough from the formula to suggest that Icona Pop might have more than one trick up their sleeves. On a debut
column10: though
column11: they can get by without showing much range.

column1: The closest Icona Pop come to matching the endorphin-drunk perfection of ""I Love It"" is ""Girlfriend""
column2: a beaming synth-pop anthem that plays out like Robyn’s ""Call Your Girlfriend"" might if the girls in that song both decided to dump their cheating dude and become best friends instead. Some might dismiss it as Girl Power recycled for generation EDM
column3: but unlike the Spice Girls
column4: Icona Pop actually seem to like each other in real life. ""All I need in this life of sin is me and my girlfriend
column5: Hjelt and Jawo sing
column6: reimagining Tupac’s sensitive thug theme song as a suga-coated ode to female solidarity. A little over the top? Sure. But coming from the group who coined post-guilty-pleasure pop's most quotable slogan
column7:
we should expect nothing less.

There are two bands called Jesu. One is a bedroom project that mostly makes minimalist
column3: experimental
column4: drum-machine-backed EPs and split singles. The other is a full rock band that makes full rock albums
column5: with drums provided by former Swans
column6: Prong
column7: and Godflesh member Ted Parsons. Both are led by Justin Broadrick-- co-founder of Napalm Death and Godflesh
column8: as well as numerous side projects. What ties both versions of Jesu together is Broadrick’s wide-angle vision: a melodic yet abstracted amalgam of industrialized metal and time-lapse shoegaze. Until now it’s been pretty easy to know which Jesu you were getting
column9: simply by noting if the release in question were an EP or an album. But on Jesu’s fifth full-length
column10: Everyday I Get Closer to the Light From Which I Came
column11: that distinction is not so strict. Neither is Broadrick’s normally high standard.

column1: Clocking in at five songs
column2: Everyday I Get Closer is the skimpiest Jesu full-length to date (not counting the single-cut
column3: fifty-minute Infinity from 2009
column4: which is neither EP fish nor album fowl). The tracks vary greatly in span
column5: but beyond that there’s not as much of a dynamic as on prior Jesu full-lengths. Granted
column6: Jesu has long been one of those great
column7: every-song-sounds-the-same kind of endeavors
column8: although a deeper immersion in any given Jesu disc reveals rich degrees of emotional engagement and layers of textured ambience. On top of that
column9: Broadrick has been turning into a stunning singer-songwriter
column10: a kind of British Mark Eitzel buried under metric tons of celestial distortion. Few of these strengths are in abundance on Everyday I Get Closer. On “Homesick”
column11: Broadrick’s trademark use of descending chord progressions is executed in his sleep
column12: as is the Swervedriver-ish swirl and chiming counterpoint. There’s an afterimage of longing that haunts the song
column13: but it never clicks into focus. Nor does the 17-minute
column14: would-be saga that is “The Great Leveller”
column15: which drifts from movement to movement-- piano-laced intro
column16: planetoid riffs
column17: antigravity interludes
column18: the low-cycle hum of synthesized melancholy-- in an anticlimactic meander.

column1: That’s not to say Everyday I Get Closer is a bust. Even when treading water
column2: it walks on air. The ambient lead-in to “Comforter” seeps like a ruptured cloud into atmospheric passages of oscillating noise
column3: tectonic bass
column4: and a collage of reverberating vocal samples. When Broadrick steps out from behind his shimmering
column5: digitized curtain to lend his angelic deadpan to the song’s sad churn
column6: it morphs from a lullaby to a lament. His voice is even more vulnerable on “Everyday”
column7: where pounding rhythms-- reminiscent of Hymns-era Godflesh
column8: Broadrick’s bridge into Jesu-- tether a gradual escalation of stratified guitar and interstellar pinging. It doesn’t come close to the orchestral sprawl of “The Great Leveller”
column9: but it’s stronger because of its conciseness
column10: not to mention a much-needed display of self-humanization in which Broadrick lets his lungs hang out.

column1: And then he goes and recuses himself-- or at least his vocal presence-- from the halfhearted instrumental closer “Grey is the Color”. An angular
column2: space-punctured approach to slowcore that imagines Codeine gone kosmische
column3: it’s an emptily pleasant
column4: mildly numbing wisp of filler. It’s also the only thing Broadrick leaves the listener holding. It shouldn’t make a difference whether a release is called an album or an EP-- only in Jesu’s case
column5: each new album is a rare event that crystallizes the aching
column6: creeping progress Broadrock makes between EPs. Despite its respectable length
column7: Everyday I Get Closer is not one of those events. Instead it drifts in listless circles
column8: waiting maybe too patiently for the other
column9:
mightier Jesu to come along.

Of all the 90s-era indie-rock bands to have reunited in recent years
column4: Girls Against Boys could be the most out of place in 2013
column5: what with the noticeable lack of sex-obsessed dystopian art-punk bands with two bassists. But even in their heyday
column6: Girls Against Boys were used to being the odd men out. Though they had roots in the D.C. Dischord scene and enjoyed a three-album run on Chicago’s Touch & Go Records
column7: this uncommonly handsome band always projected a cool suavity-- like the Rat Pack taking up residency at the 9:30 Club-- that distinguished them from more outrageous post-hardcore peers like the Jesus Lizard and Brainiac
column8: while lead mouthpiece Scott McCloud favored a sleazily suggestive crypto-speak at odds with the more earnest invectives of contemporaries like Fugazi and Jawbox. And they were putting their own singular spin on then-dormant ’80s post-punk influences-- namely
column9: the pint-glass-smashing rumble of the Fall and the icy pulse of Joy Division-- long before you could score an Unknown Pleasures t-shirt at Urban Outfitters.

column1: But Girls Against Boys’ unconventional ethos yielded an all-too-predictable outcome: a momentum-stalling
column2: instantly dated major-label debut (1998’s regrettably titled Freak*On*Ica)
column3: followed by an unceremonious return to indie-dom (2002’s You Can’t Fight What You Can’t See). Since then
column4: the band’s individual members have ventured as far away from the House of GVSB as possible: McCloud and drummer Alexis Fleisig launched the acoustic-oriented
column5: National-esque Paramount Styles
column6: and bassist Johnny Temple turned his sideline indie-book imprint Akashic into a mini-publishing empire
column7: while fellow four-stringer Eli Janney padded out his Nation of Ulysses and Jawbox production credits with the likes of Jet and James Blunt. So
column8: in light of these highly divergent pursuits
column9: it’s pretty remarkable that
column10: on their first release in 11 years
column11: Girls Against Boys manage to sound exactly like Girls Against Boys.

column1: If anything’s changed here
column2: it’s their perspective. On GVSB’s signature mid-90s releases
column3: there was a considerable ironic distance between the band’s urbane
column4: predatory sound and McCloud’s knowingly antiquated banter
column5: which invested hoary show-biz phraseology (“One more time with feeling!” “Sock it to me!” “You’re in like Flynn!”) with lecherous menace. On The Ghost List
column6: he’s still very much the cocktail-swilling cretin occupying the same corner stool
column7: but his barfly philosophy has become more rueful with age: When he observes
column8: “It’s a diamond life” (on the swaggering lead track of the same name)
column9: the luxe-lifestyle fantasies of old have hardened into post-recession desperation
column10: and his repeated insistence that “you gotta get into it/ get into it” applies the sort of aspirational pressure that inspires one to max out their credit cards. And for a guy whose lyrics could read like a news-ticker of pick-up lines
column11: the atypically confessional tone and melodic drive of “Let’s Get Killed” (“the past is all we live in and the future’s always slipping away”) suggests that McCloud’s looking for a connection that lasts longer than last call to breakfast. (Accordingly
column12: during GVSB’s hiatus
column13: he relocated to Vienna to live with his Austrian girlfriend.)

column1: Consistent with the more sobering outlook
column2: The Ghost List doesn’t quite push GVSB to peak white-hot intensity-- none of these five songs are as liable to incite a brawl like “Kill the Sexplayer” or soundtrack a drive-by like “Bulletproof Cupid"". And though GVSB were one of the few indie-rock bands in the 90s to take notes from concurrent developments in dance music
column3: there’s no attempt here to contemporize the band’s sound. (As McCloud recently told the Washington Post
column4: this sense of arrested development was a totally intentional brass-tacks move.) But from the robo-cow-punk charge of “Fade Out” to the synth-buzzed pummel of “60 Is Greater Than 15” to the industrialized meltdown of “Kick""
column5: The Ghost List EP is a successful reboot for a mothballed machine whose core components-- brawn
column6: dissonance
column7: and groove-- are shown to be still in fine working order. Sure
column8: we’ve seen this movie before
column9:
but Girls Against Boys haven’t forgotten the good parts.

column2: New Zealand

column3: New Zealand's Ulcerate a “technical death metal” band? They're certainly technical
column4: boasting complicated arrangements played at dizzying tempos. Ulcerate
column5: however
column6: cannot and should not be branded with the “tech-death” stigma. Commonly
column7: “tech-death” bands are criticized for “having no soul
column8: ” meaning they emphasize flash over songwriting. While this is often true
column9: the criticism can be saddled with the false notion that simplicity means soul
column10: as if rehashing the same Master and Asphyx songs has more integrity than trying to incorporate a few weird time signatures. In fact
column11: there's nothing duller than laboriously listening to mid-paced death metal under the guise of “Celtic Frost worship” or keeping up tradition. Credit Ulcerate for not only subverting staleness on Vermis
column12: their fourth album and first for Relapse
column13: but for doing so with vigor.

column1: Hints of Hate Eternal and Demigod-era Behemoth can be found in Vermis
column2: particularly in the faster
column3: more warlike sections of “The Imperious Weak” and the title track. Ulcerate are also aware that filling the room with blasts and riffs is only sometimes the effective battle plan
column4: and that a little space can go a long way. “Clutching Revulsion” and “Weight of Emptiness” demonstrate this most aptly-- even the parts where the band lays off the acceleration are filled with unease
column5: almost like blastbeats are a kind of security blanket. Drummer Jamie Saint Merat is crucial to the attack
column6: playing with speed and fluidity that many death metal drummers couldn't come close to after hours of watching Tim Yeung YouTube lessons. Thanks in part to Saint Merat
column7: Ulcerate possess a certain balance between precision and looseness that's usually only found only in some Finnish bands like Demigod and Demilich. They likely poured over the songs
column8: no doubt
column9: but there isn't any weariness here. As complicated as the music may be
column10: Vermis is an album of songs
column11: not exercises. Technicality is used to convey madness; it's not the ultimate goal in and of itself.

column1: Across the water from Ulcerate is Australia
column2: notorious for some of the most out-of-control metal in existence from groups such as Sadistik Exekution
column3: Bestial Warlust
column4: Portal
column5: and Impetutous Ritual. Sometimes
column6: the lines between metal and free improvisation aren't so clear. Ulcerate doesn't quite go into the stratosphere of chaos that those bands do
column7: but there's enough of a bent to prevent them from being clinical and straight-laced. Guitarist Michael Hoggard once played live with New Zealand comrades Vassafor
column8: so he's no stranger to bestial riffage. Ulcerate could be a model for how to reconcile modernity with death metal's timeless principles. The production is grungy enough to give Vermis the dirtiness death metal strives for
column9: but it doesn't conceal that Ulcerate are very efficient and very driven to kill.

column1: “Oh
column2: this isn't Cianide. When did death metal become life metal?” Drown out such groans with Vermis. They may not listen
column3:
but you don't have to listen to them either.

For two decades

column4: The Bones of What You Believe
column5: is a seamless fusion of emotive theatrics

column1: Unlike those those bands

column3: but the hooks on The Bones of What You Believe are indelible regardless of instrumentation
column4: and the sound is immaculate. After Chvrches self-produced the album in band member Iain Cook's own Glasgow studio

column5: aching
column6: triumphant
column7: fragile
column8: and weightless
column9: sometimes all at once; on ""Lies""
column10: she soars above the chorus' mountainous build

column12: the closest thing to a miss on this otherwise rock-solid album.

column1: Even when Mayberry's at her most powerful
column2: her voice possesses a specific
column3: relatable humanity
column4: which brightens the adolescent glow of her lyrics. (Occasional lead singer Doherty
column5: previously the band's weak link

column8: but when set to the emotive sounds that Chvrches trade in

column12: a spiritual antecedent

column1: The Bones of What You Believe also shares some of Depeche Mode's large-scale ambition: the arpeggiated-synth burst that closes ""Tether"" sounds like it was orchestrated for the optimal turn-all-the-lasers-on-at-once trigger at a live performance

column6: on record
column7: Chvrches know how to go big on an intimate scale
column8:
to remind us of the stuff that keeps us living.

The concept behind Golden Tickets is generous and sweet. As Yoni Wolf explained on the Joyful Noise label's website
column3: the EP is a collection of songs for and about specific WHY? fans. ""We would write a theme song for one customer who came to the [WHY?] web store and bought something every month... We'd read all about them on Facebook and Twitter
column4: and sometimes even go so far as to contact their significant other to ask them questions. Then I would write the song on piano
column5: and my brother would take the skeleton of lyrics & piano and turn it into a fully realized arrangement.""

column1: Those seven songs are collected here
column2: on the Golden Tickets EP
column3: and if I was any of these hardcore fans
column4: I would be struggling with the uncomfortable question of whether my favorite band was personally mocking or belittling me. Part of the issue with these fan-specific valentines is unfair to Wolf but hard to ignore; Wolf's acrid delivery turns everything a little smarmy
column5: which suits him well when he's addressing his favorite subject-- himself and his many faults-- but skews a little queasy when he's paying tribute to people who've done him the favor of repeatedly buying his music.

column1: If I were the fan who Wolf pays tribute to on ""Banana Mae""
column2: for instance
column3: I would have some serious questions.  Wolf opens with the room-clearing line ""Follow me
column4: @banana_mae/ If you wanna see what I have to say/ now I'm only less than twenty-tre/ But I'll Twit a tweet to make your hair turn grey"" before offering an unflattering imitation of a stereotypical vapid
column5: prattling teenage girl. Banana Mae gets the last laugh
column6: though; the second verse is cobbled together from her own tweets
column7: which ironically contain the only characteristically Yoni Wolfian insights to be found on Golden Tickets: ""I'm very impatient for science to figure out/ how I can clone myself and make the clone interact with my friends and family
column8: it's tiring."" Or: ""I think the reason I don’t have any friends is ‘cause the people that I click with the best/ Also hate to leave their beds."" You can hear what she might like in Wolf's best writing.

column1: Speaking of which: For WHY? fans who are not the seven people selected as this EP's subject matter
column2: these songs represent the nadir of the WHY? project. Every song begins with the character baldly introducing themselves: ""My name is Hunter Van Brocklin."" ""Well it's me
column3: Dropjaw."" Or ""Peta E. Godfrey
column4: I'm a bonafide Aussie."" The characterizations are less sketches of human people and more little sock-puppet retellings of the sort of basic biographical info you can glean from scanning a person's Facebook and Twitter: ""I was born to teach/ I do humanities/ Strictly public school
column5: I think that should be the rule
column6: he sings on ""Peta Godfrey"". Wolf's lyrics are bewilderingly lazy throughout: Hunter Van Brocklin is ""just a small-town boy in this big city"" and a ""a simple Southern man trying to find my fate."" Van Brocklin has ""fingers like a poem when they press the keys."" Fingers like a poem?

column1: Wolf has long been a shrewd
column2: incisive writer
column3: and his words have often borne testament to the virtues of mental sweat and finger-cramping rewriting. You could practically see the ghosted revisions hovering over a perfect line like ""God put a song on my palm that you can't read/ I'll be embalmed with it long before
column4: you'll see."" ""I want that sharpened steel of truth in every word
column5: he insisted on ""This Blackest Purse."" It's been awhile since we've seen that guy. On Golden Tickets
column6: it sounds as if he's simply given up trying. There is one remaining golden ticket
column7: by the way: ""The lucky person who receives this golden ticket will have a WHY? song written about him or her
column8: the album page says. ""No foolin."" In context
column9:
it sounds like a threat.

Potty Mouth don't shake the foundation of guitar rock

column4: in Northampton
column5: Mass.
column6: bassist Ally Einbinder and drummer Victoria Mandanas had already played the punk scene
column7: allowing Potty Mouth a driving energy

column1: With that

column1: Hell Bent inches Potty Mouth towards more profound songwriting than last year's great Sun Damage EP. The lyrics focus primarily on the many facets of what it means to be young-- desire to ditch smalltown life
column2: irresponsible choices that bring on ""The Spins

column1: More often than not
column2: though
column3: the songs on Hell Bent center on confusion
column4: uncertainty
column5: and frustration within contexts like friendship
column6: identity
column7: or dreaming. ""Damage"" charges forward with the grey melancholy and earnestness of early emo
column8: as Weems grapples with feeling helpless in a dire situation. On ""Sleep Talk""
column9: she fears what might seep into her subconscious at night-- ""I have this feeling that I'll wake up and wanna talk to you""-- coasting over one of the record's best hooks. ""Shithead""
column10: meanwhile

In the fall of 2011
column2: the last thing the world needed was a song called ""Videotapes"" that sounded a little bit like a lost Human League hit dubbed onto an old

column1: It's a testament to Portland's Blouse
column2: then
column3: that the murky earworm bearing that particular name managed to stand out even among the crowded crop of hypnagogic pop. Maybe that's because
column4: like ""Videotapes""
column5: all the songs on their unexpectedly fresh self-titled debut were driven by the tension of opposing forces
column6: as the heat generated from radiant
column7: sun-bursting synths collided with the airy cool of Charlie Hilton's vocals. Blouse found a balance between texture and melody: here was a band that clearly cared about atmosphere
column8: but never at the expense of a solid
column9: Top Gun soundtrack-worthy hook.

column1: With their second full-length Imperium
column2: though
column3: the band is making a conscious push to distance itself from those electro-tinged beginnings. Blouse have nixed the synths and drum machines: Multi-instrumentalist and producer Jacob Portrait (who also plays bass in Unknown Mortal Orchestra) proudly announces in the press release that the record was made entirely with ""instruments that don't plug into the wall."" Sure

column6: rubbery basslines-- and blends them into a gloomy swirl. ""Are you one of us?/ Are you one of us?"" Hilton chants as the song winds down
column7: in a haunting monotone that's half Hope Sandoval
column8: half creepily malfunctioning automaton. Though Hilton's out in front
column9: Portrait is Blouse's secret weapon

column11: while the up-tempo ripper ""Arrested"" has the loose

column1: And yet
column2: there's a lack of variety in Imperium's marble-cool tone that makes it feel more one-note than Blouse's debut. It's laudable for a band to push itself out of its comfort zone on its second album-- there are artists out there who lay such a lazily trendy coating of synthesizers over their songs that the electricity in their practice spaces should be cut just to stir creativity. But Blouse weren’t one of those bands. Their debut showed the promise of growth

column6:

Soma shows all the signs of an attempted slow metal classic: On their second album and first for Relapse
column2: Richmond

column4: once again

(The second-guessing circumstances were not that dissimilar to those of the preceding Nevermind-- wherein Butch Vig's original recordings were eventually handed over to Andy Wallace for a platinum-plated finish-- only this time
