column7: was the true blockbuster sequel to Nevermind. In that sense
column8: this first version of In Utero resonates as much today as a symbolic gesture as a collection of 12 unrelentingly visceral rock songs
column9: a how-to manual for any artist at the top of their game-- from Kid A-era Radiohead to Kanye West circa Yeezus-- that would rather use their elevated position to provoke their audience than pander to it.

column1: The second version of In Utero came to be on April 8
column3: from which point the album would be forever known as the rough draft for rock‘n’roll’s most famous suicide note. In the wake of Cobain’s shotgunned sign-off
column4: it became nigh impossible to hear In Utero in any other context. The infamous album-opening lyric that once dripped with sarcasm-- “Teenage angst has paid off well/ Now I’m bored and old”-- now sounded coldly nihilistic. Where the seismic stomper “Scentless Apprentice” invoked Patrick Süskind’s novel Perfume as metaphor for Cobain’s festering disgust with the music press and industry
column5: the song’s grueling shriek of “get awwwwwaaaayyyy” suddenly seemed to be directed at humanity itself. The “Leonard Cohen after-world” fantasy of “Pennyroyal Tea” turned into wish fulfillment; “All Apologies” ceased to be an innocently plaintive pop song and was instead permanently etched into its writer's epitaph.

column1: But with this two-disc 20th-anniversary reissue
column2: we now have a third version of <i>In Utero
column3: and I’m not just referring to the newly remixed iteration of the album. Taken as a whole
column4: the package-- which also includes a remastered version of the original mix
column5: B-sides
column6: outtakes
column7: a slew of embryonic demos
column8: and a cheeky but affecting liner-note essay by comedian/tourmate Bobcat Goldthwait-- puts lie to the notion that In Utero is the soundtrack to a suicide
column9: commercial or otherwise. In charting the songs’ evolution from rough instrumentals to the militaristic blasts of fury heard on the album proper
column10: and through the outré experiments scrapped along the way
column11: we hear a band that was on the cusp of an intriguing new phase.

column1: In a surprisingly conciliatory Musique Plus interview conducted just prior to the album’s release
column2: Cobain stated that In Utero would mark the end of Nirvana as grunge torchbearers and
column3: throughout the record
column4: the band screech and howl like they're skinning themselves alive to expedite their reinvention. But not a lyric goes by on the album where Cobain doesn’t sound conflicted between what he wants to do and what he feels he has to do. The scowling verses of “Serve the Servants” are countered by the chorus’ soothing incantation of the song’s title
column5: as if Cobain had to anesthetize himself in order to answer his audience’s populist demands. You didn’t need to hear the feedback assault of “Radio Friendly Unit Shifter” to sense the irony reeking from its title
column6: while the sludgy savagery of “Milk It” deploys Cobain’s fascinations with bodily fluids and birthing to depict a soul being run through the music-industry wringer. Though Cobain claimed in the aforementioned interview that the deliberately bald language of “Rape Me” was his response to misinterpretations of Nirvana’s more ambiguous portraits of sexual/power dynamics (“Polly”
column7: “About a Girl”)
column8: the fact that it cops the riff to his most famous song unsubtly directs the titular demand to his hit-seeking minders; when he answers his request by repeating “I’m not the only one
column9: ” he seems to be placating himself with the knowledge that he’s not the first punk-rocker caught in a boardroom power play. (And
column10: in light of Cobain’s mounting disdain for the media
column11: I can’t be the only person who’s always heard that line in “All Apologies” as “choking on the ashes of her NME.”)

column1: But this set supports the theory that Cobain didn’t necessarily fear or hate success; his real struggle was achieving it on his own terms. If he really wanted to clear the room
column2: he could’ve made In Utero a lot weirder than it actually turned out to be: among the outtakes here is “Gallons of Rubbing Alcohol Flowing Through the Strip” (which previously surfaced stateside on the barrel-scraping 2004 box set With the Lights Out)
column3: an exceedingly odd
column4: stream-of-consciousness ramble that sees Cobain
column5: Krist Novoselic
column6: and Dave Grohl adopting the art-damaged inscrutability of then-underground darlings Pavement. Also included are Albini’s supposedly contentious original mixes for In Utero’s two singles
column7: “Heart-Shaped Box” and “All Apologies”
column8: which the band eventually handed over to R.E.M. associate Scott Litt to create the spit-shined radio-friendly versions that wound up on the final record. Furthermore
column9: Litt's crisper alternate take of ""Penny Royal Tea"" (which scrubs off a layer of its Sebadohian scuzz) is featured here as a reinforcement of Nirvana's acquiescent impulses -- it first appeared on a special edition of In Utero created specifically for Wal-Mart that swapped out the title of ""Rape Me"" for the more big-box-shopper-friendly ""Waif Me."" (That the differences between the Albini and Litt's mixes are slight speaks to the sort of nitpicking the band were being subjected from without and within.) And in hearing the unvarnished demos of “Scentless Apprentice” and “Radio Friendly Unit Shifter”
column10: you get a clearer sense of just how much refinement and fierce discipline they were subjected to before being presented to the public. (In particular
column11: the versions featured in the band's MTV Live and Loud concert from December 1993 -- included in a deluxe four-disc version of this set -- perfectly encapsulate the In Utero ideal of arena-rock at its most anarchic.)

column1: There’s also evidence here to suggest that
column2: in spite of In Utero’s caustic reputation
column3: Nirvana were also keen to explore more sophisticated songcraft. “Sappy” was presumably kept off the In Utero tracklist (and punted over to the No Alternative charity compilation) due to its strong resemblance to Nevermind corkers like “Drain You”
column4: but it still stands as one of Cobain’s purest
column5: most effortless power-pop gestures
column6: while the hushed B-side ballad “Marigold” serves as a test flight for Grohl’s Foo Fighters. Most surprising of all is an early demo of “All Apologies” with an acoustic
column7: countrified shimmer that could practically pass for a CCR golden oldie
column8: transmuting the song's overarching sense of resignation into bright-eyed
column9: fresh-start optimism. Though Nirvana obviously had second thoughts about assuming such a radically chipper guise
column10: that sort of willingness to mess with their essence would carry over to the band’s subsequent touring formation
column11: on which ex-Germs guitarist Pat Smear was added to fill out the sound and the sight of guest cellists was not uncommon.

column1: This exploratory ethos also informs In Utero’s new 2013 mix
column2: overseen by Albini with input from Novoselic
column3: Grohl
column4: and Smear. Strangely enough
column5: the revamp was inspired by another rock icon who died at 27: Novoselic recently revealed the idea came to him after hearing a gussied-up Doors compilation that emphasized certain
column6: previously unnoticed sonic details. Albini
column7: however
column8: has offered a more pragmatic rationale: In Utero’s quick gestation period meant some mixing decisions were made off-the-cuff
column9: resulting in various instrumental parts
column10: alternate guitar solos
column11: and harmony lines being left out. As he told podcaster Vish Khanna
column12: his intention was not to replace the 1993 mix
column13: but to simply take a snapshot of the same songs “from a different angle.” The new version is in fact more textured and nuanced
column14: but not at the expense of the album's bone-dry
column15: brutalizing crunch. Most of its touch-ups are tastefully unobtrusive and illuminating
column16: like the unearthed cello lines creeping behind the chorus of “Serve the Servants” that bring a greater sense of melancholy to the fore
column17: or the screeching strings and slowly decaying fadeout of “All Apologies” that lend a more palpable degree of finality to the proceedings. But there are times where the listening experience is reduced to a parlor game of spotting what’s been added and what’s been omitted: On the upside
column18: “Scentless Apprentice” now sounds like it’s being screamed into a toilet
column19: pushing the song to exciting new levels of gnarliness
column20: but excising the cello parts that are so integral to “Dumb” is
column22: kinda dumb.

column1: Fittingly
column2: for an album that starkly contrasts Nirvana's melodic and maniacal extremes
column3: In Utero: 20th Anniversary Edition highlights another inherent contradiction: much like the Beatles’ Let It Be
column4: what was originally intended to be a raw
column5: back-to-basics reaction to past excesses has
column6: ironically
column7: been subjected to so much over-thinking and console-board tinkering (this latest mix constituting its Let It Be… Naked moment of revisionism). But all these mutations reflect the restless
column8: irrepressible nature of these songs
column9: which-- whether in the form of crude demos or modern-day remasters-- still sting and ooze like a flesh wound that refuses to heal. And yet In Utero is the sort of painful shock that
column10: paradoxicalaly
column11: reinstills the empowering sensation of feeling alive. Cobain may have been bored
column12: but he checked out before he grew old; when listening to his final collection of songs
column13: you forget
column14: for a little while
column15:
the possibility of either.

Peter Gabriel’s latest project didn’t go exactly as planned. In 2010
column2: he released Scratch My Back
column3: his first studio album in eight years
column4: which collected skeletal covers of songs by the Arcade Fire
column5: Radiohead
column6: David Bowie
column7: Bon Iver
column8: and Paul Simon. It was part of a concept where each of the artists he covered would then cover his songs on a follow-up titled And I’ll Scratch Yours. As he told The Guardian three years ago
column9: “Rather than having a passive project where you do your own thing with people’s songs
column10: I wanted to see if I could interact with the people who wrote them
column11: so they had to be living and amenable
column12: or initially amenable.”

column1: That last phrase proved crucial. Gabriel’s peculiar musical choices-- slowing every song down to a uniform crawl
column2: setting them in bleakly orchestral arrangements
column3: intoning the lyrics in a near-spoken cadence-- alienated many long-time fans as well as some of the artists. Most notably: Radiohead
column4: upon hearing Gabriel’s rococo-minimalist version of “Street Spirit (Fade Out)""
column5: decided they were no longer amenable and backed out of covering “Wallflower”. Bowie
column6: Neil Young
column7: and Ray Davies also declined to participate
column8: so Gabriel recruited Feist and Joseph Arthur as replacements. Neither of their covers proves particularly revelatory: Backed by Timber Timbre on “Don’t Give Up”
column9: Feist can’t quite muster the desperation and intimacy of the original
column10: although Arthur’s decision to slow “Shock the Monkey” to half-speed plays out surprisingly well.

column1: Originally
column2: both of these albums were intended to be released simultaneously in 2010
column3: but it took three long years to finally scratch their backs. During that time Gabriel and the other artists released some of the tracks via iTunes and Record Store Day exclusives
column4: which means nearly half of I’ll Scratch Yours has long been available. Bon Iver’s “Come Talk to Me”
column5: released on a split-7"" with Gabriel’s version of “Flume”
column6: sounds weirdly faithful to the original
column7: yet it’s so muted and understated that it ends up missing the point of the song: rather than an open line of communication
column8: it’s a busy signal. David Byrne sounds similarly noncommittal on “I Don’t Remember""
column9: his voice alarmingly thin and even sickly. At least Stephin Merritt has a good time with “Not One of Us”
column10: injecting some much-needed humor into the song
column11: and Lou Reed takes the piss out of the hoary “Solsbury Hill”
column12: a rom-com staple that ends up squatting in a Bronx tenement ca. 1976. Slowed down and skeezed up with sneers of distorted guitar
column13: it’s nearly unrecognizable delivered in Reed's supremely stoic voice.

column1: The familiarity of these songs drains much of the surprise and novelty from the album
column2: yet the new songs prove just as uneven and in many cases noncommittal
column3: as though the artists were embarrassed to be included on the tracklist. The Arcade Fire
column4: long rumored to be only initially amenable
column5: turn in a cover of “Games Without Frontiers” so obligatory it sounds like they changed their minds and decided not to participate after all. It lacks the earth-rattling pomp of their original material and
column6: worse
column7: the sharp derision of Gabriel’s 1980 version. On the other hand
column8: you can’t fault the match of Randy Newman with “Big Time”
column9: off Gabriel’s 1986 album So. It’s so perfect I’m surprised it hasn’t happened already
column10: and Newman sings the line “My ass is getting bigger” like he wishes he’d written it himself. It’s too bad
column11: then
column12: that the production is so stiff
column13: ratcheted to rigid beats that constrict his vocals considerably. He sounds like he wants to cut loose and jazz the song up in the style of Mose Allison
column14: yet has to remind himself to adhere to the strict meter.

column1: Who knows how I’ll Scratch Yours would have sounded if it had been released as planned
column2: on schedule and with all artists amenable? Gabriel intended this pair of albums to be an exercise in mutual interpretation
column3: emphasizing not only the songwriting but the distinctive tics and traits an artist naturally brings to lyrics and melody. There’s something charming about the clunkiness of that concept
column4: especially the way it ignores the realities of dealing with artists (“like herding cats
column5: ” he told The Guardian) and releasing music in a digital era. As a double album
column6: Scratch might have produced something like an elaborate mixtape with originals on one side of the Maxell and covers on the other. In execution
column7: however
column8: I’ll Scratch Yours plays like another artifact of the 90s
column9: this one less fondly remembered. It's a tribute album-- or
column10: better yet
column11:
a self-tribute album. This is Gabriel scratching his own back.

It's been a while since Alexis Georgopoulos worked under his Arp moniker
column2: leaving three years trailing in the wake of his last full-length album
column3: The Soft Wave. He's worked in art and modern dance in the interim
column4: but Georgopoulos has clearly spent some time thinking about how to retool this project as well. The Soft Wave was all balmy synth textures and endlessly repeating figures
column5: sometimes lightly prickled by waves of bass and distorted guitar. Georgopoulos found his voice toward the close of that record
column6: forgoing his mostly instrumental work to deliver a pitch-perfect pastiche of Brian Eno's 70s vocal work on ""From a Balcony Overlooking the Sea"". Surprisingly
column7: it's a thread he picks at for the bulk of MORE
column8: settling into a more song-oriented incarnation of Arp that might cause people familiar with his older work to check the package to make sure it's not some other band.

column1: Where Georgopoulos has landed is somewhere in-between various strains of the British art school tradition
column2: where the mundane and the fantastic are equally enthralling. It's part Roxy Music sci-fi fantasia
column3: part Blur down-the-chip-shop scruffiness. Georgopoulos is interested in glamour for sure-- song titles here include ""High-Heeled Clouds"" and ""A Tiger in the Hall at Versailles""-- but it's a scruffy
column4: vaudevillian form of it. The sad
column5: clangorous end to ""Clouds"" feels like a paean to actors who couldn't quite make it
column6: to singers who had a shot at the big time and just fell short. It's heavy on pastiche
column7: but very well done at times. You won't hear a better piece of Eno worship than ""Judy Nylon"" this year. Even the title is wonderfully Eno-esque. It's too bad Georgopoulos waits until the closing track
column8: ""Persuasion""
column9: to get anywhere near the same sense of pop euphoria again.

column1: So there's a strong sense of someone not reaching particularly hard to get beyond their influences
column2: but even that takes on an appropriate hue as the album progresses. MORE edges into the feel of low-rent theater at times
column3: where the makeup starts to run under the lights
column4: where the performer on stage is revealed to be a fraud. Georgopoulos does a blues track and he calls it ""(MORE) BLUES"". He's emptied out pop and found a bunch of dead ends
column5: all circling back in on themselves. Still
column6: this isn't an exercise in the futility of writing this stuff in 2013; it's more like a light
column7: cheerful prod at the parameters of pop. Along the way we get plenty of ambient interludes
column8: hints of Brill Building pop
column9: a dose of Beatles-y goodness. There's a sense Georgopoulos isn't sure what Arp should be
column10: allowing him to resist being shaped
column11: packaged
column12: and neatly filed away.

column1: In among all the switching up there's a centerpiece to all of this
column2: if one can exist in such a baffling
column3: un-centered piece
column4: titled ""Gravity (For Charlemagne Palestine)""
column5: which is one-part Steve Reich repetitive build
column6: one-part Spiritualized-style astral gazing. Naturally
column7: going from that to the cheeky end-of-seaside-pier tracks takes some adjusting. But MORE is an album that takes some time to settle in
column8: to really get to grips with all its diverse tendencies. Already it feels like it could become a weightier work over time if Georgopoulos leaves all this behind and moves on elsewhere
column9: causing this album to perpetually spin in its own odd orbit. It's mostly a delight to return to
column10: with its misshapen ways sometimes working toward a bigger picture until Georgopoulos flushes it all down the u-bend via another baffling turn. Here he's got a musical outlet that's not defined at all
column11:
and that's a strange and occasionally beautiful thing.

My first proper exposure to UK death metal staples Grave Miasma came at one of the band’s first live performances. By 2009
column2: they had outgrown their original moniker (R.I.P. Goat Molestör) under which they’d released a now impossibly rare split with their spiritual brothers Necros Christos and made steady headway in underground circles beginning with 2003’s Ancient Barbaric Assault demo. That night
column3: smeared with black paint and clad in leather
column4: the four lads jammed into the dingy basement of a goth club in Birmingham alongside fellow UK extremists Cruciamentum (with whom they share members) and Scythian
column5: then proceeded to unleash hell. I was blown away then
column6: and now
column7: years later
column8: they’ve continued to impress not only me but the thousands of others who have found themselves captivated by the band’s almost uncanny knack for morbid metal of death. Profound Lore has been courting the quartet for years
column9: and are understandably chuffed to be co-releasing Grave Miasma’s debut LP
column10: shouldering the glorious burden with the band’s longtime allies Sepulchral Voice.

column1: Odori Sepulcrorum is the product of years of slow
column2: steady work. The band has been in no rush to toe death metal’s party line and bang out three releases a year. Rather
column3: they’ve chosen to approach this first full-length with extraordinary care and precision. It shows
column4: whether in the fluttering scales and fiery solo that distinguish “έσχατος”
column5: the eerie strangeness of album closer “Ossuary”
column6: or the ominous interlude that surfaces near the album’s end to ring in the serpentine sitar melody on “Seven Coils”. Vocalist and guitarist Y is of Israeli descent and has always harbored a keen interest in Middle Eastern music
column7: and the band’s unorthodox treatment of those ancient scales alongside various traditional and unorthodox instruments slightly echoes Necros Christos’ approach (though is conducted with a considerably lighter touch). Hammond organ
column8: Tibetan gongs
column9: flute
column10: and the aforementioned sitar are woven into the songs themselves rather than isolated into interludes or standout passages
column11: and lend an air of otherworldly evil to what might otherwise seem as standard compositions at first glance. Of all the current death metal bands clamoring for recognition
column12: Grave Miasma certainly deserve a deeper look. There is more to them than what they may initially seem.

column1: A reverence for the theory and practice of death imbues the band’s aesthetic and presentation
column2: channeling Teitanblood and Dead Congregation as often as they emulate Drowned or Morbid Angel. Occult leanings are nothing new in this arena
column3: but Grave Miasma take their studies seriously
column4: littering their songs with arcane references and esoteric symbolism as well as the expected odes to decay and damnation. The recording is drenched in delay and reverb
column5: summoning up a suffocating black fog of atmosphere to envelop the clever arrangements and dynamic tempos
column6: and drummer D (Y's brother
column7: who's also in Adorior and Cruciamentum) brings the songs to life with his inventive
column8: powerful arrangements. Searing guitar work from Deströyer 666 & Cruciamentum shredder R blazes atop A’s subterranean death grooves and tears through the vocalist’s rumbling
column9: guttural invocations. Despite the sonic extremity on display
column10: the songs themselves are catchy and invite a visceral reaction-- I dare you to listen to this without nodding along to the burly mid-tempo riff on “Ascension Eye”. When witnessed live
column11: the reaction becomes more violent.

column1: The unavoidable truth is that while many of the modern death metal bands have carried on plugging away
column2: dredging up bargain basement Azagthoth riffs
column3: and listening to Onward to Golgotha on repeat
column4: these four Englishmen have focused their energies into creating something that is
column5: simply
column6: better. The quality of songwriting found on Odori Sepulcrorum stands a considerable height above every other death metal album released this year
column7:
and has cemented its creators’ fate as one of the genre’s most important new bands.

"|18394.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18394-grave-miasma-odori-sepulcrorum/|8.0|Kim Kelly

""They don't know the struggles that she was raised with... so shut the fuck up
column2: Syd tha Kyd sang last year on ""She DGAF"" with the sort of middle-finger-up irreverence often found in the music of her crew Odd Future. It was one of the few moments on the Internet's Purple Naked Ladies where you could draw a direct line from the bubbling neo-soul of Syd and Matt Martians to the rest of Odd Future. Outside of a few appearances from Left Brain and Mike G-- the latter of which Syd has produced for in the past-- Purple Naked Ladies felt largely disconnected from the entire OFWGKTA oeuvre
column3: the controversial collective mentioned more out of obligation than because of any musical or ideological kinship. On their sophomore album
column4: Feel Good
column5: the Internet continue along this path
column6: sharpening their songwriting and slowly reigning in their propensity to wander.

column1: The biggest leap forward is made by Syd herself-- where in the past she would sometimes disappear into her surroundings she now takes center stage with confidence
column2: her down pillow-soft vocals claiming the spotlight with an easy swagger. Her voice is still a delicate thing that sounds like it could blow away given the right gust
column3: but it's able to pull off things it wasn't capable of before: the sensual come-ons of ""Don'tcha"" require a self-assurance Syd hadn't quite developed yet on Purple Naked Ladies
column4: and she injects ""Shadow Dance"" with a been-here-before poise of someone at least a decade her senior.

column1: She's writing hookier songs
column2: too. ""Sunset"" unfurls with precision
column3: moments of interest arriving at a steady and consistent clip
column4: whether it's a switch-up in the track's loping groove or a colorful melodic run from Syd. Elsewhere
column5: ""Runnin'"" finds its sweet spot early on and then spends the rest of its duration playing around with the angle and strength of the light being shone at it. And although the Internet are still interested primarily in fusing the proggier elements of experimental jazz with the patient warmth of neo-soul
column6: there are fewer moments here that'll have you glancing at your watch
column7: an occurrence that happened a little too often on their debut.

column1: But while Feel Good finds the Internet latching onto hooks with greater frequency
column2: they haven't completely excised their tendency to meander into jam session territory where the music loses most of the direction. The album is never aimless-- they always succeed in setting a pleasant
column3: vibe-heavy atmosphere where detours are allowed and exploration is encouraged-- but at times it does feel like the Internet still haven't figured out how to identify what to keep and what to leave out.

column1: There's a proficiency at work on Feel Good that's undeniably impressive-- it's an album full of musicians who can play and they approach this stuff with an endearing alacrity and a willingness to let Syd do more this time around that will pay dividends on future records. She's still got room to improve where lyrics are concerned
column2: with generic clunkers such as ""I'm a fiend for your attention"" and ""You're beautiful
column3: you brighten up my day"" exposing her as the fresh-faced 21-year-old she is. But an incremental improvement is still improvement
column4: and Feel Good makes a good case that Syd
column5: like her pals Tyler and Earl
column6:
isn't going anywhere.

column1: That's okay: Loneliness

column5: hi-hats-- then what was. Nothing Was the Same is Drake and 40's most audacious experiment yet in how far inward they can push their sound; a lot of the album sounds like a black hole of all 40's previous productions being sucked into the center. Song-to-song transitions

column1: There is no uncomplicated forward motion in Drake songs; usually one small element worms forward while everything sits around it

column3: complicated claiming of Houston on Nothing

column1: The only thing tumbling endlessly forward

It felt like only a matter of time before Frankie Rose evolved from a bright light in New York indie rock to a legitimate star and unsurprisingly
column3: it happened on last year’s Interstellar
column4: the first album attributed to her and her alone. The surprising part was how she shifted from the more character-driven garage-rock she helped create with Dum Dum Girls
column5: Vivian Girls
column6: and the Outs to romanticized
column7: Reagan-era dream-pop
column8: a genre that all but requires putting form before flair (see also: DIIV
column9: Wild Nothing
column10: Lotus Plaza). The main lyric in the chorus of Interstellar highlight “Know Me” actually went “don’t know me
column11: ” which felt apt for a record with a sharp and subtly diverse array of songs that revealed the range of Rose’s talent but not much about herself. Unfortunately
column12: by making an exact replica of Interstellar minus the sharp and subtly diverse array of songs
column13: Herein Wild reveals the limitations of that range while turning its predecessor’s personality void from a cost of doing business into a serious liability.

column1: It’s futile to listen to Herein Wild without succumbing the urge to compare it to its predecessor; in fact
column2: the sequencing is so similar that it damn near dares you to do so on a track-by-track basis. As with “Interstellar”
column3: the leadoff here boasts a scene-chewing verse where Rose sings with the timbre of a touchtone phone before an anticipatory
column4: on-the-one bass-drum thump guides her out of the vaporous reverb. Only you lose the knee-buckling dynamics of “Interstellar” and instead get a smooth ascent to one of Herein Wild’s 10 lilting and lightly pitched choruses. As with “Gospel/Grace”
column5: the third song here is sleek and silvery indie-pop
column6: but instead of flowing like liquid mercury like its Interstellar equivalent
column7: “Into the Blue” sits in place like a glob of puffy glitter paint. Herein Wild is
column8: once again
column9: identically bisected by a beatless vocal showcase; previously
column10: “Pair of Wings” wisely used Rose’s voice for texture
column11: looping and weaving soft and silken harmonies. “Cliffs As High” at least acknowledges a new influence in Björk by demonstrating a similar obsession with altitude and surprisingly angular melody. But it’s the exact opposite of “Hyperballad” in every conceivable way
column12: dozing off waiting for a more forceful vocalist who can counter its somnambulant string arrangement.

column1: We could seriously do this for all 10 songs
column2: but lead single “Sorrow” about sums up the disassociation between her ambitions to sound bigger and smaller (i.e.
column3: more ostensibly “personal”) at the same time. Ignore
column4: if you can
column5: how “Sorrow” has the same drum pattern as “Know Me”
column6: since that song pretty much nicked its own from the Cure’s “Close to Me”
column7: a sort of “Be My Baby” public domain entity for artists of this stripe. It’s also easy to condone the lyrics throughout Herein Wild trying to express more individual desires through the same water/dream/sky vocabulary that kept Interstellar so purposefully vague. More important is how “Sorrow” gives you an idea of what Rose meant when discussing the influence of film soundtracks on Herein Wild
column8: in that there are real strings rather than synthesizers and songs not entirely indebted to strict verse/chorus structure. Yet the added orchestration adds bulk rather than depth; the strings arrive exactly when you’d expect and add another layer of syrupy sheen rather than counterpoint
column9: the bridge doesn’t introduce any new melody or dynamic shift and the fake fade-out just kills time.

column1: The misallocation of resources is even more pronounced when Rose tries to hearken back to Interstellar’s rawest rock song (“Night Swim”). “The Depths” makes a literal callback with its introductory lyric (“swimming across the water”)
column2: and its murky
column3: bass-driven arrangement at least recalls a different iteration of the Cure (Pornography rather than Head on the Door). But even when it tries to menace
column4: the overwhelming takeaway from Herein Wild is just how edgeless it is
column5: bearing the consistency
column6: texture and sickly sweetness of a circus peanut.

column1: It’s not like Frankie Rose forgot how to write a catchy song and there are enough here where you wonder if it would be heard as “promising
column2: ” had it come from a new band as opposed to someone more familiar. But that’s the paradox of Herein Wild: it might be subject to less scrutiny had it not followed Interstellar
column3: but then again
column4: it might not be subject to scrutiny at all
column5: and simply filed away with any other competent and unexceptional dream-pop. Besides
column6: what’s the point of pretending Interstellar doesn’t exist when Herein Wild does the exact opposite? As the saying goes
column7:
the strict imitation of Herein Wild sincerely flatters its predecessor; it just doesn’t do the same for the person who made it.

Ariana Grande
column2: a teenage actress turned singer

column1: That’s no small statement

column4: opting for a 90s hip-hop soul vibe that awkwardly sits with the more doo-wop-indebted songwriting. Second single “Baby I” is most representative of where Grande is at this stage in her career. It’s a hodgepodge of familiar clichés

Colonial Patterns is a fine album title
column2: suggesting so much yet giving little away. Read it one way and it's an allusion to the arrogance that nations are doomed to repeat. Glance again and it conjures up the lines that such behavior razes
column3: replaces
column4: and retraces on the land. Both readings reverberate throughout Kansas City producer Brian Leeds’ debut album as Huerco S. It follows a handful of 12”s and cassettes on exemplary small labels from both sides of the Atlantic-- including Opal Tapes and Future Times-- and sounds like the work of an artist hitting his stride
column5: rather than one making his first big statement.

column1: Leeds’ focus is the hidden histories of his homeland in the American midwest. He signposts as much with titles like “Quivira” named for a mythical place “discovered” by a Spanish explorer in the 16th century
column2: “Canticoy”
column3: a word of Native American origin that means a lively social gathering
column4: and “Monks Mound (Arcology)”
column5: which is an ancient earthwork in Illinois. References aside
column6: his music is heavy with layers
column7: symbols
column8: and signals. Form wise
column9: he takes futurism’s theme tune-- techno-- and filters it through yesterday’s technology: cassettes
column10: synths
column11: and cheap software. The ensuing collision of temporal zones creates a bewildering
column12: all-encompassing present
column13: which might be why Colonial Patterns presents a soundtrack for both blunting jet lag and long road trips in which the landscape is continuously cut and framed by the windshield window.

column1: “Plucked from the Ground
column2: Toward the Sun” moves like cloud formations
column3: calling to mind school science classes and the water cycle chart that detailed water’s cyclic shapeshifting from evaporation to precipitation. “Skug Commune” sounds like a forgotten quiet storm song trying to break through a broken transistor radio
column4: or a conversation half lost down a faulty line
column5: while the raw metallic percussion of “Quivira” evokes an image of acid rain falling on aluminum cutlery.

column1: There are a number of contrasts and conflicts between the natural and manmade world. “'Iińzhiid” laps and rolls like water
column2: its rhythms reflecting and refracting into an infinite horizon. On “Struck with Deer Lungs”
column3: the circling sub-bass turns with the exhausted pallor of an ancient ceiling fan. Lead single “Prinzif” is weighted with a creeping anxiety that smacks of Twin Peaks
column4: a not-so unusual relationship when you consider the cult TV show is probably the most successful illustration of contemporary culture’s fear of the ancient/(super)natural and modern/manmade worlds colliding.

column1: Of course
column2: Colonial Patterns does not exist in a vacuum. There is dialogue with Actress and Laurel Halo’s handling of techno as a form not immune to time
column3: one that can disintegrate just like the vast metropolises that inspired it
column4: leaving fragments that distill into something new once again. Oneohtrix Point Never's Replica and Forest Swords’ Engravings are also relatives
column5: for their exploration of the nature of memory and excavation of history respectively. Like his contemporaries
column6: Huerco S. seeks to unearth new languages-- trace new patterns-- within established musical world orders. In his hands
column7:
techno is a folk music in the traditional sense: a music that carries remnants of the past into the future. The final track “Angel (Phase)” is both culmination and affirmation of his archaeological digs: a vision of an ancient ambient techno gathering bathed in campfire light and dreaming into the night.

Album covers can hold higher
column2: non-decorative meaning
column3: serving as windows into a record's sound. Applying this lens to Kingdoms

column5: yields an accurate portrait of the music it contained-- a set of glamorous
column6: stylish house lent a human touch by skillful deployment of vocal samples. But it was the cover's monochromatic nature

column10: ultra-melodic vocal dance music.

column1: Looking at his set of 2013 releases that followed
column2: including the singles SW9 and Jetée/Desire
column3: the differences are striking: the muted tones and symbols of wealth and gloss have been thrown out the window for oily splashes of rich color and crude
column4: swirling spray. These aesthetic choices mirror Norris' experimentation with new tones and textures
column5: and his new EP Stay/Trueis the fullest document of that experimentation thus far
column6: a five-track collection balancing the new murk and sprawl with melodic populism.

column1: The flag-bearer for said murk and sprawl is the quasi-title track ""Stay True""
column2: a seven-minute piece that unfolds slowly and deliberately rather than immediately exploding into ecstatic territory. Built around an arpeggiated synth spine and a shifting tapestry of hand-claps
column3: ""Stay True"" eschews a single
column4: sustained peak for something like a sine wave: it never quite reaches a euphoric climax
column5: but rewards patience in its slow development. It's quite unlike anything onKingdoms. Subsequent track ""Your Light"" opts for instant engagement
column6: but still surprises
column7: its distant
column8: ghost-in-the-machine beat springing to life with an analog crackle. Instead of opting for his standard sampling
column9: Norris lays down a vocoder-affected vocal that ripples through the song like a ribbon of caramel through a carton of chocolate ice cream.

column1: The EP's closer
column2: ""Together
column3: splits the difference between those two tracks-- warbling tones inhabiting a region between synth and vocal hang and drift over an ominous
column4: patchy chug built on a field recording. Norris also uses Stay/Trueto play with the EP's very structure
column5: reserving one track for analog release and another for digital release. The former
column6: ""Trust Me""
column7: is a traditionalist slice of soaring disco that bubbles and throbs around club queen hoots; the latter
column8: ""And Now""
column9: rises from forest floor roots into a straightforward dance-ready pulse augmented by twilit clicks and chirps.

column1: Each song mentioned above is tightly composed and endlessly replayable
column2: but they fail to address the issue lying at the heart ofStay/True: for all his skill
column3: Norris has yet to define a truly distinct voice. BothKingdomsand this EP are shot through with his appreciation for classic house
column4: and they're undeniably confident and comfortable; unfortunately
column5: coasting on comfort for too long tends to relegate artists to the middle of the pack. The small steps on Stay/Trueare steps in the right direction
column6: and his recent departure from a touring/session role with synth-pop duo La Roux to focus on Fort Romeau heralds a new depth of focus on the project. If Norris can continue the growth suggested on this stopgap release
column7:
his next effort could lift him to a new level of success.

Lou Barlow's best work comes after break-ups
column3: or when he's yearning for something he doesn't have. III
column4: the classic record he released in 1991 after being dismissed from Dinosaur Jr.
column5: remains his band's most intriguing balance of heartache
column6: anger
column7: gentleness
column8: and noise. That's partly because longtime co-pilot Jason Loewenstein had just joined the group and charismatic founding drummer Eric Gaffney was still in the fold
column9: but also because Barlow was fuming at J Mascis (""The Freed Pig"") and nurturing a brand new love with Kathleen Billus (""Perverted World
column10: ""Kath""). ""Kath"" in particular is one of Barlow's true classics
column11: and shows how heartache can inspire him. It's a fragile
column12: tense
column13: warped lo-fi love ballad for his then girlfriend
column14: whom he went on to marry.

column1: That marriage has since ended
column2: and Barlow's been living with a new girlfriend for almost a year. Perhaps the new relationship has something to do with the general calm and upbeat happiness of the self-recorded/self-produced Defend Yourself
column3: the first Sebadoh full-length in 14 years and
column4: outside of the five-song Secret EP released earlier in 2013

column8: he's joined again by Loewenstein and ex-Fiery Furnaces drummer Bob D'Amico
column9: who came on board in 2012

column1: As on past Sebadoh records
column2: Barlow's material remains the real focus
column3: though he seems oddly distant. Even when he's singing about subject matter as intimate as the fear and pain of watching kids grow up and say goodbye on the catchy ""State of Mine""
column4: there's not much of a spark beyond the bounce of the backing music. Something he was great at during the band's stellar 90s run was wearing emotion in his vocal tone: you could feel the pain or elation in his voice
column5: even if you weren't paying attention to the words. On III's ""Renaissance Man""
column6: he sang
column7: ""Violence is cool/ One of two things real
column8: and you could tell he meant it. Here
column9: there are no jarring moments-- the collection lacks fight. Across the board
column10: the vocal lines are mostly forgettable
column11: and the singing's flat.

column1: Barlow once had a knack for tossing off instant indie rock classics
column2: like Bubble & Scrape's ""Soul and Fire"" and ""Cliché""
column3: Bakesale's ""Magnet's Coil""
column4: ""Not a Friend""
column5: and ""Skull""
column6: or Harmacy's ""On Fire"". On first listen
column7: you knew these were special
column8: even when they were understated. Loewenstein
column9: on the other hand
column10: though he's lodged memorable songs over the years
column11: has never been as consistent a songwriter. His primary contribution
column12: similar to Barlow on the Dinosaur records
column13: has been to serve as a dynamic and textural contrast. But on Defend Yourself
column14: outside of the ballads
column15: Barlow and Loewenstein's work tends to bleed together with little to distinguish them
column16: which makes the record feel longer than it is. Loewenstein's songs like the angular
column17: plodding ""Beat"" and ""Defend Yr Self"" are bland 90s college rock at best; his countrified rockers (""Final Days""
column18: ""Inquiries"") come off like neutered Drive-By Truckers.

column1: Barlow manages a few strong moments
column2: like opener ""I Will""
column3: a song that feels like it could last. It resonates in part because of its directness; this time it's Barlow who's leaving
column4: and he's proud of finally taking charge: ""Someone else/ Has found her way into my soul/ Things have changed/ No longer need to be with you."" The fear of leaving he's shown on past Sebadoh (and Dinosaur) albums is replaced with resolve; it's kind of like seeing Hamlet finally take action
column5: and it's a satisfying
column6: bloody moment. But it's also an exception. On the whole
column7: Barlow's songs on Defend Yourself sound self-satisfied
column8: with an almost embarrassing ""I'm doing this for me"" gloat to them.

column1: When I saw Sebadoh live in 1991 at Maxwell's
column2: in support of III
column3: Barlow was in rare form
column4: playing taped gags on a boombox between songs: bits that made fun of Dinosaur
column5: J Mascis
column6: indie rock
column7: Sebadoh themselves. It felt like therapy and catharsis. It felt punk. Most importantly
column8: it felt necessary. Naturally
column9: Sebadoh grew up and calmed down a little during their Sub Pop years
column10: but that progression made sense (especially after Gaffney left in 1994)
column11: and they were rarely boring. The best that can be said of Defend Yourself is that it isn't embarrassing; they didn't lose the plot like the Pixies

column13:
which is just about the worst thing you can say about this band.

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/19687/homepage_large.dae9c3c6.jpg|Take Me to the Land of Hell|28001.0|Yoko Ono Plastic Ono Band|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Chimera']|2013-09-20 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:52:51.691626|"

Yoko Ono turned 80 this year
column2: but on Take Me to the Land of Hell she barely sounds out of her 20s. This is another album billed to the Plastic Ono Band following the revival of that name with 2009's excellent Between My Head and the Sky
column3: although the lineup remains thrillingly fluid. We get a return of sorts of Beastie Boys Mike D and Ad-Rock
column4: plus supplementary work from tUnE-yArDs
column5: Nels Cline
column6: and ?uestlove among others. There's even room for Lenny Kravitz. Steering the ship alongside Ono are Sean Lennon
column7: Cornelius
column8: and Cibo Matto's Yuka Honda
column9: with the latter clearly exerting a strong influence over the blaze of color that streaks through its 13 songs. Honda and Ono are a great match
column10: both clearly in love with bringing whimsical touches to their music
column11: both enviably adept at bridging the divide between the sublime and the ridiculous.

column1: Take Me to the Land of Hell is unmistakably a party album
column2: albeit one pierced by familiar anti-war and pro-peace fascinations. Ono's nothing if not consistent
column3: leaving little doubt about her motivations throughout
column4: principally because she spends a decent amount of time demonstrating how she cares little for the vagaries of metaphor. ""Bad Dancer"" is simply about how she's a bad dancer
column5: something that causes her to collapse into giggles at one point. The track times are often brief
column6: causing the songs to resemble little insights into Ono's thought process
column7: delivered with the saddened glow of a torch singer (""There's No Goodbye Between Us"") or diverting into spoken-word passages strung across raging
column8: Zappa-style funk workouts (""7th Floor""). Sometimes all those tendencies get mixed up into one song; ""Cheshire Cat Cry"" is a standout
column9: full of stop-the-violence lyrics
column10: big soloing (presumably from Lennon)
column11: and spiraling 70s Moog twists.

column1: The sheer amount of guests and musical digressions makes the overall focus blur on occasion-- the thumpingly trad guitar grind of ""N.Y. Noodle Town"" causes the buildup of energy to dissipate drastically
column2: but there's a more considered and quite beautiful comedown moment in the string-laden title track that follows. Something this record does a little better than Between My Head and the Sky is show off Ono the musical omnivore
column3: shifting across multiple disciplines
column4: demonstrating how divergent universes are not quite so different after all. There are showtunes melting into trip-hop then segueing into avant rock. In Ono's world there are no boundaries between styles
column5: just natural pathways leading from one to the other. There's a ton of cultural clutter here
column6: but in a sense there ought to be. After spending so long hoovering up the arts
column7: Ono spits it all out in a glorious mess
column8: leaving her listeners to sift through the debris.

column1: Like most records that lack a central stylistic thrust
column2: Take Me to the Land of Hell often resembles a great collection of tracks instead of a coherent overall work. Indeed
column3: this album was premiered track-by-track on Ono's website prior to its release
column4: which suggests that someone behind it felt some hand-holding was necessary instead of dumping the whole album out at once. It takes an effort to reach the spot where it sinks in as an overarching piece
column5: but that ties back to more challenging Ono musical projects
column6: where time and patience are key elements in the listening process. For ""Moonbeams"" she even gets her wail on
column7: making it ache as hard as the spread of a dull blue bruise. It's there that Ono still performs most effectively
column8: using tone and gesture to say far more than most of her straight ""message"" songs. In among the ebullient atmosphere of this record
column9: there's a voice in there that says: ""I hurt
column10:
too.""

"|18494.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18494-yoko-ono-plastic-ono-band-take-me-to-the-land-of-hell/|7.0|Nick Neyland

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/19762/homepage_large.191a51e7.jpg|Coup d'Etat|31688.0|G-Dragon|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['YG']|2013-09-20 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:52:52.205291|"

The Korean pop star Kwon Ji-yong-- best known as G-Dragon-- is such a force at home that six tracks from his new solo album Coup d’Etat
column2: released earlier this month
column3: have already cracked the country’s top 10. Ji-yong
column4: a national figure since rising to prominence in the enormously popular and quite good Korean boy band Big Bang
column5: has been fleshing out his solo agenda
column6: which so far has seen 2009’s so-so solo debut Heartbreaker and the more exploratory 2012 EP One of a Kind. (Setting up a career trajectory not unlike that of Justin Timberlake
column7: many have noted.) Both sold extremely well-- at this point
column8: G-Dragon was pretty much just breaking records set earlier by G-Dragon-- but One of a Kind suggested a more frenetic and singular style
column9: best exemplified by the magnificent “Crayon”. That song represented a logical collision of fluorescent
column10: pound-the-alarm EDM
column11: the tomahawk chop chant
column12: and G-Dragon’s referential
column13: sharp rapping; every element throbbed with electricity. But it was an exception
column14: as the quality of his music hasn't always matched his innovations as a style icon. At the moment
column15: G-Dragon is getting more press for his swag than his sound.

column1: The highlights of G-Dragon’s new solo album Coup d’Etat remedy that
column2: but they only go so far. The guest spots-- Missy Elliott
column3: Baauer
column4: Sky Ferreira
column5: Diplo-- are obvious attempts at crossover that are alternately clumsy and clever. Where Missy raps with a sorely missed vitality on the exuberant “Niliria”
column6: a high-velocity flip of a traditional Korean folk song that also features playful rapping from G-Dragon
column7: the midtempo ballad “Black” features a listless Sky Ferreira providing a hook (“If you ask me what happiness is/ Your smile under the sun/ But I’m always on the run”) that feels stitched on and focus-grouped. (On the Korean version
column8: YG president Yang Hyun-suk replaced Ferreira with ascendant YG artist Jennie Kim). The title track wiggles and wobbles in all of the right places
column9: steadied by an assertive G-Dragon
column10: but the straight-up rap outro feels thin and overcooked. The overt genre experimentations that often characterize big K-pop records-- and also seen on Coup d'Etat-- feel skeletal in comparison to his work with YG’s big ticket act Big Bang. Though GD raps and sings throughout Coup d’Etat
column11: he sometimes finds himself in the uncomfortable middle
column12: with diminishing returns.

column1: Though Coup d’Etat feels forced in spots
column2: there are plenty of moments that deliver on G-Dragon’s superstar promise and capitalize on his enormous charisma. The joyous soccer chant of a single “Crooked” might just be a song you’ll play 30 times in a row and never play again
column3: but those 30 listens are pure serotonin-fueled bliss. And while “Niliria” isn’t as wild musically as a recent convention stop suggested
column4: it’s still a promising template where G-Dragon thrives
column5: he and his go-to producer Teddy spin traditional fare into a mutant banger. Lead single/lazer beam capsule “Go” approximates a “Crayon”-like frenzy
column6: and though it ends up being less memorable
column7: it illustrates how GD can carry a song on pure energy.

column1: With K-pop events selling out in major U.S. markets
column2: it’s arguable that this sphere doesn't need a “crossover” moment
column3: especially one this deliberate. (Coup d’Etat even cracked the Billboard 200 in spite of it’s two-part release and lack of a massive global single). So if you come to Coup d’Etat expecting some kind of revolution you'll be disappointed; it’s an intriguing listen
column4:
if not an important one.

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/19746/homepage_large.fa54ce15.jpg|Nommos|31665.0|Craig Leon|[]|0.0|0.0|1.0|['Superior Viaduct']|2013-09-20 00:00:00|1981|2016-06-11 16:52:52.683780|"

The name Craig Leon won’t be familiar to most music fans
column2: but take away the albums he recorded and our Top Albums of the 1970s list would look very different indeed. In the late 70s
column3: Leon produced crucial albums that defined the punk and new wave landscape for future generations
column4: ranging from the recorded debuts of Suicide and Blondie to the Ramones’ self-titled and Richard Hell & the Voidoids’ Blank Generation EP (as well as the early singles from DMZ
column5: Weirdoes and Zeros records released on Greg Shaw’s mighty Bomp! imprint). It’s easy to imagine that Leon brought a certain level of professionalism to these earliest punk sessions-- these days
column6: Leon mostly produces classical recordings for the likes of Luciano Pavarotti
column7: the London Symphony Orchestra and Joshua Bell-- but for his own debut album
column8: Nommos
column9: one can hear how the punks rubbed off on him.

column1: Originally released on John Fahey’s Takoma imprint in 1981
column2: Leon’s debut album joined ranks alongside such glorious catalog oddities as The Psychedelic Saxophone of Charlie Nothing
column3: Joesph Byrd’s Yankee Transcendoodle and Basho Sings!
column4: not to mention Fahey himself
column5: prone to play guitar atop audio collages of Tibetan monks and Nazi marches. And since Takoma is also regarded as the birthplace of placid New Age guitar
column6: releasing early albums from George Winston and Will Ackerman
column7: one can only imagine how Nommos made a certain type of music listener’s teeth grind
column8: to where the album stands alone as the most audacious and “punk” effort ever released on that label.

column1: So it makes sense that it's remained out of print for 30 years. Since then
column2: it’s found favor with Fall fans (Leon produced three early 90s Fall albums)
column3: fans of industrial and primitive electronic music
column4: techno enthusiasts as well as the recent spate of noise artists like Pete Swanson and Andy Stott who pair bracing noise to 4/4 pummel
column5: to where the album fetches ludicrous sums online. Booted in the past few years
column6: it now sees a more legitimate release. Opener “Ring With Three Concentric Discs” sets the album’s tone in a slightly schizophrenic manner. There’s a nerve-rattling metallic loop not unlike a broken fan belt thwacking aluminum siding but before long
column7: a gorgeous warbling synth melody drifts over the noise
column8: just smoothing down the sharp edges so that it might find good company alongside Cluster & Eno or Harald Grosskopf.

column1: It then leads into the polyrhythmic tock of “Donkeys Bearing Cups""
column2: which sounds like every hi-hat
column3: handclap
column4: snare
column5: rattle and thump was triggered by one of Kraftwerk’s showroom dummies: stiff yet strangely funky. About a minute in
column6: Leon introduces some unidentifiable noise that does its best anticipation of My Bloody Valentine
column7: at once blinding and body-melting. The title track again strikes a balance between skeletal beat and juxtaposed synth line that with its sense of strange negative space seems to be a subconscious template for the sorts of beats the Neptunes would craft two decades later for Hell Hath No Fury.

column1: The eleven-minute “Four Eyes To See The Afterlife” and seven-minute robotic rhumba of closer “She Wears A Hemispherical Skull Cap” comprise Nommos’s second half. And it’s here that the sparseness of Leon’s evocative metallic throbs slowly but surely steer the album away from merely being strange electronic music to drop into an adventurous DJ set into a more rarefied and unsettling space. “Afterlife” slowly develops from a near-empty clang to something approaching hypnosis. And when a female wail arises midway through the piece
column2: it turns into this anxious slice of early 80s electronic minimalism that has few peers. It’s a strain of minimal
column3:
nearly New Age music that-- rather than dissolve your anxieties away-- gives you the night creeps.

"|18553.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18553-craig-leon-nommos/|8.0|Andy Beta

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/19738/homepage_large.10a73701.jpg|Traditional Music of Notional Species Vol. I|31662.0|Rashad Becker|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Pan']|2013-09-20 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:52:53.195367|"

Rashad Becker makes a living with his ears. As engineer at Berlin’s Dubplates & Mastering
column2: he's mastered and cut a massive amount of dance
column3: electronic
column4: and experimental albums (his credits include at least 1200 records). He’s built a reputation for creating great-sounding vinyl
column5: so it’s no shock that the first record of his own music sounds great
column6: too. <i>Traditional Music of Notional Species
column7: Vol. 1 is thoroughly clear and precise. Everything on it is boldly legible
column8: and though there are tons of sounds intersecting and overlapping
column9: nothing is blurry. It’s as if Becker’s mastering his own brain and transferring what he hears in his head with little if any generational loss. It’s all pretty unpredictable
column10: sure
column11: but he’s always in control of his busy mix.

column1: What is surprising about Traditional Music is how singular it sounds. Becker has listened to so much music that it should be impossible for him not to copy some of it. And in fact there are moments that recall other artists (if you need a frame of reference
column2: think Black Dice without the beats
column3: or Fennesz with the serene poignancy replaced by an prankster-ish sense of play). But while you may have heard some of Becker’s sounds before
column4: the way he glues
column5: melts
column6: cuts
column7: layers
column8: and stretches them is unique. So is the effect of all that activity-- I rarely think of other music when I’m listening Traditional Music
column9: since the connections and juxtapositions Becker makes between the sounds themselves are more than enough to occupy my attention.

column1: Much of that attention-grab comes from how concrete Traditional Music sounds
column2: a rarity for work this abstract. There are few sounds here that you’d automatically associate with particular notes
column3: keys
column4: or instruments. But every moment feels real in a tangible
column5: three-dimensional way. Often music like Becker’s can seem dislocated from the material world
column6: cut off from any physical events that might have created the sounds. But Becker’s mix lives and breathes in pointed
column7: often hilarious detail. His sounds actually sound like things
column8: be it growling animals
column9: buzzing flies
column10: distant echoes
column11: whirring sirens
column12: or blipping radars.

column1: It’s up to you to choose which associations work
column2: which makes Traditional Music a kind of sonic mood ring. Think of one track as underwater rumblings and suddenly you can hear bubbles popping
column3: waves rolling
column4: and depth-charges rippling; think of another as a conversation and soon every sound takes on the inflections and innuendoes of human speech. Smartly
column5: Becker refrains from suggesting interpretations
column6: titling half of his tracks “Dances I-IV” and the other half “Themes I-IV”. He seems so thrilled with all the possibilities in sound creation that he’s happy to let you divine the meaning in his madness. The only thing he seems to want you to do is have fun figuring it all out.

column1: Given Becker’s background as an engineer
column2: it’s tempting to see Traditional Music as a kind of sound-effect library or technical demonstration disc
column3: and maybe it is. But if so
column4: it’s similar to Raymond Scott’s early electronic experiments
column5: which were lab exercises that produced engaging music. Scott tinkered with technology and pushed at the boundaries of the medium
column6: but he was out to do more than wow laymen with his toys. His musical sensibility and thrill of discovery birthed pieces that were compelling and often even moving
column7: regardless of how they were created. The same goes for Becker’s music. You can start by gawking at his surprising
column8: hilarious
column9: exhilarating sounds
column10: but you’ll likely find many more reasons to return to <i>Traditional Music of Notional Species
column11:
Vol 1.

"|18547.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18547-rashad-becker-traditional-music-of-notional-species-vol-i/|7.4|Marc Masters

London-based FKA twigs is a musician whose work runs in direct contrast to her interview persona. In a recent Rising feature she comes across as bubbly
column3: enthusiastic
column4: even a little goofy. This release
column5: a second four-track EP following her 2012 debut
column6: triggers a dual feeling of being buried in her suffering and a sense of relief that her music provides an outlet for it all. ""I guess I'm stuck with me
column7: she sighs on ""Water Me"". Comparisons to trip-hop have come quickly in twigs' short career
column8: most of them justified. It's closest to the moment where Tricky and Martina Topley-Bird gelled to wonderfully gloomy effect on 1995's Maxinquaye
column9: finding a perfect meeting point for weed-fuelled paranoia and all-consuming love. Yeezus collaborator Arca is on board as producer
column10: neatly building a bridge toward his own Tricky worship on tracks like ""2 Blunted"" from his UNO album Stretch 2. The level of detail is immense
column11: but never too fussy. Still
column12: the sense of space from EP1 is largely gone-- even in its sparsest moments this is a work that bears down on you
column13: barely allowing any room to breathe.

column1: Making disparate elements work together was a key tenet of trip-hop
column2: where a spacey quality was given room to flow amid beats that were more commonly associated with tightly wound hip-hop tracks. It's something twigs and Arca understand implicitly
column3: unlike the small legion of pallid genre clones that followed the Bristol triumvirate of Massive Attack
column4: Portishead
column5: and Tricky. So on ""How's That"" we get down-tuned slabs of noise and a sound that resembles a manic ping-pong ball layered under twigs' emoting. ""Water Me"" is built around a playful vocal sample that recalls Laurie Anderson's ""O Superman"". At times the most striking element is the oppressive bass that swells up
column6: bearing such weight it resembles someone dragging a gigantic rock through the desert. But twigs is the star here
column7: her voice rising and falling in unexpected places
column8: full of unique color
column9: sometimes pulling you in close even if the place she's in doesn’t feel like somewhere you necessarily want to be.

column1: Something striking about twigs' delivery is her desire to switch between the real and the unreal
column2: allowing her to open up a distance with her audience whenever she chooses. On ""Water Me"" she's coated in a thin layer of FX
column3: adding another alien layer to a music that already sounds positively extra-terrestrial. Then she’s slowly sliding down the wall again in ""Ultraviolet""
column4: beginning the song with a clutch of highly pitched lines perforated by an icy quiver. But there's always a sense of reticence
column5: of not letting you get too near her malaise-- a feeling emphasized when ""Ultraviolet"" slows down to total sludge at the midway point
column6: becoming less trip-hop and more trudge-pop. When the song bursts into something resembling a sunny R&B chorus it starts to wilt under the weight of too many good ideas stirred into the same pot. But she just about gets away with it
column7: primarily because the juxtaposition never feels forced.

column1: It's no surprise to discover that twigs is something of a loner
column2: as outlined in her Rising interview. Sometimes it's hard to imagine how the collaboration with Arca even works
column3: mainly because her music is so solitary. Twigs is only in her mid 20s
column4: but EP2 is the sound of someone who has lived a lifetime in their own head
column5: and is now letting it spill out publicly in its oddly open-yet-guarded way. There's a sense of watching her grow in public
column6: too. The progress since her first EP is strong-- if ""Breathe"" from that release resembled Topley-Bird's work with Tricky a little too closely
column7: here she's starting to shed those tendencies
column8: settling further into her own voice
column9: finding her own way around rhythms. Mostly there's a sense of poise amid the hurt and the distrust and the feelings of infatuation. Twigs' music taps into that moment of serenity that settles in when everything comes crashing down around you
column10:
where you accept your fate and just go with it to see where it might lead.

"|18590.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18590-twigs-ep2/|8.0|Nick Neyland

A small outburst of tie-loosening sounds scurry across the opening seconds of ""Walk Us Uptown""
column4: the first song on Elvis Costello and the Roots' Wise Up Ghost: We hear a few warm-up blurts
column5: studio cross-chatter
column6: and someone bringing up the volume on a laptop. When artists with historical baggage collaborate
column7: sometimes these little expectation-defusing gestures pop up
column8: a way to subtly prod reverent audiences into listening with new ears. <i>Bear with us
column9: we're just putting this together on the fly
column10: they say.

column1: For Wise Up Ghost
column2: it's a bit of a feint. Elvis Costello and the Roots are known for many things
column3: but neither are noted for ""relaxing."" And Wise Up Ghost
column4: the more you poke at it
column5: turns out to be one of the densely referential works in Costello's catalogue
column6: its lyrics a series of nested self-quotes that build a Chinese box out of his old records. The grooves
column7: from the Roots
column8: are loose
column9: muted
column10: and murky
column11: but the music glows with the unmistakable attention to detail and sense of history that the group can't help but bring to everything they touch. This isn't the sound of old masters getting loose
column12: in other words
column13: as much as lifelong A-students coasting a bit.

column1: Although the name on the sleeve is ""Elvis Costello and The Roots""
column2: Blackthought doesn't show up to rap
column3: even on the lean
column4: snapping ""Come the Meantimes"". No one raps at any point
column5: in fact
column6: which seems like a missed opportunity to make something unusual happen. The only real link to hip-hop comes from Costello's reflexive
column7: self-quoting urge: ""Wake Me Up"" and ""(She Might Be A) Grenade"" both reset lyrics from his 2004 album The Delivery Man
column8: while echoes of Punch the Clock's ""Pills & Soap"" flicker across ""Stick Out Your Tongue"". On the title track
column9: Costello's backup vocals call back to the earlier track ""Grenade""
column10: effectively creating an Escher staircase of himself. For Costello diehards
column11: the multiple callbacks trigger the same ""wait
column12: how many places do I know this lyric from?"" half-déjà vu that has always been one of hip-hop's deepest pleasures.

column1: At the record's low points
column2: though
column3: the ""legends spitballing"" vibe works against the material. Some of the songs are undercooked
column4: or at least they begin to feel that way as the grooves stretch out past five minutes. ""Stick Out Your Tongue""
column5: ""Come the Meantimes""
column6: and ""Wake Me Up"" linger longer than their thematic materials deserve
column7: and ""Can You Hear Me"" meanders through six minutes but feels nearly twice that length
column8: a collection of slapdash ideas with no audible commitment behind them.

column1: At their best
column2: both artists are great listeners
column3: capable of soaking up something they can use from new collaborators. On the slower
column4: quieter tracks
column5: you can hear Wise Up Ghost shade into something that sounds genuinely like a product of both sensibilities: ""Tripwire"" is a delicate 6/8 shuffle that Costello sings in his lovely high head voice
column6: the only time his voice sounds conventionally beautiful. ""If I Could Believe"" is one of those stunning
column7: rafter-reaching ballads Costello unfurls out of his dry
column8: unsentimental soul every few albums
column9: to remind us he can. On the left-field ""Cinco Minutos Con Vos""
column10: a series of disparate parts click together: Questlove's patient
column11: freakishly exact snare snaps
column12: horns punch soft notes
column13: strings churn
column14: Costello trades vocals with La Marisoul of  La Santa Cecilia
column15: and boom-- Elvis Costello and the Roots. It's not the kind of moment that will knock the long-since-formed careers of either out their deep
column16: geologic grooves
column17:
but it's a minor revelation nonetheless.

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/19689/homepage_large.3fee03ac.jpg|Imitations|2422.0|Mark Lanegan|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Vagrant']|2013-09-19 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:52:54.793955|"

On 2012’s Blues Funeral
column2: Mark Lanegan veered about as far from his best-known project
column3: Screaming Trees
column4: as anyone might have guessed he could. His voice hadn’t changed—it was the container it came in
column5: a synthesized and stylized sound that made Lanegan’s slurring
column6: bluesy purr seem like rotgut whiskey trapped in a crystal decanter. Since then
column7: Lanegan has circled closer to home; Black Pudding
column8: his collaboration earlier this year with Duke Garwood
column9: is characteristically rich and earthy
column10: and his vocals are almost entirely absent from the icy Like Clockwork by Queens of the Stone Age
column11: his steady side-gig over the past few years. But Lanegan’s latest full-length
column12: Imitations
column13: is more than a retreat into his cracked
column14: battered song-shell—it’s a session of musical regression therapy.

column1: That’s not a bad thing. Imitations is a self-effacingly-titled collection of cover songs
column2: with most of the originals culled from Lanegan’s childhood memories. There’s a yard-sale-LP aesthetic to choices like Frank Sinatra’s dulcet “Pretty Colors”-- which Lanegan nails via pinging harpsichord
column3: cascading arpeggios
column4: and a vocal interpolation that’s equal parts shimmering immersion and frigid distance-- and Nancy Sinatra’s James Bond theme
column5: “You Only Live Twice""
column6: whose folk-based arrangement owes more to Lee Hazlewood’s lesser-known rendition. No less than three songs by the late crooner Andy Williams-- “Solitaire
column7: ” “Lonely Street
column8: ” and “Autumn Leaves”-- are chosen
column9: and each is milked of its inherent melancholy. Lanegan wisely doesn’t try to deconstruct Williams’ buttery
column10: easy-listening delivery; instead
column11: he makes it chunky instead of smooth. And his tackling of “Mack the Knife” is audacious in more than concept; one of the most iconic songs of the 20th century is encased in a skeletal
column12: finger-picked hush. Lanegan’s vocal is so subtle it almost fades into the ether
column13: all softened consonants
column14: sanded syllables
column15: and sleepy humming. For a song with such a visceral lyric
column16: it’s a missed opportunity that Lanegan turns it into a lullaby.

column1: The nostalgia isn’t all Lawrence Welk-worthy. Half of Imitations is devoted to relatively newer artists-- the bridge being Gérard Manset. Lanegan’s faithful version of Manset’s spectral “Élégie Funèbre” sounds more like karaoke than a cover-- but it’s wholly redeemed by the fact that Lanegan rasping in French is one of the sexiest sounds the human nervous system could ever steep itself in. From there
column2: Imitations proceeds in time
column3: touching on versions of tunes by John Cale (“I’m Not The Loving Kind”)
column4: Nick Cave and the Bad Seeds (“Brompton Oratory”)
column5: Vern Gosdin (“She’s Gone”)
column6: and Lanegan’s partner in the Gutter Twins
column7: Greg Dulli (“Deepest Shade”). Of the four
column8: “I’m Not The Loving Kind” stands out—a celestial feat of cornball balladry that reconstitutes the freeze-dried heartache of Cale’s original.

column1: Imitation’s opening track spotlights Lanegan’s most contemporary muse: Chelsea Wolfe. The young singer-songwriter’s “Flatlands” is held tenderly in Lanegan’s lungs like an inhaled soul
column2: trickling out slowly through parched lips. As with the Manset cover
column3: the arrangement is nearly untouched; Wolfe’s nerve-wracked
column4: elegantly plucked plea for simplicity is honored in full
column5: even as Lanegan’s scorched-earth baritone devours all sentimentality
column6: muted as it is
column7: in an apocalyptic simmer. With Imitations
column8: Lanegan gives some of the best performances of his career. That he does so with someone else’s material only reinforces the journeyman ethos he’s extolled and embodied since Screaming Trees’ breakup in 2000. Even at the group’s outset in the 80s

0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/19748/homepage_large.0a7253cd.jpg|Return of the Silkie|29816.0|Carol Kleyn|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Drag City']|2013-09-19 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:52:55.333377|"

Between 1976 and 1983
column2: wayfaring West Coast harpist and vocalist Carol Kleyn released three albums on her own tiny Turtle Dove label. With a beatific spirit that seems sent directly from central casting and a nomadic history that includes Renaissance Festival performances and episodes of street busking
column3: Kleyn’s work eventually garnered a small but loyal following amongst fans of the era's private-press albums. Beginning with their 2011 reissue of her debut Love Has Made Me Stronger
column4: Drag City has been reissuing Kleyn’s albums one at a time and making them available in digital format for the first time. Her third album
column5: 1983’s Return of the Silkie
column6: might just be the best of three. A semi-concept album consisting solely of harp
column7: voice
column8: and the occasional bark from a distant harbor seal
column9: the album is at the very least the purest available distillation of her unique and memorable musical vision.

column1: As detailed in the album’s liner notes
column2: a silkie or selkie is a mythological half-human
column3: half-seal creature that appears frequently in the folklore of the Scottish and Irish islands. Time and again the songs on Return of the Silkie make allusion to these silkies
column4: and in Kleyn’s hands they come to serve as a symbol for man’s complicated relationship with the ocean and the natural world. A distinct sense of yearning courses through these songs
column5: a yearning (possibly from the POV of a silkie) for freedom and an escape from the modern world into the untouched paradise of nature. Throughout the album Kleyn sings about nature with a reverential passion that many artists reserve for religious hymns or romantic love songs
column6: balancing the tranquility of her gentle harp playing with ominous tidings for those who might seek to harm the natural environment.

column1: Engaging though the album can be
column2: suffice it to say this is a record without much potential crossover appeal. The notion of a female harpist singing pacific songs about nature and seal-women is likely something that either has some innate appeal for you or it doesn’t. Even for those of us with an avowed fondness for the once-lost albums of such folkie artists as Vashti Bunyan
column3: Linda Perhacs
column4: or Sibylle Baier
column5: Return of the Silkie can test one’s mettle. Kleyn’s simple
column6: direct lyrics can threaten to shift into trite post-hippie platitudes at a moment’s notice
column7: and in places her instrumental harp passages can border uncomfortably close to new age draftiness.

column1: For the most part
column2: however
column3: the clarity and simplicity of Kleyn’s music works in the album’s favor. Her second album
column4: 1980’s Takin’ the Time
column5: was recorded with a full band and produced with an FM-ready soft-rock polish that hasn’t allowed it to age particularly well. By stripping things back to just voice and harp
column6: Return of the Silkie has a much more organic
column7: out-of-time feel. The album was recorded close enough to the water in Laguna Beach that the barks of harbor seals can be heard in the background-- yet another of the album’s quirky little details that might serve as a litmus test to measure how jaded and/or grumpy a given listener might be. At any rate
column8: the album’s naturalistic production is a fine match for the effervescent likes of “Iaqua
column9: ” or the instrumental title track
column10: on which Kleyn’s harp notes effortlessly mimic the shimmer of sunlight and sea spray.

column1: The album’s most intriguing track is the one which deviates the furthest from its nature themes. “Hello Mister Drifter” details the meeting between a lonely young woman and a mysterious drifter in a fashion that manages to be at once poignant and unsettling. “I know that I’m ugly and that I’m just 13
column2: ” the song’s narrator sings to her new acquaintance
column3: “but I don’t think you care. You’ve got smiles for me and you.” Needless to say
column4: a song written in this vein today would almost certainly wind up as a dark cautionary tale
column5: but here it is treated with Kleyn’s typical breeziness and sunny good will
column6:
ending by all evidence with a budding new friendship between two lonely souls. It’s a track that serves as another small indicator of just how far removed Return of the Silkie is from the contemporary musical landscape. This peculiar sense of distance and otherness serves to summarize some of appeal of vintage private-press albums in general and helps to make Return of the Silkie the beguiling point of departure that it is.
