LA’s Friends of Friends has largely kept its stable to local artists
column2: and its core California constituents-- Shlohmo
column3: Salva
column4: Groundislava-- have carved out their own distinctive corner of the hip-hop influenced electronic music world. But last year
column5: the label added a release by Danish house producer Tomas Barfod to its catalog
column6: and 2013’s Show Me The Future compilations have seen Friends Of Friends expand outward in pretty much every geographical direction. Berlin-based Australian Kyson-- aka Jiam Kellet-Liew-- is their latest full signing.  Liew's debut album The Water’s Way has an exotic but familiar feel to it
column7: like the label's gone on vacation down under to find music that hews close to their established style but with a whole new set of sounds and ideas.

column1: Liew's work owes as much as to the more mawkish aspects of trip-hop and chillout as it does to
column2: say
column3: Shlohmo’s scorched naturescapes
column4: and like that producer
column5: he likes to blend more acoustic sounds with implacable electronic ones. Opener “We’ve Been Inside For Too Long” is a good barometer for the whole record; there’s no denying the appeal of its lapping ebb and flow
column6: but the pseudo-operatic vocal samples and world music touches could push it over the edge for some. Most of The Water’s Way has that same formula
column7: piling a bevy of sound effects and Orientalist-style instruments on gentle beats that are more anchoring than assertive. There are exceptions; “No Such Thing As Me” rides a slow-motion gallop to its climax
column8: while the jumble of “My Mother’s Eyes” recalls the early work of the percussion-obsessed Shigeto.

column1: If a sickly sweet sentimentality is at the heart of Liew's style
column2: it can work in his favor just as often as it works against him. “She Said To Me Quietly” and “How Long” both have unapologetically huge build-ups based off of driving melodies
column3: where he pours his energy into driving the tracks forward rather than dressing them up with ornate accoutrements. The way the central synth motif on “How Long” swells and eclipses everything else is downright thrilling on such a passive record-- it smoulders and overtakes like it’s trying to run the rest of the track into the ground
column4: a perfect centerpiece that keeps The Water’s Way from wafting away on its own pleasant breeze.

column1: Though a few of the tracks mold sampled vocals into Balam Acab-inspired cipher operas
column2: Liew separates himself from so many producers dealing with the same self-consciously pretty sounds by sticking mainly to his own voice. And while he’s not writing full-on verse-chorus-verse songs here
column3: these lead lines tend to give each track an indie-friendly structure
column4: something to follow along amidst all the wave-your-lighters-in-the-air swaying. There’s a polished
column5: almost Coldplay-esque sheen to his voice which could
column6: again
column7: turn potential listeners off: the chopped-up croon of “My Mother’s Eyes” definitely errs on the wrong side of maudlin
column8: but on “Missing Things” he moves closer to James Blake’s white boy soul.

column1: Like a good portion of the Friends Of Friends discography
column2: The Water’s Way is most concerned with cultivating its constant state of atmospheric beauty. It’s not always entirely clear what the record is trying to be-- there’s a big gulf between the delicately drifting opener and the straightforward and woodsy folk of closer “Shadows Cross”-- but it strikes a fine middle ground anyways. There's a little bit of newcomer syndrome when it comes to setting himself apart from the pack
column3: and his debut turns out to be a fine attempt that sometimes gets bogged down in its own heart-on-sleeve emotionality. But Kyson has the tools and the talent to dig himself out
column4:
and if nothing else The Water's Way reveals a promising addition to an already overcrowded sector of electronic music.

As the progenitors of last decade's indie-dance boom hit their “Now what?” years
column3: the definition for musical maturation stands to get a bit confused. Music that nods to a previous generation's styles also faces the pitfall of knowing how those styles ossified when their listenership aged-- a combination of more self-awareness and more conscious grabs for half-comfortable adaptation-- and artists are trying even more stringently to avoid it. Holy Ghost! appeared on the scene near the end of the DFA-dominated indie-house movement's first peak
column4: and managed to capture their stake in that scene with a couple fantastic releases (2007's “Hold On”; 2010's “Static on the Wire” EP) and an ensuing album that
column5: though slightly uneven
column6: pointed towards a promising future. Too bad that future was contingent on the party going on forever-- nowadays listeners who cut their teeth on that sometimes overamped mid-00s heyday would sooner prop up their feet than get up and move them.

column1: Naturally
column2: Holy Ghost!'s second album
column3: Dynamics
column4: addresses that condition by pulling at all the strings its title implies. Their brightest disco/house tendencies
column5: and the deep emotional highs that came with them

column7: where it could be drawn out after repeated listens; feelings that came across as insinuations at first gradually moved inescapably to the forefront. The songs here
column8: meanwhile
column9: lay it all out in detail from the start: late-night phone calls that feel like cheap stage productions in an attempt to scramble back to reconciliation (“Okay”)
column10: the summer-haze energy drain that keeps aspirations from going anywhere until anxiety sets in (“Dumb Disco Ideas”)
column11: the Bloomberg-era NYC party grind that's turned the Manhattan/outer borough clubhopper circuit into a two-way route (“Bridge and Tunnel”). This is a record that sounds like it's meant to express little more than what a drag it is to try and maintain that youthful energy in the danceclub world-- including from the music-wonk side
column12: if “Dance a Little Closer” is any indication (“And there'll be no big changes/ there'll be no asinine punchlines/ OK
column13: one's fine”).

column1: The obviousness of the lyrics isn't a huge problem. Cheap words sound like a million bucks with enough vision behind them
column2: but Holy Ghost!'s unfocused attention is so divided between a bunch of new musical ideas that getting something to click on all fronts is a rare occurrence. As singles-and-filler as Holy Ghost! seemed
column3: it did all fit together
column4: one or two tricks done appealingly rather than half a dozen that scatter across a wide-grouped target. Emerging out of the old Brooklynite neo-disco wheelhouse of six years ago into something transitional shouldn't have to mean Zeliging one's way through Aspartame Fleetwood Mac (“I Wanna Be Your Hand”)
column5: a strip-mall suburb of Phoenix (“Changing of the Guard”)
column6: or the overblown beach-cruiser bombast of late 80s AOR-pop ballads (“It Must Be the Weather”).

column1: So after throwing every kind of stylistic detour into the year-and-a-half recording process that eventually gave us Dynamics
column2: it's the stay-the-course dancefloor material that proves the most rewarding. It's definitely not as of a type as their previous synthpop-skewing material was-- “Bridge and Tunnel” is big-budget Italo a'la Kano

column5: and while half of the album feels overstuffed and overproduced
column6: that hugeness does them a favor when it's applied to the pure dance cuts. Frankel's voice is still distinct
column7: too-- clipped
column8: sawed-off
column9: and cool without being lifelessly aloof. (It helps when you can bring in Nancy Whang to push up the oomph on nearly half the tracks.) Unfortunately it's still too scattershot
column10: proof that too many ideas can be even more of a detriment than not enough. That latter scenario held back their early work a little
column11: but that's excusable; their first singles and the album that followed were the work of a band that was trying to figure out who they were. It's just a bit of a letdown to hear them
column12: more than five years into their career
column13:
not having entirely answered that question.

column2: demanding music could never be called casual. The fitful

it's hardly a stand-in for Flux Outside's pixelated weirdness.

Keep Shelly In Athens’ name is a pun on the Kypseli neighborhood in the Greek capital and their debut LP At Home often takes the tone of a homesick tour diary; you can’t help but feel that the album title is a wish or a mantra. And yet
column3: while I’m willing to admit that I’ve never been to Greece
column4: I have been to New York City
column5: and for all of its superficial hometown pride
column6: At Home actually suffers from the same criticisms as post-Giuliani Gotham: it wants to remind visitors of a cutting edge
column7: artistic vitality fostered in the 1980s while keeping the attendant danger at a very safe distance.

column1: At Home’s mid-fi synth production begs the usual descriptors: swooning
column2: soft-focus
column3: the sort of thing often considered “dream-pop” for the way it reminds people of the things they use to achieve a waking dream state: sex
column4: drugs
column5: druggy sex
column6: sexy drugs. But KSIA’s approach is staunchly risk-averse and gentrified. Sarah P’s delivery has the requisite breathiness and her words are suggestive
column7: though reverb always renders her as an observer rather than a participant. The only exception is an sparingly deployed distorted effect that makes her sound exactly like Karen O
column8: but despite its confrontational tone
column9: it’s just another obfuscation. Her partner RNR’s aesthetic is also a typical bedroom producer homebrew of smudge and sheen-- no texture here would be too radical or abrasive for any Cocteau Twins record despite its occasional nod towards harsher tones of post-dubstep or hip-hop. Nor would any retail manager in 2013 run afoul of their superiors if they played this during business hours.

column1: Which isn’t exactly a selling point
column2: since it’s hard to think of At Home outside the context of the dozens
column3: if not hundreds
column4: of aspiring
column5: wavy synth-pop duos that remind you why Purity Ring and CHVRCHES have shot up towards festival status in such a short time. They're the exceptions in a style where most bands barely even try to establish a distinct personality
column6: let alone write killer hooks. Certain production touches lend the songs on At Home variance from each other
column7: but not much KSIA can claim as their own. The possible Black Flag reference of “Room 14 (I’m Fine)” hints at punk ideals underneath a feathery
column8: Inc.-like guitar figure
column9: and the lyrics of “DIY” do the same
column10: though “you may dream of glory/ shabbiness is your story” isn’t the kind of mission statement that makes you go wild and spray paint the walls.

column1: At Home is more successful when the music tries to assume some kind of aggressiveness
column2: though the awkwardness presents its own set of problems. The heaving backbeat of opener “Time Only Exists To Betray Us” is neutralized by puffy reverb
column3: while “Higher” gets rudely punctuated by a doom metal riff and dancehall chatter. Whether the latter “works” or not feels like a moot point-- it’s exciting to hear KSIA try something that deigns for rudeness
column4: though its novelty depends on how long it’s been since you’ve listened to Salem. Same for “Madmen Love”
column5: whose juddering arrhythmia conjures an ambitious but ungainly Soundcloud remix of a recent Yeah Yeah Yeahs song before its sax-soaked
column6: arena-rock climax. Meanwhile
column7: a bluffer’s guide to the past three decades of dance-indebted
column8: record-collector indie-pop is formed by “Oostende”
column9: “Recollection” and “Flyway”
column10: respectively covering the 80s (Cocteau Twins) 90s (Saint Etienne) and 2000s (pick a chillwaver).

column1: It’s an impressive syllabus of influences
column2: but you figure At Home might appeal more to the extremely casual listener unfamiliar with all of the aforementioned. It’s an enjoyable and subtly diverse listen only if you give it your undivided attention. For all of their geographic namedrops
column3: Keep Shelly in Athens’ home is the Internet
column4: where a single referential connection can make you forget how you got there two minutes ago. It’s all obviously figurative
column5: but KSIA have built their rep not on touring but in the necessary manner to stay in our respective RSS feeds-- singles
column6: EPs
column7: compilations and remixes on top of remixes. But when all of their peers and collaborators are on a level playing field
column8: equally available to the listener
column9: does anything here inspire a conscious decision to listen to At Home instead? What have they done to distinguish themselves from Young Magic or IO ECHO or Pure Bathing Culture or Still Corners or I Break Horses or the Hundred in the Hands or any of the current bands acting as takers rather than givers in the synth-pop lineage? Is it just a matter of who gets heard first?  Maybe At Home isn’t so timid after all-- when so many bands do this
column10:
isn’t simply doing it with competence the riskiest thing possible?

The first thing you notice is that Bill Callahan is in no hurry. On ""The Sing""
column2: the ballad that opens his warm

column5: words roll by like cloud formations on a calm day: ""Drinking…while sleeping…strangers…unknowingly…keep me company."" And afterwards there's a pause as the line hovers there

column1: Call it naturalism

column3: Callahan has always been consumed by the natural world. To him
column4: nature is often a taunt
column5: a provocation
column6: a reminder of the smallness of human life. Although he is among music's most astute observers of human truth and absurdity
column7: in a Bill Callahan song
column8: being a person is often a wry
column9: cosmic joke. The sky can broadcast all the violently beautiful hues of
column10: oh
column11: say
column12: a late-summer sunset
column13: and what's the best we can do? ""Late Night With David Letterman"" (on Apocalypse's ""America!"") and radio interviews with Donald Sutherland (on Dream River's ""Winter Road"") and-- it's always implied
column14: with a meta-chuckle-- Bill Callahan records.

column1: Since 2007's Woke on a Whaleheart
column2: the first record released under his own name
column3: Callahan has moved counterclockwise to the rest of the world's spin. As life has become crowded with text
column4: Callahan has
column5: with each record
column6: become more laconic. As people have grown (ostensibly) more connected
column7: Callahan's records have increasingly embraced feelings of isolation. Those early Smog records
column8: with their aggressive textures and anarchic sneers
column9: thrashed in opposition to the outside world. Now Callahan sings like someone blissfully oblivious to its churn. ""I set my watch against the city clock
column10: he sang on the opening track of his stunning 2011 record Apocalypse
column11: chuckling with faint surprise. ""It was way off.""

column1: A quiet masterpiece
column2: Apocalypse seemed like a culmination of Callahan's career so far
column3: but it also had a feeling of finality to it. On <i>Dream River
column4: though
column5: the aesthetically restless Callahan has found a few new mountains to climb. He challenged himself to make a more subdued record where the only percussion comes from hand drums and brushes
column6: but he’s challenging himself thematically
column7: too. Dream River finds Callahan tackling a question that has haunted his music for decades: What happens if the guy who once declared
column8: ""Alone in my room I feel like such a part of the community"" makes a moving
column9: occasionally honest-to-god romantic record about the power of human connection?

column1: That line comes from ""Ex-Con""
column2: a song found on Smog's 1997 album <i>Red Apple Falls
column3: and it's striking to consider how much has changed in the years since. Callahan's baritone has lowered about an octave; he used to sing through his nose but now his voice (a much richer and more resonant instrument) seems to come direct from the murkiest depths of his lungs. His arrangements have also grown more sparse
column4: and on all fronts he’s learned how to say more with less. It’s one of many paradoxes in Callahan’s music
column5: that in abandoning a method of singing more traditionally considered “expressive
column6: ” he's actually learned how to express more. His delivery is animated by the subtlety of tiny gestures
column7: which is why although there are maybe a total of three words on Dream River that a third-grader would stumble over
column8: its musings still feel profound. “The Sing” boasts one of the album’s most undeniably quotable lines-- “The only words I’ve said today are ‘beer’/ And ‘thank you’”-- but the real joy comes from hearing him mutter
column9: “Beer” and “Thank you” a couple of times afterwards
column10: each time intoning it with an almost imperceptible change in tone. Somehow
column11: each “beer” contains multitudes.

column1: Callahan's learned to use negative space so well that there's even poetry in the pauses. Take ""Summer Painter""
column2: an instant addition to his canon of great songs; for what else can be said of a song that begins
column3: “I painted names on boats…/ For a summer” and then unfurls
column4: glacially
column5: like an elliptical yarn spun by a leathery old shanty-dweller who has
column6: without question
column7: seen some shit. Callahan’s learned how to use his voice like a camera (""When the hurricane hit some found it suspicious/ That I’d just since left the frame"")
column8: and here he’s shooting a wryly funny mock-epic. “Rich man’s folly and poor man’s dream
column9: ” he sings
column10: and then pauses for effect
column11: “I painted these.” It’s a masterful little zoom-out
column12: and it only heightens the sense that Callahan’s playing director here
column13: a feeling furthered by guitarist Matt Kinsey’s torrential freak-out when a storm rolls in.

column1: The grandeur
column2: though
column3: is short-lived
column4: and that’s the most profound and affecting thing about Dream River. At its core
column5: this is a record about accepting and even embracing the smallness of human life
column6: and how difficult that can be
column7: given our damnably innate sense of adventure
column8: ambition
column9: and restlessness. For at least four minutes
column10: though
column11: Callahan finds peace and stillness in the form of “Small Plane”. The song is a quiet miracle; an afternoon epiphany told in dream logic and simple language to no one
column12: because his only companion is taking a nap. And yet
column13: what a perfect moment to take stock of things: “I really am a lucky man/ Flying this small plane.” It’s a testament to simplicity

column15: prismatic delivery

column1: To call Dream River “content” or “serene” feels wrong
column2: because there’s still a pang of longing to it. But in all of this album's searching
column3: it does bring back one hopeful find: that maybe the closest we can come to the thrill of wilderness is the adventure of being with another person. “I see the true spring is in you
column4: ” he sings at one point
column5: and it might just be the happiest moment on the record. For once he’s not wishing he were an eagle or a tempest or a sunset. He is just Bill Callahan
column6: flying his small plane with a co-pilot by his side
column7: and for the moment at least
column8:
that is enough.

The nice thing about being in a hardcore band named Modern Life Is War is that you’re guaranteed relevancy pretty much in perpetuity. It just so happens the current moment is an exceedingly good one for the Marshalltown
column2: Iowa quintet to reconvene after a five-year hiatus: the influence of their LPs (particularly 2005’s high watermark Witness) has manifested in very successful bands like Defeater and Touche Amore
column3: while their new label Deathwish
column4: Inc. has given music of this stripe more crossover exposure than it might have received in years previous. But their name is something of a feint: Modern Life Is War isn’t an explicitly political punk band
column5: nor are they interested in disseminating big statements. Fever Hunting is a record of intense
column6: personal reckoning
column7: but one that doesn’t waste your time with concerns that are anything less than universal.

column1: There’s not a lot of room for bullshit when you’re trying to cram five years worth of life experience into 27 minutes
column2: and Fever Hunting doesn’t even have time for the kind of frills that define genre. If you come in looking for a strict hardcore record
column3: “Old Fears
column4: New Frontiers” is a hell of an entry point
column5: a one-minute repetition of the title that lets you know the source material for every song going forward. There are plenty of bracing group chants to come
column6: though MLIW aren’t as blunt elsewhere-- “Chasing My Tail” becomes Fever Hunting’s most galvanizing moment only after three minutes of beatless feedack and erratic guitar abuse
column7: while the the title track releases its tendon-straining tension by coming to a full stop of shrieking feedback. The songs on Fever Hunting always ends up sounding anthemic
column8: and while it might be a stretch to call it “melodic hardcore
column9: ” Jeff Eaton‘s jagged yells are shaped into knowable contours.

column1: And if you expect puritanical punk
column2: well
column3: MLIW certainly stand by the values. But Fever Hunting is not “raw
column4: ” nor is meant as replacement for shows like these. This is one of the cleanest and best-recorded punk records of the year; as with most productions from Converge’s Kurt Ballou
column5: the hard work was done before entering the studio and his job is to make sure that the listener hears all of it. All that effort is worth it just for the snare drum in “Health
column6: Wealth & Peace”
column7: as the precision and force you hear in each crack is something like watching Miguel Cabrera take batting practice. The sonic clarity gives the subtle variations of Fever Hunting a chance to expose themselves and this is particularly true of the relative moments of levity-- the part where a power chord breakdown in “Health
column8: Wealth & Peace” exposes itself as a 12-bar blues riff
column9: the spirited coed vocals in “Cracked Sidewalk Surfer”
column10: “Nightcrawler” taking a detour into loping
column11: California skate-rock.

column1: While accessible
column2: Fever Hunting is also deadly fucking serious. The “ballad” here is called “Brothers in Arms Forever”
column3: and Eaton yearns for nothing short of true unconditional love
column4: barking “when I saw you after you got sick
column5: I got choked up!!!!” the same way he sings lines like “I suspected you’ve been infected/ by the diseased discharge of the media cunt.” MLIW are a band obsessed with fidelity in both sound and in philosophy and it’s nothing you haven’t heard on a punk rock record before
column6: a tautological code where you have to stay true to the truth and that modern life is actually ancient warfare. When Eaton shouts down “petty politics and bullshit party lines
column7: ” it’s not in reference to Washington
column8: D.C. or some other faroff conglomerate
column9: but the divisiveness prevalent at the water cooler and rock club
column10: hand-to-hand combat for limited resources that turn people into emotional savages.

column1: Fortunately
column2: MLIW are righteous without crossing into self-righteousness; “Media Cunt” and “Blind Are Breeding” are proof enough that Eaton can take a blowtorch to strawmen and make it sound like a truly necessary act. But like a miniature version of Wrens’ The Meadowlands
column3: Fever Hunting allows you to cheat a bit and use the contextual clues to see a blue collar
column4: workingman’s dread to these songs-- a band like Modern Life Is War takes a lot physical and emotional commitment
column5: especially for guys in their early 30s. The title track and “Dark Water”

column9: but not big enough to live off of

column1: From the sound of things
column2: it’s not just a means of venting but a way of hashing out ways to simplify one’s daily existence. For the most part

column6: but their absence is more notable when he barks “Your time is precious and it’s slipping away/ your friends are precious and they’re slipping away.” The important thing is that MLIW are never preachy; the last thing Eaton wants is to have punk music be used as an another means of separating people into classes. Befitting a record that begins with “Old Fears
column7: New Frontiers” and ends with “Find A Way”
column8: Fever Hunting is guided by a pragmatic hope
column9: put into action through gratitude and reaching your hand out. In “Currency”

Eaton admits “Growing up was confusing...I might not have made it all alone/ so I thank you if you spoke to me/ or you listened.” “I thank you” is underlined in the lyrics sheet.

Last time we heard from our dour Brooklyn pysch-pop heroes Crystal Stilts
column3: they were covering the Blue Orchids and Lee Hazlewood on a victory lap EP Radiant Door
column4: released just after their fleshed-out 2011 full-length In Love With Oblivion. It was a solid year for the Stilts: two albums that reverberated off each other
column5: grew the band outward (the expansive “Alien Rivers”) and brighter (the exceptional “Radiant Door”) reiterating their already iterative sound. There was this excitement that circled around those two records
column6: even for a band that winked at dusty noise pop gems from all over the world
column7: from 14 Iced Bears to 13th Floor Elevators
column8: from Joy Division to the jangly Dunedin Sound. This is Crystal Stilts’ racket and if you’ve been keeping up with the Stilts
column9: you know they’re really good at it.

column1: On their tenth year as a band and their third LP
column2: Crystal Stilts press onwards
column3: firmly rooted in every other era but their own
column4: and demand much more of the lay listener to hang back there with them. Nature Noir is a curious album that cements the Stilts as a band whose steps forward seem grand in the scheme of themselves

The initial excitement that the Stilts created by resuscitating the various dark corners of metropolitan noise pop starts to fall as slack as the strings on JB Townsends’ guitar. Perhaps chalk that up to the prerequisite perspective one should have before sitting down with the band. You down with the Velvets at their most booted? You down with Flying Nun Records? You down with solitary psych rock whose functioning aesthetic is more notable than its songwriting? If not
column6: there’s an awkward sensation that the Stilts are performing CPR on a corpse.

column1: Which is not far from the mood Brad Hargett wants to strike with his pitchy baritone. The band aims to draw more inspiration from their outer surroundings this time out. And they do find moments of life here-- those flits and wisps when Haggett sings up in a more Dean Wareham register serve him all too well. ""Sticks and Stones"" and the lite string arrangement on ""Memory Room"" achieve those sunglasses-at-night-in-a-field vibe. Likewise
column2: ""Future Folklore"" imagines an amazing world where CCR wore black turtlenecks and eyeliner
column3: with Townsend's guitar going full swamp rock and the synth switched to a piano for a Little Richard riff. For all its attempts at natural spiritualism
column4: the Stilts get the most exciting when they're either going full throttle or just drinking in a new surrounding or record. But you know the saying: You can take the band out of the anemic
column5: soul-crushing city...

column3: without ever taking a drag. All the morbid vivre the Stilts used to channel

column6: ""Bring your ladder/ Meet me at the top of the world
column7: the beauty of the sentiment just sort of files in the rest of the album
column8: the rest of the band's other albums
column9: and the rest of the bands the Stilts love. Even with the reverb dialed down
column10: it's hard to find a human pulse in the psych-haze ""Star Crawl"" or the lolling ""Worlds Gone Weird"". The heart that Haggart seeks is beating somewhere in the past
column11: but the Stilts' ennui is now less of a listening experience and more of an chin-scratching observation in gallery of retro ideas. You nod because you catch the reference

column14: but it leaves me yearning for the days when the Stilts would put passion into trying to find the pulse. Or better yet
column15:
yearning for the days when the pulse may actually have existed.

column2: eventually

The celebrated work of post-rock pioneers like Don Caballero or Tortoise carried with it some baggage

This characterization has never been entirely accurate-- the best of these bands had plenty of impressionistically emotional music that swelled with grandeur-- but much of math/post-rock was intended to be expansive and dense

column5: as a result

column7: more personal level.

column1: Over the past few years

column3: like Battles' experimental
column4: eclectic dance music or Tera Melos’ knotty interpretation of punk pop. Bassist Greg Albert
column5: guitarist/lead singer Sam Owens

column9: emotional indie rock.

column5: emotional discontent.

column2: jumbled
column3: herky-jerky flow of “Stairs Under Stars” practically begins in media res

column8: anxious

column4: “Alien Days” feels unnecessarily fussy in both composition and production: you get actual child (not childlike) vocals
column5: distorted drum breaks
column6: and what sounds like the use of all 12 major chords within the span of thirty seconds. But once you get a sense of the labyrinthine structure
column7: every strange turn ends up being the right one
column8: each melodic resolution a small
column9: substantial and lasting surprise
column10: like continually finding a dollar in your jeans.

column1: But the “Mystery Disease” referenced on the third track might just be MGMT's allergic reaction to anything resembling a straightforward pop song.Like most of the non-singles from Oracular

column10: leaving you more confused than before.

column1: That all happens during the first half of MGMT and in a likely nod to their vinyl-era heroes

column11: it’s not MGMT vs. Oracular Spectacular; if anything’s holding MGMT back

Nick Thorburn has the power to electrify. He's always had it
column2: from his beginnings fronting tweelectro-pop band the Unicorns

column4: and even at points in supergroups (Mister Heavenly
column5: Human Highway) and his own solo projects. The songwriter formerly-and-still-sometimes known as Nick Diamonds has demonstrated a singular grasp on inventive songwriting that wriggles its way into gray matter. His twinkling melodies
column6: vivid lyricism
column7: and off-the-wall banter can amplify the rich depth of his influences
column8: from Paul Simon's Graceland and calypso to weird hip-hop and mother nature. But power amounts to little when it's not employed. Which is all to say that when Thorburn tries for something more muted-- as on Islands' fifth LP
column9: Ski Mask-- the result isn't a disaster; his music in this mode can actually be pretty nice
column10: if a little vanilla.

column1: It's been a slow process
column2: but over time
column3: Islands have changed considerably. Like a photocopy of a photocopy
column4: the imagination of each album that has followed their explosive 2006 entrance Return to the Sea has faded

column6: serving as a touching emotional rock bottom from which the band-- or more accurately Thorburn
column7: since who even knows the ever-rotating members of Islands anymore
column8: after Thompson's departure in 2008-- has now rebounded. Thematically Ski Mask is indeed ""angry
column9: as Thorburn says in a press release
column10: but it's also desperate
column11: dejected
column12: and occasionally sweet. But the rawness of Forgetting has disappeared again
column13: and the music itself pales in comparison to the blithely complex experimentalism that set the bar high in the first place.

column5: prove Thorburn's knack for memorable wordplay comes and goes these days. Instrumentally
column6: the record is more classically Islands
column7: with a few trademark flares (their calypso xylophone
column8: their cutesy theremin)
column9: though several progressions skirt self-plagiarism (the guitar on album closer ""Winged Beat Drums"" sounds like a repurposed demo for Arm's Way's ""The Arm"" or ""Creeper""). The electro-gallop of ""Sad Middle"" is easily likable and will probably be the best live performance from Mask.

column1: It's all pleasant

rarely finds either.

Many artists would pay to have the problem that L.A. beat scene veteran Daedelus has--  a surplus of ideas. Accordingly
column3: his albums
column4: including his newest effort <i>Drown Out
column5: can seem like they have multiple personalities
column6: jam-packed with ideas that don’t necessarily jive. Drown Out is Daedelus’s first record for Anticon-- he hops from label to label as easily as he hops concepts-- but rather than displaying any artistic growth
column7: he seems to be settling back into his old ways.

column1: That’s not to say that the moods he does settle on
column2: however briefly
column3: aren’t lovely. The back-to-back punch of “Tiptoes
column4: ” and “Frisson
column5: ” sets the listener up to think he’s in for a certain kind of experience: one in which heavy
column6: head-nodding beats eventually give way to an elevation of angelic treble during songs’ climax. The standout “Tiptoes”-- with its unabashedly operatic sample-- is one of the prettiest beats I’ve heard all year.

column1: Unfortunately
column2: the curtain drops on that mood  as “Perpetually""
column3: which sounds like a combination of EDM and Motown
column4: takes the stage. It’s not a bad track
column5: but it’s jolting to hear something that has so little in common with what came before it. Then there are the ideas that should never have been indulged. “Keep Still
column6: ” makes mincemeat of 2Pac’s “I Get Around.”  The sample simply doesn’t belong in a mess of a song
column7: which
column8: at times
column9: can sound as if it’s parodying the “bleep blorp” sound that people unfamiliar with electronic music use to mock it.

column1: There have been exceptions to Daedelus’ displays of musical ADD. His EP Righteous Fists of Harmony was a smooth
column2: thematically-linked listen.  And Live at Low End Theory showed him in his element-- as a live performer
column3: linked to his the crowd
column4: where spontaneity and improvisation allow a performance to be crafted according to the whims of the listener. In interviews
column5: Daedelus raves about the importance of the live experience
column6: and Drown Out sounds as if it might have been conceptualized as more grist for the live show.

column1: Another pair of linked singles later on Drown Out hints that that’s the case.  “Music Concrete” and “-Ísimo” sound like the A and B side to a traditional dance singles. As that’s the world that Daedelus is most used to
column2: it’s no wonder that he still seems to shudder and shift when confronted with the album format.

column1: Many of Daedelus’ fellows have shown an ability to ditch the dance paradigm and make cohesive albums. But the dapper dandy has always stayed true to his roots-- he simply can’t stay still long enough to put together a collection of complementary songs. Drown Out has plenty of sublime moments
column2: but as each of them has little do with any other it ends up sounding less like an album and more like a grab bag of hurried ideas
column3:
the best of which will eventually be experienced somewhere far more immediate.

At 29 tracks deep
column2: this double album from Warp Records stalwart Clark is appropriately named. The first disc
column3: or tracks 1-15 if you’re listening digitally
column4: compile the Feast side of the equation
column5: while disc two (tracks 16-29) unleash the Beast. If that wasn’t daunting enough
column6: it’s a bunch of remixes. Oh
column7: the remix. What was once the ultimate DJ tool-- dancehall heads gifting a track with a new flavor to hook a new audience or disco producers creating extended edit for the dancefloor-- has become the primary currency of the online music world. For the artist
column8: the right remixer means a leg up; a little visibility in a suffocatingly crowded scene. For the website
column9: they provide content. Finally
column10: for the remixer
column11: they are an essential source of income: more reliable than record sales and less overheads than a tour. Clark’s label-mate Aphex Twin called it in typically two-fingers fashion in 2003 with his own remix compilation: 26 Mixes For Cash.

column1: Nothing wrong with that
column2: obviously. People gotta eat. But for all these reasons
column3: remixes-- music as service
column4: as transaction-- often fall through the cracks. It’s not that they can seem half-hearted or sound half-finished (they can) but that original holds so much more weight in a realm obsessed with the real. Which means
column5: more often than not
column6: remixes are here today
column7: gone tomorrow. The internet’s equivalent of lost change down the back of the sofa. But you would hope if you paused to gather them together their value and artistry would become clear.

column1: Happily
column2: that is absolutely the case with Clark’s <i>Feast / Beast
column3: which provides an illuminating opportunity to listen through Clark’s ears; to hear how he hears music. There are patterns and threads to follow that outline the shape of the artist: a passion for percussive grit
column4: a gift for surprise transitions and
column5: underneath it all
column6: that brilliant creeping wit.

column1: Texturally
column2: Clark is all about contrast. That was made clear from day one with his 2001 debut Clarence Park
column3: which veered from glitched out acid to ambient piano loops. On Feast / Beast
column4: his love of contrast manifests in gritty percussion and grimy melodies. His Amon Tobin remix is at once beguiling airy and thick with the scent of wet soil
column5: while he takes Nathan Fake for a clip-clopping ride into satisfyingly spooked out territory. There’s a calamitously carnal re-imagining of HEALTH’s “Die Slow”
column6: with its wild-eyed and slippery instrumentation. Then on his remix of his own track “Alice”
column7: the chimes shine through the grey goo like midnight eyes catching the light. But it is the crunchy footfall of his Rone remix that catches the most. It’s thrilling to hear him work with a hip-hop vocal-- it's a highlight in an exceptional collection-- for there feels an instinctual
column8: almost sensual
column9: understanding of the form’s flow and drama.

column1: Drama could be Clark’s middle name because he loves a surprise transition. His version of Kuedo's “Glow” splits in two like a cleaved piece of fruit: one half purring in an ambient loop
column2: the other sounding a battle cry. There’s the grinding poetry of his Nils Frahm remix
column3: with its organ ploughing through a sea of static
column4: and then-- out of nowhere in the final minute-- a tribal rhythm collapses in on itself like accumulated feedback. His rework of Letherette’s “D&T” takes curves like a racing driver
column5: swerving from sparse digital funk to acid-laced techno
column6: while his take on Aufgang’s  “Dulceria” bumbles along in a bleepily hypnotic fashion until the final third when it melts into fizzy-edged sunrise ambience. Then
column7: in scene-stealing style
column8: he sweeps in with an entirely new track-- “Suns Of Temper (Bear Paw Kicks Version)”-- that starts as the kind of electronic funk that Jamie Liddell should be biting before segueing with typical sleight of hand into an epic orchestral techno number.

column1: While liquid emotion is at the heart of what Clark does-- something highlighted by how Bibio sees him on “Absence”
column2: one of the handful of remixes contributed by other artists-- Feast / Beast also bubbles and burns with his sharp humour. His Drvg Cvltvre remix is unreservedly “screw you” in its bombastic barraging
column3: and there’s a playfulness to his pairing of Dave Gahan’s vocal sighs with an elastic acid line on his version of Depeche Mode’s “Freestate”. Best of all
column4: though
column5: is his cheeky intro to his remix of Milanese’s “Mr Bad News”: “Christopher
column6: somebody's on the telephone for you.” “Oh for fuck’s sake. I’m trying to write this fucking tune
column7:
man.”

Originally signed to London’s blastfirstpetite label
column2: Factory Floor’s earliest transmissions included a 10” plus DVD box set and most telling
column3: a 12” featuring remixes from the likes of Throbbing Gristle’s Christ Carter and Joy Division/New Order’s Stephen Morris. Soon after
column4: Factory Floor collaborated with Chris & Cosey
column5: the Pop Group’s Mark Stewart
column6: and former New York downtown disco composer Peter Gordon
column7: showing that the new band was well aware of its sonic forebears. Their sinewy self-titled debut for DFA now orients Factory Floor along an axis of artists that embrace industrial
column8: post-punk
column9: disco
column10: acid
column11: avant-garde minimalism
column12: electro
column13: dub and-- most crucially-- the dancefloor
column14: without being beholden to any one genre.

column1: It speaks to the trio’s acumen that
column2: for all of the above musical signifiers
column3: their album never feels overstuffed. They’ve peeled back the industrial drones that informed their earliest releases so as to get at the throbbing heart underneath. It’s evident from the start as “Turn It Up” starts as a 164 BPM tock before quickly paring down to a sensible 124 BPMs: With just a nerve-jangling synth line and handful of percussive events-- including a hi-hat that sounds as if the band whetted it down to a razor’s edge-- Void’s processed voice slithers between the masculine and feminine
column4: and there’s enough frigid
column5: metallic-tinged negative space to suggest a meat locker.

column1: “Here Again” is similarly spartan: an ascending arpeggio
column2: a twitch of a beat
column3: a mix of sequencer and Gurnsey’s beat at its most mechanistic
column4: Void’s “ooohs” dubbed to the point of turning to steam. The trio constantly ratchet up the pressure until the song’s midway point
column5: wherein the tension finally breaks and Void’s line can finally be heard. It’s one of the few moments on the album where such anxiety actually gives way to release.

column1: The album’s highlight is the seven-minute “Fall Back”. “Did it feel like you were going to fall on the ground?”
column2: Void asks in a detached tone that falls between Throbbing Gristle’s “Hamburger Lady” and an alien abduction interrogation. The menace grows from there. When Factory Floor are in this mode
column3: DFA’s influence is most clearly felt; it’s a perfect amalgam of programmed acid lines that seem about to ooze blood and live drums that mimic a man-machine
column4: a hybrid sound of flesh and circuitry that underpinned the label’s most crucial singles. It’s certainly the most visceral music the label has released since the earliest Juan Maclean sides (and it’s the eeriest outside of the Invisible Conga People single).

column1: The album’s lone drawback is that
column2: for much of the disc’s 53 minutes
column3: there are barely varying degrees of pressurization. The pacing falls somewhere between the dread of Walter White walking down his gasoline-soaked hallway on ""Breaking Bad"" versus the dread of walking the zombie-filled prison corridors of ""The Walking Dead"". The three minute-long interludes sprinkled throughout do little to leaven the situation. It’s exhausting
column4: to where by album’s end
column5: I’d be hard-pressed to differentiate between “Work Out” and “Breathe In”
column6: even though both are bracing and thrilling as isolated tracks. But in a year where the likes of Kanye and Trent Reznor have reached deep into the dark circuitry of the Wax Trax back catalog to revive the corpse of industrial music
column7:
Factory Floor’s relentlessness suits the present moment.

column4: more measured Delorean. The band who once named an EP after a legendary race car driver has chosen to name their third album after a Basque word for ""froth
column5: sending thousands of music journalists scrambling to find a synonym for ""froth."" (Recommended: ""spindrift."") After three years of touring on Subiza's resplendent builds and easy choruses
column6: the band returned to Barcelona and built a studio for themselves. Terms like ""analog production"" have been tossed around
column7: and the band has replaced their feel-good sampledelia with Actual Female Vocalists
column8: including contributions from Chairlift's Caroline Polachek and Glasser. Singer Ekhi Lopetegi is coming off a turbulent breakup and is studying for his doctorate in philosophy. ""It was a really normal life
column9: Lopetegi said of Apar's recording process.

column1: Some restraint was probably in order. Subiza's anthems found the band exploring the limits of their manufactured expanse. There was a thinness to their sound
column2: like a strong gust could tear it apart. Apar takes pains to correct this. The tracks are sturdier and more patient. Lopetegi's delivery
column3: no longer caked in reverb
column4: is noticeably more confident and refined. On songs like ""Destitute Time"" he picks his spots
column5: emphasizing lyrics that
column6: while still difficult to parse
column7: seem to be traversing topics broader than general good vibes. His role on Subiza was as a glorified hypeman for the band's twinkling rush; on Apar he's more akin to a traditional rock frontman
column8: which moves the band still further away from the club music that underpinned Subiza.

column1: The band does find some new avenues to explore. ""Unhold""
column2: which features Polachek as lead vocalist
column3: is a bold pop song that sounds like someone blowing the Cocteau Twins up to billboard size. ""Destitute Time"" is a graceful rock song that accelerates through its chorus and requires no arms-in-the-air bridge to amplify its coda. Similarly
column4: ""You Know It's Right"" generates most of its speed with simple guitar arpeggios and suggests Delorean might be capable of indie rock as sweet
column5: simple
column6: and confident as New Order's ""Run 2"".

column1: If all of this-- strong frontman
column2: collaborators
column3: fewer samples-- sounds like Apar is more the product of a ""real band
column4: that's true and it's a double-edged sword. Even if you think that samples and piano riffs are cheap thrills
column5: they're thrills nonetheless
column6: and there are times during Apar that the group struggles to replace them. Late-album tracks like ""Walk High"" and ""Your Face"" are well constructed and tuneful
column7: but their pedestrian arrangements don't nod heads like Subiza's hammy piano riffs. They
column8: are
column9: in other words
column10: pretty tracks that don't require dance music's repetition or excess. And even given their more refined approach and darkened mood-- that breakup
column11: plus Spain's destitute financial situation-- the band still sounds capable of projecting only blissed-out warmth. If Lopetegi's reedy voice was Subiza's limiting factor
column12: the band's unchanging timbre may be Apar's.

column1: So Apar is a modest change in direction
column2: moving the band back towards their roots as indie rockers but retaining the lilt and grandness they developed on Ayrton Senna and Subiza. Apar finds both Lopetegi and his bandmates learning to finesse their songs
column3: to put a little touch on their big
column4: arcing pop. It falls flat sometimes
column5: but it offers hope that there's more to Delorean's world than bigness
column6: that those vast expanses they convey so easily won't become
column7: paradoxically
column8: a constraint. A broader palate is still under development
column9:
but Apar provides a path forward without forfeiting Delorean's effortless energy.

column6: McArdle isn't fucking around; neither
column7: it seems

column12: fuzzed-out twee
column13: violent urges
column14: zombies and pentagrams. Weird Sister is one of the most purely exuberant

column9: for all their frantic fuzzbombing

column1: At the center of the fracas is McArdle. She stomps

column3: and shouts her way through plenty of Weird Sister

column7: essentially affectless tone

column9: who'll follow up a spindly
column10: soft-focus verse with a sudden burst of noise
column11: lending Weird Sister an unpredictability it never seems to shed. This volatility's key to Weird Sister's liveliness; you could listen to this album a couple dozen times and still not be able to quite see what's around the corner. Could be another Dave Gruesome anti-solo; could be Alanna
column12: brandishing a knife.

column1: Weird Sister's frenzied tone sometimes causes leads to a bit of motion blur; there's not a bad song in the bunch

column4: ""Mickey""-style chanter ""Secret Surprise"" may be the best of the bunch
column5: tumbling from its punchy verse into an especially sweet
column6: soft-focus chorus

Shouter ""Graveyard"" moves from an echoey Edge-style guitar intro to a Thurston-worthy squeal before dipping into a regal chorus not far from UK twee-poppers Veronica Falls. But you don't listen to Weird Sister for the individual moments so much as the push-and-pull between them. Joanna Gruesome's forever pulling you close

column11: not days and weeks

then it gets you right in the chest.

If you’ve resolved every resentment you’ve carried from high school
column2: are in a conflict-free relationship with your significant other
column3: and have not taken a minute in the past few months trying to figure out in literal terms what the fuck is wrong with you people?
column4: then by all means
column5: carry on. There’s nothing to see here. Since most of you stuck around
column6: let’s consider Balance & Composure’s second LP The Things We Think We’re Missing. The Doylestown
column7: Penn.
column8: quintet have made an unapologetically old-school alt-rock album of jet-engine guitars
column9: impotent rat-in-a-cage rage
column10: and searing
column11: soaring vocals-- it isn’t about teen angst
column12: it just sounds like it. As such
column13: this record looks to fill a void for people seeking popular rock music more stylish and emotive than
column14: say
column15: Avenged Sevenfold
column16: but aren’t really in a position to opt out into counterculture. In other words
column17: it’s “alternative rock” in exact terms and nothing about this will make you feel cool or more connected to the zeitgeist. It’s even better if you don’t care about that shit at all
column18: so the only question is
column19: are Balance & Composure good at what they do?

column1: On lead single “Reflection”
column2: the answer is tacitly an emphatic <i>fuck yeah
column3: though I don’t sense that emphatic positivity is something it would cop to. But as a genre piece
column4: it’s damn near perfect. Upon hearing it
column5: a colleague of mine with more refined tastes said
column6: “I’ve never felt that way in my entire life.” It’s a testament to “Reflection” when that way can be identified so quickly. There’s no conflict here
column7: just pubescent confusion of encountering growth and emotions you don’t have the ability to process. A gorgeous lead riff from Andrew Slaymaker (real name
column8: no gimmicks) introduces “Reflection” and is bodyslammed into altered shapes by two pounding chords. Meanwhile
column9: Jon Simmons’ despondent vocals are softened with slightly flat harmonies-- he can’t decide whether to be feared or to be loved or whether he’s just in fear of being loved. A drum roll leads to what sounds like what should be a chorus of epic emotional venting
column10: yet the band effectively renders the straightjacket of one’s self by thrashing in place. As far as the lyrics go
column11: they’re filled with self-loathing
column12: envy
column13: judgment
column14: anger
column15: fear
column16: pretty much everything that registers as a character defect to an adult. And yet “Reflection” reminds you of how those qualities can feel like survival skills at an age when every social setting feels like a warzone.

column1: It’s a powerful formula and one B&C wisely try to replicate throughout The Things We Think We’re Missing. There’s a strange quirk where it sounds like the band is trying out new guises in two-song chunks: during the opening duo of “Parachutes” and “Lost Your Name”
column2: B&C are a plutonium-powered emo band relying more on force than finesse
column3: on slowly cresting melodies and sustained vocal howls rather than sharp hooks. They’re inversions of Sunny Day Real Estate’s “Circles”
column4: forgoing grunge dynamics entirely by lunging out of your speakers and using the chorus as respite before another tidal push. They provide an easy segue into the more traditionally structured
column5: car-friendly hooks of “Back of Your Head” and “Tiny Raindrop” and as Things progresses
column6: B&C have subtly involved into a band that learned enough from their heroes to troubleshoot some of their mistakes. “When I Come Undone” asks what if the Cure’s Ross Robinson-produced album wasn’t some kind of forced primal scream therapy? What if Billy Corgan realized that he could rock a trenchcoat
column7: pancake makeup
column8: and a Stratocaster at the same time during his goth phase? Enjoy “I’m Swimming” and forget Silversun Pickups ever existed.

column1: That said
column2: The Things We Think We’re Missing is overwhelming four minutes at a time
column3: galvanizing in 10 minute spans
column4: and utterly exhausting taken as a whole. There are cracks in the brick wall of radio-adjusted compression-- hints of acoustic jangle peek through the stormy romanticism of “Tiny Raindrop”
column5: “Ella” and “Cut Me Open” incorporate reverberating drone
column6: and while the acoustic solo performance of “Dirty Head” works against just about every single strength of B&C
column7: it’s probably what they meant when acknowledging the influence of Neutral Milk Hotel. Problem is they’re all mastered at the same extremely loud volume
column8: negating the idea that Things is a record meant to be listened to sequentially rather than strip-mined for singles.

column1: Simmons encounters similar issues with flexibility and nuance as a vocalist. When he’s going full blast
column2: his tone articulates more than his actual words and standard issue angst (“I need a spark to light this house so dark and deep”) detonates into nuclear catharsis. When he tones down his delivery
column3: a bratty
column4: nasal edge puts an unfortunate spotlight on lyrics that draw from the usual sources for sensitive dude poetry-- Morrissey’s auto eroticism (the night drive fantasies of “When I Come Undone” and “Tiny Raindrop”)
column5: Microsoft Word thesaurus (“I need you on my garments/ come at me horrid eyes that seep into my system”) and Robert Smith’s playful surrealism
column6: only without the playful part. The most wincing lyric here (“I’m the spider in your room/ and I got eight eyes all on you”) is taken from a song whose title projects the emotional tenor of the entire record: “Notice Me”.

column1: It’s understandable
column2: since B&C are in a position where they do have to beg for recognition. The Things We Think We’re Missing is a strong alt-rock album when such a thing is about the least fashionable thing imaginable
column3: and its practitioners and fans are largely ignored-- their sonic ideals about punk and indie are sourced from Nirvana
column4: but at a time when the platinum polish of Nevermind has become weirdly undervalued compared to the more ethically admirable In Utero. It carries on the tradition of alt-rock records that were crucial entry points for young listeners while being scoffed at by their older siblings: Siamese Dream
column5: the Cure albums that got MTV airplay
column6: Foo Fighters’ The Colour & The Shape. Not to mention their modern analogues
column7: Deftones’ White Pony
column8: Brand New’s <i>The Devil and God Are Raging Inside of Me
column9: Thursday’s A City By The Light Divided
column10: artful and ambitious heavy pop-rock albums that respectively transcended three genres that triangulate B&C’s coordinates (nu-metal
column11: pop-punk
column12: emo and/or screamo) and were still treated with hostility if not ignored entirely by ostensibly open-minded indie rock fans based on prior reputation. B&C aren’t at that level
column13: but considering the leap they’ve made from their pedestrian debut Separation
column14:
The Things We Think We’re Missing serves notice that we shouldn't be surprised if they get there.

Goldfrapp have spent the last decade trying on different outfits
column3: never really letting anything stick long enough to see if it was a good look. It’s a strategy that pays off as often as it turns out distracting: they’ve struck gold (the sensual disco of Supernature)
column4: they’ve fallen flat (2008’s snoozeworthy Seventh Tree)
column5: and they’ve stumbled admirably (the uneven 80s pastiche of Head First). But on Tales of Us

column1: Tales of Us

column1: Her voice is more affected than it’s ever been on Tales of Us; she’s dead serious all the time. The sexuality of “Strict Machine” and the sly humour of “Rocket” are gone

column1: Of course

column4: say

column6: ” subtle electronics turn the chorus into a gorgeous smear of melody

column10: fingerpicked guitar and sweeping strings. These are glimpses of the typical Goldfrapp genius
column11: but now they’re mere flashes rather than tangible entities.

column1: Admittedly

Acousmatic Sorcery
column3: the 2012 debut by Chicago songwriter Willis Earl Beal
column4: was an album of mysterious
column5: crudely recorded folk and blues that wouldn't have gotten half the attention it did if it weren't for Beal's backstory. An army vet drifting from Albuquerque to his grandma's house on Chicago's South Side
column6: Beal released his earliest recordings via CD-R
column7: usually accompanied by hand-drawn zines
column8: left
column9: as he put it to GQ
column10: ""all around the hipster places and the coffee shops""-- places where Beal rightly guessed that people would be drawn to strange
column11: singular art objects that seemed like missives from a subterranean world.

column1: If that all sounds calculating
column2: it's because it was: Like his hero Tom Waits
column3: Beal presented himself as a savant-like character who just crawled out of the swamp but was in reality a savvy performer aware of peoples' longstanding fascination with outlaws
column4: boogeymen
column5: and characters who present themselves as forces of nature rather than products of society. At one point last year
column6: he even told Time Out Chicago he wanted to be an outsider artist
column7: somehow forgetting that one of the conditions of being an outsider artist is not knowing you're an outsider artist.

column1: Thankfully
column2: Beal's backstory isn't as relevant to Nobody Knows
column3: which in 2013 arrives more or less like any other album: Recorded in a studio
column4: released by a label (instead of picked up by one retroactively)
column5: marketed
column6: hopefully
column7: like the work of another singer-songwriter just elbowing his way through the crowd. The music is more diverse and expansive than it was on Acousmatic Sorcery
column8: which is probably just a function of better resources: Sounds and styles Beal only had the tools to hint at before are rendered professionally and in high definition
column9: and his voice-- a bellowing
column10: conventionally soulful instrument-- is given the sonic space it probably deserves
column11: sitting in the mix like an old iron anchor.

column1: The songs on Nobody split their influences between old-fashioned blues and indie ballads
column2: replete with the sounds of glockenspiels and warm
column3: staticky ambience. The modes aren't all that different. Blues ballads
column4: like indie confessionals
column5: can be almost threateningly intimate
column6: like a cage built from the singer's feelings designed to trap and hold a listener in place. Parts of Nobody-- like parts of Acousmatic Sorcery-- imitate nervous breakdowns
column7: sexual frenzy
column8: and other states of uncomfortably heightened awareness
column9: but that's the point: A born seducer
column10: part of Beal's routine is to draw his listeners into dark places
column11: lower his eyes
column12: jingle a set of keys
column13: and grin.

column1: Like Waits
column2: Beal is a mishmash of tropes made from a shared language you know without having to be taught it: he's ""Cool like a fool in the summertime"" on the hymn-like highlight ""Wavering Lines""; he's ""in transition goin' from town to town"" on ""Ain't Got No Love""; he's ""nine hard inches like a pitchfork prong"" on ""Too Dry To Cry"". He's a shadowy figure skulking the streets at night; he's a corner-store preacher on the brink of revelation; he's a little hambone and a little field holler. He's less a blues singer than a blues incarnate-- an artist that will appeal to people more interested in blues as a theatrical concept than a genre of music.

column1: Which is all to say that despite his apparent idiosyncrasies
column2: Beal is pretty up the middle. Compared to TV on the Radio
column3: Autre Ne Veut
column4: or even Daughn Gibson-- all of whom have experimented with weird
column5: histrionic mutations of the blues-- Beal sounds like a traditionalist more interested in moving ideas around than expanding on them. The real irony of Nobody Knows is that it makes him sound like a more fully realized artist
column6: but a more conservative one
column7:
too.

column4: there was a perfect Jimmy Eat World mall-emo anthem called ""Sex"" by a Manchester band called the Slowdown. The black-and-white video showed four telegenic people with perfect haircuts performing near a carefully placed Johnny Cash poster

column2: and
column3: in fact

Matthew Healy's pinched vocals hit that ice-cream-headache sweet spot between pretty-boy quaver and adenoidal yelp

Situated on the southwestern corner of Lake Ontario
column2: the midsize industrial city of Hamilton
column3: Ontario
column4: has a grittiness that stands in stark contrast to the diverse cosmopolitanism of its northern neighbor
column5: Toronto. While Hamilton may lack the cultural cachet of Canada's largest city
column6: Steeltown served as a creative incubator for singer Jessy Lanza: she fell into a collaborative role with a local acquaintance
column7: Junior Boys member Jeremy Greenspan
column8: that led to studio sessions and a deal with the UK electronic label Hyperdub. The result of Lanza and Greenspan's work together is Pull My Hair Back
column9: Lanza's debut collection of glacial electro-R&B.

column1: Pull My Hair Back rings with a level of confidence surprising for a first record: Lanza experiments with bold minimalism
column2: and frequently employs her voice to meet melodic and rhythmic ends in nontraditional ways. Hiccupping lead single ""Kathy Lee"" is ultra-stark
column3: with Lanza's breathy vocal backed by little more than tiny percussive shakes and snaps; on ""Fuck Diamond"" she becomes a percussive tool herself
column4: her casual readings of ""Fuck that"" and other wordless bits strung together and made part of a burbling tapestry that's reminiscent of the work of Jamie xx. Lanza's willingness to play a supporting role on her own songs
column5: and to give those songs room to breathe
column6: suggests an admirable level of restraint and a good ear for the larger sonic picture.

column1: With all that restraint and space
column2: Lanza's showier gestures stand out. There are several such moments on standout track ""5785021
column3: including a featherlight
column4: fluttering vocal in the chorus and a beautifully textured
column5: rippling synth that unfolds over the song's back half. The remainder of the album has its share of turns in the spotlight
column6: from a wickedly funky synth drop on the stellar ""Against the Wall"" that's straight out of a 1980s playbook to the thrilling closing section of ""Keep Moving""
column7: surely the album's peak in terms of sonic density.

column1: While Greenspan's production choices and craftsmanship are integral to the album's success
column2: Lanza is more than just a producer's pawn. One of her strengths as a vocalist is her ability to convey personality in small but definite ways
column3: even if it's just through a word or short phrase. When she coos ""You know my address"" on ""5785021
column4: it glows with heat and intelligence and control
column5: just enough to paper over the oddity of its existence in a song that's ostensibly about calling someone. It may be a stretch to say Lanza is creating characters within these songs
column6: but she's certainly injecting personality.

column1: It's tempting to imagine how these songs would transform if Lanza unleashed the considerable chops that occasionally shine on Pull My Hair Back. While this record's sense of self and attention to detail deserve to be praised
column2:
a small shift in Lanza's positioning and prominence could be the change that takes her next project from good to great.

J-Zone never set out to make failure his career's overarching theme-- Failure just zeroed in on him to the point where he incorporated it into his persona
column2: accepting it enough that he came across as someone more levelheaded than just another bitter
column3: aging rapper complaining about not having made it. Not that he deserved that kind of fate; in a just world his punchline-barrage insult comedy bars and no-bullshit boom-bap should've introduced at least a couple of his records into the collections of future Scribble Jam battlers. But even on 2001's Pimps Don't Pay Taxes-- the album that broke him through to his cult audience-- he was stressing about illegal downloaders and the prospect of being permanently stuck underground
column4: unable to afford a Caddy with some dice in the mirror. Disillusionment set in by the end of 2008
column5: when the realization finally set in that his DIY-fueled hobby had become a slog of a job. After swapping out his music career to focus more on his writing
column6: his 2011 industry-casualty memoir Root for the Villain and his rap-encyclopedia columns for ego trip provided a less stressful outlet for his wiseass insight.

column1: And yet here he is again with a new record. It's not a contractual obligation
column2: not something that sounds like he forced himself to make it
column3: not a convenient tie-in to his now two-year-old book. It's him in his home studio putting together vintage-sounding beats and talking that same brand of shit he trafficked in when he did it for the love a dozen years ago. Bandcamping it circumvents the dilemma of having pallets of unwanted copies in some Fat Beats back room waiting to be destroyed. But other than that
column4: he put it all together with the same old fervor-- self-enforcing low-tech limitations on the production process and avoiding anything outside his came-up-in-the-80s wheelhouse. Peter Pan Syndrome is such a focused and niche-satisfying record that it likely wouldn't work worth a damn if J-Zone didn't have his heart in it
column5: but in what appears to be a welcome 180
column6: he goes off and performs like somebody who's never been burned by the business.

column1: Peter Pan Syndrome initially seems like a comedic exercise in balancing the crass barb-spitting of his younger self and the aging cynic who sees things changing in ways he doesn't like. His crankiness at the expectations of the dating world is where things get the rawest. “Black Weirdo” hinges on his stated inability to get with the “grown & sexy” thing because he doesn't want a caesar cut and can't stand 90s R&B (aside from Jodeci
column2: Aaron Hall and R. Kelly “'cause they some goons”). “Gadget Ho” cusses out women at the club who seem more interested in texting and taking cameraphone photos than listening to his come-ons. And “The Fox Hunt""
column3: a back-and-forth session with Juggaknots member Breeze Brewin
column4: is an exercise in lowered expectations-- going for “ugly chicks” to cut down on relationship drama-- that gets to the old “it's what's inside that counts” truism as irreverently as possible.

column1: If that all sounds immature as hell at best and troublesome at worst
column2: it's also tied in to a bigger theme at the album's real heart. The Peter Pan Syndrome is an examination of the midlife crisis of an artist who realizes he's not cut out for the 9-to-5 life
column3: or much of anything else that the American Dream expects of him. J-Zone's aggravated flow and stand-up-ready delivery lends itself to some sharp observations on class struggle
column4: gentrification
column5: and the travails of thwarted upward mobility. “Trespasser” calls out Midwestern transplants who displace Brooklyn beef patty restaurants and give neighborhoods new euphemistic names to avoid the scary connotations of Bushwick or “Do-or-Die Bed-Stuy
column6: ” damning these newcomers not simply because they're quirky hipster cliches but because they're assholes who won't nod to the trash collector or let kids pet their Cosby-sweatered dog. Philly indie luminary Has-Lo joins up on “An Honest Day's Robbery
column7: ” where the dead-end lack of job prospects has them resorting to the desperate measure of engineering a “slip and fall” insurance scam at a Whole Foods. And there's an obvious but much-needed observation in “Jackin' for Basquiats” that J-Zone trades with his Lord Quas-esque rodent-voice sidekick Chief Chinchilla: How'd rappers turn paintings into status symbols when their $50 million price tags never go back to the cash-strapped arts community?

column1: That feeling of broke-but-fuck-it itchiness
column2: that fine blend of frustration and defiant creation
column3: shines through in J-Zone's production as well. Keeping in mind that a lot of the hip-hop he grew up with and reveres came about through technical limitations
column4: mistakes
column5: and low budgets
column6: he kept his studio Roger Corman thrifty and leaned heavily on equipment that got a bit janky with age and neglect. After being run through an MPC 2000 with ten busted pads and a couple four-tracks
column7: his beats sound 1995 in ways Tumblr rappers born that year have been flailing to reproduce. It's a setup that only getting old and happy with being set in his ways can really justify
column8: but its layered
column9: painstakingly battered into shape compositions never fail to claim that boom-bap revivalist sweet spot
column10: especially with J-Zone's own chopped-up live drumkit breaks as part of the equation. (He even offers a few bars of uninterrupted solo playing for break purposes at the end of “Hog Slop”: “you can sample 'em
column11: just gimme some credit
column12: a'ight?”)

column1: There's approximately zero reason not to get this if you like Pimps Don't Pay Taxes-- it's that same perspective
column2: larger than life without living large
column3: marinated in a dozen years worth of life lessons. There's a dividing line that runs through it where it could be either the triumph of ageless unfiltered spirit
column4: or the kind of extended middle finger to propriety that has you reaching for the word “manchild."" That it exhibits both of these sides and does its damnedest to reconcile them-- from the dirty-joke crash-pad lament “Crib Issues” to the soul-searching monologue of “Rap Baby Boomers”-- makes Peter Pan Syndrome a compelling listen
column5: even through the jokey moments. Sure
column6:
J-Zone hasn't changed a lot stylistically since he hit that first peak back in 2001-- but that's kind of the point. And it's a point well made.

Their first record was called Whatever People Say I Am
column2: That's What I'm Not-- a Nevermind the Bollocks-type sendup of the generation-defining Self-Titled Debut Album as well as a bratty act of defiance from four Yorkshire youths drunk on their own twitchy cleverness. Their fifth album is called AM
column3: and those mountainous initials stood sky-high behind the band as they preened and stomped like proper rock stars through a headlining Glastonbury set earlier this year. Their face-shrouding hair and brown hoodies are out; greaser streaks and bespoke suits are in. And the same band that once aimed its sights at windbag poseurs on ""Fake Tales of San Francisco"" is now based in Los Angeles. These changes have caused some to question Arctic Monkeys' commitment to their initial no-bullshit ideals. But the quartet isn't giving into the mindless grandeur of rock'n'roll as much as they're working within its confines to mine new territory; over the last eight years
column4: as they've gone from spastic punk
column5: to doomed stoner rock
column6: to sparkling guitar pop
column7: to this new album's skinny-jeaned funk
column8: Arctic Monkeys have stayed close to the spirit of their debut's title while minimizing its excess at the same time.

column1: Meanwhile
column2: singer and lyricist Alex Turner has moved from syllable-stuffing chronicles of indie nightlife culture to songs that are sleeker
column3: more blue-black
column4: more self-lacerating. Thematically
column5: AM centerpiece ""No. 1 Party Anthem"" comes off like a seedier take on Arctic Monkeys' breakout track ""I Bet You Look Good on the Dancefloor"" as it tells of a collar-popped lothario on the prowl in a dank club made up of ""lights on the floors and sweat on the walls
column6: cages and poles."" But instead of blaring
column7: this anthem is wistful
column8: its piano
column9: acoustic strums
column10: and croons suggesting days gone by (along with 70s Elton John and Rod Stewart). Its swirling bridge sums up the scene in just a few choice phrases-- ""The look of love/ The rush of blood/ The 'she’s with me'/ The Gallic shrug""-- and sounds like a definitive endnote to Turner's most notable songwriting style.

column1: So AM goes beyond the sweaty clubs and furtive flirts into the hotel rooms
column2: after parties
column3: and bad decisions that can follow. The crux of the record is neatly summed up by the hook to the blistering ""R U Mine?"": ""R U mine tomorrow
column4: or just mine tonight?""-- an entire world of sex and love and desire distilled to quick-hit text-speak that Drake could appreciate. Turner isn't sure of the answer to that question
column5: and the resulting limbo does his head in all over the LP. He's an avowed romantic living in an unromantic world
column6: grasping for meaning in a city-to-city road-dog lifestyle hellbent on repelling it. In some ways
column7: Turner's struggle and his band's recent gleaming transformation into something like rock gods is reminiscent of U2's turnaround circa Achtung Baby
column8: when that quartet traded in deep virtuousness for sin
column9: rhythm
column10: and leather jackets. For Arctic Monkeys
column11: loosening the tether to credulity can be freeing
column12: allowing the band to live out their classic-rock dreams: T. Rex bop
column13: Bee Gees backup vocals
column14: Rolling Stones R&B
column15: and Black Sabbath monster riffage are all rendered modern throughout AM with the help of longtime producer James Ford. And for Turner in particular

column17: some bleary
column18: some a bit frightening.

column1: Two of the album's slinkiest and best tracks have Turner sounding slyly wolfish
column2: like a perplexed predator confusing lust and longing. ""I dreamt about you nearly every night this week
column3: he purrs on opener ""Do I Wanna Know?""
column4: which slowly rolls forward thanks to guitarist Jamie Cook's lizard-brain riff and drummer Matt Helders' Queen-sized beat; ""Knee Socks""
column5: meanwhile
column6: tells of a wintertime tryst that climaxes with an operatic guest vocal from Queens of the Stone Age's Josh Homme
column7: who could've used some of AM's groove on this year's lumbering … Like Clockwork. Whereas 2009's Homme-produced Humbug had the Arctic Monkeys trying on QOTSA's heaviness with varied success
column8: AM integrates its influences more fully-- and
column9: at times
column10: even beats Homme at his own snake-rock game.

column1: The only solace found on this paranoid and haunted album is within its eclectic music
column2: as well as the idea of music itself. ""Mad Sounds"" is AM's most hopeful song
column3: an achingly sincere ballad that employs melody
column4: swing
column5: and ""oh la la las"" to attest to the power of melody
column6: swing
column7: and ""oh la la las."" It teases out the purest interpretation of the Rorschach-like sine waves that adorn AM's cover
column8: which-- depending on your vantage
column9: or mood-- could also read as leering sunglasses or maybe a bikini top. Creeping closer ""I Wanna Be Yours"" combines all three meanings while seemingly answering the question posed by opener ""Do I Wanna Know?"" That is: When faced with the choice between easy pleasures and lasting devotion
column10: Turner is picking the latter. Sweet
column11: right? But upon further inspection
column12: it's not so simple. ""I Wanna Be Yours"" features lyrics by UK punk poet John Cooper Clarke from his 1982 track of the same name
column13: which uses the language of commercialism to express the deepest love. ""I wanna be your vacuum cleaner
column14: breathing in your dust
column15: sings Turner as a lonely drum machine highlights the sentiment's emptiness. Still
column16: the song doesn't sound cynical. It's genuinely affecting. The ultimate message-- will future generations have the capacity to love people as much as their cars
column17: their coffee pots
column18: their phones?-- rings terrifyingly true in our time of personal branding. Arctic Monkeys let these thoughts languish. ""Maybe I just wanna be yours
column19:
Turner sings. Maybe not.

column2: befitting a rapper who seems more interested in his skateboard than in his music. Wayne’s lyrics still consist of packets of plangent nonsense delivered straight off the dome through predictable flows
