column6: more relaxed Lil Wayne which
column7: in spots
column8: makes Wayne’s unholy 2000s mixtape run seems like less of a distant memory.

column1: Dedication 5
column2: it should be noted
column3: comes at a particularly interesting point in Wayne's timeline. Though it's unclear when the collection was recorded
column4: Wayne is coming off a major health scare and returning to his best-known mixtape franchise
column5: a series highlighted by the modern rap classic Dedication 2. He's certainly coasted in recent years-- that hasn't cost him his radio ubiquity thanks to songs like ""Love Me"" and ""Rich as Fuck""-- but Dedication 5
column6: on the surface
column7: could be seen as an opportunity to reinvigorate his fanbase's interest. Certainly
column8: it's deeper than recent mixtape one-offs like Dedication 4 or stopgaps like Sorry 4 the Wait
column9: but D5 still has its fair share of issues.

column1: The tape is long-- 29 songs-- but fortunately highlight “You Song”
column2: which finds Lil Wayne kicking back and letting an eager Chance the Rapper steal the track
column3: comes early. (It would have been a highlight on Dedication 2
column4: too). We're well past the point where Young Money marquee signees Nicki Minaj and Drake are obligated to step onto the boss’ mixtape
column5: so the strength of the newcomer’s guest spot suggests that Wayne’s reputation is still sterling in some corners of the industry. Other tracks
column6: like the Weeknd-featuring opener “I’m Good”
column7: would work well on a retrofitted Tha Carter IV
column8: while echoes of the “Mixtape Weezy” heyday come on the goofy
column9: spoken interludes that punctuate Dedication 5
column10: where Wayne introduces new
column11: unmemorable signees before jumping onto the next instrumental.

column1: It all feels pretty familiar
column2: and those who’ve bothered to tune in to Wayne during recent years will find plenty to groan over as well. He somehow outdoes himself with his lewd take on “Bugatti”-- don’t think about it
column3: please just don’t think about it-- and often mails it in lyrically (“Had a phone in jail/ That’s a cell phone”). Though he’s still got an ear for the beat and can manipulate his flow to fit-- and
column4: again
column5: most of these bars are rapped without rehearsal
column6: so adjust your mindset accordingly-- Dedication 5 is uneven
column7: front-heavy
column8: and too long for one sitting. But with both recent mixtapes as well as recent projects
column9: Wayne has set the bar very low. What more can he say? It’s hard to know until the artist himself decides
column10:
but Dedication 5-- a release whose DatPiff page earnestly reads ""Welcome back Mixtape Weezy”-- shows that some gears are still moving.

There was a brief moment in the 90s when every indie-rock guitar in the Pacific Northwest seemed to have dimples. Fuzz distortion was suddenly as threatening as the fur on a baby chick
column2: and two lead guitars didn't duel so much as squiggle playfully alongside each other
column3: creating exuberant
column4: but manageable
column5: finger-painted messes. It was a time of bands like Built to Spill and the Spinanes
column6: whose drummer Scott Plouf played with a patient
column7: graceful thump that signaled the scene's genial lack of urgency and whose last name was an onomatopoeia for his style: A soft-pedaled plosive
column8: a polite exhalation
column9: a cumulus cloud clearing its throat.

column1: The Brooklyn band Grooms are a floating piece of mid-90s Portland
column2: serenely bobbing in the shoals of the 2010s indie world. This has been their function ever since 2010's Rejoicer
column3: an album immune to talking points and sturdily replayable even today. Their third album
column4: Infinity Caller
column5: feels like just as much of a welcome tonic to the squabbling Now conversation as ever
column6: which means they are very
column7: very good at what they do.

column1: Grooms don't just humbly steward indie-rock nostalgia into our laps like pizza-delivery guys
column2: though. The reason their music is comforting is because the band sounds so
column3: well
column4: comfortable: Grooms have been playing together since before they were even Grooms
column5: and went by the name Muggabears. By now their assured interplay is a joy in itself. Their guitars tangle and pull apart like kite strings
column6: and the drums hit with a gentle splash (or maybe a ""plouf"") rather than a crack. From the very first watercolor glimmers of guitar on ""Lion Name""
column7: the bass nudging carefully forward and elbowing lead singer Travis Johnson's Peanuts yelp to the forefront
column8: Infinity Caller announces itself: You can relax
column9: this will be easy on everyone.

column1: This is one of their most fully realized albums
column2: something longtime fans will delight in discovering. Bassist Emily Ambruso's vocal turns (lead on ""Iskra Goodbye
column3: prominent backing on ""Sometimes Sometimes"" and many others) have darkened and grown more distinctive and interesting
column4: making her a welcome and equal counterpoint to Johnson. Their songwriting also has developed into something sharper
column5: less atmospheric and blobby. ""Play"" pivots on a pedal tone
column6: allowing it to swing gracefully between major and minor
column7: and ""I Think We're Alone Now"" has one of their stickiest choruses.

column1: It's a minor music-writing cliché to observe that a derivative band ""sound more like themselves"" with each passing release
column2: but if Grooms still don't quite sound like some platonic ur-Grooms
column3: standing on their own and beholden to no one-- or something--  they do sound like a more fully realized and sharply etched iteration of the indie-rock they clearly love. Their lyric and song titles stir echoes in a way that feels intentional and even playful -- they have a song called ""Something I Learned Today"" in addition to the one called ""I Think We're Alone Now""
column4: and on ""Completely""
column5: Johnson sings ""I never was the name of the pacifist one"" with a cadence and phrasing that brings the non-sequitur reference ""Ballroom Blitz"" to mind. They know they remind you of that band
column6: whatever that band is
column7: and have some sly fun confusing your memories of exactly which band it is.

column1: To be perfectly honest
column2: the lyric quoted above might be inaccurate. I didn't even check with the publicist. It might be ""blasphemous one
column3: or even ""pessimist one."" But the truth is that it doesn't quite matter; the song nudges Johnson's voice down the same lazy river of guitars. It's hard to get worked up about specifics when in a reclining position
column4:
and Infinity Caller invites you to grab a Koozie and float on.

Swansong
column2: the final LP of Carcass' initial run
column3: wasn't much of one. That 1995 album-- on which the pioneering Liverpool band broke definitively with their grindcore roots
column4: opting for a groovier
column5: more hard-rock-oriented sound-- had its moments
column6: but in retrospect
column7: it plays like a period curiosity rather than a worthy cap to one of extreme metal's most impressive evolutions. The band members seem to agree. As guitarist Bill Steer told Decibel recently
column8: ""To me
column9: it's really evident when you listen to Swansong that it's a band on the decline.""

column1: Carcass haven't explicitly framed Surgical Steel
column2: their new comeback LP
column3: as a gesture of atonement
column4: but all signs suggest that they're engaging in some savvy revisionist history. Instead of picking up where Swansong left off
column5: this record rewinds the tape further. Surgical Steel reconciles choice elements from the band's early classics-- records like 1989's Symphonies of Sickness and 1991's Necroticism: Descanting the Insalubrious
column6: which married grindcore's primitive blurt to gross-out lyrical tongue-twisters and a refreshingly progressive compositional sense-- with their mid-period masterpiece
column7: Heartwork
column8: perhaps the greatest example to date of an extreme-metal band nodding to the polish and swagger of above-ground rock while retaining their core ferocity.

column1: Surgical Steel is a nostalgic statement
column2: seemingly designed to trigger a Pavlovian response in fans. Not only does the album mark the return of the machine-gun tempos that were absent from Swansong and the animalistic back-up growls
column3: jettisoned on Heartwork
column4: of Steer and original drummer Ken Owen (who suffered a brain hemorrhage in 1999 and doesn't appear behind the kit here); it also features a pulse-quickening instrumental intro
column6: on which Steer expands a fragment from a vintage rehearsal tape into a triumphant multitracked overture. Surgical Steel's immaculate production values are familiar too; the band worked here with Colin Richardson
column7: who helmed every Carcass record from Symphonies through Swansong. Even the album art is a blatant riff on an old image: the cover of the band's 1992 EP
column8: Tools of the Trade. So it's a testament to the strength of the material-- a set of fast
column9: fun and
column10: thanks to vocalist-bassist Jeff Walker
column11: witheringly witty songs-- that Surgical Steel is as enjoyable as it is. The record might be calculated
column12: but it doesn't feel forced; like A Different Kind of Truth
column13: Van Halen's 2012 reunion with David Lee Roth
column14: it's a document of middle-aged lifers trading ponderous maturity for the visceral thrills they relished in their prime.

column1: The strongest songs here sum up how Carcass bridge two proud British traditions: filthy grindcore and flashy rock'n'roll. ""Cadaver Pouch Conveyor System"" finds Walker unleashing his patented sneering rasp over a blastbeat-accented thrash gallop. His longtime foil
column2: Steer-- also an early member of Napalm Death
column3: and an avowed blues-rock junkie who founded his own bellbottom-friendly retro act
column4: Firebird
column5: in 1999-- seasons the track with a Thin Lizzy–worthy melodic lead
column6: lending Walker's gory polemic (""Total arousal/ A frigid wanton wargasm engaged/ Bloodlustmord"") an air of throwback pomp. The William Blake-referencing ""The Granulating Dark Satanic Mills""
column7: Surgical Steel's catchiest track
column8: employs an Iron Maiden-esque midtempo feel that harks back unmistakably to Heartwork. The more relaxed pace allows the band to flaunt the unlikely skill they honed in their heyday: seamlessly integrating extreme-metal moves into the context of old-fashioned anthemic songcraft. Despite Walker's typically arcane lyrical turn-- a grim evocation of the Industrial Revolution-- it's not hard to imagine a rabid crowd fist-pumping along.

column1: Surgical Steel features tons of outstanding playing from Steer
column2: as well as some of the tightest drumming in the band's discography
column3: courtesy of new recruit Daniel Wilding. But the star of the record is undoubtedly Jeff Walker. The frontman returns to some of his pet themes here-- the horrors of the meat industry
column4: the senselessness of war-- but he sounds improbably inspired. Though he established himself in the early 90s as one of the wittiest lyricists in metal
column5: a connoisseur of perverse puns and obscure terms mined from a medical dictionary
column6: Walker has lacked a proper literary outlet since Carcass imploded. (Other than a short-lived continuation of the Swansong lineup-- sans Steer-- under the name Blackstar
column7: Walker's most high-profile project during Carcass' lengthy break was a 2006 record of offbeat country covers
column8: Welcome to Carcass Cuntry
column9: credited to Jeff Walker und die Fluffers.) On Surgical Steel
column10: he's overflowing with ideas
column11: as though he'd been saving up an album's worth of zingers in case his main band ever returned to active duty.

column1: The record's linguistic barrage features playful tributes to John Lennon and the Stones-- ""A working class hero is something to bleed
column2: ""Exiled on maim street""-- a venemous namecheck of humane-slaughterhouse advocate Temple Grandin and
column3: on the masterfully sardonic dis track ""Noncompliance to ASTM F 899-12 Standard""
column4: the coining of a new term (""dearth metal"") to call out tediously derivative extreme-metal practitioners. While Walker seems most at home with barbed
column5: often darkly comedic social critique
column6: his tone turns introspective on ""316L Grade Surgical Steel""
column7: a disturbing portrait of a blackened heart. ""Always love the ones you hurt/ Passion killer with no time to mourn/ Cold comfort that your heart is torn/ I wish you hell-- sealed with a kiss
column8: Walker spits
column9: reminding the listener that his fixation on bodily incision extends to emotional wounds as well.

column1: Most of the record lives up to the high standard set by Walker's pen. Whereas Swansong yielded only one live staple (""Keep on Rotting in the Free World"")
column2: it's clear that the band designed Surgical Steel with the stage in mind; despite these songs' off-the-charts shred quotient and countless baroque flourishes
column3: many of them are as immediate and unshakeable as great punk. Tracks like ""The Master Butcher's Apron"" and ""Unfit for Human Consumption"" epitomize the fiendish hookiness that established Carcass as one of the most trusted brands in extreme metal. Occasionally-- as on the almost comically nimble speed-picked bridge of ""Captive Bolt Pistol""-- the band can sound like they're straining
column4: as though they were overly concerned with convincing fans that the old maximal Carcass is back. And though 8-minute album closer ""Mount of Execution"" is a potent effort in its own right
column5: the song's acoustic-guitar intro and proggy multichapter structure feel out of place on this otherwise admirably compact LP.

column1: As a whole
column2: though
column3: Surgical Steel succeeds brilliantly in its return-to-form mission. The record plays like a big
column4: bloody kiss planted on the cheek of longtime fans; at the same time
column5: it's clearly a selfish statement
column6: the overdue fulfillment of Walker and Steer's desire to rewrite their pet project's final chapter. The end of Carcass' first phase was a disappointing peter-out
column7: but this vigorous do-over effectively reframes Swansong as an archival footnote. So long
column8: dearth metal; hello
column9:
Surgical Steel.

On Nobody Realizes This Is Nowhere
column2: San Fran scuzz-punkers' Terry Malts seem bored. Bored with acting serious
column3: with pretending to be well-adjusted; on ""They're Feeding
column4: even the act of chewing and swallowing seems to send them into fits of tedium. Word to Harvey Danger
column5: but ""Flagpole Sitta"" was wrong-- just because you're bored doesn't necessarily mean you're boring. Lyrically

column8: ""Who brought this chainsaw to the sock hop?"" permabuzz. Even when they're singing about slapping the snooze button
column9: they rip through these songs with a focus bordering on maniacal. Nobody even runs a little leaner and meaner than 2012's Killing Time
column10: tamping down some of the pre-British Invasion mistiness and just flooring it. Nobody
column11: at just 27 minutes and change
column12: is an album about wasted time that doesn't give itself any time to waste.

column1: This strange blend of disaffection and drive finds its way into lead singer Phil Benson's delivery. Clipped and impassioned in roughly equal measure
column2: Benson really seems to care about not caring; in his hands
column3: ""you ought not take yourself so serious"" is a stern admonition
column4: ""live like there is no tomorrow"" a most forlorn-sounding YOLO. The first sound on Nobody Realizes is an alarm call
column5: an unwelcome announcement of yet another day you'll be slouching your way through. Terry Malts describe this all-too-familiar draggy feeling well. But whenever it leeches into the music
column6: Nobody just gets to feeling like a drag.

column1: Every surface on Nobody is blanketed in a thick fuzz; fitting
column2: since Terry Malts aren't the type who can be arsed to do much dusting. The grey pallor this casts over Nobody can get a bit oppressive
column3: but it does the most damage to the vocals
column4: often muddled past the point of comprehension. There's not much point in railing against something if you're not going to let anybody else in on the object of your ire. And when the lyrics don't come through
column5: these songs seem driven by a fervor they haven't quite figured out where to direct. Even when you get the message-- work's a bore
column6: hell is other people
column7: moving my jaw requires too much effort-- it's all about the same; Killing Time's ""Where is the Weekend"" made just about every one of Nobody's listless points in 1/10th the time.

column1: The playing's punchy
column2: rarely less than impassioned. But the songs themselves are pretty much ripped right out of your pop-punk textbook
column3: frantically careening from one power-chord to the next. After a while
column4: Nobody-- frenetic but faceless
column5: too nonchalant for true nonconformity-- starts to blur together. A song like ""Well Adjusted""
column6: with a little more clarity on Benson's voice and a hook sharp enough to stick around for a second round
column7: quickly recaptures your attention
column8: but it's only temporary. Soon after
column9: there's ""Comfortably Dumb""
column10:
its narcotic melody and tendrils of feedback lulling you into a boredom of your very own.

Janelle Monáe opens her second album the same way she did her 2010 debut: with a sumptuously recorded studio orchestra tossing off flourishes with abandon. When the smoke clears
column3: the first full song features a guest vocal from...Prince. Monáe is not the kind of entertainer who takes prisoners; she operates at the locus of generosity where ""generous"" shades subtly into ""aggressive."" The song is called ""Givin Em What They Love""
column4: but the feeling is a little more ""take you home and make you like it.""

column1: The facts of Monáe's emergence have occasionally made it difficult to embrace her music: She arrived so thoroughly anointed by so many key figures in the entertainment industry that it has sometimes felt pointless to try and touch her. At the heart of her ornate
column2: impressive music
column3: a hint of chilliness kept us at arm's-length; she was a conqueror
column4: undoubtedly
column5: but maybe she glossed over the whole ""winning the hearts of the people"" thing.

column1: With The Electric Lady
column2: she finds a way to give us more of herself. Together with her tight-knit Wondaland collaborators-- Kellindo Parker
column3: a magnificent guitarist who singlehandedly gooses several songs into transcendence; her college friends Nate “Rocket” Wonder and Chuck Lightning
column4: and Roman GianArthur-- Monáe supervises and synthesizes a parade of golden touchstones (Sly
column5: Stevie
column6: Marvin) into a show-stopping display of force and talent. And at the heart of it
column7: she embeds some of the most personal pain she's allowed to leak into her music.

column1: Many of her lyrics here telegraph a desire to break away
column2: to ""find a way to freak out
column3: as she puts it on ""Dance Apocalyptic""
column4: which is the closest the album comes to an immediate calling card like ""Tightrope"". The album is overall looser and more physical than its predecessor
column5: more concerned with dancing
column6: sex
column7: love
column8: and abandon. ""I wanna scream and dream and throw a love parade
column9: she sings
column10: in a creamy mid-register
column11: on the moonlit Miguel duet ""Primetime"". The song rides a cerebral whine into an ""I Only Have Eyes For You"" glide
column12: with a ""Purple Rain"" solo cascading over the top like an MGM waterfall.

column1: The emotional core of the album
column2: and its unique loneliness
column3: derives from how Monáe both fails and succeeds to connect. She wants to scream and dream
column4: she's found a way to freak out. The most pleading passages on Electric Lady-- gorgeously tender soul ballads like ""It's Code"" and ""Can't Live Without Your Love""-- feature some of her most emotionally bare
column5: strikingly abject singing. But for all of the sex-positive
column6: queer-friendly utopianism of her music (one between-song skit advertises a ""bouncing electro booty contest""; on the title track
column7: she pictures ""all the birds and the bees dancing with the freaks in the trees""; and on the Erykah Badu-featuring ""Q.U.E.E.N.""
column8: she asks playfully
column9: ""Is it weird to like the way she wears her tights?"")
column10: her music has always been about the the exhilaration coming from the sensation of total control.

column1: Attention to detail is nothing new for the admittedly obsessive Monáe
column2: but man
column3: there are some knockout details here: the rusty poking bedspring of a guitar that powers ""Q.U.E.E.N.""; the percussion loops on ""Electric Lady""; the manic clean-toned jazz guitar skittering behind the vocal breakdown on ""Ghetto Woman"". The strings carry some of the most heart-tugging melodies
column4: and the most beautiful moments come when songs melt from an amped-up funk groove into a glimmering
column5: soul-revue orchestra
column6: like ""We Were Rock and Roll""
column7: ""Give Em What You Love""
column8: and ""Q.U.E.E.N"". Gorgeous soul ballads like ""Can't Live Without Your Love"" are built on the kind of rich
column9: finely managed melodies and jazzy modulations that haven't been the sound of the radio since the late 70s.

column1: Taken as a whole
column2: The Electric Lady is a convincing argument for the virtues of micromanagement
column3: but some of the most powerful
column4: tender moments come from acknowledging  limits. On ""Sally Ride
column5: she admits defeat
column6: of sorts
column7: declaring she's ""packing my spacesuit
column8: and I'm taking my shit up to the moon."" On ""Victory
column9: Monáe offers
column10: ""I'll just keep singing until the pain goes
column11: and there's something humbly stoic in her voice. She's not singing to exorcise pain
column12: which will hang around until it's good and ready to go
column13:
she's just passing the time until it does doing the thing she does best.

0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/19666/homepage_large.3ca262a9.jpg|Coming Apart|30653.0|Body/Head|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Matador']|2013-09-10 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:53:19.578593|"

The musical approach Kim Gordon and Bill Nace chose for their duo Body/Head seems intentionally restrictive. Both play only guitar. Their songs are slow and sometimes static
column2: an effect enhanced by the near-total absence of beats (and
column3: in concert
column4: by the slowed-down films projected behind them). Gordon sings mostly in monotone
column5: spreading her words out in a glacial rap or moaning them in a breathy whisper. The mood is similarly confined
column6: sticking to a strident heaviness through serious lyrics and dirge-like guitar.

column1: This limited palette could feel claustrophobic
column2: or just boring. But on Body/Head’s first full-length album Coming Apart
column3: the duo treat it as a challenge
column4: like the straitjacket a magician dons to prove he can break free. (Not coincidentally
column5: the album is named after a 1969 movie set in a single apartment and shot from a single camera angle). In nearly 70 minutes of music over two LPs
column6: Gordon and Nace burrow deep into their narrow sound
column7: mining it for more variety and emotion than it should rightfully hold. The effect is subtle-- at first the music feels aimless
column8: in search of something vague and elusive. But give Coming Apart a few listens
column9: and distinctive shapes emerge. Eventually
column10: the duo’s dedication to a specific point of view becomes intoxicating.

column1: That dedication shows up most strongly in the conversational guitar work of Gordon and Nace (himself a veteran of many excellent collaborations). Oddly
column2: the duo chose to pan their individual sounds to opposite sides of the stereo space. But rather than making them feel disconnected
column3: that tactic gives their interplay a call-and-response synchronicity. When one of them hits repetitive chords or plucks two-note patterns
column4: the other weaves long tones or dense distortion; at other times
column5: one’s left turn into dissonance inspires the other to find melody in the noise. (The chiming quality of that noise sometimes recalls Evol-era Sonic Youth
column6: but there are many other evocations in the pair’s timbres.) The timing of these actions and reactions makes Coming Apart surprisingly engaging-- though all 10 pieces were mostly improvised
column7: many have an arc that’s thoughtfully song-like.

column1: Even more engaging is Gordon’s singing
column2: which is as expressive as anything she did in Sonic Youth
column3: and often more so. She stretches out syllables
column4: expands phrases
column5: and melts her voice into the rising guitar lava. At times it seems she’s simply exploring the way words sound
column6: treating them like physical objects sliding up her throat and pouring off her tongue. At other points
column7: the concrete meaning of her lyrics is all that matters. So when her simple yell of the title in “Actress” turns urgent
column8: it suddenly sounds like the most important word in the world.

column1: Gordon’s voice also provides an entry point into tunes
column2: which can otherwise be a bit forbidding. But it’s also easy to get lost in them
column3: much the way the most intense work by Jandek or Scott Walker can take on the quality of a dream. As in dreams
column4: time on Coming Apart becomes a moving target
column5: and sometimes seems to disappear altogether. As a result
column6: these songs often feel longer than they actually are-- but this is the rare case where that’s a strength rather than a weakness.

column1: Still
column2: given the music’s endless feel
column3: closing Coming Apart with its two longest tracks is risky. But Gordon and Nace manage to find new ideas in these elongated settings. 17-minute closer “Frontal” is like an album unto itself
column4: gradually moving from distant echoes to the duo’s most aggressive tones. Its predecessor
column5: “Black”
column6: is even more mesmerizing. It’s ostensibly a cover of the traditional folk song “Black Is the Colour (Of My True Love's Hair)”
column7: but Gordon was likely inspired by one version in particular: the radical take recorded by singer Patty Waters and her free-jazz group in the late 60s.

column1: Gordon doesn’t get as frantic or desperate sounding as Waters; in keeping with the album’s tone
column2: her interpretation is darker and heavier. But it’s just as radical. Waiting almost seven minutes before singing
column3: Gordon reworks simple stanzas into zombie mantras
column4: eventually duetting with herself in a chorus of abstract hums. The re-imagining is typical of her career
column5: which has featured more detours than she’s perhaps been given credit for. Count Coming Apart as another fascinating step in that journey
column6:
and Body/Head’s musical path as one that she and Nace will hopefully follow for a long time.

Like every Man Man album
column3: On Oni Pond finds the wolfish Philadelphia crew to be more traditionally tuneful and less grating than the last time out. The obvious play is to acknowledge it as part of the ongoing maturation of Man Man
column4: yet it always feels strange talking about “maturity” for a band that never sounded young. That isn’t to say Man Man sounded old
column5: as in tired and tame. It’s more in the sense that everything from Honus Honus’ lupine howling to their dilapidated percussion warranted adjectives like “grizzled
column6: ” “feral
column7: ” “untamed.” The junkyard dog descriptor made sense-- Man Man sounded like a band that lived on scraps and aged seven times quicker than everyone else. But really
column8: “maturity” is something of a feint listening to On Oni Pond. Perhaps they’re becoming more “adult”
column9: in that while Man Man puts forth the outer appearance of having their shit together
column10: on the inside
column11: their darker impulses are repressed into something more grotesque and frightening.

column1: But at first
column2: what you’ll notice is the utter lack of the kind of squealing
column3: squawking affectations that could clear the room on The Man in a Blue Turban With a Face or Six Demon Bag. As with 2011’s Life Fantastic
column4: Saddle Creek majordomo Mike Mogis produces and more than ever
column5: Man Man's reliance on pure rhythm becomes readily apparent-- I hesitate to call On Oni Pond a “danceable” record or even “funky”
column6: though it’s got groove and Honus’ lyrics often function like chants
column7: regardless of how verbose they are. I couldn’t imagine this getting booted off any radio playlist
column8: but I think of On Oni Pond as positioning Man Man as an offbeat version of bands like My Morning Jacket or even Animal Collective-- rootsy and rooted in indie
column9: but now a big deal rock band with a body-moving impulse that puts them up for pretty much every festival other than Warped Tour or Rock the Bells.

column1: By the same token
column2: Man Man’s confrontational edge happened to be one of their greatest assets. Previous piano ballads like “Van Helsing Boombox” and “Rabbit Habits” were certainly heartbreaking due to their despondent lyrics
column3: but there was an endearing
column4: pathetic nature to the sound that drove the point home-- here was a guy unlucky at love
column5: trying as hard as he can to make typically “pretty” music and failing. First single “Head On” is sweetened with a classic soul melody
column6: strings and Honus’ chin-up solace directed at one of those poor souls who might’ve related to the aforementioned:  “hold onto your heart/ never let nobody take it over.”

column1: But don’t take “Head On” as being indicative of the lyrical direction here. On Oni Pond shifts Honus’ attention from the paranoia and morbidity that marked Life Fantastic to what can be heard as a concept album about male sexual futility. This is a theme that’s hardly new for Man Man. But while Honus is one of indie’s most lecherous lyricists
column2: there’s always been a sadomasochistic bite to it. Here
column3: there’s something of paradoxical swagger is in his ability to empathize with those getting no satisfaction. The inability to get one’s rocks off is arguably the lifeblood of rock and roll
column4: and people tend to do crazy shit when engorged-- for example
column5: using Anne Frank as a psychosexual muse and having the Civil War serve as a contextual framework for a tough time at college. Maybe you think it’s tasteless and even insulting for Honus to evoke Guantanamo
column6: conflict diamonds and “that child raised by Kony
column7: but he’s flexing and realizing his subject matter is inherently absurd. Just as often
column8: the humor results in some real groaners (a played-out Silence of the Lambs reference
column9: the faux-Oriental vocals on “Pink Wonton”
column10: the title of “Pink Wonton”) and the narrowness of the subject matter can feel stifling for everyone involved-- the self-explanatory submission fantasy “Loot My Body” is the first song to really feel like Man Man madlibs.

column1: The worry here is that maturity might actually mean Man Man getting stuck in their ways
column2: though “End Boss” can be read as a self-aware self-help talk: “if you won’t reinvent yourself/ you can’t circumvent your hell.” And if “Fangs” isn’t a late-album intervention
column3: it’s a certainly a welcome acknowledgement of the other side in the war of the sexes. It’s not the first time Honus has written about a woman with something to hide. But unlike the murderous cross-dresser of “Poor Jackie”
column4: the subject here is more relatable
column5: someone who “had a fantasy of being the female Steve McQueen” but instead
column6: “hides her fangs/ behind her back … pretends to laugh/ at the boxes she’s been born in.” Like most songs of this nature
column7: there’s the threat of Man Man being far longer on good intentions than keen insight. Fortunately
column8: “Fangs” avoids condescension as the rest of On Oni Pond serves as an unintentional vindication for Honus’ viewpoint here: when you consider the horny
column9: slobbering suckers that populate the majority of Man Man songs
column10: you might begin to understand how shitty it must be to have to deal with it all. So while softer and more empathetic the band isn’t quite tamed yet; On Oni Pond is a Man Man album through and through
column11:
delivering an occasionally bizarre and fantastical look at the very real human condition.

The breathtakingly pretty “moonbath.brainsalt.a.holy.fool” is indicative of the mood on Stitches-- the ticking plunk of piano chords set against sweeping steel guitar sighs instantly conjures images of tumbleweeds blowing across a desolate desert at sunset

column3: Killer Mike and more)

(More recently Cee-Lo has worked as a judge on the NBC singing contest ""The Voice."") Nowadays Cee-Lo’s a soul singer with the juice to push almost 200
column9:
000 units of a Christmas album with guest appearances from Christina Aguilera and the Muppets. It’s quite possible that a good portion of his new fanbase has no idea that he raps.

Getting the band back together seems counterintuitive to Cee-Lo’s career trajectory
column10: but it maybe makes sense for the rest of the group. Goodie Mob reformed as a trio for 2004’s pithily titled One Monkey Don’t Stop No Show but quickly disintegrated after it bombed. In that sense

Age Against the Machine functions best when it’s not reaching. Brass tacks rap cuts like “Vallelujah” win for dispensing with the gimmicky pop-soul of the Cee-Lo tracks. When “Pinstripes” lobs shots at Atlanta’s trap elite and “Special Education” suggests that “V.I.P. stands for ‘very insecure people

The sad spoils of a job in music criticism: I am finally given the chance to review a new release by the Pixies

column7: one

column11: fatuous alt-rock songs distinguishes them as the music of the Pixies. Nothing
column12: in fact
column13: distinguishes them at all. Kim Deal is absent
column14: having left the band
column15: but no one else-- not Santiago or Lovering or even Frank Black-- seem to have shown up either.

column1: From the moment Black’s bleating vocal take begins on “Andro Queen”
column2: it’s painfully clear: There is no Pixies in this Pixies. No tension between preschool giddiness and grad-school sophistication

There is no alien shimmer to the guitars or the vocal melodies. The cheerily plodding power chords and excruciating rhyme scheme of “Another Toe in the Ocean” recall Green Album-era Weezer

column1: For anyone with even a mild investment in the music the Pixies made in the 1980s-- which

column3: is a fair amount of people-- the utterly anonymous sound of EP-1 is shocking. On “Indie Cindy”
column4: Black rants and mutters lines like “You put the cock in cocktail
column5: man/ I put the tail in wait
column6: watch me walk."" It's terrible

column1: It's hard not to take the EP's failure personally. If not for the once-faraway promise of the Pixies
column2: and bands like the Pixies

column4: nine years ago

column9: wasn’t supposed to be. I was cheating death
column10: or time

column12: it would certainly backfire in some way. And so it has. Very soon
column13: no one will remember much about this EP

column15:
and it’s almost enough to make me wish the reunion and even that magical show I saw never happened.

By their very name

column1: The Howling Wind is the black metal side project of multi-instrumentalist Ryan Lipynsky and drummer Tim Call
column2: respective East Coast and West Coast metal musicians with exhaustive résumés. During the last two decades
column3: Lipynsky has cycled through a series of related acts
column4: from the black metal benders Thralldom and the futuristic sludge crew Unearthly Trance to the newly slow and brutal Serpentine Path. Thralldom’s best moments came when they treated black metal as a textural starting point and not a technical endgame

column6: tectonic quakes. Relatedly

column8: plays with down-tuned Pacific Northwest outfit Shadow of the Torturer and powers the creeping majesty of Portland’s great
column9: funereal Aldebaran. But as the Howling Wind
column10: they’ve made four albums of knotty
column11: atavistic black metal that’s shaken off the tempo torpor of their other outfits. But that’s not to say that they treat the imprint of their other acts as anathema; in fact
column12: Vortex
column13: their latest and fourth

column15: too.

column1: The Howling Wind have long played fast and loose with the expectations of black metal: Though their 2007 debut Pestilence & Peril mostly charged through distorted
column2: deadpan heaviness

column4: after all. But last year’s excellent Of Babalon moved more toward firm rock'n'roll ground

column6: swift beating of “Beast of the Sea” highlighting the differences between this and their other activities. To an extent

column9: with Lipynski’s tar-thick riffs pushed along by Call’s italicized beats. While “Alignment of Celestial Bodies” takes shape around several old-school black metal sequences; it tends to rumble along like Motörhead
column10: too
column11: with a mid-tempo chug functioning as the glue between its flickering leads and blast beats. Most notable
column12: though

column14: psychedelic solo at song’s end. The knot of notes is too colorful to be grim. It’s an a-ha moment for the band
column15: proof positive of their broad interests.

column1: That enthusiasm for pushing slightly but decidedly past the confines of the “black metal side project” mold keeps Vortex compelling and unstable. “Waves Come Crashing Down” begins as a blitz
column2: with jagged riffs slicing through a relentless stomp. But an inexorable weight seems to linger from the outset

In case you forgot
column2: Smash still has jams for days. When Jackson Fourgeaud released his 2005 debut album as Jackson and His Computer Band after years of prodigious singles and hot-stove development
column3: it was a delirious tangle of ideas that just got messier the more you tried to pull it apart. It was an agile mixture of glitch
column4: electro
column5: left-field hip-hop and early French Touch that was less a blend than a collision. Everything sounded like a remix of a remix of a remix of a seventh draft
column6: the odd paradox of something so fussed over that it shuddered into chaos as some kind of survival mechanism. Yet you could still move to it despite its apparent disinterest in locking into an easy-fit groove. That his public work post-Smash was limited to a string of remixes by electro/house acts that could be considered his less-outlandish usurprers-- Justice (“D.A.N.C.E.”)
column7: Kavinsky (“Pacific Coast Highway”)
column8: Planningtorock (“Living It Out”) -- seemed
column9: for a while
column10: like one of dance music's more perplexing mysteries. What the hell happened to him?

column1: Eight years later
column2: Glow retains the same question but shifts its target-- not to Jackson's absence
column3: but to the diminishing returns he brought with him when that absence ended. If there's one overarching flaw to Glow that covers all the little accumulated ones
column4: it's that Jackson's genre-pastiche seams are starting to show a bit more. Instead of hacking pieces away from a solid block of beats to create something jagged and slippery to grasp
column5: he comes up with a riff or a figure-- something easily identifiable as neo-new wave or caricaturized electro or half-hearted gabber-- and scuffs the surface a bit so it looks dingy. Not enough to be challenging or do anything surprising with its corrosion
column6: but enough that it makes it difficult for his production to breather.

column1: Worse still
column2: it feels like he's spent so much time pulling remix duty that he can only find ways to channel his own sound through other artists' work. “Orgysteria” and its cheesily grandiose android-love ooze is a few Hz short of Air's 10
column3: 000. “Dead Living Things” is the mushroomy analog sludge of Black Moth Super Rainbow with an ill-advised Random Access Memories budget and a nasal falsetto whine that could use a dirtier filter or three. And the aluminum-rattling haunted house throb of “Pump” takes the giallo sensibilties of Justice's † and waters its art-horror aspirations down to third-rate direct-to-VHS splatter.

column1: It gets worse. The unpleasant surprise of “G.I. Jane (Fill Me Up)”-- where gastric hoovers fill in for power chords
column2: mock-Phoenix backbeats tick away rotely
column3: and vocals are handled by a choir of distracted Mark Knopfler A.I.s-- doesn't work as either a sendup of arena indie or an embrace of it. And overdriven opener “Blow” and late-album churner “More” try to punk it up with quirky noise and noisy quirk
column4: but can't stay focused long enough to keep their dopey momentum going before beatless interjections of droning synths let all the air out. Eclecticism and unpredictability used to be what made Jackson's work so exciting. But it's gotten so out of control that even the bits that almost work (“Seal” as bass-music flirtation; the swooning
column5: dreamlike synthpop of the Classixx-ist “Vista”) still fail to come across integral threads in a new phase of his style. Instead
column6:
they feel like the pieces that stuck to the wall when he threw everything at it. I don't envy whoever has to clean up that mess.

It feels quaint to think of the days when people called Neko Case a country singer; she has spent the past decade moving towards a sound that makes genre descriptions seem as confining and anachronistic as corsets. Case got her start playing drums in Vancouver punk bands. Then at some point

column5: that word feels inadequate to describe the meteorological event that takes place when Neko Case opens her mouth. Case has a moonbeam for a voice: imposing in timbre

column7: magnificently weird. All of Case’s subsequent solo records have a surreal

column10: female prisoners
column11: man-eating tigers) and the idiosyncratic grit of her songwriting voice. ""If I puked up some sonnets

column1: After the release of her last record

column3: though
column4: Case weathered a rough patch. She lost her grandmother (with whom she was close)
column5: and then both of her parents (with whom she was not)
column6: and as a result-- something she’s begun to talk about in interviews for this record-- sunk into a depression. ""It was physically debilitating
column7: she told The Guardian recently. ""You’re just in this murk. And you’re with other humans but you lose all your human skills and it’s just like you’re in this plastic bag and you can’t quite connect with people."" Case’s remarkable new album
column8: <i>The Worse Things Get
column9: The Harder I Fight
column10: The Harder I Fight
column11: The More I Love You is an exorcism of this dark period of her life-- and also her most plainly autobiographical album yet. It is to Case’s discography what 2005's The Sunset Tree was to the Mountain Goats’: a seasoned songwriter known for evocative portraits of fictional characters finally turning that gimlet eye in on itself. The result is the most potent album of her career.

column1: The Worse Things Get is made of the same metal as Middle Cyclone
column2: but fashioned into a much sharper object. The languid
column3: mid-tempo ballads that occasionally made Cyclone sag have been replaced by songs that are shorter
column4: tighter
column5: and more cutting. Not a single one overstays its welcome
column6: from the bracing
column7: minimal self-help credo ""Afraid"" to the wistful ""Calling Cards""
column8: a quietly devastating tale of long-suffering long-distance longing. ""We’ll all be together
column9: even when we’re not together
column10: Case's voice swells
column11: finally landing on a bittersweet image that rings out long after the song fades: ""I’ve got calling cards from 20 years ago.""

column1: The evolution between these two records is most striking
column2: though
column3: when the tempo revs up. When it first came out
column4: the punchy lead-off single ""Man"" sounded like a retread of Cyclone’s caustically poppy ""People Got A Lotta Nerve"" (""I’m a man
column5: man
column6: man/ Man
column7: man
column8: man-eater"")
column9: but within the context of the record (or even more obviously

column11: which

column13: unbridled vocal point out
column14: is exactly what it feels like to be imprisoned in the impossible expectations of femininity. ""I’m a man/ That's what you raised me to be
column15: she taunts like a shit-talking prizefighter. ""Fat-fingered bullies were no match for me/ I still taste them in my teeth.""

column2: she announced memorably on Blacklisted
column3: ""Not afraid to die!"")
column4: but at the same time they reject simple

column6: independent woman” is a cliché that society often paints in black and white
column7: but Case’s take on the subject is a portrait of innumerable grays. In a Neko Case song
column8: freedom
column9: strength and womanhood are all statements punctuated by question marks rather than exclamation points. But whenever The Worse Things Get risks getting too conceptual
column10: a casual
column11: mildly self-deprecating humor always brings these songs back down to earth. ""I was surprised when you called me a lady
column12: she sings on ""I’m From No Where""
column13: a subdued
column14: acoustic comedown following ""Man""
column15: ""'Cause I’m still not so sure that’s what I wanna be."" It might sound like a grand
column16: abstract statement

column1: It’s an emotionally wrenching record throughout
column2: but The Worse Things Get is at its most devastating when it takes up motherhood. Animated by rattling percussion and an arrangement that chatters like a dense forest
column3: the opener ""Wild Creatures"" has an intrepid air about it (""I’m not fighting for your freedom/ I am fighting to be wild"") until it ends on a minor-key revelation: ""There’s no mother’s hands to quiet me."" This particular absence hovers constantly in the ether of The Worse Things Get
column4: until it finally bubbles over on the stunning a capella centerpiece ""Nearly Midnight
column5: Honolulu"". It’s a bold move and perhaps the most polarizing song she’s ever released; Case usually dresses her subjects up in magical realism and poetic turns of phrase
column6: but she’s never worn her heart on her sleeve as plainly as she does here. The song tells the story of a mother Case saw screaming at a child in an airport in Hawaii-- ""Get the fuck away from me!/ Why don’t you ever shut up?""-- and as she sings them she slathers the mother’s words in reverb
column7: the echo poignantly suggesting ripple effects they’ll have on the kid’s psyche. ""Honolulu"" hits like a shot to the gut. Case writes the song as an open letter to the neglected child (""Don’t you ever shut up
column8: kid/ Please have your say"") and amidst the arrangement’s negative space
column9: her voice is a thick blanket in the shivering cold.

column1: And that’s the most impressive thing about The Worse Things Get: though it’s a record that looks at topics like depression and parental neglect square in the teeth
column2: its overall tone is one of resilience. The penultimate track
column3: ""Where Did I Leave That Fire"" begins with a sparse
column4: post-rock arrangement but eventually gathers into a triumphant and surprisingly comic midtempo ballad about mojo returned. But the true victory lap is ""Ragtime""
column5: a rousing blast of ""Crimson and Clover""-esque pop that serves up hard-won hope and plenty of mantras for carrying on. ""I’ll reveal myself invincible soon
column6: Case sings
column7: as a parade’s worth of brass swells around her in agreement.

column1: Somehow
column2: The Worse Things Get is Case’s tightest record and also her strangest. With its off-kilter arrangements and eccentric turns of phrase
column3: it’s a world unto itself. If it has any contemporaries
column4:
they’re records like Fiona Apple’s The Idler Wheel… or Cat Power’s Sun-- the works of artists for whom “maturity” has not meant putting out that fire that Case sings so evocatively about chasing.

Foxygen’s devotion to 60s rock knows no bounds. Along with adopting all of those paisley clothes and groovy organ sounds
column2: the polarizing psych-pop duo even conforms to the era’s compressed sense of time. Similar to how the Beatles and the Rolling Stones released new albums every six months
column3: and went through full-scale musical transformations pretty much every other year
column4: Foxygen has already endured a career’s worth of ups and downs since the release of 2012’s Take the Kids Off Broadway EP. There was the acclaimed full-length debut We Are the 21st Century Ambassadors of Peace & Magic
column5: a series of tumultuous tours
column6: rumors of intra-band strife
column7: a wacky appearance at the Pitchfork Music Festival
column8: and now Law & Order

column10: Jonathan Rado. As if that wasn’t enough activity

column1: No matter what lies ahead in Foxygen’s future

column5: Lennon
column6: and Barrett are his main touchstones-- adds extra authenticity to the group’s studious genre exercises. Rado’s vocals
column7: meanwhile

column1: Rado didn’t set out to make a record as pristine as We Are the 21st Century Ambassadors; Law & Order is a homemade grab-bag of jams and rough-cut gems that sounds like it was hashed out in a matter of days. It’s basically Rado's version of McCartney
column2: which is one among approximately 83 classic-rock references on Law & Order smothered in the requisite air quotes.

column1: Rado might be derivative
column2: but at least there’s an admirable consistency to his prodigious output. Studying the masters has taught him how to put together catchy songs seemingly at will. The best tracks on Law & Order are frontloaded: The album-opening “Seven Horses” blobs along on a trippy groove that’s surprisingly funky

Things get weirder in the album’s second half-- “I Wanna Feel It Now!!!” recalls the thrilling cacophony of Broadway-- but the glitchy closer “Pot of Gold” is Rado’s most focused pop song yet. He even indulges in a slick yacht-rock guitar solo-- is this a sign that he’s moving on to the 70s
column4: as all 60s heroes must eventually do? Knowing Rado
column5:
the wait won’t be long to find out.

It’s scary to think that John Dwyer is maturing. Not just because he’s been at this racket-making racket for over 15 years now
column4: but because his current outfit
column5: Thee Oh Sees
column6: has hit an oxymoronic equilibrium of garage-barf refinement-- a stable instability that only comes from grooming chaos as if it were your own child. In that sense
column7: Dwyer couldn’t be prouder. The pride has led to the re-release of one of the stray wastrels of Dwyer’s back catalog: Hands on the Controls
column8: the 2002 debut album by Coachwhips
column9: his band immediately prior to Thee Oh Sees. The band lasted from 2001 to 2005
column10: and in that time Dwyer grew in leaps in bounds from the noisenik animatronics of Pink and Brown and toward the cracked-skull songcraft of Thee Oh Sees.

column1: Hands on the Controls was never issued on vinyl-- ironically
column2: one of the greatest nil-fi recordings of the 00s only came out on CD-- but that’s being remedied now. Along with the sympathetic format comes six unreleased tracks laid down during the 2001 recording session that birthed Hands on the Controls. Twenty-five songs total seems a remarkable achievement for a two-day studio spurt
column3: until you realize just how spastically these tracks came into being. More like shards of shattered glass than songs
column4: “Wheelchair” and “That Bitch Is Gonna End Up Dead” draw blood as they drag themselves across the disc in minute-and-a-half slashes of minimal blues-punk that makes most minimal blues-punk sound like Wagner.

column1: But there’s more to the mix than simply updating what Supercharger and the Spaceshits had done in the 90s. This was 2001
column2: and viewed in that context
column3: Dwyer-- and Hands on the Controls in particular-- could be seen as an emergency retoxification of garage rock in the wake of the Strokes and the White Stripes. Not that Coachwhips seemed to give a shit. But that was the point. The thought-blotting saxophone and fuzz-fried vocals of “These Things Belong to Someone Else” might as well have been a reclamation of the rudiments of caveperson primitivism. And they still could be.

column1: Context aside
column2: there’s a moronic
column3: monomaniacal joy to Hands on the Controls that pushes it to the precipice of timelessness. This is a party in a studio with the tape rolling
column4: no doubt about it
column5: with all the in-jokes and wall-climbing that entails. “Mary Ann’s gonna sit this one out
column6: ’cause this songs about her. [Belch.] ‘Mary Ann’
column7: ” is how Dwyer starts out the song “Mary Ann”
column8: referring to the group’s organist Mary Ann McNamara. What follows is 59 seconds of the same numbskull riff played like a locked groove at the end of a Troggs 45. Dwyer’s only lyric: “Mary Ann”. Then it just stops
column9: a love song yanked from the turntable. Later he begins “Wite Lites” by calling out
column10: “John Harlow on drums!”-- as if the beat Harlow lays down was something more dazzling than what a food processor might have accomplished.

column1: Those shout-outs
column2: weird starts
column3: loose threads
column4: and dead ends are what make Hands on the Controls far more than the sum of its shrapnel. Of the previously unreleased tracks
column5: “American and Europe Too” is the best premonition of what Dwyer would go on to do in Thee Oh Sees: pull together all these fragments of half-forgotten influences just long enough to take a blurry snapshot. It may be no coincidence that many of the six added tracks are among the heaviest and most pummeling of the repackaged Hands; “Not Gonna Make it Thru the Night” feels more like a still-steaming leftover from Pink and Brown
column6: rather than the juicier
column7: catchier nuggets that Dwyer would eventually start digging up. As a document of a chaos system in motion
column8: Hands on the Controls is breathtaking; as a showcase for Dwyer’s emerging slop-psyche magnificence
column9:
it couldn’t sound more frighteningly vital.

column6: but he’s similarly capable of pairing yearning sentiment with big
column7: bludgeoning riffs. “The Difference” evokes tender images of backlit cities and fractured feelings (“Hearts beat in the distance/ Until you witness the quickness/ and what’s left but the difference / Repeating sequence of sequins”) before aiming ascendent
column8: and there’s a glow within the soaring thrash of “Ruins” that slips out like light through a cracked vase as Lukas sings about a love that’s worn and weathered but still standing. Sundowning is filled with quickly paced axe theatrics
column9: but the band can be less direct
column10: too: On “Who I Belong To”
column11: listen for the guitar line that veins off from the main melody
column12: wandering as the remaining parts swell toward a luminescent outro that never meanders.

column1: You sense this is an act that sounds heftiest in person or at a volume that begs a police report. Heavy times aren’t created equally
column2: and the line between bitchin’ and butt rock is different for every band that’s decided their best plan of attack is to keep on attacking. If Sundowning ever feels staid
column3: it’s when the band spends a little too long hammering a single progression. “Occupy Within” and “Dead Cities” don’t get weird enough to justify the formulaic arrangements that might bring uncharitable comparisons to
column4: say
column5: Disturbed. By contrast
column6: the moments where they find the balance are sublime
column7: like when the gnarled freakout of “Western Child” suddenly yawns into a staticky
column8: swirling drone before collapsing back into itself. It’s not powerfully original
column9: but it is powerful. Another name change would justify a further refining
column10:
but Pink Frost appear to have found a home in the middle.

column1: 0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/19641/homepage_large.e7a26145.jpg|Repave|27996.0|Volcano Choir|['Rock'

'Experimental']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Jagjaguwar']|2013-09-04 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:53:32.807852|"

The music Justin Vernon creates as Bon Iver leaves itself wide open to interpretation
column3: comically so at times. But almost no one interprets it as “fun.” Now consider Wisconsin experimental post-rock outfits Collections of Colonies of Bees and All Tiny Creatures and the fact that “experimental post-rock” never promises a load of laughs either. These are the parties that comprise Volcano Choir and on their second LP Repave
column4: the sextet have created a grandiose record with arena-rock ambitions and ostentatious beauty that is mostly inscrutable on a lyrical level. And yet
column5: here’s the way in: I think this is the sound of them having fun.

column1: This may sound counterintuitive
column2: but it was also the key to unlocking their 2009 debut Unmap. Lyrics such as “conserve it with an omelette/ and you’re on it with the carpet” from “Island
column3: IS” would’ve been a dead giveaway if you could make them out in the slightest. But while all those beatless
column4: free-time mbira excursions could have been interpreted as experimental artists indulging their least accessible ideas
column5: let’s not forget that thumb pianos are really fun to play when you’re stoned.

column1: Repave is a decidedly more extroverted affair-- “with enough kief/ you can really bore someone” is the most straightforward and sound advice you’ll get from Vernon
column2: though he sings it with chesty zeal on “Byegone” like it’s a regal proclamation. Volcano Choir are less interested in getting high this time out as they are achieving spiritual uplift
column3: or at least getting a rise out of the listener-- if you still are doubting the sincerity of Bon Iver’s Hornsby tribute “Beth/Rest”
column4: Repave establishes that some things will never change with Vernon.

column1: The near entirety of it could be described as “power balladry
column2: ” a comprehensive denomination that owes plenty to the 1980s’ most popular Bruces
column3: but also those that stood at their periphery and the bands that would ultimately carry their lineage. Overdriven organ
column4: booming drums
column5: and Vernon’s multitracked falsetto push opener “Tiderays” to an elevated plane where post-prog Genesis and pre-Eno Coldplay meet. The magisterial orchestration of “Byegone” enrobes a grizzled folk tune; it’s a place where early Pearl Jam and Arcade Fire find common ground in their ability to reconcile the supposed incongruity of humility and bluster within a cohesive aesthetic. Those bands tended to make songs with “sea” or “ocean” in their title and you don’t need that damn album cover for Volcano Choir to drive the point home. All songs on Repave begin quietly and almost none stay that way for long
column6: so when those crescendos hit
column7: you’re supposed to envision waves crashing on cold
column8: barren outcroppings
column9: white mist spraying as seabirds take majestic flight.

column1: That’s really what “power ballad” means on a literal level-- an intimate song blown out to widescreen proportions to the point where you have to call it epic and it can be shared with thousands of people who all think it was written for them. It’s worth acknowledging the mutual benefit that gets passed on to CoCoB and ATC here: let’s not forget
column2: for all the ill will directed towards any of the influences here
column3: their records were often the outcome of the most technically proficient musicians on earth given frightening sums of money and unlimited studio time with the express purpose of making ""it sounds like a million bucks"" feel tangible.

column1: And the instrumental contingent of Volcano Choir gets to live out their hockey shed visions by isolating the most bombastic sections of Bon Iver albums and making entire songs out of them. They still fill out the margins playing tricky
column2: off-kilter guitar lines that wouldn’t be out of place in their own work. Here
column3: they’re polished
column4: shellacked
column5: and gilded to the point where you couldn’t imagine Vernon picking up one of their guitars and strumming out “Skinny Love”-- they sound more like harps. The depth of the drums evoke not just canyons and churches
column6: but the Grand Canyon and Sistine Chapel. In short
column7: Repave sounds amazing
column8: almost intimidating in its clarity
column9: so even when “Keel” and ""Almanac"" start to integrate the more free-form and abrasive sounds of Unmap towards the end
column10: you’re more likely to hear the spirituals of later Talk Talk than anything truly confrontational.

column1: Still
column2: they never overpower Vernon
column3: who focuses solely on his vocals here and anthologizes every mode he’s been in for the past half decade. His most quoted line by now is “I was not magnificent
column4: ” and Repave answers “like hell I wasn’t.” A couple of my colleagues noted the influence of Bruce Springsteen on this record
column5: and while I concur
column6: it’s more of a visual than a sound. On late-album lighter-waver “Alaskans”
column7: you can sense a perspirant Vernon two hours into a cathartic
column8: marathon show
column9: toweling himself down
column10: sitting at a piano bench. There’s a performative edge that might seem out of place in Bon Iver-- even though the band’s personnel exploded to over a dozen
column11: you still have the expectation that Vernon’s singing his pain up there. As he explained to Ryan Dombal
column12: Volcano Choir doesn’t just sound romantic or like make-out music
column13: it’s distinctly sexual. When he sings ""We're talkin’ real love” in a seductive lower register on “Alaskans”
column14: it’s like the drums were removed so you can hear the adulation of the crowd in your mind. Vernon howls “I won’t beg for you on acetate” and it’s a knowing
column15: self-referential barb from a guy whose music often gets characterized as doing just the opposite.

column1: What Volcano Choir get out of this is the ability to indulge in extravagant power balladry without taking on the seemingly requisite overblown persona where all this heavy lifting is necessary when you're carrying the weight of the world. But just as often
column2: the subtle levity gets a little too heightened. Had Vernon done away with lyrics completely and gone Wisconsin Hopelandic on us
column3: Repave might be worthy of being called the third Bon Iver album
column4: which it sorta is-- the majestic choruses of “Tiderays” and “Comrade” are way more in line with Bon Iver’s “Perth” or “Calgary” than anything on Unmap. But too often
column5: Vernon’s lyrics range from puzzling to utterly too goofy to ignore
column6: creating a discomfiting dissonance with the stone cold sobriety of the music.

column1: Authenticity is always something of a bugaboo outside of Vernon’s main gig-- you use For Emma
column2: Forever Ago and Bon Iver as standards and everything’s going to sound potentially insincere by comparison. Usually
column3: skepticism is succesfully met head on-- the louche and lewd nature of Gayngs assured that while they weren’t winking
column4: they were definitely leering. As far as the blue-collar
column5: cheesehead rawk of Shouting Matches
column6: the whole point is to remind you that Vernon is a Wisconsinite from Eau Claire
column7: not just a dude who happened upon a cabin there. For all I know
column8: Vernon might be entering his Ghostface Killah ca. Supreme Clientele phase-- simply toying with words for maximum surrealistic value. But while Repave's sounds trigger skygazing
column9: googly-eyed emotion
column10: lines like ""tossin' off your compliments
column11: wow/ sexin' all your Parliaments"" and ""that Ticonderoga shit/ made my mind and my heart/ all split up over/ the floor of the jackpot"" can make you immediately question how much you should trust them.

column1: Vernon explained Repave's carnality as damn near necessary in the indie rock discussion: ""It's been built up so hard and so high that people are afraid...I'm talking about how what happens between people is so misunderstood even between the people who are having sex. Maybe some of the lyrics on this record are my way of cracking the egg."" It's a noble cause
column2: but indicative of the obfuscation and loopiness that undermines Repave; he uses a mixed metaphor to describe what might happen if people discuss the emotions that result from a physical act. But in the way its tremendously seductive and overwhelming overtures can be jeopardized by one embarrassing line or wrong move
column3:
Repave does become a realistically sexualized record. Just not exactly in the way it intended.

"|18447.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18447-volcano-choir-repave/|7.8|Ian Cohen

Arish Khan may surround himself with an army of nine and call himself a king
column3: but at heart
column4: he's a court jester. For all the voodoo mystique and sex-machine swagger he wields onstage
column5: his songs brim with anxiety and humility
column6: whether he’s lusting after cute record-store clerks
column7: professing his weakness for plus-size paramours
column8: or measuring his commitment in food stamps. It’s the sort of charm offensive that comes naturally when-- as a brown man in the traditionally white world of garage-punk
column9: not to mention in Khan’s adopted hometown of Berlin-- you’ve lived your life as an outsider among outsiders. But in the six years that have passed since he and his band the Shrines last released a new album
column10: Khan’s sassy self-deprecation has turned to sobering introspection
column11: and for good reason. He’s endured the death of three close friends (including punk-rock pal Jay Reatard)
column12: and a reportedly nasty falling-out with long-time collaborator Mark “BBQ” Sultan (his frequent partner in crime since their late-90s tenure in Montreal’s the Spaceshits); the cumulative effect of all this turmoil saw Khan seeking solace in psychiatric hospitals and Buddhist monasteries alike. If his 2011 solo release for Scion’s A/V series-- released under the ad-hoc King Khan Experience banner-- sounded like a mess
column13: that’s because
column14: well
column15: at the time
column16: he felt like one.

column1: But if you need any proof that Khan is back to fighting trim
column2: just look at the spine of his latest record
column3: which bears not only the imprimatur of the Shrines-- the band that brings out the show-bizzy best in him-- but the logo of his first proper U.S. label: Merge Records. (Khan’s 2008 Vice Records issue
column4: The Supreme Genius of King Khan and The Shrines was a compilation culled from various European releases.) Khan’s work with the Shrines has typically drawn from the funk
column5: psych
column6: and soul of the turn-of-the-’70s black-power era
column7: but seemingly had little use for its ideological intent. Idle No More
column8: however
column9: takes an inverse approach: its fusion of Brian Jones-era Rolling Stones paisley pop and Spectorian pomp pushes Khan and the Shrines beyond their usual JBs jones
column10: but the album’s title speaks to a burgeoning social consciousness. It’s named for an emergent Canadian Aboriginal-rights protest movement
column11: one Khan particularly identifies with after spending his teen years hanging on reservations in Quebec with a Mohawk friend (one of the aforementioned casualties). Though there’s not a single song here that explicitly addresses the plight of First Nations people
column12: Khan has essentially donated his album title to the cause as if it were an advertising billboard-- the first indication of the album’s more sanguine
column13: openhearted spirit.

column1: Even in the absence of any overt political sloganeering
column2: Khan evinces a new sense of purpose here. The album’s first side counts as the most majestic music the King has produced
column3: blowing up his garage-rock roots to a cinematic scale without losing the ballsy attitude. The Shrines bring the brass
column4: of course
column5: but this time they’re bolstered by sweeping strings and ba-ba-da-ba choruses that transform songs like “Born to Die” and “Thorn in Her Pride” into the stuff glitzy 60s prime-time variety specials were made of. But the more opulent environs don’t dilute Khan’s finely tuned sense of irreverence: When he cops Lou Reed’s “and all the colored girls sing” directive prior to the latter songs’ “shoobie-doo-wop” finale
column6: it becomes immediately clear he doesn’t have the budget to hire an actual troupe of back-up singers
column7: so he just pitches his voice up and sings the hook himself. “Luckiest Man”
column8: meanwhile
column9: is a cheeky account of his soul-searching sojourn and recovery set to the buoyant groove of Archie Bell & the Drells’ northern-soul classic “Tighten Up”. But even when there’s a lightness and congeniality to the songs that Khan has rarely evinced before
column10: the Shrines’ big-band effect lends them an imposing wall-of-sound grandeur and fierce Motown momentum.

column1: That is
column2: until the brooding ballad “Darkness” brings the album’s vigorous pace to a screeching halt. A dark-soul-of-the-night document of his recent breakdown
column3: it should be Khan’s “It’s a Man’s Man’s Man’s World”
column4: a slow-burning
column5: show-stopping set piece that prompts the singer to his knees and bring the house down with him. Instead
column6: he opts for a campy
column7: drag-queen croon that saps the song of its emotional impact by constantly drawing attention to how far Khan is singing outside of his usual raspy range. From there
column8: Idle No More never fully regains its footing
column9: as the album tries to balance deeply personal subject matter and the Shrines’ party-hearty energy with inconsistent results: “Pray for Lil” (featuring a beautifully yearning guest lead vocal from Jena Roker) is a winsome tribute to Khan’s wife and the support she provided in his hour of need
column10: but the songs dedicated to late Atlanta garage-scene fixture Bobby Ubangi (“Bad Boy”) and Reatard (“So Wild”) feel a touch too slight and undercooked
column11: given their inspirations. However
column12: the closing Hendrixian ballad “Of Madness I Dream”
column13: peacefully reconciles Idle No More’s overarching themes of remorse and renewal--for King Khan
column14:
the premise of mourning and the promise of morning are one and the same. 

"|18448.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18448-king-khan-and-the-shrines-idle-no-more/|6.8|Stuart Berman
