“Most of the time Roky would have a yellow legal pad
column3: and he’d be sitting in the hallway somewhere
column4: writing music
column5: real weak and slumped down like that. He was a real nice little guy
column6: didn’t have a whole lot to say.” So remembers Bob Priest in the 2005 Roky Erickson documentary
column7: You’re Gonna Miss Me. According to Priest-- a psychiatrist at the maximum-security mental institution Rusk State Hospital in East Texas during Roky Erickson’s imprisonment there in the late 60s and early 70s-- writing music is what kept Erickson going during those horrifying years of compulsory electroshock therapy and Thorazine doses: “He wanted to write his music
column8: and he wanted to play his music. And that’s all. At least it took his mind off where he was.”

column1: The legend of Roky Erickson is one of the most compelling in rock history. As the leader of the 13th Floor Elevators
column2: he codified 60s psychedelia-- helping establish the genre’s American vernacular
column3: distinct from the prim Sgt. Pepper’s-isms of its British counterpart. Even further
column4: the native Texan staked out a parochial claim on druggy
column5: transcendental rock that was fuzzier and more deeply fried than the West Coast’s more cultured iteration. Regardless of geography
column6: it was clear Erickson claimed citizenship in one place and one place only: his own head. At Rusk
column7: he was forced to explore-- or retreat into-- previously uncharted fringes of that psychic territory. There he peered inward
column8: hummed to himself
column9: and wrote. And when he was released in 1974
column10: he took that yellow legal pad and set about making those visions real.

column1: Fits and false starts later
column2: The Evil One was made manifest. Erickson’s official solo debut album
column3: I Think of Demons
column4: was released on CBS in 1980
column5: but it was recorded concurrently-- by Creedence Clearwater Revival’s Stu Cook-- with the tracks that appear on The Evil One
column6: which came out in 1981 after Erickson had been shunted to the Columbia-subsidized indie label 415. Erickson was just as out of place on a new-wave imprint as he was on a major. By then
column7: he'd burned through a litany of sidemen and backing bands
column8: not to mention a significant amount of momentum. Still his songs refused to trade in on the lingering glory of the Elevators or 60s nostalgia at large
column9: hewing instead to a monster-movie fixation that-- at least in the arena where Erickson now found himself-- only the Misfits and the Damned might have been able to relate to. It was almost as if
column10: after serving nearly four years in the mental institution at Rusk
column11: he was being sentenced to another: punk.

column1: Thanks to synchronicity
column2: osmosis
column3: or both
column4: the punkness of The Evil One is one of its great strengths. Played by his new band the Aliens
column5: “Two Headed Dog” and “Bloody Hammer” pump and slam with a stiff
column6: chiseled precision that couldn’t be further from the Elevators’ shimmering multi-dimensionality. Then again
column7: Erickson is a fucking monster-- one who sings about monsters. In a spasms of feral
column8: lip-twisted fury
column9: he snarls about demons
column10: zombies
column11: vampires
column12: ghosts
column13: and demons again with all the intensity of a rabies victim. That said
column14: the album has just as much in common with the progressive
column15: sci-fi-obsessed hard rock of Blue Öyster Cult-- or the lurid phantasmagoria of Alice Cooper
column16: minus the camp-- as it does with punk.

column1: The best-known track on The Evil One
column2: “I Walked With a Zombie”
column3: neatly pinpoints Erickson’s perception of rock'n'roll circa 1980. It’s batshit-- but in the most composed way
column4: possessing the kind of coherent
column5: clear-eyed
column6: convinced-of-its-own-sanity insanity that makes the blood of the observer run cold. Zombies it is
column7: then
column8: as Erickson draws on (or gives in to) his preoccupation with George Romero’s Night of the Living Dead and the Ronettes’ “Be My Baby”-- decades before those signifiers would become self-consciously cool again. There’s also something eerily Television-like about the oscillating
column9: icicle guitars and the emotionless petrification of Erickson’s voice. He may have
column10: as he sings
column11: “walked with a zombie last night”-- but the zombie probably had more to fear than Erickson did.

column1: The Evil One is getting a fresh coat of paint as part of a trifecta of Erickson reissues
column2: the other two being Don’t Slander Me and Gremlins Have Pictures
column3: both from 1986. Their genius is less feverish
column4: but only by a few degrees. Originally released on the retro-garage label Pink Dust
column5: Erickson was now being lumped in with the pointy-booted likes of Plan 9 and Plasticland-- not to mention a forward-looking new psychedelic outfit called the Flaming Lips
column6: whose Pink Dust debut Hear It Is also came out in 86. Perversely
column7: Don’t Slander Me has more in common with early Lips than with the retro-60s acts; predictably
column8: it still sounds like no one but Erickson.

column1: If Erickson’s schizophrenic paranoia was on the rise-- at the time he was fanatically obsessed with finding messages in random pieces of mail
column2: leading to his arrest in 1989 for mail theft-- his music didn’t show it. The Aliens now gone
column3: he led his new outfit the Explosives through a lean
column4: sinewy batch of songs that display Erickson at his most lucid and direct. True
column5: he sings about “false gods” and “devils” on the album’s title track
column6: but the song also ditches the hard-rock sheen of The Evil One in favor of souped-up garage rock. Erickson sounds more at home in his skin
column7: even as he sings far more prosaic lyrics about love and
column8: well
column9: the Bermuda Triangle. There’s even a lunge toward power-pop on the ringing
column10: jangly “Starry Eyes” and the Buddy Holly-esque “You Drive Me Crazy”
column11: which aches so sincerely for Erickson’s lost 60s that his “heart pounds suffocatingly loud.” And even when he laughs maniacally after singing “the candles in my candelabra burn hellishly” in “Burn the Flames”
column12: it’s good
column13: clean
column14: Halloweenish fun.

column1: The cleanliness and control of Don’t Slander Me makes for a more palatable but less vital Erickson. Gremlins Have Pictures has no such problem. Culled from a decade’s worth of live recordings and studio outtakes-- ranging from his first post-incarceration show in Austin in 1975 to his sessions for Slander-- Gremlins provides a candid peek under Erickson’s hood during his most potent years as a solo artist. Top to bottom
column2: it’s a revelation. Songs that would later appear on The Evil One
column3: including “Night of the Vampire” and “Cold Night for Alligators” (renamed “It’s a Cold Night for Alligators”)
column4: are rendered live
column5: jagged
column6: and unhinged enough for the chaos of Erickson’s subconscious to bleed through. And his pummeling cover of the Velvet Underground’s “Heroin” is so hoarse and harrowing
column7: it gives new insight into the taken-for-granted original.

column1: But it’s the acoustic material on Gremlins Have Pictures that truly stuns. The queasy slide guitar on “I Am” removes any semblance of solid ground from Erickson’s hammering folk and Satanic sentiment; “Song to Abe Lincoln”
column2: with its lo-fi sing-song and off-kilter shuffle
column3: could pass for the Shaggs; “I Have Always Been Here Before” allows Erickson to extend his titular paradox into a skeletal meditation on memory-- both its contents and its malfunction. Of Gremlins’ many high points
column4: “I’m a Demon” sears the brain most vividly. An unplugged
column5: unaccompanied rockabilly stomper that suffers not at all from its starkness
column6: the song burns through a litany of variations on Erickson’s beloved demon motif: “I’m a demon and I love rock'n'roll”; “I’m a demon/ I have a big family”; and spine-chillingly
column7: “I see a demon/ And at the same time I see you.” It’s an eternal
column8: elemental performance
column9: a roughhewn mass of outsider self-exorcism that echoes alongside Hasil Adkins
column10: Syd Barrett
column11: Jonathan Richman
column12: Daniel Johnston
column13: and Alex Chilton. It does this all in a minute and a quarter.

column1: Erickson’s place in the pantheon of outsider art isn’t in question. The best thing about this trio of reissues
column2: though
column3: is how accessible Erickson actually is. Even at his most deranged
column4: his songs snag and beguile the mind with jagged remnants of classic pop-rock hooks-- as if remembered from a previous life-- and imagistic twists of phrase that turn schlock into catharsis and b-movies into mythic sagas. Erickson’s own myth does not enter into the equation. After his comeback bid in the 80s
column5: he wound up retreating again
column6: popping up occasionally in the 90s and early 00s before You’re Gonna Miss Me (and a new generation of disciples) sparked his current renaissance. He may be a character in his own narrative
column7: hero and/or villain
column8: but he sings from the perspective of a man standing outside himself
column9: having escaped the prison he carries with him. If only for a few minutes at a time-- just long enough to commit it to his yellow legal pad
column10:
or what passes for it.

column1: The cleanliness and control of Don’t Slander Me makes for a more palatable but less vital Erickson. Gremlins Have Pictures has no such problem. Culled from a decade’s worth of live recordings and studio outtakes-- ranging from his first post-incarceration show in Austin in 1975 to his sessions for Slander-- Gremlins provides a candid peek under Erickson’s hood during his most potent years as a solo artist. Top to bottom
column2: it’s a revelation. Songs that would later appear on The Evil One
column3: including “Night of the Vampire” and “Cold Night for Alligators” (renamed “It’s a Cold Night for Alligators”)
column4: are rendered live
column5: jagged
column6: and unhinged enough for the chaos of Erickson’s subconscious to bleed through. And his pummeling cover of the Velvet Underground’s “Heroin” is so hoarse and harrowing
column7: it gives new insight into the taken-for-granted original.

column1: But it’s the acoustic material on Gremlins Have Pictures that truly stuns. The queasy slide guitar on “I Am” removes any semblance of solid ground from Erickson’s hammering folk and Satanic sentiment; “Song to Abe Lincoln”
column2: with its lo-fi sing-song and off-kilter shuffle
column3: could pass for the Shaggs; “I Have Always Been Here Before” allows Erickson to extend his titular paradox into a skeletal meditation on memory-- both its contents and its malfunction. Of Gremlins’ many high points
column4: “I’m a Demon” sears the brain most vividly. An unplugged
column5: unaccompanied rockabilly stomper that suffers not at all from its starkness
column6: the song burns through a litany of variations on Erickson’s beloved demon motif: “I’m a demon and I love rock'n'roll”; “I’m a demon/ I have a big family”; and spine-chillingly
column7: “I see a demon/ And at the same time I see you.” It’s an eternal
column8: elemental performance
column9: a roughhewn mass of outsider self-exorcism that echoes alongside Hasil Adkins
column10: Syd Barrett
column11: Jonathan Richman
column12: Daniel Johnston
column13: and Alex Chilton. It does this all in a minute and a quarter.

column1: Erickson’s place in the pantheon of outsider art isn’t in question. The best thing about this trio of reissues
column2: though
column3: is how accessible Erickson actually is. Even at his most deranged
column4: his songs snag and beguile the mind with jagged remnants of classic pop-rock hooks-- as if remembered from a previous life-- and imagistic twists of phrase that turn schlock into catharsis and b-movies into mythic sagas. Erickson’s own myth does not enter into the equation. After his comeback bid in the 80s
column5: he wound up retreating again
column6: popping up occasionally in the 90s and early 00s before You’re Gonna Miss Me (and a new generation of disciples) sparked his current renaissance. He may be a character in his own narrative
column7: hero and/or villain
column8: but he sings from the perspective of a man standing outside himself
column9: having escaped the prison he carries with him. If only for a few minutes at a time-- just long enough to commit it to his yellow legal pad
column10:
or what passes for it.

“Most of the time Roky would have a yellow legal pad
column3: and he’d be sitting in the hallway somewhere
column4: writing music
column5: real weak and slumped down like that. He was a real nice little guy
column6: didn’t have a whole lot to say.” So remembers Bob Priest in the 2005 Roky Erickson documentary
column7: You’re Gonna Miss Me. According to Priest-- a psychiatrist at the maximum-security mental institution Rusk State Hospital in East Texas during Roky Erickson’s imprisonment there in the late 60s and early 70s-- writing music is what kept Erickson going during those horrifying years of compulsory electroshock therapy and Thorazine doses: “He wanted to write his music
column8: and he wanted to play his music. And that’s all. At least it took his mind off where he was.”

column1: The legend of Roky Erickson is one of the most compelling in rock history. As the leader of the 13th Floor Elevators
column2: he codified 60s psychedelia-- helping establish the genre’s American vernacular
column3: distinct from the prim Sgt. Pepper’s-isms of its British counterpart. Even further
column4: the native Texan staked out a parochial claim on druggy
column5: transcendental rock that was fuzzier and more deeply fried than the West Coast’s more cultured iteration. Regardless of geography
column6: it was clear Erickson claimed citizenship in one place and one place only: his own head. At Rusk
column7: he was forced to explore-- or retreat into-- previously uncharted fringes of that psychic territory. There he peered inward
column8: hummed to himself
column9: and wrote. And when he was released in 1974
column10: he took that yellow legal pad and set about making those visions real.

column1: Fits and false starts later
column2: The Evil One was made manifest. Erickson’s official solo debut album
column3: I Think of Demons
column4: was released on CBS in 1980
column5: but it was recorded concurrently-- by Creedence Clearwater Revival’s Stu Cook-- with the tracks that appear on The Evil One
column6: which came out in 1981 after Erickson had been shunted to the Columbia-subsidized indie label 415. Erickson was just as out of place on a new-wave imprint as he was on a major. By then
column7: he'd burned through a litany of sidemen and backing bands
column8: not to mention a significant amount of momentum. Still his songs refused to trade in on the lingering glory of the Elevators or 60s nostalgia at large
column9: hewing instead to a monster-movie fixation that-- at least in the arena where Erickson now found himself-- only the Misfits and the Damned might have been able to relate to. It was almost as if
column10: after serving nearly four years in the mental institution at Rusk
column11: he was being sentenced to another: punk.

For 20 years
column2: Richard Buckner has elusively drifted through alt-country
column3: electric folk
column4: acoustic rock. Over the past decade
column5: he has shrouded his abstract singer/songwriter music with vast
column6: ominously serene arrangements. But no matter which way Buckner tacks
column7: he always contrasts imagery so nonfigurative it seems shaped from vapor with tactile
column8: oaken music. His deep-grained acoustic guitar playing is splintery as a raw plank. His voice is a long gnarled shape with a silky finish
column9: like a sea-polished branch
column10: and gives a roughshod impression that belies its smooth range and secure pitch. Its heaviness is most affecting when it floats vulnerably high to breathe out the merest hints of a narrative
column11: as on ""Portrait""
column12: one of many gorgeously charged songs on new discography highlight Surrounded.

column1: As much as I love the Buckner of early classics such as ""Rainsquall""
column2: where he beat up his guitar like it owed him money and sang as stridently as a car alarm
column3: I prefer the oracular poise and oceanic atmosphere he cultivated during the mid 2000s on Dents and Shells and Meadow. That's probably why I didn't strongly connect with his arid 2011 comeback Our Blood
column4: which some regarded as a stripped-down return to form. But there were some concrete problems with it
column5: too. Owing to a series of misfortunes
column6: he remade the album twice
column7: and you could tell: it felt threadbare
column8: leached of inspiration. It's hard not to receive the lush
column9: focused Surrounded as a correction. You can hear the difference as soon as you press play
column10: with the title track's acoustic guitar dancing crisply in a full reflective cloud
column11: languid high harmonies pouring over Buckner's dreamiest croon like honey.

column1: Buckner sent off his tracks for mixing to the ubiquitous Tucker Martine as soon as he finished them
column2: to prevent loss and overthinking
column3: and frequently bottled lightning. He used an electric autoharp and an octave pedal to create a stormy
column4: bright-seamed sound profile for the album
column5: with piercing melodies condensed out of dark
column6: sliding layers of pulses and drones. The shaker percussion on the darkly coiled ""When You Tell Me How It Is"" comes back several times
column7: reinforcing the general sense of something about to strike. ""Foundation"" sails majestically on sweet
column8: choppy feedback
column9: while the extraordinarily tense ""Mood"" rumbles on a deep
column10: skipping howl. These are some of the boldest sounds he has ever put forward
column11: and that's before you even get to ""Cut""
column12: where the golden crests of his voice ride on what sounds like a sultry trance-gated organ.

column1: As one-of-a-kind lyricists go
column2: Buckner is the least quotable ever. He uses the plainest language to obscure rather than clarify
column3: slowly unspooling long
column4: slippery clauses that linger tantalizingly on the threshold of resolution.""It seems like you're there
column5: he sings
column6: ""as someone removed/ and left in their place/ with nothing to do."" There would be nothing exceptional about this careful
column7: evocative blankness if he didn't maintain it over the course of the album. It feels like one large
column8: refracted thought
column9: always just out of focal range
column10: which almost comes clear on the dusky and powerful conclusion ""Lean-To""
column11: with its uncommonly sharp-edged images of dying stars breaking windows and bodies swinging from rafters in the dark.

column1: The liner notes reveal that these lyrics are drawn from one continuous prose text; the most substantial foray into a mode Buckner previously explored on Since and Impasse. The printed lyrics are embedded with extra text in red
column2: which alters the implications of the sung words. You can see how he freely breaks lines across sentences to add even more shades to his meaning-- which matters a lot when your meaning is nothing but shades. That sense of loaded omission that defines his lyrics is confidently placed on display
column3: on a record marked by a revivified confidence. Buckner has long been a cherished cult object
column4: fuelled by the devotion of the few (especially the ones at Merge who keep him afloat with that Arcade Fire war chest)
column5:
but Surrounded is polished and persuasive enough that everyone should give it a try.

When Brandon Stosuy interviewed Chris Alfieri
column2: co-founder and guitarist for the New Hampshire metal band Vattnet Viskar
column3: last year
column4: he asked what the band's name-- Swedish for ""the water whispers""-- meant  to them. Alfieri's reponse was blunt: ""Currently
column5: I interpret our name to signify the environment's constant passive reminder that we're slowly destroying it."" Alfieri also waxed lyrical about his home state
column6: telling Stosuy that ""New Hampshire is a land of contrast. Cold
column7: bleak winters give way to hot
column8: humid summers. The green leaves of spring burn red orange in the fall. You can see the ocean from the mountains."" The reverence and the lyric note in his voice provide some insight into the band's awe-inspiring
column9: violently gorgeous first full-length
column10: Sky Swallower.

column1: The album starts in the recognizable
column2: misty-forest environs of early Scandinavian black metal: Opener ""New Alchemy"" bludgeons with the familiar all-sixteenths assault of guitars
column3: drums
column4: and bass
column5: and the riff is a close harmonic cousin of Darkthrone's ""Transilvanian Hunger"". But after a few minutes of this locked spiral
column6: the grip slackens
column7: the drumming relaxes into eighth notes
column8: then quarters
column9: before the song yawns open into droning doom metal. By the end
column10: ""Alchemy"" has receded further into glimmering
column11: clean-toned guitar notes and lightly syncopated drum fills
column12: and we're no  longer in any one place: Vattnet have already stormed across acres of territory. They rage and mourn across this massive open space for the next 32 minutes
column13: and by the time the album has reached the regally chilly final track ""Apex""
column14: you
column15: too
column16: can see the ocean from the mountains.

column1: Like many other American metal bands (Inter Arma
column2: Deafheaven
column3: Woe
column4: and Castevet
column5: for example)
column6: Vattnet Viskar are stylistic nomads; in a field where every choice of drum beat is loaded with fiercely specific
column7: coded information
column8: they pluck useful stuff from wherever they find it. The middle-distance savagery of metalgaze
column9: dour instrumental rock
column10: the shuddering churn of doom metal-- Vattnet Viskar swallow it all
column11: all usually within the space of the same song. The expansive power chords opening the short instrumental ""Monarch"" could be from Arkansas doom outfit Pallbearer
column12: though when Nick Thornbury sings on the following track
column13: ""Breath of the Almighty
column14: his voice is harsh and guttural and wet-sounding in a way more reminiscent of death than black metal-- you can hear individual spit bubbles pop and gurgle in back of his throat. The band's full attack has a similarly muscular ugliness to it
column15: a visceral sound that can shrink suddenly pinhole-quiet.

column1: In his Show No Mercy interview
column2: Alfieri also talked about how hard the band thought about long-form structure-- peaks
column3: dynamics
column4: threading themes through a composition. This kind of under-the-hood point-plotting rarely sounds sexy
column5: but you can feel it
column6: even without an iota of musical training
column7: coursing beneath Sky Swallower's 38 minutes
column8: whispering beneath the roar. There are a few stunning moments on Sky Swallower when everything drops away: Midway through ""Breath of the Almighty"" for instance
column9: the band dissipates after three or so minutes and nothing is left but two strings of guitar and a bass. The moment hangs
column10: darkening
column11: for several minutes
column12: echoing a similar
column13: earlier interlude in ""Fog of Apathy"". The last sound on the album is a lone acoustic
column14: strumming two chords-- the lingering note of sadness
column15: maybe that pulses beneath Sky Swallower
column16:
trailing off.

0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/19637/homepage_large.34136cee.jpg|Hesitation Marks|3043.0|Nine Inch Nails|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Columbia']|2013-09-03 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:53:36.306949|"

In the past decade
column2: Nine Inch Nails have earned more notice for how they release their records than the songs that are actually on them. In his attempts to reach audiences beyond his faithful base of goths and gamers
column3: Trent Reznor has embraced both high concepts (2007’s interactive song-cycle Year Zero) and low overhead (2008’s self-released offerings Ghosts I-IV and The Slip); even a guy who got famous by screaming needed a good news hook to get himself heard over the incessant din of a quick-click online-music marketplace. For his latest Nine Inch Nails release
column4: Reznor is resorting to the most radical release strategy an independent-minded artist can employ in 2013: he’s re-signed to a major label. Those e-commerce experiments proved NIN can remain a viable business in the absence of corporate-funded marketing campaigns
column5: but he presumably wants something that not even 100 per cent royalty rates can buy you: to be a game-changing pop cultural force once again. And despite what tech-topian industry analysts would have us believe
column6: for the time being at least
column7: traditional tools like global major-label distribution and aggressive radio promotion still often mean the difference between an artist being a household name or a merely respected one.

column1: That said
column2: even as Reznor is rallying everyone from David Lynch to Downward Spiral cover artist Russell Mills to heighten the sense of occasion
column3: he’s not giving his Columbia Records benefactors an easy sell: The aptly titled Hesitation Marks is a record that pokes and prods and teases instead of going in for the kill. It’s the first record to bear the Nine Inch Nails name since Reznor announced a hiatus in 2009 but the valorous comeback narrative is undermined by the fact that Reznor often took five years to release new NIN albums anyway. Not to mention the fact that he's remained highly active in the interim
column4: releasing two albums with his trip-hoppy outfit How to destroy angels while embarking on a successful composing career that allowed us to see what he looks like in a suit. And yet Hesitation Marks is stuffed with more knowing resurrection references than Jay Z’s Kingdom Come-- for an artist whose every second lyric has begun with the word “I
column5: ” this could be Reznor’s most intensely self-reflexive work yet. But unlike the themes of depression
column6: madness
column7: and addiction that defined his most enduring music
column8: Hesitation Marks chronicles a more existential crisis of relevance. Accordingly
column9: its sound is skeletal and spare
column10: as if picking up right where The Slip’s more subdued second act left off
column11: with Reznor's usual adrenalized aggression replaced with jagged digital tics and queasy atmospheres.

column1: And yet the more austere
column2: minimalist approach allows Reznor to explore the outer limits of the Nine Inch Nails sound. Notwithstanding the ambient excursions of Ghosts I-IV
column3: NIN’s song-based post-millennial discography has mostly functioned within the sonic parameters laid down by Reznor’s all-time favorites-- Depeche Mode
column4: Berlin-era David Bowie
column5: Pink Floyd’s The Wall
column6: Jane’s Addiction
column7: and a pinch of Prince-- while seeming impervious to shifts in the contemporary dance-rock landscape. Hesitation Marks is much more in tune with the spartan grooves of the xx and the elastic electro of the Knife than his usual arena-rattling influences: “Copy of A” follows an uncannily similar trajectory as the latter duo’s “Full of Fire”
column8: locking into a motorik beat that remains coolly resolute in the face of all the intensifying textural disorder mounting overtop of it. In a world where there are no more Stabbing Westwards to kick around
column9: Reznor directs the song’s critique of conformity at himself: “I am just a copy of a copy of a copy/ Everything I say has come before.”

column1: For a song that acknowledges the predictability of lapsing into old patterns
column2: “Copy of A” ironically marks an intriguing change of pace for Nine Inch Nails
column3: stripping down their metal machine music and rebuilding it with only the most integral scraps. The best songs here follow a similar process of gradually fleshing out a skeleton
column4: from the fidgety funk of “Satellite” to the disquieting drive of “Disappointed”
column5: where wondrous
column6: Indian-inspired string swirls -- a la the Beatles’ “Within You
column7: Without You”-- cut through the song’s claustrophobic clap-track. And even when the threadbare presentation casts a harsh light on the odd underwritten lyric (“Hey!/ Everything is not/ Okay!”)
column8: Reznor introduces new melodic changes to push a song in unexpected new directions: just when you think “All Time Low” can’t get any closer to “Closer”
column9: the song detours into a kaleidoscopic coda that introduces a brief flash of radiant colour to Nine Inch Nails’ typically grim and grimy terrain.

column1: But the danger of stretching your sound out to its extremities is that it will eventually snap back in your face
column2: and the completely incongruous “Everything” overcompensates for Hesitation Marks’ ominous mood with a wincingly bright pop-punk chug-- and unflatteringly strained vocal from Reznor-- that sounds like a second-stage Warped Tour act trying to cover “Just Like Heaven”. And the album is ultimately lacking in the concision and sequential logic that made The Slip such an invigorating late-career triumph. For every circuit-overloading workout like “Copy of A” and “Disappointed”
column3: there are a number of tracks where Reznor reverts to the teeth-gnashing angst of old without the pig-marching blitzkriegs to back it up
column4: applying undue pressure on the the songs’ brittle structures. The all-too-aptly titled single “Came Back Haunted” is just that
column5: a ghost of Nine Inch Nails’ more convincing ragers
column6: while the album’s second half in particular is bogged down by dead-weight plodders (“Various Methods of Escape”
column7: “I Would For You”
column8: “In Two”) whose predictably amped-up choruses can’t enliven their sputtering tempos and flagging energy.

column1: Alas
column2: their presence mutes the impact of the strategically placed penultimate piece “While I’m Still Here”
column3: which
column4: with better lead-in tracks
column5: could’ve served as a more dramatic comedown moment
column6: but here feels like a pained stumble to the finish line; when Reznor says
column7: “I’m still here”-- overtop a synth line that flickers like a dying fluorescent light tube-- it feels less like a statement of survival and defiance than the ennui-ridden admission of an office drone. But in the album’s dying moments
column8: an encouraging sign of life emerges: a surprisingly playful series of saxophone blurts give way to the closing “Black Noise”
column9: a slow-motion 90-second swell of grueling guitar noise that feels like all of this album’s simmering tension bubbling up to the surface and ready to erupt. Hopefully
column10: next time
column11:
Reznor will unleash it without hesitation.

0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/19651/homepage_large.0133332f.jpg|The Silver Gymnasium|3141.0|Okkervil River|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['ATO']|2013-09-03 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:53:36.877348|"

Physical copies of Okkervil River’s eighth album-- their ATO Records debut-- include a map of frontman Will Sheff’s hometown of Meriden
column2: New Hampshire
column3: designed by the band’s long-time visual artist William Schaff. Points on the map correspond to songs on the tracklist to show where each is set. First single
column4: “This Is Our Season""
column5: takes places at Plainfield Elementary School before heading west on Chellis Road; “Walking Without Frankie” wanders from Soucy’s Gas Station over to the Lake of the Strangled Crane. It’s a clever visual element
column6: a reminder that packaging can complement an album and help shape our listening experience. Without getting into the debate over physical vs. digital
column7: I will say that holding the paper map in your hands as you listen to these new songs is very different from looking at a .pdf on your computer screen
column8: where it has no texture
column9: no physicality-- and therefore no memory rhyme of the real treasure maps that most children make of their own neighborhoods. That is exactly what Sheff and evoke with this piece of ephemera: the mystery of childhood
column10: the unbridgeable gulf between what was and what we remember.

column1: The Silver Gymnasium is
column2: in other words
column3: a coming-of-age album: 11 songs that plumb the loss of innocence and youth
column4: a young man’s first glimpses into the adult world of conflict
column5: compromise
column6: and confusion. It’s exactly as cohesive and novelistic as Okkervil river’s last decade’s worth of work
column7: which explored the mythology of rock and roll. In 2005 Black Sheep Boy told a phantasmagorical tale of Tim Hardin’s doomed character (from the song of the same title) coming to pained life
column8: while both 2007’s The Stage Names and 2008’s The Stand-Ins delved further into that world’s rock-and-roll grotesquerie
column9: famously wrenching “Sloop John B” out of Brian Wilson’s hands and casting it as a boat-trip to hell. Rather than romanticize the experience of a life spent in tour vans and on club stages
column10: Sheff presented it as a dark picaresque. This was a different way of writing what he knew
column11: and his fictions were drawn from liner notes
column12: band photos
column13: song lyrics
column14: and the tall tales of backstage crews in small markets.

column1: The difference between that string of albums and The Silver Gymnasium is that on this new album Sheff is singing about his own personal mythology
column2: mapping the terrain of his own life
column3: and commemorating (perhaps memorializing) old friends who’ve grown too far apart. Sheff has ostensibly mined this territory before
column4: on early tracks like “Listening to Otis Redding at Home During Christmas” (on the band’s second album Don’t Fall in Love with Everyone You See) or like “A Favor” (off their 2004 EP Sleep and Wake-Up Songs). But this album represents the deepest he has descended into this material as well as his most sustained examination of his own origins. While not quite as fantastical as previous albums
column5: The Silver Gymnasium avoids the pitfalls of self-absorption and confessionalism; he’s less a participant in these stories than an observer and enabler who understands his own memory is unreliable.

column1: Sheff evokes the milieu briskly
column2: hinting at a 1980s childhood without resorting to cheesy period details. “Tell me about the greatest show
column3: or the greatest movie you know
column4: ” he cajoles a friend on “Down Down the Deep River”
column5: “or the greatest song that you taped off the radio. Play it again and again. (It cuts off at the ending
column6: though.)” He’s literary without being pretentious (those parentheses are Sheff’s)
column7: his text-block lyrics lending themselves to slippery sentiments and corkscrew melodies. Those lines in particular
column8: much like the Meriden map
column9: are simultaneously personal and universal: every kid in 1988 was waiting for his or her favorite song to come on the radio
column10: and every kid was waiting for just the right moment to press <RECORD>. Yet Sheff manages to make the experience sound new and immediate
column11: not to mention loaded with uncomfortable meaning.

column1: Conceptually
column2: The Silver Gymnasium is sound; lyrically
column3: this is incredibly fertile territory and more than enough to hang an album on. Musically
column4: however
column5: it may be Okkervil River’s weakest to date. On previous albums Sheff sang like a man who had already seen too much in a single lifetime
column6: delivering his lines with a sputtering urgency that lent even the quieter songs a palpable dread. Meanwhile
column7: the band itself sounded like they were trying to stave off his hysteria. They played like a slap to the face. On <i>The Silver Gymnasium
column8: however
column9: they rarely let the cracks and strains show
column10: and the songs suffer considerably. There’s little menace or madness here; instead the music gives the false impression of emotional orderliness.

column1: This is Okkervil River’s first album working with producer John Agnello
column2: who has helmed period-specific albums by Cyndi Lauper and John Mellencamp
column3: among others. He lends these songs a careful sheen when they ought to sound taped off the radio. Synths play a prominent role on The Silver Gymnasium
column4: even more so now than when Jonathan Meiburg was still with the band. Rather than reach back to this particular era in pop music
column5: on “Stay Young” and “Lido Pier Suicide Car” the synths sound generically crisp
column6: reinforcing the sense of polish and calculation. Even the sax and harmonica solos on “Stay Young” are mixed low
column7: as though the band remains noncommittal about featuring those instruments.

column1: It’s hard to miss that this sonic development coincides with the band’s move from Jagjaguwar (their home for more than a decade) to ATO Records (home to the Drive-By Truckers
column2: Alabama Shakes
column3: and the True Blood soundtrack). Ostensibly they’re making a bid for a wider audience
column4: and why shouldn’t they? It would be amazing to hear how Sheff’s mythologies play to larger crowds in roomier venues. Okkervil River don’t have to sound right on the precipice of madness to be interesting
column5: but unfortunately The Silver Gymnasium buffs away their eccentricities and robs the music of its impact. They aim for jittery energy on “Walking Without Frankie”
column6: but it sounds inert. They shoot for triumphal on “On a Balcony”
column7: but there’s no heft to those backing vocals. They reach for tattered majesty on closer “Black Nemo”
column8: but they never hoist the flag quite high enough. Perhaps when performed live these songs will accrue the desperation and dynamism their studio versions lack
column9: but for now The Silver Gymnasium too often makes the act of remembering sound like a consequence-free undertaking
column10:
as though certain horrors are too far in the past to do us much harm in the present. Anyone with a memory-- especially Sheff-- knows that’s not the case.

John Wizards is one of those bright
column2: restlessly creative albums that transitions from one idea to the next the way a kid reels off details of a made-up story without ever considering how it might end. The music-- which with the exception of some vocal lines by a Rwandan singer named Emmanuel Nzaramba was recorded entirely by 25-year-old Cape Town
column3: South Africa resident John Withers-- is a bird's eye view of styles that are not only pan-African but
column4: as goes the great promise of cultural consumption in the internet age
column5: pan-global. Click down on one section of John Wizards and you'll hear the peppy end of Ghanaian highlife or the crisp optimism of Withers' native mbaqanga; click down on another and you'll hear 80s disco or swing-heavy instrumental hip-hop not all that far removed from Clams Casino
column6: executed in compact
column7: synthetic sounds that pop in the mix like foil-covered candy from a crystal dish.

column1: A self-diagnosed daydreamer who makes his living writing ad jingles
column2: Withers breaks down music into short
column3: catchy bursts. Most of the songs on John Wizards are under three minutes long
column4: and even those rarely hold onto a single melody or idea for more than 30 seconds. There are high points-- all of the kaleidoscopic opener ""Tet Lek Schrempf""
column5: most of ""Lushoto""
column6: the sweet
column7: Auto-Tuned vocal of ""I'm Still a Serious Guy""
column8: or ""iYongwe""'s guitar line
column9: which once heard required active mental scrubbing to forget-- but the album's strength is ultimately in its breadth
column10: not depth. Look too close and its songs crumble
column11: but take them as pieces of a whole and the music takes on the playful energy of a mixtape: sweeping its diversity
column12: charming in its curiosity
column13: and generally more geared to the pleasure of the listener than the self-expression of the artist.

column1: All of which can sometimes make John Wizards feel slight or disposable-- a Tumblr-era album made by an artist who functions more as a shrewd organizer of style than a composer of indelible music. Toward the end of an interview he did with Pitchfork in June
column2: Withers was asked two questions: One was if his employers in the ad business ever asked him to imitate other bands; the other was how he might feel if someone ever asked him to imitate John Wizards. The second question struck me as funny
column3: because Withers still basically sounds like an imitative musician. What sets him apart is the range and fluidity of his imitations
column4: and the unifying cheerfulness with which he executes them.

column1: Obviously African but easily fit into a conversation about contemporary American indie-pop
column2: released on the mostly-techno label Planet Mu despite not being a techno album
column3: satisfying an imagined ideal of post-internet globalism while remaining a personal and localized experience
column4: arriving at a time when hot colors and wild geometric patterns remain fashionable
column5: John Wizards is
column6: to paraphrase the anthropologist Claude Levi-Strauss' opinion on animals
column7: ""good to think with."" But that won't make people want to listen to it. What will is its hip diversity
column8: sunny disposition
column9: and the fact that Withers never asks more of his audience than he's willing to give: A man of contract
column10:
he puts his clients first.

column3: there is no scene. At least
column4: there’s no scene like they have in Copenhagen
column5: a community centered around the boutique Posh Isolation label started in 2009 by Christian Stadsgaard and Loke Rahbek. This is the label that launched a thousand Danish hardcore post-punk bands and their synth-noise side projects like Sexdrome
column6: Damien Dubrovnik
column7: Marching Church
column8: Lust For Youth
column9: Vår
column10: Lower
column11: and Iceage-- all of whom share at least one or more members between them. Andreas Lagerström
column12: the lead singer and bassist for Holograms
column13: said in an interview earlier this year
column14: “we have nothing like that in Stockholm. We really like Iceage [and] Lower but most of us didn’t know about them when we started.” Though
column15: he did admit to talking with Iceage on MySpace “like
column16: five years ago when they were like thirteen or something.”

column1: So there’s Posh Isolation and then there’s real isolation like what the young Holograms have experienced after a grueling and bank-breaking 2012 world tour. Returning to their homes in the night-swept winter of Stockholm with no jobs
column2: no money
column3: and no real scene to speak of
column4: their only lifelines were each other. Add in the only six or seven hours of sunlight that Stockholm was getting in the winter
column5: the backdrop for the band’s sophomore album Forever starts to come into focus. Even for hyperborean punk

column7: and their precedent for synth-heavy dourness on their self-titled debut
column8: it would be understandable for the band to turn in an exhausted and slapdash placeholder until conditions improved

column10: the factory-floor post-punk quartet doubled down on their sound and literally went for broke
column11: taking their fear and desolation and sending it out to near arena heights.

column1: Lead single
column2: the corporeal “Flesh And Bone” served as a bellwether as to where the band was heading
column3: but it was just the tip. Its Peter Hook bass line and down-stroked eighth-note guitars lead the album much like they lead the song-- Now they have more in common with the sharpness of Joy Division or even the thickness of Editors
column4: and creep further away from the electro-punk or hardcore-punk of their Danish doppelgangers. Most remarkable about Holograms is how they transform their pitch-black palate of sounds into something remarkably bright. Flying in the face of insular self-pity
column5: they avoid all the trappings of isolation and turn it into 10 songs whose every syllable warrants a fist pump.

column1: And that’s mainly because every syllable Lagerström sings in his hollow-headed voice is fully loaded with drama. Forever
column2: much like its artwork-- cropped from a William Bouguereau painting depicting two cursed souls battling in the pit of hell-- is about epic themes told with tendons and teeth. Near every song makes mention of fire
column3: whether in a positive light like the fire of love on “Luminous”
column4: or a funeral pyre on “Wolves"". Or sharing fire at the bottom of the ocean on “Rush”. Or fire and stone on “A Sacred State"". Or just all of “A Blaze On A Hillside"". Lagerström’s almost Promethean obsession with flames notwithstanding
column5: he always has one foot in his own reality and the other in something far more mythical. The songs strike a sort of lost-in-translation vibe between the personal and the preposterous
column6: like the sleepy ""Ättestupa""
column7: named after a kind of cliff where
column8: according to Nordic myth
column9: old men once threw themselves to their death when they were no longer useful. In a blind taste test
column10: you probably wouldn’t be able to tell the difference between an Opeth lyric and a Holograms lyric.

column1: But pair these songs of ice and fire with the band’s newfound lean rock look
column2: and that’s where it starts to kick. “Meditations” has this everybody-now chorus of “Destruction! Destruction! Destruction!” that is just the kind of populist punk Holograms can excel at. Likewise
column3: the finale of “Luminous” features a drunken pub-punk shout-chorus
column4: a refreshing break in the self-serious tone acting as welcomed and well-earned indulgence in a punk trope.

column1: On Forever
column2: Holograms take lofty themes and personal trials and make them a communal experience. They reflect their depression and mistrust into melodies with just enough pop to let people in
column3: never getting too cagey or technical. Though the too familiar Factory Records sound helps color the mood

column5: most biblical phrase about eternity seem deeply personal. He puts all his chips in the climactic “A Blaze On The Hillside”
column6: which might be the best update of “Transmission” that’s been written. Lagerström lets loose for the only time on the album and screams “Mother! Father!” in a moment of uncalculated emotion. Hs seems finally unconcerned with aesthetic
column7: or a scene
column8: or money
column9: or jobs
column10: or fire. As the show-stealing cameo from a theremin-style synth closes the song
column11: all of Holograms' debts-- emotional or otherwise-- are on the table. You'll probably be moved to help repay them
column12:
emotionally or otherwise.

Art gallery primness has always gnawed at the edge of Wolfgang Voigt's considerable output. He's mostly avoided it
column2: adopting new monikers and collaborators at the pace of a much younger artist. The rot has crept in lately

column7: Art Cologne-- returns to more pliable textures laid out in familiar
column8: rhythmic sequences that could reasonably be described as riffs. In that sense

column11: repetitive and limited

column13: repeating phrases.

column1: Zukunft is built from a paucity of elements
column2: containing essentially two sounds: a thick
column3: flatulent synth that functions as the bass
column4: and a high-pitched
column5: piano-like twinkle. Occasionally
column6: as on ""Z.O.M 1.4""

column8: though

column10: its patterns are boxy. It is music that rubs its limits in your face.

column8:

Vol. 10: Another Self Portrait (1969-1971)|1177.0|Bob Dylan|['Rock']|0.0|1.0|0.0|['Columbia']|2013-08-30 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:53:39.307087|"

It’s a little hard for those of us who weren’t there to understand the critical reaction to Bob Dylan’s 10th album
column3: 1970‘s Self Portrait. First
column4: let’s pause a moment to reflect on the fact that there was a 10th album already at that point
column5: only eight years and a few months after Dylan released his self-titled debut. It was a busy time: he wrote and performed
column6: culture was churning ahead and changing at what was then an unprecedented pace
column7: and some people in the music world thought of him as a sort of leader of a new consciousness. Into this world he released an album called Self Portrait. One imagines seeing that title and expecting something deeper
column8: heavier
column9: some kind of reckoning with what has gone before. But what the listening public got instead was a mish-mash-- a few original songs
column10: a few live cuts
column11: lots of covers
column12: and a generally disjointed sound. It seemed slapdash. And it caused Greil Marcus
column13: Dylan’s best critic
column14: to begin his review of the double album in Rolling Stone with the words “What is this shit?”

column1: The latest entry in Dylan’s Bootleg Series provides a new opportunity to evaluate the music of this period. Calling this volume Another Self Portrait
column2: including liner notes by Marcus
column3: and offering up a new painting by Bob Dylan as a cover image
column4: is a sly and gutsy move. By most accounts
column5: Dylan was hurt by the initial savaging of Self Portrait
column6: and rushed out its 1970 follow-up
column7: New Morning
column8: to put the album in the rearview as quickly as possible. Later
column9: there was a sense that he wanted to scrub it from his own history. In interviews
column10: Dylan sometimes suggested that Self Portrait was deliberately bad
column11: thrown together as a way to confuse his audience or provoke the media into moving on to someone else so that he could have more privacy in raising his family.

column1: Though we’ll never know exactly what he was thinking
column2: the idea of Dylan making a poor album on purpose never made sense. He worked with too many top-shelf musicians that he cared about
column3: and had friends and colleagues investing too much time
column4: to make something that would embarrass them. It seems more likely that the “intentionally bad” storyline was a defense mechanism for a mysterious artist who did
column5: after all
column6: have a pretty hefty ego and was deeply aware of his own talent. So it’s reasonable to conclude that Self Portrait was a strange and all-over-the-place album because
column7: for one reason or another
column8: that’s the kind of album Dylan wanted to make at that time.

column1: Another Self Portrait complicates the narrative. Considering the strength of these alternate takes
column2: demos
column3: stripped-down mixes
column4: and live cuts
column5: it's a little hard to believe that these were the cast-offs from what was perceived to be an artist’s worst album. Many of the songs come from the sessions for New Morning
column6: but there were no clear lines between Self Portrait and New Morning sessions in 1969 and 1970. Akin to Neil Young’s later method
column7: Dylan at the end of the 60s seems to have been about recording songs first
column8: lots of them
column9: and figuring out how they fit into an album later.

column1: There was a marked shift in Dylan's music at the end of the 60s. “For sure my lyrics had struck nerves that had never been struck before
column2: ” he wrote of this time in Chronicles Volume One
column3: “but if my songs were just about the words
column4: then what was Duane Eddy
column5: the great rock'n'roll guitarist
column6: doing recording an album full of instrumental melodies of my songs? Musicians have always known that my songs were more than just words
column7: but most people are not musicians.” This passage provides a good framework for understanding the music here. After the word-drunk work he’d created in the mid-60s
column8: and following the mysterious motorcycle accident that laid him up in 1966
column9: his music became simpler and more tuneful. Drawing on his longstanding interest in country music
column10: standards
column11: and any well-constructed song
column12: he began to write and perform songs that felt universal.

column1: That is where the deep and immense pleasure of this set resides: hearing melodies-- some new
column2: some old
column3: some borrowed-- performed by a distinctive singer at the height of his powers. The two discs are arranged for flow
column4: with songs roughly split along two lines. Disc one is mostly songs recorded prior to Self Portrait
column5: and is heavy on alternate versions of Dylan tunes and renditions of traditional songs. This “Time Passes Slowly” and the demo of “Went to See the Gypsy” don’t supplant better-known takes
column6: but they’re different enough in feel and arrangement to make the songs sound new. Other differences
column7: like the alternate version of Nashville Skyline’s “I Threw It All Away”
column8: are more subtle
column9: and the appeal is in hearing the song tinted by a new setting.

column1: But the real revelations on the first disc are the unreleased versions of songs from the public domain. It’s now accepted that Dylan returned to relevance late in his career when he released two albums of traditional songs
column2: 1992‘s Good as I Been to You and 1993‘s World Gone Wrong. The idea being that
column3: in times of trouble
column4: when he’s not sure where else to go
column5: the songs Dylan grew up with and studied were there for him. The versions here of “Railroad Bill”
column6: “Little Sadie”
column7: “Pretty Saro”
column8: and the especially powerful “This Evening So Soon” are brilliant showcases of his ability to inhabit old material and make it his own. And they benefit from the generally spare and acoustic sound. Dylan started his career singing traditional folk songs
column9: but his understanding of them eight years later was far richer.

column1: The second disc is heavier on versions of Dylan originals
column2: with roughly equal smatterings of alternate takes from Self Portrait
column3: New Morning
column4: and Nashville Skyline and live cuts from Dylan and the Band’s 1969 Isle of Wight Festival performance. Some of the differences in these versions are striking. The radically altered take of “If Not For You” is performed by Dylan with piano and violin
column5: making the song sound even more tender and vulnerable. There’s an alternate version of the funky Nashville Skyline trifle “Country Pie” that
column6: when it breaks down
column7: shows just how in-the-pocket his session pros were when playing live in the studio. There’s a version of “New Morning” with a shimmering horn section
column8: giving it an even more buoyant and joyous cast. “Wigwam”
column9: the instrumental that was given a bombastic treatment on the Self Portrait album
column10: is heard without orchestration
column11: revealing it as an effortlessly tuneful cowboy tune (the countrypolitan near-instrumental “All the Tired Horses” is heard in a similarly lean version).

column1: Most of the music is heard in versions with minimal instrumentation: Dylan’s guitar
column2: a second guitar adding fills
column3: sometimes piano. Which makes the set oddly cohesive and album-like
column4: ironically more so than the Self Portrait album itself. The outliers in this regard were also some of the stranger inclusions on the original album-- the in-concert tracks with the Band. Given that neither Dylan nor the Band played live during this period
column5: the fact that they came together for a massive festival was surely big news
column6: so the set is obviously of historical importance. That is doubly true since by this time the recordings they made together in Woodstock were leaking out on bootlegs like The Great White Wonder
column7: so the desire for Dylan/Band collaborations was high. But plucking random numbers from that Isle of Wight set didn’t make much sense on the original album
column8: and it doesn’t make much sense on Another Self Portrait either. The deluxe version of this set includes a disc with the full set
column9: which is welcome-- it has a ragtag charm
column10: Dylan mostly sings in his Nashville Skyline voice
column11: and the song selection is ace. But there’s still a weird distance to it all
column12: a lack of intensity that is hard to put a finger on
column13: with laid back versions of familiar tunes that don’t really probe for any new meanings.

column1: The deluxe version also includes a remastered version of the Self Portrait album proper. Returning to it
column2: it’s hard for those of us a generation or two younger to understand the reaction to it not because it paled in comparison to the greatness that came before
column3: because it obviously did. If you’ve spent any time listening to Bob Dylan’s 1960s catalog
column4: you are still trying to wrap your head around the thought that one person wrote the 56 songs on Bringing it All Back Home
column5: Highway 61 Revisited
column6: Blonde on Blonde
column7: John Wesley Harding
column8: and Nashville Skyline between 1965 and 1969. Self Portrait
column9: next to these records
column10: in that moment
column11: must have seemed like a joke. But later generations hear it differently. We’ve discovered Self Portrait in the used bins
column12: torrent downloads
column13: and streaming services alongside records like Street Legal
column14: Saved
column15: Empire Burlesque
column16: Down in the Groove
column17: and Under the Red Sky. And in this broader context
column18: it sounds quite good
column19: another weird and sloppy record from a guy who released a lot of them. And hearing it again with all the fantastic music that surrounded it
column20: music that further cements Dylan’s Bootleg Series as one of the most important archival projects in modern pop history

The past couple years haven't been too kind to Los Angeles sleaze merchants Icarus Line. In fact
column2: when you come to think of it

column6: an all-over-the-place
column7: holy mess of an album that all but completely sapped any momentum Penance Soiree might have gained them. By the time their fourth album--the snaky
column8: villainous Wildlife-- rolled around
column9: Icarus Line had been relegated to lifer status
column10: an act all but forgotten thanks to their cockroach-like ability to soldier on in the face of utterly toxic circumstances-- drugs
column11: money troubles
column12: lineup-shifting creative differences. Though largely ignored in spite of its obvious quality
column13: Wildlife marked the welcome return to the Stooge-ian hedonism of Penance Soiree. And now it's with Slave Vows that the Icarus Line continue on their road to redemption
column14:
offering up their best record since the one that should've made them contenders.

It's unlikely that the Icarus Line are going to hold it against you for brushing them off (""I don't care enough to hate you
column15: Cardamone grumbles on ""Rat's Ass"")
column16: but sure as hell don't expect them to hold your hand
column17: either. ""Dark Circles"" is an 11-minute ""fuck you"" of an opener
column18: moving from a squall of torrential feedback to seasick
column19: churning rhythms to an arid spaghetti Western-styled final act. It's not a great song
column20: but rather a warning that if you aren't with them
column22: and now would be a good time to get out of the way. What follows is more earthen and scorched than anything the band has released to date
column23: and while the formula on Slave Vows is fairly consistent-- songs start out comely
column25: only to explode into id-startled fits of furious chaos and noise-- nothing feels forced or wasted. Recorded live to tape (the band's preferred method)

column27: complete with acid-scarred guitars and Cardamone's unique yelps and mutters and screams
column28:
which exude as much sex as they do terror.

""It's my fault I'm dedicated
column30: sounding uncommonly principled for once. But it's his commitment to keeping Slave Vows as feral and uncompromising as it ultimately needs to be is what makes it so exciting. ""Marathon Man"" starts out snarling and slow
column31: eventually giving way to a torrent of strangled noise that suggests every instrument is being physically wrestled and beaten into submission like rabid dogs. Even better is the sordid
column33: which starts off sounding like the perfect soundtrack for a good old fashioned roll in the glass
column34: but as it explodes with such raw power and hellish riffage
column35:
the only thing it feels good for is triggering a panic attack. It's a jarring reminder of the viciousness this band is capable of.

Very little has been written about the Icarus Line without some mention of Iggy and the Stooges
column36: and it's no wonder. Visit the band's official website

column38: garage and no wave acts is to discount just how good they are at translating and nourishing these touchstones. If you could convincingly pull off an approximation of the Stooges frenzied fusion of sex and danger
column39: then why the hell wouldn't you? Only on the final three tracks do the band go full Wild Child
column42: slavish are instead nothing but a pleasure. The closest they get here to an actual bite is ""No Money Music""
column43: which sounds almost exactly like Suicide's ""Ghost Rider""
column45:
echoed screams. In less capable hands it would feel cliché; here it's convincingly harried and frightening and nuts.

Slave Vows could use a little fine tuning
column46: of course. At 45 minutes it's shorter than Penance Soiree
column47: but lacks its concision and punch
column48: at times wading a little too deeply into the indulgent waters of burdened
column49: discordant blooze. And Cardamone-- despite convincingly inhabiting the sunken-eyed Lothario he truly is-- plays up the misestimated shock value a little more than he needs to (""Brick by brick
column50: white people are fucking sick""). But at its core

column53: Cardamone murmurs on the sulphuric ""Laying Down for the Man"". If Slave Vows is any indication

column2: the UK label REKIDS released a single from an underground Brooklyn production duo Runaway
column3: comprised of Jacques Renault and Marcos Cabral
column4: which was subsequently snatched up and released stateside by the DFA. “Brooklyn Club Jam” was precisely that
column5: a track buoyed by an echoey piano line that built into a track and felt right at home amid house
column6: disco
column7: and electro without being beholden to any one genre. It also felt like one of the first well-beneath-the-radar “Made in Brooklyn” tracks to travel far outside of the borough to other cities. For those listening close
column8: it suggested that something was brewing beyond the island of Manhattan.

column1: And while his Runaway counterpart Jacques Renault has gone on to throw the popular “Let’s Play House” party and release records on an imprint of the same name
column2: Cabral has kept a relatively low profile. Yet it was his 24 Hour Flight EP on the nascent Long Island Electrical Systems (L.I.E.S.) that began to turn heads
column3: both to Cabral and to the label that released it. And for good reason: the extremely limited release showed Cabral to be a master craftsman at making hypnotic and deep three o’clock in the morning style tracks. So it makes a certain amount of sense that L.I.E.S.’s inaugural full-length artist release would also come from Cabral
column4: marking his first album with False Memories.

column1: But as its title suggests
column2: things are not quite as they appear
column3: as instead of offering up a selection of tracks that might complement the sounds to be found on 24 Hour Flight and subsequent releases
column4: False Memories instead digs into Cabral’s personal cassette tape archive. As the press sheet for the album notes
column5: the album’s 14 tracks stem from Cabral’s initial forays into recording
column6: done while living in upstate New York. “I knew nothing about ‘making’ music at this time and was using this fairly primitive wav-looping program called Acid
column7: ” Cabral wrote
column8: using a 303 and his computer to make loops.

column1: The result offers a very rough
column2: primitive portrait of the producer
column3: which hews close to the L.I.E.S. aesthetic but not always to Cabral’s strengths. Opener “Downhill” is murky and throbbing but while its metallic stabs shine through
column4: not much else happens on the track. The kinetic three-minute “Homemade Muffler” suggests the junkyard playfulness of Eric Copeland's recent Joke in the Hole. There’s an almost cartoonish scampering sound running head on into a 303’s kick
column5: which sends noisy curlicues shooting off in every direction.

column1: The tiny squelches and cricket-sized noises of “North Carolina” remind me at times of the obtuse releases of Lithops
column2: the solo guise of Mouse on Mars’ Jan St. Werner. But where those tracks fidget
column3: Cabral is cautious
column4: feeling his way through the track. “Unusually Early” mixes pulses
column5: snare hits
column6: and another drum sound flanged to the extreme
column7: with no other melodic element
column8: to where its three minutes seem to last a lifetime. “Repaired Clocks” has a stronger beat but still feels incomplete
column9: missing the sound of Cabral’s chords that would emerge on later productions. Loping and lo-fi as “Virginia” is
column10: it has a lightness not to be found elsewhere courtesy of a metallic snare sound stretched like taffy. “Broken Clocks” is the grittiest and most distorted track on here
column11: as if transmitted through heavy static.

column1: False Memories is true its intent of documenting the sound of experimentation at its most unlearned by a producer who has an excellent touch for his productions in the present moment. Unfortunately
column2: here ""experimenting"" mostly means letting the tape run as one plays with pitch and gain
column3: or else cloaking everything in delay
column4: or else turning the filter knob every which direction. For the first long look at Cabral for most outside of L.I.E.S. devotees
column5:
it’s unlikely to make a lasting impression.

Golden Suits
column2: the new project from Department of Eagles' Fred Nicolaus
column3: takes its name from the last line in John Cheever's ""The Country Husband."" It's the story of a man who
column4: after surviving a plane crash no one in his life seems to care much about
column5: rapidly comes unmoored from the things he's come to know. His wife leaves him
column6: he acts up in front of friends and neighbors
column7: he falls for the underaged babysitter. ""Country Husband"" examines the intersection of our public and private selves
column8: about the things we hold back to make it through the day. Nicolaus is something of a Cheever obsessive; the video for Golden Suits' ""Swimming in '99"" finds Nicolaus criss-crossing Manhattan
column9: looking to buy up every copy of The Stories of John Cheever he can get his hands on. But his relationship with ""The Country Husband"" goes well beyond the need to fill empty bookshelves. In the year or so leading up to Golden Suits
column10: he underwent a massive
column11: life-upending transformation of his own. He went broke
column12: saw the end of a longstanding relationship
column13: lost an apartment to a rat infestation
column14: and dropped 40 pounds.

column1: Despite the hardships
column2: Nicolaus puts on a fairly good face throughout Golden Suits. On the surface
column3: Golden Suits is a lilting folk-pop record
column4: deliberate as they come
column5: swimming in sumptuous
column6: sunlit arrangements. With their nimble verses floating into stately
column7: borderline regal choruses
column8: Nicolaus is clearly aiming for a certain time-honored decorousness here
column9: hewing to classic forms at every turn
column10: letting any weirdness seep out in the arrangements. He's a precise vocalist
column11: hanging out just behind the beat
column12: finding some space for every syllable. Still
column13: that kind of composure does seem a bit at odds with the Nicolaus who's spent the last year picking through the wreckage of his life.

column1: This authorial detachment-- along with all the flirting-with-anodyne ""classic"" structures-- occasionally leaves Golden Suits feeling guarded. Nicolaus
column2: a student of the short story
column3: will set a scene (""Restaurant Song"")
column4: introduce a character or two (""Dearly Beloved
column5: ""Little One"")
column6: toss out couple tantalizing details
column7: and leave it at that; he makes plenty of intimations of loss and regret-- ""please tell me you need me
column8: keep me where I am
column9: that sort of thing-- but rarely does it feel like he's laying it all out there for you. This ambiguity leaves Golden Suits feeling both safe and slightly unknowable
column10: as Nicolaus-- perhaps still gun-shy after everything he's had to endure-- plays things just a little too close to the chest.

column1: Between the straightforward songcraft and the spare lyricism
column2: there's plenty of space to fill. Whether it's a scurry of strings (arranged by Kris Nolte and Ian Davis of Mason Jar Music)
column3: a warbling clarinet
column4: or an anxious Rossen-style arpeggio
column5: instruments sweep in and out of these songs like gusts of wind. While the songs themselves stay on the straight-and-narrow
column6: these arrangements often lead them into strange places; the serrated guitar underneath highlight ""Find a Way"" sways like a drunkard trying his damnedest to stay upright
column7: and the harmonies swirling around ""You Can't Make Your Mind Up""-- courtesy of Ava Luna's Becca Kauffman and Felicia Douglass-- split the difference between eerie and ethereal. Best of all is ""Dearly Beloved""
column8: its trickling guitars abruptly rising like crashing waves. Nicolaus seems to be counting on this instrumental interplay to amplify the implicit drama in his lyrics. Truth is
column9: it usually works the other way; next to this rich
column10: peculiar music
column11:
Nicolaus' reticence to reveal too much leaves Golden Suits' story feeling a little unfinished.

In the grand scheme of things
column2: Vasaeleth are still a pretty new band. The first proper introduction to the Georgia/Colorado duo came courtesy of a 2009 EP-- our loyalty was won halfway through the savage opener “Figures of Chained Spirits”. That they bounced to Profound Lore the following year to release their debut full-length
column3: Crypt-Born and Tethered to Ruin
column4: hasn’t hurt
column5: nor have two split releases with perfectly-suited conspirators Vorum and Cruciamentum. Crypt-Born was a sleeper hit with the black/death elite; four years later
column6: it seemed high time for O.A. and Antinom to release a new full-length. Anticipation ballooned when Profound Lore announced its arrival
column7: but instead of the long-playing overdose of death metal one may have expected
column8: we’ve been blindsided with a short shock of an EP.

column1: All Uproarious Darkness blasts by in under 20 minutes
column2: with nary a song stretching beyond the four-minute mark. In a subgenre characterized by excess-- more distortion
column3: more blastbeats
column4: more riffs
column5: more violence-- Vasaeleth have delivered a lethal death strike in the amount of time it takes lesser bands to hit their first Incantation-biting groove. That influence is there
column6: of course; the crumbling road to Golgotha has nearly buckled under the past few years’ heavy traffic
column7: but out of the many au current old-school death metal bands
column8: Vasaeleth are one of the few that truly get it right. Think Teitanblood or Grave Miasma instead of the armies of less stimulating clones. O.A. infuses his meaty chunks of vintage death metal riffage with a putrid black atmosphere
column9: summoning a bestial effect akin to an updated version of Demoncy’s best material or even Impiety’s earlier work. The Archgoat and Incantation linchpins noted by the label are in there
column10: too
column11: but Vasaeleth are too smart to simply lift riffs from their own record collections.

column1: They remain coldly focused
column2: whether they’re hammering away with blunt force on the title track or allowing the frenzied mauling on “Black Curse Upheld” to decay into a painfully slow middle passage. The production remains appealingly murky
column3: embracing the swirling chaos within and allowing only a faint glimpse into its inner workings. Milton would have wept had “Paradise Reconsecrated” ever crossed his consciousness-- the Fall of Man sounds like a stroll through Sumerian paradise compared to the aural barbarity on display here. When O.A. crashes down into a heaving torpor at 1:27
column4: again at 2:19
column5: and at the song’s end
column6: it feels like the sky has blackened and fallen. It’s the kind of heaviness that sinks into your gut
column7: drags your neck down
column8: and overtakes you entirely. “Fathomless Wells of Ruin” embraces a similar dynamic
column9: peppering its slow dives with harmonic squeals and a hideous hissed gurgle torn from O.A.’s throat. Vasaeleth are excellent at blasting through their manic paces
column10: but they’re deadliest when they slow it down
column11: ramp up the intensity
column12: and just fucking punish.

column1: “Throat of the Grey Watcher” is the album’s strongest track
column2: exemplifying each of Vasaeleth’s best habits and tying it all together into a neat display of malice and control. All Uproarious Darkness could have felt too short
column3: but such is Vasaeleth’s mastery of their craft that they knew just when to stop
column4: and just how hard to strike. There's no room for fluff or ostentation here
column5: no fat to be trimmed or bloated sections to be padded out. This band is above such petty tricks. Here
column6: there is only darkness
column7: desolation
column8:
and damn good songwriting.

The 19-year-old Londoner Archy Marshall has the pale
column3: fine-boned features of Ron Weasley and the rough shout of someone sent to crush your kneecaps. Unsteady
column4: urgent
column5: and skirting tonelessness
column6: it leaks out of him in hair-raising bursts

column11: singular sound out of nothing but that voice

column13: some quiet
column14: sputtering drum loops
column15: and a blank wall of reverb. He sounded profoundly alone
column16: but it was a jagged sort of aloneness
column17: full of raw
column18: exposed nerves and devoid of the comfort that solitude brings. ""My heart got hold of my head and ripped it to its seams
column19: he sang on ""Bleak Bake""
column20: a representative sentiment.

column1: Marshall recorded those early songs on a malfunctioning laptop; now he's on True Panther (and XL Recordings in the UK)
column2: working with producer Rodaidh McDonald. <i>6 Feet Beneath the Moon
column3: his full-length debut
column4: sounds roomier and warmer
column5: and you can hear the music echo into the expansive room tone that McDonald brings to his work. But otherwise
column6: this is the same chipped-brick urban landscape that Marshall prowled through on his EP. The music's surface swarms quietly with breaks
column7: but nothing sounds busy or crowded

column10: the chirping ""I just want you to know"" vocal sample in ""Will I Come.""

column1: Marshall's voice is pushed further to the forefront
column2: and he explores its gnarliest crags and catches. Something in Marshall's stance reminds me vaguely of Modest Mouse's Isaac Brock; like Brock
column3: Marshall's words seem to escape his gut like odd-angled shapes that hurt him as they exit. Also like Brock
column4: he sounds warily intelligent
column5: and though he projects a surly air
column6: his songs are tender at the root. The lovely
column7: drunken ballad ""Baby Blue"" turns on velvet
column8: indigo guitar chords and a gently swooning vocal melody. Marshall has name-checked Chet Baker in interviews
column9: and you can hear in ""Baby Blue"" what Baker's influence means to him: The song is flickering
column10: low-lit
column11: and romantic in a knowingly dime-store sort of way.

column1: His lyrics occasionally play with clichés
column2: and the way they emerge mangled from his vocal chords. ""When positivity seems hard to reach/ I keep my mouth shut/ Because when you're going through Hell/ You just keep going
column3: he yowls on ""Easy Easy"". The lyrics read terribly
column4: but even these ""Hang in There"" clichés are intriguingly dented by the sound of his voice. He loves rap
column5: and some of the word tangles here suggest an interest in the way rappers get to fling around vivid clumps of language: ""The brain lives on but the vibes are dead/ Corrosively tread through emotionally spoonfed purpose
column6: from ""Neptune Estate"".

column1: There are some departures here
column2: and they don't work well: a re-recorded version of the old Zoo Kid ""A Lizard State"" brings in a manic horn section to crash the party and Marshall punches up some of the least appealing lyrics he's ever written with an extra pinch of Tom Waits
column3: yowling ""Where's the fucking fat bitches"" and ""I'm gonna tear you apart from the inside to the out."" Some of his earlier material is included (""Out Getting Ribs"" and ""Ocean Bed"") and it still rings out as some of his strongest work.

column1: The only issue with 6 Feet Beneath the Moon is that Marshall's sound is still a little inchoate
column2: and you get a few compelling ideas rattling around loosely like pocket change
column3: searching for a joining place. Over the course of 6 Feet's 52 minutes
column4: the sound loses some of its essential mystery. Marshall still has a blood-freezing voice

column6: but 6 Feet Beneath the Moon doesn't feel like his Big Statement
column7:
not yet.
