0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/19636/homepage_large.9b8bc2d3.jpg|Higher!|5239.0|Sly and the Family Stone|['Rock']|0.0|1.0|0.0|['Epic / Legacy']|2013-08-29 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:53:43.756155|"

Sly & the Family Stone can be easily found in just about every possible context-- soundtracks
column2: oldies radio
column3: hip-hop sample standards
column4: 60s festival documentaries
column5: lists of essential albums
column6: and the annals of genre-building funk pioneers
column7: for starters. Yet there's something strangely elusive about them
column8: owing not the least to Sly Stone's decades-long battle with his own public presence. The Cliff's Notes version of introductory pop music history tends to focus on only two albums: 1969's Stand!
column9: their breakthrough smash filled with material that they'd work out at Woodstock
column10: and 1971's There's a Riot Goin' On
column11: a masterpiece of spotlight-panic resistance that heralded the decline of their crowdpleasing tendencies and the rise of funk as the decade's most innovative pop-music laboratory. They released three albums beforehand and another two afterwards on Epic
column12: and getting that entire run isn't too difficult; the 2006 box set The Collection has them all remastered and supplemented with bonus B-sides and outtakes. But even a listen to that whole discography
column13: from 1967's A Whole New Thing through 1974's Small Talk
column14: retains a bit of enigma. Where'd they get their funk from
column15: and why couldn't they stay
column16: no matter how many people wanted them to?

column1: Amazingly
column2: Higher! expands on Sly & the Family Stone's history and big-picture role in the development of pop and soul
column3: acting as that rare box set that works as both an introduction for the unaware and a deep excursion into further context for dedicated fans. The major selling point for the physical media edition is an exhaustive run of annotated liner notes
column4: the kind of detail-intensive minutae that satisfies curiosities alongside the usual supplement of rare photos and merchandise detritus. But the musical material alone is an attraction in itself
column5: with 17 unreleased tracks and a good number of underheard ones to go with the big hit singles. Instant-recognition milestones like “I Want to Take You Higher”
column6: “Hot Fun in the Summertime”
column7: and “Everyday People” are released in original single-mix masters (including original mono versions where applicable)
column8: strewn amongst obscurities
column9: live cuts
column10: and alternate takes-- from a Francophone “Danse a La Musique” (credited to 'The French Fries') to a major chunk of their rarely heard set at 1970's Isle of Wight Festival. It's a perfectly balanced mix of stuff casual fans know and stuff even obsessives haven't heard.

column1: If you want to get to where Sly & the Family Stone came from
column2: there's some vintage material that reveals origin points from the circa-64 days when the man then calling himself Sly Stewart was cutting dance-craze tracks for Autumn Records. Labelmate Bobby Freeman had a top 10 hit that year with the Sly-penned “C'mon and Swim”
column3: and the first Sly Stewart single has him treading similar thematic water (“I Just Learned How to Swim” b/w “Scat Swim”). But it's also an early indicator that his vision wasn't easy to slot into any specific format-- the A-side's Chuck Berry riffage and Beach Boys harmonies flirt with garage and surf rock
column4: with a horn-drenched backbeat that makes it good playlist lead-in material when you've got the Sonics on deck. The B-side? A little blues

column1: The sides he'd record the following year-- “Buttermilk (Pt. 1)”
column2: “Temptation Walk”

The only audience it specifically aimed towards was one that rocked go-go boots and Cuban heels-- everything else could fall into place later. Meanwhile
column5: Stone hammered away at the keyboard and had a blast shaping his voice into something a bit out of control and distinct; he gargles out the titular ad-libs of “Buttermilk” with a comedic rasp that made him sound 50 years older than his early twenties.

column1: That voice was heard on the regular through transistors and stereos in the Bay Area
column2: as his radio DJ gig built up his rapport and performing persona to the point where his frontman status seemed inevitable. It's significant that Stone mixed up rock royalty like Dylan and the Beatles in with the Motown and Atlantic hits he spun during his sets
column3: since he wound up putting his band together in a similar fashion: some rock here
column4: some R&B there
column5: voices of men and women over instrumentation from both black and white artists. With brother Freddie and sister Rose as the literal Family
column6: he brought in a versatile crew to act as the figurative one-- slap-and-pop fuzz-bass motivator Larry Graham
column7: breakbeat Rushmore inductee Greg Errico
column8: the two-person brass powerhouse of Jerry Martini on sax and Cynthia Robinson on trumpet
column9: and the backup singers collectively known as Little Sister.

column1: The material they released in their initial 11-month span-- A Whole New Thing
column2: Dance to the Music and Life-- built up their progressive
column3: funky musicianship
column4: broke it down into more commercial-friendly get-down music
column5: then reconstructed it all over again. All those albums charted modestly or worse
column6: and only the title track of “Dance to the Music” approached anything resembling hit status. They're all excellent albums with plenty of highlights
column7: though; the James Brown-gone-nova defiance of “Underdog”
column8: the tongue-in-cheek creepshow devotion of “Trip to Your Heart”
column9: and the motivational carnival-barker bounce of “Life” all could've and should've been hits before the band hit real chart paydirt in 69. But it's just as telling getting an earful of what was left off their records at the time. There's enough unearthed material from 1967 alone to emphasize all the directions the band were trying out: “Silent Communications” is a slow-building minimalist ballad that proves the players all sounded as amazing in drawn-out isolation as they were collectively
column10: “I Get High on You” sneaks a country twang and nasal
column11: drawling cartoon harmonics into their bottom-heavy thump

column1: If there's any truth to the popular notion of upbeat music catching on when it's most needed to soothe our frayed collective nerves
column2: Stand! was the album that 1969 needed. As psychedelia dissolved into roots-rock and heaviness eclipsed mellowness

column4: their characteristic optimism given a deeper edge of resilient strength and wicked provocation in the face of the previous year's brutal turmoil. “Sing a Simple Song” becomes something that's “all I have to hang on to”; “Everyday People” turns prejudice into a mocking playground chant; “Somebody's Watching You” is the lightest performance with the heaviest sense of dread. Factor in Stand!

column1: When their Greatest Hits was released late in 1970
column2: Robert Christgau's A+ review called it “among the greatest rock and roll LPs of all time”; the categorization more surprising in hindsight than the high praise itself. column4: if it could be contained at all. There's plenty that's been said about There's a Riot Goin' On that further words can't do much justice to; it's the sound of one man splintering apart away from the Family he shared a name with and singing like someone dragging a key across the finish of a gleaming new supercar. Given the constant delays and the drastic change in tone

column6: the massive departure from crowdpleasing party music to half-tempo introversion pointed towards several imminent musical futures
column7: and the wellspring of an auteur's brush with drug-damaged withdrawal resonated with everyone

column1: Tellingly

column5: a deadpan-to-the-point-of-glazed Sly tries to get to the heart of the universal experience by stating that “it hurts if you step on my toe
column6: ” appending the least-pained reading of the word “ouch” you could imagine.) The later 70s work
column7: particularly the material from 1973's Fresh and 1974's Small Talk that takes up most of the fourth disc's latter half
column8: attemps to pull back from the fatigue
column9: isolation
column10: and bitterness that made Riot such a bracing work of genius and reconcile it with the more upbeat funk the Family Stone trafficked in at the end of the previous decade. It usually works-- “Time for Livin'”
column11: “If You Want Me to Stay”

column14: boisterous

column1: But the band had already started to splinter noticeably by then-- Graham and Errico were out of the group before Small Talk came out

A couple mid-decade vault findings show glimpses of decent songcraft-- the uptempo organ-driven “Hoboken” makes Sly's complete inability to work well within the confines of disco that much more inexplicable
column5: and “High” is a valiant stab at hitching a ride on the Mothership six years before he dropped in on Funkadelic's The Electric Spanking of War Babies. But it's more a coda of a career's prime than the beginning of another phase.

column1: It's funny

column10:
yet realistic enough to know what to do when that bullshit wasn't so easy to ignore.

My Country. That’s the translated title of Vieux Farka Touré’s latest album. It refers to his homeland
column2: Mali
column3: and it is a more pointed and political title than it first appears to be. Since early 2012
column4: Mali has been embroiled in a complex series of political crises and internal wars; briefly
column5: an independence movement in the country’s vast northeast briefly succeeded and the government in Bamako was deposed in a coup. The northeastern independence movement faltered when Islamist fighters turned on the movement they’d supported
column6: and ultimately foreign troops launched an offensive to drive them out.

column1: If the Islamists had been allowed to consolidate power
column2: one of their policies would have been to ban music. It’s hard to imagine Mali without its music
column3: from the internationalist pop of Amadou & Mariam to the majestic dance band music of Rail Band and Les Ambassadeurs to the desert rock of Tartit and Tinariwen to the guitar music of Touré’s father
column4: Ali Farka Toure
column5: to the dozens of traditional sounds found across the country
column6: music is the face Mali presents most prominently to the world. To lose it
column7: even in a part of the country
column8: would be to lose a hugely important piece of the place’s identity.

column1: Touré
column2: who is a moderate Muslim
column3: has openly decried the invaders who've hijacked his religion
column4: and Mon Pays seems a conscious effort to wrap his arms around Mali and its many sounds to show how they can come together to make something coherent. His most important collaborator is kora player Sidiki Diabáte
column5: son of Toumani Diabáte; their fathers made two excellent records together before Ali Farka Touré passed away
column6: and it’s neat to hear the collaboration passed down to a new generation.

column1: Where Touré’s records in the past have been electric and expansively international in their sound
column2: this one is more focused on acoustic instrumentation outside of the electric bass
column3: and traditional instruments such as kora and ngoni make appearances alongside his guitar. It all gives the recording an earthy
column4: elemental feel that nicely supports Touré’s weary
column5: weathered vocals.

column1: The whole album is compulsively listenable
column2: but in its final third
column3: it reaches a height of intense beauty that the rest only hints at. This is highlighted by a pair of guitar/kora duets with Diabáte that sound as though they’ve existed for a million years and we’re just now having the privilege of hearing. It leads up to the haunting “Ay Bakoy”
column4: which features Israeli pianist Idan Raichel; Raichel’s piano alternately flutters a bit like a kora and provides a heavy anchor in the left hand that no other song on the album quite has. The two artists have worked together before as the Touré-Raichel Collective; but the presence of an Israeli pianist on this album can’t help but feel like a bit of a finger in the eye of the fundamentalists whose attempt to rule the place of his birth was so narrowly averted.

column1: How smoothly his homeland returns to peace remains to be seen
column2: but if Mon Pays can be taken as evidence
column3: Mali is in no danger of slipping from its perch in the global culture. Touré is well on his way to carving his own path out of the shadow of his father. His vision of how to build bridges between his own music and the music others is already his own
column4:
and Mon Pays puts it on brilliant display.

Modern Hut's Joe Steinhardt is the co-founder of New Jersey's Don Giovanni Records

column4: California X and others. Steinhardt has an enviable ear for developing talent
column5: and in recent years

column7: Steinhardt played guitar for Jersey punkers For Science
column8: and after their 2009 split
column9: Steinhardt began writing and recording the songs that would become Generic Treasure
column10: Modern Hut's Don Giovanni debut. Generic Treasure is a sparse
column11: straightforward anti-folk record in the vein of Jeffrey Lewis (now a DG signee) or Kimya Dawson and Adam Green's Moldy Peaches. It's a personal record in almost every sense of the word
column12: an unadorned address from performer to listener. Modern Hut finds Steinhardt laying his weary
column13: lonesome
column14: cynical self out there
column15: all but daring you to take him as he is.

column1: Produced by Screaming Females' Marissa Paternoster
column2: the rickety Generic Treasure feels less like a proper LP (some six years in the making
column3: as Steinhardt suggets) than a home-recorded demo. Apart from the occasional single-string accouterment and Paternoster's overpowering vocal turn on duet ""Life""
column4: Modern Hut is little more than Steinhardt
column5: a couple bumbling chords
column6: and his overwhelming unease with both himself and the world around him. ""Life's been so mid-tempo these days
column7: Steinhardt sings right at the top of Generic Treasure
column8: ""and I don't even know what I am trying to say."" Later
column9: he asks his guitar to ""shut the fuck up
column10: wonders if he was born ""without a taste for life
column11: admits his ""brain is to capacity with someone else's stupid dream."" It's sobering stuff
column12: the product of a troubled mind working things out over a few shaky strums
column13: taking self-examination to uncomfortable
column14: often unflattering places. ""Well
column15: I finally stopped drinking
column16: Steinhardt lets slip
column17: ""but what I can't stop is this negative thinking."" So it would seem.

column1: Steinhardt
column2: no fan of dressing up his feelings in metaphor
column3: starts roughly 80% of Modern Hut's lyrics with either ""I"" or ""my."" Coupled with his close-miced vocals and the barely-there arrangements
column4: this approach invites you right into Steinhardt's head
column5: a place he's made as uninviting as possible. Steinhardt seems to have to drag himself through these songs
column6: sluggishly strumming through the simple chord progressions
column7: glumly intoning the lyrics with only a passing regard for pitch. Steinhardt's voice is laconic
column8: faintly adenoidal
column9: both tiring and just plain tired. He makes constant reference to his crushing self-doubt
column10: to mistakes from the past and fuck-ups waiting to happen
column11: without the slightest hint of levity.

column1: Between the amateurish music (however willful) and the sulking lyrics (however honestly Steinhardt comes by those feelings)
column2: Generic Treasure doesn't always seem to care about itself very much
column3: which leaves one wondering why Steinhardt would've thought anybody else might've. It's not meant to be an easy listen
column4: but even at 28 minutes

column9: his self-laceration becomes a sort of self-obsession; he may not like himself much
column10: yet he's still his own favorite subject. He's certainly good at letting you know about his problems
column11: he never quite makes himself sympathetic enough to get you to care.

column1: On the rare occasions Steinhardt pull back the camera enough to focus on something other than himself

column7: Steinhardt's a shrewd guy with a lot going for him: he runs a great label
column8: he'll soon have a Ph.D
column9:
and he's tight with Marissa Paternoster. But the Steinhardt who made Generic Treasure comes off as a guy far too stuck in his own head to get himself into yours.

There’s something exciting about a rock band playing tight and sharp without sounding like they’re wearing straitjackets. Bleeding outside lines without losing sight of them gives any music extra juice-- especially when that music is punk or post-punk
column2: where blurring rules is often the point. Sometimes it’s just about having a reckless singer: think of the way Darby Crash slobbers over the Germs’ chords
column3: Mark E. Smith rants upstream of the Fall’s repetitions
column4: or David Yow grunts and hacks through the Jesus Lizard’s rubber-band dynamics.

column1: Without that vocal variable
column2: a band can still hit a sweet spot between tautness and sloppiness
column3: but it’s tougher. One way is to play with so much muscle and adrenaline that the music bulges and tears at the seams. It’s a solution common to a bunch of 80s Australian post-punk bands-- groups with aptly guttural names like Fungus Brains
column4: Sick Things
column5: and People With Chairs Up Their Noses. My favorite was feedtime
column6: who stretched punk by grinding it into a heavy
column7: air-sucking marsh. Not far behind were Venom P. Stinger
column8: a quartet who could sound as weighty as feedtime
column9: but preferred quicker tempos and slightly more standard songs.

column1: The emphasis there is on slightly
column2: because Venom P. Stinger’s take on punk was far from middle of the road. Most of their tunes began with a simple beat and a few chords
column3: but soon revved into noisier
column4: wilder territory. This was due in part to the singing of ex-Sick Thing Dugald McKenzie
column5: a fiery chanter who could veer off course when the moment demanded it. But most of the band’s unruliness came from two elements: the slashing
column6: spilling guitar of Mick Turner
column7: and the shuffling percussion of Jim White
column8: who managed to make drum rolls sound like punk beats. (Not coincidentally
column9: the pair went on to expand these styles as part of the Dirty Three).

column1: This new compilation 1986-1991 collects Venom P. Stinger’s first four releases-- two LPs
column2: a 7-inch
column3: and an EP-- spotlighting a band for whom energy and insanity were much higher priorities than melody. Not that the songs didn’t have some strong semi-hooks. But there’s not a ton of melodic variance between tracks
column4: which makes them less memorable as songs than as visceral experiences. After the dust settles
column5: what echoes loudest is the vicious
column6: sometimes daring power of the quartet’s workout-like performances.

column1: Venom P. Stinger’s songs did get catchier as they made more of them
column2: though. Their 1986 debut LP Meet My Friend Venom is a marvel of primal thrust
column3: tearing through the air so forcefully you often feel like you’re just catching its smoke trails. But on 1990’s What’s Yours is Mine
column4: some hooks begin to creep in-- albeit ones that feel just as fleeting amidst the band’s high-octane assault. Even relatively mid-tempo tunes like the lumbering “Those Snakes” and the swaying “Pressure Inside” sound as urgent as their more frantic jams. By the time of 1991’s Waiting Room EP
column5: things had become even more streamlined
column6: with no loss of urgency. Turner in particular learned to play more melodically without abandoning his loose
column7: impulsive attack.

column1: Waiting Room was the final release for the first version of Venom P. Stinger (they reunited a few years later with a different singer)

column3: some of the more rock-damaged stuff on Load Records
column4: and recent Aussie bands such as Eddy Current Suppression Ring and Slug Guts. Perhaps their music is ultimately for punk diehards seeking deviations from the genre’s norms. But if you’re inclined that way at all
column5:
it doesn’t get much better than this.

In the late 90s
column2: Belle and Sebastian were one of the first bands to capitalize on the internet’s ability to unite small clusters of enthusiasts into a sizeable and vocal international cult. And they did so by embodying the very values that the internet would eventually displace: patience
column3: privacy
column4: scarcity. To be a Belle and Sebastian fan in North America was to play armchair detective
column5: whether it was gleaning personal details about a band that never appeared in publicity photos or granted interviews
column6: or simply trying to track down their records in your local music shop’s import bin. It was a situation that came about partially by choice (the band’s 1996 debut Tigermilk was famously limited to a first run of just 1
column7: 000 copies)
column8: partially by circumstance (with their first U.S. label the Enclave going belly up just as 1997’s If You’re Feeling Sinister was making waves Stateside). But what made Belle and Sebastian such a joy to discover was not just the fact they emerged seemingly out of nowhere with a fully realized sense of songcraft
column9: a self-contained narrative universe populated by first-name-basis characters
column10: and a cryptic (if unabashedly Smiths-indebted) visual aesthetic
column11: but that there was a helluva lot more where that came from. The band’s first two albums washed ashore alongside a trio of equally top-notch
column12: equally hard-to-find EPs that felt less like spillover releases than stand-alone works in their own right that subtly expanded the band’s musical scope while deepening their sense of mystique.

column1: That moment now seems so very long ago. With Stuart Murdoch csharing the songwriting reins with his bandmates
column2: the post-millennial Belle and Sebastian have turned both less prolific yet more accessible
column3: more physical but also more frivolous. And while the records they’ve released since have lacked the pen-pal intimacy of their earliest efforts (they’ve gone from initiating inside-baseball commentary on zine culture to writing songs about actual baseball players)
column4: Belle and Sebastian have eagerly adapted to the digital-age gig economy by focusing on its road game: A band that once seemed like it would sooner enter the Witness Protection Program than face the public started touring regularly
column5: taking requests
column6: and hosting onstage dance parties. But in the process
column7: Belle and Sebastian have more or less abandoned the EP format as an organizing principle
column8: instead issuing non-album tracks as B-sides to singles from their full-lengths-- with all the remixes and throwaways that tack implies. Where the 2005 compilation Push Barman to Open Old Wounds rounded up the band’s entire 1997-2001 EP output into a two-disc 26-song package-- presenting each extended-player in complete
column9: chronological sequence-- The Third Eye Centre cobbles together a cherry-picked sampling of post-2003 rarities in randomized order.

column1: It’s an odd approach for a band that’s put so much effort into proper album presentation
column2: but one that’s reflective of the more freewheeling nature of their post-2000 records. The formative influences-- classic country
column3: northern soul
column4: baroque psychedelia
column5: glam rock
column6: 70s easy-listening pop-- that once drifted subliminally and seamlessly through their early work came to the fore and codified into discrete
column7: often-winking genre exercises. And on The Third Eye Centre
column8: you get the oddball attempts that were deemed too lightweight for placement on the already frothy Dear Catastrophe Waitress and The Life Pursuit: “Last Trip” and “Stop
column9: Look
column10: and Listen” gussy up age-old B&S themes of romantic longing in more droll
column11: cornball-country dressing; “Mr. Richard” sees Stevie Jackson make an ill-advised attempt at calypso patois. By contrast
column12: the smoky ska of “The Eighth Station of the Kebab House” finds Murdoch wading into the murky waters of Middle Eastern geopolitics-- weaving a tale that’s sympathetic both to the displaced Palestinian worker and the Israeli checkpoint solder obliged to frisk him-- but the hushed
column13: conspiratorial tones with which he imparts the lyrics add an unnecessary layer of contrivance.

column1: Compared to the self-mythologizing narratives that lent Belle and Sebastian’s 90s output a timeless
column2: fantastical quality
column3: Murdoch’s more topical
column4: contemporary concerns root some of this material firmly in the aughts. (By the time the skinny-tied power pop of “Suicide Girl” surfaced as a Write About Love bonus track in 2010
column5: the emo-porn website was already a good five years and several scandals removed from its moment as an internet phenomenon.) You can also trace origin dates by the band's choice of remixers: the radical reworking of “I’m a Cuckoo”-- which situates the Dear Catastrophe Waitress highlight inside the namesake type of clock-- bears the idiosyncratic imprimatur of once-vanguard
column6: now-dormant beat scientists the Avalanches; Write About Love’s winsome
column7: wallflowery opener “I Didn’t See It Coming” gets a New Orderly overhaul from electro-pop practitioner du jour Richard X
column8: translating the song’s yearning chorus line-- “make me dance/ I want to surrender”-- into wish fulfillment. The album’s other key remix forges an even more explicit extrapoloation of lyrics into sonics. In lieu of 2004’s multi-sectional masterpiece “Your Cover’s Blown”-- the band’s hands-down best non-album track of the past decade-- we get a jacked-up previously unreleased reworking by Scottish producer Miaoux Miaoux that heightens the intensity of Murdoch’s dancefloor panic attack (the migrane-inducing happy-hardcore oscillations practically taunt him as he sings
column9: “the DJ’s picking up speed/ That’s something I just don’t need”)
column10: while greatly increasing Belle and Sebastian’s chances of getting booked at the next HARD Festival.

column1: As a band that started out singing in the secret codes of clubhouse confidantes
column2: Belle and Sebastian are fully aware of how their shifting stylistic course and more aggressively crowd-pleasing mode of performance may alienate those long-serving fans who’d prefer they still communicate in whispers. And some of the best songs here knowingly allude to that dynamic: Jackson’s plaintive piano ballad “I Took a Long Hard Look” is an affecting admission of feeling disconnected from those you once considered heroes
column3: while Murdoch’s “Your Secrets” is a sly slice of folk-funk that juggles the comforts of insularity and the desire for more open dialogue. After being told he’s “introspective to a fault
column4: ” Murdoch errs on the side of assertiveness: “You could tell me all your secrets/ All you want to do is run and hide/ You keep it inside.” Rather than shroud themselves in mystery
column5: Belle and Sebastian would rather blow their own cover and
column6: for all its inherent inconsistencies
column7:
The Third Eye Centre provides a clear view of how a band that once made music fit for a library is now more liable to get kicked out of one.

column3: YouTube clips
column4: and in-jokes floating in a cumulonimbus cloud of weed smoke that ranks among the best rap records of 2012. It’s possible that you may also know him as an MPC jockey who builds beats from scratch in front of a live audience with the same kind of hyperactive energy.

column1: Neither experience is much of an indicator of what to expect from Tough Love
column2: the short-ish first proper album from Party Supplies
column3: which has expanded into a duo with the addition of multi-instrumentalist Sean Mann. Loose-limbed rap beats and frenetic improvisation are in short supply here. Instead
column4: Nealis has decided to unveil another musical identity: the slightly sensitive electropop singer-songwriter.

column1: In one fell swoop
column2: he's put himself at considerable risk of alienating the not-insignificant fan base his beats have attracted
column3: while also entering the crowded electropop market
column4: whose product is being steadily devalued by a seemingly endless procession of knockoff Phoenixes. It’s a risky maneuver
column5: but against all odds
column6: Nealis has pulled it off. Earnest
column7: emotional records with dancefloor aspirations are a dime a dozen in 2013
column8: but few of them work as effectively as Tough Love. It turns out that behind all of the pranky YouTube rips and Guns N’ Roses flips
column9: Nealis is not only a more flexible producer than expected
column10: he’s actually a songwriter of considerable skill and subtlety
column11: not to mention a surprisingly decent vocalist.

column1: Tough Love’s influences are broad and easy to spot. It borrows rhythms from old disco and house records
column2: the plastic-y synthesized sounds of 80s pop
column3: and even a little bit of hair metal in the title song’s drums. Several tracks follow the same dynamic shape that his labelmates like A-Trak and Flosstradamus use to make arena-worthy EDM.

column1: But mostly Nealis seems to draw his inspiration from the evolutionary line of artists blending pop with serious dance music that begins somewhere around New Order and Talking Heads and runs all the way through contemporaries like LCD Soundsystem
column2: Chromeo
column3: and
column4: yes
column5: Phoenix. Like his predecessors
column6: Nealis has found a balance between dance music’s rhythmic focus and pop’s melodic requirements
column7: one that leans a little more heavily on melody’s side-- none of Tough Love’s nine tracks are difficult to imagine in an electronics-free arrangement. And also like his forebears
column8: his best songs combine dance music’s ecstatic qualities with a sense of urgent yearning
column9: expressed in vocal parts that glide over the eddies that their stomping backing tracks propulsively kick up. It’s the type of thing you can find yourself singing along to without knowing it.

column1: Despite the dramatic change in direction and mood
column2: Tough Love still sounds essentially like a Party Supplies record. The songs are more carefully considered and arranged than Blue Chips
column3: and a world away stylistically
column4: but you can still identify Nealis’ quirks in the way he places sounds against each other
column5: the odd near-subliminal jokes (like sampling David Lee Roth’s isolated vocals from “Running With the Devil” on “Cherry Valley”)
column6: and in the slightly grimy lo-fi sonic aura that surrounds even the most straight-up pop cuts.

column1: In a July interview with the rap blog Nah Right
column2: Nealis described Tough Love as having “a few hit songs” on it. It’s not a humble statement
column3: but it may not be inaccurate. There are a few tracks here-- “New York 2017”
column4: “Going Back to New York”
column5: and “Touching Your Face”-- that sound like hits already
column6: the type of thing that you’ll hear in a DJ set at a club
column7: then put on again when you get home
column8: and hear again at the coffee shop the next day. The songs on Tough Love may be aimed at the dance floor
column9:
but they’re designed to creep into every aspect of your listening. It’s easy to let them.

Zach Saginaw
column2: who makes music under his middle name
column3: Shigeto
column4: has shown a nice range of influence within the past few years. On projects like Lineage and Full Circle
column5: the Michigan producer demonstrated the ability to gravitate from the kind of gentle pastoral sound associated to early Four Tet
column6: to the more stripped-down
column7: driving sound of a producer like Actress
column8: and back again
column9: to the glitchy psychedelia of a Matthewdavid. Shigeto’s newest album
column10: No Better Time Than Now combines these separate facets into a single sound
column11: though it’s often easy to identify the dominant mode with which Saginaw is working.

column1: Typically
column2: the more well-blended Shigeto’s influences
column3: the better the result. The standout ""Detroit Part 1"" is the best example: it's an intricately plotted track on which shifts in tone and texture build a small world within a manner of minutes. The album’s title track
column4: also
column5: uses well-chosen details to advance a narrative
column6: granting it a sense of purpose which climaxes beautifully with a series of well chosen instrumental flourishes. These tracks take lessons from hip-hop and bass music
column7: creating structures which allow Saginaw’s lighter touches to flourish.

column1: Those light touches are often exquisite: beauty is something of a Shigeto specialty. Several of the tracks here
column2: though somewhat formless
column3: are simply too pretty to ignore. “Miss You” uses a warm
column4: full synth to imbue a diffuse track with some soul. And the shuffling “Safe in Here
column5: ” opts for sublety
column6: with tonal ornamentation in its back half making up for a lack of direction at its outset.

column1: “Safe in Here
column2: ” points at the largest problem on Better Time-- and it’s a problem common to Matthewdavid-style beat music. Tracks too often lose their way
column3: and the listener’s attention along with it. The worst of the tracks here seem almost arbitrary
column4: with randomly chosen loops that don’t fit in with the more in-depth miniatures that the record has to offer. “Ritual Howl""
column5: as if to spite its own name
column6: is a barely-there chime loop which doesn’t make much of an impression.  Ditto “Soul Searching""
column7: which sounds
column8: for the entirety of its running time
column9: as if it’s actually searching for that essential
column10: memorable moment of levity. The lack of structure is confusing
column11: given that Saginaw came up as a drummer
column12: and obviously understands the importance of percussion in buttressing the melodies above.

column1: Though Shigeto has absorbed a host of positive qualities from his fellow beatmakers
column2: he seems caught
column3: between a more purposeful
column4: narrative form of music (like that of Four Tet
column5: and the calmer compositions of Flying Lotus) and the abstruse
column6: diffuse form that’s endorsed by the Leaving Records camp. As the best tracks on No Better Time Than Now show
column7:
Saginaw has more than enough talent to pull off the former with aplomb-- a style of music-making that will force him to focus and propel his sound forward. Someone who’s shown the ability to shape such intricate moments of beauty should be able to make music that consistently provides something more than just a passive experience.

Well
column2: if you end up liking this record
column3: it’s not going to be easy to tell your friends what you’re “into these days.” But whatever shock value or comic relief you get from Pity Sex’s name
column4: there’s no phrase in the English language that more accurately foreshadows the concerns of this co-ed Ann Arbor quartet-- which is to say
column5: the effect of sex on exceptionally self-pitying people. Their debut LP Feast of Love is post-coital pop-punk
column6: far enough removed from the physical act where any intimacy or legitimate emotional connection has given way to the neediness and self-loathing that drove these poor souls to pursue their couplings in the first place. And of course
column7: they're saddled with the additional depression of realizing that another person isn’t going to fix them; in fact
column8: it always makes it worse. <i>Feast of Love
column9: sure. But the whole affair just makes Pity Sex kinda sick to their stomach.

column1: That much is conveyed on “Wind-Up”
column2: where Brennan Greaves demands space to nurse an incapacitating hangover or the fact that he just cannot fucking deal right now. Hell
column3: maybe he just woke up still drunk
column4: as there’s an illicit giddiness to “Wind-Up”; ripping through their most anthemic riffs and a righteous fuzz solo
column5: Pity Sex are having a blast here
column6: even though Greaves' droopy vocals try to tell a different story. His counterpart Britty Drake isn’t much better off on the subsequent “Keep”
column7: where a surprising melodic (mis)step occurs in the tipsy chorus
column8: possibly because she’s too despondent to reach the next higher note in the scale. The two have about equal billing here
column9: though Feast of Love doesn’t sound like a concept album or a back and forth conversation. When Greaves and Drake trade verses on the acrid “Drown Me Out”
column10: it's a standoff between two friends who might be getting a little sick of telling each other about their failed romances as well as hearing about them. Misery loves company on Feast of Love
column11: but it also wants some damn space.

column1: Which makes a lot of sense-- after all
column2: Feast of Love is a record of limited scope
column3: to put it lightly. It’s also limited to 10 songs and 28 minutes
column4: so it never has the opportunity to get too oppressive. Plus
column5: the music itself could not be more adept at channeling Pity Sex’s particular brand of hangdog horniness-- melodic and punchy enough to be attractive
column6: rumpled and lethargic enough to let you know it's not trying too hard…which in turn makes it more attractive depending on your tastes. The distinctions are incremental on Feast of Love and even after so many listens
column7: I’m still taken aback by how ""Fold"" makes no concession to being a grand finale
column8: ending the LP with zero fanfare. Within the record's narrow musical arc
column9: “Hollow Body” establishes itself as the “ballad” by ditching the drums and distortion
column10: while the whammy-bar abuse on “Drawstring” sonically embodies the masochism of the lyrics-- ""Your name is a a drawstring around my neck/ tighter with every breath."" And while happiness appears to be comically unattainable on <i>Feast of Love
column11: at least there’s ownership of one’s misery on “Honey Pot”
column12: where Greaves snarks
column13: ""I'll take what I want/ I'll concede to all my faults...I won't feel guilty when you kiss me.""

column1: Though not as lyrically sharp as either Waxahatchee or Speedy Ortiz and more affiliated with pop-punk despite its shoegazy alt-rock leanings
column2: Feast of Love is a record that finds Pity Sex as part of an uninentional ""moment"" for slack
column3: sexualized indie rock. So the initial temptation is to think of it as reactionary-- is it possible that these bands are interested in a reclamation of 90s indie rock ideals at a time when “indie rock” rarely means “guitar rock” and deals with the actual
column4: mundane mechanics of relationships even more rarely? Doubtful. Judging from their unsurprisingly active Twitter feeds
column5: none of the aforementioned appear the least bit interested in being scolds. Nor do I think an album like Feast of Love is a reaction to the countless thinkpieces about how the
column8: 00.html"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">self-involvement of 20-somethings or the romantic complications caused by technology somehow didn’t exist before 2013. Nah
column9: but it is a nice refutation of both
column10: and though every sound on Feast of Love existed before the end of the first Clinton term
column11:
Pity Sex's tales are as timeless as the band’s name-- self-pitying people are still having sex and nothing seems to stop them.

0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/19634/homepage_large.34ba0aaf.jpg|Eccentric Soul: The Forte Label|0.0|Various Artists|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Numero Group']|2013-08-28 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:53:50.791548|"

When Marva Whitney died last December at the age of 68
column2: her obituaries were overshadowed by another name: James Brown. Her association with Brown only lasted for three years-- she walked out alongside most of the Famous Flames in 1970
column3: prompting Brown to form the J.B.’s-- but her output as a member of the Godfather’s revue during that brief time proved both fertile and enduring. In particular
column4: her 1968 singles “Unwind Yourself” and “What Do I Have to Do to Prove My Love to You” showed just how punchy the Kansas City native could be when paired with strong tracks of sinewy (and often speedy) funk. It took The J.B.’s’ “Female Preacher” Lyn Collins to replace Whitney in 1970 and that speaks volumes about the size of the hole Whitney left in Brown’s roster.

column1: The Forte Label-- the latest archival anthology in Numero Group’s consistently superb Eccentric Soul series-- brings up the question
column2: “What did Whitney do next?” The short answer: She kept on rocking. After her relationship with Brown crumbled
column3: her marriage to singer Harry Whitney ended in divorce. Back in Kansas City
column4: she remarried
column5: and her new husband Ellis Taylor would help her usher in the next phase of her career at his label Forte Records. Small R&B labels in the 60s and 70s weren’t just typically regional-- they were often family affairs. Such was the case with Forte. With Ellis orchestrating a string of 45s tied to the platform his wife had built beside Brown
column6: Whitney dropped the greatest single of her post-“Soul Sister No. 1” career: “Daddy Don’t Know About My Sugar Bear"". Cut from the same cloth of saucy adultery as Candi Staton’s output at the time
column7: the song opens with a piercing squeal unmatched by any singer of the era save for Alfreda Brockington on her ear-cleansing “Your Love Has Got Me Chained and Bound"". Tuneful
column8: compact
column9: and ringing with passion
column10: “Daddy Don’t Know” is a raw yet infectious funk track that’s still as hard and bright and the gems she made with Brown.

column1: The compilation amply demonstrates
column2: Ellis’ eye for talent was as keenly ambitious as it was devotedly KC-centric. That led to standout cuts from Lee Harris-- whose “I Am Gonna Get Your Thing” siphons Johnnie Taylor’s percolating sexiness-- to the Hot Wax-esque funk-pop of “You Confuse Me Baby” by the girl group the Rayons. Beyond that
column3: Ellis lined up the doo-wop-inflected “I’m Gonna Get You” by the Tear Drops
column4: which could be mistaken for an early-60s R&B classic if not for the tight
column5: shuffling
column6: near-funk snare. Louis Chachere’s “The Hen Part 1” is pure
column7: greasy
column8: orgasmic organ-pounding
column9: and Tony Ashley’s “All Along I’ve Loved You” clocks in with the collection’s only ballad-- although it’s a tender
column10: sensuous slow-burner of the Jerry Butler variety. Even the label’s day-late-dollar-short stab at disco-- 1980’s sinuously sultry “Reaching For Our Star” by Sharon Revoal-- shines
column11: thanks to minimal production and an endearingly twinkly jazz-fusion vamp.

column1: Regardless of the fire
column2: fun
column3: grit
column4: and eclecticism of Forte’s roster
column5: the label failed to break through nationally. The occasionally flashes of anachronism in Ellis’ taste might have had something to do with that but mostly that was symptomatic of a larger problem. Ellis followed instead of led
column6: and because of that hesitance he was never able to fully capitalize on his biggest star: Whitney. In addition to “Daddy Don’t Know""
column7: she contributes three other singles to the anthology
column8: and two of them under her new married name Marva W. Taylor
column9: “Nothing I’d Rather Be (Than Your Weakness)” and “I’ve Lived The Life"". Her most bankable marketing asset at the time-- “Marva Whitney” in bold letters on the face of her 45s-- was gone. Her voice remained
column10: but with little radio play outside KC
column11: that wasn’t going to do much good
column12: at least not success-wise. Artistically
column13: these songs still slam; in particular
column14: “I’ve Lived the Life” is a poignant downshift in Whitney’s funky bluster in which she struts her hard-won wisdom over a sauntering
column15: bad-girl beat.

column1: On the disc’s final song
column2: though
column3: she sounds bruised
column4: if not defeated
column5: on “We Need More (But Somebody Gotta Sacrifice)"". A novelty-leaning
column6: call-and-response song reminiscent of Otis Redding’s and Carla Thomas’ “Tramp
column7: ” the song is Ellis’ only vocal appearance on the collection. He uses that opportunity to scold Whitney for wanting too much out of life
column8: not tightening her belt enough
column9: and lamenting his own poor fortunes as a would-be impresario. “What are you gonna be?/ What are you gonna sacrifice?” he asks her over a chugging track of bargain-basement funk. Her valiantly spirited response: “I need more/ You need more/ Everybody need a little bit more.” As the song fades out
column10: she can be heard rattling off lines that sounds ad-libbed: “I’m trying to hold up… I just can’t hold up to the pressure too long.” In the 80s
column11: Whitney wound up putting her career on hold where it stayed
column12: despite occasional mini-comebacks
column13: until her death. The history of funk has long needed a little bit more of Marva Whitney; her music
column14: her context
column15: her soul. Thanks to The Forte Label
column16:
we now have it. And then some.

0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/19596/homepage_large.f2e8fe13.jpg|Engravings|28042.0|Forest Swords|['Rock']|1.0|0.0|0.0|['Tri Angle']|2013-08-27 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:53:51.461362|"

On Forest Swords’ 2010 EP Dagger Paths
column2: the web of dub
column3: psych
column4: dance
column5: and drone spun by UK producer Matthew Barnes felt instantly singular. So singular
column6: in fact
column7: that the task of creating a worthy follow-up must have seemed daunting
column8: which I assumed was why it took him a while. It turns out there were other reasons-- for one
column9: he suffered from hearing problems that made his new work sound different with each listen
column10: and forced him to consider ending Forest Swords. But also
column11: in keeping with his music’s slow-growing vibe
column12: he was wary of rushing things. As he admitted in a February interview
column13: “I’m glad I took a step back…I’ve seen so many bands who strike while the iron’s hot and then burn out.”

column1: Barnes’ judgment proved sound
column2: as did his ears
column3: at least in their ability to assess his work. Created at his own pace in his own home in North West England
column4: Engravings is the perfect sequel to Dagger Paths. Barnes steadfastly retains his sturdy loops
column5: simple beats
column6: and evocative guitar lines
column7: refusing to overhaul his potent formula just to dodge accusations that he’s repeating himself. But he also gradually inserts new sounds into that equation
column8: fitting them snugly into his songs’ accumulating layers. The result is both familiar and fresh
column9: cementing Barnes’ knack for creating complex effects with elementary methods.

column1: Engravings also confirms his ability to conjure more than just a chilly
column2: faded-memory vibe. Dagger Paths did that too
column3: but it was easy to get lost in its burned-out echo and miss other ideas and moods that Barnes explored along the way. Here
column4: those diverse facets of his music are unavoidable. Every song is boldly sensual
column5: and each note has a distinct emotional hue. Mixing that intensity with dream-like atmospheres lands Engravings in a unique emotional space
column6: one Barnes accurately describes as a “balance between really intense euphoria and this almost bleakness.”

column1: Trying to balance those opposites could produce disjointed
column2: even jarring art. But one of the biggest strengths of Forest Swords’ music is its fluidity. Although Barnes adds and subtracts loops and beats without hiding the seams
column3: he persistently maintains a DJ-like flow. As a result
column4: following the curving path of his melodies feels more like riding a wave than cutting through choppy waters. So even a track as spliced together as “Onward”-- which opens with a stuttering clang
column5: grafts on glittering guitar
column6: then drifts into strings and a pounding beat-- feels completely logical
column7: as if this is the only way time could march on.

column1: Barnes’ strong sense of flow lets him add new twists to his sound without forcing them in. Often they emerge sneakily
column2: like the radio-static transmissions in “Ljoss”
column3: the New Age piano on “Gathering”
column4: the horn-section accents in “An Hour”
column5: or the near-militaristic beat of ecstatic closer “Friend
column6: You Will Never Learn”. In other places
column7: these additions are clearer
column8: but they’re always well-suited to their environment
column9: as if Barnes had no other choice but to include them in his mix.

column1: That’s especially true of the increased amount of singing on Engravings. The majority of it comes from Barnes’ own voice
column2: which he sampled and then edited down to a nearly molecular level. This digital abstraction of the music’s most human element gives Engravings subliminal warmth
column3: as if the ghosts of long-dead lyrics are watching over the songs. At times
column4: vocals even become the focus: “Gathering” is nothing but overlapped singing for its first half
column5: and the inclusion of Brighton-based vocalist Anneka on “Anneka’s Battle” adds vivid soul to Barnes’ brand of negative-space R&B.

column1: Barnes inviting a guest onto a Forest Swords song is a bit surprising. His one-man music is usually a personal affair: you can practically hear him thinking through the songs as they unfold
column2: and all the reverb and atmosphere make them feel like internal monologues. But compared to Dagger Paths
column3: there’s more acknowledgement of the external world on Engravings. Barnes incorporates field recordings and refers to his locale in song titles; he also mixed the entire album on his laptop while sitting outside. Opening his process up a bit to include his environment perhaps explains how music this skeletal can sound like it has so much blood coursing through it.

column1: It also explains how the one-man world of Forest Swords can feel so universal. Unrestricted by words or verse-chorus structures
column2: Barnes’ songs reflect the way life can feel like an endless loop
column3: growing and building without ever losing its cyclical nature. Maybe that’s why
column4: even though Forest Swords’ sound skirts an array of genres
column5: it doesn’t belong to any single one. Barnes’ work is less concerned with trends or scenes than experiences and memories that everyone has had
column6: regardless of what music they’ve listened to before. On that count
column7:
Engravings is a broad success.

"|18401.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18401-forest-swords-engravings/|8.5|Marc Masters

0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/19579/homepage_large.a1b00d04.jpg|Carrier|5680.0|The Dodos|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Polyvinyl']|2013-08-27 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:53:51.945996|"

The titles of the previous three Dodos records-- Visiter
column2: Time to Die
column3: No Color-- provide an unfortunate and eerie foreshadowing for the band’s fifth LP Carrier. It’s the San Francisco duo’s most subdued and solemn album
column4: inspired by the passing of guitarist Christopher Reimer
column5: who joined Dodos for a brief period between his departure from Women and his death at the age of 26 in 2012. Though Reimer doesn’t play on Carrier
column6: he’s a spiritual and musical inspiration that guides Meric Long and Logan Kroeber throughout
column7: an incorporeal third member that still holds the most influence over the record’s direction. The short time in Reimer’s presence has shaken the band to its core and
column8: understandably
column9: Carrier isn’t always steady. But while it’s Dodos least immediate work
column10: it lingers and resonates in ways that give it a unique place in their discography
column11: a promising path forward rather than what can initially be heard as a return to Time to Die’s soft-focus indie pop.

column1: The most noticeable superficial difference on Carrier is that Long has switched almost entirely to playing electric guitar. Surprising
column2: but not sacrilege-- though Dodos broke out on Visiter as an acoustic-and-drums duo and returned to that format on No Color
column3: they’re not wedded to that setup
column4: having incorporated electric guitars in a live setting and even a full-time vibraphonist on Time to Die. The strange thing is that they might be the first band to ever plug in for the sole purpose of rocking less. On prior singles such as “Fools”
column5: “Fables”
column6: and “Black Night”
column7: Long played his acoustic with force and resourcefulness
column8: utilizing the resonance in alternate tunings
column9: inverted chords and string buzz and sending the signal through looping and distortion pedals. He’s not as focused on multiplicity here
column10: neatly lacing together pinging
column11: high notes rather than chords or riffs. You can sense a tentativeness in the shift towards a gentler minimalism-- both the first song (“Transformer”) and the first single (“Confidence”) begin as calm and quiet meditations
column12: Long singing in a hushed
column13: lower range over sprightly fingerpicking before giving way to the kind of percussive jams that we’ve come to expect. But those sections end up feeling mismatched and you sense that while Dodos were ready to do away with their old habits
column14: they couldn’t quite figure out how to replace them.

column1: Wedged in between those songs are rewarding mergers of their new approach with their old skills. The crisp production and autumnal glow of Carrier is a world away from Women’s meat-locker severity
column2: though Reimer’s stylistic tics as a guitarist manifests in tangible ways. There’s a dissonant
column3: deconstructive edge to the gnarled riff and fractious rhythms driving “Substance”
column4: and the momentum makes for a seamless transition towards the tumbling chorus and a surprising brass section. “Stranger” similarly aligns Long’s tuneful folk-pop harmonies with tensile post-punk arrangements
column5: as silvery palm-muted loops
column6: pitch-shifted guitars and Kroeber’s unorthodox percussive clatter encase the delicate melodic core in steely armor.

column1: The instrumental pyrotechnics of “Stranger” are a rare pleasure here and the combustion can be missed
column2: as the energy exerted by Long and Kroeber as instrumentalists often was the hook on past records
column3: rather than a certain melody or lyric. It’s an understandable loss
column4: as the songwriting process has been completely inverted. Whereas previous records evolved out of instrumental jams
column5: the lyrics on Carrier came first. But much like the six-string switch-up
column6: it has the exact opposite effect of you might expect. Long hasn’t become a wordier or more poetic lyricist
column7: in fact
column8: Carrier is Dodos’ most plainspoken album. There seems to be a “first thought
column9: best thought” approach as he asks cosmic
column10: open-ended questions that strike to the heart of the human experience or sensible
column11: legible fragments that can fleshed out over equally inquisitive music.

column1: <div>“What does a song hold?/ Was it love?
column2: ” Long asks to open the record and there’s no impatience or pedantry in it. Carrier instead has a quiet fortitude
column3: searching for “substance
column4: out of reach
column5: ” to use a phrase that pops up on two separate songs. To get there
column6: Long occasionally reaches into the past
column7: as on the station wagon reminiscence “Family”. More often
column8: he’s just trying to be a better actor in the present. He’s a concerned father at the beginning of the heart-welling ""Relief""
column9: and a consolate husband at the end-- ""So I sit with my wife/ thinking of nothing much when we fight/ and I squeeze till we dry.""  Carrier’s final stretch gets a bit too wispy
column10: but not before the suitably titled “The Current” delivers the lyric that feels like the record’s valedictory address: “If this love comes unto me/ I’m with it.”

column1: So despite the role Reimer’s passing played in the creation of Carrier
column2: it’s not Dodos’ answer to Tonight’s the Night-- it never feels haunted or wracked with morbid reflection
column3: even the supposedly blunt “Death” is imbued with a sense of gratitude
column4: seeing the natural order of things. Though Long claimed “we put our backs into this one” in an email to fans
column5: it doesn't convey that force and struggle on the listener

wondering where they are and if they ever think about you.

I'd been listening to Flaamingos for a couple weeks before curiosity got the best of me. A quick image search confirmed my every suspicion: Flaamingos aren't the smiling kind. The LA duo's self-titled debut is steely
column2: stone-faced

column4: the icepick guitars
column5: the rattling drum machines and the baritone desperation
column6: Flaamingos' grey pallored gloom-rock is somewhere in the same shadowy neighborhood of early Depeche Mode
column7: or the Echo and the Bunnymen songs you never hear on the radio. Frontman Jerry Narrows sings-- moans
column8: really-- of ""sick salvation
column9: of ""wrestling a ghost
column10:
of ""Fractured Love"" and ""Modern Behavior"" with the weight of the world on his slumped shoulders.

Theirs is a murky sort of melancholy: though Narrows opens wide on most of Flaamingos' choruses
column11: he mumbles his way through these verses
column12: unpursing his lips only to replace a spent Lucky Strike. (Unfiltered
column13: I'm sure.) Fizzling
column14: squealing synths come in twos and threes
column15: which-- when coupled with the rigid drum programming found of most of Flaamingos-- gives the disc its been-a-while-since-we-left-this-basement-hasn't-it claustrophobia. Narrows stews
column16: wallows
column17: declares himself all but unfit for humanity; ""Explicitly
column18: all I wanna do is live
column19: he sings on the album's first track
column20: then spends the rest of it making you wonder how true that could be. ""If by chance you seek romance
column22: I'm not fit to stay
column23:
he moans on Flaamingos closer ""Creation."" That's more like it.

Flaamingos is muggy
column26: a not-undanceable bummer for the type of people who leave their trenchcoats on indoors. In essence
column28: even if there's nothing particularly new about it; the band's SEO-enhanced moniker might be their only concession to anything more modern than
column30: Black Celebration. This particular strain of mope-rock never really went away
column32: it's having another little moment; Flaamingos' fellow left-coasters Crocodiles and Weekend each have new records steeped in a similar synthy

column1: Lyrically
column2: Narrows often seems a bit stuck inside his own head. He wisely sidesteps the maudlin brood of many of his contemporaries
column3: but the way he jumps from image to fragmented image makes for a slightly scattered listen. And
column4: while they've got a way with desperation-- never better than on ""She's Never Satisfied""
column5: with its cracking ""there's only one of us in ecstasy on this night"" refrain-- these songs lose their centers whenever tempos slow. But
column6:
where so much mopey post-punk/early new wave revivalism gets itself stuck in the shadows-- letting foul moods cloud out anything resembling a novel melody or a texture any lighter than dark grey-- Flaamingos have a way of slipping just enough color into their songs to keep Flaamingos from turning into a total drag.

""In between the lines
column7: there's texture
column8: colored by an active mind
column9: Narrows sings on the dubbed-from-Dolby ""Digital Dialogue."". With so much of Flaamingos outlined in charcoal-- the deadpan verses
column10: the chest-clutching choruses
column11: and Narrows' pining
column12: self-lacerating lyrics-- any color's left to the detail-work. This
column13: truly
column14: is where Flaamingos excel. Little bursts of neon jut out through the darkness and momentarily light up the night. Terse synth-popper ""Expressions"" is just another lonely night at the danceclub until a slippery little guitar lick works its way out from the backdrop
column15: casting Narrows' gunmetal-black lamentations in a far more flattering blacklight-purple. ""All I Wanna Do Is Live"" offsets its pleading verses with a downright symphonic synth line
column16: raising Narrows' inner drama to cinematic heights. It doesn't always work; the reverb-spackled ""Fall With Me"" wobbles as if encased in Jello
column17: and from time to time
column18: all these burbling baselines and dust-ridden drum machines crowd Narrows out of his own frame. But
column19: while the dark and narrow path Flaamingos finds itself on sometimes gets a little cramped
column20:
these moments of luminosity help keep Flaamingos from retreating too far into the fog.

column1:

Chicago’s Disappears would like you to believe that their fourth LP
column2: <i>Era
column3: stands for a new beginning. Well
column4: they’re only half right. The album marries their previous releases in one noisy
column5: polyamorous black wedding that shows promise for the future
column6: but is more a celebration of the past. Think about the band’s 2012 LP Pre Language
column7: and their song ""Minor Patterns"" where singer Brian Case sneers
column8: “Why bother
column9: it’s been done.” That defeatist phrase must be something that sticks in the craw of young psych acolytes. The well-worn motorik highway now seems too predictable
column10: calling out for more hairpin turns
column11: off-road detours
column12: and above all some better scenery. On Era
column13: Disappears begin to pave a path to transcendence that's a little more varied
column14: grabbing the more anemic sounds of Clinic and Liars
column15: while keeping the forward momentum of their most obvious influences Spacemen 3 and rough-edged Velvet Underground. They know they trade in the business of the past and work within confined musical language
column16: but they play on
column17: middle fingers scratching their eyebrows.

column1: In the macro scope of Disappears’ catalog
column2: Era is the moment when the groove finally locks into place. To call it a new beginning would be a disservice to the somewhat ill-advised territories the band has ventured into
column3: especially with their EP Kone
column4: released earlier this year. Kone's title track seems like a 15-minute flavorless psych wafer in contrast to the spritely but unfulfilling Pre Language. But it all starts to come together on Era: the post-punk propulsion
column5: the protracted kraut rhythms born out of the negative spaces of no-wave
column6: the macabre baritone croons. It’s been done before
column7: but now it’s being done like Disappears.

column1: Era swirls around its centerpiece
column2: the nine-and-a-half minute “Ultra”. It's the song Disappears have been angling toward their career. If Swans ever decided to replace their bolo ties with skinny ties
column3: they might’ve written something like it. After the departure of Sonic Youth drummer Steve Shelley
column4: Noah Leger lends a new energy to the band. He lays back in the pocket right with bassist Damon Carruesco for a rhythm section that sounds like it’s trying to be the extroverted kid but can’t stop sulking in the corner. So often Era sounds like an indictment of dance music with an industrial bent
column5: a Ciroc martini served with a black beetle crawling around the rim.

column1: Placed around the load-bearing “Ultra” is a family of tunes cut from a familiar cloth. “Elite Typical” is the burlier brother with a similar four-to-the-floor beat
column2: while “Girl” opens the album like a starter canon
column3: a one-song best-of compilation of the band’s shorter noise-rock tracks. There was always an unfulfilled desire with their songs on Lux and Guider
column4: that sense that you wish the band would extend these songs out because if they’re just gonna cruise they might as well try to jam. With “Girl”
column5: the band finally writes a shapely rock song in under four minutes.

column1: Case’s sour baritone on Era is the final piece of the puzzle. He mirrors the band and obsesses over oblique phrases like
column2: “Does it end together/ Does it end soon” on “Ultra” or “A new house in a new town” on the closer “New House.” Even with all his lyrical repetition
column3: his words tend to crumble around the music
column4: leaving only hints of something about fists answering first and waking up to a girl's touch. There’s a slice of glam sexuality to it in that disconcerting Birthday Party kind of way
column5: though
column6: like its lyrics
column7: some of the music can veer into the murky waters of unspecificity. When Disappears don't shape their songs
column8: like the unremarkable “Power”
column9: they end up loitering in the space somewhere between air-drumming and space-tripping. Mostly
column10: though
column11: Era showcases all the work Disappears have done cutting and splicing and regathering their sound together to regain their identity. It’s still lurking in the shadows
column12: but finally
column13:
it's there.

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/19595/homepage_large.baaa43e2.jpg|Collected Works Vol. 1 The Moog Years|30175.0|M. Geddes Gengras|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Umor Rex']|2013-08-27 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:53:53.694049|"

It's easy enough to get to know M. Geddes Gengras
column2: a Los Angeles-based musician whose career to date has been a super-charged blitz through myriad genre shifts and musical accomplices. (Fortunately
column3: he has a huge amount of music streaming for free on his Bandcamp page
column4: and the Out Door comprehensively chronicled his work in a feature from earlier this year.) It's not necessary to become fully acquainted with Gengras' output to enjoy Collected Works Vol. 1: The Moog Years
column5: a limited vinyl and digital release of contemplative instrumental work. In fact
column6: anyone familiar with his most popular release to date
column7: as part of the Gengras/Sun Araw/Congos culture crash that gave us the euphoric Icon Give Thank
column8: will find themselves stepping onto craggier land here. Gone are the sunshine and purity from Icon
column9: with a strong sense of embrace replaced by something far more inward looking and ruminative.

column1: Gengras' work with the Moog largely sidesteps common sounds connected to the instrument. This isn't the giddy
column2: frothy
column3: bubbly tone found on countless covers records in the vein of Moog Plays the Beatles. Gengras cites Stereolab as the first band he heard who used the instrument
column4: but their avant-pop approach lies in sharp contrast to his work here. Instead
column5: he's remarkably restrained
column6: choosing to tease out tiny motifs
column7: letting oscillators softly pulse in the background
column8: barely leaving a trace of hefty bass. It's not clear which Moogs Gengras was using
column9: but clearly he's more enamored with using them to paint fainter traces than he is with going into all-out attack mode. It's a sound with more common companions in the past than the present
column10: at times recalling Daphne Oram's moody ""Brociliande"" or the processor noise of Suzanne Ciani's ""Second Breath"".

column1: The strong shift in mood strung across Collected Works is to be expected from something that was recorded in different periods
column2: but what's surprising is how well that creates a sense of journey across the record. Compilations don't often hang together well
column3: usually forging rather awkward trails that hint at how ideas evolved. But here it's mostly seamless
column4: with a lament punctured by noises that sound like a fried circuit board (""Resistor"") segueing perfectly into a minimalist composition that resembles the work Aphex Twin was indulging in around the time of Selected Ambient Works Volume II (""Untitled #4""). Gengras can alternate between big and small in a heartbeat-- the opening ""10.17.2009"" has a boundless feel that positions it in a place as vast as Mountains' most recent output
column5: while ""Inductor"" meshes a mix of twinkly electronics and new age yearning that aligns it with Laurie Spiegel's The Expanding Universe.

column1: Clearly Gengras is well schooled in this stuff
column2: but there are only a handful of too-obvious steals from the music that preceded him in this field. Mostly he's focussed on setting and mood
column3: reaching down to a place that makes it feel like he's trying to make the electronic equivalent of an old blues record. At its best this album has a weather-worn feeling
column4: a sense of analog circuitry entering old age
column5: maturing gracefully from frivolous beginnings. It fits well with the idea that these synths are very personal instruments
column6: with each having unique quirks and characteristics. It's not always successful
column7: but Collected Works reaches moments of poignancy
column8: usually when a bank of synth noise rolls in and provides a dark cloak to hang over the track. In those moments you can almost picture Gengras carefully stabbing at a Moog keyboard
column9:
trying to figure out where the emotional center of such a surprisingly malleable instrument could possibly lie.

column2: Right Words
column3: Right Action|1605.0|Franz Ferdinand|['Rock'
column5: a near perfect debut is nowhere near as hard to follow as a scattered and sluggish third album. Especially if the “more of the same + calculated risks” sophomore bow comes in between. Though Franz Ferdinand’s Tonight was a fine record
column6: it was a largely hitless one
column7: rounding off a common career arc from which few
column8: if any
column9: bands make a meaningful artistic recovery. Just ask yourself whether Interpol
column10: the Strokes
column11: Bloc Party
column12: Maximo Park
column13: or the Killers made the best fourth album. The festival circuit still beckons
column14: so you either blow things up or just keep trudging forward
column15: but on <i>Right Thoughts
column16: Right Words
column17: Right Action
column18: Franz Ferdinand do a little bit of both and not enough of either.

column1: After a four year hiatus
column2: the mere act of sounding like Franz Ferdinand can feel like a “comeback” in both a literal and figurative sense. Perhaps for that very reason
column3: the first half wisely tries to provide a contact buzz by establishing a subtle
column4: but unmistakable proximity to Franz Ferdinand’s better-known material. The opening title track repeats its name enough times where it becomes a hook in spite of its clunky rhythm and dull
column5: anhedonic sentiment; better is the one-bar drum fill bearing the same EQ'ing as the 16th-note snare rip from “Take Me Out.” It's damn near a sampled breakbeat. The chorus of “Evil Eye” slinks and skulks enough to recall a time when Franz Ferdinand sounded sleazier and more dancefloor-oriented than your average rock band
column6: but it has to fight through a verse filled with bothersome vocal filters (an indulgent byproduct of their self-production) to do so.

column1: There is something pleasant and quaint about hearing Franz Ferdinand reestablish themselves as a workmanlike
column2: crowd-pleasing dance-rock band by going heavy on the midtempo disco thump; mind you
column3: they arose at a time when “dance-rock” still meant guitar bands and went heavier on the right side of the hyphenate. And bringing in Bjorn Yttling and Todd Terje to help out on production and slightly nudge them out of that stasis has to constitute right thoughts and right actions
column4: right? Yet
column5: the biggest letdown here is how often Kapranos fails to find the right words.

column1: Franz Ferdinand initially stood out amongst the glut of post-Strokes pretty boys for their wit and playful sexuality
column2: qualities which aren’t tied to a particular sound and tend to age well. Similar to Arctic Monkeys’ Alex Turner
column3: you’d figure Kapranos would make for a good balladeer-- as far back as Franz Ferdinand
column4: he already sounded like an older man playing a young man’s game
column5: wearied and louche. But Franz Ferdinand have yet to prove a knack for balladry. The baroque pop flourishes of “Fresh Strawberries” and “The Universe Expands”’s bleeping electro show how crucial momentum and groove are to Franz Ferdinand’s musicianship by their lack thereof; though four minutes apiece
column6: they feel twice as long. The prevalence of insistence over finesse is confirmed by lead single “Love Illumination”
column7: which doesn’t grow on you as much as twist your arm into submission; a Los Angeles nightmare of overeager-to-please Fitz & the Tantrums soul-pop and Edward Sharpe's clap-trap uplift (“sweet love illumination/ sweet
column8: sweet love elevation”)
column9: I doubt it would be improved in the slightest if Franz Ferdinand were being sarcastic about the whole affair.

column1: They’re probably not-- if you’re trying to draw blood
column2: sarcasm’s a pretty dull blade and Franz Ferdinand aren't in attack mode either musically or thematically. Still
column3: just about anything's sharper than the diffident lyrics that Kapranos brings to Right Thoughts. If you’re still holding him to the standards set by the clever repartee in “Dark of the Matinee” and “Michael”
column4: you’ll drive yourself mad trying to force additional layers of meaning into the central metaphor of “Fresh Strawberries”-- “We will soon be rotten/ We will all be forgotten.” Same goes for “Bullet”
column5: which sanitizes and lobotomizes the sex-as-target practice construct of “Take Me Out” (“Never get your bullet out of my head/ Never get your bullet out of my mind”) and “Treason! Animals”
column6: which exists for the sole purpose of its titular pun
column7: which is really not worth living for.

column1: But I suppose half-assed is preferable to when Kapranos puts his whole backside and thensome into “Goodbye Lovers and Friends”. Already saddled with the stale meta-textual effect of using a presumptive breakup song as an album closer
column2: an additional coat of unfortunate irony is laid on by the self-reference that suggests it’s Franz Ferdinand’s breakup song. “You know I hate pop music
column3: ” Kapranos sings and like a lot of <i>Right Thoughts
column4: he sorta kinda means it
column5: but not really. On the other hand
column6: the last words on Right Thoughts are ""When they lie and say this is not the end/ You can laugh as if we’re still together/ But this really is the end"" and their sincerity is a moot point. You're just meant to applaud an obvious punchline.

column1: Still
column2: while Right Words achieves a baseline level of quality or at least competency with the exception of “Goodbye Friends and Lovers” and ""Love Illumination""
column3: they lack the conviction to take most of their lesser ideas to the realm of being unpleasant rather than kinda boring. Maybe that's a positive; if anything on Right Words came up on satellite radio
column4: you probably wouldn’t turn it off. But by the same token
column5: you also wouldn’t hesitate to use them as a bathroom break in a live setting
column6: lest you miss “Take Me Out” or ""Do You Want To?"" At the very least
column7: while the letdown of <i>Right Thoughts
column8: Right Words
column9: Right Action isn’t all that surprising
column10: the reasons for it are. It’s got nothing to do with the currency of a template the band all but perfected over a decade ago-- if anything
column11: Franz Ferdinand sounds even fresher in 2013
column12: since it's not like they have to duke it out with the Rakes
column13: the Fratellis
column14: and the Kaiser Chiefs or their modern day equivalents. Yet you can’t help but feel like the title isn’t a tribute to resolve or a refreshed sense of purpose
column15:
but rather a more erudite way of telling us they’re going through the motions.
