column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/19580/homepage_large.06162b29.jpg|Warm Blanket|29113.0|Dent May|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Paw Tracks']|2013-08-26 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:53:54.647095|"

Dent May's songs really work in the context of his label
column2: Animal Collective's Paw Tracks. He comes off as the inverse of lablemate Ariel Pink's narcotic AM kaleidoscopes: a button-up
column3: FM-obsessive who just has his shit a little more together. In the context of a boutique label like Paw Tracks -- with Black Dice
column4: <a href=""http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/13303-alien-in-a-garbage-dump/"" target=""_blank"">Eric Copeland
column5: and Excepter on the roster -- May is the palate cleanser
column6: the fresh drink of sweet lemonade after a cocktail of Campari and motor oil. Maybe at Paw Tracks luncheons he’s the odd man out
column7: where the other noiseniks are sharing an experimental demo tape recorded with a vintage arpeggiator in a large field
column8: Dent May is pacing around humming a pop melody with his hands in his pockets
column9: thinking about where he last had his keys.

column1: Considering that Dent May obsesses over the banalities of love in his songs
column2: that fantasy really isn’t a stretch. Last year’s LP Do Things saw him doing the kind of unremarkable things best suited for the notes in the margin in the book of summer-- breezy songs filled with platitudes about young love and the woes of paying rent. On Warm Blanket
column3: May revisits many of the same themes that he did just over a year ago
column4: only with fuller orchestrations
column5: and a partial explanation for his love of the mundane. His debt to and admiration of Brian Wilson is more prominent than ever
column6: sounding almost like he had Murray Wilson in the studio with him cracking the whip and tightening the harmonies to make each melody as sticky as possible. The problem is Dent May -- the one-man band who wrote
column7: arranged
column8: and performed the bulk of this album -- is not only still not doing things
column9: but he’s not really saying things
column10: either.

column1: May’s main worry on Warm Blanket is this idea that he is living in the wrong era. The album’s thesis is presented in “Born Too Late”
column2: where May cascades down a chorus singing “Born too late to tell you that I love you baby/ But I want you to know I been thinkin’ about you lately.” It’s a sweet tune
column3: one of the best he’s ever written
column4: and it sticks around longer that it has any right too. Similar is “Ready to Be Old”
column5: where we get a hint of May’s malaise: “I think the future will feel much better than I feel now.” His dissatisfaction with the present informs his songwriting
column6: born ceaselessly into the past with lyrics that could be anything from schoolyard love-notes to something that could've been crooned by Bing Crosby. Wit
column7: irony
column8: satire mostly elude May across the album-- instead there are 11 songs of bedroom-surf rock that are so bizarrely simple they become ingratiating.

column1: Maybe that’s May’s goal: to shine a light on efficacy of simplicity in the face of the complexities of modern life. The syncopated way he sings the chorus of of “Summer Is Over” that borrows from the Beach Boys wholesale doesn’t require any subtext or cleverness. Maybe its May’s exhaustion with the layers of 21st century communication that pushes him to use colorless nouns and tropey turns of phrase to write songs
column2: like ""So let them hate us/ 'cause we're not haters"" on ""Let Them Talk"". Whatever the case
column3: his hooks get stuck in your head but his lyrics are thin and forgettable. If May’s prolific pace and knack for a hook continues into next year
column4:
he could afford to be a bit more May Schmay and a little less ""Dent May Sings Of Mixed-Up Hearts"".

"|18385.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18385-dent-may-warm-blanket/|6.2|Jeremy D. Larson

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/19539/homepage_large.e59eb5ae.jpg|Colored Sands|31518.0|Gorguts|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Season of Mist']|2013-08-26 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:53:55.218991|"

Like any respected underground band staging a comeback
column2: Gorguts have a lot to live up to. In order to understand why expectations are unusually high for Colored Sands-- the first new LP since 2001 from this Quebec death-metal institution-- you have to look back to 1998's Obscura
column3: one of the most pungently progressive albums ever made
column4: in or out of metal. Obscura didn't just register as technical; it sounded downright excruciating
column5: as if its shuddering blastbeats
column6: doleful bellows
column7: and deliriously inventive guitarwork were being torn straight from the chests of its makers.

column1: But as brilliant as Obscura was
column2: and as wide as its influence has spread-- it holds a hallowed place not just among discerning death-metalheads
column3: but in open-eared jazz circles as well-- it wasn't exactly a definitive Gorguts release. The band made their name playing in a very different style. Their first two LPs
column4: 1991's Considered Dead and 1993's The Erosion of Sanity
column5: demonstrated impressive tightness and a flair for involved composition
column6: but they were very much of their time-- unrelentingly intense dispatches descended from the bulging-vein aggression of 80s thrash. Conceived as early as 93
column7: but not issued until 98
column8: Obscura shocked longtime listeners
column9: who couldn't believe the madness the band's lengthy gestation had birthed.

column1: That chapter of Gorguts was short-lived
column2: though
column3: as guitarist/vocalist Steeve Hurdle-- a key co-architect of Obscura
column4: who died tragically last year at age 41-- left the band in 1999. On the next Gorguts LP
column5: 2001's sorely underrated From Wisdom to Hate
column6: founder and sole constant member Luc Lemay streamlined Obscura's demented sprawl
column7: yielding a less outlandish yet equally distinguished statement. This was a wise move; there would've been no way to out-weird Obscura.

column1: Fans have known for a while that the next Gorguts record was shaping up to be another fresh start. When Lemay revived the group in 2009
column2: after a suggestion from Hurdle that he commemorate Gorguts' 20th anniversary
column3: he took a new approach to bandbuilding. Gorguts had always been a locally sourced project
column4: staffed by musicians from Lemay's Quebec home base-- including Hurdle
column5: bassist Steve Cloutier and current Voivod guitarist Daniel Mongrain-- but this time
column6: he set about assembling a North American progressive-metal all-star team. This band
column7: which appears on Colored Sands
column8: includes two NYC luminaries: bassist Colin Marston
column9: of Krallice and Behold… the Arctopus
column10: and guitarist Kevin Hufnagel
column11: Marston's bandmate in Dysrhythmia. The drummer is John Longstreth
column12: best known for his work in Kansas's hypertechnical Origin. It would be reductive to peg any of these players as members of a post-Gorguts generation
column13: but their work during the past decade embodies the same spirit that drove Obscura: a conception of metal as art music
column14: not in the Sunn O))) sense-- where the genre commingles with drone
column15: noise and other abstracted forms-- but in the sense of a creatively restless pursuit
column16: a union of unfettered imagination and rigorous virtuosity. Like Luc Lemay
column17: Marston
column18: Hufnagel
column19: and Longstreth have each established themselves as master players driven to expand their idiom without assailing its core tenets.

column1: The highest compliment you could pay Colored Sands would be a simple description of what it is: a fully formed outing from an outstandingly pedigreed new incarnation of an already legendary band. Thanks to Lemay's trademark anguished roar and dark-prog riff savvy
column2: Colored Sands feels unmistakably like a Gorguts record
column3: but the compositions-- most by Lemay
column4: with Marston and Hufnagel each contributing a single song-- don't mimic any particular chapter of the band's past. The record's greatest strength is its vast dynamic range. On one hand
column5: it contains some of the thorniest
column6: most aggressive death metal ever issued under the Gorguts name; on the other
column7: it includes moments of stunning textural beauty. That duality is a perfect fit for the album's surprisingly specific lyrical theme: the way Tibetan culture encompasses both ancient majesty and modern despair.

column1: It seems odd to praise a Gorguts record for its prettiness
column2: but some of the most memorable passages on Colored Sands are also the subtlest-- transitional sections that punctuate the band's signature gritted-teeth shred. Opening track ""Le Toit du Monde"" orbits a hypnotic
column3: clean-toned motif-- a waltz-time riff marked by chiming harmonics-- and Hufnagel seasons his extraordinary ""Absconders"" with a dreamy interlude
column4: an oasis of eerie calm in the middle of a churning epic. Other pieces thrive on adrenaline. Marston's ""Forgotten Arrows"" features a thrillingly complex central theme
column5: which seems descended both from Dysrhythmia's intricate chiaroscuro riffs and the blastbeat-driven turbo-prog of Behold… the Arctopus. On the other hand
column6: Lemay's title track-- a doomy plod that trades math-metal daredevilry for hard-grooving 4/4-- is one of the most straightforwardly headbangable tracks in the Gorguts discography.

column1: Diverse approaches aside
column2: all the songs here share a rare coherence: they're as info-packed as the pieces on Obscura or From Wisdom to Hate
column3: but their construction feels especially logical. While not the most extreme compositions Gorguts have issued
column4: they might be the richest and most memorable; the patiently unfolding arrangements-- complemented by a spacious
column5: full-bodied production job that contrasts sharply with the harsh
column6: brittle sound of Obscura and From Wisdom-- give each idea room to really sink in.

column1: There's also a strong band unity at work here
column2: honed onstage over the past several years. No Gorguts album has grooved harder than Colored Sands
column3: a fact that has a lot to with John Longstreth
column4: who excels at making dauntingly proggy riffs feel sprightly and pliable. His rapid-fire snare/hi-hat stutter on the verse sections of ""Ember's Voice"" and the chopsy yet remarkably relaxed post-fusion fills he busts out during the ""Absconders"" outro exemplify how technical flourishes can enhance a song's momentum rather than hinder it. During moments when the full quartet digs into a meaty pattern-- the sci-fi thrash episode in the middle of ""Forgotten Arrows
column5: the lurching slam breakdown in ""Enemies of Compassion""-- you're hearing four expert players uniting with Voltron-like purpose: not just a provisional assemblage but a real band at work.

column1: At the same time
column2: Colored Sands is
column3: like each of the four Gorguts albums that precedes it
column4: a personal statement from Luc Lemay. For those inclined to read liner notes and follow a lyric sheet
column5: there's a hefty amount of thematic data in the margins of this record that gives it a very different feel than any of the band's prior efforts. The first two Gorguts albums dealt with standard-issue death-metal topics (disease
column6: corruption
column7: madness); Obscura turned inward
column8: tackling depression and spiritual crisis; From Wisdom to Hate was a topical grab-bag
column9: covering religious delusion
column10: political megalomania
column11: and the fascination of antiquity. Here
column12: simply put
column13: Lemay has Tibet on the brain. An admitted outsider to the culture
column14: he nevertheless taps into some profound emotions
column15: touching on the deep spirituality of Tibetan Buddhist tradition
column16: as well as the region's purgatorial struggle with Chinese rule.

column1: The idea of a death-metal vocalist howling about sand mandalas and snow lions might look iffy on paper
column2: but the concept sticks
column3: thanks to the dynamism of the music and the conviction Lemay brings to every line. The frontman isn't holding Tibetan culture at arm's length; his seething bellows on tracks such as ""Reduced to Silence"" come off as a kind of rigorous method acting
column4: as though he were revisiting personal trauma in an effort to comprehend the Sisyphean ordeal of the culture he's depicting. It's admirable that just as Lemay has regularly renovated the Gorguts sound
column5: moving ever further from death-metal orthodoxy
column6: he's also worked to find fresh thematic approaches like the one that unifies Colored Sands.

column1: Lemay also shows off his creative breadth on ""The Battle of Chamdo""
column2: an instrumental piece for string ensemble. Previous Gorguts albums have featured classical-style intros and interludes
column3: cluing fans in to Lemay's training as a violinist and composer
column4: but ""Chamdo"" is the first full-length stand-alone track of this type issued under the band's name. The composition's strident
column5: martial rhythms and mournful melodies give it a distinct soundtracky quality
column6: as though Lemay were narrating rather than simply evoking China's 1950 invasion of Tibet. ""Chamdo"" appears at the album's midpoint
column7: and while the piece isn't as arresting as the metal-oriented material that surrounds it
column8: it serves as a smart palate cleanser.

column1: Obscura found Gorguts reemerging in bizarrely mutated form; Colored Sands represents a subtler yet similarly striking evolution. Just as he did on Obscura and From Wisdom to Hate
column2: Luc Lemay has chosen expert collaborators here and given them the freedom to leave their mark on the band's legacy. With Colored Sands-- an album of breathtaking detail and scope-- he
column3: Marston
column4: Hufnagel and Longstreth pay fitting tribute to Gorguts' remarkable history. Instead of reclaiming the past
column5:
they've pooled their resources to create a new present.

For fans of Boston's relatively cloistered DIY punk scene
column2: Bent Shapes' debut LP Feels Weird is a long time coming. Originally known as Girlfriends
column3: the trio-- bassist Supriya Gunda
column4: drummer Andy Sadoway
column5: and guitarist Ben Potrykus-- has been a hometown hero of small venues and house shows since they formed in 2009
column6: racking up nominations and wins for their high-strung
column7: merciless garage-pop at the Boston Phoenix's annual Boston Music Poll. Aside from a handful of short
column8: micro-distribution releases
column9: however
column10: they were almost exclusively a live act
column11: one that required fans to seek them out in person to get a proper fix. Then in May of last year
column12: blaming a need for change and the addition of a new guitarist (who vanished almost as soon as she appeared)
column13: Girlfriends became Bent Shapes. They collected the bitingly catchy punk songs they'd released over their three years as a band and released a compilation called Cull Shorts
column14: a sort of scrapbook retrospective on the Band That Was Girlfriends.

column1: Though Cull Shorts marked the end of an era
column2: its patchwork structure lingers on Feels Weird. Despite the new collection's intention as a formal album
column3: it contains disordered messes of frenetic declarations
column4: judgments
column5: and uncertainties that have become part of the band's character. While incongruous
column6: seemingly unplanned mishmash on a debut would sink a less experienced band
column7: Bent Shapes' honed songcraft is such that missing the forest for the trees is actually a great idea. As a debutante collection-- celebrating the band's introduction to the world beyond New England at long last
column8: something their contemporaries
column9: and they too
column10: until now
column11: have eschewed-- Feels Weird serves as an eclectic
column12: vivid primer on its creators' sprightly misanthropy.

column1: From the outset
column2: ""Behead Yrself Pt. 2"" establishes the band's innate grasp on the alluring grievance: bullshit abounds
column3: especially in their uniquely overeducated
column4: often self-important city. Drawing on proto- and post-punk influences like the Feelies and Jonathan Richman
column5: each track exposes a different blistering sore; Sadoway's mellow vocals and Gunda's bouncing
column6: all-business ones knock Potrykus off his earnestly charming soapbox in healthy doses. ""Brat Poison""
column7: the most explicit
column8: electrifying
column9: and outright funny cut on the record by a wide margin
column10: drips with sarcastic contempt as it eviscerates the hypocritical arrogance of loudmouthed local-scene personalities. (With lines like ""drum circle jerks"" and ""Go put yourself into orbit/ where verbose is verboten/ ferocious
column11: forgotten
column12: it's also a quintessential example of Bent Shapes' immaculate attention to wordplay.) You don't have to have spent time in Boston to appreciate its diss-track qualities
column13: but those fans probably get an amplified experience.

column1: At times
column2: their disgust waxes preachy; at others
column3: like on the garrulous ""Boys to Men""
column4: their need to say something the right way tangles a song in its own feet
column5: like the words of someone who's been holed up alone in his apartment for too many days in a row
column6: and the band stumbles. But for every overstep
column7: there's a song like ""Bites and Scratches""
column8: a personal and heartbreakingly sweet cut about love amidst baggage
column9: that serves as a reminder that they're also dissatisfied with their own complicity and intimate failings. And even as it bubbles over into excess
column10: it's hard to bemoan Bent Shapes' knack for marrying lyricism and melody. Every song-- save ""Hex Maneuvers""
column11: a dreamy experiment that evokes Real Estate's aqueous twang with moderate success-- is irresistibly upbeat in its complaint. Their criticisms
column12: on paper
column13: can seem distant
column14: but somehow-- whether it's vulnerable moments like ""I'm not saying you need some deep-seated hatred of self/ But it helps"" and ""I met a girl
column15: to my surprise/ Said 'I'm damaged goods'
column16: she said
column17: 'So am I
column18: ' / so I held her hand
column19: or the blithe delivery of even the most biting invectives
column20: or merely a trick of the pop-guitar lick-- there's something genuinely warm about them. Ultimately
column21:
theirs are statements that both ask for and infinitely reward a second spin.

column3: Arizona's Lycia have been pioneers of “darkwave
column4: ” a reverb-drenched
column5: gothic take on dreampop. This is the Cocteau Twins
column6: if they looked so far inward that they began to focus on the darker
column7: downer-ridden side. Along with lovesliescrushing
column8: who freed shoegaze from pop conventions

column1: At this point

column4: though longtime member Tara Vanflower contributes vocals to “The Soil Is Dead” and Spring Trees”. They sound like a band that takes their time. It's not just in the pace of the music

column7: and its repetitiveness lends to the drone. Guitars sound like disembodied rock solos
column8: severed from boogie and strangled out into something darkly beautiful. There are faint memories of sweet leads from radio jams
column9: but they become mutated and placed into a context wholly unlike anything that would resemble rock. In particular
column10: the guitars bring to mind the lush metal of October Rust-era Type O Negative
column11: albeit spaced out and even more blissful. Peter Steele was an early champion of Lycia
column12: stating in an interview from 1995 that their album A Day in the Stark Corner had a great effect on him: “If I put it on in the morning when I get up...I'm useless for the rest of the day. It's just devastating
column13: as beautiful as it is devastating.” Lycia opened for Type O Negative on some of the dates in support of Rust. He picked up on their sound for one of the band's biggest albums

column1: If they could

column3: the title of their record from 1996. It's an apt word for their sound
column4: which
column5: like the Rockies in December

column7: whose names and placements next to each other on Moments could hardly be considered a coincidence
column8: represent Moments at its most frost-bitten. Percussion becomes more sparse
column9: the guitars feel even more alien: “Grand Rapids” makes the album crawl slower
column10: and the next track
column11: “The Pier
column12: ” sees Lycia bringing Moments to almost a halt. The last three songs on Moments reflect a sharp shift towards more beat-oriented territories. Still
column13: it's hardly danceable.

column1: If Justin K. Broadrick was listening to Lycia when he first began making music as Jesu

column3: and his vocal approach even resembles Broadrick at his most tender and vulnerable. “The Visitor” is devastating

Pains of childhood are also touched upon in “Antarctica” (“I see old pictures of a boy (me)/ standing
column5: so alone and far away/ buried for miles and miles and miles”) and “Rapids” (“In sleep I see the city/ from building tops alone/ fading childhood memories/ This never
column6: can ever
column7: by my home”). Moments' cover features photos from VanPortfleet's family collection

column13:
but many people can relate to VanPortfleet's sense of loss and mystery.

Growing up in rural Louisiana and then later on a farm in Missouri
column2: Julianna Barwick was a preacher's daughter at a church whose organ got very little use. ""We would always sing a cappella
column3: she explained in an interview a few years ago
column4: ""And instead of instruments we would clap or sing in rhythmic rounds."" A curious kid and a bit of a loner
column5: Barwick showed a precocious fascination with the human voice. Her hobbies included harmonizing with random sounds
column6: making up songs about whatever she was doing at the moment
column7: and singing long
column8: loud notes in hollowed-out spaces like parking garages and inside the trunk of a giant tree just to see what the echo would sound like. ""It sounds kinda psycho
column9: I know
column10: she admitted in our interview
column11: but sometimes ""I would sing to myself and get so lost in it that I would cry.""

column1: Actually
column2: it doesn’t sound that crazy; it’s very easy to become lost in the music that Barwick now makes as an adult. Over the span of her career
column3: from her imaginative 2006 debut LP Sanguine up through 2011's dazzling breakthrough The Magic Place (the name is a nod to that aforementioned giant tree trunk
column4: where she'd unwittingly discovered reverb)
column5: Barwick's gradually refined a process that is at once inventive and incredibly simple. She sings short
column6: reverb-drenched
column7: often wordless vocal fragments into a loop station (though she made the loops on the painstakingly lo-fi Sanguine using just a guitar pedal) and layers them into luminous compositions that feel like the aural equivalent of an airplane ride through a cloud. Toweringly sublime yet invitingly human
column8: her music has an uncanny power to transform whatever space it's played in. It can make a cramped apartment feel like a high-ceilinged cathedral
column9: or-- when she plays in one-- an actual cathedral feel like a gear-cluttered basement show.

column1: Following the warm reception of The Magic Place
column2: Barwick's approach has often been compared to ambient pioneers like Steve Reich and Brian Eno or the conceptual vocal artist Meredith Monk
column3: but something about her music remains approachable and deeply personal—more intuitive than academic. Even as Barwick's songs become as polished and ambitious as those on her third full-length album
column4: Nepenthe
column5: they’ve managed to retain a certain playfulness and an openness to the process of discovery. It deserves mention among the best and most artful ambient music being made today
column6: but Barwick’s work still feels like the realization of a dream left over from childhood
column7: made by someone downright giddy that she has finally figured out a way to sing a round song with herself.

column1: Sanguine
column2: the 2009 EP Florine and The Magic Place all conveyed a sense of serenity found in solitude
column3: which is maybe why her collaborations with other artists have been such a mixed bag. Her records with Ikue Mori (for RVNG’s FRKWYS series) and Helado Negro (as the duo OMBRE) have been solid
column4: but a 2011 remix EP (featuring versions of Magic Place songs reworked by the likes of Diplo
column5: Lunice and Prince Rama) basically just underscored how beside the point it is to remix a Julianna Barwick song. Her music is so pure and reliant on moments of quiet that another artists’ presence often overwhelms. So Nepenthe was a potentially risky move: It marks the first time she’s worked with other artists on one of her solo albums. And we’re not exactly talking anonymous session guys here: she recorded it with Sigur Rós collaborator Alex Somers (members of múm and the string quartet Amiina also contribute) at Sundlaugin
column6: the band’s famed Icelandic “swimming pool studio.” (As a kid Barwick probably couldn’t have even imagined what sort of natural reverb you can get out of an abandoned swimming pool.)

column1: Thankfully
column2: Nepenthe sounds like a step forward for Barwick
column3: a noticeable expansion in scope that still honors the sensibility that made her early records so unique. Somers’ lush production gives her music a larger and crisper depth of field
column4: making it that much easier to get lost in its many overlapping folds. The structures of some of her tracks have become more complex: The billowing “The Harbinger” finds drama in the movement from crescendos to moments of quiet and back again
column5: while the misty incantation “One Half” feels (true to its title) like a seamless fusion of two separate arcs. (For once
column6: there’s even discernable lyrics in that song
column7: but their purpose is purely phonetic
column8: like words spoken in a strange dream.) But even in its most epic moments
column9: one of Nepenthe’s greatest virtues is restraint. Given free reign in one of the most spectacular studios imaginable
column10: Barwick didn’t go all kid-in-a-candy-store on us here. Nepenthe is a modest evolution-- the work of an artist growing
column11: smartly
column12: to scale rather than adding on needless bells and whistles or pushing prematurely past her limits.

column1: It’s also more emotionally complex than her past work. The Magic Place was a slice of pure
column2: unfiltered bliss
column3: but the songs on Nepenthe ache and yearn. Album opener “Offing” hovers like thick fog over a remote pond
column4: while Amiina’s strings drone and growl ominously throughout “Pyrrhic”-- these songs are still ethereal
column5: but they’re stormier clouds than Barwick’s conjured before. On a few tracks
column6: Róbert Sturla Reynisson from múm plays a guitar that
column7: true to his post-rock pedigree
column8: sounds more like a tiny spaceship or the noises made by a comfortingly unthreatening alien. But it’s Amiina’s presence that’s particularly harmonious with Barwick’s overall aesthetic. They're creative with the sounds they get out of stringed instruments
column9: which allows Barwick to use them in a way that says something more complex than “[insert orchestral grandeur here].” They often feel like an extension of her own voice. “Waving to You”
column10: the muted
column11: palliative finale
column12: fits in so well with Barwick’s vibe that it took me a few listens to realize it’s the only song on the album without vocals.

column1: Barwick claims she went to Iceland with nothing written ahead of time. This is how she’s always worked
column2: from her childhood experiments up to The Magic Place-- tapping into the vibrations of the present
column3: and turning them into something that is somehow both enduring and impermanent. You sense feelings of longing and unease all over Nepenthe
column4: which makes it a less blissful place to spend time than her previous album. But that also makes it a much more cathartic listen
column5:
and perhaps a more rewarding one. 

"|18408.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18408-julianna-barwick-nepenthe/|8.5|Lindsay Zoladz

From their Echo and the Bunnymen-inspired moniker to their Automatic-for-the-people appropriation
column2: Crocodiles are so studious in retracing the moves of their stoned 'n' dethroned 80s post-punk forbears that their most intriguing moments come when they aimlessly start drawing outside the lines. Note how ""Hung Up on a Flower""
column3: the otherwise dirgey balladic centerpiece of last year's Endless Flowers
column4: degenerates into two minutes of a woman nattering on in German

column6: Crimes of Passion -- yield something equally nonsensical yet startling: The song's joyous gospel-delic groove fades out

column8: as he lets loose with an extended
column9: a capella stream of beat-poet babble that was seemingly being drowned out all along by the boisterous song preceding it
column10: like a dubbed-over cassette that didn't fully erase its previous contents.

column1: No other moment on Crimes of Passion approaches the same degree of wanton absurdity. But where that random Deutsch-laden rant on ""Hung Up on a Flower"" stood into stark contrast to Endless Flowers' student-disco formalism

column3: unguarded spirit

column7: it's in precisely the same ways U.K.-indie idols like Primal Scream and Spiritualized once did

column9: gospel-diva vocal wails
column10: and steeple-shaking piano rolls as signifiers of Southern-soul authenticity or sci-fi synths to exude some Teutonic futurism. However
column11: thanks to Rose Wagner's punchy production and emphasis on economy
column12: Crimes of Passion-- unlike the band's previous records-- doesn't require the accompaniment of strobe lights and dry ice to fully connect. The new record basks in Endless Flowers' sunny afterglow
column13: but the songs here are brasher
column14: nervier
column15: and a lot more fun.

column1: Even at its most slavishly Mary Chained-- ""Cockroach"" practically comes outfitted with its own pompadoured Afro-- Crimes of Passion evinces a fidgety
column2: tambourine-rattled exuberance that lends the record a brisk momentum
column3: meaning a band that once routinely droned on past the five-minute mark can now get the job done in three. But the album is most distinguished by its starry-eyed ballads
column4: like the Las-esque jangle-pop standout ""She Splits Me Up"" or the Jean Genet-copping moonlit lullaby ""Un Chant D'amour"". And while it may be a stretch to call the retro-gear fetishism of ""Teardrop Guitar"" a love song
column5: its ecstatic verve makes for as solid a sequel to ""She Bangs the Drum"" as the reunited Stone Roses could come up in 2013 if they tried. Such open-hearted gestures may not be enough to fully redirect Crocodiles away from the nihilism-by-numbers of ""Me and My Machine Gun"" and ""Gimme Some Annihilation""
column6: but they offer encouraging evidence that the band is becoming more adept at not just projecting the aloof attitude of their Brit-rock influences
column7: but their flair for disarming
column8: emotionally resonant songcraft. At this point in the game
column9:
we've grown accustomed to seeing Crocodiles flash their teeth; it's much more interesting to see them shed their skin.

DIANA began after another project that Toronto artists Joseph Shabason (whom you might recognize as the guy blowing saxophone all over Destroyer's Kaputt) and Kieran Adams had intended to work on fell through
column3: leaving them with a bunch of studio time and Rural Alberta Advantage producer Roger Leavens at their disposal. Unsatisfied with demos that featured their own vocals
column4: they eventually reached out to Carmen Elle
column5: a friend who had toiled around the local music scene for years
column6: playing guitar with Austra and fronting her own garage-rock duo
column7: Army Girls. Almost immediately she became a full-time member of the group
column8: assuming all of the band's vocal responsibilities
column9: and the decision to bring her in pays out dividends on their full-length debut
column10: Perpetual Surrender
column11: a confident collection of vaseline-smeared synth-pop that marries chillwave atmospherics with strong songwriting.

column1: Let's address the chillwave thing first-- yes
column2: there are a lot of aquamarine environments to get lost in on Perpetual Surrender
column3: and yes
column4: it's unafraid of pushing Elle's vocals so deep into the mix that it sounds like she's singing from the other side of a wall
column5: but it does so with a panache that never forgets that this sort of thing can also knock the air out of your stomach when done right. A lot of the credit goes to Leavens
column6: who proves himself an instinctive producer that knows when to keep adding and when to pull back and let things breathe. ""Foreign Installation""
column7: for instance
column8: is shrouded in a pre-dawn fog that calcifies into a black mass of a chorus before dissipating back into a fine mist. And then there's ""Strange Attraction""
column9: where clanging percussion leads the way forward as much as the track's approaching-storm bass. He even manages to help turn the saxophone solo of the title track into one of the album's most rewarding moments
column10: earning it with a keen ear for structure that finds the band more often than not placing sounds where they'll achieve maximum impact.

column1: An emphasis on lower frequencies gives Perpetual Surrender a surprising heft in addition to its lush Balearic sprawl; it ends up a sturdier incarnation of a sound often charged with lacking bite. There are basslines that not only approach funky but actually deserve the adjective
column2: producing a physicality that only someone who knows just how valuable a rhythm section can be to a band is capable of conjuring. When DIANA clear everything out
column3: they're just as effective: ""New House"" is the album's sparsest moment
column4: consisting of nothing more than moaning floorboards and intermittent bass
column5: and it shines the spotlight on an affecting vocal performance from Elle
column6: who effortless toggles between been-hurt-before reticence (""Am I just another thing to use
column7: grow tired of
column8: and throw away?"") and empathetic reassurance (""Baby
column9: I know you're terrified""). It bowls you over with gentle-but-firm encouragement.

column1: As much credit as DIANA deserve for their ability to create texture
column2: Perpetual Surrender is first and foremost a pop record
column3: and it's most successful when it plays up this ambition. Its songs-- mostly tales of romantic uncertainty aimed inward rather than outward-- were all written by Shabason and Adams
column4: who have a knack for large earwormy hooks. The type of vocalist whose voice actually sounds better the harder it's pushed
column5: Elle imbues these songs with a lived-in intimacy that belies the fact she didn't have a hand in penning them herself. ""Now's the time for believing/ Lay your hands on me
column6: I need healing"" she sings on ""Born Again""
column7: bestowing carnal relations with the power of spiritual purification. It's the album's best song
column8: possessing a widescreen romanticism that the rest of the album can't quite duplicate elsewhere. A general wobbliness pervades the album
column9: and there are places where it might benefit DIANA to zoom further out and sharpen their focus. Case in point: the album-closing instrumental ""Curtains"" is entirely inessential
column10: aiming for epic but barely achieving consciousness.

column1: This sense that DIANA are still figuring out how to best fit together the pieces they've got to work with serves as a reminder that Perpetual Surrender is a debut record-- a very compelling one
column2: but a debut nonetheless. Now that Elle is a full-time member
column3: it will be interesting to hear how their eventual follow-up differs in its songwriting
column4:
given that she does wonders with the material here. There are enough explosive moments to suggest that DIANA have another gear to explore.

Born and raised in the pocket-sized college town of Newark
column2: Delaware
column3: about as far as you can get from the other Newark
column4: Katie Dill and Sam Nobles make sweet music together as Mean Lady. Even though the pastel crocheted album art
column5: Dill's flower tiaras and bindis
column6: and firm belief in smiling at strangers can sometimes be too sweet
column7: it's a little
column8: well
column9: mean to hate on a band that likes to spontaneously play music for homeless subway riders. Mean Lady's debut full-length
column10: Love Now
column11: the duo's first for Fat Possum
column12: usually manages to transcend first impressions. Despite the inevitable baggage that comes with being a boy-girl indie-pop duo
column13: Love Now is more than the sum of its small-town parts.

column1: First
column2: let's get the Zooey Deschanel comparisons out of the way
column3: because Dill plays the ukulele and hula-hoops and describes herself on her Facebook page as ""music and art and giggles."" She even called it herself
column4: citing She & Him as an influence insofar as ""M. Ward producing a record and Zooey being a singer
column5: a polite way of saying that's where the similarities end. Deschanel and Dill both occupy the contralto spectrum and their bands share ambiguous eye contact onstage
column6: but the closest Mean Lady comes to any of the Volumes is probably ""I Will Marry You""
column7: which floats a simple promise on a nuptial bed of crickets and banjos. If anything
column8: Love Now draws more from Amber Coffman and Dave Longstreth's discordant chemistry
column9: or even the dreamy dub of Peaking Lights
column10: than She & Him's retro jingles. (That exotic sound can also be traced to Dill and Nobles' stint in the tropicalia-inflected five-piece Diego Paulo before they formed Mean Lady.)

column1: Though Dill's vocal pitches bear uncanny resemblance to Coffman's and the house-of-mirrors delay on ""Why'd'ya Haftabee Sucha"" could be an outtake from Lucifer in Dub
column2: most of Mean Lady's material fits a completely different two-person mold. Dill has said the album can be divided into three-ish-song sets
column3: each a variation on a theme. The ""theme"" is just Nobles arranging piano chords and Dill adding her voice
column4: a couple of instrumental effects
column5: and an intro
column6: but somehow it doesn't feel repetitive; in fact
column7: Love Now's best songs are the ones that stick to that formula. ""Far Away"" opens with sleigh bells and a single-note harmony
column8: like an om
column9: before joyously diving into sticky
column10: sitar-driven handclaps. ""Bop Bop"" takes a bit longer to get there
column11: but its opening dual guitars are almost a better platform for Dill's voice than the following synthesizer flourishes.

column1: It's when Mean Lady experiment that Love Now tends to falter. ""Haftabee"" is an admirable exercise in dub
column2: even if it sounds like a misguided mash-up of Ella Fitzgerald and King Tubby
column3: but the nine-minute ""Pony Ony O"" is just a drag. The song's title is cloying enough before it rhymes with ""Honey
column4: you're the best best best best honey
column5: don't you know"" or ""Why am I cry-crying… O"" (in that case
column6: the stuttering mimics hiccupping sobs
column7: which is pretty clever in theory
column8: if not in execution). They're outliers on an otherwise cohesive album
column9: which is itself part of the problem: Mean Lady's tried-and-true methods are so simple they might not sound as fresh on the next album. If Dill and Nobles have trouble when they try to grow as a band
column10: they might want to revisit those building blocks.

column1: But why do I have to be such a mean lady? After all
column2: Dill and Nobles play music to make people happy
column3: and Love Now shows that. It's a confident debut of ""nice music played and sung by a goofy lady"" and her partner
column4: and an appropriately breezy
column5: wistful album for the summer. And for now
column6:
that's enough.

Exhumed’s 2011 comeback album
column2: <i>All Guts
column3: No Glory made it clear that the California death metallers still had plenty of curdled piss and vinegar left
column4: and now
column5: with Necrocracy
column6: the self-styled progenitors of gore metal have proven that there’s no such thing as aging gracefully. They’re still the same morbid blood freaks that released classics like Slaughtercult
column7: Gore Metal
column8: and the most perverse Led Zeppelin cover in existence
column9: but as this new record shows
column10: they've loosened up a little in their old age.

column1: Necrocracy marks a turning point in the band’s career. They’ve long hinted at their melodic inclinations
column2: but this album makes no bones about it: longtime Carcass acolytes Exhumed have entered their Heartwork period
column3: trading the sloppy savagery of old for a more refined kind of audio violence. They’ve upgraded their tools of the trade
column4: casting aside meat cleavers and dripping chainsaws in favor of freshly sharpened surgical steel and opting for a cleaner production job.  Instead of burying the evidence
column5: Exhumed ensure that each galloping riff and phlegmy gurgle is right there
column6: mean-mugging right back at your ugly face. The grind has faded
column7: and only death (and maybe a smear of punk) remains.

column1: One of the biggest things that sets Necrocracy apart from the untold numbers of death metal records released so far this year is how damn catchy it is. It comes as no surprise
column2: of course; Exhumed have always delighted in crafting ghoulish ear worms like perennial favorite
column3: “The Matter of Splatter”
column4: but the gang chants
column5: groovy breakdowns
column6: and meaty headbanger riffs strewn throughout this record take things to a new level. (Just try to get those gang-growls on the title track or “Ravening”s gruesomely audible chorus out of your head.)

column1: “Coins Upon The Eyes” proves that intros are for wimps
column2: slamming straight into a groovy death jam punctuated by Matt Harvey’s strangled Tompa “Go!” It creeps and vamps through a muscular Stockholm riff and searing Swedish melodeath solos
column3: swaddled in a thick
column4: satisfying guitar tone with just enough spit shine to make sure every instrument bleeds through. The bass tone is on point
column5: too
column6: leaving lots of space to throw its weight around. The band delight in shifting tempos and shocking their listener awake with wild solos and unexpected breakdowns. Closing track “The Rotting” goes off into an extended melodic passage that never gets boring
column7: while the burly “Dysmorphic” breaks into an ominous acoustic interlude before diving back into the pit. “Sickened” starts with a perfectly spewed “Bleagh!” from Harvey
column8: blasting through a perfect example of the interplay between the band’s trademark guttural bellows and frantic high-pitched squawks before barking out “Move your ass!” The jittery d-beat on “(So Passes) the Glory of Death” ensures that you’ll do just that. These tracks (as well as damn near everything else on the record) are going to slay in a live setting
column9: just as Exhumed intended. They’re no slouches onstage
column10: and Necrocracy is poised to add plenty of ammunition to that formidable live onslaught.

column1: This may be Exhumed’s most accessible offering yet
column2: but that doesn’t mean they’ve lost their edge. Matt Harvey and his merry maniacs know exactly what they’re doing
column3: and have spent 20-0dd years perfecting their poisonous formula. The riffs still bludgeon
column4: the snare still snaps
column5: and the dual vocal assault still growls and yelps with the best of them. The wailing solos and brilliant flashes of melodic death metal perfection are a welcome addition
column6: as is their maturing approach to songwriting. Ultimately
column7: Necrocracy is one more in a long line of killer albums
column8: and thanks to its dynamic range
column9: clever riffs
column10: and newfound melodic focus
column11:
is likely to ensnare the youth of today the same way its spiritual predecessor lured in the young heshers of old.

Darold Ferguson Jr.-- best known as A$AP Ferg

column4: he can write (take his bendy
column5: gleeful “Shabba”)
column6: and he’s weird-- when he’s feeling purple
column7: he channels his inner Fergenstein
column8: a lewder
column9: more hedonistic persona. He also talks big: “I wanna be as known as Jesus
column10: ” he told me earlier this year
column11: later mentioning his affinity for artists like Jean-Michel Basquiat and Warhol. (Sounds like he’d enjoy Jay-Z’s bathroom). He’s funny
column12: he’s got a peculiar style
column13: and he’s got
column14: for a lack of a better word
column15: a sizeable amount of swag. Like Rocky

column1: Trap Lord
column2: Ferg’s debut mixtape turned debut album
column3: probably isn’t that record
column4: though it has quite a few bright spots. While it begins with a fierce
column5: feverish bundle of tracks-- the hulking
column6: patois-smeared “Let It Go”
column7: the infectious knocker “Shabba”
column8: the emotional
column9: mythologizing “Hood Pope”-- it’s also listless in spots
column10: too reliant on underdeveloped ideas. Some of that can be chalked up to the nature of the record's existence-- like Flockaveli
column11: it was originally conceptualized as a mixtape and only later was transformed into a major label debut. But a fair chunk of Trap Lord finds Ferg trying to figure himself out in real-time-- a natural shape shifter
column12: he never stays in the same form for long
column13: switching personalities and flows at the drop of a hat. Where it’s effective on songs like “Hood Pope” and the thundering opener “Let It Go”
column14: it’s less so on scatterbrained songs like “Fergivicous” and “Make a Scene”. For an artist drawing effortlessly from what seems to be a wellspring of creativity and thoughtful tribute
column15: Trap Lord can
column16: at times
column17: feel underdeveloped and skeletal.

column1: But
column2: that’s not to suggest that Trap Lord doesn’t sound great-- A$AP Mob still has the best ears in town. The production is leering and paranoid but rippled with muscle. It’s a dark-tinted record
column3: to be sure
column4: sonically and lyrically. The VERYRVRE-produced “Hood Pope” chronicles the loss of a young child; “Murder Something” uses a Kirk Franklin analogy to underscore a particular
column5: graphic ass-kicking; the closing
column6: experimental “Cocaine Castle” uses a crack house as the setting
column7: a location where the protagonist sees “doctors in their suits”
column8: babies
column9: his mom. It’s heavy shit
column10: reinforced by thick
column11: tense production from under-the radar producers like Frankie P
column12: P on the Boards
column13: Snugsworth and HighDefRazjah. The stormy sonic texture is the backbone that the album aligns itself along
column14: a logical combination of Cleveland smoke (Bone Thugs-N-Harmony incidentally show up on ""Lord"")
column15: Death Row menace
column16: and classic New York rap radio that's perfectly tailored to A$AP Ferg's reverential package.

column1: When Trap Lord flashes-- Ferg’s speed-it-up-slow-it-down verse on “Work” is pure thrill-- it’s brilliant. But despite its status as his commercial debut
column2: it's easiest to approach it as a low-stakes introduction to Ferg
column3: an artist who
column4: like Rocky and other newcomers like Travi$ Scott
column5:
has the ability to push the boundaries of the genre toward more experimental sounds and ideas. Though Trap Lord's vision is refracted through split personalities-- for better or for worse-- A$AP Ferg still sounds like a star in the making.

The contemporary composer's life is a complicated thing. Not only are there commissions to be written and personal works to be performed
column2: but there are musicians
column3: academic directors
column4: tony labels
column5: demanding benefactors
column6: and gala-happy chamber arts societies to be placated. Not only is there the classical canon and instrumentation to be managed; there are also all kinds of electronic devices and experiments to be integrated
column7: not infrequently amid multidisciplinary performance settings. And if navigating this demanding new music world isn't enough
column8: there's the indie one it increasingly mingles with
column9: sending you scampering between campus auditoriums and nightclub stages.

column1: Scottish composer Anna Meredith knows what it's like to keep such a complex machine of prestige and exigency humming along. She has been a composer-in-residence at the BBC Scottish Symphony Orchestra. She's made classically trained young people perform something like a goofy symphonic version of Steve Reich’s Clapping Music at Royal Albert Hall. She's padded her income with commercial work including
column2: reportedly
column3: music for MRI scanners. That's a terrifying prospect if you consider it through the lens of her solo style
column4: which is shaping up-- understandably
column5: given the aforementioned context-- as a pressure vent for overwhelming
column6: spontaneous
column7: brazen grandeur. Would you want to hear Death Star explosion music while getting your brain scanned in a metal pod?

column1: Meredith unveiled her smart
column2: intrepid electronic music last year on the Black Prince Fury EP
column3: which was steeped in a sense of adventure associated with the fantasy video games and fantasy metal of the 1980s
column4: when Meredith was a child. The EP was spearheaded by ""Nautilus""
column5: a sentient tidal wave of synthetic brass pulses more gloriously malevolent than anything cooked up by TNGHT or ripped off the Godzilla soundtrack by Pharoahe Monch. ""I came up with a bit of it
column6: and thought
column7: 'Well
column8: that's a bit ridiculous
column9: but let's just roll with it!'"" Meredith told Pitchfork. On the new Jet Black Raider EP
column10: she adds some real clarinets
column11: glockenspiels
column12: drums
column13: cello
column14: and even singing to her virtual instruments
column15: but otherwise
column16: she picks up in the same retro-flavored
column17: high-spirited
column18: questing mood where she left off.

column1: The 8-bit video game scores of the 80s were influenced by medieval music-- its limited polyphony suited the handful of channels you could get on a chip-- and by hair metal guitar solos
column2: for their built-in adrenaline. Video game composers used these channels as maximally as possible
column3: stuffing them with ghoulish chromatic bass lines
column4: runaway arpeggios
column5: and memorably brave or haunting melodic themes. Meredith's solo work feels couched in this dated techno-cultural moment. Her song titles sound like Zelda monsters; her EP names like Final Fantasy summon spells. With the short hair and puffy shirt she wears in promo photos
column6: she would make a great bard at a LARP session. ""Orlok""
column7: which fills the monstrous-banger slot established by ""Nautilus""
column8: begins with a fast sinister progression that makes you feel like you've booted up Wizards & Warriors
column9: then rampages through seven minutes of explosive final-boss music
column10: but with contemplative respites and beats nudged around in time.

column1: As on Black Prince Fury
column2: the new EP's initial shock-and-awe campaign is rounded out by three shorter
column3: lighter pieces
column4: though the mercurial ""Unicron""-- imagine if there was such a thing as a pipe organ with a built-in digital sequencer
column5: and it was totally haunted-- nears ""Orlok"" in groaning weight and playful menace
column6: and often feels
column7: as do many of Meredith's tracks
column8: like the brief moment when an orchestra scrambles for a tempo change protracted for a breathlessly long time. The sparse ""Bubble Gun"" is as quirkily schematic as its name
column9: with effervescent arpeggios for bubbles
column10: a bass and some brass chords for the gun. Most surprising is ""ALR""
column11: where Meredith sings ingenuous lyrics in a clear
column12: humble voice over molten electro-pop
column13: melding the breezniess of Au Revoir Simone with the wide-open thrusters of M83.

column1: Certainly
column2: Meredith must share Anthony Gonzalez's love of 80s synth-pop; this is someone who twisted apart ""The Power of Love"" on her last EP. But rather than a nostalgic embalming of old feelings
column3: this is rough and ready music that bursts with contemporary inspiration
column4: aiming to flood the synapses and master the senses. Though musical subtleties naturally emerge from Meredith's training and practice
column5:
the extroverted impact and unserious charisma of Jet Black Raider is even more admirable and rare.

Laura Veirs' music is focused on her voice
column2: lyrics
column3: and guitar
column4: but to call her simply a singer/songwriter misses the mark. It captures the pick-up-and-play directness of her songwriting while leaving out a whole other dimension: the formal distance and art-music aesthetics she brings to her albums. It's not that Veirs' songs-- where vestiges of jazz and blues enrich a sparse
column5: rocky soil of folk and country-- couldn't be beat out on an acoustic guitar at a coffeehouse. But they would lose something crucial without their arrangements; a malleable sense of time and place. And not many coffeehouse singer/songwriters have recorded for Nonesuch or worked with jazz greats such as Bill Frisell and Brian Blade. Blade
column6: Wayne Shorter's genius drummer
column7: is but one of the illustrious guests on Warp and Weft
column8: Veirs’ new album of sinewy
column9: elemental songs
column10: overcast with the anxieties of motherhood.

column1: ""Overcast"" is nearly a constant in Veirs' music
column2: which is easy to connect to her vantage from the Pacific Northwest. But more than Portland skies
column3: Warp and Weft conjures a low
column4: angular desert with percussion like rattlesnakes
column5: guitars like scorpion stings
column6: and pedal steels and string bends like reeling stars
column7: all reverberating into shrouded gray distances. Veirs' voice runs through as clear and even as moonlight. With husband and long-time producer Tucker Martine
column8: she fleshes out her wind-scoured terrain with pearly swirls of keyboard
column9: a bit of mandolin and viola
column10: some ruminative piano and organ. An electric guitar glints like mica chips from the woozily pitched terrain of ""Sun Song""
column11: where Veirs alternates her breathiest and flintiest vocal timbres with shivery results. American music history is a ghostly presence: Jazz pianist and harpist Alice Coltrane is feted
column12: strangely enough
column13: with zooming guitar rock
column14: and you know they had a harp around because it appears on ""White Cherry""
column15: an unabashedly jazz number with a lush sax and big soft cymbals and chromatic organ vamps.

column1: Warp and Weft was recorded while Veirs was eight months pregnant
column2: and inklings of ambient violence
column3: unthinkable abandonment
column4: and maternal isolation toughen up her mannered idylls of the natural world. On ""Dorothy of the Island""
column5: she belts out a snippet of a ""Motherless Children""
column6: a folk song that's been recorded by everyone from Roseanne Cash to Eric Clapton. ""Dorothy of the island fell into a well inside her head
column7: Veirs adds in her own words
column8: developing a stirring vocal melody over a softly ringing bed of electric guitar and keyboard. On the churning ""America""
column9: she stares down an ominous country where ""everyone's packing heat."" And ""Sadako Folding Cranes"" enshrines a child who survived the atomic bombing of Hiroshima in a music-box shanty topped off with forlorn whistling
column10: dispensing with several affectations at once.

column1: At worst
column2: Veirs can be a mite precious: You couldn't think up a better Decemberists parody title than ""Finster Saw the Angels""
column3: which is about the folk artist who painted the cover of R.E.M.'s Reckoning. But the delicately chained unison of the guitar and vocal melodies makes for a standout passage in a record that feels fresher and sharper than we've heard from Veirs in awhile
column4:
and perhaps serves as the dark flipside of children's record Tumble Bee.

"|18188.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18188-laura-veirs-warp-and-weft/|7.4|Brian Howe

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/19557/homepage_large.39c957fd.jpg|Personal Appeal|2930.0|R. Stevie Moore|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Care in the Community']|2013-08-22 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:54:02.596729|"

R. Stevie Moore’s body of work is unmanageably vast. One estimate put his discography at over 400 releases
column2: and that was a decade ago. But there’s a simple contradiction running through all of it. On one hand
column3: Moore is the prototypical outsider
column4: mostly home-recording his idiosyncratic tunes since the early 1970’s. Yet he’s also a kind of hyper-insider. Born in Nashville to a session-musician father
column5: he has long explored many established genres
column6: including pop
column7: rock
column8: classical
column9: funk
column10: metal
column11: even hip-hop. Maybe it’s best to think of him as an outsider looking in. His work reveres the history of American popular music
column12: yet his methods prove you can make an original contribution to that canon without bending to commercial conventions.

column1: Not that Moore wouldn’t welcome popularity. In fact
column2: his music often struggles with the temptations and frustrations of chasing success and fame. One example opens <i>Personal Appeal
column3: a compilation culled from three decades of his mail-order “Cassette Club” series. It’s called “Why Can’t I Write a Hit?”
column4: which Moore must mean as at least half a joke-- he clearly can write catchy hooks and choruses
column5: and he knows it. His music is so full of them sometimes you wonder if they’re the only thing in his brain.

column1: Maybe what Moore really is asking is
column2: “Why can’t I write a simple hit?” Because on that song and many of his others
column3: his melodies can include bracing time-changes
column4: bizarre left turns
column5: hard cuts to dissonance
column6: and stirring moments of reflection. (Or
column7: as he puts it bluntly at end of the track
column8: “The songs are too weird.”) Moore rarely keeps things simple for an entire tune
column9: and while that’s made his music hard to sell
column10: it’s also made it interesting. He knows this
column11: too-- as he told The Wire last year
column12: “I wish I wasn’t so desperate
column13: and yet I’m damned glad I’m so desperate because it kept me innocent and not a bullshit artist.”

column1: Moore’s aversion to easy solutions-- alongside his obsession with diverse musical styles-- can make listening to him a whiplash-inducing challenge. The tonal shifts come hard and fast
column2: and I often find myself skipping over a few tracks on any given Moore album
column3: especially the more precious pieces whose novelty can be hard to see beyond. But his high-speed unpredictability is ultimately thrilling
column4: and delivers lots of payoffs. You can approach his music the way Mark Twain advised dealing with the weather in New England: if you don’t like it
column5: just wait a few minutes.

column1: You can also wait until the next time Moore devotees pick gems from his back catalogue to reissue. Right now is a particularly good period: alongside Care in the Community’s Personal Appeal
column2: Brooklyn’s Personal Injury-- a label that’s so far solely focused on Moore records-- has reissued 1978’s Delicate Tension and 1986’s Glad Music. All three offer solid entry points into Moore’s oeuvre
column3: and the fact that I’m not sure which to recommend first is testament to how tireless Moore is. There are ups and downs on each
column4: but you never get the sense that he’s phoning anything in. He’s made hundreds of albums because he wants to
column5: not because anyone expected or demanded it.

column1: Of these three records Personal Appeal is naturally the most diverse. It offers sides of Moore not often seen elsewhere
column2: like the old-timey crooner of “Quarter Peep Show”
column3: the space-age balladeer of “Man Without a Purpose”
column4: and the looney-tunes rapper of “Forecast”. There are some straighter pop gems too
column5: but the overall variety makes Personal Appeal one of the more dizzying Moore releases-- a considerable feat given how predisposed he is to changing things up.

column1: In comparison
column2: Delicate Tension and Glad Music are more consistent. The latter offers the most shoulda-hit tracks
column3: such as the new-wavey “I Like to Stay Home” and the riff-happy “Part of the Problem”. It also has a healthy share of requisite oddball ditties and brain-fired experiments. Delicate Tension goes a bit deeper. In many places across its 14 tracks
column4: Moore gives humor and seriousness equal weight without letting either cancel the other out. It might be overdramatic to say that during tunes like the bouncing “Funny Child” or the “I Go Into Your Mind” (wherein Moore declares “I swim upon your tears”) you won’t know whether to laugh or cry. But Moore certainly knows how to make heavy subjects hilarious and make funny lines moving
column5: in a way matched by few (Captain Beefheart and Eugene Chadbourne come to mind).

column1: Both Delicate Tension and Glad Music include some skit-like transitions that give them the feel of an amateur radio show (Moore often employs that style when crafting albums; he even spent time in the early 80s as a DJ on the great freeform station WFMU). In that sense
column2: they sound almost as much like compilations as Personal Appeal does. But then most R. Stevie Moore albums do
column3: and that’s a big part of his charm. When he’s at his best
column4:
you feel like you’re getting a well-selected sample from the endless trove of sounds and ideas blubbing inside his brain.

column1:
1|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/19659/homepage_large.8a1004a8.jpg|Delicate Tension|2930.0|R. Stevie Moore|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|1.0|['Personal Injury']|2013-08-22 00:00:00|1979|2016-06-11 16:54:02.596729|"

R. Stevie Moore’s body of work is unmanageably vast. One estimate put his discography at over 400 releases
column2: and that was a decade ago. But there’s a simple contradiction running through all of it. On one hand
column3: Moore is the prototypical outsider
column4: mostly home-recording his idiosyncratic tunes since the early 1970’s. Yet he’s also a kind of hyper-insider. Born in Nashville to a session-musician father
column5: he has long explored many established genres
column6: including pop
column7: rock
column8: classical
column9: funk
column10: metal
column11: even hip-hop. Maybe it’s best to think of him as an outsider looking in. His work reveres the history of American popular music
column12: yet his methods prove you can make an original contribution to that canon without bending to commercial conventions.

column1: Not that Moore wouldn’t welcome popularity. In fact
column2: his music often struggles with the temptations and frustrations of chasing success and fame. One example opens <i>Personal Appeal
column3: a compilation culled from three decades of his mail-order “Cassette Club” series. It’s called “Why Can’t I Write a Hit?”
column4: which Moore must mean as at least half a joke-- he clearly can write catchy hooks and choruses
column5: and he knows it. His music is so full of them sometimes you wonder if they’re the only thing in his brain.

column1: Maybe what Moore really is asking is
column2: “Why can’t I write a simple hit?” Because on that song and many of his others
column3: his melodies can include bracing time-changes
column4: bizarre left turns
column5: hard cuts to dissonance
column6: and stirring moments of reflection. (Or
column7: as he puts it bluntly at end of the track
column8: “The songs are too weird.”) Moore rarely keeps things simple for an entire tune
column9: and while that’s made his music hard to sell
column10: it’s also made it interesting. He knows this
column11: too-- as he told The Wire last year
column12: “I wish I wasn’t so desperate
column13: and yet I’m damned glad I’m so desperate because it kept me innocent and not a bullshit artist.”

column1: Moore’s aversion to easy solutions-- alongside his obsession with diverse musical styles-- can make listening to him a whiplash-inducing challenge. The tonal shifts come hard and fast
column2: and I often find myself skipping over a few tracks on any given Moore album
column3: especially the more precious pieces whose novelty can be hard to see beyond. But his high-speed unpredictability is ultimately thrilling
column4: and delivers lots of payoffs. You can approach his music the way Mark Twain advised dealing with the weather in New England: if you don’t like it
column5: just wait a few minutes.

column1: You can also wait until the next time Moore devotees pick gems from his back catalogue to reissue. Right now is a particularly good period: alongside Care in the Community’s Personal Appeal
column2: Brooklyn’s Personal Injury-- a label that’s so far solely focused on Moore records-- has reissued 1978’s Delicate Tension and 1986’s Glad Music. All three offer solid entry points into Moore’s oeuvre
column3: and the fact that I’m not sure which to recommend first is testament to how tireless Moore is. There are ups and downs on each
column4: but you never get the sense that he’s phoning anything in. He’s made hundreds of albums because he wants to
column5: not because anyone expected or demanded it.

column1: Of these three records Personal Appeal is naturally the most diverse. It offers sides of Moore not often seen elsewhere
column2: like the old-timey crooner of “Quarter Peep Show”
column3: the space-age balladeer of “Man Without a Purpose”
column4: and the looney-tunes rapper of “Forecast”. There are some straighter pop gems too
column5: but the overall variety makes Personal Appeal one of the more dizzying Moore releases-- a considerable feat given how predisposed he is to changing things up.

column1: In comparison
column2: Delicate Tension and Glad Music are more consistent. The latter offers the most shoulda-hit tracks
column3: such as the new-wavey “I Like to Stay Home” and the riff-happy “Part of the Problem”. It also has a healthy share of requisite oddball ditties and brain-fired experiments. Delicate Tension goes a bit deeper. In many places across its 14 tracks
column4: Moore gives humor and seriousness equal weight without letting either cancel the other out. It might be overdramatic to say that during tunes like the bouncing “Funny Child” or the “I Go Into Your Mind” (wherein Moore declares “I swim upon your tears”) you won’t know whether to laugh or cry. But Moore certainly knows how to make heavy subjects hilarious and make funny lines moving
column5: in a way matched by few (Captain Beefheart and Eugene Chadbourne come to mind).

column1: Both Delicate Tension and Glad Music include some skit-like transitions that give them the feel of an amateur radio show (Moore often employs that style when crafting albums; he even spent time in the early 80s as a DJ on the great freeform station WFMU). In that sense
column2: they sound almost as much like compilations as Personal Appeal does. But then most R. Stevie Moore albums do
column3: and that’s a big part of his charm. When he’s at his best
column4:
you feel like you’re getting a well-selected sample from the endless trove of sounds and ideas blubbing inside his brain.

"|18364.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18364-r-stevie-moore-personal-appeal/|7.7|Marc Masters
