column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/19578/homepage_large.cd249cf2.jpg|Mourning Trance|28498.0|Still Life Still|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Arts & Crafts']|2013-08-22 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:54:03.367936|"

Toronto quintet Still Life Still's 2009 full-length debut Girls Come Too was a shaggy collection of post-Broken Social Scene indie rock
column2: co-produced by that band's head honcho Kevin Drew. It was the sort of first record that came with immediately apparent strengths and weaknesses: the band's knack for spindly
column3: easily melodic guitar hooks was evident
column4: but counteracted by lyrical conceits that ran the gamut from immature to disgusting. The grotesquerie climaxed
column5: quite literally
column6: on the back-half of ""T-Shirts
column7: a song that hinges on its narrative participants engaging in a sort of barter involving bodily fluids.

column1: The band's new record
column2: Mourning Trance
column3: is grappling with weightier issues
column4: drawn from the deaths of one member's parents and a close friend of the group. The series of traumas inspired the record's title
column5: which refers to the natural struggle to continue on with our lives and duties in the face of loss. And while newfound maturity and thematic concerns borne out of personal problems are not foolproof indicators of musical quality
column6: Mourning Trance is a major step forward from the debut on multiple fronts.

column1: Vocalist Brendan Saarinen has described album opener ""Burial Suit"" as a ""starting point"" for Mourning Trance
column2: and it's easy to imagine the band in the studio playing the track back and realizing they'd struck a vein. It's a fantastic song
column3: nicely textured and ringing with anthemic ambition. It's also notable for its sense of scale and pace: a guitar line that might've previously been pushed to the foreground is relegating to a role of an atmospheric backing whine
column4: and a vault into a climactic round of full-band vocals feels organic and well deserved. The song finds solid lyrical footing
column5: too
column6: with Saarinen struggling to get out of bed so he can piece his life back together.

column1: The band manages to sustain the momentum generated by ""Burial Suit"" over Mourning Trance's first half. “Dancing Spines” lives up to its title
column2: quickly driving forward with jittery percussion and a viscous bass line
column3: and the title track hides a potentially dark sentiment underneath a sweet vocal melody as Saarinen chants
column4: “I don’t wanna see it when you wake up.” These songs share a refreshing guitar-related restraint: where the best tracks on Girls Come Too possessed little to recommend other than memorable leads
column5: even less successful Mourning Trance cuts offer a new emphasis on other elements
column6: from splashy and engaging rhythmic sections to buzzing synths like those on lead single “In Enemies”. The guitar parts are still worth commending
column7: but they're not the sole reasons for each song's existence.

column1: The album does falter a bit at the back end of its second half
column2: closing with a set of songs that are propped up by one or two good ideas but lack the tight construction and craft of earlier cuts. Take ""Deer Hologram""
column3: for instance: an introductory riff worthy of a Smashing Pumpkins C-side circa Siamese Dream and a decent ""dear/deer"" homophone pun are appealing
column4: but their delivery mechanism is far from indelible. That said
column5:
it's easy to gloss over a few missteps in light of the leap Still Life Still have taken.

"|18383.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18383-still-life-still-mourning-trance/|6.6|Jamieson Cox

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/19593/homepage_large.2d4fc36f.jpg|Sleeper|27962.0|Ty Segall|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Drag City']|2013-08-21 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:54:04.009978|"

As a recent promotional tour video pointed out
column2: Sleeper's title can be seen as a comment on Ty Segall's own prolificacy. But it also has a deeper resonance. Last December
column3: the singer and guitarist's adopted father died after a long battle with cancer
column4: and shortly after
column5: Segall stopped speaking to his mother. (He doesn't go into detail in interviews
column6: saying only ""she did some bad stuff."") Speaking to NPR
column7: he called this period of his life a ""weird
column8: intense time
column9: and Sleeper is a document of what came out of him in that moment. ""It was kind of a purge
column10: to be honest
column11: he said.

column1: Gone is the brazen
column2: screaming Segall behind Slaughterhouse
column3: Melted
column4: and Twins. Even the relatively sedate Goodbye Bread
column5: with its exploding heads and angry California commercials
column6: featured a more intense Segall than the one who made Sleeper. ""When I was making [Sleeper]
column7: I couldn't have written a loud
column8: heavy song if somebody had paid me to
column9: he said. Instead
column10: he picked up his acoustic guitar and made something that owes less to Sabbath and more to Tyrannosaurus Rex-era Marc Bolan or early Bert Jansch. The title track opens quietly with a whistle
column11: and slowly
column12: he strums a minor chord progression louder and louder. ""Oh sleeper/ My dreamer/ I dream a dream for you
column13: he sings. It's a gentle track that Segall said was initially written for his slumbering girlfriend
column14: but Sleeper's much weightier symbolic connotations of sleeping and dreaming hang heavy over the album.

column1: While the album's tone and pacing seem to reflect its initial inspiration
column2: the lyrics are rarely confessional in the most explicit sense-- any references to Segall's personal life are cloaked in more broadly relatable terms. Occasionally specific details pop out (""He packed his bags this morning/ He bought his ticket today/ Don't you go away/ Not today
column3: he sings on ""She Don't Care"")
column4: and he gets slightly more blunt with ""Crazy""
column5: which is sung to a ""little one
column6: offering comfort because ""He's here/ He's still here/ Though she is crazy."" Segall said that ""Crazy"" was written spontaneously the moment he recorded it-- something he's never done before-- about his mother. ""It’s kind of that thing where a person crosses a line and you just snap
column7: he said. ""You hit a point where you don’t care how it affects that person because you just have to say it so you can move on."" The way he talks about the song
column8: it's easy to imagine a diatribe
column9: but it's a catchy
column10: sweet
column11: two-and-a-half minute song with a lyrical twist. For all its personal significance
column12: ""Crazy"" is as open-ended as Segall's best songs.

column1: So after all his shrieking
column2: shredding
column3: and psychedelic freakouts last year
column4: Sleeper offers a welcome sonic respite. It's easily his most stripped down effort to date
column5: full of elegantly simple
column6: catchy
column7: well-crafted songs. And although everything's acoustic
column8: aside from one well-placed electric solo near the end of ""The Man Man""
column9: the album's packed with subtle diversity. While ""6th Street"" recalls the more psychedelic-leaning folk he made with Tim Presley on Hair
column10: ""The West"" could've been plucked from the rambling Carter Family songbook. Then there's ""Queen Lullabye""
column11: with its distant-sounding falsetto
column12: sludgy guitar
column13: droning low-end
column14: and trudging-through-molasses pace.

column1: But even when he's switching things up on Sleeper
column2: the album never feels as scatterbrained as his previous work. Goodbye Bread opened with a sing-songy ballad and went straight into a shout. Twins featured psychedelia and garage pop. Melted had acoustic-driven catchiness and blown-out fuzz. Those albums could pull off a scattershot of styles with well-placed transitions
column3: but Sleeper is something else. Everything here easily lives in the same universe-- 10 tracks of similarly hued songs
column4: all of a piece. It's his most focused album
column5: with every song's tone easily flowing into the next
column6:
and it's also one of his best. 

"|18398.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18398-ty-segall-sleeper/|8.2|Evan Minsker

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/19577/homepage_large.b1a6e479.jpg|Deep Trip|31063.0|Destruction Unit|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Sacred Bones']|2013-08-21 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:54:04.455328|"

There’s a chapter in Mark Barrowcliffe’s 2007 memoir The Elfish Gene: Dungeons
column2: Dragons and Growing Up Strange in which the author recounts the time in the late 70s when he stopped listening to punk-- the cool music of his native England at the time-- and got into Hawkwind instead. Hawkwind
column3: so his teenaged self reasoned
column4: was more conducive to his Dungeons & Dragons lifestyle and its fixation on all things mystic
column5: cosmic
column6: and denim-jacketed. Punk was about confrontation; Hawkwind was about escapism. At the same time
column7: Barrowcliffe glosses over the basic irony: Many early punk bands
column8: including the Stranglers and the Damned
column9: were influenced by Hawkwind-- and Hawkwind could rage as ferociously as their punk cousins
column10: even when singing about psychedelic warlords and space rituals.

column1: For Destruction Unit
column2: this is all so much false dichotomy. The Arizona collective’s sophomore album
column3: Deep Trip
column4: is spacey. And it’s punky. And it refuses to acknowledge that there’s anything remotely untoward about that particular alchemy of elements. Void
column5: released earlier this year
column6: showed glints of this shimmering space-punk alloy
column7: but it hadn’t quite cohered and hardened. That’s understandable; although the band came together a decade ago
column8: while frontman Ryan Rousseau was serving in the Reatards-- Jay Reatard and his Lost Sounds bandmate Alicja Trout were original members of D-Unit back then-- the group’s current lineup is relatively new. The scrambled
column9: scratchy shakiness of Void has given way to a sound that’s far more focused
column10: corralled
column11: and even refined in its primal ergonomics of paranoia. Chaos abounds
column12: but it’s been funneled into Deep Trip’s streamlined and astrodynamic pulse.

column1: As pulses go
column2: it’s still an erratic one. One of Rousseau’s strengths is knowing the difference between being spacey and being droning; although Deep Trip tracks such as “Slow Death Sounds” and “Final Flight” are brutally
column3: brain-poundingly simple
column4: their riffs don’t lapse into repetition for the sake of repetition. There’s some deceptively catchy and even classic songwriting going on
column5: as one might expect from an ex-Reatard. Here
column6: though
column7: those caveman hooks are given an even more corroded crust of gunk
column8: howl
column9: and echo. On “Control the Light”
column10: Rousseau gulps for air in some bug-eyed trance
column11: like Lux Interior’s last gasp stuck in a near-death-experience loop. Grinding washes of wah pedal and modulated distortion evoke misanthropic freakouts and crises of pataphysical identity
column12: and the low throb of motorik locomotion creeps in to calm the spasms.

column1: The chemical formula is a familiar one to Hawkwind cultists. But “The World On Drugs” and “God Trip” are far less merciless in their cenophobic contemplation of the emptiness of space
column2: both inner and outer. Rousseau and crew are shoveling noise like frantic androids to fill the void
column3: a process of proto-industrial dehumanization that mirrors Chrome at their most savage and severe. But where Chrome-- and their closest contemporaries
column4: Hawkwind-- skirted punk
column5: Destruction Unit embraces it
column6: sticking everything from garage slop to hardcore convulsion into its nihilistic nightmare fantasy. But in the same way Chrome and Hawkwind crafted eternal hymns to stellar and cellular entropy
column7: Deep Trip is anything but fixed to any one time and place-- contemporary or retro. Even when the album infrequently dips into crooning
column8: diffuse looseness on “The Holy Ghost”
column9: there’s something more timelessly potent in the way D-Unit throttles the warp drive. If space-rock as a whole is a role-playing game
column10: one in which its players imagine having front-row seats for the heat-death of the universe
column11:
then Deep Trip is the one of most advanced vehicles yet designed to take them there.

"|18382.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18382-destruction-unit-deep-trip/|7.4|Jason Heller

column1: 0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/19618/homepage_large.96864cf2.jpg|Whenever
column2:
If Ever|31608.0|The World Is a Beautiful Place & I Am No Longer Afraid to Die|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Top Shelf']|2013-08-21 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:54:05.697041|"

By the time you've finished reading the name ""The World is a Beautiful Place & I Am No Longer Afraid to Die
column3: you've likely made two assumptions about this band and both are warranted-- yes
column4: they identify as ""emo"" and yes
column5: they have little to no use for restraint and understatement. Though on a much
column6: much smaller scale
column7: TWIABP resemble Arcade Fire prior to Funeral
column8: having made their name on a promising EP and unpredictable
column9: cathartic live performances that feature nearly a dozen people making music at the same time. But the greater similarity lies in <i>Whenever
column10: If Ever being a rare debut that’s powered by an almost frightening will to live
column11: a desperation that strongly suggests the people involved have no other option to deal with what's inside of them-- when Thomas Diaz screams “let's hope that this works out/ this has got to work out!"" during the frantic conclusion of “Fightboat”
column12: you realize “this” means everything.

column1: TWIABP have already become a bit of a cause célèbre as emo reemerges as a viable
column2: visible genre of independent rock rather than just a pejorative adjective. Understandable
column3: even if there wasn’t anything like them the first time around-- for one thing
column4: they’re from Connecticut and roll about 10 deep
column5: switching vocalists on the fly and utilizing strings and horns to create textures that are more based in post-rock or mid-00s indie rock. And at the risk of revisionist history
column6: I’m just going to put this out there: Cap’n Jazz
column7: Jazz June
column8: and all that other jazz was never this melodic
column9: never this instrumentally tight
column10: and never this well-produced. But if that sound meant everything to you at some point or if you’ve been waiting for a comeback for the sole purpose of airing out old grievances
column11: <i>Whenever
column12: If Ever suits your needs.

column1: They have a weakness for the emo trope of singing being the truest form of self-expression
column2: an act even purer if you don’t have any kind of studied vocal capability-- ""we sang songs/ but we never learned your words or melodies""
column3: ""and when our voices fail us/ we will find new ways to sing
column4: things like that. And on first proper track “Heartbeat in the Brain”
column5: TWIABP sounds like the kind of band where you get the lead vocals simply by wanting it more-- there’s the adenoidal guy
column6: the screaming guy
column7: someone named ""Shitty Greg"" who might not be either of them
column8: and they sometimes sing in tandem
column9: initially exaggerating their hiccuping modulations to a degree that feels like trolling; you’ll know pretty quickly if you’re built for this stuff if “Kinsella” is your safe word. There are the musical cues as well-- searching arpeggios over palm-muted clean chords
column10: spastic drum fills
column11: nasal Casio synth leads. Hell
column12: “Fightboat” might even cause squabbling amongst the old heads as its introductory horn line recalls the one from American Football’s “The Summer Ends”
column13: which some people still complain about to this day.

column1: It takes a little while for Whenever
column2: If Ever to get going
column3: but once it does
column4: TWIABP establish they are not an emo revival act
column5: but more of a spiritual descendent of Danielson Famile or an early 00s Saddle Creek band
column6: a community whose albums serve as a time capsule
column7: a documentation of their lives. It’s unclear exactly when that click happens
column8: but it’s definitely during “Picture of a Tree That Doesn't Look Okay”. Perhaps it’s the part where Greg Horbal asks over desiccated
column9: detuned guitars
column10: “Do you think the landlord’s pissed?/ We left a car parked on the lawn again”-- it’s an inside joke that doubles as a conspiratorial invitation
column11: indicating that you’re welcome to join in and
column12: hell
column13: maybe you were there the whole time (the car ends up on the lawn again by the very next song). Or it could be the point where Whenever
column14: If Ever starts to incorporate clever segues to establish a chronology and continuity to the story-- a delayed guitar resembles a bong rip as “Picture” drifts into “You Will Never Go to Space” and the final line of that song (""Did we dream when we were skeletons/ or did we just wish for our skin?"") becomes foreshadowing for “The Layers of Skin We Drag Around”. Or
column15: maybe it’s after the pace picks up and TWIABP shake off the slowcore rust
column16: a drum roll crescendo leading into a rousing call and response coda where the hooks work out their kinks and become singalongs.

column1: Either way
column2: once “Picture” passes
column3: TWIABP already have accrued the confidence and wisdom to do things they seemed incapable of only minutes prior. “Ultimate Steve” distills the band’s post-rock and emo extremes into concentrate
column4: an all-together-now
column5: 30-second shoutalong bookended by a gorgeous build and fade. During the revolutionary final third
column6: the stakes and consequences of this life pursuit start to push back on TWIABP. “Gig Life” bears the record’s most instantly memorable melody and lyrics
column7: an acoustic power ballad that would’ve been intolerable if performed with the same abandon from earlier. Diaz sings
column8: “You ran away/ You were afraid to make mistakes/ but that's the biggest one you made."" It’s unclear to whom it’s pointed (a former bandmate? A high school friend? An ex?) or where ""somewhere to the west
column9: I suppose"" even entails
column10: it could be New York City or the next town over for all we know. But “Gig Life” establishes that TWIABP understand the sacrifices and the rewards of their chosen gig life and are saddened at losing this person

column1: “Low Light Assembly” follows as a solemn

column5: the low end is heavier and reverbed
column6: the screaming sounds aimed rather than scattershot. And it closes on a chorale that the band created itself to express: ""The world is a beautiful place/ but we have to make it that way... and if you're afraid to die/ Then so am I.""

column1: Yeah

column6: pushing against a palpable resistance without turning existence into an ""us vs. them"" zero sum game. <i>Whenever

column8: societal expectations
column9: preconceptions
column10: and the metaphysical for the greater good of society
column11: and I mean
column12: for crying out loud

It’s taken eight years and seven albums for White Hills to achieve this: cruising altitude. The group’s latest full-length
column2: So You Are… So You’ll Be
column3: arrives on the heels of 2012’s Frying on This Rock; in place of the seething riffage leader David W. has been stoking lately
column4: So You Are tacks toward cooler climes. It’s an interesting direction for the band to take. At its best
column5: like 2011’s H-p1
column6: White Hills' devotion to rock’n’roll of the intergalactic variety is fueled by the urgency of ritual abandon
column7: a heart-pounding
column8: pants-wetting chant in fuzz-pedal form. So You Are's surfaces are not as gloriously scummy.

column1: Turns out that White Hills clean up pretty nicely. That’s “clean” in the relative sense. “In Your Room” pummels and whispers simultaneously
column2: a Dalek nursery rhyme spiked with cyborg call-and-response. The drone-propelled “Forever in Space (Enlightened)” picks up the pace
column3: but there’s a flat-line sameness that supersedes White Hills’ avowed homogeneity. So You Are’s three long instrumentals-- “The Internal Monologue”
column4: “Rare Upon The Earth”
column5: and “MIST (Winter)""-- are full of simulated seagull cries and new-age waterfalls
column6: slabs of padding that swallow and obscure the album to the point where the more energetic tracks feel like the interludes. These are bland turns for a group that usually packs so much kinetic cut-and-thrust.

column1: Still
column2: there’s plenty of So You Are worth sinking teeth into
column3: including the title track
column4: which shows White Hills’ ability to do away with distended
column5: faux-epic intros and just jump straight into the guts of the jam. “In Your Room”'s refreshingly sloppy drum rolls are used to strong effect
column6: but an incessant sequence of sci-fi raygun noises wears out its welcome a quarter of the way through. And the screeching
column7: minimalist breakdown at the end gets points for being the antithesis of the wild-guitar freakout
column8: but it only adds more empty atmosphere to an album top-heavy with it. The pointless snippets of electronic bleepery
column9: “InWords” and “OutWords
column10: ” don’t help.

column1: It isn’t just a matter of volume. There’s a bestial snarl to White Hills that’s mostly missing
column2: and nothing’s rushing in to replace it. Occasionally a hint of shoegaze filigree or kosmische bliss gets drawn into the swirl
column3: but it’s not enough. White Hills sound best when every instrument is dialed up to “bruising” just before the control panel melts. That rarely happens here
column4:
so there are entire dimensions of texture and harmonic overload that haunt the disc with their absence.

column5: I call my own phone and say
column6: 'Don't even trip

a mind nurtured by the alternate universe of the Bay Area rap scene and a gimlet eye that sees everything.

An Object is protest music. Though their crusade is more principled than political
column3: No Age employ a common countercultural tactic on their third proper LP
column4: reappropriating a derogatory term: what are you calling an object? This is art
column5: with an intrinsic value that cannot be quantified or commoditized and society is worse off when any record is treated differently. But the irony is that it's a clever marketing tactic whether intentional or not; No Age’s music
column6: successful as it’s been
column7: never tells their whole story. Whether it’s the Smell
column8: the T-shirts
column9: the ""planned contradictory action
column10: Dean Spunt’s Post-Present Medium label
column11: or anything else bearing their imprimatur
column12: the band’s always been a multimedia affair. They are a bundle of righteous affiliations
column13: “lifestyle music” for people who shudder at the term because their lifestyle is an <i>ethos
column14: upholding certain ideas about DIY
column15: local scenes and anti-corporatism.

column1: When speaking to us earlier this year
column2: Randy Randall promised a total teardown and the time did feel right for the duo to sell high on the “dream-punk” sound they’ve cultivated since Weirdo Rippers. Strikingly spare compared to their previous releases
column3: An Object ensures the shortest distance between the listener and the songs
column4: but with an idealistic corollary that still momentarily shifts the focus away from the music-- with Sub Pop’s blessing
column5: the duo packaged and shipped the record with their own four hands. But what’s left of No Age when you take away the “dream-“ and “-punk”? An Object proves that all the reverb
column6: shrieking noise
column7: and velocity of their past work were hardly afterthoughts or subversive tactics to disguise pop songs. They were essential and the actual mechanics of songwriting-- melody
column8: harmony
column9: structure
column10: instrumental chops-- are exposed on An Object as something that’s far down the list of No Age’s strengths.

column1: You sense that in the three year hiatus between Everything in Between and now
column2: the songs came quickly and most of the time was spent painstakingly turning them inside out-- to mute the drums or excise them completely
column3: use feedback as a backdrop rather than an overlay
column4: to turn rhythms into melody
column5: bass into treble. This is the album that might’ve better earned the title <i>Everything in Between
column6: as the songs are composed of scraps
column7: MacGyver tricks achieved with contact mics
column8: bass guitars
column9: and doctored amps. Occasionally
column10: the effort manifests in notable progress. “An Impression” has a novel rhythmic swing that could actually pass for dancehall and the miniature bumps and bleeps bleed into sighing strings-- it’s No Age’s most typical “pretty” moment
column11: something that could sway people who don’t seek out beauty in harmonic feedback.

column1: But for the most part
column2: An Object consists of potential rock songs denied everything they need to actually rock. The minimalism doesn’t make for a fighting trim No Age-- they sound emaciated
column3: subject to a crash diet equally fueled by asceticism and stubbornness. None of which is helped by the clammy production
column4: which casts a green-grey
column5: sickly pallor over An Object rather than clarity. On past records
column6: Spunt’s rigid vocals could most kindly be described as “effective in context
column7: ” but freed from the obligations of beating the shit out of his drums
column8: he shrinks in the spotlight. There aren’t vocal melodies on <i>An Object
column9: so much as 11 iterations of one note being budged until it moves in the slightest one way or the other. Meanwhile
column10: Randall forgoes riffs for granular
column11: ephemeral textures and rather than building tension through restraint
column12: the lack of rhythmic
column13: tonal or melodic variation causes the album’s midsection to drone more than their past work which intended to be drone music.

column1: No Age attempt to compensate by making An Object their most lyrically direct album
column2: and at the outset
column3: most of Spunt’s words are pointed towards “you.” You know who “you” are-- “Who do you think you are/ trying so hard/ to make that stage/ but it’s not made that way
column4: ” “When I see you/ underneath your lies
column5: ” “You’re a broken leg/ a knife with no blade.” It’s “us vs. <i>the man
column6: maaaan” boilerplate for sure
column7: though the generality can work in the favor of a band that’s always had a cause but not much of a rallying cry. When Spunt sings “I won’t be your generator/ you get no power from me
column8: ” odds are it’s a bird flip to corporations who co-opt underground art
column9: gentrify scenes
column10: and buy out idealism
column11: or whatever. But if you don’t know the first thing about No Age’s extracurriculars
column12: “I Won’t Be Your Generator” is a multi-purpose rager at parents
column13: bosses
column14: boyfriends
column15: girlfriends
column16: whatever’s harshing your buzz. Much like ditching the drums
column17: it’s an obdurate artistic move that’s effective three minutes at a time. But when a band that’s taken up the role of indie’s moral compass gets stuck in the same black and white thinking on “No Ground” and “C’mon
column18: Stimmung”
column19: the pervasive “you” becomes a strawman version of actual No Age enemies like Kings of Leon and Walmart-- certainly worthy of derision
column20: but too big to bother fighting back in a way that might put those principles to the test.

column1: As An Object trudges forward
column2: a strange and welcome change slowly occurs; you can sense No Age growing fatigued enough to let their guard down. After spending the first half of An Object raging against shadowy power brokers
column3: they’ve retained their autonomy only to find out they can’t outrun their own shadows. “Running From A-Go-Go” is the first point where the drab tone matches the mood; when Spunt complains about “bullshit on the stereo
column4: ” he’s probably not taking shots at Imagine Dragons or Macklemore or anyone else specific. It’s just a mundane acknowledgement of a touring musician’s crippling boredom
column5: abject
column6: incapacitating loneliness and how inadequate the moral high ground from earlier can be against emotional encroachment--  “There’s no escaping when it pays your way/ I tell myself it’s one more day/ and one more night alone again.”

column1: On Nouns
column2: Spunt shouted “with passion
column3: it’s true!” So does the pervasive disillusionment of An Object make it false? Of course
column4: not-- the subjects at hand are taken straight from Spunt and Randall’s lives
column5: they've never dealt in fictional songwriting. But perhaps it’s too real
column6: as you get the sense that the hot-button topics that can sustain a punk rocker through their 20s-- art vs. commerce
column7: stability vs. freedom
column8: underground vs. mainstream-- eventually grow tiresome and repetitive and best left to those who have the time and energy for endless debate. That doesn’t mean these conversations shouldn’t happen and perhaps An Object can spark a few. But as a musical document more utile and enjoyable as a conversation piece than for its intended purpose of listening
column9:
An Object sadly lives up to its own name.

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/19604/homepage_large.5d8e7e0f.jpg|History of Man|31588.0|Illangelo|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Bromance']|2013-08-20 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:54:08.190934|"

After becoming the Weeknd’s personal sound guru-- a list of credits that includes not only the entirety of the singer’s sprawling Trilogy as well as every other song Abel Tesfaye has been a featured artist on-- Carlo ""Illangelo"" Montagnese was perfectly poised to ascend from behind the board to legitimate pop stardom. The smart business decision for someone in his place would have been to reach out and grab up some of the offers from A-plus-list rappers and Miley Cyruses that have probably been stacking up in his manager’s inbox. Instead
column2: Montagnese has taken the more unorthodox path of releasing an album of challenging electronic music that’s also an adaptation of Milton’s Paradise Lost. It's also set in space. It’s not the most marketable decision he could have made.

column1: History of Man is an album designed to defy expectations
column2: which can be frustrating because most of the fairly reasonable expectations Montagnese’s well-established fan base had for his debut solo album-- simply more of the same nocturnal
column3: narcotic slow jams that have until now constituted his entire catalog-- would have made for a perfectly good record
column4: or possibly even a great one. What we get instead is kind of a mess
column5: but to its credit
column6: it’s a fascinating one.

column1: Adapting Milton’s masterpiece as an instrumental electronic album is an ambitious task
column2: but ambition is one thing Montagnese doesn’t seem to lack. Everything about History of Man is a challenge to himself and his audience
column3: from the harsh synth patches to the partsy songwriting
column4: all the way down to the lengthy liner notes that juxtapose a sci-fi retelling of Satan’s (or rather “prisoner #870729’s”) prideful revolt with images that blend classical European art with iconography inspired by NASA’s Voyager probes.

column1: It’s a far different way of working than Montagnese is known for. His collaborations with the Weeknd are sometimes abrasive
column2: but they’re always aimed at seducing their audience. On History he’s more than willing to risk alienating listeners for the sake of following his most experimental instincts. Some of his gambits pay off nicely
column3: like interrupting the slow ambient accretion of the opening track
column4: “One Dreamy Hum""
column5: with glitchy snippets of noise jump-cut in at unexpected moments. Others
column6: like the aggro drum & bass pastiche “A Strange World""
column7: are less successful.

column1: History’s best moments come when he’s not playing against type. Songs like “One Dreamy Hum” and “Farewell” showcase his talents for creating deeply fascinating sonic textures that work just fine without a vocalist
column2: or even a beat
column3: for that matter. The first minute and a half of “War” is a tense amalgam of dissonant sound design and post-hip-hop rhythms that doesn’t need the liner notes to suggest dystopian sci-fi. But Montagnese can’t seem to resist the urge to overwork things. “Hum” and “Farewell” both eventually pick up beats near their ends that spoil the mood that they had set so nicely
column4: and after that flawless 90 seconds “War” takes a totally unnecessary turn into dubsteppy post-rock.

column1: It’s hard not to respect Montagnese’s enthusiasm for upending his own trademark aesthetic and recklessly exploring new ground
column2: but in the process History sacrifices too much of the pleasures that his trademark offers. Ambition can be an admirable virtue
column3: but it has a way of getting out of hand
column4:
and ultimately turning self-destructive. Somebody wrote a really good poem about that once.

The women in the Seattle indie group Chastity Belt met and formed in college
column2: and their debut is sly and charming about college
column3: and fresh-out-of-college concerns-- how dumb the objects of your sexual desire can be; which parties suck
column4: because of whom and what can be done about it; fucking and drugs

column5: when you fuck me

column14:

The instrumental hip-hop popularized by J Dilla and Madlib has resulted in producers who are more intrigued by creating interesting production than in making beats that are easy to flow over. Rappers who have shown an ability to ride such volatile trains-- where the loops are twisted
column2: split
column3: difficult to get a feel for-- are few and far between. But when a wordsmith
column4: someone like Blu or Open Mike Eagle
column5: is able to keep their balance
column6: the music that results can be thrilling
column7: a rapper dodging the obstacles of the noise underneath with breathtaking lyrical agility.

column1: The Chicago producer Jeremiah Jae is yet another artist in thrall to the genre's forefathers-- an early Jae project was a Dilla tribute
column2: Eating Donuts & Other Refined Foods-- and like many of his peers
column3: he also deigns to rap. On his first album
column4: Raw Money Raps
column5: he figured out a nice hack
column6: pasting popsicle-stick lyrics onto warped
column7: interesting beats. In an inversion of the norm
column8: the raps became the consistent through-line

column10: his new release from Warp records
column11: Jae pulls back on his production in order to give his rapping a little more of the spotlight. The result is a compromised tape that doesn’t leave enough room for the production skills of a musician who’s a far better producer than he is a lyricist.

column1: With a running time under thirty minutes

column3: and like the best of those tapes

column6: but never tough enough to give the record much bite. Even contributions from outré producers like Jonwayne and Flying Lotus snap into line
column7: with pleasant
column8: well-chosen loops that don’t present Jae with much of a challenge.

column1: Jae’s raps are competent
column2: but unfocused. They don’t concentrate on any particular subject matter
column3: hopping topics DOOM/Cam’ron style
column4: without the kind of internal rhyme magic that made those rappers’ rambles so entertaining. His best songs here
column5: like that Flying Lotus contribution
column6: ""Oatmeal Face""
column7: have him finding pockets and keeping steady but there’s not much content-wise that can hold a listener’s attention.

Imagining Watain as one of the most popular heavy metal bands in the world feels surprisingly easy: During the last decade
column2: they’ve stretched and sculpted what was once primitive black metal bluster
column3: moving from a mess of mimesis at the start of their career to
column4: with their last two records
column5: an invigorated update of an old and infamous sound. Sworn to the Dark
column6: their 2007 transcontinental breakthrough
column7: was grim and mean-- and really
column8: really fun. With blast beats and dashing riffs that felt strangely ecstatic
column9: Sworn to the Dark was an alternative universe hit parade. Its follow-up
column10: 2010’s Lawless Darkness
column11: proved that Watain could reanimate those feelings while studding the blitzes with unlikely new elements-- solos that spun out like Hawkwind
column12: doom impasses that created new centers of gravity
column13: symphonic moments that nodded back toward prog. Like America’s Nachtmystium
column14: these Swedes could extract and expand upon their initial fury and potentially pick up a lot of new listeners in the process. And they invoke an intriguing element of danger
column15: too
column16: with their deadpan Satanic proselytizing
column17: their ornate and inflammatory stage show
column18: and their controversy-stoking past. Watain could be their own heavy metal parking lot scene
column19: with kids ready to run to the devil inside the arena and concerned parents ready to picket and protest outside.

column1: The Wild Hunt
column2: Watain’s first album in three years
column3: won’t quell any such fantasies concerning their could-be ascendance
column4: at least for a bit. In fact
column5: the first side of this 11-track
column6: hour-long album brims with the sort of magnetism that first suggested this band for popularity over so many of their peers. “All That May Bleed” is a set of stops and stomps
column7: with an introduction that begs for fists to be pumped and a rhythm section that sends every verse and chorus into a frenzy. And just ahead of a dervish guitar solo
column8: frontman and provocateur Erik Danielsson yells “The salt of Satan in the wounds-- of Christ!
column9: ” hanging out the sort of Slayer-shaped totem that a few thousand fans might happily yell back at him. And “The Child Must Die” suggests an unholy trinity of Black Sabbath
column10: Judas Priest
column11: and Bathory. Danielsson broadcasts his mortal invective over a stubborn rock’n’roll march
column12: with the blast beats smartly reserved to enliven the breaks between the verses and the space behind the solos. Following the steady instrumental build that opens the album
column13: The Wild Hunt rushes ahead as a hyperbolic
column14: overdriven onslaught
column15: using black metal as bait rather than barrier.

column1: But more than three years have passed since the release of Lawless Darkness
column2: a good chunk of which Watain spent writing and recording The Wild Hunt. The band built the songs for six months and recorded them for four more months in four different studios. Unfortunately
column3: the work shows not in a string of 10 breathless Watain bruisers but instead in a series of tracks that force the band far from its onyx comfort zone. While Watain has often folded alien elements into their black metal
column4: The Wild Hunt tries to fold black metal
column5: or at least its essence
column6: back into those other influences. The title track
column7: for instance
column8: is an arching dirge that takes shape around distended and dramatic guitar lines and choir-of-hell harmonies. It’s an awkward doom pose
column9: like a tourist that knows the language of the land he’s visiting but lacks the subtlety or fluidity to engage native speakers. The first 90 seconds of closer “Holocaust Dawn” are incredible
column10: as though Watain has forced its own basic form onto a carousel ride of horror. But the next five minutes mostly feel like a showcase for other heavy metal bona fides
column11: with demented sound-art incantations brushing up against prog rock moves and thrash metal march. Outside of their element
column12: Watain often sound simply like outsiders. They have strong interests and ideas
column13: if not the experiences and abilities to actualize them. The effort is laudable
column14: at least: Remember
column15: Watain didn’t emerge as a fully formed great band
column16: but they’ve grown into something of one. Maybe their clumsy stumbles
column17: however public now
column18: simply take time to perfect.

column1: Watain’s most flagrant attempt to push past their expected border-- a nine-minute
column2: lighters-up ballad called “They Rode On”-- serves as The Wild Hunt’s unprecedented centerpiece. Like Bob Seger’s “Turn the Page” if Metallica had recorded it in 1988 instead of 1998
column3: it’s a melodramatic portrayal of roving warriors on the lam
column4: preparing for dismissal or death. While it’s symptomatic of the sickly self-conscious feeling that permeates at least half of The Wild Hunt
column5: it’s also great
column6: with Danielsson selling the role of beleaguered vagabond with the same authority he uses as seething frontman. Throughout The Wild Hunt
column7: Danielsson lands some incredible phrases and images
column8: painting his visions of Moloch and apocalypse in poetic couplets and teases. If nothing else
column9: “They Rode On” serves as a clear showcase for his enthusiasm for Watain’s increasing intricacy. Maybe this is the song that introduces Watain to the masses. But more likely
column10: maybe it’s just another indication of a band too restless for easy notoriety or Second Wave replications. That
column11: at least
column12: is more than what most everyone initially expected from Watain
column13:
The Revivalists.

When Odd Future first tumbled out of Southern Los Angeles County in 2010
column3: it wasn’t the high-strung antics of the group’s de facto figurehead <a href=""http://pitchfork.com/artists/29179-tyler-the-creator/"" target=""_blank"">Tyler
column4: the Creator that tipped them into the spotlight. It was Earl Sweatshirt
column5: unbelievably young (15? 16?) and skilled beyond his years
column6: a methodical wordsmith whose splatterpunk murder fantasies were rendered all the more unsettling by his incredible poise. The video for “Earl” (off the mixtape of the same name)
column7: wherein Sweatshirt and company down a risky drug cocktail and party until they begin to decay
column8: was integral in setting the then-unknown collective on its crash course with hip-hop notoriety. But just as Odd Future took off
column9: Earl appeared to vanish. Once a menacing presence over Tyler’s post-Neptunes synth wheeze
column10: Earl was frustratingly absent from the group’s inaugural round of live shows and festival spots as well as the second round of Odd Future solo efforts. The group refused to provide an explanation for the lingering absence of its best rapper when pressed
column11: opting instead to lead fans through a quixotic “Free Earl” campaign immortalized in t-shirts
column12: records
column13: and elaborate satirical fan fiction.

column1: After a winding investigation
column2: Complex was eventually able to trace Earl to a Samoan retreat for at-risk teen boys. It seems his mother
column3: a civil rights activist and law professor
column4: had shipped him overseas to clear his head after behavioral problems bled into his schoolwork. Barring an expository chat with The New Yorker
column5: Earl fell silent after the reveal until turning up unexpectedly on Twitter one night in early 2012 with a new song called “Home” that closed with Sweatshirt giddily announcing his return: “I’m baaaack. Bye.” He appeared on various ephemera afterward: a supremely anesthetized spot on “Super Rich Kids” off Frank Ocean’s Grammy Award winning Channel Orange
column6: an unannounced freestyle on the posse cut “Oldie” from The OF Tape Vol. 2 compilation
column7: and tracks with OF compatriot Domo Genesis and Flying Lotus’ rap alter ego Captain Murphy. He seemed to pick right up where the maleficent EARL left off
column8: the new verses touting the same deadpanned orgies of bloodletting and misanthropy.

column1: It wasn’t until the end of 2012 release of the single “Chum” that Earl addressed his story in song. Built around a simple
column2: affecting piano figure and clattering boom bap low end
column3: “Chum” was a travelogue of a lost soul seemingly back on track. In it Earl opens up about a life of struggles
column4: from the absence of his father
column5: one-time South African Poet Laureate Keorapetse Kgositsile
column6: after a split from his mother (“I just used to say I hate him in dishonest jest/ When honestly I miss this nigga like when I was six”)
column7: to discovering drugs and petty crime
column8: finding a big brother in Tyler
column9: and the fallout from the Complex expose. “Chum” was the most personal and direct he’d ever been on record; it was gobstopping without relying on the trick of sullying the youthful zest of his voice with grim stories of death and defilement.

column1: Loosed from the nauseating gutbucket grit of EARL
column2: Sweatshirt uses his Columbia Records debut Doris to convey a more varied palette of emotions. He challenges the uplifting mood of “Burgundy”’s jazzy Neptunes production
column3: addressing the illness of his grandmother
column4: insecurities about the new material
column5: and lingering issues with his father in one fell swoop (“My priorities fucked up
column6: I know it
column7: I’m afraid I’m going to blow it/ When them expectations raising cause daddy was a poet”). He’s a distant lover on “Sunday”
column8: trading verses with Frank Ocean about trying to tend to withering relationships as studio rats and touring musicians. “Hive” captures the sobering realities of L.A.’s inner city as Earl
column9: his voice just above a whisper
column10: speaks of hopeless commuters biking to jobs that don’t pay their bills (“From a city that’s recession hit/ Where stressed niggas could flex metal with pedals to rake pennies in”). The resignation in his voice in these moments of reflection is every bit as communicative as his unflappable stream of internal rhymes and arresting visual images.

column1: Even in the face of the newfound depth in Earl’s songwriting
column2: Doris’ primary concern is his wordplay
column3: which presents itself in thickets of rhymes so dense they can register as inscrutable on first listen. “Hive”’s second verse opens with: “Desolate testaments trying to stay Jekyll-ish/ But most niggas Hyde
column4: and Brenda just stays preg-a-nant
column5: ” a glob of offbeat references
column6: double entendres
column7: made up words
column8: and brilliantly disguised slant rhymes that hit as great exercises in rhyming words well before the deeper meanings can be teased out. Doris is also relatively hookless; where heaping doses of melody helped Tyler
column9: the Creator break form earlier this year with Wolf
column10: here it’s just raps on raps on raps. Guests are frequent
column11: but they either come out rhyming for dear life
column12: as Odd Future affiliate Vince Staples does when he swipes “Hive” out from under Earl in the third verse. Or they play hype man like Wu-Tang Clan’s RZA on “Molasses” and Vince in the spirited pep talks between Earl’s verses on “Burgundy”. The focus never strays from Earl’s fractious
column13: DOOM-influenced songwriting for long
column14: and Doris prefers to dispense it in short
column15: impactful bursts as the “half short and twice strong” EARL did in 2010.

column1: The album breezes by in 44 minutes
column2: but it feels longer. Earl favors droning
column3: lumbering productions full of intriguing sound textures
column4: but he pulls in enough curveballs to give the album a jerky energy. In the first few minutes alone
column5: we get the airy keys and trap drums of opener “Pre”
column6: brash horns and live drums on “Burgundy”
column7: and piddling video game synths battling chunky bass on “20 Wave Caps”. Between the campy drum shuffle newly added to the end of the otherwise austere “Chum” and the shrill violin trills that usher in a shock beat change in the middle of “Centurion”
column8: Doris gets as much of its jollies from settling into dark
column9: forbidding soundscapes as it does from unexpectedly ripping us up out of them. Without the noirish serial killer stories of earlier work to fall back on
column10: Earl has discovered new ways to shock and disorient the listener.

column1: Doris is full on its author’s prodigious abilities as a formidable young voice in L.A.’s resurgent hip-hop scene
column2: but it’s not as concerned with the wider significance of the moment as it is with disbelief it’s actually happening. As comebacks go
column3: it’s shockingly insular and unassuming. Earl remains self-deprecating throughout; he produces a number of the album’s tracks under the telling moniker Randomblackdude. Even when he skirts the mainstream
column4: he does so with cautious optimism. Earl made a television appearance with the Roots on ""Late Night with Jimmy Fallon"" this month
column5: running through the boisterous “Burgundy” with eyes closed after a tense walk from the blue room to the stage. It was a peculiar event
column6: the anticlimactic unveiling of a star who’d been the talk of rap circles for three years but scarcely able to relish the attention. With Doris
column7:
Odd Future’s Odysseus is finally back and chasing the ghosts out of his head.

When Porcelain Raft’s first singles started circulating in 2010
column3: Mauro Remiddi distinguished himself from the glut of similarly wavy electro-pop acts on numerous levels; for one thing
column4: “Tip of Your Tongue” and ""Dragonfly"" stood out for their craft as opposed to being mere coneyances of vibe. You could also sense that he was a veteran songwriter and you’d be correct. While many of his peers were young men trying to cultivate mystery through anonymity
column5: Remiddi was in his mid-30s and became more interesting with every revelation about his actual life experiences. A number of short-lived and far-flung musical projects took him around the globe and the Italian-born
column6: London-based Remiddi created songs that were equally implaceable: they had shades of Swedish indie
column7: UK bedsit and American lap-pop
column8: and blurred the distinction between a guitar-toting singer/songwriter and a synth-pop artist. The inability to define Porcelain Raft contributed to the initial intrigue
column9: but with his second LP in two years
column10: Remiddi has cemented his sound; Permanent Signal is more or less more of the same
column11: a mutual fatigue passed on from Porcelain Raft to the listener.

column1: As Josh Love noted in our review of Porcelain Raft's 2012 debut Strange Weekend
column2: Remiddi had a vocal connection-- if not a spiritual one-- with glam-rock space cadets of the past without overtly getting into interstellar role playing. Maybe we can chalk it up to the obligations that come with making a debut album and having to tour the thing
column3: but Permanent Signal is more earthbound

column5: but you sense their presence in Permanent Signal’s overall demeanor
column6: a sort of mundane
column7: window-staring melancholy
column8: even if highlight ""The Way Out"" was inspired by the incapacitating effect of Hurricane Sandy in his new home of Brooklyn.

column1: Remiddi's abstract lyrics are shot through with a longing that never devolves into outright despair-- “If I think about it/ Just don’t get me started
column2: ” is the first line on the record and indicative of how candid
column3: direct conversation is something that’s just out of reach. It makes Permanent Signal effective mood music
column4: in that it sounds heartbroken or at least wistfully romantic
column5: and Remiddi's own feelings never trample upon yours.

column1: Consider opener “Think of the Ocean” as guidance for a means of surveying the record: it’s blue
column2: moves in regular
column3: steady tides and difficult to portion out into distinct territories. Hooks slowly reveal themselves
column4: but are almost always instrumental and often referential.  “Cluster” employs a classic Cure trick
column5: using descending guitar lines to make a major key melody draw tears like a minor one. Likewise
column6: “I Lost Connection” is the musical and lyrical centerpiece of <i>Permanent Signal
column7: conveying its emotion not so much through his words but rather the slow rollout of major 7th piano chords
column8: beautifully bright
column9: wispy and touched with a dissonance that makes them sound sad anyway.

column1: In one of the fleeting moments of pleasure
column2: Remiddi breathes “This feeling is taking over/ The sky is made of blue
column3: evocative
column4: sweet nothings underscored by deep piano chords suggesting a house anthem about to break out. Instead
column5: a steady kick drum pulses and eventually fades
column6: a climax denied-- the name of the song
column7: naturally enough
column8: is “Minor Pleasure"". Conversely
column9: “The Way Out” and “It Ain’t Over” interrupt the liminal
column10: waking dream spell with distorted
column11: rumbling breakbeats. They aren’t distractions
column12: but all the same
column13: what are you supposed to make of an album operating under the auspices of pop that needs drum machines to provide the hooks?

column1: At the very least
column2: Permanent Signal proves Remiddi is still distinguishing himself from the long-forgotten also-rans that clogged many an MP3 blog three years back. Whereas most of them couldn’t transition from singles to albums at all
column3: let alone cohesive ones
column4: Porcelain Raft has become too adept at making cohesive
column5: whole statements. Even if Strange Weekend achieved a similarly unified sound
column6: if obvious singles didn’t stand out
column7: key phrases did. And they've taken on a prophetic resonance
column8: ""Put Me to Sleep"" being the least of them. Previously
column9: Remiddi doubted the worth of conversation “Unless You Speak From Your Heart

column14:
an unintentional criticism of Permanent Signal’s lack of definition and presence.

I was lucky: I was spared the knowledge of Diarrhea Planet's name when I discovered them. Walking into a low-ceilinged club in Austin at this year's South by Southwest
column2: I was assaulted by the sight of six twenty-something guys
column3: all shirtless
column4: seemingly none of them over 5""4
column5: essentially scaling the walls. There were guitars played behind backs
column6: over heads
column7: with teeth. I'm pretty sure three guitar solos were happening at once. The people in the audience looked happier than anyone I'd ever seen. It was only when I tapped someone on the shoulder to find out what this band
column8: this epochal experience
column9: called itself
column10: that I learned the awful truth. It didn't help that the exhilarating song they were blasting out
column11: the fan-favorite encore

column1: My experience is a luxury you have been denied
column2: which is unfair and I am sorry. You are
column3: naturally
column4: wisely skeptical-- this picture probably doesn't help. But ""skepticism"" and ""Diarrhea Planet"" cannot meaningfully coexist. They are matter and antimatter

column8: and you can hear some of their joyfully fist-pumping spirit coursing through it. But by itself

column10: but it's tricky and risky getting the dosage correct
column11: and the main problem with a Diarrhea Planet full-length
column12: amazingly
column13: is that it's somehow not quite ridiculous enough.

column1: There are some really good moments
column2: here
column3: to be sure. Diarrhea Planet are a pop punk band
column4: essentially
column5: one that has iron-enriched its sound with the good-times hedonism of hair metal and Tenacious D-style guitar heroics. Their songs sound as much like teen-movie ideas about rock-and-roll bands-- the Wyld Stallyns
column6: the Lone Rangers-- as they do the work real-world rock bands.

column1: Tellingly
column2: many of the songs on I'm Rich Beyond Your Wildest Dreams could pass for KISS: ""Lite Dream""
column3: in particular
column4: sounds like an Ace Frehley vocal take. There are furtively odd moments in the songs that remind you they are being made in 2013
column5: not 1977
column6: like ""Lite Dream""'s shivery little outbreak of Sonic Youth guitars in the bridge

column1: This is an album you yell along to

column3: it may not
column4: but it was certainly not designed for those listening conditions. The most satisfying songs on I'm Rich are the ones that adapt a bit to the fact that all six members

column7: for instance

column8:
of the experience.

The music of the Norwegian one-man black metal band Ildjarn is harsh. Every aspect of the project's output has always been unwelcoming and inaccessible. Some may call it unlistenable
column2: while others will swear the music represents the pinnacle of black metal art. Beauty is in the eye of the beholder
column3: after all
column4: but no matter which way you slice it
column5: there's nothing pretty about Ildjarn. That said
column6: starting with Ildjarn’s best-known albums from 1995 and 1996
column7: Season of Mist has taken it upon themselves to rerelease the project's back catalog (including the short-lived Sort Voktor side project). These will be available on CD and limited edition vinyl with new artwork
column8: which will likely delight some longtime fans
column9: disgust the purists
column10: and thoroughly bewilder newcomers.

column1: To consider oneself an Ildjarn fan requires a certain suspension of belief
column2: or at least
column3: of any expectation that it will sound like anything but what it is. The polarizing effect of Vidar Vaaer's project
column4: which started in 1991 and continued until the 2005 Ildjarn Is Dead compilation
column5: stems from an unwillingness to compromise on anything
column6: from recording quality (zero) to vocal style (singular). Unbearable or irresistible are the only two options
column7: and the former camp is far more populous than the latter. Whether one is reacquainting oneself with these three albums or encountering them for the first time
column8: it’s important to bear in mind that Ildjarn’s heyday was in the early 90s. The recordings come off as brutally minimalist and lo-fi when considered within a modern context
column9: but are honestly fairly par for the course when compared with what many of his peers were doing when Vaaer first began.

column1: Vaaer was an early member of Norway’s Second Wave black metal scene
column2: appearing on a 1991 demo from the pre-Emperor project Thou Shalt Suffer and acting as a live bassist for Emperor themselves in 1993 before splitting off to continue expanding upon his own vision with Ildjarn. Trivia nerds will remember how his former bandmates repaid the favor
column3: with both Ihsahn and Samoth contributing guest vocals on several of Ildjarn’s releases. Though Vaaer definitely takes things to an exceptionally primitive level
column4: the sonic quality does not deviate much from that found on similar recordings from the same time period. Listen to any Beherit demo
column5: or even Mayhem’s Deathcrush.

column1: Unlike his peers that eventually evolved and became more acquainted with a soundboard
column2: though
column3: Vaaer remained loyal to his long-suffering 4-track tape recorder. Ildjarn embraces the singlemindedness of raw punk
column4: bashing away at three chords or less and keeping song lengths taut for maximum impact. He aims for brute force. Most of his songs flirt with the three-minute mark
column5: and come and go in quick
column6: ugly spasms. The result reeks of misanthropic hate.

column1: It’s not hard to see how the likes of Willing Feet
column2: Bone Awl
column3: and even Raspberry Bulbs could owe a hefty debt of gratitude to albums like 1995’s Ildjarn. Nearly every song is populated by simplistic distorted power chords and strong bass lines that bleed together into one steady monotonous drone
column4: broken up by occasional ambient passages a la Burzum's Filosofem that make more sense when his latter-day synthesizer fixation is taken into account. The uniformly coarse vocals are almost always buried low in the mix. As for the percussion
column5: even the most casual of music listeners would have a hard time believing that human hands are holding down those beats. Vaaer works his rickety kit into a lather of constant
column6: unapologetically simple 4/4 beats that serve as both metronome and
column7: often
column8: inadvertent focal point and an absurd number of drum count-ins serve to further disorient. The majority of its 27 songs follow the same rough format
column9: but Vaaer does throw his listener the odd bone on dense
column10: hypnotic tracks like the slow
column11: punishing “Krigere” or uncharacteristically well-developed melody on “Blikkets Storhet”. Here
column12: he proves that he can write compelling
column13: nuanced material. He just doesn’t particularly care to.

column1: Strength and Anger was released barely a year later
column2: swiftly followed by Landscapes
column3: the Svartfråd EP
column4: and then Forest Poetry. Strength and Anger is short by Ildjarn’s standards
column5: with only 18 tracks crammed into its 70-odd minutes. The song largely remains the same
column6: but there are a few hints of progress. Vaaer continues to browbeat his listeners with barbaric lo-fi black metal
column7: but tracks like “VI” and “XV” show melodic development
column8: and the 14-minute dark ambient piece “Black Anger (Hate Meditation 1)” is a total 180. Its harsh noise proclivities carry over onto “Interchange”
column9: and devolve once more into a long
column10: unsettling ambient outro “Midnight Strength
column11: Black Anger (Hate Meditation 2)”.

The music of the Norwegian one-man black metal band Ildjarn is harsh. Every aspect of the project's output has always been unwelcoming and inaccessible. Some may call it unlistenable
column2: while others will swear the music represents the pinnacle of black metal art. Beauty is in the eye of the beholder
column3: after all
column4: but no matter which way you slice it
column5: there's nothing pretty about Ildjarn. That said
column6: starting with Ildjarn’s best-known albums from 1995 and 1996
column7: Season of Mist has taken it upon themselves to rerelease the project's back catalog (including the short-lived Sort Voktor side project). These will be available on CD and limited edition vinyl with new artwork
column8: which will likely delight some longtime fans
column9: disgust the purists
column10: and thoroughly bewilder newcomers.

column1: To consider oneself an Ildjarn fan requires a certain suspension of belief
column2: or at least
column3: of any expectation that it will sound like anything but what it is. The polarizing effect of Vidar Vaaer's project
column4: which started in 1991 and continued until the 2005 Ildjarn Is Dead compilation
column5: stems from an unwillingness to compromise on anything
column6: from recording quality (zero) to vocal style (singular). Unbearable or irresistible are the only two options
column7: and the former camp is far more populous than the latter. Whether one is reacquainting oneself with these three albums or encountering them for the first time
column8: it’s important to bear in mind that Ildjarn’s heyday was in the early 90s. The recordings come off as brutally minimalist and lo-fi when considered within a modern context
column9: but are honestly fairly par for the course when compared with what many of his peers were doing when Vaaer first began.

column1: Vaaer was an early member of Norway’s Second Wave black metal scene
column2: appearing on a 1991 demo from the pre-Emperor project Thou Shalt Suffer and acting as a live bassist for Emperor themselves in 1993 before splitting off to continue expanding upon his own vision with Ildjarn. Trivia nerds will remember how his former bandmates repaid the favor
column3: with both Ihsahn and Samoth contributing guest vocals on several of Ildjarn’s releases. Though Vaaer definitely takes things to an exceptionally primitive level
column4: the sonic quality does not deviate much from that found on similar recordings from the same time period. Listen to any Beherit demo
column5: or even Mayhem’s Deathcrush.

column1: Unlike his peers that eventually evolved and became more acquainted with a soundboard
column2: though
column3: Vaaer remained loyal to his long-suffering 4-track tape recorder. Ildjarn embraces the singlemindedness of raw punk
column4: bashing away at three chords or less and keeping song lengths taut for maximum impact. He aims for brute force. Most of his songs flirt with the three-minute mark
column5: and come and go in quick
column6: ugly spasms. The result reeks of misanthropic hate.

column1: It’s not hard to see how the likes of Willing Feet
column2: Bone Awl
column3: and even Raspberry Bulbs could owe a hefty debt of gratitude to albums like 1995’s Ildjarn. Nearly every song is populated by simplistic distorted power chords and strong bass lines that bleed together into one steady monotonous drone
column4: broken up by occasional ambient passages a la Burzum's Filosofem that make more sense when his latter-day synthesizer fixation is taken into account. The uniformly coarse vocals are almost always buried low in the mix. As for the percussion
column5: even the most casual of music listeners would have a hard time believing that human hands are holding down those beats. Vaaer works his rickety kit into a lather of constant
column6: unapologetically simple 4/4 beats that serve as both metronome and
column7: often
column8: inadvertent focal point and an absurd number of drum count-ins serve to further disorient. The majority of its 27 songs follow the same rough format
column9: but Vaaer does throw his listener the odd bone on dense
column10: hypnotic tracks like the slow
column11: punishing “Krigere” or uncharacteristically well-developed melody on “Blikkets Storhet”. Here
column12: he proves that he can write compelling
column13: nuanced material. He just doesn’t particularly care to.

column1: Strength and Anger was released barely a year later
column2: swiftly followed by Landscapes
column3: the Svartfråd EP
column4: and then Forest Poetry. Strength and Anger is short by Ildjarn’s standards
column5: with only 18 tracks crammed into its 70-odd minutes. The song largely remains the same
column6: but there are a few hints of progress. Vaaer continues to browbeat his listeners with barbaric lo-fi black metal
column7: but tracks like “VI” and “XV” show melodic development
column8: and the 14-minute dark ambient piece “Black Anger (Hate Meditation 1)” is a total 180. Its harsh noise proclivities carry over onto “Interchange”
column9: and devolve once more into a long
column10: unsettling ambient outro “Midnight Strength
column11: Black Anger (Hate Meditation 2)”.

column5: though typing the word “accessible” in any sort of Ildjarn discussion is farce. Thanks to a minute increase in sound quality and the strangely catchy “Visions of the Earth (2nd Returning)”
column6: the dominant bassline in “Deepening in Grey”
column7: and fuzzy dirge of closing track “No Place Nowhere” it’s more consistent and slightly more listenable than its predecessor. Even for a humorless Scandinavian
column8: the whimsical title is so tongue-in-cheek it hurts.

column2: on these records
column3: Ildjarn achieved what Norwegian black metal ostensibly set out to accomplish in the first place
column4: by creating the most resolutely unlistenable

This has been a great year for solo acoustic guitarists. So far in 2013
column2: three of that instrument’s masters-- William Tyler
column3: Glenn Jones
column4: and Chuck Johnson-- have made possibly the best albums of their respective careers
column5: while Nathan Salsburg and Bill Orcutt are poised to do the same soon. But apparently Danny Paul Grody isn’t afraid of competition. Having already made two solid LPs in the past three years
column6: he decided to get more ambitious and expansive on his latest
column7: Between Two Worlds. And guess what? It might be the best album of his career.

column1: It also manages to carve out a sonic niche in an arena full of them. Grody’s approach stands out for a lot of reasons
column2: but two in particular fascinate. First
column3: his songs are more about repetition than melody
column4: more about hypnosis than hook. There are memorable note patterns all over Between Two Worlds
column5: but a deeper impression is left by the way Grody turns them into mantras. His playing stretches time
column6: making even his busiest passages patient and meditative. There’s a reason he called one of the best tracks here “Time Spirals”.

column1: In addition
column2: Between Two Worlds is a singular acoustic guitar album simply because it’s more than an acoustic guitar album. It starts off as one
column3: with three songs focused on Grody’s ringing string work. But as the album winds forward
column4: he subtly adds other elements-- piano chords
column5: synth drones
column6: tape manipulation
column7: wordless vocals-- to accent and surround his guitar. This evolution from simple strands to denser fields happens naturally
column8: bolstered by Grody’s experience crafting larger environments with Tarentel and the Drift. So by the time closer “Ojito (At Sunset)” arrives
column9: its long
column10: space-filling tones feel like the logical extension of earlier finger-picked figures.

column1: Before you get that deep into Between Two Worlds
column2: though
column3: take some time to get lost in those first three tracks. On each
column4: Grody gradually massages a loop of notes
column5: crafting a spectrum of shapes and colors without ever deviating far from his starting point. I’m especially intoxicated by “You
column6: the Invisible”
column7: which begins as a kind of one-man funeral march with slow strums and dramatic pauses. But as the pace quickens and the gaps close
column8: Grody hits an ecstatic rush while steadfastly maintaining a sense of gravity.

column1: That range of moods persists as Between Two Worlds shifts focus from string-plucks to held tones. Grody never really gets light-hearted; most of the time the atmosphere is pretty heavy. But it’s hard to imagine anyone getting bummed out by any part of Between Two Worlds. Even its most somber moments are infused with optimism-- a trust that non-verbal sound can
column2: when played well
column3:
express pretty much any emotion imaginable.
