column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/19573/homepage_large.4ad323d6.jpg|Loud City Song|29994.0|Julia Holter|['Electronic']|1.0|0.0|0.0|['Domino']|2013-08-16 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:54:14.118411|"

In an early scene in the still-fascinating
column2: delightfully bizarre 1958 MGM musical Gigi
column3: a few characters enter a restaurant called Maxim’s. The vibe is Moulin Rouge meets Cheers: a frenetic
column4: turn-of-the-century Parisian haunt where
column5: for better or worse
column6: everybody knows your name. When each couple enters Maxim’s-- yes
column7: couple; somehow you get the sense that it would be social suicide for a respectable lady of the time to step foot in the place unaccompanied-- a crowd of patrons begins to chant in a hushed
column8: gossipy tone. As they whisper the kinds of things that people rarely say aloud (even when they’re thinking them)
column9: and the scene draws a bleak
column10: ironic contrast between people’s private thoughts and the outward demands of polite society. “Isn’t she a mess? Isn’t she a sight?” they say as one pair enters. “Let’s invite them out tomorrow night!”

column1: “There’s something kind of creepy about that scene that I wanted to bring out
column2: ” L.A. avant-pop musician Julia Holter said in a recent interview
column3: talking about “Maxim’s I & II”
column4: a gorgeous (if slightly sinister) pair of songs that appear on her mesmerizing third album
column5: Loud City Song. Holter’s said that the album is her own loose interpretation of Gigi-- both the musical and the original 1944 novella by the French writer Colette (the plot
column6: in the expert
column7: proto-Twitter brevity of a Turner Classic Movie blurb: “A Parisian girl is raised to be a kept woman but dreams of love and marriage.”).

column1: Plenty of other songwriters might fumble or stiffen when drawing on source material from decades before they were born
column2: but not Holter. Maybe it’s because making a record based on a 1950s MGM musical is actually her idea of keeping things new-school: Tragedy
column3: her 2011 debut
column4: was an ambitious yet intimate meditation on ancient Greek playwright Euripides’ Hippolytus
column5: while her dreamily crystalline follow-up Ekstasis (also a nod to ancient Greece) sounded like bedroom pop made by somebody with pin-ups of Heidegger and Virginia Woolf (and also maybe Laurie Anderson) papering the walls. Holter’s music is learned (she studied musical composition at CalArts) and proudly erudite
column6: and yet not in a way that feels like it’s talking down to the listener. Still
column7: she’s never made a record quite as inviting as Loud City Song-- her first album for Domino and the one most likely to turn skeptics to believers. From the panoramic ballroom swoon of “Maxim’s I” to the twinkling
column8: kinetic chatter of its sequel
column9: there’s an energy coursing through Loud City Song that makes it feel-- more than anything she’d done so far-- breezy
column10: contemporarily resonant
column11: and at all times flutteringly alive.

column1: Loud City Song is the first album that Holter recorded outside of her bedroom
column2: and-- like a 19th century French literary heroine seeking the therapeutic air of a seaside vacation-- the change in scenery seems to have loosened her up a bit. If Ekstasis had the serene intimacy of home recordings made with the apartment curtains drawn
column3: Loud City Song finds her flinging open the drapes and taking rhythmic cues from the bustle of people below. Much of this newfound dynamism comes from adding new collaborators (and returning to trusted old ones: like Ekstasis
column4: the record was mixed and co-produced by Ariel Pink collaborator Cole Mardsen Greif-Neill) and embracing a more jazz-oriented instrumentation-- trombones
column5: strings
column6: and a double bass all add a little drama
column7: agility
column8: and even playfulness to her sound.

column1: Holter name-checks old Parisian landmarks like Maxim’s and says she was also inspired by the disconnectedness and buzzing anonymity of her hometown (""In L.A.
column2: it's like everyone's invisible. That's why I like it here.""). But what gives these songs an emotional resonance beyond the confines of her own imagination is the way they capture something universal about the joys and anxieties of living in any modern city. As Holter's nimble voice skips between her siren-song falsetto and a more percussive delivery closer to spoken word
column3: the mood of the album is in constant flux: in the menacing “Horns Surrounding Me” the brisk footfall of her fellow passersby evokes claustrophobia
column4: danger and paranoia (is she being chased? Or is it all in her head?)
column5: but by the next song
column6: the playful pop-cabaret “In the Green Wild”
column7: she’s looking at her fellow pavement-pounders with a sense of bemused wonder.

column1: Still
column2: it’s the album’s centerpiece
column3: a hypnotizing six-and-a-half minute rendition of Barbara Lewis' “Hello Stranger”
column4: that might just be the most uncomplicatedly gorgeous thing Holter’s ever done. It’s risky to tackle a tune that’s been covered enough times to make it feel like a modern-day standard
column5: but Holter’s atmospheric take finds a particular strain of longing and serenity in the song. It's a heart-stopper. Amidst the rest of Loud City Song’s chatty
column6: high-concept vitality
column7: “Hello Stranger” is a moment of comfort and instant connection
column8: like suddenly spotting a familiar face on a busy street.

column1: Though there’s definitely a narrative arc to the record
column2: it doesn’t stick so close to the Gigi script to become tedious; Loud City Song moves with an internal logic that’s more impressionistic than literal. Some of its pieces do stand sturdily on their own
column3: but taken in one sitting the album unfurls like one long
column4: thoughtfully arranged composition-- lyrics and images recur
column5: and characters gradually evolve. The narrator at the center (Gigi? Holter? Some kind of poetic hybrid of the two?) begins as a detached
column6: observant outsider-- just another anonymous face gazing curiously at the city below from the perch of her fifth-floor walk-up (""I don't how why I wear a hat so much
column7: Holter sings beneath the sparse groan of a cello on the opening song
column8: ""World""
column9: ""The city can't see my eyes under the brim."") But by the end-- the second-to-last track
column10: “This Is a True Heart” prances like a lazy-Sunday carousel ride-- she sounds not only more vulnerable but lighter
column11: too. In a way
column12: the arc of Loud City Song mirrors Holter’s artistic evolution: Ekstasis found kindred spirits in statues and goddesses (“I can see you but my eyes are not allowed to cry
column13: ” she repeated on “Goddess Eyes II”
column14: cloaked in a vocoder)
column15: but the psychologically complex narrator at the heart of Loud City Song moves like flesh and blood.

column1: “There’s a flavor to the sound of walking no one ever noticed before
column2: Holter chants in a rapt whisper throughout ""In the Green Wild"". It's a telling line: Loud City Song is one of those records so full of un-jaded wonder and attuned to the secret music of ordinary things that the world looks a little bit different while it's playing. I don't think I fully appreciated it until I listened to the whole thing while looking out a second-story window onto a crowded street during rush hour
column3: watching an endless procession of people with eyes hidden to the city under the brims of hats (or
column4: to update Holter's image
column5: staring down at their iPhones). To the tune of ""World""
column6: I started wondering who they all were
column7: where they were rushing
column8: and what they were thinking. Though it draws upon the distant past
column9: Julia Holter's made a timeless people-watching soundtrack: an acutely felt ode to the mysteries of a million passersby
column10:
all the stars of their own silent musicals.

"|18378.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18378-julia-holter-loud-city-song/|8.6|Lindsay Zoladz

column1: 0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/19520/homepage_large.4b0dd6c3.jpg|Flourish//Perish|29315.0|Braids|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Full Time Hobby'
column2: 'Flemish Eye'
column3:
'Arbutus']|2013-08-16 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:54:14.612125|"

Musical restraint is often confused with abstinence-- the idea is that artists are constantly warring with a natural compulsion towards adding that extra vocal overdub or drum solo or two-minute coda and should be rewarded for “winning.” Montreal's Braids made restraint feel a lot less theoretical on their 2011 debut Native Speaker and the results were often fascinating. The songs averaged about seven minutes and made no secret about the influence of Animal Collective at their most hormonally charged. But they weren’t defined by indulgence so much as a Hulk-like instability. ""Lammicken"" had a single
column4: telling lyric-- ""I can't stop it."" When Raphaelle Standell-Preston’s soft-spoken surrealism exploded into carnal caterwauling and the band’s intricate interplay gave way to washes of free-form noise
column5: you sensed that Braids had to work their asses off just to keep themselves in check
column6: and were doing it for our good and theirs as well. Braids appear to have their impulses under control two years later
column7: and if Native Speaker drew its power from being the proverbial tip of the iceberg
column8: Flourish // Perish is the iceberg itself
column9: impressive and monolithic
column10: cold and impenetrable.

column1: Perhaps it’s not all that surprising
column2: as Montreal has seen a chill come over it since entering 2013 as indie's hottest city-- Majical Cloudz’s Impersonator achieved a glacial
column3: barren beauty
column4: something like sunlight on the Antarctic
column5: while Doldrums disappeared into his laptop with static-laden
column6: cracked pop. Grimes did somewhat likewise
column7: retreating from music and relating her experiences with incisive and invective Tumblr posts. Then there’s Preston
column8: the first in the scene to receive widespread attention; the humid romance of 2010’s Blooming Summer was a distant memory for her side project Blue Hawaii
column9: as Untogether was filled with disaffected
column10: click-and-whir electro laments that could be taken as a commentary on an artistic community that’s grown apart from each other.

column1: On first exposure
column2: it can feel like Flourish // Perish is an extension of Untogether rather than a complement. Pared down to a trio after losing founding member Kate Lee
column3: Braids all but ditched their guitars and got deep into programming and sequencers. As such
column4: Feels has been exchanged for mind music-- the mechanistic Flourish is heavy on turn of the century Warp (Aphex Twin
column5: Squarepusher) and Warp-influenced crossover acts
column6: i.e.
column7: Björk ca. Vespertine and Radiohead. Hermetic and kinetic
column8: the band’s production bears the mark of “intelligent dance music”
column9: not because it’s smarter than other electronic forms (as if that could be quantified) but due to its mirroring of cerebral function. The songs here are built from short
column10: synaptic and repetitive firing
column11: tiny loops
column12: short glitches
column13: silvery hooks that corkscrew into your memory.

column1: It’s an interesting and daring turn for Braids
column2: retaining the complicated
column3: prog-like arrangements of their past while working within the textures of IDM and minimal techno. The spaciousness and clarity of Flourish does make it an easy record to return to; while challenging
column4: it’s not a difficult listen. This is crucial
column5: as the underlying rhythm beds rarely give Braids much melodic structure and put the focus on Preston’s lyrics
column6: which are simultaneously more poetic and yet less evocative than her past work.

column1: On Native Speaker
column2: Preston functioned like an anthropologist in the wild
column3: experiencing the strange rhythms and rituals of those around her
column4: journaling the frightening results without judgment. There’s a scientific method to <i>Flourish
column5: where she’s inquisitive
column6: probing and more concerned with challenging her own findings within clinical surroundings.  Examples of self-examination and self-recrimination abound on Flourish-- Preston’s ego is a bed too comfortable to leave
column7: her head a lake in which to drown. Yet
column8: she maintains critical distance and for that reason
column9: Braids are a lot tougher to read here. On the whispery morning-after ballad “Girl”
column10: a lover serves as a mirror for the narrator’s inadequacies rather than comfort: “Every day I wake/ To sunlight on his face/ He is so care free/ Why can I not be.”  On “Hossak”
column11: Preston acknowledges “a boy knocking outside my window with a slice of pizza” with the eerie absenteeism of someone describing a UFO sighting.

column1: The extraterrestrial quality cuts both ways. Flourish is a purposefully alien and repetitive album
column2: and at the outset
column3: it works-- the fractious
column4: percussive rhythms of ""Victoria"" and ""December'' are hypnotic
column5: as is the overlay of high
column6: diaphonous cooing atop Preston's spoken word during ""Freund"". But in the second half
column7: the iterance becomes tedious; footholds are few amidst the long stretches of vast electronic tundra and the Perish side B can feel like a sheer drop towards revelatory closer “In Kind"".

column1: In a way
column2: it makes you want to try and listen to Flourish // Perish in reverse-- “In Kind” feels like a continuation of Native Speaker
column3: with the same kind of cresting dynamics and the one time where Preston lets off a scream
column4: a satisfying
column5: feral shriek that almost compensates for its lack thereof prior. And there’s also its introductory lyric
column6: “I must have saw a girl/ Who looked a lot like myself ... knowing all the answers/ And it is a problem.” And if that’s the problem of this intriguing but insular album
column7: the solution is found on “Victoria”-- “My father always said/ To get out of my head/ Maybe he meant to see what's next to me.” That’s the first line on <i>Flourish // Perish
column8:
and the one that Braids could be wise to heed going forward.

0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/19620/homepage_large.79c37349.jpg|Bitchitronics|31611.0|Bitchin Bajas|['Experimental']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Drag City']|2013-08-16 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:54:15.238068|"

You might not think a group called Bitchin Bajas would be making beatific drone music; the name suggests a drug-rug-wearing
column2: Tuesdays-only Tex-Mex bar band. But Bitchin Bajas
column3: which began as the project of Chicago's Cooper Crain
column4: has grown into a trio that specializes in the kind of calmly interstellar music that feels unconnected to time
column5: space
column6: or trends. Bitchitronics
column7: their fourth proper album
column8: is a serene cloud of hovering tones and near-zero motion
column9: an album of sounds that feel so good that they feel like events in themselves.  The title sure sounds like a sly nod to Robert Fripp's Frippertronics
column10: and the dazed spirit of Brian Eno and Fripp hovers like a mild uncle
column11: but Bitchitronics doesn't feel overly concerned with any other music. It doesn't seem overly concerned at all. If you have absolutely nowhere to go in the near future
column12: Bitchitronics will make an excellent travel companion.

column1: Bitchitronics is made of three tape machines talking to each other: Two machines generate loops
column2: the third records them. The loops start out as musical information
column3: but quickly melt into shapes
column4: and the Bajas surround those shapes with other
column5: live instruments-- fluttering jazz flute
column6: noodly guitar soloing. Sometimes the loop sputters quietly
column7: like someone clearing their throat in church. Heavily reverbed guitars leave little condensed little raindrops of notes on their surfaces. A little bass enters; the bass recedes. At one point
column8: an electric guitar arcs beautifully upward
column9: but it's gone and forgotten shortly after it appears.

column1: This doesn't sound like everyone's idea of a good time. I can sympathize; structure-free music meant to soothe usually leaves my nerve-endings seething
column2: grasping for stimulus like the tubers shooting out of a dying potato. But the four pieces on Bitchitronics are so beautiful that their patient steadiness doesn't bore or irritate me. Making an album that makes doing this little sound so charming and inviting is no minor accomplishment. I can spend time with Bitchitronics' four pieces
column3: let them decide how they're going to arrange themselves this time through. Each time
column4: they settle a little bit differently.

column1: ""Reviewing"" Bitchitronics is difficult
column2: because isolating moments in an album like this feels like pointing out a particular section of a cloud. All four pieces seep slowly into view the same way-- a slow corona in a major key
column3: one warm chord steadily accreting in size. The pieces swell into view
column4: but once they're present
column5: they don't build much further upon themselves; drone music often pairs nicely with grandeur
column6: but the tones on Bitchitronics are often quavery and weak-sounding. This isn't visceral
column7: or elemental music-- unlike
column8: say
column9: Oneida
column10: Boredoms
column11: Grails
column12: Swans
column13: Om
column14: you can't imagine taking Bitchin Bajas to the desert. If you're going to use it to meditate
column15: meditate indoors
column16: preferably in a room with old carpeting and low shutters; if you take it outside
column17: it might sound pale and timid. There are no revelations
column18:
no crashing waves. Their ""om"" is the 2 a.m. hum of a refrigerator.

0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/19586/homepage_large.9523a72c.jpg|Slow Walkers|30034.0|Slow Walkers|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Peak Oil']|2013-08-16 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:54:15.758424|"

Liz Harris' music as Grouper is often intensely private
column2: a feeling she's amplified tenfold on this debut collaboration with Australian musician (and Room40 label head) Lawrence English. Released on the Peak Oil label
column3: the package includes only a handful of track titles and a note hinting it was recorded between 2010-12. Those titles are ultimately meaningless; Slow Walkers' music runs together with barely any separation
column4: feeling more like a continuous journey than a series of separate narratives. It's instrumental
column5: drone-based work
column6: leaning heavily on repetition and the kind of eerie ambience for which Harris is known. Had this record been released earlier in her career then questions may have been raised about how she and English could reach such a troubled
column7: lonely
column8: barren place. But by now it's clear that this is the spot where Harris operates most effectively.

column1: Part of Grouper's power is in the way the music feels like it's made in a vacuum
column2: shorn of contemporary reference points or settings. Slow Walkers aren't exactly out there tweeting up a storm
column3: but this record has been alluded to as ""meditations for the zombie as cultural phenomena"" in the description below a video for the track ""Wake"". What that means or how it applies here is suitably foggy
column4: and the fact that the clip was uploaded to the Room40 Vimeo account over a year ago suggests it may no longer be appropriate. If Slow Walkers are thinking about death as a process
column5: then they're imagining it as a long
column6: drawn out
column7: painful undertaking. There's a strong sense of journey here
column8: similar to the depth felt in the Haxan Cloak's excellent afterlife meditation
column9: Excavation. Except with Slow Walkers everything is much less chiseled
column10: with Harris and English foregoing definition for suggestion
column11: choosing to imagine feelings instead of laying out a tangible roadmap.

column1: At times this feels of a piece with the rolling tundras of Harris' Violet Replacement work
column2: which similarly juxtaposed anxiety with something far more relaxing. What Slow Walkers do is similar
column3: setting up an unsettling atmosphere and then letting beautiful drones arc and dissolve across its gloomy surface. This project has been talked up as a multi-media undertaking
column4: with video installations and audio-visual concert performances
column5: but it's hard to picture how that would work when the music itself is so visually suggestive. The second side opens with a positively holy feel
column6: its wispy ambience bringing to mind an abandoned
column7: wind-whipped cathedral. It's impressive how Harris and English can work in tandem to build tension and then just let it float away
column8: turning trepidation into bliss. By the close of the second side
column9: deep into ""Wake""
column10: there's a lightness present
column11: a sense of calm settling in
column12: a feeling that this isn't such a bad place to be after all.

column1: Slow Walkers may be hiding from the world to a certain extent-- the nature of this album helps frame it as a tentative step instead of a full-blown leap. It's not clear if that will develop further
column2: although there's enough here to suggest potential not yet fully realized. This isn't on a par with Grouper's The Man Who Died In His Boat from earlier this year
column3: but Slow Walkers is definitely a secret that's a little too good to be kept in the province of a select band of Harris devotees. Appropriately
column4: it begins with a crackle of radio static
column5: lending it a lost-transmission feel that only a few people are privy to hearing
column6: either alive or
column7: perhaps
column8: undead. If this is a record about death
column9: then it's primarily about the process of letting go
column10: of watching someone transform from present to past tense
column11:
fading from the physical world to become a bundle of memories for people to carry around.

0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/19601/homepage_large.06baf3c9.jpg|Better Unsung|28563.0|The Delta Mirror|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Lightwave']|2013-08-16 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:54:16.396044|"

There's little doubt that Delta Mirror frontman Chris Acosta believes in reincarnation. The last time we heard from his band was in 2010 with the release of their debut Machines That Listen
column2: a downcast
column3: glitchy ghost-pop exercise that imagined each of the album's 13 tracks as separate rooms in a hospital. Back then he went by Craig Gordon (an inside joke amongst friends)
column4: an ex-hip-hop wannabe who decided to explore more mysterious atmospheres with bandmates David Bolt and Karrie K. Now Acosta's back
column5: using his own name to record what he considers a more personal album with Better Unsung
column6: a lengthy
column7: overly-ambitious piece of work that finds him in the role of a solo artist
column8: despite enlisting the help of the Machines-era players
column9: as well as Seattle production team Blue Sky Black Death and Anticon co-founder Alias
column10: who also co-produced the record. Clocking in at almost an hour
column11: Better Unsung is divided by four suites entitled ""Probability and Outcome""
column12: which take their name from dialogue featured in the 1978 Warren Beatty vehicle Heaven Can Wait. The film follows a football star who is taken from earth prematurely by his guardian angel following a car accident
column13: only to be returned in the body of a recently murdered millionaire. Better Unsung is most certainly Acosta's new millionaire disguise
column14: pushing the ideas found on the understated Machines to convoluted
column15: beat-oriented
column16: maxims.

column1: It's not such a bad idea
column2: after all. Machines did harness something promising in the ""electro shoe-goth"" realm (genre description courtesy of Acosta's Twitter account)
column3: and blowing that up to the festival-ready size of an M83
column4: Nine Inch Nails
column5: or even a School of Seven Bells could prove pretty satisfying. But Better Unsung misses the opportunity at almost every turn
column6: packing disorienting production
column7: clunky lyrics
column8: and undercooked hooks into interminably long
column9: aimless songs that mean to either invoke chills or stimulate some kind of freeing catharsis
column10: but instead end up bludgeoning you into an uncomfortable submission. There's no denying that Acosta has ambition
column11: talent and-- thanks to hints of trip-hop
column12: arena-made alt-rock
column13: and starry-eyed shoegaze pop-- pretty good taste
column14: but it's in the execution where he falls short. In making the leap from a somewhat insular musician to one now begging for space on a larger stage
column15: his knack for detail and follow-through feels lost
column16: resulting in an album too bloated to ever get its feet off the ground.

column1: It's unlikely Acosta set out for self-sabotage
column2: but at times it's hard to come up with an alternate excuse in the case of some of these songs. ""Undeveloped Unreturned"" is a nice change of pace from the preceding ""Goldfish""
column3: which relies heavily on a set of played-out tropes (backwards vocals
column4: fuzz-fucked drums). Despite its problematically schmaltzy chorus (""I’m the photo that you throw away/ I’m the phone call that you don’t take"")
column5: there's a noticeable melody that helps carry the song. But it's Acosta's nagging need to kick things into overdrive in order approximate some sort of big
column6: effusive high that often sinks these songs. With its blown-out climax
column7: ""Undeveloped Unreturned"" is sapped of its potential transportive qualities. Sadly
column8: this is a recurring theme. ""Lead Me In""'s plaintive
column9: glassy guitars give way to a cinderblock-smashing mechanized beat drop
column10: in which the song again aims to become some kind of celestial
column11: lighter-waving sing-along that
column12: instead of inspiring
column13: feels like anesthetized. The thing is
column14: he can get away with this kind of thing occasionally. ""Goodbye Horses"" is easily the best cut on the album
column15: and despite coming off as more than a little silly
column16: actually soars. But it's a fleeting example of Better Unsung getting things right
column17: and suggests that on this level
column18: Acosta just doesn't have the stuff to make this kind of thing gel in a coherent
column19:
exciting way.

In the end
column20: Better Unsung feels kind of hollow in the face of its too-muchness. It begins to appear compulsive at times with Acosta throwing so many different things at the wall at once
column21: ultimately sacrificing any sort of clarity of vision thanks to too many ideas and too many collaborators. It's unlikely that you wanted an industrial remix of ""Goldfish""
column22: but there it is
column23: tacked on as a hidden track at the end of an already exhaustively long record. It might be easy to suggest a little restraint is necessary here
column24: but ballads like the yelp-y ""The Bear"" or the folk-like ""The Happiest Endings Are the Ones That Never Come"" (not true) reveal that misguided bombast is sometimes better than just plain old boring. You can't fault Acosta for pushing himself as an artist
column25:
but Better Unsung proves that this reinvention is merely just a disguise if the songs aren't there.

Queens
column2: New York
column3: 2009: in a dark kitchen-cum-venue muraled with grimy rainbows
column4: a young woman sat curled on the floor belting out her operatic soul to the ring of a small keyboard. In what seems today like a past life
column5: this was Nika Roza Danilova
column6: the now 24-year-old Wisconsin-bred singer-songwriter who makes music as Zola Jesus-- a vision planted with the noise-flecked seeds of Throbbing Gristle and gloomy Diamanda Galás that has since bloomed into widescreen industrial art-pop. This D.I.Y. show four years ago epitomized the fly-by-night Brooklyn indie scene at the height of late-aughts blog-rock. In the spring of 2012
column7: Danilova was in the same city but a different world. On the Upper East Side
column8: donning an angelic high-fashion contraption that featured the likeness of wings
column9: she performed within the cylindrical ramps of the revered Guggenheim Museum. A conductor was present.

column1: From this moment comes Versions
column2: a new collection from Danilova's collaboration with a string quartet led by J.G. Thirlwell
column3: a vet of experimental industrial music since the 1980s who is also known as Foetus. (His collaborations range from transgressive electronic like Nurse With Wound and Coil to provocateur rock legends Nick Cave and Lydia Lunch.) The orchestral realm is new for Danilova
column4: but not unexpected; from the start
column5: Zola Jesus has exhibited a devoted narrative of change. Songs like Versions' ""Night"" and ""Sea Talk"" were once ensconced in surreal
column6: grating reverb-- see New Amsterdam's ""Lady Maslenitsa"" for how far the lo-fi abrasion went-- and later turned into thundering ballads
column7: while she evolved further on 2011's Conatus LP
column8: embracing metallic percussion and the skittering beats of 1990s Intelligent Dance Music. ""There's a sense of anarchy to it
column9: she’s said of IDM. Making industrial sounds with avant-garde influence but foremost pop sense
column10: she could also find a kindred spirit in
column11: say
column12: Trent Reznor
column13: and they've shared many collaborators
column14: of them iconic film director David Lynch
column15: the producer Flood
column16: and Thirlwell.

column1: Despite the shifts
column2: there are essential qualities that bind the Zola Jesus songbook. The enormity of her morose voice is a constant
column3: as are ominous themes
column4: from ""Six Feet (From My Baby)"" (a song about her own burial) to titles such as ""Lick the Palm of the Burning Handshake"". Her songs remain elegant and brutal with a life-or-death seriousness
column5: exorcising loneliness with tension you could pop with a pin. The best of Danilova's songwriting
column6: most of which is collected here
column7: has grown anthemic
column8: as she gestures towards grander reaches of ambition-- ""Ever since I wrote my first song I wanted to be playing Madison Square Garden
column9: she's said. She has collaborated with the rapper El-P
column10: covered Rihanna's ""Diamonds""
column11: and in 2011 sang on M83's commercial breakthrough Hurry Up
column12: We're Dreaming.

column1: There's something curious about Versions
column2: though. Many of the qualities that strings typically cast upon an artist's work-- austerity
column3: grace
column4: a cinematic sweep-- already exist in the original takes of her songs. (The songs here have all been released before
column5: some twice
column6: save for the exceedingly romantic new track ""Fall Back"".) Conatus itself used acoustic strings
column7: but what gives its orchestral versions value is a brighter take on her expressive singing. Danilova has described her creative process as self-critical and emotionally draining; ""Why does it always have to be war for me?"" she's asked. Here
column8: her voice is less menacingly deep and air-tight; it sounds open
column9: sweet
column10: and full of light. Often
column11: it is conventionally beautiful
column12: like she's freed herself. ""Avalanche (Slow)""
column13: for instance
column14: is a sublime deconstruction where Danilova's words blissfully crawl
column15: hitting notes sharply with stronger vibrato. As the piercing high strings weep
column16: she sounds fixed in a dream of total control
column17: slowing her pace as a chaotic world buzzes about.

column1: The older songs
column2: off Stridulum and Valusia
column3: are the best of her catalog. It's hard to imagine any take of the epic ballads ""Sea Talk"" or ""Night"" losing value; fans of previous versions
column4: which had programmed strings
column5: will want to hear them with real ones. But relative to the originals
column6: the orchestral versions have a distancing effect
column7: as if listening in on something once removed. Their emotional core is dramatic as ever
column8: but some details
column9: washed out here
column10: are missed
column11: like the ghostly buzzing that prefaces ""Night"" or the louder beats that crash ""Sea Talk"" open. Versions offers welcomed arrangements
column12: but in both cases they are trumped by the visceral power of those songs' heavier incarnations.

column1: Versions benefits from the inclusion of ""Fall Back""
column2: the new song
column3: which seems composed with the grandiose potential of an orchestra in mind-- the pizzicato parts are celebratory
column4: and a colossal violin crescendo adds sweeping dimension
column5: building to an overwhelming cloud of sound that conjures the feel of a gleaming
column6: open sky. ""This is my home/ You are my only one
column7: Danilova sings in booming
column8: crystalline lines
column9: holding back nothing of a rapturous heart. ""I would do anything to be with you forever."" As heard here
column10: it’s not hard to imagine these passionate admissions mixing with the sounds of clinking champagne glasses at a wedding.

column1: The most compelling thing about Versions has more to do with Danilova herself than Thirlwell or the Mivos Quartet. Zola Jesus is rarely discussed in a capital-p Pop context
column2: as if having left noise behind her work could be more truly populist. Stripped of most electronics
column3: though
column4: these massive hooks and their collective human core are put under a microscope
column5: and it's impressive to see the songs carry themselves without all the dark
column6: propulsive production. Danilova has taken these compositions about as far as they can go
column7: and still there remains something intriguing about Zola Jesus
column8:
not just for her ghostly enigma or art world appeal but now for what really comes next.

Robbie Basho died in a California hospital room more than 27 years ago. His vertebral artery ruptured during a visit to a chiropractor’s office. He had a stroke
column2: slipped into a coma and
column3: at the age of 45
column4: passed away. In the decades that have followed
column5: his already-wavering reputation as a pioneer of finger-picked acoustic guitar experimentation has passed largely like a shadow behind the music and myth of John Fahey
column6: Basho’s old pal who released several of his earliest albums.

column1: It should be remembered that Fahey experienced a renaissance in the 90s. The music press famously championed his early work and helped goad him from semi-retirement. He followed the laurels both with a string of strange
column2: daring records and a brilliant new record label
column3: Revenant
column4: which advocated alternate strains of the avant-garde and the hillbilly music that had helped inspire his own. Basho
column5: being dead
column6: enjoyed no such revival. In fact
column7: a large chunk of his catalogue now languishes out of print
column8: serving as grails for collectors rather than essential bits in a narrative much broader than Blind Joe Death. And that’s a shame: Nearly 30 years after his death
column9: and after multiple waves of guitarists have risen to revive the mantle Fahey and Basho both helped shape
column10: Basho’s manic
column11: hyperkinetic approach to playing
column12: singing
column13: songwriting and living in general have very few peers. Basho’s tenth album
column14: 1978’s Visions of the Country
column15: was the fifth album Windham Hill Records ever released. After more than three decades out of print
column16: it is finally back in circulation; on its 35th anniversary
column17: it serves as an ecstatic testimonial for a guitarist in need of a popular resurrection.

column1: Basho’s relative anonymity isn’t only a byproduct of his untimely death
column2: of course: Even when he was alive
column3: his allegedly inscrutable personality and debated quirks kept him a bit at arms length. Those same strange traits are part and parcel to his music. He did not aim for Fahey’s steady
column4: solemn gaze or Leo Kottke’s eccentric approachability. Rather
column5: Basho’s music was a blunderbuss of feeling
column6: tied to unstoppable technique. He whistles loudly over the Keith Jarrett-sized piano clouds of “Leaf in the Wind”
column7: as though it were his aim to spoil the song’s billowing beauty. And he ends Visions of the Country by urging listeners to “follow the Milky Way-- home!” in a voice that suggests Mr. Rogers.

column1: Indeed
column2: Basho’s singing generally wasn’t what you’d call pretty or subtle. During “Night Way”
column3: from the second side of Visions of the Country
column4: he obscures the wonderful ribbons of his six-string guitar with singing generously described as zealous. He wails a ceremonial Navajo chant
column5: his voice locking into and falling from falsetto
column6: its vibrato smearing the track with warble. For the listener
column7: the guitar is the star here
column8: but you have to peer past the bleat to find it. During “Orphan’s Lament”
column9: he slurs and nearly screams his tribute to the poor and peripatetic above sheets of stacked piano notes
column10: delivering empathy like a bar-side Irisman. These aren’t songs you’d really put on during a party or in a mix for a love interest. Basho’s sound is dramatic and yearning and very personal
column11: altogether unapologetic for the way he saw the world.

column1: What’s most remarkable about Basho is how busy and emphatic but absolutely effortless his songs could feel
column2: especially when he touches the guitar. At once
column3: Basho could appear to be laying it all on the line and simply breezing through the notes. During “Rocky Mountain Raga”
column4: he practically howls as he sings “Oh
column5: you grand Rockies
column6: ” pretending that he’s an opera star. But even so
column7: his fingers are frantic and unfailing
column8: delivering a perfect and convoluted stream of notes that never loses momentum just because he’s now got something to say. Early in his career
column9: Basho was a rather plainspoken folk musician. A natural roamer
column10: though
column11: he developed an enthusiastic embrace of world religion and music-- from India to Ireland
column12: from Native American lore to Sufi teachings. On Visions of the Country
column13: those polyglot tendencies allow him to slip Middle Eastern accents and chamber ensemble flair into “Variations on Easter”
column14: a four-minute fantasy that’s as close to a “simple” acoustic instrumental theme as he ever really got. Conversely
column15: he’s comfortable singing a pretty song over somewhat plain chords
column16: too. On “Blue Crystal Fire”
column17: he sustains that falsetto
column18: his voice curling like that of Antony Hegarty in a song that’s coincidentally about natural wonder-- “Smooth singing sunshine/ wrap your blanket around me.” Basho constructed his ecumenical complications above solid foundations. Visions of the Country uniquely shows every layer.

column1: Gnome Life’s reissue of Visions of the Country won’t be enough to resuscitate Basho’s reputation
column2: to turn him
column3: like Fahey
column4: into shorthand for adventurous acoustic guitar. But that’s OK. Basho will never have the same broad appeal or the same cyclic story as Fahey. His music is
column5: at first
column6: rather off-putting
column7: but ultimately
column8: he imagined modes for the guitar and composition that we’re still reconciling. Marnie Stern sometimes maneuvers against her instrument in the same way
column9: and James Blackshaw explores the same nebulous majesty. But Robbie Basho’s music mostly remains a pan-everything oddball
column10: and Visions of the Country is
column11: at last
column12:
once again living proof.

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/19493/homepage_large.88c816e8.jpg|Pura Vida Conspiracy|1744.0|Gogol Bordello|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['ATO']|2013-08-15 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:54:17.839705|"

Punk's always been something of an us vs. them proposition: you're either the one getting sneered at
column2: or the one doing the sneering. Even when their music's faltered
column3: self-styled gypsy punks Gogol Bordello have always found a way to make punk's tricky division problems work in their favor: when it's borders-- and the people who keep them in place-- that separate us
column4: that ""us"" gets to be quite a crew. While the pointedness of Eugene Hütz and company's all-inclusive message has dwindled some on recent records
column5: the overarching lesson holds: wherever you are
column6: stand with us
column7: the rabblerouser-slash-raconteur always seems to be saying
column8: and eventually we'll figure it out. Hütz is
column9: as ever
column10: a vat of charisma
column11: enthusiastic to a fault. At every turn on Pura Vida Conspiracy
column12: Gogol Bordello's first LP in three years
column13: sometime-thespian Hütz doesn't just deliver his lines
column14: he devours them
column15: like an actor chewing on the scenery. Whether he's trotting out his tried-and-true borders-as-scars metaphors--  long a popular topic for ex-refugee Hütz and the genre-meshing band he leads-- or spinning a wild yarn about a couple chatty midwives
column16: he mugs and marionettes his way through Pura Vida Conspiracy like a man possessed. Hütz's vocal rigor is
column17: itself
column18: kind of an in-or-out proposition; you either find dude's world party cheerleader routine transfixing
column19: or you wish he'd take it down a couple notches.

column1: But if you don't mind Hutz in your ear for the better part of an hour
column2: Pura Vida Conspiracy is the sharpest Gogol Bordello record in some time. Opener ""We Rise Again"" immediately stakes out its territory
column3: as Hütz sings ""for the love of you
column4: for the love of me
column5: for the love of everyone who's yet to be free… we rise again!"" For every ""I"" or ""you"" on Pura Vida
column6: there's a lot more ""we
column7: and while Hütz
column8: as ever
column9: busies himself by drawing lines in the sand
column10: he's always sure to place both you and him on the same side. ""We who seek long enough
column11: dig deep enough
column12: find a diamond in the rough one day
column13: he belts throughout ""Dig Deep Enough""
column14: strongly suggesting that you and the Ukranian-born
column15: New York-transplanted
column16: Brazil-based Hütz are travelers on the same path to glory.

column1: And
column2: though Pura Vida's forged from the same roots as past Gogol Bordello records—Eastern European folk melodies
column3: politically savvy UK punk-- the music here feels less like a retread than a gathering of strengths. Where past Gogol Bordello records could steamroll right over you-- structure falling by the wayside as they'd rushing past verses to get to the breathless chorus-- even Pura Vida's more boisterous moments feel carefully mapped out. The basic building blocks of Gogol Bordello's sound-- traditional Eastern European folk melodies matched to the energy of politically savvy UK punk-- have never really changed. But by tamping down the tempos a hair and not letting the embellishments overpower the songs themselves
column4: Pura Vida feels like the fullest musical expression of Gogol's borderless sound since at least 2005's Steve Albini-recorded mission statement Gypsy Punks. Sweeping fiddles and smears of Romani brass add color instead of blotting out everything around them. Flecks of ska
column5: surf-rock
column6: dustbowl blues all sneak their way onto Pura Vida. But where past Gogol records seemed to throw everything at you in the hopes that something might catch your ear
column7: with Pura Vida
column8: Gogol hang back just as much as they let loose
column9: rolling into crescendos instead of barreling through them.

column1: Firebrand-from-birth Hütz opts for a fairly conversational tone throughout much of Pura Vida
column2: and this ""you and me both
column3: brother"" routine is a few shades more compelling than the throat-shoveling confrontation that marred lesser Gogol records. A couple sweet
column4: faintly supernatural love songs aside
column5: Hütz is still rallying around the same flags he's always hoisting
column6: upping individual freedoms while decrying institutional follies. But
column7: next to some of Gogol Bordello's earlier outbursts
column8: the message being conveyed here feels a bit less distinct
column9: largely because Hütz seems to be relying on the listener to have already picked up at least a little bit of what he's been laying down. We can celebrate our differences without using them as a wedge
column10: Hütz seems to be saying
column11: and the disenfranchised everywhere need to band together: good advice
column12: to be sure
column13: but not far from what the eternally on-message Hütz has been saying all along. Without using his own story as an allegory for the plight of others as he's done in the past
column14: every vague declaration here comes with an implicit ""you know what I'm saying"" attached
column15: which makes Pura Vida more galvanizing than genuinely illuminating.

column1: Between the spirited music and Hütz's delivery
column2: you're not likely to walk away from Pura Vida feeling uninspired. But if you want to really hear what Gogol Bordello is saying on Pura Vida
column3: a little history with the band is going to go a long way. Perhaps Hutz knows anybody picking up a Gogol Bordello LP in 2013 is part of the proverbial choir he's preaching to
column4:
and doesn't see the need to waste time with too much exposition. But the strongest Gogol Bordello record in a while would be all that much stronger if only Hutz could better elucidate to us just what's wrong with them.

column1: 0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/19500/homepage_large.4e9c15b0.jpg|We Knew It Was Not Going to Be Like This|27557.0|Surf City|['Rock'
column3: 000-plus miles away from Brian Wilson’s gold coast
column4: Auckland indie-rockers Surf City exuded enough beach-bound exuberance on their 2008 self-titled EP to justify their sand-swept moniker. But in the wake of 2010’s decidedly more plugged-in and spaced-out Kudos
column5: their name has taken on decidedly different connotations. With a growing affinity for discordant frequencies and motorik rhythms chasing that imperfect sound forever
column6: these guys make music for people whose idea of surfing involves a channel clicker; the only tans anyone’s getting here are from cathode rays. But
column7: damn
column8: is the sofa ever comfy
column9: and on Surf City’s second full-length
column10: this sort of spirited slothfulness codifies into a modernity-shunning mission statement.

column1: Surf City songs tend to be differentiated only by which strain of Velvet Underground-inspired rock they choose to mainline on any particular day
column2: be it the Krautrock pulse of Neu!
column3: the stoner drone of Spacemen 3
column4: or their formative
column5: flagrant Flying Nunnery. On We Knew It Was Not Going to Be Like This
column6: they tilt toward verbose Pavementian slop-pop
column7: though Davin Stoddard is much more pointed in his fight-this-generation polemics than Stephen Malkmus’ notoriously oblique observations-- we’re no less than 40 seconds into the album before Stoddard’s spitting
column8: “fuck the kids who don’t know what’s around.” It’s the first strike in Surf City’s war on totally wired
column9: fractured and distracted 21st-century living
column10: one that eventually sees Stoddard proudly proclaim
column11: “I don’t change!” But Surf City aren’t just going back to those gold sounds
column12: they’re updating them for their own ends. In his finest Thurstonian drawl
column13: Stoddard builds the chorus of “NYC” upon a line from Sonic Youth’s classic “Cotton Crown”-- “New York City is for every kitty”-- before adding this telling rejoinder: “But I don’t think I’m one of those kitties.”

column1: Ironically
column2: these statements of non-conformism are backed up by Surf City’s most streamlined batch of songs to date. On Kudos there was a real sense of the band taking their familiar influences and simultaneously distending and corroding them in search of a new noise. We Knew It Was rarely evinces the same boldness
column3: proffering instead a steady procession of jangle-fuzz jingles that yield moments of brain-massaging beauty (the gleaming outros of “Song From a Short-Lived TV Series” and “What Gets Me By”
column4: in particular) but little of Surf City’s more combustible qualities. And with the songs often adhering to simple A/B melodic patterns
column5: only a subtle lean on the distortion pedal provides any indication that they’re coming to the chorus now. The penultimate “Oceanic Graphs of the Wilderness”
column6: however
column7: presents exciting new possibilities for this band-- with its looped psych-soul groove
column8: brass accents
column9: and Ira Kaplan-esque guitar freakout
column10: the track serves as a portal to an alternative universe where Surf City have graduated from slackadasical slop-popsters to studio-tweaking sophisticates. Because even these dudes have come to the realization that
column11: as comfy as slumbering on the sofa can be
column12:
there’s always the nagging feeling that you could be doing something more productive.

column1: 0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/19602/homepage_large.c971ce74.jpg|Cassette 3: The Marion Morrison Mixtape|30131.0|Jonwayne|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Stones Throw']|2013-08-15 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:54:18.775848|"<div class=""contents dropcap"" data-reactid="".212g8m0r9c0.1.6:0.1.0.$18407/=1$18407.0.3.2.0.1.0.1""><blockquote class=""twitter-tweet"">
Damn. If people are actually caring about lyricism now I might have a fucking chance!
— Jonwayne (@jonwayne) <a href=""https://twitter.com/jonwayne/statuses/367334706167021569"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">August 13
column2: 2013

column1: <script charset=""utf-8"" src=""//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js"" type=""mce-mce-mce-mce-mce-mce-mce-mce-text/javascript""></script>
That’s rapper Jonwayne’s reaction to Kendrick Lamar’s verse on “Control (HOF)”
column2: a verse which temporarily made rap seem like the competitive lyrical landscape it once was. Wayne’s response is telling: he shares Kendrick’s small-c conservative tendencies and longs for those halcyon (if not mythical) days where a rapper’s facility with a mic alone could elevate him to stardom.

column1: His new mixtape The Marion Morrison Mixtape is the third of a series of cassettes the rapper's released with Stones Throw. Jonwayne is perfectly emblematic of the label's second generation of artists
column2: with an offbeat sensibility and allegiance to rap's former glory but Cassette 3 is set apart from its predecessors with a full flowering of Wayne's once nascent ambition.

column1: Wayne originally made waves as a producer
column2: and Marion Morrison is filled with a nice cohesion of recycled and original beats
column3: all of which evince a boom-bap classicism with a slight psychedelic edge. There are beats from DJ Premier
column4: J Dilla
column5: and Madlib
column6: and triangulating those three influences gives you a nice idea of where Jonwayne is coming from as a rapper and producer.

column1: It takes some time for the tape to ease into a groove rap-wise. Wayne has a deadpan delivery that occasionally belies the intensity of his subject matter
column2: and he has a penchant for slow-flow abstraction that can blunt the force of his rhymes. But by the time the DJ Premier produced-beat from Jeru Da Damaja’s “Black Cowboys”
column3: rolls around
column4: Wayne finds a nice balance and he doesn’t let up.

column1: Wayne’s rhymes are laced with absurd shit-talk (“Rappers are falling off like hip-hop is having chemotherapy”) and a kind of workman’s log of his daily grind. There’s a mix of contempt and amusement in his discussion of other rappers balanced by a love for what he does (“rap could never die
column2: that shit is a zombie.”) His ambition is palpable throughout-- the subject of many songs is simply that his skills merit attention-- but the constant demands for more are disguised by various lyrical devices which keep them from becoming tedious.

column1: Marrion Morrison is paced perfectly-- rappers often talk about the importance of track sequencing
column2: but it’s rare to find a project on which every song is a legitimate improvement on the last. The last three songs here
column3: “Dog iT” (which features Flying Lotus’ cloaked alter ego Captain Murphy)
column4: “Notes to Myself”
column5: and the album-ending title track solidify the tape as the best thing that Wayne has ever done.

column1: “Notes to Myself”
column2: in particular
column3: is a brilliant song
column4: a harsh indictment of the artist
column5: by the ghost of his better self that’s delivered in a sad
column6: sympathetic tone which makes it ever more poignant. It’s a pensive call to action over Donuts-era Dilla
column7: on which Wayne takes the energy that he’s concentrated externally throughout Marion Morrison and focuses on himself. The song manages to be extraordinarily personal and wholly universal at the same time
column8: the artist’s constant doubting distilled over wax.

column1: That softening of the mixtape’s message is essential to its success and “Notes to Myself” and the accompanying monologue
column2: which mythologizes the rapper’s namesake opens things up for “Marion Morrison”. Taking the beat from Madvillainy classic “Rhinestone Cowboy” is audacious
column3: but Wayne does it full justice
column4:
wrapping up the Cassettes series with a place-staking bid for some measure of the spotlight. It’s a powerful moment after the hesitance of the track before and an annunciation for a skilled musician just beginning to receive the attention he craves and deserves.

column1: 0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/19558/homepage_large.2b6ed36c.jpg|I Hate Music|3998.0|Superchunk|['Rock'
column3: people tend to discuss the way age has entered their work
column4: even if the topic doesn't quite fit. With Superchunk's 10th album
column5: I Hate Music
column6: a collection that focuses on the forward march of time and the pain that goes along with it
column7: this kind of commentary is unavoidable.

column1: The Chapel Hill quartet has been a reliable and surprisingly consistent force for almost 25 years. They formed in 1989
column2: a little bit before ""punk broke
column3: during a time when people with their eyes on the underground and ears on college radio thought of the band's North Carolina hometown as an indie-rock Seattle. They released their ninth album Majesty Shredding in 2010 after the almost 10-year hiatus following 2001's Here's to Shutting Up
column4: and nothing much had changed: Superchunk still delivered amped-up
column5: pogo-inspiring power pop. They've had a formula from the beginning
column6: but it's one that works.

column1: Their second post-hiatus record
column2: I Hate Music
column3: has a strong title that carries a deeper layer of meaning with it. They've released records upon records full of unbridled joy
column4: frontman Mac McCaughan also records solo material as Portastatic
column5: and he and bassist Laura Ballance are still going strong with their powerhouse indie label
column6: Merge. So
column7: no
column8: Superchunk don't hate music. The sentiment speaks to something you find happening when you edge closer to 40 and beyond: loved ones start dying
column9: and something that used to seem distant starts hitting close to home. As McCaughan sings on ""Me & You & Jackie Mittoo"": ""I hate music-- what is it worth?/ Can’t bring anyone back to this earth/ Or fill in the space between all of the notes/ But I got nothing else so I guess here we go…"" It's an ""I can't go on
column10: I will go on"" sort of thing
column11: and they create one hell of a ruckus in the process of moving on.

column1: Like post-SST and then present-day Dinosaur Jr.
column2: the pace is a little slower here
column3: some of the guitars quieter
column4: and the production shinier
column5: but the upward push of McCaughan's voice and that Superchunk momentum remains. (The acoustic and synth flourishes lend it a feeling similar to the early work of the more downcast
column6: stripped-back Portastatic.) It's more grounded and focused than Majesty
column7: and more thoughtfully reflective. Superchunk's best songs have always been the spastic ones
column8: but though this is their darkest album to date
column9: they don't fall into a midtempo torpor. McCaughan's nasal yowl can't help being anthemic
column10: whether he's calling a co-worker a slack motherfucker
column11: asking you to punch him harder
column12: or
column13: as in I Hate Music's excellent opener
column14: ""Overflows""
column15: singing lines like: ""Everything the dead don’t know/ Piles up like magazines and overflows/ And everything that you won’t see/ Just swirls around/ Comes down and buries me."" The subject matter here stings.

column1: I Hate Music doesn't treat loss as vague or theoretical. The album's dedicated to a close friend of McCaughan and the band
column2: the filmmaker and artist David Doernberg
column3: who died after a battle with cancer in March of 2012. As McCaughan wrote in a blog post around that time: ""I can't possibly enumerate the ways that Dave was intertwined into the fabric of our own family and lives. Likewise I have a feeling the hole that his passing leaves is larger than we even yet know."" Once you learn where the songs are coming from
column4: the sad lyrics are sadder
column5: the happy lyrics more wistful.

column1: Doernberg haunts the record beautifully. McCaughan sings in the final song
column2: ""What Can We Do"": ""Meet you on the corner every time it snows/ I’ve got wrinkles around my eyes/ I’ll say I love you
column3: I won’t say goodbye
column4: while the breezy ""Me & You & Jackie Mittoo"" references the Skatalites founder and the joy of hearing his music in a van with friends. On another standout
column5: ""Trees of Barcelona""
column6: McCaughan shares the wonderfully rendered memories of Portastatic playing Primavera Sound in 2007
column7: and the friends who ran through the city when that set was over. The quieter
column8: milder ""Your Theme"" asks for the impossible in simple terms: ""Oh what I’d do/ To waste an afternoon with you/ Eating obscure
column9: looking at girls
column10: shopping for jeans/ Learning how to be and not to seem/ Singing your theme.""

column1: Thoughtful
column2: quiet moments like that work but
column3: this being Superchunk
column4: the uptempo tracks still hit hardest. The fantastic ""FOH""
column5: for instance
column6: is cut from the same the cloth as Superchunk's raging best
column7: as McCaughan asks a series of questions with few answers: ""Did you lose something?/ Oh
column8: I lost something.../ Tell me
column9: are you coming around?/ When are you coming around?"" Mount Moriah's Heather McEntire lends distant backing vocals to ""Breaking Down""
column10: a jaunty song about fading memory. And things get especially amped on ""Staying Home""
column11: a one-minute punk song about staying home that feels like their ""Screaming at a Wall"".

column1: A song that combines both approaches is the the previously mentioned slow-builder
column2: ""What Can We Do"" with its ""I won't say goodbye."" It's an epic recounting
column3: and a fitting end to an album about listening to the music you loved with a friend and hating that music because it won't bring him back. But all the band can do is create more music anyway
column4: offering up songs that will inevitably soundtrack other lives and deaths
column5:
too.

0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/19614/homepage_large.b80561ae.jpg|Dual EP|31502.0|Sampha|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Young Turks']|2013-08-14 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:54:20.698113|"

Part of the charm of SBTRKT's 2011 self-titled debut was the presence of Sampha Sisay
column2: a now 24-year-old South Londoner who lent his voice to nearly every track on the album. There was never a doubt that
column3: based on raw talent alone
column4: Sampha was not only an artist to keep a close eye on (the same year found him collaborating with then-upstarts Jessie Ware and Lil Silva)
column5: but one with star potential. On the bracing ""Hold On""
column6: his vocals-- warm but damaged
column7: understated yet dynamic-- ache with loneliness
column8: whereas on more movement-minded concoctions like ""Sanctuary""
column9: it's transformed into a conduit for light-speed
column10: future-minded R&B. In other words
column11: Sampha's instrument is a dexterous one
column12: effortlessly commanding attention in whatever context it's placed. Now after spending the past few years as an integral part of SBTRKT's live show
column13: he's finally stepping out on his own with the deeply personal Dual EP.

column1: Last month
column2: Drake debuted his new single ""The Motion"" in anticipation of his forthcoming third record Nothing Was the Same
column3: with Sampha in tow on both vocal and production duties. Though Sampha's singing isn't featured prominently
column4: the melancholic tug of his presence is felt in nearly every corner of the track
column5: from the lighter-than-air atmospherics to his downcast
column6: honeyed croon. It signified what could be a more noticeable arrival for Sampha
column7: especially when coupled with the the release of Dual. But somewhat surprisingly
column8: it feels as if he's pushing against the idea of an elevated profile with the 17 minutes of music that make up his first solo venture. Instead of acting as a grand coronation
column9: Dual is a patient piece of work that finds Sampha in no rush to capitalize on a moment
column10: instead opting to showcase simple
column11: relatable musings on loss
column12: uncertainty
column13: and moving forward. At the same time
column14: Dual carries a strange urgency with it
column15: as if these songs had to come out of him now (despite their genesis going back years
column16: in certain cases). The result is unexpected
column17: but refreshing
column18: with Sampha comfortably inhabiting the role of an artist interested in staying true to himself.

column1: So it goes without saying that Dual isn't something you'll find yourself dancing much to (save maybe for the sultry ""Without""
column2: complete with plastic bucket street drumming and bleary synths). Instead
column3: these ruminative
column4: revealing songs paint a more intimate portrait of Sampha. There are ghosts hiding around almost every corner
column5: like on the lost lullaby ""Beneath the Tree""
column6: which finds him wishing a monster would ""take all its things and go."" Anchored by his delicate piano
column7: it's the first thing that truly springs to life on the EP (it follows opener ""Demons""
column8: one of two very short
column9: homemade sounding one-offs). Sampha's relationship with keys are important to Dual; almost everything here seems to orbit around his voice and piano. The radiant ""Indecision""
column10: with its gospel-like quality
column11: feels as if it would be just as effective unplugged. But to do away with all the wonderful details
column12: like those strange
column13: mechanized backing vocal snippets
column14: would be to ignore Sampha's deft ear for detail and his restrained but vibrant approach to mixing. These songs are nuanced and uncluttered. At the same time
column15: the humanizing imperfections are never lost. (It's no wonder Drakes has revered him as a producer as much as a singer.)

column1: Unfortunately
column2: this probably means that many won't pay as much attention to Sampha as a bonafide songwriter. And it's a shame
column3: because while a passing glance at these songs may not reveal many layers
column4: his use of repetition and unfussy language afford Dual some startling emotional relevance. Closer ""Can't Get Close"" is sung for his late father
column5: who Sampha lost at the age of nine and still regards as one of his most important musical influences. Tapping into something haunting and pure
column6: he sings over a mournful weave of pitched vocals
column7: lamenting
column8: ""I can't get close to you."" The desperation is something that will resonate with anyone familiar with the helplessness of loss. For someone so willing to lay himself this bare as a first impression is rare
column9: but in terms of the music found on Dual
column10:
nothing could be more natural. It's further proof that following the sound of your own voice is often more fruitful and rewarding than doing what everyone else expects of you.

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/19600/homepage_large.32ba9016.jpg|Dour Candy|31587.0|Billy Woods|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Backwoodz Studioz']|2013-08-14 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:54:21.363800|"

For somebody who recorded a grip of tracks in 2003 with Cannibal Ox's Vordul Mega on his debut album (Camouflage) and spent the ensuing 10 years writing and recording his ass off
column2: Billy Woods has spent a long time laboring under obscurity
column3: even by indie rap standards. It's really up to bad timing-- Woods came into his own at around the same time younger listeners weren't having any of this ""underground rap that's not for partying"" business. But Woods has stayed busy. He runs his own label
column4: puts out his own vision
column5: and maintains camaraderie and connections with all the dedication of a restless idea machine. His last album
column6: 2012's everyman-firebrand gem History Will Absolve Me
column7: gave him a renewed mission-driven identity after a few years sharing the spotlight in the group Super Chron Flight Brothers. But as someone who tends to keep his face deliberately obscured in his promotional photos
column8: Woods keeps tabs of what that identity looks like from the outside
column9: and does what he can to claim it and own it to the point where it stays legitimately whole.

column1: If History Will Absolve Me was a ""political"" record
column2: then Dour Candy is its reflection
column3: outlines of a day-to-day existence under all the toil and thought. Woods is a reference-heavy MC who tells stories from multiple angles and keep things evocatively multi-layered no matter how many asides and metaphors he tosses in. This is a record about doing shows
column4: getting wasted
column5: having sex
column6: watching over the city-- stuff that gets so much play in lyrics that it's good to have a reminder that these things aren't actually mundane. They uplift you or they wreck you
column7: sometimes one after the other
column8: occasionally simultaneously.

column1: And Woods has the words to back that up. When he's straightforward
column2: he's a powerful scene-setter: the outset of ""The Undercard""
column3: a narrative about the run-up to a live gig appearance
column4: is filled with you-are-there details. When he gets abstract or free-associative
column5: like he does with the hazy connections of ""Tinseltown"" or ""Manteca
column6: there are phrases that stand out-- ""Optimistic?/ Every morning between my first sip of coffee/ Last digit on my scratch off ticket""; ""Knot in my sock
column7: pot in the lungs
column8: black on the skin/ Cops on the block
column9: hands on their guns
column10: piss in the wind""-- and keep the listener oriented and looking for those same insights in the more tangled syntax. But he doesn't spend a lot of time stuffing in unnecessary words; he's deep
column11: but efficient.

column1: The record's biggest draw for those unfamiliar with Woods is the fact that Blockhead produces it in its entirety. Given his extensive history with intricate MCs that demand close
column2: repeated
column3: interpretation-searching listens -- particularly Aesop Rock (who turns up at his allusively weirdest here on ""Tumbleweed"") -- it's easy to see how a team-up like this could come to pass. And Blockhead's production is integral to upholding Dour Candy's ruminative momentum. Sometimes it's on multiple levels. It's no coincidence that Woods drops Clipse references on ""The Undercard"" over a grimier mutation of the sampled riff from Til the Casket Drops opener ""Freedom"". More often
column4: it's as simple enough as maintaining the sense of oddly melancholy cartoon futurism that comes with his best work-- slow-floating space graveyard drones on ""Gilgamesh""
column5: eye-darting prog synths and ghostly wails on ""Manteca""
column6: fourth-beer mariachi-soul horns weaving through ""One Thousand One Nights"". All in all
column7:
it completes a clearer picture of an artist who still hasn't let a lot of other people speak for him. 

"|18405.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18405-billy-woods-dour-candy/|7.8|Nate Patrin

column1: 0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/19574/homepage_large.45db43e7.jpg|Moon Tides|30663.0|Pure Bathing Culture|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Memphis Industries'
column2:
'Partisan']|2013-08-14 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:54:22.077088|"

Pure Bathing Culture is a band that's steeped in the past
column3: though the enduring effect of their debut Moon Tides is one of disorientation rather than nostalgia. Encounter any of its nine tracks
column4: and “what year is this?” is a question asked with genuine befuddlement
column5: not sarcasm. Their entire presentation-- the band name
column6: the album title
column7: the aquamarine cover
column8: Sarah Versprille and Daniel Hindman relocating from Brooklyn to Portland-- instantly recalls pure blogging culture
column9: something from the deadbeat summer of 2009. Then you take into account Versprille's dreamcatcher lyrics
column10: which namedrop pentacles and wizened wanderers and push the 60s Laurel Canyon pop they’ve explored as part of Vetiver into the cocaine 70s. But Moon Tides is also rife with 80s signifiers that range from Cocteau Twins to Benny Mardones. The fact that this all goes on at the same time rather than piece by piece ensures Moon Tides actually coheres
column11: but the underlying songs are so fetching and statuesque that you wonder why Pure Bathing Culture feels the need to play thrift store dress up.

column1: “Pendulum” makes it easier to take the necessary widescreen approach
column2: an instantly alluring song that gets very confusing under close examination. Its main progression is rigid and bold
column3: a descending three-chord riff you could seriously hear in a classic rock song if it wasn’t being played on pliable acoustic guitars that evoke the citric scent of a Mediterranean coast rather than funnel cake at the county fair. Versprille's lyrics somehow combine palatial Europe and cornpone Americana by getting deep into Ren Faire symbolism-- ""You're the cat's eye/ You're the pendulum/ When the orator says it's your time/ You're the one."" Those are the lines that her piercing vocals allow you to hear
column4: but by the time it gets to the chorus
column5: her words lapse into an amorphous
column6: swooning gesture while the whole thing gets liquefied by wet reverb. Richard Swift produces it to feel like a sudden
column7: sloppy tongue kiss and you appreciate how the words attempted to set the mood
column8: but it was all prelude to the physical expression.

column1: The dynamic between the wobbly production and the sturdy songwriting defines Moon Tides
column2: though I wouldn’t say it causes any tension. Conflict is clearly something avoided within the tenets of Pure Bathing Culture. But it does result in a listening experience that causes more ambivalence than it probably should. You wonder if the herbal essence is compromised by the clarity of the melodies and lyrics
column3: or vice versa
column4: whether the disparate artistic impulses detract from each other rather than amplify each other’s qualities. When Moon Tides hits right
column5: it has the consistency of a Jello shot-- simultaneously solid and gooey
column6: warm and transportive
column7: Versprille's acidic tone giving it a tart aftertaste.

column1: By the same token
column2: when the balance is off or your mood is not compatible
column3: the whole affair can remind you it’s a pretty chintzy way to have a good time. If you had to pinpoint an era where Pure Bathing Culture truly feels at home
column4: it’s the 80s and not necessarily the indie rock 80s. Those conditioned to hear the 4AD influences in any breathy
column5: reverbed synth-pop can trace the Kate Bush and Cocteau Twins effect
column6: particularly the latter-- the drum machines on Moon Tides are no more technologically advanced than those on Treasure and though it’s a little too easy to make out the content of lyrics like ""Sea-slicked symboled wants for more/ He draw's the Raven's card
column7: the effect is similar to Elizabeth Fraser in setting an overarching mood of mysticism and a non-erotic sensuality.

column1: But there’s a sneaking suspicion that Pure Bathing Culture are secretly repping for the kind of music made by millionaires to whom MTV was not kind during the Reagan era. The palm-muted guitar figures of closer “Temples of the Moon” make a serious pass at “Boys of Summer”
column2: though it just reminds you of the vast difference between Don Henley’s idea of a “demo-sounding” cut and everyone else’s. Meanwhile
column3: there’s a strange dissonance between the nonsensical or impenetrable narrative of “Scotty” and its 8-bit quiet storm arrangement. Until you realize it’s a three-minute segue into a coda taken straight from ""Into The Night""; fortunately
column4: it's the chorus
column5: not the part that goes ""She's just 16 years old/ 'Leave her alone' they say."" Are they trying to show artistic kinship? Irony? Either way
column6: Benny Mardones' lyrics become the most straightforward and earnest on Moon Tides and it's a little unsettling.

column1: You end up wondering how this presentation appeals to Pure Bathing Culture
column2: whether they’re one of the many indie acts who think a lo-fi
column3: homemade rendering of an expensive-sounding genre “fixes” it or if it’s just a reflection of their current recording budget and studio acumen.  What are their goals? Do they avoid polishing ""Pendulum"" and ""Scotty"" to a diamond-bright glare because they fear backlash or studio bills? Or none of the above? This sort of culture clash does have its charm
column4: but in light of the professionalism
column5: slickness and ambition that allows bands like Chvrches and Haim to have real-deal hits
column6: you realize when it comes to appropriating megabucks 80s pop
column7:
greed is good.
