column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/19565/homepage_large.579d220b.jpg|Mutazione: Italian Electronic & New Wave Underground 1980 - 1988|0.0|Various Artists|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Strut']|2013-08-14 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:54:22.706875|"

Really good comprehensive
column2: scene-focused reissue compilations can have the effect of making you nostalgic for a very specific time and place that you were never a part of-- for instance
column3: Nuggets’ mythopoeic postwar suburban ur-garage
column4: or New York Noise’s rawkus downtown disco-punk-hip-hop soundclash. Strut’s new Mutazione: Italian Electronic & New Wave Underground 1980-1988 offers a unique location in space
column5: time
column6: and aesthetics to daydream about
column7: namely a too-good-to-be-true music scene in 1980s Italy where Suicide and Throbbing Gristle made the same impact that the Ramones and Sex Pistols had elsewhere
column8: and Foucault and Sartre were considered rock stars on the same level as David Bowie and Iggy Pop.

column1: As appealing as Mutazione makes this particular place seem
column2: it was actually fairly grim at the time. The 1968 student uprising that rocked society and politics across Europe reverberated in Italy longer than in other countries
column3: and the nation was “on a war footing
column4: ” according to an essay in the compilation’s liner notes by Italian music journalist Alberto Campo: “on one side there is the extreme right wing and secret security’s degenreated fringes; on the other
column5: the extreme left movements that had chosen the armed struggle.” In 1978 the leader of the country’s Christian Democratic party was kidnapped and assassinated by members of the Marxist-Leninist terrorist group Red Brigade; two years later the bombing of a rail station in Bologna that killed 85 people and wounded over 200 was attributed to the neo-fascist Nuclei Armati Rivoluzionari. In Italy this period was known as the Years of Lead.

column1: According to recent interviews by journalist Andrea Pomini (who records electronic music under the name Repeater) with the members of the groups-- collected in an illuminating essay in the liner notes-- their music was a direct reaction to the hostile political atmosphere it was made in. The words “New Wave” and “electronic” might imply a certain brightly colored escapism
column2: possibly with the Moroder-isms and discomania that defined most synth-based music being made in Europe at the time
column3: but the material collected here is relentlessly dark
column4: paranoid
column5: and for the most part well out of bounds of even the most generously broad definitions of pop at the time.

column1: The compilation begins the blurry
column2: overdriven drum machine that introduces Die Form’s “Are You Before""
column3: which is quickly joined by reggae-esque guitar and bass lines
column4: a squealing free jazz saxophone
column5: and vocalist F. White sinisterly stage-whispering second-person lyrics-- ""You are strange [...] you dislike everything""-- that implicate the listener in some sort of vague aesthetic thoughtcrime in between stridently barking the titular question. Listening to it on headphones feels like being in the center of a brainwashing session from a 70s political paranoia thriller.

column1: Not every track on the collection is as harrowing of a listen. Neon
column2: Carmody
column3: and Pale TV are among the acts who contribute relatively upbeat cuts that you can actually dance to. But even the poppiest songs here are still deeply strange. Some of the musicians who played on the material collected here went on to mainstream pop success
column4: but the most common musical references cited in Pomini’s interviews are such uncompromisingly harsh experimentalists as Suicide
column5: Throbbing Gristle
column6: the Residents
column7: and Wire
column8: and artists like Andy Warhol who are considered equally influential. It says a lot about how darkly intellectual the whole scene was that one of the members of Carmody
column9: whose affably bleeping “Vulcani” is one of the most accessibly pop tracks on the compilation
column10: says that the group as a whole was
column11: “fascinated by the sensation of falling down deep into an abyss
column12: a bottomless pit
column13: an endless fall.”

column1: The material collected on Mutazione was never meant for mass consumption. Not only was that built into the most basic elements of the music itself
column2: which was as antagonistic towards mainstream tastes as the British crust punk of the time
column3: much of it was originally released on cassette
column4: a throwaway medium even during its heyday
column5: and many of the members collaborated via tapes sent through the mail on projects that were never even intended for release. On top of that there was a whole multimedia facet to what many of these bands were up to-- visual art
column6: performance art
column7: video art-- that even the niche audience who digs up Mutazione isn’t going to get.

column1: But even though the stuff on Mutazione never spread far out of its original territory
column2: its creators offer a sometimes haunting prescience for musical ideas that popped up independently in other communities around the world
column3: and which still have resonance today. They devised weird signal chains running through gear that was never meant for that kind of thing. They took personal computers meant for geeky hobbyist programmers and used them to make music. They used cheap
column4: disposable media to transmit subversive ideas encased in something that closely resembled pop.

column1:
This isolated community of radical freaks in the 1980s predicted everything from power electronics to Tumblr’s avant garde fringe. Grappling with new technology by figuring out interesting ways to break it? A pervasive feeling that some kind of terrible new totalitarianism is lurking just offstage? Blood in the air and on our broadcast media? Mutazione might be the most right-now sounding record out there.

"|18370.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/18370-mutazione-italian-electronic-new-wave-underground-1980-1988/|8.2|Miles Raymer

0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/19556/homepage_large.f891f435.jpg|Mark Kozelek and Desertshore|2331.0|Mark Kozelek|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Caldo Verde']|2013-08-13 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:54:23.414598|"

On “Livingstone Bramble”
column2: from his new album with Desertshore
column3: Mark Kozelek sets a lonely
column4: late-night scene: It’s 3 am
column5: his girlfriend is asleep in bed
column6: and he’s got insomnia. “So I called up my Spanish promoter about a tour coming up in October
column7: it was 4 am when I hung and I cuddled up next to my love.” Except for the strict rhymes
column8: it almost sounds like he’s reading directly from his diary: describing a hotel room that looks like every other hotel room
column9: recounting the most mundane aspects of the music business
column10: watching Ray “Boom Boom” Mancini fight Livingstone Bramble on ESPN Classic.

column1: For those uninitiated into the cult of Kozelek
column2: such seemingly reverse-engineered lyrics might sound a bit cynical in their plain-spokenness: a bad-faith effort by a songwriter putting the least amount of effort possible into connecting words to form phrases and connecting phrases to form thoughts. On the other hand
column3: these songs deliver grave truths
column4: which means Mark Kozelek & Desertshore may be an ideal starting point for nonbelievers trying to figure out why so many people care.

column1: Taking the old adage “write what you know” as the alpha and omega of his process
column2: Kozelek pens songs with very little fictionalizing imagination
column3: or at the very least he slyly disguises his fabrications as matters of pure fact. So maybe he really didn’t buy The Satanic Bible at a mall in Ohio and maybe he really hasn’t actually met Anton LaVey
column4: head of the Satanic Church
column5: as he claims on “Hey You Bastards I’m Still Here”. But he sings those verses like pure autobiography
column6: so you believe him
column7: just as you believe him when he says he loves the movie Papillon and really misses Jason Molina.

column1: Whether he’s singing solo or with collaborators like Desertshore or the Album Leaf
column2: Kozelek presents his songs as aggressively autobiographical. Even “Don’t Ask About My Husband”
column3: on which he sings from the point of view of a cheating wife
column4: comes across as a work of empathy-- as though he’s trying to see the world from the point of view of a friend or lover. Because he lives so comfortably in his own words
column5: even the most banal event in a Kozelek song accrues poignancy
column6: if only because he’s doing it alone. These are solitary songs
column7: sharply introverted and occasionally emotionally desolate
column8: but they are never artless.

column1: This collaboration with Desertshore-- a band featuring former Red House Painters guitarist Phil Carney
column2: keyboard player Chris Connolly
column3: and Sun Kil Moon drummer Mike Stevens-- is Kozelek’s fourth full-length release of 2013
column4: his second featuring all new compositions
column5: and his second featuring a prominent collaborator. It’s also arguably his best of the calendar year
column6: thanks to strong songs as well as the band’s sensitive accompaniment. Rather than evoke the romanticism of the road (as Sun Kil Moon did on 2003’s Ghosts of Great Highway) or the emotional detachment of touring life (as Kozelek does on every live album)
column7: Desertshore pry open his brain and soundtrack his thoughts. On “Katowice or Cologne” and “Don’t Ask About My Husband”
column8: Carney and Stevens put some rhythmic thrust behind Kozelek’s conversational cadence
column9: and Carney’s guitar lends “You Are Not of My Blood” an eerie somnambulatory quality
column10: like Slint covering Santo & Johnny.

column1: They also tease out and amplify his sharp sense of humor
column2: which can often get lost in his deadpan delivery. “I can play like Fripp or Johnny Marr
column3: and I can play circles ‘round Jay Farrar
column4: ” he boasts or possibly just daydreams on “Livingstone Bramble”
column5: and when he claims
column6: “I hate Nels Cline
column7: ” Carney inserts some scribbles and skreeks behind him
column8: suggesting a very sly parody of Wilco’s artsy noise. It’s one of the album’s best moments-- and also its funniest.

column1: Just when you think Kozelek might be relating his days without reflecting on them
column2: he lays out a stunner of a lyric to catch you off guard. “Tavoris Cloud”
column3: named after another boxer
column4: laments the sudden passing of his pet cat (who “slipped off to kitty heaven”) and
column5: much more seriously
column6: the death of his friend Tim Mooney of the San Francisco band American Music Club. “I’m grateful for your love
column7: ” he sings
column8: “but at the age of 46 I’m still one fucked-up little kid who cannot figure anything out.” The senselessness of death-- the universe’s utter antipathy toward human closure-- reduces us all to idiot children
column9: but it makes Kozelek revel in the small moments
column10: like watching an old boxing match or waking up next to the woman he loves. The power of this collaboration
column11: which will hopefully be the first of many to come
column12:
is that sometimes he sounds like he can’t believe his good fortune.

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/19514/homepage_large.5e88a140.jpg|To the Happy Few|2729.0|Medicine|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Captured Tracks']|2013-08-13 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:54:23.917524|"

The 1990s revival has seen a lot of odd reunions
column2: but L.A. noise-pop band Medicine’s return after its split 18 years ago still stands out. The group
column3: best known for its inclusion on The Crow soundtrack in 1994
column4: didn’t leave behind a sizeable fan base
column5: and while there’s been recent resurgence of interest in the decade’s shoegaze scene
column6: to which the band was tangentially involved
column7: they’re not exactly a household name.

column1: If it’s a highly unexpected reconciliation
column2: it’s also well timed. The combination of shoegaze’s aggressive guitar turbulence and dream pop’s phantasmagoric hookiness that they perfected on 1993’s The Buried Life sounded out of place at the time
column3: but their new To the Happy Few
column4: made with the same exact formula
column5: now sounds perfectly situated at the leading edge of rock tastes.

column1: The group’s sonic mastermind Brad Laner has spent much of the intervening years in the studio as a producer
column2: engineer
column3: and multi-instrumentalist on recordings by Brian Eno
column4: Caribou
column5: µ-Ziq
column6: and the Faint
column7: among others
column8: and he seems to have not only kept up with new technology and changing tastes
column9: but to develop a whole range of new talents and techniques. (He also spent a little time in the early aughts attempting to relaunch Medicine as a more electronic-oriented project with new collaborators
column10: but that part’s easily skipped over.) To the Happy Few will very likely turn out to be one of the best sounding guitar-based albums of the year.

column1: And it’s the raw sonics where Medicine’s real appeal lies. Vocalist Beth Thompson has a gorgeously ethereal voice
column2: especially when it’s multitracked several layers deep and drenched in reverb and modulation effects
column3: as it often is. But while her uncomplicated melodies perfectly suit the group’s intentions and offer listeners a crucial personal identity to latch onto
column4: they don’t do any more heavy lifting than any other instrument.

column1: In fact
column2: it’s usually pushed back deep in the mix
column3: well behind Laner’s guitar. He’s an enthusiastic pedal junkie and a connoisseur of feedback
column4: and one of the primary draws Medicine albums offer is a chance to see all the inventive ways he’s come up with to abuse a guitar signal. To the Happy Few has guitars that sound like squealing power drills
column5: guitars that sound like sheets of white noise
column6: guitars that sound like stroboscopic synth tones
column7: and guitars that sound like Neil Young’s amp being recorded by a broken microphone that doesn’t pick up half the frequencies it’s supposed to.

column1: Laner’s electronic phase has carried over from Medicine’s last incarnation
column2: and the bulk of the songs here show some sort of dance music influence. Interestingly
column3: it’s usually not in the form of synthesized sounds
column4: as is usually the case in these kinds of cases. Instead it shows up in how he treats the stacks of guitars he piles up on each song
column5: sweeping their frequencies like a rave DJ
column6: saturating them with enough choppy distortion to start evolving into a quasi-synth sound
column7: switching from one sound to another with edits he doesn’t even try to polish into an organic-sounding transition. (Drummer Jim Goodall’s noticeably beat-ier playing underlines the influence.)

column1: Their first time around
column2: Medicine was an oddity: a band in L.A. drawing heavily from two quintessentially British sounds that hadn’t found any significant traction within 5
column3: 000 miles of their home base. If things had gone differently-- like not getting placed on The Crow soundtrack-- they could easily have ended up an obscurity known only to a few noise pop obsessives. (And as it is their emphasis on tone over melody will likely continue to limit their audience to listeners who are fine with records without memorable hooks.) But two decades later
column4: musicians fusing arcane subgenres have become incredibly common
column5: and everything else that Medicine was doing that was so strange-- putting their studio techniques up front
column6: making their guitars sound like anything but guitars-- has also become the norm. Unlike the other reunited groups of their generation
column7: Medicine doesn’t sound nostalgic at all
column8:
and in fact they sound more contemporary than the majority of young guitar bands playing right now. It’s just been a matter of waiting 20 years for the world to come around.

Here’s a decidedly old-fashioned request: Listen to The Word as Power
column3: the first-ever vocal-oriented album from dark ambient pioneer Lustmord
column4: multiple times in short succession
column5: as though it’s the only new album you’ll hear all month
column6: or at least all week. Don’t just listen to it on repeat
column7: either: Hear it in different settings-- on different sound systems
column8: in different rooms
column9: sometimes in public places and
column10: when possible
column11: in private
column12: with as few distractions as possible. If making that sort of commitment to a 75-minute album of largely wordless chants and torpid electronics doesn’t seem likely
column13: maybe skip this one; its length and generally tectonic pace are easy targets for accusations of boredom. But if you want to live in a record and to treat every time it breathes or adjust its posture as a major event
column14: The Word as Power is an architectural wonder-- an album that feels strangely interactive and dynamic
column15: as though its music was never meant to be final.

column1: For more than three decades
column2: Lustmord has been the primary outlet of Brian Williams
column3: an electronic arranger and producer with a broad view of darkness. Williams defined Lustmord’s central and largely stable aesthetic early into the project’s discography-- couch samples captured in oft-lugubrious places within foreboding sonic settings
column4: with mile-wide craters of bass and razor-sharp veins of noise serving as the constants within alternating conceptual constructs. But as he’s refined the approach
column5: particularly with a string of subgrene-galvanizing albums in the 90s
column6: he’s attempted to expand its application
column7: too. Not only has Williams pushed Lustmord’s lurch into video games and movies
column8: he’s also invited other commanders of the bleak and heavy into Lustmord’s own slow folds. In a 2010 interview with Fact
column9: Williams talked about how creating and listening to the music of Lustmord was a very solitary experience. “I can’t imagine anyone listens to my music at a party
column10: ” he said
column11: understating the case. But he’s worked with Nurse With Wound and stylistic progeny Larsen. He’s contributed to albums by both Maynard James Keenan’s Tool and Puscifier. And he’s recorded with Isis’ Aaron Turner (on the great [Other]
column12: which Turner released) and with the Melvins on 2004’s Pigs of the Roman Empire
column13: a curious collaborative full-length. If Lustmord is solitary music
column14: it’s created surprisingly often. That’s helped keep it vital during the last 30 years.

column1: On The Word as Power
column2: Lustmord continues that tradition of using outside sources to build from his clear and consistent artistic base. Here
column3: he pairs long
column4: slow
column5: and steady vocal takes from five singers with his usually sedate machinations of plunging bass and droning textures. The distant
column6: near-monastic intonations of Maynard James Keenan
column7: for instance
column8: echo as though from the mouth of a cave on “Abbadon”
column9: fading in and out of a punishing electronic web like they’re being whipped by a gale. He practically bullies Jarboe’s bewitching tone on “Andras Sodom”
column10: occasionally letting it drift like smoke above a fire only to soon scramble
column11: reverse or otherwise warp it.

column1: But it’s the fair-voiced Aina Skinnes Olsen who serves as Williams’ most malleable material on The Word as Power. She takes the spotlight on four of its seven tracks. Sometimes she sings solo
column2: her clear tone sending notes sailing into a great
column3: yawning void. Elsewhere
column4: Williams fashions her voice into ghastly
column5: crisscrossing duets with his electronics
column6: her purity taunted by his menace. And sometimes
column7: he even multiples her sound as though with mirrors
column8: turning her into a choir of phantasms capable of overrunning his own din. On “Chorazin”
column9: the album’s 17-minute centerpiece
column10: Williams blurs the distinctions between this troika of roles
column11: lifting Olsen’s voice above perilous stillness before letting it slip
column12: if only momentarily
column13: into a rapturous vortex.

column1: Lustmord uses a very broad spectrum of sounds-- foundation-quaking lows beneath the singers’ throat-rattling mids and almost-vaporized highs-- to create a very intricate microcosm of music. Each time you listen
column2: you notice something new. That’s the point
column3: too
column4: as illustrated by the record cover
column5: a Simon Fowler design in which a maze of symbols and words and shapes and watermarks is intended to reveal more about the source material only with careful and repeated study. (“Those looking to properly decode the subject matter of the album are advised to study Simon Fowler’s fiendishly elaborate
column6: double-spread cover illustration
column7: ” teases the album’s accompanying materials.) This material is meant for furrowed brows.

column1: But the real trick of The Word as Power is its plasticity. Because of the range of sound at work
column2: each time you listen in a different setting
column3: the struggle between the warlord bass and the angelic-and-or-demonic voices shifts slightly
column4: revealing new relationships about passages you thought you already understood. It’s like staring at a particularly detailed painting by Bruegel the Elder up-close in the light of day and then
column5: later
column6: from some distance at twilight.

column1: When discussing the isolation of this sort of music in that 2010 Fact interview
column2: Williams also spoke of the arduous process of creating Lustmord’s music: “In the studio
column3: I can spend hours on individual sounds
column4: ” he said. “Things take days if not weeks to develop.” That process affords The Word as Power a certain inescapability: When you start to pay attention to its manifold subtleties
column5: you’ll likely only lean in closer
column6:
noticing even more details within an album that suggests they never end.

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/19572/homepage_large.60ecebbf.jpg|The Affliction|31563.0|Bare Mutants|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['In the Red']|2013-08-13 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:54:24.862248|"

It sort of seems like Jered Gummere made a bet with himself. Can he write and record an entire album made out of nothing but clichés? The most threadbare chord progressions? The most predictable lyrics? The same standard-issue touchstones-- Television
column2: the Modern Lovers
column3: the Velvet Underground-- that his last band
column4: the Ponys
column5: wound up settling on? With The Affliction
column6: the debut by his new outfit
column7: Bare Mutants
column8: the answer to all the above is a yawning “Yeah
column9: I guess.” But where the Pony’s 2007 swansong
column10: Turn the Lights Out
column11: showed some promising progression for Gummere as a songwriter
column12: The Affliction is a head-retracting shrug back into the shell.

column1: You can't accuse the album of lacking consistency. No less than half the songs follow the same infuriatingly precise formula-- strummy
column2: two-chord intro followed by dreamy buildup followed by full-bore freakout-- without deviating from the template VU threw down long ago with “Heroin”. (Let that sink in: a large portion of this album sounds not only exactly like VU
column3: but exactly like “Heroin”.) Occasionally Gummere and crew branch out-- like on the jaunty
column4: bittersweet “Nothing Is Gold”
column5: which is one of two songs that effectively utilize backup singer Jeanine O’Toole
column6: also of the 1900s
column7: as a full duet partner. (That said
column8: “Nothing Is Gold” sounds like VU’s “After Hours”.)

column1: O’Toole makes an even stronger showing on “Cunt”
column2: one of the few glimpses of the rich
column3: thrilling range-- both tone-wise and inspiration-wise-- that Gummere is capable of
column4: if only he’d bother more often. Ragged
column5: glammy
column6: and sauntering on broad stomps of bubblegum boogie
column7: “Cunt” gives Gummere and O’Toole enough fresh air to trade verses in a vivifying rush of power-pop fun. Conversely
column8: the album’s other standout track
column9: “I Suck at Life”
column10: falls way down on the despondent end of the spectrum
column11: although it’s buoyed by a streak of grim wit
column12: Gummere’s gluey croon
column13: and a colossally sloppy guitar solo that’s nearly as good as Dean Wareham’s sloshed pyrotechnics in Galaxie 500.

column1: The Affliction
column2: then
column3: has two speeds: copying the Velvet Underground and copying other bands that copy the Velvet Underground. What helps mitigate the disc’s unconcern with its lack of dynamic is the fact that Gummere the singer has never sounded better. His jittery Tom Verlaine yelp on the Ponys’ stellar first album
column4: 2004’s Laced With Romance
column5: has gradually given way over the past 10 years to a warm
column6: worn-smooth murmur
column7: and that low-level hum of atmosphere serves songs such as “Devotion” well
column8: even if little else in the song does-- including Gummere’s lyrics
column9: which rarely dare to try rising above boilerplate angst and vagueness. On top of lazy phrasing
column10: he recycles many specific words and images throughout
column11: including repeated mentions of the ocean. Then again
column12: that is the name of a VU song.

column1: The lack of ambition on The Affliction is almost ambitious. The Ponys never broke through to the level they could
column2: and maybe even should have
column3: so it isn’t surprising that
column4: after a six-year hiatus
column5: Gummere is simply coasting on what he loves most-- as narrow as that wave of overused influences may be. Despite a few lovely moments
column6: The Affliction sounds more like an album made for him than anyone else. But with a voice so suffused with dimension and soulfulness

column11: distractingly derivative
column12:
and blandly safe. It’s a lot easier to win bets when you hedge them.

These days
column2: the words ""English folk music"" can easily conjure a certain UK quartet hooting and stomping their way across arenas worldwide and scaling the literal sound of their efforts to match. Suffice to say there are countless other approaches
column3: both new and old
column4: and the Horse’s Ha
column5: a long-running if rarely recorded collaboration between Eleventh Dream Day/Freakwater stalwart Janet Bean and journeyman singer/guitarist James Elkington
column6: showcase several on their second album
column7: Waterdrawn.

column1: In contrast to their sprawling first effort
column2: 2009’s Of the Cathmawr Yards
column3: Waterdrawn is a more focused
column4: stripped down collection. The band here is less an ensemble led by Bean and Elkington and more the two core performers-- though strings do still play a role throughout. On first blush it's easy to note the performers’ clear and open love of noted singers like Shirley Collins-- there’s that sense of immediate
column5: focused performances done with little fuss
column6: Bean and Elkington’s voices matched in close harmony without overt finesse. Similarly
column7: their guitar performances seem unadorned and steady
column8: bespeaking their experience by means of calm understatement.

column1: But again
column2: that’s on first blush. Though there’s nothing as immediately striking as breaking into a bossa nova-tinged number like Of the Cathmawr Yards' “Left Hand”
column3: the Horse’s Ha are less about revivalism then they are the employment of their own easy-going aesthetic. For instance
column4: the sudden punctuation of guitar at the start of the title track leads into a brisk arrangement that’s a kissing cousin of Nick Drake’s “Cello Song” but with a queasy string secton that feels like a snippet of a raga alongside a sudden swirl of flutes. And it's anything but simple cheery good times
column5: even while Bean and Elkington’s vocals establish a feeling of calm restraint.

column1: Bean’s opening line on the first song “Conjured Caravan”
column2: “Lately I don’t try to linger
column3: ” sounds equally at home in Appalachia as in Cumbria
column4: while the sudden shift away from the sprightly guitar to a single violin towards the song's end adds subtle drama to an already strong number about starting something up and hitting the road. Bean’s differently cast lead on the following song
column5: “Willing Hands”
column6: helps introduce the careful variety throughout the album
column7: as does the song’s shifts between waltzing paces
column8: steady fingerpicking
column9: and sudden stops and hushes. (That one of the loveliest tracks on the album is called “Stick Figure Waltz” makes perfect sense.)

column1: Bean has general pride of place on much of the performances
column2: usually singing first and in a couple of cases taking sole lead
column3: but Elkington’s role never feels secondary. It’s more the sense of a well-matched performer happily contributing to a whole. Sometimes
column4: as on the easy going counry-tinged “A Stony Valentine”
column5: Elkington’s vocals are the perfect extra element: Hearing him sing a line of the chorus by himself then returning to back Bean at the song's conclusion is one of those punch-in moments as thrilling as the right pedal stomp or bass drop.

column1: Track for track
column2: the basic approach may remain generally the same
column3: but something’s always changing
column4: whether it’s pace
column5: lyrical focus
column6: or simply the core sonic texture (often within the same song). The stateliness that begins and drives “Contenders” starts with banjo
column7: builds up with guitar
column8: adds strings
column9: and reaches a long pause for Bean’s singing
column10: then continues while the strings glide serenely in the mix
column11: a background
column12: genteel tension that’s its own treasure of a moment. When the building moment is repeated later
column13: the extra elements become a soft click of percussion and quick guitar filigrees
column14: neatly avoiding a repetition within the song itself. The Horse’s Ha are clearly anything but slapdash here
column15: and that’s the key for Waterdrawn as a whole
column16:
a wonderful treat from artists at their best.

column1: 0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/19518/homepage_large.e8359767.jpg|Paracosm|28094.0|Washed Out|['Rock'
column2:

The titles of Washed Out’s breakthrough song and the first single from Paracosm share the two most important words in Ernest Greene’s musical language: feel it. It’s a simple request
column3: as well as the dividing line between those who think of Washed Out as an evocative catalyst of warm nostalgia and those who hear Greene as someone fumbling around for a tune like he's trying to find the snooze button. Four years after “Feel It All Around” defined chillwave
column4: and two since Within and Without stood against the backlash
column5: Paracosm presents Greene as a man without a movement
column6: someone whose music can no longer be used to project opinions about a larger trend. Due to the attrition of his peers and imitators
column7: as well as his own artistic refinement
column8: this sound is all his now. While Paracosm isn’t going out of its way to convert anyone
column9: it’s a modest display of staying power<i>
column10: proof that Greene is a niche artist who hasn't yet suffered from redundancy.

column1: Greene’s referred to Paracosm as “daytime psychedelia
column2: ” a response to its predecessor’s nocturnal amorousness. Once again working with producer/engineer Ben H. Allen
column3: the album's instrumentation sloshes around in lush
column4: warm reverb and palpable bass frequencies. As such
column5: each song is sensual and immersive
column6: indulgent and often feeling shorter than their average five minute length would suggest. While Paracosm never rocks
column7: it always knocks
column8: as few producers are better than Allen at ensuring indie artists stress the low end. Under his hand
column9: the tactility of Washed Out’s studio albums have stood out in comparison to any drizzly replicas that have followed.

column1: Elsewhere
column2: Paracosm finds Greene doing subtle and effective troubleshooting. Though Within and Without wasn't a huge change for Washed Out's aesthetic
column3: it was understandable why people who enjoyed his earliest work might’ve been turned off: “Feel It All Around” had an organic
column4: homemade ingenuity
column5: but Within blended nearly every known variant of makeout music-- shoegaze
column6: Balearic
column7: trip-hop
column8: chillwave
column9: R&B-- into a silken
column10: sweet whole.

column1: Paracosm possesses more texture
column2: which can be partially attributed to the presence of a live rhythm section. “Entrance” begins with chirping birds
column3: and elsewhere there's snippets of laughter
column4: harps
column5: house parties
column6: bongos
column7: and slight swings of human imperfection in the rhythm section. “It All Feels Right” bumps with light reggae upticks before momentarily collapsing into a sunstroke
column8: while “Great Escape” leans off the beat just enough to generate a little bit of Southern soul.

column1: The range of Paracosm helps Greene present himself as more of a singer/songwriter than a producer
column2: though the former part of that dynamic still lags. His voice is an effective and imperfect apparatus that suggests rather than commands; his enunciation is still slack
column3: as hard consonants and most vowel sounds dissolve into a semipermeable gauze. Maybe it’s for the best
column4: though
column5: since the lyrics of “It All Feels Right” are indicative of how much of Paracosm boils down to “Have a nice day” and not much more. However
column6: Greene is growing in terms of melodic construct
column7: as the chorus of “Don’t Give Up” is the strongest and trickiest he’s ever written. The way he manages the song's nimble rhythm suggests Washed Out’s future depends more on the development of Greene’s internal instruments rather than the external ones.

column1: That said
column2: Paracosm’s diversity leaves its individual songs subject to more scrutiny than they were on its overly cohesive predecessor. “Weightless” is equal parts Cocteau Twins and Calgon
column3: but its soapy texture wants for Elizabeth Fraser’s fierce elocution and command of syllabic nonsense. And whether or not “Great Escape” is an intentional homage to “Mercy Mercy Me (The Ecology)”
column4: it’s probably in Greene’s best interest not to remind listeners of the difference between his vocals and those of Marvin Gaye.

column1: When Greene misses the mark
column2: it’s a demonstration of his musical limitations as well as a counter to the misconception that Washed Out is unambitious or complacent. It’s not unthinkable for Greene to take notes from M83’s Anthony Gonzalez
column3: another innovator in electro-pop ambience who learned to transcend the mumbly vocals of his early work by gradually embracing the role of a true frontman while working with powerhouse guest vocalists as well. But Paracosm is a document of someone who sounds satisfied with his place in life
column4: and that can understandably drive people nuts. There’s plenty of art responsible for describing and inducing vertiginous highs and lows
column5: and Paracosm is more than happy to soundtrack the satisfying moments that seek you out instead of the other way around
column6: effectively triggering the kind of subtle joys that course through you without warning – manageable contentment
column7: sustainable romance.

column1: Those moods are easy to dismiss when they're captured in a lyric like ""Call your friends
column2: I'll call mine/ We'll head out for a long ride/ Sun is coming out now
column3: it all feels right."" There's a cognitive dissonance
column4: and maybe some embarrassment
column5: in recognizing that emotional state and hearing it expressed back to you in such naïve
column6: plainspoken language.  You can call it a guilty pleasure in action-- or
column7: you can just take this accessible escapism at face value and just
column8: you know
column9:
feel it.

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/19251/homepage_large.8a7cf8ce.jpg|Filthy EP|539.0|The Bug|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Ninja Tune']|2013-08-12 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:54:26.537947|"

This isn't the same musical landscape that Kevin Martin left a crater in when he released London Zoo as the Bug five years ago. Even leaving aside every radical mutation and crossover blowup that's splintered off from the dancehall
column2: grime
column3: and dubstep scenes that ran through the album's veins
column4: Martin himself has proven to be just as hard to pin down. The eerie
column5: stripped-down ghost-dub King Midas Sound evolved from side project to remixers' platform to ongoing concern (don't sleep on the “Aroo” single). Kiki Hitomi
column6: the wraithlike vocalist who's served as a regular collaborator with Martin across multiple projects since 2009
column7: teamed up with him to explore heavier digital dub styles as Black Chow. And the last time anything was released under the Bug name proper
column8: it was a series of 7” records on Martin's aptly-named Acid Ragga subsidiary label late last year that were abrasively confrontational in the best way
column9: stuff that sounds like a future path few have successfully caught on to yet. Familiar comfort is not what you should expect out of him.

column1: And yet familiarity is what you get on the Filthy EP-- familiar names
column2: familiar rhythms
column3: familiar beats. Not enough to breed contempt
column4: but just enough to make it clear that it's not one of his more revolutionary releases. The last time five years passed between Bug albums
column5: the difference between Pressure's glitchy dancehall and the blistering ragga/dubstep of London Zoo pointed to an engaged expansion of an already versatile toolbox. Filthy is more like using whatever nearby blunt object as a hammer. The two twice-versioned beats that comprise the EP are strong and borderline anthemic but nothing all that revelatory: the drum patterns are solid but simple
column6: the basslines throb but don't really explode
column7: and the melodic elements (such as they are) more or less churn in place
column8: with insistent horn blats (“Freakshow”/”Dirty”) and warped calliope synth (“Kill Them”/”Louder”) doing more to reinforce the beat than play off it. It's heavy stuff
column9: but Martin's wheelhouse is bigger than this.

column1: Most of the vocal collaborators are previously known quantities
column2: too-- good ones
column3: but only one of them an actual change of pace. Roll Deep cornerstone Flowdan
column4: one of the strongest presences on London Zoo and several Bug singles released beforehand
column5: shows up twice and gives his booming
column6: gravelly drone of a voice a thorough run. And while he sounds fired up sneering at horsemeat fast food on “Dirty” or challenging sound systems on “Louder”
column7: neither of them sounds like a major advancement from the 2007-08 run of collaborations that included the likes of “Warning”
column8: “Ganja”
column9: and “Jah War”. Daddy Freddy's leafblower-growl turn on “Kill Them” covers the dancehall front
column10: but the juxtaposition of a previous Pressure collaborator running amok on the dubstep-styled turf that London Zoo laid down is more a quick jolt of recognition than a sustained rush of the new. That leaves us with the leadoff track
column11: “Freakshow”
column12: in which Hitomi wails in that odd hushed midpoint between vulnerable and threatening before Danny Brown's libido goes nova during a characteristically unhinged sing-song rampage. (All I'll say about the lyrics is that you'll probably want to start ordering your Caesar salad with vinaigrette from here on out.) It's the one moment that actually feels exciting and daring instead of just reassuring
column13: and on the heels of Darq E Freaker teamup “Blueberry (Pills & Cocaine)” and the Purist's “Jealousy”
column14: it does just as much to reinforce Brown's unique chemistry with UK producers as it does to play up Martin's collaborative insight.

column1: Not that a two-riddim EP this short is much of a harbinger of anything. As a teaser for the upcoming Angels & Devils
column2: it does less to stir up oh-shit anticipation for a devastating blindside of a record than the prospect of Gonjasufi and Death Grips collaborations do. If you're looking for evidence of any major stylistic shift in Martin's approach on Filthy
column3:
it's better to settle for a solid reiteration of a lot of the stuff he was doing on his last album. Who knows-- this might be the last chance you get with it.

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/19567/homepage_large.85e16913.jpg|Home|31420.0|Rudimental|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Asylum']|2013-08-12 00:00:00|2013|2016-06-11 16:54:27.137260|"

We're in the middle of a golden year for British pop music
column2: one that has found young artists digesting the future-forward sounds of their formative years and distilling them into ruthless
column3: radio-ready pop forms. Some of these debut efforts
column4: like Disclosure's masterful Settle and AlunaGeorge's R&B-leaning Body Music
column5: have already hit North American shores; others
column6: like singles from smoky
column7: soulful crooner John Newman and garage producer Naughty Boy
column8: have yet to make a transatlantic connection. The latest salvo from across the pond comes courtesy of London quartet Rudimental
column9: whose debut record Home earned a #1 British debut in April on the heels of two chart-topping hits
column10: ""Feel the Love"" and ""Waiting All Night"".

column1: Rudimental's members-- Piers Aggett
column2: Kesi Dryden
column3: Amir Amor
column4: and DJ Locksmith-- pride themselves on lending an earned musicality and eclecticism to dance music. The group's name draws from Dryden's childhood piano lessons: he was routinely disciplined for forgetting his rudiments
column5: a book containing elementary principles of rhythm and musical theory. Their experiential approach to songwriting is evident throughout Home's dozen tracks
column6: many of which are stuffed to the brim with disparate parts and unfold in unexpected ways.

column1: More than a few songs on Home feature frenetic drum 'n bass loops
column2: and the success of those songs varies. ""Feel the Love"" launches warped synth lines and horn riffs alongside a gritty guest performance from Newman before abruptly switching gears in its final third; ""Waiting All Night"" rides a star-making spot from young vocalist Ella Eyre to similar heights. But the tracks that follow a similar template feature soaring but ultimately bland vocals overwhelmed by their rhythmic counterparts.

column1: Home's finest moments occur when Rudimental stray from the sound that led them to chart success. The album's two best songs were co-written and sung by British up-and-comer MNEK
column2: who possesses a rich
column3: nuanced voice at the age of 18. ""Spoons"" glides on a gently pulsing synth and a clicking percussive line tapped out on the titular instrument; the skittering
column4: mid-tempo ""Baby"" features interplay between MNEK and a sparkling
column5: sassy Sinead Harnett. The relatively straightforward house of these songs stand with the best of this year's strong batch of British pop singles.

column1: Home's American release is poorly timed. In recent months
column2: their contemporaries have released well-crafted
column3: self-assured debuts. Rudimental are casting a wider musical net than their peers
column4: which has the unintended effect of magnifying their flaws by comparison
column5:
making for a decent but ultimately second-tier effort in a crowded year for big-ticket dance-pop.
